title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, ARTHUR M., JR.
description: ROSS--Arthur M., Jr. On May 20, 2004 at the age of 91, Arthur M. Ross, Jr., died peacefully at his home at 38 Glen Parkway, Hamden CT 06517 with his family by his side. Born at 599 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, on July 27th, 1912, Arthur Ross graduated from Yale University (B.S. 1934, Ph.D. in Chemistry 1939), worked in the research lab of General Electric in Schnectady, NY, and on the Manhattan Project at Columbia University. He was founder and president both of Ross & Roberts Plastic Co. of Stratford and Ridge Top Swimming and Tennis Club of North Haven. In 1965 he became Assistant to the Provost for the Sciences, and Secretary of the Science Advisory Committee at Yale. He was a Fellow of Branford College and also Secretary of the New Haven Chapter of Sigma and Xi. He served on the Board of Trustees of Congregation Mishkan Israel and was a Commissioner with the North Haven Conservation Commission. After retirement, he enjoyed many years as a reader at Recording for the Blind & Dyslexic in New Haven. Arthur Ross was a kind, gentle person who loved the out-of-doors and spent more than 35 summers in Forest City, ME. He was predeceased by his sisters, Lucile Pollak and Edna May Thalheimer. He was the beloved husband of Kathryn (Kay) Gips Ross for 58 years, father of Judith Ross of Milwaukee, WI, William and Carolyn Ross of Ridgefield, CT, Sarah Ross Mali and Derek Mali of NYC, Martha Ross and Robin Green of Kansas City, MO, Michael Ross and Beth Stenger of Hamden, and Jonathan Klee Ross of New Haven and grandfather of Nina, Zachary, Joshua and Eliana. Contributions may be made to Recording for the Blind & Dyslexic, 209 Orange St, New Haven, CT 06510.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COWIN, DAVID M.
description: COWIN--David M. Age 79, formerly a longtime resident of Manhasset, NY, passed away on May 29th at his home in Covington, LA. Born on June 19th, 1924, Mr. Cowin grew up in New York City and Bayside, Queens. He was a decorated W.W. II veteran having served with the Army in the European Theater where he received two Purple Hearts and The Bronze Star. Following the Korean War, Mr. Cowin served as the Director of Foreign Trade in Korea at the behest of the U.S. government. Prior to his retirement in 2002, he was the president and owner of Cowin Associates, an executive recruitment firm specializing in aeronautics and electronics that he founded in 1960. As a resident of Manhasset, NY, Mr. Cowin was involved in several civic organizations and served as President of the Manhasset Board of Education, The Manhasset Community Fund, The Manhasset Booster Club, and the Flower Hill Association. Mr. Cowin is survived by his wife of 48 years, Peggy Hale Cowin, three children, Nan Cowin of White Bear Lake, MN, Dr. David H. Cowin of Ridgefield, CT and Robert N. Cowin of Covington, LA and four grandchildren, Jessica H. Cowin, David H. Cowin, William P. Cowin, and John M. Cowin. A memorial service will be held at The Congregational Church of Manhasset on June 4th at 2:00PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Mr. Cowin to the Make-A-Wish Foundation of Louisiana, 320 Hammond Highway, Suite 402, Metairie, LA 70005 or Spirit of America, 215 So. State, Suite 1170, Salt Lake City, UT 84111.

title: Cleansing the Olympic Team
description: Sports authorities are moving aggressively, as they should, to block any athletes who have been using illegal performance-enhancing drugs from the American Olympic team. The doping of athletes so that they can train harder, recover from injuries faster and perform better has become such an international scandal that fans no longer know which records are legitimate and which are the fruit of chemistry. But as the United States Anti-Doping Agency casts its investigative net wider and relies on less conclusive forms of evidence than in the past, its own performance will be on trial. There is some danger that its zealous crackdown could ensnare some innocent athletes and bar them from a once-in-a-lifetime chance at Olympic gold and the endorsement opportunities that can bring.

Top-level contacts between the countries have increased in the months since Mr. Sharon announced his intention to evacuate Israeli soldiers and settlers from Gaza, a plan his government has yet to approve. Egypt has indicated it is willing to work with the Palestinian leadership to stabilize Gaza in advance of an Israeli withdrawal. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Widow's Broadcast Barred
description: An interview with the widow of a Chechen separatist, Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, was prohibited from being aired on the independent NTV channel at the last moment on orders of the police, the local press reported. The interview with the widow, Malika, was filmed in Qatar, where Mr. Yandarbiyev was taking refuge and where two Russians are on trial for his killing. Leonid Parfyonov, the anchor of the current affairs program that had prepared the segment, told the daily Kommersant, ''I do not know what level the instruction came from, but I can say that it was the kind of request you can't refuse.'' Russian news media have come under increasing pressure from the government. Last autumn, an interview on the same channel with a Kremlin news reporter was also canceled at the last moment. title: MEMO PAD
description: INTERNATIONAL AIR TRAVEL UP -- How crowded will airports be this summer? The advance numbers are coming in. Airports are expected to handle 3.5 percent more domestic flights this summer compared with last summer, according to Executive Travel SkyGuide, a unit of American Express. Meanwhile, the International Air Transport Association said worldwide passenger traffic this summer would likely return to pre-2001 levels. The trade group added that for the first four months of 2004, worldwide passenger traffic was up 15.4 percent over the same period in 2003. Compared with the same period in 2000, worldwide passenger traffic (measured by passenger revenue miles, or one paying passenger flown one mile) was up 8.5 percent, the trade group said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Moderate Growth
description: Canada's economy expanded at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, adjusted for inflation, in the first quarter, Statistics Canada reported. The figure exceeded analysts' expectations, but slowed from the 3.3 percent pace of the final three months of 2003. Final sales accelerated to 4.5 percent from 2.2 percent, but exports and buoyant spending by consumers were offset by a deceleration in the building of inventories. The Bank of Canada is expected to respond to growing evidence of a rebound in demand by raising interest rates this fall, reversing a year of declines. Bernard Simon (NYT)

And in the six months since Arnold Schwarzenegger took office, the comparisons with Ronald Reagan have been staples of his news coverage. But in truth, the similarities between the men ended shortly after Mr. Schwarzenegger was sworn in. In many ways, he has made himself into the non-Reagan -- with remarkable results.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Energy Secretary Quits
description: Energy Secretary Felipe Calderon Hinojosa resigned after an open dispute with President Vicente Fox over the minister's presidential aspirations. Over the weekend, Mr. Caldron, who plans to run for president in 2006, staged an event in Guadalajara with all the trappings of a campaign rally, while Mr. Fox was holding a summit meeting there of Latin American, European and Caribbean leaders. Mr. Fox later criticized Mr. Caldron's event, calling it inappropriate. In response Mr. Caldron resigned, calling the president's comment ''unjust and exaggerated.'' Mr. Fox appointed Mr. Caldron to the post just nine months ago. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

Instantly, the anti-immigration forces in Mr. Bush's own party began venting their outrage about anything that might impose a measure of rationality on the system, especially if it eased the plight of the nation's millions of illegal immigrants. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Sibneft Split Upheld
description: The Moscow Arbitration Court upheld a lower court ruling that nullified a stock issue used by Russia's largest oil company, Yukos, to acquire a rival, Sibneft, according to the news agency Interfax. Under the ruling, formal control of Sibneft would revert to Millhouse Capital, the company that manages the assets of the Russian billionaire Roman A. Abramovich. It was not clear if Yukos would appeal. Yukos has owned 92 percent of Sibneft on paper since October, when the deal was completed, though Yukos has not been able to establish operating control. Sibneft scrapped the merger after Yukos's founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was jailed last October. As a result of the ruling, Millouse Capital will see its stake in Yukos fall to 9 percent from 26 percent.

title: Regulators Reject Migraine Drug From Pozen
description: Pozen Inc., a developer of treatments for migraine headaches, said yesterday that federal regulators had rejected the company's experimental MT 100 drug because of concerns about its safety and effectiveness. Pozen's shares fell 37 percent. The treatment's combination of naproxen sodium and metoclopramide for migraines is not superior to naproxen and may pose a health risk, the Food and Drug Administration said in a letter. MT 100, which would have been Pozen's first product, had the potential to generate annual sales of as much as $400 million, the company said in January, after the drug was shown to be safe in rats.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Computer Sciences Wins Contract From Sears
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the nation's third-largest computer-services company, won a 10-year contract valued at $1.6 billion to run part of Sears, Roebuck's computer systems. Computer Sciences, based in El Segundo, Calif., will install and manage desktop computers, file-storage servers and systems to support Sears's Web sites and data networks, the companies said in separate statements. Sears will save about $40 million a year with the new contract; it had been spending about $200 million a year on the services, a Sears spokesman, Chris Brathwaite, said. As many as 200 of Sears's 1,100 information-technology workers will be hired by Computer Sciences beginning next week. Shares of Sears, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., fell 13 cents, to $37.87. Computer Sciences fell 41 cents to $43.18.

title: Interstate Wine Sales

The court should rule for the retailers and the consumers challenging these laws.

description: NEWMAN -- Frank. The Teachers College community grieves the loss of our colleague, Frank Newman. Frank was a dreamer; a person of integrity, vision, warmth and humor; who spent his career battling for excellence, equity and a better tomorrow for education. He was a giant and there is no one to fill his shoes. The TC community sends condolences to his wife, Lucille, and the family he so deeply loved. title: Mets Pay MSG in Bid To Explore TV Future
description: The Mets paid $54 million last week to escape their cable-television contract with Cablevision's MSG Networks, beginning the process of negotiating a better deal to stay with MSG, create their own TV channel or make a deal to join the Yankees' YES Network as a partner.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Park Attack
description: A Bronx man was arrested yesterday in a sexual assault of a woman in Central Park last month, the police said. The man, identified by the police as Tito Rodriguez, 32, was already in custody when he was charged with attempted rape, attempted sodomy and sexual abuse in the May 12 attack against a woman who was jogging with her dog, the police said. The police were notified of a DNA match with Mr. Rodriguez, who has had several previous arrests -- most recently on May 16, in connection with an attempted rape, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Lubrizol Chief Executive Is Battling Cancer
description: The Lubrizol Corporation, a maker of additives for lubricants and fuels, said yesterday that its chief executive, James L. Hambrick, 49, would begin treatment for testicular cancer. Mr. Hambrick plans to maintain daily responsibility for the company during his treatment, with assistance from the chairman, William Bares, Lubrizol said. Mr. Hambrick will undergo seven weeks of chemotherapy expected to eradicate the early-stage cancer, a spokesman said. The treatment will have no impact on the proposed acquisition of the closely held Noveon International Inc., the company said.

description: With the Indiana Pacers' season on the line Tuesday night, Ron Artest all but begged to guard Richard Hamilton, the Detroit Pistons' sharpshooter.

description: This march to the championship, which has gone from being inevitable to improbable to inevitable all over again, was supposed to be about the superstars, about Shaq's dunks, Kobe's air shows, Karl's brawn, Gary's orchestration.

description: Al Leiter is missing a muscle in his left shoulder, has a frayed left labrum and talks about a condition in his throwing arm that makes doctors wonder how he can still get a baseball to home plate without rolling it.

description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller announced yesterday that he had appointed Charles E. Meara as his chief of staff. Mr. Meara, 54, who has been the longtime assistant director of government and community affairs for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will begin at the Council on June 14. He succeeds Forrest R. Taylor, who resigned in February. Mr. Miller also recently hired Barry D. Ford to the newly created position of chief of policy. Winnie Hu (NYT)

description: THREE mornings a week, Peter Hoffman pedals down the side streets of Lower Manhattan with his children Theo, 11, and Olivia, 7, perched inside the pallet-size basket of his unusual bicycle, a tricked-out reverse rickshaw. After he drops them off at school, Mr. Hoffman, the chef and owner of Savoy in SoHo, rides over to the Greenmarket at Union Square to fill his basket with the makings of a restaurant menu.

title: Health Chief In Nassau Announces Resignation
description: The chief of Nassau County's troubled health care agency announced his resignation yesterday, ending a stormy tenure in which he cut hundreds of jobs to avert bankruptcy as county officials demanded an even more radical makeover.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Early Release For 680 Inmates
description: The State Correction Board approved the early release of 680 inmates to ease prison overcrowding and sought approval to build a second prison for women. The 19 prisons in the state held 11,700 inmates on Monday, almost 1,000 more than a court-imposed maximum, and 763 other felons were housed in city and county jails awaiting transfer to the state. The women's prison held 100 inmates more than its lawful capacity of 660. A second unit would cost $3 million, officials said. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: U.S.-Mexico Traffic Dispute Settled
description: Mexico and the United States have ended a long-running dispute over rules governing the $2 billion in telecommunications traffic across their border. The countries have agreed to accept the decisions of an April ruling by the World Trade Organization. Mexico will end the monopoly that Telfonos de Mxico, the country's dominant telecommunications company, has in negotiating the settlement fees that American carriers pay Mexican companies to complete calls from the United States to Mexico. The United States has argued that competition would lower the cost of calls to Mexico. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Talks This Month On Kashmir
description: India and Pakistan will hold high-level talks on nuclear issues and Kashmir this month, said India's new foreign minister, Natwar Singh. On June 19 and 20, nuclear experts from the two countries will meet, followed by talks between foreign ministers on June 27 and 28. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Wake Up and Save a Gorilla
description: Rwanda's biggest export is coffee, mostly from thousands of small family farms. The Thanksgiving Coffee Company in Fort Bragg, Calif., has started a program to help both the farmers and the endangered mountain gorillas for which Rwanda is famous: it buys coffee from a small Fair Trade cooperative near a gorilla habitat, roasts and blends the beans, sells them whole or ground in 12-ounce packages with a picture of a gorilla on the label and donates $2 of the $9.50 price to the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund International. The blend, called Gorilla Fund Coffee, is full-bodied and rich, with just enough lively acidity. It is available in three grinds at www.thanksgivingcoffee.com or (800) 648-6491. Shipping is extra on orders up to $200; above that, it is free.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Limits On Public Rallies
description: Parliament has given preliminary approval to a law that limits public rallies but is considerably less stringent than a draft that was approved earlier. The bill has now passed two readings in the legislature and will become law if it passes a third reading. It restricts public rallies at presidential residences, courthouses and jails as well as some other sensitive areas. However, at the instructions of President Vladimir V. Putin, it no longer bars rallies at many other places like government offices, schools, hospitals, concert halls and embassies. The measure was opposed by Communists and other opposition parties, who said it restricted democratic freedoms. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: Federal regulators released a report yesterday that raised new questions about the stability of 15-passenger vans and how they are used. The report comes two days after three members of a Bronx church group were killed and nine were injured in the rollover of a large van at the Canadian border.

description: Gov. John G. Rowland's lawsuit fighting a subpoena from the House committee investigating whether he should be impeached has prompted some committee members to discuss avoiding a distracting court battle by withdrawing the subpoena.

title: Children On the Side, Baby Sitters On the Menu
description: THE woman flattened against a back wall of the restaurant Sambuca was doing her best to disappear. She wasn't dodging the check. She was just trying to sneak a peek at Emma, her 2-year-old daughter, without Emma seeing her. Yep, there she was, playing happily. Barbara Vlak let herself exhale.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Importing Tycoon For Cabinet
description: Georgia appointed one of Russia's wealthy industry tycoons, Kakha A. Bendukidze, as its economics minister, and he immediately pledged changes to invigorate the impoverished former Soviet republic, including widespread privatization. Mr. Bendukidze, 48, an ethnic Georgian who has lived in Russia since 1977, is the second major cabinet member brought in from abroad by President Mikhail Saakashvili. He also appointed a French diplomat, Salom Zurabishvili, as foreign minister. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wyandanch: Report Clears Police In Prisoner Death
description: A 33-year-old man who died Saturday evening after being subdued by Suffolk County police officers did not die as a result of police actions, a preliminary post-mortem examination showed, officials said yesterday. The police took the man, Jamal Blount, into custody at the Wyandanch station of the Long Island Rail Road after he confronted passengers and appeared to be fighting with imaginary people, Detective Sgt. Vincent Posillico said. Mr. Blount ran onto a train when he saw the police approaching, and the officers handcuffed Mr. Blount ''to protect themselves and him,'' Sergeant Posillico said. Mr. Blount told officers he had taken crack cocaine, the police said. As he was being taken to a hospital for psychiatric care, Mr. Blount had a seizure, stopped breathing and died. The police said they were still waiting for complete autopsy results. Patrick Healy (NYT)

But some Republicans and even a Democrat or two say the victory could have unintended consequences for a fellow Democrat  Senator Tom Daschle.

title: ViroLogic to Buy Aclara BioSciences
description: ViroLogic Inc., which conducts medical evaluations of AIDS and hepatitis patients, said yesterday that it would buy Aclara BioSciences Inc. for about $180 million in stock, a move that would expand ViroLogic's business into cancer treatments. Aclara's stockholders will receive 1.7 shares of ViroLogic for each Aclara share they own, ViroLogic said. That values the deal at $4.78 a share, 24 percent higher than Aclara's closing price on Friday. ViroLogic, based in San Francisco, evaluates patients' molecular compositions to determine the best therapies for treating hepatitis and H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Aclara, based in Mountain View, Calif., develops technology used in laboratory testing, particularly for cancer.

title: Teenager's Murder Conviction Is Reinstated After Challenge Based on Miranda
description: The Supreme Court reinstated a 17-year-old's murder conviction on Tuesday, ruling 5 to 4 that the California courts were not wrong to disregard his youth in deciding that the police were not obliged to read him his Miranda warnings before questioning him.

description: ''This study should put to rest doubts about whether these drugs work in teenagers with severe depression.''

title: Revised Plan Would Give More Control To the Iraqis
description: The United States and Britain introduced a revised resolution on Iraq Tuesday night that would give the newly selected interim government control over the Iraqi military and police and end the mandate of the multinational force by January 2006.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Bar Association Names Chief
description: The New York State Bar Association has named Kenneth G. Standard, 67, of Chappaqua, as its president. He is the second black leader in its 127-year history. Mr. Standard, a Harvard Law School graduate, previously served as the association's treasurer. He took office yesterday. A former general counsel for Consolidated Edison, Mr. Standard has worked for Morgan, Lewis & Bockius in Manhattan since 2000. In 1993, the association named its first black president, Archibald R. Murray, the former executive director of the Legal Aid Society. Mr. Murray died in 2001. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: U.S. Judge in San Francisco Strikes Down Federal Law Banning Form of Abortion
description: A federal judge in San Francisco yesterday struck down a federal law that banned a form of abortion, saying it created a risk of criminal liability for virtually all abortions performed after the first trimester. The law, the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act, enacted in November, makes it a crime for doctors to perform any ''overt act'' to ''kill the partially delivered living fetus.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Rating Upgraded
description: Vivendi Universal, which cut its debt by $34 billion in almost two years, returned to an investment-grade credit rating at Standard & Poor's after it sold its movie and cable-television assets. The company's long-term debt rating was raised by two steps to BBB-, the lowest investment-grade level. Its old rating was below investment grade, or junk, for 22 months. The outlook on the rating is stable. The company in two years has sold more than $25 billion of assets to help reduce debt and losses.

title: 30 Inmates and Guard Die in Jail Revolt in Brazil
description: At least 30 inmates and one guard were killed in a three-day uprising at a jail in Rio de Janeiro, in the worst prison violence in Brazil in more than a decade, authorities said Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Petition Ruling Near
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, an official monitor of an opposition drive to remove President Hugo Chvez through a referendum, said that by Saturday at the latest electoral authorities will have ruled on the validity of hundreds of thousands of signatures needed to force a recall, despite delays on Monday. Government supporters continue to contend that signatures were fraudulently collected in a three-day signature "repair period" ending Sunday. The opposition says that 750,000 disputed signatures were reconfirmed and that they now have 100,000 more signatures than required. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: As Cars Become More Intricate, Automotive Tech Class Is Junked

Its eight stories contain more than 4,200 students, well beyond official capacity, and the academic record could be charitably described as middling. Kennedy, then, is exactly the sort of massive school viewed with disfavor by Mayor Bloomberg and his Department of Education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROOKS, HARVEY
description: BROOKS--Harvey. It is with deep sorrow that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the loss of Harvey Brooks, distinguished physicist, science policy advisor, and President of the Academy from 1971 to 1976. Throughout his fifty-three years as a Fellow of the Academy, he worked to advance its historic mission to bring together accomplished individuals from all fields and professions in service to society. He broadened the scope of the Academy's work in every direction, from its studies on international security, the environment, and social issues, to its role as the catalyst in the creation of the National Humanities Center in North Carolina. With his remarkable range of interests and concerns, he epitomized the value of the interdisciplinary enterprise, championing the importance of science in the public interest and the significance of the humanities as a critical presence in civic life. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Helen; his family, and all those touched by his brilliance, his grace, and his generosity of spirit. Patricia Meyer Spacks, President Leslie C. Berlowitz, Executive Officer Louis W. Cabot, Vice President Emilio Bizzi, Secretary John S. Reed, Treasurer

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mandela Parks The Plane
description: Nelson Mandela, the Nobel Prize winner and South Africa's first post-apartheid president, said he would severely reduce his public activities, saying he wanted to spend his remaining years resting, thinking and completing his memoirs. Mr. Mandela, who turns 86 on July 18, has maintained a hectic international schedule, recently flying to Switzerland to promote South Africa's winning World Cup bid, despite increasing frailty and difficulty walking. ''I'm confident that nobody present here today will accuse me of selfishness if I asked to spend time, while I'm still in good heath, with my family, my friends and also with myself,'' he said, adding, ''Don't call me; I'll call you.'' Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Record Trade Surplus
description: Brazil posted a record trade surplus of $3.1 billion in May, easily beating forecasts of about $2.6 billion. It was the first time that the country has registered a monthly surplus exceeding $3 billion, the government said. The numbers widened the trade surplus so far this year to $11.2 billion, up from $8.04 billion a year earlier. Exports boomed in May on the back of a weak local currency, reaching $7.94 billion, the highest monthly total on record, while imports were $4.8 billion. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Gunman Shoots Model, 22, in the Subway
description: In a violent outburst yesterday in a moving subway car, an actress and model was shot in the shoulder as her train approached the Times Square station, the police said. Then, as her assailant fled into the station's teeming midday crowds, the young woman staggered to a token booth for help, blood gushing from her wound.

title: Puckering Up for Rhubarb's Tart Kiss
description: CONTROVERSY clings to rhubarb. For nonadmirers its very name elicits snickers about medicinal-tasting concoctions or baseball brawls, but to devotees its rosy color and bracingly tart flavor are emblematic of spring, of idylls in grandma's garden.

title: Brooklyn Assemblyman Quits After Admitting False Billing
description: Assemblyman Roger L. Green, a Brooklyn Democrat who pleaded guilty in February to billing the state for false travel expenses, resigned on Tuesday, but said he is ''prepared to seek re-election'' in November.

title: Initial Offering Of Postbank Hits Snags
description: Postbank was supposed to be the year's biggest stock offering in Germany, a blockbuster public sale of shares that could single-handedly awaken Germany's snoozing capital markets.

title: Iraq's Interim Government
description: For weeks, Washington encouraged the world to believe that the United Nations was putting together Iraq's new interim government. Instead, the most critical appointments were made by the outgoing Iraqi Governing Council, an American-appointed body heavy with exile politicians that has limited public support and a dismal record of nonperformance. That messy process will now become the interim government's first burden as it tries to set up elections for a legislature and constitutional assembly early next year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: U.S. Terror Expert Expelled
description: An American expert on terrorism in Indonesia, Sidney Jones, who has published authoritative reports on the militant group Jemaah Islamiyah, was served with deportation papers. She said she had been given no explanation. The head of Indonesia's intelligence agency, General Hendropriyono, has complained in the past week that her reports on the group, which has been linked to Al Qaeda and is accused of the deadly bombings in Bali in 2002, were inaccurate and harmful to Indonesia's interests. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: ANTIDEPRESSANTS SEEN AS EFFECTIVE FOR ADOLESCENTS
description: In the midst of a worldwide debate on whether depressed children should be treated with antidepressant drugs like Prozac, a landmark government-financed study has found that Prozac helps teenagers overcome depression far better than talk therapy. But a combination of the two treatments, the study found, produced the best result.

title: Valenzuela Is Replaced In Belmont
description: Patrick Valenzuela, the talented but sometimes troubled jockey, was denied a stay of a California racing suspension yesterday and will not ride Rock Hard Ten in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Developer Unearths Burial Ground and Stirs Up Anger Among Indians
description: With the precision of a watchmaker, an archaeologist clasped a small paintbrush and gently swept the brown, sandy dirt off the spine of a Native American woman buried some 200 years ago.

description: The former head of the United Nations' oil-for-food program in Iraq says the Security Council prevented him from effectively administering the multibillion-dollar-a-year program that is now the focus of several inquiries into allegations of corruption and mismanagement.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Religious Leaders Ask Powell To Restart Talks
description: A delegation of top religious leaders met Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and requested the appointment of a special presidential envoy to go to Jerusalem to restart peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians. The Christians in the delegation included two Roman Catholic cardinals, several evangelicals and leaders of the Greek Orthodox, Lutheran, Presbyterian, Episcopal, United Methodist and United Church of Christ and Disciples of Christdenominations. Jewish leaders represented Reform, Reconstructionist and Conservative branches, and Muslims included leaders of the Islamic Society of North America and the Council of Mosques. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Saudis Dissolving Charity Linked to Terror Groups
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  The Saudi government said today that it was dissolving a large Riyadh-based charity, the Al Haramain Foundation, that has raised as much as $50 million a year and has been linked to the financing of terrorist organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LISCHNER, CELIA R.

She will be sadly missed by her cousin, David J. Lischner of Allentown, his wife Elizabeth, their four children and the many dear friends she leaves behind. A memorial service will be held at 1:00 pm on Sunday, June 13, 2004 at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue, New York.

title: Skip the Butter, and the Bib
description: TREVOR CORSON took a minute or two to examine the lobster put in front of him at Pearl Oyster Bar in Greenwich Village. He picked up the bright scarlet one-and-a-quarter pounder, turned it over and remarked that it was a female. Then he put it back on the plate and set about methodically demolishing it. He was too macho to wear a bib or even to put a napkin around his neck.

title: The Yankees Are Home, and Jeter Is Back at Last

title: Saluting American Artistry, From Sousa to Ives to Cage
description: A cascade of guest artists, including dancers and conductors, flowed over the weekend into performances that the New York City Ballet devoted to American music. The composers were mainstream and maverick: the range took in John Philip Sousa, Leonard Bernstein, Morton Gould, Louis Moreau Gottschalk, Charles Ives and John Cage.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Court Urges Appeal In Life Support Case
description: The state's Second District Court of Appeal recommended that the State Supreme Court immediately take up the case of a brain-damaged woman. The appeals court struck down a law last month that let Gov. Jeb Bush prolong the life of the woman, Terri Schiavo, against the wishes of her husband, Michael Schiavo. Mr. Bush appealed that decision, which led Mr. Schiavo to seek immediate resolution by the Supreme Court. Mr. Bush's lawyers have also asked for a stay because of a dispute over whether Mr. Schiavo should remain his wife's guardian. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Trying to Make Their Lives Into Stories Worth Telling
description: When we label a play melodrama and complain that it depends too much on coincidence, we tend to add, ''Things don't happen that way in life.'' But lots of things happen that way in real life. How do playwrights make us accept them in realistic theater?

title: Senate Delays Overhauling Torts to Focus on Military
description: Faced with the threat of a Democratic filibuster, Senate Republicans on Tuesday temporarily abandoned an effort to consider limits on class-action lawsuits and instead will try to complete a major Pentagon spending measure in the coming days.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Investigation Advances
description: The European Commission threatened to open legal proceedings against Coca-Cola later this month if the company failed to address the antitrust concerns the commission has been investigating for five years, a spokesman said. If no settlement is reached in the next couple weeks the commission will send Coca-Cola a statement of objections, the spokesman, Tilman Lueder, said. Coca-Cola has intensified its efforts to avert legal action in recent months. Settlement talks are believed to be focused on Coca-Cola's practice of paying retailers rebates in return for ensuring prominent shelf space for its weaker brands. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: A Grater That Can Count
description: Even without little extras -- a measuring guide and a trap -- the new three-sided stainless steel Cuisipro grater has a lot going for it. The three grating surfaces, from fine to coarse, are as razor-sharp as a Microplane grater's. And a snap-on plastic base will catch nearly all the gratings (though some will fall off the front and onto the work surface). In addition, using the calibrations on the side, you can measure the amount grated, in half-cup increments. The grater is $38 at Williams-Sonoma stores or www.williams-sonoma.com, and $36.75 at the Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (Perry Street).

title: U.S. Court Blocks Rules For Snowmobile Emissions
description: A federal appeals court threw a roadblock on Tuesday in front of the Bush administration's proposed emission standards for snowmobiles, saying the Environmental Protection Agency had not adequately explained its rationale for standards that are to go into effect two years from now.

title: NASA Weighs Robot Mission To Maintain Telescope
description: Four and a half months after he seemed to doom the Hubble Space Telescope by ending maintenance missions by the space shuttle, NASA's administrator, Sean O'Keefe, brought brighter news to astronomers on Tuesday by announcing that NASA was seeking proposals for a robotic mission to extend Hubble's life.

That man was not wearing the big hat yesterday as he testified for the prosecution about the killing of Bobby K. Gibson, who was gunned down less than 48 hours before he was to take the stand.

title: Bombardier Considering a New Line of Jets
description: Bombardier, the aircraft and rail car maker, expects to decide by early next year whether to add a family of passenger jets to directly compete with the Boeing Company and the European Airbus consortium, Paul M. Tellier, the company's chief executive, said on Tuesday.

title: The City Life; Unbearable Memories of Marketing
description: Who knows how long it's been weighing on his conscience, but Angus has finally confessed to stealing a string bean every time he went into the West Side Market, a now-defunct supermarket on Broadway north of West 110th Street in Manhattan. Construction plans have abruptly shut down the all-night grocery for good -- or bad, as so many scrawled messages, including Angus's, cry out from the plywood that now seals off the place. The boards have become an instant Upper West Side wailing wall, an unplanned scrim where witnesses commemorate -- and, for sure, complain about -- 30 years of 24-hour sustenance. In truth, the market was a grossly crammed, chaotic challenge. But it was undeniably the neighborhood's very own.

Thus far, neither the government nor the private sector has done an adequate job.

title: Truth In Fudginess
description: WHENEVER I see a new recipe for brownies, I cringe, because some things cannot be improved upon. These days, there are chefs and cookbook authors who insist that only expensive chocolate be used (not 1 in 10 of us could tell the difference) and those who add a huge amount of flour and baking powder to make something that resembles cake. (To me these are not brownies at all.) Even more offensive is adding chocolate chips or M &M's: they are fine for kids' parties but not for a classic American dessert.

description: Japanese salaries increased in April for the first time in 10 months in a sign that the nation's economic recovery was on solid ground. The average monthly income for Japanese workers was 280,746 yen in April, up 0.3 percent from the same month a year earlier, mostly because of a 4.7 percent increase in overtime pay, according to the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare. title: Moscow: Art For Sale
description: Basel, Maastricht, Palm Beach, Moscow? More than 20 of the top private art galleries in the world have brought more than 1,000 artworks valued at a total of $350 million -- including Picasso's ''Portrait of Olga'' -- to show off to the growing number of rich Russian art collectors at the first Moscow World Fine Art Fair, running through Sunday. For now it is look, not buy, because new regulations exempt individuals importing art into Russia from taxes and customs duties but impose large fees on commercial imports. But deals are clearly being made to wrap up sales abroad. Russian business executives and their spouses stroll the halls of the Dolgorukov Palace taking in everything from Flemish masters to Francis Bacon and Fernando Botero. Among exhibitors are the Marlborough Galleries, showing the Bacons, and Jan Krugier, displaying the Picasso. The fair is being organized by Yves Bouvier, the president of an art transport company, and Zurab Tsereteli, a sculptor who is president of the Russian Academy of Arts. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Tough Washington Insider to Face His Critics on Bank Regulation
description: A tiny wooden canary in the Washington office of John D. Hawke Jr. serves as a reminder of the proverbial canary in a coal mine, doomed to perish as a warning sign of pending danger.

title: Suffering and Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: And Now, Enter the Two Who Would Be One
description: It was not quite the last scene from ''Casablanca,'' but in talking yesterday about their new roles as co-presidents of Viacom Inc., Leslie Moonves and Tom Freston said just about everything but ''this is the start of a beautiful partnership.''

title: Firm Fined Over Trading Involving Annuities
description: In the first settlement in the investigation of variable annuities trading abuses, Davenport & Company, a regional brokerage firm in Richmond, Va., has agreed to pay $738,000 in a fine and restitution, NASD, the regulatory arm of the brokerage industry, said yesterday.

title: Democrats Starting to See Chance Of Keeping Senate Seats in South
description: Not so long ago, the South provided a bleak landscape for Democrats. Struggling to recover from devastating defeats in the 2002 off-year elections, the party saw five of its incumbent senators announce their retirements -- John B. Breaux in Louisiana, John Edwards in North Carolina, Ernest F. Hollings in South Carolina, Zell Miller in Georgia and Bob Graham in Florida.

title: Critics of Nielsen's changes in its television ratings methods take their battle to the small screen.
description: NIELSEN MEDIA RESEARCH is offering a compromise approach in response to intensifying efforts by critics to delay or derail changes in the way it measures television ratings in New York City. The changes are scheduled to begin tomorrow. Initially, at least, the olive branch is being swatted away with skepticism as some of the critics step up their protests by adding television commercials to an aggressive campaign of print advertising and public relations initiatives.

title: W.T.O. Moves to Revive Talks on Farm Subsidies
description: With little fanfare, trade ministers and diplomats have revived the global trade talks that fell apart in Cancn last year, hoping to salvage a framework agreement by the end of July.

title: Ryanair Posts Drop in Profit and Foresees a Tough Year
description: Ryanair, the biggest of Europe's low-cost airlines, posted its first decline in annual profit in seven years on Tuesday, raising questions about how many discount carriers would survive the challenges of soaring fuel costs and competition to lure passengers through rock-bottom fares.

title: Summer Nights in the Gardens of Spain
description: IT happens all the time. You read something exciting about Spanish wine, you proceed to your local shop, look over the selections and then wimp out and pick up something from California. Or France. Or Italy.

title: U.S. Congress moves to clarify the rules : Just how 'American' must a president be?
description: WASHINGTON:  The U.S. Constitution specifies that only a "natural born citizen" can become president of the United States, and after more than two centuries of uncertainty about the phrase, Congress is taking steps to clarify its meaning.

title: Off the Menu
description: One by one, the restaurants in the Time Warner Center are getting up and running. V STEAKHOUSE, the contribution of JEAN-GEORGES VONGERICHTEN, below, is open and taking reservations at (212) 823-9500. The menu -- steaks and other meats, fish, sauces and sides -- seems too mundane for the gilded-leaf canopy and ruby-red boudoir setting.

title: An Illness in Smarty's Family Interrupts the March Toward the Belmont
description: Stewart Elliott has ridden Smarty Jones to victory in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, and he hopes to complete the first Triple Crown in 26 years by riding his horse to the winner's circle Saturday in the Belmont Stakes. But yesterday Elliott stepped away from the fanfare surrounding the Belmont to deal with his fiance's sudden medical problems.

title: Griffey Is Not Gone, Not Forgotten
description: Ken Griffey Jr. had a football in his left hand and he kept rolling out, around that nuisance of a table and those annoying chairs in the narrow clubhouse, searching for eligible receivers. Everyone from the Cincinnati Reds was suddenly eligible.

title: A Democrat Who Would Be Shrek
description: THE big fish from this small pond is in hot water, and we're not talking about the raindrops dappling his gray suit as he hustles into Henry's Candy Shoppe, an unassuming luncheonette across the street from the elegant stone edifice of City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALBERT, MANNIE
description: HALBERT -- Mannie. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn with deepest sorrow the passing of Mannie Halbert, beloved Honorary Trustee, staunch benefactor and friend of 35 years. His sophisticated understanding and dedicated efforts were profoundly influential in expanding the Foundation's grant programs and advancing chemotherapy research and clinical science for the control, cure, and prevention of cancer through innovative medical therapies. In 1972, Mannie and his family were co-sponsors in launching our original Chemotherapy Laboratory in the Division of Medical Oncology at The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and in 1989 were distinguished benefactors, once again, to accomplish the Lab's rebuilding and expansion. Mannie has been a driving force and an inspiration to us all to pursue the promise on the horizon. Progress achieved through our aggressive research efforts will forever remain a tribute to his unwavering encouragement. His warmth of spirit and steadfast loyalty of more than three decades will be remembered with affection and gratitude always. Ezra M. Greenspan, M.D. Chairman & Medical Director Barry Richter, President Chemotherapy Foundation

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Fallen Object May Be Part Of A Dead Bear
description: A fallen object on a boat, first thought to be a clamshell and then a decomposed human hand, may actually be part of a dead bear, perhaps a claw awaiting treatment by a taxidermist. On Sunday, a startled deckhand at the Lawrence Village Marina in Nassau County reported the object to the police. It was then taken to the county medical examiner's office for analysis. Yesterday, Detective Lt. Dennis Farrell of the Nassau County Police Department said that a taxidermist working on a bear in his backyard, near the marina, reported that a bird might have flown away with a bear part. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Little Film Studio on Campus Fosters Dreams as Big as Texas
description: It usually works this way: You go to film school to learn about making movies, then you graduate and work your way up at a place where real movies -- and maybe real money -- are made. But if the University of Texas has its way, that whole graduate-and-get-a-job part might become incidental.

title: Taking Candy From Pupils? School Vending Bill Says Yes
description: After a spirited debate during which feeding candy to schoolchildren was equated with giving them pornography and drugs, the State Assembly overwhelmingly passed a bill that would severely limit what could be sold in school vending machines.

description: What better place to avoid mowing the lawn than in a swaying hammock or a porch swing?

description: Sotheby's exhibition of property to be auctioned from Katharine Hepburn's estate reinforces the image that Hepburn so deliberately crafted over the decades.

One of them, a laptop, is password-protected, and even though Mr. Purnell considers himself somewhat of a computer geek, ''the really obvious passwords,'' he said, like the names of Mr. Cochran's cats and combinations of his Social Security number, have failed.

description: WASHINGTON, June 3 - George J. Tenet, the besieged director of central intelligence who presided over a major expansion of American spy agencies but also critical intelligence failures, abruptly resigned Thursday.

title: Bush Camp Lashes Out at Kerry's Missing a Vote on Iraq
description: Senator John Kerry avoided a tricky situation on Wednesday when he did not vote on a proposal to add $25 billion for the war in Iraq to a Pentagon measure, but the Bush campaign is not about to let him off the hook.

title: And the Magic Number Is Now...
description: After Texas redrew its political boundaries last year, the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives was buzzing with talk of big increases in their majority. But when Representative Tom Reynolds of New York, the chairman of the National Republican Campaign Committee, offered his outlook for 2004 on Wednesday, it did not include such expansive predictions.

title: Cramming Issues Into 30 Seconds, Kerry Spot Is Upbeat Without Beating on Bush
description: This 30-second spot for Senator John Kerry began running on Wednesday in 20 states, and on some national cable networks, as part of his $18 million advertising campaign this month.

title: Trenton to Get Weaker Bill On Limiting Campaign Gifts
description: The Democrats who control the New Jersey Legislature are close to an agreement on limiting campaign contributions by government contractors, the most difficult of the many ethics issues before them, but their proposal falls far short of the comprehensive measure that good-government groups have urged for more than a year.

title: Sports of The Times; The Triple Crown Pursuit Is the Ride of a Lifetime
description: BILL FOSTER once worked for the Pennsylvania Bureau of Corrections, monitoring prisoners in their last six months of confinement. They were all innocent, or so they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANN, SOL
description: MANN--Sol, 77, died on June 1st, 2004 in Queens, NY. Beloved husband of Pam (deceased) and Ethel (deceased). Loving father of Dennis and Joy Mann (Queens, NY), David Mann (Queens, NY), Donald Mann (Brooklyn, NY), Andrew Mann (Jacksonville, FL), Douglas Mann and Jane Schweitzer (Falmouth, MA). Loving grandfather of Hannah, Emily, Benjamin and Maxwell. Sol served as a drummer in the Navy Band in the Pacific Fleet during WWII. A graduate of Columbia University he taught music to thousands and finished his teaching career as a school principal in Brooklyn. Services at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Mount Pleasant, NY at 11AM, June 3rd, 2004.

title: CBS joins the critics as a defiant Nielsen proceeds with changes to its television ratings methods.
description: THE nasty war of words between Nielsen Media Research and its opponents is heating up as Nielsen defies the critics and proceeds today with plans to change the way it measures television ratings in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, WALTER B., JR.
description: ALLEN--Walter B., Jr., longtime resident of Norwalk, CT, on May 31, 2004. Graduate of St. Paul's School, 1944 and Yale University, 1948. He was an avid sportsman and sailor. Beloved father of Kimberly Allen Walsh, and loving companion of Charlotte Vale-Allen. Brother of Polly Allen Mellon, Leslie Hart Tapscott and Patricia Wall. Memorial Service will be held at the Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT on Friday, June 4, 2004 at 12 noon. Memorial donations may be sent to High Watch Farm, 62 Carter Road, Kent, CT. 06757.

title: Model Shot on the W Train May Leave the Hospital Soon
description: The bullet that struck an actress on Tuesday afternoon as she sipped a soda on a northbound W train came within a centimeter of hitting a major blood vessel and possibly killing her, a surgeon who treated her said yesterday.

title: Arts Groups Call for Openness at Ground Zero
description: Lower Manhattan arts groups -- concerned, in part, that a Freedom Museum has been selected for the World Trade Center site without public debate -- are calling for greater transparency in the competition for a cultural presence at ground zero.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Arrested In Stabbing Death
description: The police arrested a man last night who had been sought in the stabbing death of his girlfriend, a 21-year-old Bronx woman. The man, identified by the police as Raphael Javier Castro, fled to the Dominican Republic after his girlfriend, Vanessa Reynoso, was found stabbed to death in a bathtub in her apartment on Freeman Avenue in mid-May, the police said. Ms. Reynoso's mother, Miriam Rivas, 48, was also stabbed, but not fatally, and is now recuperating. Mr. Castro surrendered to Dominican authorities on Sunday, and Bronx homicide detectives brought him back to the United States yesterday, a police spokesman said. He was charged with murder, attempted murder and criminal possession of a weapon, the spokesman said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: In Los Angeles, Innovation Is No Longer Just for Mansions
description: Los Angeles is a hotbed of architectural innovation. ''But it only very occasionally happens with respect to large civic undertakings and large commercial developments,'' said Richard Weinstein, professor of architecture at the University of California, Los Angeles, ''and Caltrans is a great exception.'' The new headquarters for District 7 of Caltrans, the California Transportation Authority, in downtown Los Angeles, above, was designed by the Los Angeles firm Morphosis, headed by Thom Mayne. And that is just one notable project. Above left, the Hollywood Bowl, the amphitheater in the Hollywood Hills, is to reopen on June 25 with a space age acoustical system, top, and new shell (its fifth since 1922) by the architects Craig Hodgetts and Ming Fung. The roof of the new south campus of the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena has skylights, above right, of a tough filmlike material called Foiltec, with patterns by the graphic designer Bruce Mau. Morphosis is in the running to help turn eight acres in downtown Los Angeles -- home to the Walt Disney Concert Hall, Rafael Moneo's Roman Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels and the Museum of Contemporary Art -- into an entertainment, retail and residential center. And the Italian architect Renzo Piano has started on a design for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, after the project, awarded in 2001 to Rem Koolhaas, foundered because of high costs.

title: McDonald's to Offer Free Song Download
description: The McDonald's Corporation in Oak Brook, Ill., will join the ranks of major marketers seeking to cash in on the online music boom when it continues the "I'm lovin' it" campaign with a new commercial starting Monday.

title: An Adolescent Wizard Meets A Grown-Up Moviemaker
description: For certain grown-ups in the audience, the most thrilling moment in ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' may well be the director's credit at the beginning. Alfonso Cuarn, who made the feverish and romantic ''Y Tu Mam Tambin,'' is a name sure to set many critics' hearts aflutter, even as the majority of hard-core Harry Potter fans, who tend not to see many unrated, subtitled pictures or to know the names of many foreign filmmakers, are likely to respond with a shrug.

title: Birth Parents Retaining a Voice In New York Foster Care Model
description: Kristal Johnson nestled deep into the sofa between her mother and her foster mother and listened to the two women laugh about how she used to try playing one against the other.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Las Vegas family court judge, Gerald W. Hardcastle, and the difficulties he faces in raising his teenage daughter misspelled the given name of a friend of the daughter who lives with the family. He is Stephen Matthews, not Steven.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ford Loses Rollover Case
description: The Ford Motor Company lost its first case in 14 trials involving rollovers of its Explorer sport utility vehicle and was ordered by a San Diego jury to pay $122 million to a paralyzed California woman. The woman, Benetta Buell-Wilson, 49, was injured in January 2002 when her 1997 Explorer flipped over as she tried to steer around a metal obstruction on a highway. A spokeswoman said that the company would appeal.

title: Local 226, 'the Culinary,' Makes Las Vegas the Land of the Living Wage
description: Ask people here why Las Vegas is the nation's fastest-growing city, and they point to the thriving casino industry and to its ever-growing appetite for workers.

title: Hot Bids And Cold Sweat
description: OWNING antiques is like being in love. What you don't know won't hurt you.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Municipal Workers Ratify Pact
description: New York City's largest union of municipal workers, District Council 37, announced yesterday that its members had overwhelmingly voted to ratify a three-year contract with the Bloomberg administration. The union, which represents 121,000 workers, said 47,752 members had voted for ratification and 5,753 against. The contract calls for a $1,000 one-time payment but no raise in the first year, a 3 percent raise in the second year and a 2 percent raise in the third year, with the possibility of an additional 1 percent if the union agrees to further productivity savings. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEILLER, JOHN ALEXANDER
description: WEILLER--John Alexander, 1927-2004, of Amagansett, NY. Born NYC, longtime resident of Hartsdale, NY. Beloved husband of 47 years to Jane Kenigson Weiller. Father of Ken and Susan, Dan and Tom, Matt and Brigid, Chris and Leslie. ''Pop'' to Katie, Sam, Maureen, John, Terence, Allie and Jack. Donations suggested to the Kerry for President campaign, Southampton Hospital or charity of your choice. Service June 3rd, 12 noon, Jewish Center of The Hamptons, East Hampton.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Oyster Bay: Development Proposed
description: Charles Wang, the Long Island billionaire who founded Computer Associates, unveiled a plan yesterday for a 166-acre development of condominiums, townhouses, restaurants and a 300-bed hotel. The project, called Old Plainview, would occupy one of the last large parcels of undeveloped land in Nassau County. County legislators said they liked Mr. Wang's idea of mingling shops with housing but worried that the new units would strain public schools. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Swinging on a Summer's Breeze
description: WITH Memorial Day weekend already becoming a distant memory, the laid-back summer life can begin. And what better place to avoid mowing the lawn than in a swaying hammock or a porch swing?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Profiling Measure Advances
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved legislation that would prohibit law enforcement officers from engaging in racial, ethnic and religious profiling. The measure, which moved forward after substantial revisions and has the support of the Bloomberg administration, is expected to be approved by the entire Council later this month. Council members said the law would broaden a Police Department ban and extend it to other city agencies. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Rheingold's Homecoming: Brewed Again in Brooklyn
description: The crack of the home-team bat echoes once again over Brooklyn. Cruise liners may soon steam away from the shores of Red Hook. And as the mining of yesteryear continues to reign supreme among the borough's self-obsessions, the brewing of Rheingold Beer has returned, almost 30 years after the company called it quits.

description: A game of cricket in New York requires more than a squared bat, white clothes and the patience of a saint.

description: There are certain unflattering facts about Scott Peterson that even his lawyer, Mark Geragos, considers beyond argument.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of an article in The Arts about a police raid on a museum in Aguilar de la Frontera, Spain, reversed the identities of the men shown. Francisco Paniagua Molina, the town's mayor, was at the left. Antonio Snchez Romero, the owner of the winery where the museum is housed, was at the right.

title: The Campaign Comes to Rome
description: In June 1983, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, then prime minister of Poland, received Pope John Paul II at the Belvedere Palace in Warsaw. It was the pope's second trip to his home country, but the first since the general had imposed martial law 18 months earlier, and in a speech before their meeting the general defended his decision. Despite the defiant tone of the speech, many reporters noticed, General Jaruzelski's knees were shaking.

title: U.N. Envoy Wants New Iraq Government to Court Foes of Occupation
description: The United Nations special envoy called on the new Iraqi government on Wednesday to broaden discussions to include Iraqis who oppose the American occupation, and he suggested that his own authority in shaping the new government had been sharply limited by American officials.

title: Sharon Is Confident Cabinet Will Pass His Gaza Plan
description: In a surprising show of confidence, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said Wednesday that he expected his deeply divided cabinet to give its approval on Sunday for his broad plan to withdraw Israeli settlers and soldiers from the Gaza Strip.

title: ARMY EXTENDING SERVICE FOR G.I.'S DUE IN WAR ZONES
description: The Army announced Wednesday that it would require all soldiers bound for Iraq and Afghanistan to extend their active duty at least until their units have returned home from duty there, a move that could keep thousands of troops in the service for months longer than they expected over the next several years.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Brozo Hangs Up His Nose
description: After 10 years on television, Brozo the clown, most recently the salty host of Mexico City's hottest political talk show, retired. Vctor Trujillo, 43, who plays Brozo, explained on the air that he was ending his morning news program, Maanero, because of the death of his wife, the program's executive producer, a month ago. As Brozo, Mr. Trujillo delighted in making the powerful people of the nation the butt of his fun. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Musical Royalty Gazes Back to Beginnings
description: THE gospel songs Queen Esther Marrow belted out here Sunday night were much more than music to the large numbers of older African-Americans in the audience. They were anthems of another time and place, anthems of pain and sacrifice, anthems that gave them courage and faith in the dark days of segregation and the struggle of the civil rights movement. Several listeners bowed their heads and wiped tears from their cheeks.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SPINAL DISK CLOSER TO F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: Johnson & Johnson moved closer to winning the first Food and Drug Administration approval of an artificial spinal disk, a device intended to replace natural cushioning between vertebrae. An F.D.A. advisory committee meeting in Gaithersburg, Md., voted 8-0 to recommend that the agency approve the company's Charite device. The F.D.A. often accepts the advice of its panels. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: EUROPEAN ELECTIONS 2004 : In France, the EU election is looking for a spark
description: PARIS:  There are humbling moments in every political campaign when tedium gives way to cold clarity. So it was that Alain Lipietz confronted the brutal truth about his stature as a veteran European Parliament member from France.

description: Correction Appended

title: A Special Prosecutor
description: Archibald Cox, who died last weekend at the age of 92, outlived most of the major figures in the Watergate scandal. The people who once occupied the very center of American consciousness -- Richard Nixon, H. R. Haldeman, Sam Ervin, Barbara Jordan, Elliot Richardson, Samuel Dash (the counsel for the Senate Watergate committee, who died the same day as Mr. Cox) -- are all gone. The spirit of the post-Watergate era, when issues of ethics were central to the nation's political debate, has seemed to fade along with their memory.

title: Stage Is Set To Rebuild Ground Zero, Board Says
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation set the stage yesterday -- that is, if all the needed money can be found and all the inevitable lawsuits can be won -- for the full-fledged redevelopment of the World Trade Center site.

title: Russian TV Newsman Fired in Media Crackdown
description: One of Russia's most outspoken television broadcasters has been fired after he aired a program against the wishes of the government and then objected angrily when the broadcast was abruptly halted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GHIAUROV, NICOLAI
description: GHIAUROV--Nicolai. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of a unique artist and beloved colleague, Nicolai Ghiaurov. With his large, velvety bass voice and imposing stage presence, he created a sensation in his 1965 Met debut as Mephistopheles in ''Faust.'' In a Met career spanning thirty years, he sang 81 performances of ten roles, ranging from the title role of ''Boris Godunov'' to Padre Guardiano in ''La Forza del Destino.'' But he will perhaps be best remembered for his most frequent Met role, his noble King Philip in ''Don Carlo.'' It is with great sorrow that we extend our sincerest sympathies to his wife, Mirella Freni, and his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Where to Keep Your Prints, Digital or Not
description: Even digital pictures are printed and need to be stored. John Porter, a Minneapolis photographer, has a line of attractive archival albums and supplies. A 4-by-6-inch book for 36 photographs is $13.99. A 12-inch-square album is $39.99. Target, 7100 Santa Monica Boulevard, West Hollywood; (323) 603-0004; www.target.com or (800) 800-8800. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNELL, JOHN D. (JACK)
description: O'CONNELL--John D. (Jack) long time resident of Port Washington, NY, born May 26, 1915, died June 1, 2004. Beloved husband of the late Kathryn, loving husband of Marie. Dear father of Patricia Van Dusen, John Jr., Terrence, Thomas (Nancy), Kathryn, Mary Ellen Lyons (Kevin) and Daniel (Susan). Also survived by 14 grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Jack was a distinguished F.B.I. Special Agent for over 25 years; 4th degree Knight in the Knights of Columbus; served as special counsel to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy; served his country as part of National Security during World War II. He started a legal and security firm, INTERTEL, whose missions included protecting interests of national security and foreign diplomats, and served as chief counsel to the NFL. Jack wasa past chairman of St. Peter of Alcantara Parish Council and School Board. He was loved by all who knew him. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting hours Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:30 A.M. St. Peter of Alcantara RC Church. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Business Leaders Expect Job Gains
description: The nation's economy will generate steady employment gains this year, according to a survey by the Business Roundtable, an association of corporate leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, LEVITAN, ZELDA K.
description: LeVINE-LEVITAN--Zelda K. On May 30, 2004. New York City and previously St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. Beloved wife of Milton Levitan and the late Herbert S. LeVine. Loving mother of Andrea, Nancy and John and motherin-law of Lee and Marlene. Proud grandmother of Adam, David and Abby. Sister of Charlotte and Claire. Stepmother of Dan, Richard, and Robert Levitan. Her joie de vivre will be greatly missed by her family and dear friends. A memorial gathering will be held on June 4 at 10:30AM at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Jacob Perlow Hospice or the Cancer Center, both at Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St at 1st Ave, New York, NY 10003.

title: Oil Prices Fall Below $40, In 5.6% Slide
description: Crude oil prices fell sharply on Wednesday after rising just as precipitously the day before, highlighting the extreme volatility of the market at a time when supplies are tight and major oil-producing countries must grapple with threats to their industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALDONADO, CATHERINE COCKE
description: MALDONADO -- Catherine Cocke, mother of Dolores, Maria Clara, Magdalena Moyano, and Lewis Maldonado, died peacefully at 97, May 31. Born in 1906 in Columbus, Mississippi; educated at Parsons; lived in Paris in the 20s. Married Horacio Moyano of Cordoba, Argentina and lived in Argentina until 1948; remarried Fernando Maldonado and settled in Greenwich Village, where she remained until her death. Author ''The Malvern Stories,'' admired teacher at the Lenox School, prominent member of the Church of St. Luke in the Fields. Generous of spirit and love, she cared deeply about people and literature. She touched us all. She will be greatly missed. Service June 5 at Bremo, her beloved ancestral home in Virginia. Memorial service in New York in September. Contributions to St. Luke in the Fields.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Effort To Coordinate Some Disease Research
description: Thirteen members of Congress urged health officials to create a task force to coordinate research among federal agencies and universities into diseases like mad cow, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy. The disease is caused by a protein, called a prion, that folds itself into an abnormal shape. When a misfolded prion comes into contact with a healthy prion, it can cause the healthy proteins to misfold. ''We are concerned that there is limited coordination among the crucial components of a national research program around the prevention, surveillance and study of prion disease,'' the lawmakers wrote to Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services. Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut, organized the effort. John Files (NYT)

title: WATERFORD WEDGWOOD SELLING SUBSIDIARY TO FRENCH GROUP
description: Waterford Wedgwood, the Irish luxury goods manufacturer, will sell its American cookware division, All-Clad, to Group SEB of France for $250 million. It bought All-Clad five years ago for $110 million, and the subsidiary earned $11 million on sales of $105 million in the fiscal year that ended in March. In a statement, the chief executive, Redmond O'Donoghue, said that Waterford had hired Accenture consultants to cut costs and improve earnings, which were about 68 million euros ($83 million) for the year to March, or 12 million euros ($15 million) below expectations, as a result of difficult conditions in the German market for its Rosenthal porcelain business. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paramus: Nurses Strike Hospital
description: About 425 unionized nurses, pharmacists and mental health and social workers struck the Bergen Regional Medical Center yesterday morning in a dispute over wages, pension benefits and staffing. Nonstriking employees and replacement nurses crossed the picket line at the main gate of the 1,185-bed hospital, and hospital officials said the center was open and providing all patient services. Jeanne Otersen, a spokeswoman for the union, the Health Professionals and Allied Employees A.F.L.-C.I.O., said nurses were seeking raises comparable to those the union received in negotiations with five other hospitals in Bergen and Hudson Counties. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Looks for Terrorist Link To 2 Arrested in Identity Theft

title: Al Qaeda's Small Victories Add Up
description: Al Qaeda carried out its most successful attack since 9/11 last weekend, and much of that success was a result of the American reaction. It was the second time in a month that the terrorists struck at a soft target in Saudi Arabia's petroleum industry. Twenty-two people -- Saudis, an American and other foreigners -- lost their lives, and this is truly tragic. But in the grand scheme of things, it was a small-scale attack, and should not have been treated as more. The terrorists did not strike at the Saudi petroleum industry; not a barrel of export capacity was lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLSTENHOLME, SIR GORDON
description: WOLSTENHOLME--Sir Gordon. We mourn the passing of a beloved friend. We are fortunate to have had the privilege of knowing this passionate and cultured man and to have enjoyed for many years his irresistibly engaging intellect, charm and wit. His contributions, during a long and distinguished career, to medicine and allied health sciences consisted of acting as initiator, catalyst, and guide. He led the Ciba Foundation, London, from its inception in 1949 and perfected the most difficult of performing arts: productive meeting of brilliant minds. His conception of World Health Service found its culmination in his superb accomplishments as founder and Life President of Action in International Medicine (AIM) from 1988 until this year. His numerous publications, mainly on world health, international cooperation, and medical history revealed his love of medicine and his lifelong efforts to bring healthcare to the remotest parts of the world. These accomplishments were recognized far and wide with numerous honorary degrees. We extend our sympathy and love to his beloved wife Dushanka, his adoring daughters Olivia & Sarah & all his devoted family. Patricia and Michael Bral

He also inspired the creation of one of our most popular and effective outreach tools, the ''Why Technion?'' brochure. A Technion Guardian along with his late wife Eve, their unstinting generosity is evident throughout the Technion campus, most notably at the Eve Topf Neurodegenerative Disease Research and Teaching Center of Excellence, dedicated to the eradication of maladies such as Parkinson's Disease. Their unwavering commitment also includes the Sam and Eve Topf/Miami Dormitory and the Sam and Eve Topf Miami Manufacturing Entrepreneurial Center, as well as the Southern Region Technion Emergency Fund for Soviet Immigrant Absorption and vital student scholarships. We extend our heartfelt condolences to their children and spouses, Joel and Pat Weissman, Rhona and Gary Leggiere, Steven and Joanne Weissman, Frances and Barry Hesser, Jeffrey and Mary Topf; their grandchildren and great-grandchildren; and the entire Topf Family. title: THE NEXT NEXT WAVE
description: A Polish ''Dybbuk,'' a German Ibsen and two British companies are among the highlights of the theater-heavy offerings this fall at the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It opens on Oct. 5 with the Cheek by Jowl company of London in ''Othello'' and runs through Dec. 18. Other plays are ''The Dybbuk,'' the Polish director Krzysztof Warlikowski's adaptation of the Jewish folk tale; Robert Wilson's ''Temptation of St. Anthony,'' with music and libretto by Bernice Johnson Reagon; ''Nora (A Doll's House),'' an Ibsen update by Schaubhne am Lehniner Platz of Berlin; and David Gordon's Pick Up Performance Company in an adaptation of ''The Chairs'' by Ionesco. Other productions include Bang on a Can's multimedia ''Lost Objects'' and the Kronos Quartet performing Terry Riley's ''Sun Rings'' with deep-space imagery projected on the stage. Dance presentations include Ballet Preljocaj in a work with new music by the pop group Air, and the return of a BAM regular, Pina Bausch's Tanztheater Wuppertal. Subscription tickets go on sale June 21.

title: JUDGE PERMITS REGAL ENTERTAINMENT TO ISSUE DIVIDEND
description: A Delaware judge refused to block Regal Entertainment Group, the theater chain operator, from paying a $5 a share extraordinary dividend. The judge, William T. Chandler of the Delaware Chancery Court, made the ruling Tuesday in a lawsuit filed by the Teachers' Retirement System of Louisiana. The suit said that the dividend might force Regal into bankruptcy while enriching Regal's controlling shareholder and director, the billionaire Philip F. Anschutz, by $368 million. In his ruling the judge said that none of the fund's claims had merit. At issue in the lawsuit was whether Regal's assets were greater than its liabilities, because Delaware law requires that a company must have a surplus to declare a dividend. Stuart Grant, a lawyer for the teachers system, said the fund might sue to recover the dividend for the corporation. Rita Farrell (NYT)

title: Celebrity Keepsakes
description: Today, when Sotheby's opens its exhibition of property to be auctioned from Katharine Hepburn's estate, the public can see for the first time two startling, unflattering self-portraits. One shows Hepburn with Spencer Tracy, both in profile; he is rough-jawed and she has large squares all over her face to represent freckles. The drawing is playful, but she looks as if she has chickenpox. An even stranger portrait is a full-faced drawing of herself in which her mouth is made of blood-red gashes, her cheekbones are cadaverously sharp and her eyes so blazing green they look spooky -- an image that reveals more of her cold, hard side than she ever did onscreen (maybe more than she intended).

title: Revenge of Pac-Man: Vintage Games Are Back
description: IN the early 1980's, when he was 25 and working on the arcade games Defender and Robotron 2084, Eugene Jarvis wasn't sure video games would last. ''There was a fear that everything would just kind of die,'' he said recently. Video games were new and seemingly impermanent, vulnerable to business convulsions that made him fear that he was involved in a faddish ''digital Hula-Hoop'' and that ever improving graphics would render early games obsolete. There were even wild theories that spaceborne alpha rays could cause arcade machines to decay.
