title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Pegasus Units File For Bankruptcy Protection
description: The Pegasus Communications Corporation, a provider of satellite-television service in the rural United States, said yesterday that two units -- Pegasus Satellite Television and Pegasus Satellite Communications Inc. -- had filed for bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said in a statement distributed by Market Wire that it had filed for Chapter 11 reorganization to stop the DirecTV Group from terminating Pegasus's contract to resell DirecTV's satellite service. Earlier yesterday, DirecTV said it had offered to buy Pegasus Communications' satellite-TV subscribers for as much as $750 million. DirecTV also said in a statement that it and the National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative ended Pegasus's exclusive contract to market DirecTV service in some rural areas. DirecTV and the cooperative cannot cancel the contract, Pegasus said. DirecTV, controlled by the News Corporation, said that by revoking Pegasus's contract it could reverse a decline in rural subscribers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALTZER, PAUL
description: SALTZER -- Paul, passed away on May 31, 2004. Age 87. Survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Mildred (Wurman), daughters Susan Saltzer-Drucker (Daniel) and Sandra Saltzer - Duzak (James), grandchildren, Joshua Drucker (Kristin Martin) and Matana Drucker, sister Irene, several nieces and nephews. Paul was a graduate of Baruch School of Business, 1939, and a C.P.A. He was a Captain in the U.S. Army during WW II. He retired from Witco Chemical Corp in 1981, where he was Corporate Vice President and Secretary of the Corporation for many years. Paul was an accomplished violinist and an avid golfer and a sports enthusiast. He will be greatly missed by his family and all who knew him. Funeral service will be Thursday, June 3, at 1:00PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Seagate To Cut Jobs
description: Seagate Technology, the world's biggest disk-drive maker, said yesterday that it expected $50 million in restructuring costs this quarter and would cut 2,940 jobs because of shrinking market share and price declines. Seagate's board approved a plan to reduce annual operating costs by about $150 million that includes a 7 percent cut in the work force. The company expects costs associated with the actions to be recorded in the current fourth quarter, according to a company statement. Seagate said its ability to stay profitable hinged on selling enough drives in June, which typically represents about half of the quarter's total. Seagate shares rose 14 cents in extended trading. Earlier in the day, they fell 47 cents to $12.21.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Backer Of Former Justice Wins Primary

The adviser, Tom Parker, left, defeated Jean Brown, an incumbent justice criticized for voting to remove Mr. Moore's Ten Commandments monument from the state judicial building. Two other pro-Moore candidates who ran for vacant Supreme Court seats lost, though one may be eligible for a runoff. And a Congressional candidate, Phillip Jauregui, Mr. Moore's lawyer, lost to an incumbent, Spencer Bachus. Ariel Hart (NYT)

The former bookkeeper, Lloyd Clarke, 58, of the Bronx, had worked for more than 20 years for the union's Local 375, which represents city-employed architects, engineers and other professionals. Mr. Clarke, who has paid $1 million in restitution, was charged with grand larceny and could have faced up to 25 years in prison if convicted. He faces a maximum of nine years in prison. A sentencing date has not been set. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLZMAN, PHILIP S.
description: HOLZMAN--Philip S. With great sorrow and a deep sense of loss, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the passing of its Communications Secretary, Philip Holzman. The Esther and Sidney R. Rabb Professor at Harvard University and an innovative researcher on schizophrenia, Phil was widely recognized for the breadth of his accomplishments and his contributions to the field of serious mental illness. He instilled in his students the scientific curiosity and integrity that defined his career and he set a standard of excellence for them to follow. A beloved Fellow of the Academy for twenty-two years, he brought his far-ranging interests and insights to every aspect of its work, and his wise counsel to all who sought his guidance and advice. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Ann; to his family, and to all those who were fortunate to experience his wit and wisdom, his sensitivity, kindness, and generosity. Patricia Meyer Spacks President Leslie C. Berlowitz Executive Officer Louis W. Cabot, Vice President Emilio Bizzi, Secretary John S. Reed, Treasurer

title: REGULATORS SEEM CLOSER TO APPROVING ALLOS CANCER DRUG
description: Allos Therapeutics Inc. said federal regulators were moving toward approving its RSR13 drug, a treatment for patients with breast cancer that has spread to the brain, setting off a 45 percent gain in its share price. The Food and Drug Administration told Allos in a letter that it had to complete a clinical trial and amend its drug application before the medicine could be approved. The F.D.A. also needs to inspect the company's manufacturing plants, Allos said. The letter is a turnaround for Allos, which last month failed to win an F.D.A. panel's support for the drug. The advisory committee said Allos had not proven that RSR13 improved the effectiveness of radiation treatments. RSR13 would be Allos's first approved product. The company is based in Westminster, Colo.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Carmaker Plans Cheap Export
description: The French carmaker Renault introduced a Romanian-built, $6,000 car to increase sales in the expanding markets of Eastern Europe, China and Iran. ''Renault's international growth can't rely just on exporting European cars, which are very expensive,'' the chief executive, Louis Schweitzer, said after showing the car at Renault's research center near Paris. ''The idea of a modern, robust and accessible car strikes me as necessary.'' The four-door small car called the Logan, above, has been under development by Renault's Romanian unit Dacia since 1998 and will go on sale late this year. Renault, based in Boulogne-Billancourt, hopes to sell more than 700,000 Logans a year by 2010. The company sold 2.35 million vehicles last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIFFIN, JOHN IGNATIUS
description: GRIFFIN--John Ignatius, 87, former resident of Manhattan and North Haven, CT, died Monday, May 24th, 2004, at a care facility in Sherman Oaks, CA. He was the husband of the late Carmela Barbuto Griffin, a retired librarian; and father of John M. Griffin, documentary filmmaker. He held a bachelor's degree in History and a master's degree in Economics from Georgetown, and a Ph.D. in Economics & Statistics from Columbia. He retired from the City University of New York as Emeritus Professor of Statistics after attaining the rank of Dean of Graduate Studies. He began the Police Science Program at Baruch College, later transformed into the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. He taught at Fairfield University and retired as Dean Emeritus of the School of Business. He also served as Dean of Quinnipiac College's School of Business, and did adjunct teaching at SCSU and UNH. He was president of the CT and NY chapters of the ASA, and the Fairfield Chapter of the NABE. He was published in numerous journals, and wrote 13 books. He consulted for public and private institutions on economic conditions and data collection & analysis. His college enrollment at age 13 received national newspaper coverage. During World War II, he served in NY as Army Staff Officer in military counter-intelligence. A memorial service will be held at the Wallingford Funeral Home, 809 N. Main St. Extension, Wallingford, Friday, June 4th, 2004, at 6:30 P.M. Graveside services will be Saturday, at 11:30 AM, in Calvary Cemetery I, Woodside, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Rothschild Declines Bank Position
description: Edouard de Rothschild said he would not run Rothschild & Cie. Banque, the French arm of the banking group bearing his name. Mr. Rothschild, 46, will instead become nonexecutive chairman of the bank's supervisory board while undertaking projects unrelated to finance, he said. He was named to run the French business last July, before taking time off from the company. Edouard's half-brother, David de Rothschild, 61, took managerial control of the British arm of the bank from his cousin, Evelyn, 72, who retired as chairman earlier this year. David's succession cemented control of both the Paris and London businesses by a French Rothschild, a first for the family firm. Edouard joined David in 1987 to help rebuild the French bank after it was nationalized in 1981.

The list, including all of Vermont and 2 Columbus Circle, the former Huntington Hartford Museum, is at www.nationaltrust.org/11Most/2004.

title: BIO-RAD TO BUY MJ GENEWORKS FOR $47 MILLION IN CASH

MJ GeneWorks is the parent of MJ Research Inc. of Waltham, Mass., which developed a machine that helped analyze the human genome. The company's instruments reproduce DNA, a process that may have benefits in the development of drugs and the treatment of diseases, Bio-Rad's treasurer, Ron Hutton, said. Bio-Rad is based in Hercules, Calif.

description: The Senate may consider today whether to allow the Energy Department to reclassify certain nuclear wastes at a weapons plant in South Carolina so they can be disposed of faster and cheaper than if the department complied with current law. Although many senators may be tempted to skim over this issue as a matter of parochial concern to South Carolina, they need to consider this matter carefully lest they set a terrible precedent. The Energy Department has a notoriously poor record in handling environmental issues. It should not be granted such unbridled power to define its waste problems away with the stroke of a pen.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Energy Minister Named
description: President Vicente Fox named Fernando Elizondo Barragn, his top negotiator on tax reform, as the new secretary of energy. Mr. Elizondo, who will be Mr. Fox's third energy minister, will be responsible for restarting an energy overhaul that has stalled in Congress. The Fox administration has been trying to win congressional support for measures to open up electric power generation to more private investment. Mr. Elizondo will also continue efforts by his predecessor, Felipe Caldern, to free up more investment capital for the government-controlled oil monopoly Petrleos Mexicanos. Mr. Caldern resigned on Monday in a political dispute with the president.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cable And Wireless Loss Narrows
description: Shares of Cable and Wireless, Britain's second-largest phone company, had their steepest climb yesterday in more than two months as the company reinstated dividends and narrowed its second-half loss. The stock rose 6.2 percent to 129 pence. The net loss shrank to 157 million ($290 million) in the six months to March from 2 billion a year earlier, when the company had 1.48 billion in write-downs, a company spokesman, Peter Eustace, said. The chief executive, Francesco Caio, is returning cash to investors after quitting the United States at a lower cost than analysts expected and stemming a three-year sales slide in Britain, the biggest market for Cable and Wireless, which is based in London.

title: Inside the Gorgeous Tents Of Gobi Desert Camel Herders
description: The surprise in ''The Story of the Weeping Camel,'' a documentary set in Mongolia, is not only that it has emotional punch but also that it is a visual stunner. Film students from Munich shot this account of herders and a camel who rejects her newborn colt. They juxtapose the wilds of the Gobi Desert with the vivid, highly decorative interiors of the gers, tents that are more familiar by their Russian name, yurts. Below, the herders' tent decorated with bright textiles and ornate painted paneling. As a bonus, there is a scene showing how to secure your tent in a sandstorm. (The camels stay outside.) The movie opens tomorrow in Los Angeles and New York.

Clay, as did a correction in this space on Saturday. The general, whom Mr. Lasky advised at the start of the cold war, was military governor of the American zone of Germany, not military governor of Berlin.

title: A Palazzo Undreamed of by Doges Rises on a Venice Canal
description: Whitney Sander, left, an architect based in Venice, Calif., built himself a 1,500-square-foot house, plus a 500-square-foot studio, on the Venice canals, fueled by his quest to use new materials. ''I'm looking for stuff that's really remarkable,'' he said. His house, above right, has resin sinks and an atrium sheathed in acrylic panels. One facade has a glass curtain wall, a galvanized-steel staircase and perforated aluminum cladding. Above left, his kitchen counters were made of Panelite, a lightweight translucent honeycomb material. Prices for Panelite range from $12 to $35 a square foot. Mr. Sander used 50 square feet of it with cast resin facing for about $4,000. He is at www.sanderarchitects.com; information on Panelite is available at e-panelite.com.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Starbucks Employee Seeks Union
description: Lawyers representing the Starbucks company and the Industrial Workers of the World met at the Manhattan office of the National Labor Relations Board yesterday for a hearing on a drive to unionize a Midtown Starbucks, which would be the chain's first union shop in the United States. An employee at the shop at 200 Madison Avenue, Daniel Gross, submitted a petition on May 17 seeking an election that would be administered by the board. About 13 employees in the shop would be represented by the union, Mr. Gross said. The lawyers argued yesterday over whether a lone shop has the right to form a union. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Move To Expel Judge
description: Parliament began impeachment hearings against a judge for the first time in the country's history. The government will have difficulty proving that the judge, Brian Curtain, engaged in improper behavior since an out-of-date police search warrant caused his acquittal in April on charges of viewing Internet child pornography. Mr. Curtain, who has refused to resign his post in County Kerry, was subsequently arrested for drunk driving and is receiving treatment in Dublin. Brian Lavery (NYT)

Overseas investors will be allowed to buy as much as 49 percent of the airports, which are in New Delhi and Mumbai, compared with the 74 percent that was planned earlier, Praful Patel, the aviation minister, said at a news conference in New Delhi. India also extended the last date for companies to bid for the airports.

title: Report May Have Hastened Tenet's Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 - George J. Tenet's resignation may have been hastened by a critical, 400-page report from the Senate intelligence committee that was presented to the Central Intelligence Agency for comment last month. Government officials and people close to Mr. Tenet said the classified report is a detailed account of mistakes and miscalculations by American intelligence agencies on the question of whether Iraq possessed illicit weapons before last year's invasion by the United States. An unclassified version of the report is to be made public later this month. Some close to Mr. Tenet say the report was among the factors that led him to step down from a post he had considered leaving for several years. Officials who have read the report described it as presenting an across-the-board indictment of the C.I.A.'s performance on Iraq. They said its criticisms ranged from inadequate prewar collection of intelligence by spies and satellites to a sloppy analytical peformance, often based on uncorroborated sources, that produced the mistaken conclusion that Iraq possessed biological and chemical weapons. "There are some things that are indefensible," said a recently retired intelligence official familiar with the report. "There are some real errors, of omission and commission, and it's not going to be a pretty picture." A congressional official declined to comment on the tone or specific content of the report, but said: "Our intention has been to be as detailed and as thorough as possible, and we've been very specific." The version of the report that was shared with the C.I.A. included only factual findings, not the separate conclusions that are still being worked out by Democrats and Republicans on the Republican-controlled panel, government officials said. But the findings alone were portrayed by three separate officials as likely to be particularly embarrassing to the C.I.A., whose analysts were the main proponents within the intelligence community of the view that Iraq possessed illicit weapons. To date, Mr. Tenet and his agency have insisted that it is too soon to say whether the C.I.A. made mistakes in its prewar assessment. But even before Mr. Tenet announced his resignation, the committee chairman, Senator Pat Roberts of Kansas, said at a breakfast meeting on Thursday that he believed the intelligence community was still "in denial" on the issue. Richard J. Kerr, a former deputy director of central intelligence who has been leading the C.I.A.'s own internal review of its performance, said in an interview that he had not read the Senate report. But he said he believed it had been a factor in Mr. Tenet's decision to step down. "This has been a very rough go," Mr. Kerr said, citing the criticism during Mr. Tenet's tenure of the agency's performance on other issues, including the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States, the subject of another forthcoming report, by an independent presidential commission, which is due to be released next month. The reports by the Senate committee and the Sept. 11 commission "are going to be very critical" of Mr. Tenet and his agency, Mr. Kerr said. "I think he was at a point where he thought maybe it was better that he was no longer the person up front on this." Until early this week, congressional officials said, Mr. Tenet had been tentatively scheduled to appear before the Senate committee in a closed session on Thursday, in what would have amounted to a final rebuttal before the report was released. The officials said that Mr. Tenet had cancelled that appearance, citing other committments but giving no hint that he was preparing to step down. A senior intelligence official said that the C.I.A., which has the power to decide how much of the classified report can be released in unclassified form, was expected to complete its review soon. One senior government official who works outside the C.I.A. and who has seen the report described it as prosecutorial in tone. "This is not what you'd call a balanced, analytical document," said the official, who is not normally an ally of Mr. Tenet. "It's very, very harsh." Mr. Tenet and President Bush both said Thursday that Mr. Tenet's reasons for leaving were personal, and others close to Mr. Tenet endorsed that account. Some, including David Boren, the former Democratic senator from Oklahoma who was Mr. Tenet's mentor on Capitol Hill, emphatically denied that the forthcoming Senate report or the one by the Sept. 11 commission had anything to do with the resignation. But in anticipation of the report, Senator Roberts, the intelligence committee chairman, had by Thursday morning adopted a newly critical tone toward the intelligence agencies that Mr. Tenet oversees. "Simply put, I think the community is somewhat in denial," Senator Roberts said at a breakfast meeting, at which he also called for "fresh thinking" within the intelligence community. A joint statement issued later by Senator Roberts and his Democratic counterpart, Senator John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia, praised Mr. Tenet for his contributions but also called attention to to the stormy environment in which he was departing. "While he steps down during a period of controversy over events leading up to the attacks of 9/11 and the quality of intelligence prior to the Iraq War, we should not lose sight of a simple truth: George Tenet has served his country with distinction and honor during difficult and demanding times," the two senators said in the statement. Among the particular criticisms that government officials said were spelled out in the classified version of the Senate report were the failure of the C.I.A. to develop human sources of intelligence within Saddam Hussein's government before the war. As late as 2002, intelligence officials have acknowledged, American intelligence agencies could count on no more than four informants within the Iraqi government. The report is also critical of what is described as the C.I.A.'s heavy reliance on foreign governments for intelligence about Iraq, including sources who were never interviewed by American intelligence agencies and whose veracity is now doubted. Among those sources were one known as "Curveball," who was introduced to German intelligence by the Iraqi National Congress, a group headed by Ahmad Chalabi, and who was cited in American intelligence reports as the primary basis for what now appears to be the mistaken assertion that Iraq had mobile laboratories for the manufacture of biological weapons. The report also calls attention to what one official called "slipshod work" and "factual errors" by C.I.A. analysts and operations officials, including cases in which single sources of intelligence were identified as multiple sources, and in which at least one warning that identified a source of intelligence as a fabricator was ignored. The information provided by the fabricator - that Iraq possessed mobile biological laboratories - found its way into Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's presentation last February to the United Nations Security Council making administration's case for war. In a speech earlier this year, Mr. Tenet acknowledged in general terms the mishandling of the notification about the fabricator, who was also linked to the Iraqi National Congress. Other intelligence officials, also in general terms, have acknowledged mistakes involving a single source being listed by various names, so that the accounts were presented as corrroborating one another. But government officials who have read the Senate report said it spells out many more mistakes and does so in abundant detail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MITNIK, JANET
description: MITNIK--Janet, on June 2, 2004, of Scarsdale, NY. Born June 13, 1919. Beloved wife of Raymond J. Mitnik for 55 years; loving mother of Stacie, Michael and Daniel. Devoted grandmother of Catie Bessie Mitnik, David and Max Mitnik, Zachary, Ethan and Lindsay Mitnik. Adoring sister to Ruth Rifkin of Great Neck, NY. Graduated from Hunter College in 1941, Master's in Remedial Reading from Columbia University. Owner of the Potpourri Antiques Store in Eastchester, NY. Long time member of and contributor to Temple Israel Center, White Plains, NY, Hadassah and other Jewish organizations. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY, near Fleetwood on Friday, June 4, at 12pm. Shiva at 15A Richbell Rd, Scarsdale, NY beginning Saturday evening June 5. Contributions may be made to UJA Federation.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Report On Jurez Killings
description: An initial report by a special prosecutor looking into the killings of hundreds of women in Ciudad Jurez has found gross incompetence by 81 local officials. The special prosecutor, Maria Lpez Urbina, who presented her report at the presidential residence in Mexico City, said the police had lost and mishandled evidence in 29 of the 50 cases she has studied so far. More than 300 women have been found killed in Jurez, across the border from El Paso, during the past decade. Some suspect the killings were organized, but Ms. Urbina said she had found no evidence indicating that they were the work of a serial killer or killers. President Vicente Fox said she would receive more money for her investigation. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: E*TRADE TO SELL AUTOMATED TELLER UNIT TO CARDTRONICS
description: The E*Trade Financial Corporation, the online broker, agreed to sell its automated teller machine unit to Cardtronics Inc. for $106 million. E*Trade said the sale of the unit, E*Trade Access, would result in a pretax gain of about $55 million. The company, which is based in New York, will still offer banking customers free automated teller service by refunding surcharges incurred at any machine worldwide, E*Trade said. Cardtronics is based in Houston.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Fatally Stabbed On His Birthday
description: Two brothers from the Bronx were stabbed yesterday, one fatally, after greeting a passing woman, according to the authorities. Their attacker apparently was her boyfriend, the police said. The assault occurred shortly after 1 p.m. at West 174th Street and Montgomery Avenue in Morris Heights, where the brothers -- Ronald Blackman, who turned 21 yesterday, and Ramiel, 20 -- said hello to a woman on the sidewalk. A man confronted them, saying, ''What are you looking at my girl for?'' He then stabbed Ronald Blackman in the throat and Ramiel in the side, the police said. Ronald died of his injuries at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, and his brother is in stable condition, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Printmaking in Various Stages, From Underdone to Overdone
description: The artist's right to declare a work finished when others may deem it markedly not is one of the first principles of Modernism. It laid the foundation for other prerogatives now taken for granted: the right to express private emotion; to incorporate accident and randomness into works of art; to improvise and experiment; and, in the spirit of Duchamp's urinal, to designate as artworks not only everyday objects but everyday activities as well. In other words, Robert Rauschenberg's famous statement, ''This is art if I say so,'' was necessarily preceded by several centuries of artists saying, ''This is done when I think so.''

description: MICHETTI--Toby (Anthony) of Yonkers, NY, died Thursday June 3, 2004. He was the loving husband of the late Phyllis (nee Colatruglio) and the beloved father of Felice, Larry and his wife Patty, and Anthony and his wife Dawn. Dear grandfather of Trisha, Matthew, Jacqueline and Lauren. Loving brother of Felice DiBianco and the late Armand and Lawrence. Police officials said that the woman, Erica Gilmore, was pronounced dead after being found unconscious in her apartment on Downing Street on Wednesday. A police investigator said that she appeared to have been struck in the face several times but that the injuries were not severe enough to have caused her death. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Vanunu Appeals To Leave
description: Mordechai Vanunu, who was released in April after an 18-year prison term for divulging nuclear secrets, said he was appealing restrictions that included a ban on travel outside Israel. The government said it had imposed the measures because it believed Mr. Vanunu, a former nuclear technician, might try to divulge additional details about Israel's nuclear program. Mr. Vanunu says he has no more secrets and wants to begin a new life abroad. ''Here there is hate and even danger to my life,'' he said. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Exactly What About White Don't You Understand?
description: For me, abstract painting is the great modernist art invention, the one that finally switched the channel from representations of the world more or less as we know it to something else. What else, exactly? To an art as much about thinking as about looking, among many other things. And, in consequence, to an art as inaccessible as it is expansive.

title: CENDANT TO SELL TAX-PREPARATION UNIT IN SHARE OFFERING
description: The Cendant Corporation, the travel and real estate services company, said yesterday that it would sell its Jackson Hewitt Tax Service unit in an initial public offering that might raise as much as $750 million. Jackson Hewitt, the No.2 tax preparation service in the nation behind H&R Block, plans to sell 37.5 million shares for $18 to $20 each, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Cendant is selling its entire stake in the unit. Jackson Hewitt, based in Parsippany, N.J., had 4,330 franchised offices and 605 company-owned offices in the United States as of April. About 1,100 offices are inside Wal-Mart stores. In 2004, the company prepared 3.1 million tax returns, an 11 percent increase from 2003.

description: In a clear sign of improved business confidence in the economy and its prospects, the Labor Department said today that employers added nearly a quarter million jobs to their payrolls in May. As significant, the government said that hiring in March and April was more robust than previously reported.

But less than three months ago, Mr. Guettel, an immensely gifted creative artist but a perfectionist who has spoken openly of his personal struggles in the past, announced that he would not be able to complete the work in time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Six Eviscerated Cats Found
description: Authorities found six dead cats with their undersides sliced open on a roof in Long Island City yesterday, a special agent from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said. A telephone complaint led A.S.P.C.A. agents to the roof of 31-27 Thomson Avenue, where they found the cats, all positioned with the pads of their paws facing up, their organs visible and their mouths open, said the agent, Joe Pentangelo. He said that one cat had been skinned. No blood was found on the roof, indicating that the cats had been cut elsewhere, he said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Final in Paris Gives Echo Of Glory Era For Russians
description: It was late afternoon in the players' lounge at Roland Garros, and the past and present of Russian tennis had come together around a long table. There was Olga Morozova, the first woman from the former Soviet Union to reach a Grand Slam final. There was Alex Metreveli, the first man from the former Soviet Union to reach a Grand Slam final. There, standing nearest the window, still dressed in her tennis clothes and visor, was Elena Dementieva, the 22-year-old Muscovite who will play in Saturday's French Open women's final against her compatriot and childhood rival Anastasiya Myskina.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Evidence In Identity Theft
description: A Brooklyn man who became the target of an F.B.I. investigation after he was charged with identity theft had sent $200,000 to a bank account in Turkey, Suffolk County prosecutors said yesterday. County investigators and the federal Joint Terrorism Task Force began investigating the man, Yunus Unlu, 29, after officers searching his apartment found fake passports, fake driver's licenses and forged credit credit cards, as well as subway maps and suspicious computer disks, including a program to identify bacteria, the authorities said. Mr. Unlu's lawyer, Glenn Obedin, said Mr. Unlu had absolutely no links to terrorist groups. Mr. Unlu and his girlfriend, Sai Jiang, 32, were arrested last week and charged with running a computer identity-theft scheme. Patrick Healy (NYT)

The son of the late Pauline Klein, he is survived by his loving father Maxwell Kramer and children Stephanie and Zachary and their mother Norma Kramer. title: A Scapegoat Is Not a Solution

In this they will echo the staff report of the 9/11 commission, issued in April, which asserted that the intelligence community failed to recognize the ''catastrophic threat'' that Al Qaeda represented and did not shake the pre-9/11 ''conventional wisdom'' about the extent of this danger.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Food Executive Named
description: The dairy and foods company Wimm-Bill-Dann appointed Francesco Giuffredi as head of production. Mr. Giuffredi, 61, was a member of Parmalat's executive committee until March 2003, and has been named in lawsuits related to Parmalat's bankruptcy filing. Parmalat, the dairy giant based in Parma, Italy, disclosed that it had inflated financial reports by more than $10 billion. ''We are delighted that we are being joined by one of the most respected and experienced professionals in the dairy business,'' the chief executive of Wimm-Bill-Dann, Sergei Plastinin, said. ''I am aware of the current situation at Parmalat, but remain convinced that the production side of Parmalat's business was a highly sophisticated and enviable one.'' Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: The Truth About Tiananmen
description: In countries around the world, people will recall the searing drama that unfolded 15 years ago today in and around Tiananmen Square in Beijing after a divided Chinese Communist leadership ordered in army tanks to crush a peaceful student-led democracy movement. People will recall it in China, too. But there, public commemoration is strictly forbidden, accurate information is legally secret, and an honest official assessment of Tiananmen's true significance is not in sight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tank Builder Acquisition
description: The European military contractor BAE Systems agreed to buy Alvis, maker of the Challenger II battle tank, for 355 million ($652 million), topping an offer from General Dynamics. BAE, based in London, offered 320 pence for each Alvis share, the companies said. General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., bid 309 million, or 280 pence a share, for Alvis in March. BAE already owns 29 percent of Alvis, which makes all-terrain Viking and scouting vehicles.

description: Tap knows no age. Tap dancers young and old gathered at the Fashion Institute of Technology on May 30 for "Tap Extravaganza 2004," and a result was a panorama of tap styles past and present.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Two-Step On Gay Unions
description: The Anglican Church of Canada sidestepped a decision on whether to approve same-sex unions when church leaders at a national meeting opted instead to defer one for three years while passing a conciliatory resolution that affirmed the ''integrity and sanctity'' of gay relationships. Individual bishops and dioceses may still bless same-sex unions without approval of the church's governing body, the General Synod. Colin Campbell (NYT)

description: President Bush confirmed that he had consulted a private lawyer to see if he needed legal advice to deal with the grand jury investigation into how the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer was revealed. title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES INCREASES BID FOR WHEATON RIVER
description: The Coeur d'Alene Mines Corporation, the biggest silver producer in the United States, raised its bid for Wheaton River Minerals Ltd. by about 11 percent after Wheaton, a Canadian gold producer, rejected an earlier offer. Wheaton River investors would get 5 Canadian dollars ($3.67) a share in cash, notes or Coeur d'Alene stock for each share, an increase of 50 Canadian cents, or 285 million Canadian dollars, from an offer on May 27, Coeur d'Alene said. Coeur d'Alene Mines, which is based in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, has said the acquisition will increase cash flow and help increase silver production by 45 percent. The bid threatens to derail Wheaton's plan to be acquired by Iamgold to create Canada's fourth-largest gold producer. Wheaton is based in Vancouver and Iamgold is based in Toronto.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bank Robber Sought
description: A man who robbed an Apple Bank on 18th Avenue in Bensonhurst with a handgun yesterday was being sought by the police last night. He handed a note to a teller around 10 A.M. and fled with an undetermined amount of money, the police said. There were no injuries. The robber (photo at left), is described as a white man in his 40's, about 5 feet 5 inches tall, 240 pounds, and with thinning gray hair. He was wearing a blue Windbreaker, a blue Adidas shirt, torn and dirty jeans and white sneakers. Anyone with information is asked to call Crime Stoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477).

He was also a member of the Society for American Baseball Research. Mr. Pappas is survived by his mother Carolyn Reed Pappas and his stepmother Karen Pappas. Visitation at Edwin L. title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Afghan Journalist Freed
description: The authorities released an Afghan journalist employed by Newsweek after holding him in secret detention for six weeks, the press advocacy group Reporters Without Borders said. The Afghan, Sami Yousafzai, was arrested April 21 in Pakistan's tribal areas while working with an American freelance writer for The New Yorker. Pakistani officials bar foreign journalists from entering the tribal areas, where hundreds of foreign militants -- including possibly Osama bin Laden -- are believed to be hiding. The American, Eliza Griswold, was expelled several days after their arrest. The group said the Pakistani driver used by the journalists, Mohamed Salim, was still being held in secret detention. David Rohde (NYT)

title: The French Connection
description: On Sunday, President Bush will stand at attention next to President Jacques Chirac of France at the American military cemetery near Omaha Beach. They will be there to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the Normandy landings. Thousands of Frenchmen and Americans will mingle on the site to remember, mourn and celebrate the young men who died there. While there are, today, some Americans who like to think that the French don't remember D-Day, that is far from the truth; they do remember, and they are grateful.

title: George Tenet Resigns
description: It's impossible to argue with George Tenet's resignation after seven years as director of central intelligence. President Bush said Mr. Tenet had done a ''superb job'' -- the same dissonant compliment he paid Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld after a visit to the Pentagon in which the two men viewed images of American soldiers torturing Iraqi prisoners. It's true that Mr. Tenet has always demonstrated intense dedication to the nation and his job, but he presided over some of the most astonishing and costly failures of American espionage in recent history.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Drops Alliance Talks
description: Swiss International Air Lines, the unprofitable national carrier, ended talks on an alliance with British Airways, leading to speculation that it might become affiliated with Lufthansa and setting off a rally in its share price. ''We have no set deadline for entering another alliance,'' the chief executive of the carrier, Pieter Bouw, above, said. ''It still remains a priority, but is not required for survival.'' Swiss said an alliance with British Airways was not possible because of a disagreement over frequent-flier programs.

title: MAKER OF TWINKIES SAYS IT MAY HAVE TO RESTATE RESULTS
description: Interstate Bakeries, the maker of Wonder bread and Hostess Twinkies, said costs for worker compensation insurance, primarily in California, had risen so fast that the company might have to restate results. The expenses cut pretax earnings by about $40 million in fiscal 2004, and results for one or more of the first three quarters of the period, which ended Saturday, might be restated if the company finds it underestimated insurance costs. Employee insurance costs have risen about 40 percent in the last year, the company said. Sales and net income have declined for almost two years as consumers on low-carbohydrate diets cut consumption of bread and cake.

title: How L.I. Prepares for a Blackout: Practice, Practice, Practice
description: As if last year's Northeast blackout was not enough practice, Long Islanders are being asked to cut back on electricity three hours next Thursday as a blackout drill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLINETZ, NAOMI
description: WOLINETZ--Naomi. AMIT is deeply grieved by the untimely passing of an astute communal leader and beloved AMIT national board member who, together with her most devoted husband Harvey, generously contributed to the support of thousands of needy AMIT children. A true ''Woman of Valor'', Naomi Wolinetz, Z''L, will be fondly remembered for her charming and warm demeanor, her loving kindness, artistic skills and deep devotion to Torah values and the State of Israel. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Jan Schechter, National Pres Marvin Leff, Exec Director

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Cellphones Banned
description: North Korea banned cellphone use two weeks ago, possibly as a security measure prompted by the April 22 train explosion that missed the nation's leader, Kim Jong Il, by a few hours. A South Korean newspaper, The Chosun Ilbo, said the ban might have been imposed because security officials now suspected that mobile phones were used to set off the blast. In the 18 months since cellphones were introduced in North Korea, the number grew to about 20,000. Three-quarters of South Korea's 48 million people carry at least one cellphone. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Sierra Leone War Crimes Trial Opens Without Chief Suspect
description: A international war crimes tribunal set up to try those responsible for this country's long and crippling conflict opened here on Thursday morning, with vows from the court's chief prosecutor to slay what he repeatedly called ''the beast of impunity.''

title: The Pied Piper of Las Vegas Seems to Have Perfect Pitch
description: Every dream needs a merchant, every myth a mythmaker. In Las Vegas, that job falls to Billy Vassiliadis, adman, huckster, deal maker and fixer extraordinaire.

description: Jack Binion, son of the legendary Benny Binion, who ran the Horseshoe Club casino in Las Vegas for years, once said that Las Vegas was the best town in the world to live in if you had no weaknesses.

title: Kerry Slows Things Down
description: Senator John Kerry left his Kansas City, Mo., hotel around 10:45 central time Thursday morning, and arrived in his hotel in Minneapolis before 8 p.m. In between, he delivered one 35-minute speech, at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: SABMILLER DROPS FIGHT FOR CHINESE BREWER
description: The brewer SABMiller of Britain said yesterday that it would not counter an offer from its rival, Anheuser-Busch, for Harbin Brewery of China because the price was too high. The $720 million offer from Anheuser-Busch for Harbin ''more than fully values the potential of the company,'' Graham Mackay, the chief executive of SABMiller, said in a statement. SABMiller, which owns 29.4 percent of Harbin, will get $211 million from Anheuser-Busch, a ''substantial profit'' from the price SABMiller paid, the company said. Busch's offer, tendered Tuesday, was a 30 percent increase from one made by SABMiller last week. Busch is based in St. Louis.

description: The Pentagon has proposed a plan to withdraw its two Army divisions from Germany and undertake an array of other changes in its European-based forces, in the most significant rearrangement of the American military around the world since the beginning of the cold war, according to American and allied officials.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New York Lags In Children's Well-Being
description: New York State ranks far behind New Jersey and Connecticut in children's well-being, according to a report released yesterday. Based on 10 measures of child well-being, like school dropout rates and infant mortality, New York ranked 25th, the report said. New Jersey was third, up from fourth place last year, and Connecticut was seventh. The Kids Count report, released by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, a Baltimore-based philanthropy, rated Minnesota No. 1. The report is based on data from 2001, the most recent year for which information was available, foundation officials said. For the five previous years, New York's ranking was 32nd. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: Struggling Contreras Has Drawn Interest From Mariners

title: Intensity of Performance Lost on Setting
description: Eiko and Koma have learned how to murmur the great human stories of life and love and death in the 40 years they have worked together. The winners this year of the Samuel H. In recent years, they have incorporated natural surroundings in their archetypal tale-telling. But the surroundings did them in on May 27 in a performance of "Tree Song" in the old cemetery of St. Mark's Church in the East Village.

description: Capital spending increased at the fastest clip in seven years in the first quarter, driven by investment in plants and equipment by makers of flat-panel televisions and DVD players. Capital spending rose for the fourth consecutive quarter, rising 10.2 percent for the period ended in March from a year ago, the Ministry of Finance reported. The increase reinforces the view that Japan's two-year-old recovery is on solid footing. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: FLEDGLING GOVERNMENT At the United Nations, the newly appointed interim government's foreign minister told the Security Council that a resolution on the June 30 transfer of power must give Iraq full sovereignty, but he also appealed for the continued presence of foreign troops. An early departure could mean chaos and civil war, he warned.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rye: Playland Ride To Get Seat Belts
description: When the amusement park ride where a 7-year-old girl was thrown to her death last month reopens today at Playland Park it will have seat belts, better lighting and an extra employee to make sure riders stay in their seats. The State Labor Department, which oversees amusement parks, released a statement on Thursday that confirmed what witnesses had reported: that the death of the girl, Stephanie Dieudonne of New Rochelle, was caused not by mechanical malfunction, but by her own actions. Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County executive, said at a news conference yesterday that Playland would hire a safety specialist to review all of the rides at the park, which is owned and run by the county. Debra West (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Meat Ban Challenged
description: European Union regulators demanded an immediate end to Russia's ban on meat imports from Europe, saying the restrictions may hold up Russia's effort to join the World Trade Organization. Citing health concerns, Russia shut its market on Tuesday to meat certified by individual governments in the European Union and insisted that commission authorities start issuing animal health certificates. A commission spokesman, Reijo Kemppinen, said the curbs affect 1.3 billion euros ($1.6 billion) of European exports a year.

title: Preserving an Era, Image by Image
description: THREE young German farmers are strolling down a weedy path on their way to a dance in a neighboring village. They are dressed like dandies in matching dark suits with high collars, fancy hats and walking sticks. It is a Saturday evening during the summer of 1914. In this part of Germany, between the towns of Dnebusch and Hallscheid, in the Westerwald, near Cologne, the countryside is flat and nondescript. The farmers come upon a man with a bicycle. Or maybe he was waiting at that spot for them.

Casey can feel opposing players touching his leg, patting his back or brushing bodies with him, all in a superstitious search for some of Casey's hitting magic.

title: 'Shadow' Play Lacks Brilliance
description: MUNICH, May 26 - "Shadowtime," the new opera introduced by the Munich Biennale at the Prinzregententheater on Tuesday, had so much going for it. The score was by the British composer Brian Ferneyhough, whose music typically sparks with febrile energy. His choice of subject was characteristically rich and arcane: the death (in 1940) of the German thinker Walter Benjamin, who became recognized posthumously as a hero of intellectual adventure. And the libretto by the New York poet Charles Bernstein seemed intended for a mix of high concept and high jinks.

title: I Hope I Get It: Amateurs Audition for Boston Pops
description: It was a scene this city is more accustomed to seeing outside the Boston Red Sox ticket window at Fenway Park than the sidewalk outside Symphony Hall: people camped on lawn chairs and huddled under blankets, eyes drooping but hearts racing with the possibility of a major payoff.

title: Ex-Executives At Symbol Are Indicted

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; An Intense Italian Actor Driven by Unruly Passions
description: If you imagined that the once-glorious film tradition of Italy had fallen into hopeless disarray, two recent films starring the great 50-year-old actor Sergio Castellitto demonstrate otherwise. The Italian star, whose sad, hangdog eyes suggest a man who has seen too much of the world for comfort, radiates a rumpled intensity that suggests a more high-strung descendant of the middle-aged Marcello Mastroianni. As passion, sorrow, guilt and fury pour out of him, Mr. Castellitto personifies a shambling Mediterranean everyman driven by unruly passions that he refuses to stifle.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Computer Crash Disrupts Flights
description: It seemed as if the millennium bug had arrived four years late. The nation's air traffic control computers failed at dawn during a test, and the whole system had to be rebooted, a step that blanked out computer screens and grounded hundreds of flights across Britain. Engineers had the system running again by 7 a.m., but the domino effect of grounding so many flights threw the whole air transport system into chaos, delaying most flights up to two hours. The opposition Conservative Party leader, Michael Howard, called the failure as ''yet another example of government incompetence.'' Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Guthrie, Okla.
description: GUTHRIE was settled with such chaos, when land that had been reserved for Indians was opened to homesteaders in 1889, that the cavalry marched out on the prairie to lay out its streets. Soon it was the bustling Oklahoma capital, but resentful politicians helped Oklahoma City snatch away that title in 1910, and Guthrie went into a deep slumber. It awoke in the 1990's as a preserved piece of Americana -- its downtown historic district is a National Historic Landmark -- where visitors walk brick streets, take snapshots of elegant facades and poke through folksy antiques stores. Crowds come for events like the Oklahoma Cattlemen's Association Range Roundup, a rodeo taking place this weekend, or the International Bluegrass Festival in the fall, with the likes of the Japanese Bluegrass Band. At the State Capital Publishing Museum, you can read the newspaper editorials that provoked Oklahoma's first governor, Charles N. Haskell, to threaten, ''I'll see grass grow on the streets of Guthrie.'' The grass never came, but his curse left a late 19th-century prairie town intact for 21st-century pleasure. KATHLEEN LEIGHTON

But no one on the trail, not even the spandex-wearing weekend warriors, could pinpoint where the path begins or ends.

Powell. In June Mr. Powell pleaded guilty to manslaughter while blaming post-Sept. 11 traumatic stress for the killing, and was sentenced to 25 years.

title: Frank Newman, 77, Dies; Shaped Education
description: Frank Newman, the former president of the Education Commission of the States, who helped to shape state education policy in the 1980's and 1990's and prodded colleges and universities to respond to a rapidly changing society, died on Saturday in Providence, R.I. He was 77 and lived in Jamestown, R.I.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Woodbridge: Slain Man Had Planned To Move
description: A few days before he was slain and dismembered, William T. McGuire, 39, a computer specialist at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, told a neighbor that he and his wife planned to move from their townhouse in Woodbridge, N.J., to a house they had bought in Warren County, the neighbor said yesterday. After that meeting, the neighbor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he never saw Mr. McGuire again. On Wednesday, the police in Virginia Beach, Va., where Mr. McGuire lived in the 1980's, disclosed that his remains had been found in three suitcases discovered in the lower Chesapeake Bay between May 5 and May 16. A spokesman for the Woodbridge police, Capt. Charles Rowinski, said Mr. McGuire, the father of two young children, had not been reported missing by his wife, Melanie, a 31-year-old nurse, or by other family members or co-workers. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Higher! Faster! Wetter! Racing to Be Summer's Hot Ride
description: LAST Saturday, at exactly 9:12 a.m., SeaWorld San Diego threw down the gauntlet in the amusement park wars of Summer 2004. After six years of zoning battles and construction, an expenditure estimated at $20 million to $50 million and the efforts of countless theming consultants, storyboard artists, animal behaviorists, educational theorists, architects and focus-group participants, the park's general manager, Dennis Burks, cut a ribbon of plastic kelp, and hundreds of eager parkgoers surged toward a turquoise-and-tangerine castle of curved concrete and swooping steel.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Ex-Premier Convicted In U.S.
description: Pavlo Lazarenko, the former prime minister of Ukraine who fled to the United States as a very wealthy man in 1999, was found guilty by a federal jury in San Francisco on charges of money laundering, wire fraud and extortion. Mr. Lazarenko, who has been under house arrest, is the first former head of government to be tried in the United States since Manuel Noriega of Panama. No sentencing date was set. Dean Murphy (NYT)

description: George J. Tenet's surprise departure as director of central intelligence removes from President Bush's inner circle one of the lightning rods for the criticism that America went to war based on faulty intelligence. But it also keeps Mr. Bush exposed to the election-year charge that his White House politicized the work of the intelligence agencies, stretching the data to justify its decision to topple Saddam Hussein and perhaps paying insufficient attention to other threats.

Redstone, the chief executive of Viacom, owns about two-thirds of Midway, either directly or through National Amusements Inc. Midway's directors approved Mr. Redstone's suggestion last month that the board be cut to 8 members from 11, and accepted the nominations to the board of Shari Redstone, Mr. Redstone's daughter, and of Kenneth Cron, the interim chief executive of Computer Associates International Inc.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Drops
description: Canadian employers created 56,000 new jobs in May and the unemployment rate dropped to 7.2 percent, the lowest in nearly three years, Statistics Canada said. The rate was 7.3 percent in April. Several analysts said that the unexpectedly robust labor market, coupled with other signs of a rebounding economy and quickening inflation, made a rise in interest rates all but certain within the next few months. The Bank of Canada will meet to consider interest rates on Tuesday. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Spain and U.S. at Odds on Mistaken Terror Arrest
description: Two weeks after United States authorities cleared a Portland-area lawyer of any connection to the deadly terrorist bombing in Madrid, high-level Spanish law enforcement officials who were also involved in the investigation are challenging key aspects of the United States' version of events in the case, touching off a muddy dispute between the two allies and painting a portrait of F.B.I. officials who repeatedly rejected evidence that they had the wrong man.

title: The Taxing Merry-Go-Round

Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, have each put property tax reduction proposals on the table. The problem is that both plans ignore a chorus of forecasts of long rainy days ahead, with budget shortfalls that could approach $12 billion in the next three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RATTAZZI, MARIO C., M.D.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Jewish Youth Stabbed
description: In what seemed to be a hate crime, a Jewish teenager wearing a skullcap was stabbed in the neck and seriously wounded outside his private Jewish school in the Paris suburb of pinay-sur-Seine. The 17-year-old was attacked by a young man of North African origin who shouted ''God is great!'' in Arabic as he stabbed him, according to Sammy Ghozlan, president of the Council of Jewish Communities of Seine-Saint-Denis. Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin condemned the attack, and Interior Minister Dominique de Villepin pledged that the police would use all necessary means to punish whoever was responsible. description: The United States military said it had killed 17 suspected militants in heavy ground fighting and aerial bombardment in the south over the past few days. The main battle began when American and Afghan forces pursued a group of Taliban fighters into a remote area that straddles Kandahar and Zabul Provinces in the south on Wednesday, an Afghan government official said. title: Kerry Woos a Crossover Bloc: Others Who Served

Each man signed next to the other's image, ''with admiration'' for Mr. LaBarre, who, like Senators Kerry and McCain, had fought in Vietnam.

title: FUND ADVISER SAID TO WEIGH IN ON BIDS FOR WHEATON
description: The Coeur d'Alene Mines Corporation, which made an unsolicited bid for Wheaton River Minerals Ltd., said yesterday that an adviser to institutional investors had urged Wheaton shareholders to vote against a competing bid by the Iamgold Corporation. The Fairvest Corporation, the Canadian affiliate of Institutional Shareholder Services, the largest adviser in the United States for mutual funds, changed its recommendation on the Iamgold deal, Coeur d'Alene Mines said. Shareholders of Wheaton River, a gold producer based in Vancouver, British Columbia, are scheduled to vote Tuesday on Iamgold's bid to acquire Wheaton. The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, the 11th-largest Wheaton shareholder, said it had voted against the Iamgold bid, a day after Coeur d'Alene Mines raised its offer. Coeur d'Alene, based in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, raised its offer by about 11 percent on Thursday after Wheaton River rejected its initial bid May 27.

title: In Baghdad, Restrained Optimism About the Interim Government

title: To Homer, Iraq Would Be More of Same

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, BENJAMIN
description: ROSS--Benjamin, who died on June 2nd, 2004, was a true but quiet hero. Born in Poland in 1921, he survived the Warsaw Ghetto, Dachau, and started a new life with his wife Esther in New York. Although he came to America with nothing he went on to own three bakeries--most notably the Clearview Bake Shop. For over two decades he delighted New Yorkers by supplying Zabar's and Balducci's with their Russian coffee cake and strudels. He retired to Hallandale, FL twelve years ago. He is survived by his loving wife and best friend Esther, and by his children Steven Ross, his wife Linda Kent and children Lydia and Gabriel, and Fran Ross Berger, her husband, Dr. William Berger and children Sydney and Harrison. Funeral services on June 7th, 10AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. Shiva will be held at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Berger from Monday to Friday at 50 Cedar Drive, East Hills, NY.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Measure To Limit Damage Awards Advances
description: Both houses of the State Legislature have passed a tort reform bill that would limit awards for damages like death or pain and suffering to $500,000 in health care cases and $1 million in all others. Under terms of the bill, juries would not be told of the limits, but judges are to reduce the awards when they exceed them. Judges would decide whether a jury could even consider punitive damages, which in most cases would be capped depending on the defendant's net worth, up to $20 million for defendants worth $1 billion or more. Gov. Haley Barbour said he planned to sign the bill. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: A Victory for Abortion Rights
description: At a perilous moment for women's reproductive freedom, it was a heartening development this week when a federal judge in California firmly rejected the 2003 federal ban on what its critics call ''partial-birth abortion.'' With separate suits still pending in New York and Nebraska and the likelihood of appeals right up to the Supreme Court, this will not be the last word from the judiciary on this issue. But the clear and forceful parsing of the statute's myriad constitutional defects by the judge, Phyllis Hamilton, provides a worthy model for decisions to come.

title: HEAD OF SLIM-FAST TO DEPART UNILEVER
description: Unilever said yesterday that the president of its Slim-Fast unit would step down, as the company tries to increase sales of its diet shakes and meal-replacement products. The executive, Marc Covent, will leave on July 1 as the unit is folded into Unilever BestFoods North America. Terry Olson, a Unilever food executive, will become responsible for the Slim-Fast unit, the company said. Sales of Slim-Fast fell 21 percent last year. New low-carbohydrate Slim-Fast products accounted for about 20 percent of the unit's sales, Unilever said when it reported first-quarter results.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: School Districts Move To Block Consolidation
description: Twenty small rural school districts scheduled to be consolidated under an education overhaul program approved by the General Assembly asked a federal district judge to block the plan, which is to take effect July 1. The request for a restraining order contended that the school consolidation would unconstitutionally deprive voters of effective control of their public schools and discriminate against minorities. Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, had sought even more extensive school consolidation and denounced the lawsuit as heedless of the best interests of students. Lawmakers approved the consolidation plan this year to address a 2002 State Supreme Court order declaring the state's school-financing system unconstitutional. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Chvez Recall Vote: Edging Closer, but Still Facing Obstacles
description: After two and a half years of pushing by a fractious opposition, the door to a recall vote on President Hugo Chvez's rule has finally swung open, but his opponents face an array of obstacles that could still stall their effort to end his turbulent presidency.

title: Don't Know, Should Care

But the government's intelligence failures extend far beyond the C.I.A. and the countries where we are at war or chasing terrorists. In the world's poorest regions, from the Andes to Central Asia, the government seems to operate almost blindly, facing challenges that it simply does not understand and therefore can't resolve.

title: DYAX RESUMES TESTING ANGIOEDEMA TREATMENT
description: The Dyax Corporation said yesterday that federal regulators had permitted the company to resume tests of the recombinant protein DX-88, used to treat a genetic disorder that causes swelling in parts of the body. The Food and Drug Administration suspended the clinical trials last month until it could review results of animal studies, the company said. Dyax, a developer of drugs to treat cancer and inflammation, is developing DX-88 with the Genzyme Corporation for the treatment of hereditary angioedema. The protein is in the second of three stages of human testing. Dyax said results of a 48-patient trial might be announced this month. Stock in Dyax rose $2.06, to $12.96 a share.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Attack On Governor Was A Hoax
description: The federal attorney general's office said a reported assassination attempt against the governor of the southern state of Oaxaca was a hoax. It said the governor, Jos Murat, was trying to cover up the truth surrounding the alleged attempt on his life in March. Governor Murat, a member of Mexico's former ruling party, said the administration of President Vicente Fox was staging a political attack against him. But a senior federal prosecutor, Gilberto Higuera, said the shots fired in the incident had come from inside Mr. Murat's car. He said the federal authorities would arrest the governor's bodyguards for giving false testimony and would begin an investigation against the governor, who was slightly wounded in the incident. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Indicators Improve
description: Japan's index of leading economic indicators remained above the boom-bust line of 50 for an eighth consecutive month in April, a sign that the country's economic recovery may continue. The index fell to 66.7 in April from 75 in March. A figure above 50 indicates the economy is likely to grow for the next three to six months. Japan's economy expanded at an annual rate of 5.6 percent in the first quarter, and economists say the growth is being sustained by robust export growth and rising consumer demand at home. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, DR. STANLEY
description: GOLDSTEIN--Dr. Stanley, 75, died Friday, June 4, 2004. Adored husband of Sheila, and beloved father of David, Amy & Bruce and Matthew. Adoring grandfather of Brett Aaron. He was a graduate of Harvard Medical School, Harvard School of Dental Medicine and The Citadel. He was a practicing pediatric cardiologist for nearly fifty years, and later in his career, he was a Physician Executive. He held many academic appointments, including Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at New York University; Associate Professor of Pediatrics and later Associate Dean at State University of New York-Downstate Medical Center; Professor of Pediatrics at Northeastern Ohio Universities College of Medicine; Vice President, Medical Director, and Director of Medical Education of Interfaith Hospital in Brooklyn, NY, and Clinical Professor of Pediatrics, University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. As a researcher, he was noted for his identification of the genetic syndrome distichiasis. He authored many original articles, abstracts and book chapters, and was an accomplished teacher and lecturer. He also completed cantorial training, and sang with two choral groups. He served as Vice President of the Jewish Congregation of Concordia. He was a very special person to all who knew him. He was kind and caring, and loved life. He will be missed by everyone who knew him. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, 10:45 AM, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels (www.msmc.us), Cranbury Rd. at Evergreen Blvd., East Brunswick, NJ. Memorial contributions to the charity of choice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bomb At Market Kills 9
description: An explosion tore through an outdoor market in the southern city of Samara at lunchtime, killing at least 9 people and wounding 32. The blast was initially reported as an accident caused by exploding gas or oxygen cylinders, but within hours the authorities said they had found evidence of a bomb. Aleksandr P. Kromin, spokesman for the region's prosecutor, said in a telephone interview that more than two pounds of explosives had been used. It was not immediately clear who placed the bomb or what the motive might have been. Televised images of the site showed destroyed stalls and mangled aluminum roofing strewn over the ground. A representative for the Ministry of Emergency Situations said Samara, a city of roughly 1.2 million near the border with Kazakhstan, had no history of terrorism related to Russia's war in Chechnya. Mr. Kromin said the possibility that the bombing was related a dispute among criminal gangs had not been ruled out. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUTENBACH, TERRY R.
description: LAUTENBACH -- Terry R. Long time Darien, Conn., resident and retired IBM senior executive, Terry R. Lautenbach died Wednesday in Bedford Hills, NY. He was 65. He died of heart failure, according to his family. He was with his nephew, Marc Lautenbach, at the time of his death. Born August 10, 1938, in Cincinnati, Ohio, Mr. Lautenbach was the second son of the late Frances Herbert and Robert Charles Lautenbach. Mr. Lautenbach graduated from Xavier University in Cincinnati in 1959 and joined IBM that same year. Mr. Lautenbach and his wife, Carole, moved to Darien in 1974, where they raised their six daughters. He held a variety of senior executive positions while at IBM. When he retired in 1992, he was a senior vice president and a member of the four-person IBM Management Committee. He oversaw a large part of IBM's operations, including its U.S. sales force and its worldwide manufacturing and development. He held a number of marketing and management posts during his rise to become the youngest president of the data processing division in 1976. Afterward, he served in a series of senior positions in the United States and internationally, including chairman IBM Americas, Far East, and Group Executive Information Systems and Communication Group. Mr. Lautenbach left a strong legacy at IBM. Retired IBM Chairman and CEO, John Opel, said of Mr. Lautenbach ''Terry has an extremely bright and quick intellect matched with his sensitive good humor and energy that gave him the ability to be excellent in everything he pursued -- family, business, career and social and civic endeavors--every place he added value. We all wanted him on our team.'' Part of Mr. Lautenbach's legacy included contributions to the advancement of women and African Americans at IBM. Ted Childs, IBM vice president, said of Mr. Lautenbach, ''Terry was committed to all people and ensured that everyone has a fair chance. He hated intolerance and injustice and had a profound impact on my career and ability to do the work that I do at IBM.'' Mr. Lautenbach was also an active member of the Darien community, serving as president of the board of trustees of the Darien Library, Campaign Chairman for the Darien United Way, and on his church council. After retiring from IBM, Mr. Lautenbach moved to Sanibel, Fla., but continued to visit Darien frequently. Mr. Lautenbach remained active after his retirement, serving as a director on various corporate boards, including Varian Medical Systems, CVS, Footstar, Air Products, and Loomis Sayles. Mr. Lautenbach was also an avid golfer and a founding member and first president of the Sanctuary Golf Club in Sanibel, Fla. While known primarily as a leader in the business world, Mr. Lautenbach was most proud of his family, both immediate and extended. He was a beloved husband, father and grandfather known to his thirteen grandchildren as Poppop. He was at his happiest when surrounded by as many family members as possible. Mr. Lautenbach is survived by his wife of 44 years, Carole; his six daughters, Jennifer Streeter of Darien, Conn., Susan Bates, Julie Maxman, Martha Lautenbach, Mary Lautenbach, and Anne Stern of Atlanta, Ga.; three brothers, Ned Lautenbach, Dan Lautenbach, Jim Lautenbach and one sister, Cynthia Chappell. Mr. Lautenbach's oldest brother, Thom, is deceased. Mr. Lautenbach is also survived by his thirteen grandchildren and four godsons. A memorial service will be held at the Harvey - Englehardt - Metz Funeral Home, 1600 Colonial Boulevard, Fort Meyers, Fla., Sunday, June 6, 4-8 PM. The mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Monday, June 7 at the Saint Isabel Catholic Church, 3559 Sanibel Captiva Road, Sanibel, Fla., at 1 PM. Private urnment will be at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Elder High School in Cincinnati, Ohio, The Lautenbach Scholarship Fund.

The scene below, taken from ''Afterbirth: Kathy and Mo's Greatest Hits,'' imagines a support group for Disney moms. Ms. Najimy and Ms. Gaffney -- or Kathy and Mo, as they are billed -- had their first major New York theater production in 1986 with ''The Further Adventures of Kathy and Mo'' at Second Stage Theater. Since then, they have filmed two HBO specials and also worked separately in movies and television. title: Girls Just Wanna Have Fun
description: Girls (this is meant postmodernly), you must remember this: a kiss is still a kiss. And, more important, it can save you thousands at the day spa. In the words of Lucy Baldor, the narrator of Janice Kaplan and Lynn Schnurnberger's midlife-crisis bonbon, THE BOTOX DIARIES (Ballantine, $23.95), which should be sold with fuzzy slippers and a tube of cucumber eye gel: ''One good kiss from the right guy still makes you more radiant than a year of dermabrasion.'' But don't cancel that beauty appointment just yet because, in these metrosexual times, a good kiss can be hard to find. Lizzie Miller, the nubile agency peon who stars in Clare Naylor and Mimi Hare's high-spirited sprint of a novel, THE SECOND ASSISTANT: A Tale From the Bottom of the Hollywood Ladder (Viking, $21.95), likes to frolic in pools wearing nothing but diamonds and a G-string, but even she usually strikes out. Caroming from one cad to another, she grows used to ''men who wear mascara in between eyelash dyes'' and tell their girlfriends how to dress to go shopping at Whole Foods. ''I was starting to think that if I had to kiss one more freak,'' she wails, ''I might not make it through.'' And yet, in the opinion of Drew Vance, who tackles a conquest in the elevator of a doorman building in THE RIGHT ADDRESS (Broadway, $21.95), a bitchy and brittle Park Avenue fable by Carrie Karasyov and Jill Kargman, a kiss remains ''a good way to pass the time.'' Last year, the pageant made a $1.7 million profit on the broadcast, but since advertising revenue will shrink because of the truncated broadcast, it is expected to make less money this year, when it is shown on Sept. 18. The show will be the 50th broadcast of the pageant, which started in 1921 as a gimmick to extend the summer season in Atlantic City by a few weeks. Robert Strauss

title: Sonic Youth's Latest Summer Soundtrack
description: MARIA RITA -- One peril of contemporary Brazilian pop is that though the singers may be sublime and the songwriting at a high level, there's a strange disconnection about backup bands. It's rare to find a performance going on behind a singer that sounds relaxed and organic, like a working band rather than a pile of studio musicians' excited contributions. The young singer Maria Rita happens to be the daughter of Elis Regina, one of Brazil's greatest pop stars in the 60's and 70's, and her first album, ''Maria Rita'' (Warner Music Latina), proves an exception. It's produced by Tom Capone, who recorded Ms. Rita and her acoustic band live in the studio, with nicely clanky details and open space in the sound. They switch happily from samba to Afro-Cuban rhythm to ballads to funk, using great songwriters, and Ms. Rita's lithe, small voice warms the mix without her mother's nervous edge. The album has become a hit in Brazil, and rightly so.

title: Proceed With Caution
description: Bill Joy finished his 21-year career at Sun Microsystems, the huge technology company he helped create and build, early last September. At that time, Sun sent out a press release to announce that its chief scientist was leaving and had no definite plans. This was true: Joy had only vague notions of what he would do next. As he departed, he told a reporter he wanted to sit down and relax with a glass of wine and a blank sheet of paper. This was perhaps not so true: it's hard to imagine Joy with a blank sheet of paper. Thoughts and ideas pile up furiously in his notebooks; diagrams and scribbles and equations issue forth at all hours of the day and night. When Joy, 49, finally moved out of a small Sun office in downtown Aspen, where he had worked since the late 1980's, he had to archive 900 pounds of professional papers. Then it took him months to go through his personal records, which filled 20 fireproof file cabinets.

title: Not Another Lincoln Center
description: THE housing of various worthy, prestigious, philanthropically well-endowed arts institutions at ground zero will only serve to accelerate the cultural decline of New York City. The plans currently being discussed are all in the best of taste, which is why they should be rejected. We already have more than our share of monuments to polite culture -- more than we can use, actually. Furthermore, the concentration of dance companies, museums, performance spaces and whatever else on newly developed acreage is a recipe for urban desolation. The last time such a thing was tried on a large scale, it produced the Lincoln Center complex, which has demanded respect for 40 years without inspiring much in the way of love. Why, on the site of our biggest civic catastrophe, would we want yet another middle-brow mausoleum?

title: Throwing Away The Key
description: Nine years as a prosecutor taught me this: given time, people will get used to anything. A criminal proceeding can drag out for a year over dozens of appearances in court. Very quickly everyone involved grows strangely comfortable. The defendant will get used to being the defendant. He'll nod at the D.A. and say hello. He'll rise before the bailiff says to rise. He'll know which jailer (usually the sergeant) holds the keys to the cuffs. As the sergeant comes across the courtroom in the morning, the defendant will know why and, barely pausing in his chitchat with his lawyer, lift his hands together in the gesture of a begging dog. When outsiders attend trials, hoping for a glimpse of something true, they peek at the defendant and are often disappointed with the picture of a man who is totally relaxed, in fact a little bored with his own defendantness.

title: June 6, 1944
description: Sixty years ago today, the free world held its breath. In America, daily life paused almost completely, subdued by the news that the invasion of Europe -- D-Day -- had begun. From the 21st century, we try to imagine the scale of what went forward in that gray dawn after years of preparation -- the ships and men and matriel, the reserves of willpower and determination. What we sometimes forget to imagine is the almost prayerful nature of the day, the profound investment of hope and fear it entailed. It was a day in America and in Europe when civilians as surely as soldiers felt the whole of their lives concentrated on the outcome of a few hours. There has not been another time like it, when we knew that history was about to turn before our eyes.
