After his installation, scheduled for July 6, Bishop Serratelli will preside over a New Jersey diocese that includes about 388,000 Catholics in 111 parishes in Passaic, Morris and Sussex counties. Bishop Serratelli is a biblical scholar who grew up in Newark and became a seminary professor and skilled speaker. He has served for the last two years as the vicar general of the Archdiocese of Newark, the highest-ranking post under Archbishop John J. Myers, who has said that elected officials who favor abortion rights should not take communion. During a news conference, when asked if he favored denying communion to such officials, Bishop Serratelli said that a committee of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops was studying that matter and that it would be premature to offer his views until the committee issues a report. But he added, ''I have a sense, and it's only a personal sense, that most bishops are not thinking of making the altar a place of confrontation.'' Robert Hanley

Loving father of Nancy Edgar-Howard of Springfield, N.H., Laura Ladd Edgar of Iowa City, Iowa, Caroline Albert of Pawlet, VT., Donald Jameison Edgar of Andover, VT. title: Gardening
description: I learned a new word the other day: ''marcescent.'' The Oxford English Dictionary says it means ''withering but not falling off'' -- a grim definition. I came across it in the glossary of NATIVE TREES FOR NORTH AMERICAN LANDSCAPES: From the Atlantic to the Rockies (Timber Press, $59.95), by Guy Sternberg with Jim Wilson, which gives marcescent a more hopeful spin: ''persistent but not evergreen.'' Young beech trees in the forest understory in early spring are marcescent, last year's brittle leaves still clinging to their branches and rattling in every breeze. It's a word used almost exclusively of plants, but I suspect that every gardener hopes to be marcescent, in the persistent if not evergreen sense. The garden teaches no inappropriate mercies. If we wither, lop us off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PFEIFER, HENRY CHARLES, JR.
description: PFEIFER--Henry Charles, Jr. 89, of Wading River, NY, passed away June 4, 2004. He was born August 18, 1914, in NYC, son of Henry and Frances (Hilker) Pfeifer. He served with distinction in the Army during WWII, rising from private to captain and over a 24-year career to colonel. At the U.S. Customs Bureau he rose to the position of Regional Commissioner. He was committed to working for the benefit of seniors to protect their interests and promote community and government responses to their needs. He received many awards for his contributions and in 1994 he was named Senior Citizen of the Year for NY by the state legislature. He is survived by his wife of more than 60 years, Audrey (Reynolds) Pfeifer and by his four children, Henry (wife Pringle Bowman, grandson Henry), Karen Sauerbrey (grandchildren Lori and Robert), Suzanne Colgan (grandchildren Kim, Kenneth and Jill), and Robert (wife Linda DeYoung, grandchildren Andrew and Meredith), and ten great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his nieces Linda (McCabe) Gallagher and Marilyn (Shugars) Hancock, and cousins Madeline Leuck, Fred Hilker and LeRoy Hilker. His sisters Frances Shugars, Eleanor McCabe and Lucille Pfeifer predeceased him. For information, Alexander - Tuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Route 25A, Wading River. Interment, Calverton National Cemetery.

Darryl and his four siblings - two brothers, two sisters - would pluck the fruit off the tree, peel the dimpled skin back, and slurp it down right there in the yard. Then they would run back out on the street or to the nearby park and resume playing ball, juice still dripping from their faces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, BENJAMIN
description: ROSS--Benjamin, who died on June 2nd, 2004, was a true but quiet hero. Born in Poland in 1921, he survived the Warsaw Ghetto, Dachau, and started a new life with his wife Esther in New York. Although he came to America with nothing he went on to own three bakeries--most notably the Clearview Bake Shop. For over two decades he delighted New Yorkers by supplying Zabar's and Balducci's with their Russian coffee cake and strudels. He retired to Hallandale, FL twelve years ago. He is survived by his loving wife and best friend Esther, and by his children Steven Ross, his wife Linda Kent and children Lydia and Gabriel, and Fran Ross Berger, her husband, Dr. William Berger and children Sydney and Harrison. Funeral services on June 7th, 10AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. Shiva will be held at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Berger from Monday to Friday.

title: This Summer's Weather? Sort of a Mixed Message
description: Once the Memorial Day weekend arrives, people can't stop talking about the weather.

title: Think Global, Act Local
description: The Wall Street Journal had a front-page story last Wednesday that caught my eye. It was about how the antiglobalization movement seemed to be losing steam, with police not expecting the sort of violent protesters of the late 1990's to show up at the G-8 summit in Sea Island, Ga., this week. If you want to understand why the antiglobalization movement -- which was always a mishmash of groups and ideologies -- has lost its edge, you should study the recent Indian elections. And if the antiglobalizers want to understand how they could again become relevant, they should study those elections as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUSHMAN, FLORENCE BLAUVELT
description: CUSHMAN -- Florence Blauvelt, 89, of San Marcos, California, died peacefully on Thursday, May 27, 2004 in Pasadena, California, surrounded by her three loving sons. She was preceded in death by her parents, Louis Frank Blauvelt and Laura Lay Blauvelt; her husband of 59 years, John Clydesdale Cushman, Jr; and her sister, Alice Blauvelt Melville. Survivors include her brother, Henry Storms Blauvelt of Basking Ridge, New Jersey; three sons, twins John Clydesdale Cushman, III of Pasadena, California and Louis Blauvelt Cushman of Houston, Texas, and David Goodrich Cushman of Glendale, California; and nine grandchildren and five great - grandchildren. Born in New York, New York on April 7, 1915, Florence grew up Montclair, New Jersey, where she and her husband raised their family. In 1981, they moved to North San Diego County to be closer to their children and grandchildren. Her three sons followed in the footsteps of their father at Cushman & Wakefield, Inc, the global real estate services company headquartered in New York City and founded by their grandfather and great uncle; a grandson now works in the firm's London office. Florence was a lady of immense warmth, love, compassion and giving. Gardening, flower arranging, bridge, entertaining and travel were her passions, but none more so than her family and friends, which were many and from all walks. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Florence B. Cushman to the Boy Scouts of America, Philmont Campership Fund, 1325 West Walnut Hill Lane, Irving, TX 75015-2079, or The Glaucoma Foundation, 116 John Street, Suite 1605, New York, New York 10038.

title: The Spitzer File: 'Dear Sandy . . .'
description: Turnabout being fair play, Eliot Spitzer, attorney general of New York, could not cry foul when Arthur Levitt skewered him at a gathering of journalists last week. Playing off the use of e-mail messages to expose wrongdoing on Wall Street, Mr. Levitt, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, read mock e-mail messages that he said Mr. Spitzer had sent to targets of his investigations. (Ages 4 and up) Here are familiar fairy tales, including ''The Three Bears'' and ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' retold in two voices, to be read aloud, as miniature plays, by almost any combination of readers young or old. The page design and illustrations make it clear who is speaking.

The tie-dyes suggest the so-called broomstick skirts of the 40's, which were folded wet around a broom handle and tied to create vertical pleatlike wrinkles.

description: Villa Carafa's 2001 aglianico, a perfumed, hearty red from Sannio, a district northeast of Naples, fills the palate with tarry, spicy, berrylike flavors and the spirit with la dolce vita. This juicy, caressing wine shows why aglianico, a native grape, is nurturing a revolution in winegrowing in inland Campania.

title: Adding Value To Immigrants' Cash
description: ON the highway connecting El Salvador's national airport to the capital, San Salvador, most of the billboards don't promote luxury cars, fancy tourist hotels or clothing stores. Instead, they advertise the electronic transfer of remittances -- las remesas -- the money earned by Salvadoran men and women in the United States and sent back in allotments of maybe $200 or $300 a month.

title: Mourning Rooms
description: TWO weeks ago, when the body of a Juilliard student, Sarah Fox, was found in Inwood Hill Park, 150 of her grief-stricken classmates gathered in the school's Room 304. Normally used for classes in movement and rehearsals, this spare, unassuming studio has, over the last five years, taken on a grim secondary purpose as Juilliard's unofficial grieving space. Students filled the room a few years ago when another drama student was found dead, for example, and after Sept. 11, of course, the room was full of mourners.

title: Discreditable
description: My husband works for a store that urges sales associates to promote credit cards with an annual rate of 21 percent. He considers it unethical to push this card on poorer people who cannot pay off the balance promptly. He suggests the card only to customers who spend a lot, although he processes an application for anyone who asks. He says he's refusing to victimize poor people; I say he's making unwarranted assumptions about people's best interests: discounts come with the card. What do you say? J.M., Washington

title: What Is Google's Secret Weapon? An Army of Ph.D.'s
description: HEY, it's not rocket science. And it's not brain surgery. But if your background is in either, you're welcome to take a shot and apply at Google. The company's employees include a former rocket scientist and a former brain surgeon.

title: Commuting Community
description: THE sound of hissing brakes from the bus as it slowly rounds Sixth Street into Front is the signal for the regulars to meekly straighten up in the line, gather up bags and take out their bus passes. A starting bell of sorts goes off in my mind as I step into the 190. The bus driver smiles as he dispatches my ticket, and then I go through the narrow aisle and look around at all the strange and yet already familiar faces, daily companions in my commute to work.

title: Dover Makes a Name for Itself
description: One day many years ago, Denis McGlynn found himself with a dictionary, thumbing through the words that started with the letter M. He was in charge of drumming up publicity for Dover International Speedway, and he had appointed himself to a marketing mission.

title: Green Mountain Shoppers, Unite
description: For a small state, Vermont gets more than its 15 minutes of fame. First, our own Jim Jeffords upset the Senate balance when he defected from the Republican Party and became an independent in 2001. Then Howard Dean put us on the political map -- for a while. Most recently, the National Trust for Historic Preservation put the entire state of Vermont -- all 9,250 square miles -- on its list of ''most endangered'' places, an annual list more commonly filled by historic buildings or unusual scenic areas.

title: Rossellini, Surrealism and a Polite Smile
description: HER fans stood six and seven deep in a tight circle, nearly obscuring Isabella Rossellini from anyone else's view. One man dropped a heavy arm around her narrow shoulders, loudly supervising his wife's attempt to snap a photograph. A woman held a plastic cup of white wine in one hand and fingered the silk sash of Ms. Rossellini's kimono with the other. She then asked her where she had bought it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DICKSTEIN, EDITH
description: DICKSTEIN -- Edith. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital Center mourn with extreme sorrow the passing of our dear friend, Board member and benefactor, Mrs. Edith Dickstein. Edie's, along with her beloved late husband Frank's, participation and contributions to our Hospital spanned more than 30 years and did a great deal to make possible our pre-eminent position as the leading health care provider in Westchester County. Her continuing support and inspirational leadership created the Dickstein Cancer Treatment Center, Westchester's only free-standing cancer treatment facility, which offers compassionate stateof-the-art cancer care. Edie's devotion to the Hospital was extraordinary. She was a respected philanthropist who was deeply committed to improving the quality of life for families and children. Her endearing nature and vivacious spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her children: Dennis and Nancy Gilbert, Pam and Jeffrey Gittleman, and Laurie and Barry Siegel and their children and grandchildren. Robert Feder, Chairman of the Board of Directors Jon B. Schandler, President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VINCENT, WILLIAM J., JR.
description: VINCENT--William J., Jr., loving husband of Anne (1925-1999) and father of Judith, passed away peacefully May 30, 2004 at North Shore Hospital in Glen Cove, at the age of 84. A Glen Head resident for 60 years, he served as the Town of Oyster Bay's first Commissioner of General Services from the early '60s until 1980. He was active in the Glen Players theater group, Civil Defense, politics and numerous charities. An avid boater, Bill was a USCG Auxiliary member for 35 years, serving three terms as Commander, US Coast Guard Auxiliary, Flotilla 12-3. He was a lifetime member of US Power Squadrons, acting until recently as Port Captain for Hempstead Harbor. Bill is survived by his daughter, Judith Questo (David) of Salt Spring Island, BC, Canada. A funeral service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Sea Cliff on Wednesday, June 9th, at 2:00 P.M.

title: Images of India
description: To the Editor: When I visited the Taj Mahal (''A Glorious Survivor,'' May 16), I found the setting every bit as important as the edifice in striving to appreciate the magnificence of the whole. My companions and I arrived in Agra by train an hour before dawn. After a quick drop-off of bags at our hotel, we walked to the gate, too early for entrance but not too early for a cup of chai and a chat with the tea seller while we waited. Later in the day, as I walked self-consciously about town in my white kurta and matching pajama pants, I was treated to many smiling greetings from locals, a ''Hello, Gandhi-ji!'' from the Hindus and ''Salaam Aleikum'' from the Muslims. I had to jump out of the way of an elephant lumbering down the street as I entered a shop for some serious negotiations over a bauble. The Taj Mahal without Agra?

title: A Renaissance on Campus at Southern
description: A SWING around the perimeter of Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven, once a drab mishmash of two-and three-story buildings dating back to the 1950's and 1960's, is these days a startling expedition. The 168-acre campus on the outskirts of the city is dotted with impressive brick and glass structures recently completed or under construction. Along a wire fence that surrounds a construction site is a huge plastic banner welcoming the school's new president, Cheryl J. Norton, the first female head in its nearly 111-year history.

description: In the May 2 issue, the magazine ran a headline claiming that I said ''immigration is ruining America.'' That claim is false. I did not say immigration is ruining America, and I have never said that.

title: Francis Brunn, Circus Juggler Extraordinaire, Dies at 81
description: Francis Brunn, who cared little that he was often described as one of the half-dozen best jugglers of the 20th century, because his art, he said, transcended mere juggling, died on May 28 at a hospital in Frankfurt, Germany. He was 81.

title: The Panorama of Denali
description: NOTHING could have prepared me for the riveting view 10,000 feet over Denali National Park and Preserve, the vast wilderness in Alaska. We had taken off just 20 minutes before, passengers in a 10-seat single-engine turboprop, ascending over flat green and brown earth punctuated by water pooling on the tundra. But the green turned white as we neared the snowy Alaska range, and the terrain gained texture and clarity, as if we were peering through a microscope of increasing power.

''The world,'' he vowed, ''will see how a free system, a democratic system, functions and operates transparently.''

title: Commencement Speeches; Threats to Rights and Financial Barriers to Poor Are Cited at Graduations
description: Ted Koppel warned of a rising threat to basic constitutional rights. The president of Amherst College decried the increasing financial barriers that the poor face in obtaining a college education. Robert Redford said America was on the brink of a moral crisis comparable to Watergate and the Iran-contra scandal because of the growing ''political gains of not telling the truth.''

title: Staking a Claim in the Silicon Valley
description: MOSTAFA AMIRI moved to this little Silicon Valley city in 1980 and became the ice cream man, selling chocolate drumsticks to kids from his truck. That was dangerous enough, said his friends, who worried that anyone driving around with a lot of cash would be a prime target for crime. But when he proposed buying a home here, that was just too much. They begged him to reconsider.

title: Argentine Men Delivering on Grand Slam Potential
description: PARIS, June 5 (AP)  This year Argentina will claim its first men's singles title at the French Open since 1977. On Sunday, Guillermo Coria, who was expected to reach the final here, will meet Gaston Gaudio, who was not. The third-seeded Coria, the hottest player in the world on clay, downed the resurgent Briton Tim Henman in the semifinals while the unseeded Gaudio continued his surprising run to defeat his eighth-seeded countryman, David Nalbandian.

title: School's Out. Now What?
description: NEW JERSEY is a small state with a long coastline, and most people can get from home to a favorite beach in well under two hours. The Shore is a classic family destination, but there are other ways to slip into another time and place, some of which even allow families to avoid traffic on the Parkway, which is as inevitable as sand in the beach blanket. Here are some suggestions for getting away. And, remember, the kids will be out of school before you know it.

title: Mosque and State in Turkey
description: When looking for hopeful signs that Islam and democracy can indeed coexist, the international community turns to Turkey. So it was a disappointment recently when Turkey's president vetoed a law that would grant graduates of religious high schools equal access to the nation's secular universities.

title: Amid the Parmesan and Olive Oil, An Unexpected Symbol
description: On Arthur Avenue, the main drag of the Little Italy of the Bronx, stands a corner store that is as authentic an Italian grocery as you can imagine. Huge salamis, as big and dangerous as torpedoes, hang from the ceiling; creamy mozzarella swims in vats of milky water, and prodigious Parmesans crumble next to pyramids of tinned olive oil in various states of virginity.

title: When Mothering Is a Pain in the Wrist

But as days went by, it started to hurt more and more until the pain was so severe, she had trouble holding her baby.

Of course they do: that was the day when their lives touched history; the day they proved to themselves that they were soldiers; the day death came near and then moved on; the day they survived.

The television series ''Alias'' notwithstanding, you can be pretty sure that gizmos of mass destruction are not always stored in the immediate vicinity of spectacularly glamorous parties.

description: GOLDBERG--Natalie Perlo. Died June 3rd, 2004 after a long battle with cancer. title: What The Bagel Man Saw
description: Once upon a time, Paul F. dreamed big dreams. While studying agricultural economics at Cornell, he wanted to end world hunger. Instead, after doctoral work at M.I.T., he wound up taking a job with a research institute in Washington, analyzing the weapons expenditures of the United States Navy. This was in 1962. After four years came more of the same: analyst jobs with the Bureau of the Budget, the Institute for Defense Analyses, the President's Commission on Federal Statistics. Still, he dreamed. He had ''potent research ideas,'' as he recalls them now, which the Environmental Protection Agency failed to appreciate. He developed a statistical means of predicting cancer clusters, but because he was an economist and not a doctor, he couldn't make headway with the National Cancer Institute. He still loved the art of economics -- the data-gathering, the statistical manipulation, the problem-solving -- but it had led him to a high-level dead end. He was well paid and unfulfilled. ''I'd go to the office Christmas party, and people would introduce me to their wives or husbands as the guy who brings in the bagels,'' he says. '''Oh! You're the guy who brings in the bagels!' Nobody ever said, 'This is the guy in charge of the public research group.'''

title: Dough A La Mode
description: I recently grabbed a quick bite at Bar Masa, in the new Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle. The bar has a short menu, so ordering was simple. The waiter proposed a plate of assorted sashimi at $85. I accepted. Sea-eel tempura sounded like a nice way to start off, and corn croquettes, in a Japanese restaurant, seemed weird but interesting. My eye wandered to an Asian-style risotto of lobster and black truffles. Irresistible, so why resist? -- although $34 was pushing the upper limit on what was, when you got down to it, a glorified bar menu. The bill for two, with no dessert and no drinks, was about $200.

So what if the first one she encountered happened to be married, with several adolescent children? Whether in the wake of tragedy or not, the shamelessness and self-interest exhibited by these two people is astounding and embarrassing.

title: Bush and Chirac Say Iraq Discord Narrows
description: President Bush and President Jacques Chirac of France, in Paris, say they have narrowed their differences over a United Nations resolution establishing a framework for returning self-government to Iraq and may reach an agreement within days. A mechanism has been worked out to ensure that Iraqis will be consulted about and comfortable with American military operations in Iraq after the return of sovereignty on June 30, officials say.

title: A Long Way Down
description: You could hear the corrections officer jingle his chain and turn his heavy Folger Adam key in the lock before the door swung open and Jay Jones came walking into the visiting room. It's a big space with a lot of chairs but no exterior windows, so Jones had no way of knowing the sun shone brightly outside and high-up clouds were drifting over the grassland west of Oklahoma City. Dressed in forest-green pants and shirt, with white socks and black shoes, he looked more like the guy who comes to fix your dishwasher than an inmate of a federal institution. This was the Transfer Center of the United States Bureau of Prisons, the transportation hub for thousands of state and federal convicts passing through each year on their way from one prison to another. Jones was part of the ''cadre,'' or group of inmates who dish up the meals, cut the grass and generally keep the facility running. I had last seen him six months before, on June 30, 2003, in an upscale subdivision south of Tulsa where he wished goodbye to his wife and his daughter and his son-in-law standing on the steps of their house. He had changed considerably since then. His ruddy face had acquired the proverbial jailhouse pallor; he was down about 20 pounds, owing to his distaste for prison food. And he wasn't as quick to smile as he had been the previous spring.

title: The Price Of Parsimony
description: My anxiety about spending money reared up one day when I was walking down the aisles of a C-Town in the Bronx. I was a few years into the fieldwork for a book I was writing on inner-city poverty, living on less than a quarter of the salary I'd earned at my last proper job. That afternoon, I was trailing my book's main subject, Lolli, as she bought the month's groceries. She was a teenager, pregnant, homeless and already the mother of two children. Her young family subsisted on food stamps and vouchers from the federal subsidy program, WIC. The shield of my judgment rose when she passed right by the C-Town weekly discount flier and made her way down the dirty aisles with her shopping cart. She just grabbed things -- packs of chicken legs and pork chops, bags of sugar and rice, bottles of vegetable oil; in went cans of beans and tins of Spam. I stood, stunned, as she reached for the individual-portion cartons of juice -- with their brightly colored miniature straws -- ignoring the larger, economy-size bottles. No calculation of unit price, no can'ts or shoulds or ought-not-to's, no keen eye to the comparative ounce. By the time her stuffed cart reached the checkout line, my unease was turning into anger. Didn't she know she was poor?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLBURN, RICHARD D.
description: COLBURN--Richard D. Los Angeles Opera mourns with profound sadness the death of our very dear friend Richard Colburn. His singular commitment to the performing arts, and especially his deep appreciation and joyous pleasure in experiencing the beauty and wonder of opera, has been an inspiration to our Company. Richard Colburn's generous leadership support as a Founding Angel, through the Colburn Foundation and as a Domingo Angel enabled Los Angeles Opera to reach higher levels of artistic achievements each season and grow into an internationally acclaimed major opera house. Richard Colburn leaves a legacy of vision in philanthropy and the arts. He will be remembered especially for his personal energy, his prodigious knowledge of music and musicians, and his passion for excellence in performance. An accomplished violist himself, Richard had a deep appreciation for musicians and their accomplishments. He was a memorable presence in the opera house where he particularly relished opening nights, premieres and other festive evenings. We will miss his quiet encouragement from the first row at each performance he attended and the unusual rapport he had with our musicians and other members of the Company. We will miss his wise counsel during challenging times and his irreverent wit in even the most difficult of circumstances. His unabated enjoyment of his involvement with Los Angeles Opera, his extraordinary philanthropy and most of all his abiding friendships within our Board and Company set an example that will inspire music lovers in future generations. He will be deeply missed by all who were privileged to know him as a friend. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Lisa Colburn and to his family. Marc I. Stern, Chairman and C.E.O. Frank E. Baxter, President Placido Domingo, General Director Kent Nagano, Music Director Edgar Baitzel, Artistic Director Elizabeth Kennedy, Administrative Director

title: More Power To the People

The same is true of genocide -- in Germany, Cambodia or Rwanda. These dark capabilities exist in us all and can surface with the right potent mix of ingredients. That realization is the first step toward prevention.

title: A Museum Opens At Concentration Camp
description: The Sachsenhausen concentration camp in Oranienburg, Germany, where 200,000 people were imprisoned between 1936 and 1945, recently opened a visitors' center and historical museum. Sachsenhausen, 20 miles north of Berlin, was one of the first concentration camps established by the Nazi regime. Tens of thousands of the inmates are believed to have died there.

title: 'Grant and Twain'
description: Ulysses S. Grant never understood how to handle money. That was not true of his father, Jesse, who understood it so well that he became a successful and affluent businessman. A tanner by trade, Jesse Grant came to the Ohio country and opened a business in Point Pleasant, a small trading town on the Ohio River. Tanning is a dirty and bloody business, but it's honorable and ancient: The apostle Paul was a tanner, a fact undoubtedly pointed out repeatedly by Jesse's devout and dour Methodist wife, Hannah. Hannah Simpson was a strong-willed Pennsylvania woman who believed that work could save souls and who told people (apparently with some repetition) that she wanted to live "unspotted from the world." People noted that she meant what she said. Hannah worked from sunrise to sunset, like her husband, Jesse, whose face was pockmarked by tannic acid but whose biceps were as hard as iron cannon-the result of throwing ungainly pickled hides out to dry.

title: Page Two: May 30-June 5; DON'T JUST TALK

title: Travel
description: TRAVEL writing has traditionally been an escapist genre, with a mandate to seduce; its natural subjects are pleasure, beauty, food, wine. All the senses are appealed to, and inconvenience and discomfort are purely vicarious. But in today's international climate, the tried-and-true staples of travel literature -- Provenal cuisine, Americans in Paris, the hill towns of Tuscany -- have come to seem not just irrelevant but boring. Tame. A handful of recent travel books, featuring subjects that range from the only slightly offbeat (revisionist looks at Germany and modern Greece) to the truly mind-stretching (Kyrgyzstan, the Gobi Desert, wartime Afghanistan, peacetime Iraq), have thoroughly trumped the standard travel literature this summer.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE BOUNTY: The True Story of the Mutiny on the Bounty, by Caroline Alexander. (Penguin, $15.) In this vigorous retelling of the 1789 mutiny that left Captain Bligh and 18 crewmen in an open boat to journey across some 3,600 miles of the South Pacific, Bligh was a brilliant navigator and hardly the sadistic disciplinarian portrayed in the movies (at least not by Royal Navy standards). Alexander's account, which focuses largely on the Navy's attempts to bring to justice the mutineers who did not escape to Pitcairn Island, was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2003. ''A sea mist hangs over this age-old tale,'' Verlyn Klinkenborg wrote here. ''Alexander dispels it, to the reader's fascination.''

The shows will be advertised as ''The Bowery Presents,'' and a new sound system will be installed, said John Moore, who books the Bowery. Webster Hall will be available for bookings seven nights a week, he said, although its late-night dancing on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays means that any other concerts will have to end by 11:30 p.m., resulting in strange meetings of rock and dance fans on their way in and out, already a common occurrence there. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUSHMAN, FLORENCE BLAUVELT
description: CUSHMAN -- Florence Blauvelt, 89, of San Marcos, California, died peacefully on Thursday, May 27, 2004 in Pasadena, California, surrounded by her three loving sons. She was preceded in death by her parents, Louis Frank Blauvelt and Laura Lay Blauvelt; her husband of 59 years, John Clydesdale Cushman, Jr; and her sister, Alice Blauvelt Melville. Survivors include her brother, Henry Storms Blauvelt of Basking Ridge, New Jersey; three sons, twins John Clydesdale Cushman, III of Pasadena, California and Louis Blauvelt Cushman of Houston, Texas, and David Goodrich Cushman of Glendale, California; and nine grandchildren and five great - grandchildren. Born in New York, New York on April 7, 1915, Florence grew up Montclair, New Jersey, where she and her husband raised their family. In 1981, they moved to North San Diego County to be closer to their children and grandchildren. Her three sons followed in the footsteps of their father at Cushman & Wakefield, Inc, the global real estate services company headquartered in New York City and founded by their grandfather and great uncle; a grandson now works in the firm's London office. Florence was a lady of immense warmth, love, compassion and giving. Gardening, flower arranging, bridge, entertaining and travel were her passions, but none more so than her family and friends, which were many and from all walks. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Florence B. Cushman to the Boy Scouts of America, Philmont Campership Fund, 1325 West Walnut Hill Lane, Irving, TX 75015-2079, or The Glaucoma Foundation, 116 John Street, Suite 1605, New York, New York 10038.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: 2 Killed In Early-Morning Violence
description: Two men were killed and three others were wounded in four separate shootings and a stabbing in the city early yesterday, the police said. The only victim identified by the police, Oscar Kennedy, 27, was shot in the head and back about 12:30 a.m. in the lobby of the building where he lived at the Coney Island Houses in Brooklyn and pronounced dead at Coney Island Hospital. Seven minutes later in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, a 20-year-old man was shot once in the head in the hallway of 185 Nevins Street, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in critical condition, the police said. At 4 a.m., the police, responding to a 911 call of an injured person, arrived at 104-39 Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, to find a man in his 20's without identification who had been shot in the arm and chest. He was pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital Center a short time later. And, at 5:24 a.m. one man was shot twice and another was stabbed in a fight, apparently over a woman, at 2341 McDonald Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn, the police said. They were taken to Lutheran Medical Center in serious condition. There were no arrests in any of the cases. Michael Wilson (NYT)

description: A jail inmate fell to his death yesterday when a homemade rope broke as he tried to escape from a psychiatric ward at Kings County Hospital Center, a spokesman for the city Correction Department said yesterday. Just after midnight, the inmate, Anthony Borelli, 37, fell six floors from the ward where he had been held since April 27, according to the spokesman, Thomas Antenen. Mr. Borelli had removed an air-conditioner from a wall in a room where he and several other inmates were staying. He went out the slot for the air-conditioner and was climbing down using a rope made of strips of torn bedsheets when the rope apparently broke, Mr. Antenen said. A section of the rope was still attached at the sixth floor while the rest was found on a ledge near Mr. Borelli's body, Mr. Antenen added. The other inmates in the room did not alert correction officers to the escape, but an officer discovered Mr. Borelli missing on his usual 15-minute check of the room, Mr. Antenen said. Mr. Borelli had entered the jail system in January on charges of violating parole, robbery and attempted burglary. He was awaiting a psychiatric evaluation at the hospital.

title: 1929:British Embassy Is Dry : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: WASHINGTON: The British Embassy here is to go Dry as soon as its present supply of liquor is exhausted. Sir Esme Howard, the Ambassador, has informed Attaches at the Embassy that he will refuse to sign requests for shipments of intoxicants, which are allowed to enter the United States as privileged "diplomatic liquor." Sir Esme Howard is thus voluntarily renouncing the drinking privilege, as he announced he was willing to do when recently he replied to a letter from a resident of Virginia, who wrote to him protesting the "shameful abuse of diplomatic immunity with regard to the importation of intoxicating wines and liquors." The French Ambassador, M. Paul Claudel, disagrees with his British colleague on this question. It is reported here that M. Claudel has received notes from nine wine merchants at Bordeaux, who fear the loss of their trade with the Diplomatic Corps in Washington. The business, they state, is worth $50,000 annually.

title: INDIE OUTLETS CLOSED
description: Moviegoers in three cities unexpectedly found themselves without an option for independent films last week. The Madstone Theater chain abruptly shut theaters in Ann Arbor, Mich.; Chandler, Ariz.; and Atlanta, citing a lack of business. The move cut Madstone's locations to 7 cities from 10 across the country. Madstone said those theaters, in places like Denver, San Diego and Baltimore, would remain open. Madstone, based in New York, is an offshoot of Madstone Films, a production company founded in 1999. Its theaters aimed to attract movie buffs with documentaries, foreign films and retrospectives, as well as first-run films. They also offer BYOBaby, a weekly film series that allows parents to bring children under 2 years old at no charge. Officials said attendance at the three theaters did not meet expectations. In all three cities Madstone competed with nearby houses showing similar films, as well as big cineplexes that often pick up the most popular independent movies. MICHELINE MAYNARD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHMAN, SYLVIA ELLEN
description: FISHMAN--Sylvia Ellen. Died June 5, 2004. She was the devoted daughter of the late Robert and Lillian Fishman. Sylvia began her long and distinguished career at Hunter College as an Associate Professor in the Department of Health and Physical Education. In 1979 she was appointed Vice President of Student Affairs and Dean of Students and served in that capacity until her retirement in 2002. From 1995-96 she served as acting Vice President for Administration and from 1992 until the present she was Chair of the College Association, among numerous other roles at Hunter College, during her career. Sylvia's life was dedicated to her father, Hunter College and her students. She earned her B.S. from Tufts University, her M.S. from Hunter College, CUNY and her Doctorate in Education from Columbia University Teacher's College. Outside of Hunter, she was also active in many professional associations. Surviving are two cousins, Emanuel Fishman and Sylvia Rubin, as well as countless loving friends and former Hunter students the world over. Funeral 10 a.m. Wednesday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY (Saw Mill Exit 17). Memorials to the Robert, Lillian and Sylvia Fishman Scholars Fund at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Ronald Reagan
description: Ronald Reagan, who died on Saturday after his long battle with Alzheimer's disease, projected an aura of optimism so radiant that it seemed almost a force of nature. Many people who disagreed with his ideology still liked him for his personality, and that was a source of frustration for his political opponents who knew how much the ideology mattered. Looking back now, we can trace some of the flaws of the current Washington mindset -- the tax-cut-driven deficits, the slogan-driven foreign policy -- to Mr. Reagan's example. But after more than a decade of political mean-spiritedness, we have to admit that collegiality and good manners are beginning to look pretty attractive.

The suspects, Jorge Aureliano Flix and Efran Prez Pazuengo, were wanted men in the United States and in Mexico. The United States Justice Department had posted a $2 million reward for information leading to their capture. They are accused of being senior members of the Arellano Flix cartel, based in Tijuana, where their arrests took place. The heavily armed cartel, which sends billions of dollars of drugs to the United States annually, earned an unmatched reputation for violence in the 1990's, when it dominated the drug trade in Mexico. title: A Stroll Across the Sun
description: If you didn't know that the ''transit of Venus'' is a celestial event -- as Venus, the second planet in the solar system, passes between Earth and the Sun -- you might understandably suppose that it was the name of some human life passage, like the entrance into puberty, perhaps, or the exit from same. Even as celestial events go, this is one of the plainest: a tiny black speck will cross the Sun's disk in six hours, from early this morning until about 7:26 a.m., Eastern time. This is not the stuff of summer blockbusters, just the coincidence of being where we are, when we are: Venus, Earth and the Sun. The next coincidence like this will be eight years hence.

title: Colorado Republicans Lose Redistricting Effort
description: The battle over a new Congressional map for Colorado, one of the country's most closely watched redistricting cases, ended Monday in a Democratic victory at the Supreme Court. Falling one vote short, the justices refused to hear the Colorado Republicans' appeal of a state high court ruling that invalidated an unusual second redistricting plan the Republicans had pushed through the legislature in the closing days of its 2003 session.

description: BAKALAR--Alan. 83, of New York City, died peacefully on June 6, 2004. Husband, father, and grandfather, World War II Army Air Corps pilot, quiet benefactor of many personally known and unknown to him. His steady presence will be sorely missed by Ruth,his wife of 62 years; his sons Jake, Nick, and Kenny; his daughters - in - law Susan, Francine, and his grandchildren Elizabeth, Dana, and Matthew.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Textile Concern Cedes Control
description: The struggling chemicals and textile conglomerate Cydsa has agreed to an exchange of debt for equity that will hand control of the company to creditors. Cydsa, which is based in Monterrey, has struggled for years against foreign competition and has built up debt of almost $400 million. Fintech Advisory, a trader of distressed debt, will exchange $159 million of Cydsa notes it holds for 60 percent of the company's shares and an additional $25.5 million in new debt due in 2007. Cydsa's chairman and chief executive, Toms Gonzlez Sada, will remain in his post. Fintech's managing director, David Martnez, said, however, that Cydsa would sell assets, eliminate most corporate overhead costs and appoint a new board. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHRIVER, DENTON A.
description: SHRIVER--Denton A., 80, died June 6, 2004, at Paoli Memorial Hospital from a sudden illness. Born on Staten Island, NY, son of Anna Fowler Shriver of Haverstraw, NY and Alfred Shriver, a founding partner of Morgan Stanley, Denton graduated from Yale University and Harvard Law School. From 1953 until 1967 Denton served as General Counsel and Executive Vice President of Vanadium Corporation of America. In 1968, Denton moved to the Philadelphia area to take a position as Vice President and Secretary of Safeguard Scientific where he worked until his retirement in 1982. He brought his family together at his first love, Merriewold, his summer home inthe Catskills. He was also an accomplished gardener, enjoyed writing short stories and visiting England. He was the devoted husband of Joan Grant Shriver, deceased, and is survived by his siblings: Nancy Shriver Hahn and Donald Shriver, children: Gifford Shriver, Anne Shriver, Susan Jankus, Kimberly Cameron, Alexander Shriver, and eight grandchildren. There will be a service at Mauger/Givnish Funeral Home, 24 Monument Ave., Malvern, PA on Wednesday, June 9, 2004 at 3 p.m. Memorial donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

Loving sister of Harry Serulneck of Framingham, MA, Kenneth Serulneck of Staten Island, NY & Jacqueline Schoenbloom of NYC. Cherished aunt of many nieces and nephews. Porto's savvy, English-speaking coach, the 41-year-old Jose Mourinho, has left for the riches and tumult of the English Premier League. Last week, he replaced Claudio Ranieri at Chelsea.

title: OWENS CORNING REACHES ACCORD WITH CREDITORS
description: The Owens Corning Corporation, the insulation maker, has reached an agreement with asbestos claimants, bondholders and suppliers on a bankruptcy recovery plan. Under the accord, bondholders, bank lenders and suppliers would be paid about 38.5 percent of the $3.2 billion they are owed. Asbestos creditors, owed an estimated $16 billion, would be paid cash and new shares to settle existing and future claims, according to papers filed yesterday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. The accord, a milestone in Owens Corning's 44-month effort to resolve its liabilities and exit bankruptcy protection, must be approved by a federal bankruptcy judge and a federal district judge. description: Wheaton River Minerals, the gold and copper producer, based in Vancouver, has rejected a $2.1 billion takeover offer by Coeur d'Alene Mines of Idaho, urging its shareholders instead to approve a proposed share exchange with the Iamgold Corporation of Toronto. Wheaton River said yesterday that a deal with Coeur d'Alene, a major silver producer, would not achieve Wheaton's goal of widening its exposure to gold. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Last Chechen Refugee Camp Closes
description: After years of political and economic pressure that at times amounted to intimidation, Russian officials have ordered the closing of the last of several sprawling tent camps in Ingushetia where refugees from Chechnya lived after fighting erupted in 1999, according to officials and television reports. The tent camps, some housing thousands of refugees, have been an embarrassment for Russia, though officials have denied forcibly resettling Chechens. At least 170 families remained at the last camp, called Satsita, until the regional government issued its decree ordering them to leave, saying they would no longer receive aid, according to Tamerlan Akiyev of the human rights organization Memorial. ''There was no violence, no force used to make people go,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''Former refugees are leaving for Chechnya not because they want to,'' he added, ''but because there is no choice.'' According to official numbers that some believe to be understated, tens of thousands of Chechens remain in Ingushetia, living in private homes or makeshift housing. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Fitting Tribute to Mr. Reagan
description: The death of Ronald Reagan is a poignant reminder of the devastation wrought by Alzheimer's disease, an incurable neurological illness that robs patients of their memories and ultimately takes their lives. Our hearts go out to Nancy Reagan, who watched her husband slip away over the past decade to a place where she could no longer reach him. We hope that when the tributes are done and the former president is laid to rest on Friday, she will renew her efforts to eliminate restraints on embryonic stem cell research, perhaps the most promising route toward cures for Alzheimer's and other devastating ailments. It would be a fine tribute to her husband's memory.

Lawrance, Jr. of Redding, CT. The draft is expected to win the approval of the court-appointed panel, which will oversee changes to the state's child welfare system. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Fujitsu And Samsung Settle Patent Dispute
description: The Japanese electronics giant Fujitsu and Samsung SDI of South Korea settled a dispute over patent rights for plasma display panels. The agreement should lead to the resumption of imports into Japan of Samsung's displays. Imports were halted in April after Fujitsu filed suits in Japan and the United States claiming that Samsung SDI, 20 percent of which is held by Samsung Electronics, violated Fujitsu patents on basic technologies used in the production of plasma display panels, the crucial component in flat-panel plasma televisions. The companies refused to disclose the terms of their agreement but said they would drop competing lawsuits over patent rights. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: A Manhattan assemblyman said yesterday that any third grader at risk of being held back under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's new policy on school promotions should be screened for learning disabilities. Parents will learn as early as this week whether their children passed the third-grade reading and math tests that will be the basis for promotion. The assemblyman, Steven Sanders, left, the chairman of the Assembly's Education Committee, said, ''Whether it's 12,000 or 13,000 or 14,000 kids the city is holding back, some significant percentage are failing because they have some kind of physical or cognitive disability.'' An Education Department spokeswoman, Eileen Murphy, responded, ''Our judgment is that we do a good job of detecting learning disabilities right now.'' Ashlei N. Stevens (NYT)

title: MEMO PAD
description: MORE SEATS IN THE AIR -- Domestic airline capacity rose significantly in May, and with all the extra seats in the skies, some carriers were unable to keep their planes as full as they had been in May 2003. JetBlue Airways reported one of the biggest increases in capacity: a 43.5 percent gain compared with May 2003. But JetBlue's load factor, the percentage of available seats sold, dropped 3.1 percentage points, to 81.8 percent. American Airlines' capacity was up 9.7 percent; its load factor dropped 0.5 percentage points, to 73.1 percent. At Delta Air Lines, capacity rose 19.1 percent, but the load factor fell 0.4 point, to 73.9 percent. Continental Airlines increased capacity by 13.8 percent; load factor fell 1.2 points, to 74.7 percent.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: New Supervisor For Elections

Ms. Roberts, 41, will take over on June 15 and will oversee the first presidential election in Florida since the overhaul of the voting system after the 2000 election. Mr. Kast, 53, who is leaving the department after 10 years, said he wanted to pursue other interests. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

All are invited. The family will have an East Coast celebration of her life on Sunday July 18. Call Roberta at 309-699-5246 for details.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Pharmaceutical Acquisition
description: The Swiss pharmaceuticals group Novartis said that it had agreed to buy Sabex Holdings, a privately held generic drug maker based in Boucherville, Quebec, for $565 million. Sabex, which is controlled by RoundTable Healthcare Partners, a private equity firm based in Lake Forest, Ill., specializes in generic versions of injectable medications and suppositories. Its sales totaled $90 million last year. Novartis cited prospects for rapid growth in Sabex's business in the United States, where patents on many injectable brand-name drugs are due to expire over the next few years. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Emotions That Overflow Their Small Packages
description: Small-scale dances were filled with grandly scaled emotions in the works Pascal Benichou and Company presented on Friday night at the Theater for the New City.

title: Suggestion of Anti-Semitism Colors House Primary in Virginia
description: Voters in Northern Virginia have considerable acquaintance with Representative James P. Moran's controversial remarks and erratic behavior, but they have kept him in office since he first ran for the House in 1990. This year, that loyalty may be tested.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor To Attend Reagan Funeral
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would attend the funeral of former President Ronald Reagan in Washington on Friday. "Whether you're a Democrat, Republican, an independent, this is a city that understands quality people, and Ronald Reagan was one of them," Mr. Bloomberg said. Earlier, during a news conference in Queens, Mr. Bloomberg said that there was ''nothing partisan'' about the former Republican president. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Coalition Forces Free Italian and Polish Hostages
description: ROME, June 8  Coalition forces stormed a hideout south of Baghdad today, freeing three Italian security guards who had been taken hostage in Iraq on April 12 and a Polish businessman abducted there last week, officials said.

title: Karzai Shows He'll Cast Lot With a Corps Of Warlords
description: President Hamid Karzai has accepted the support of powerful mujahedeen leaders for the presidential elections scheduled for September, indicating he will continue an alliance with them in a future government. His move has dismayed many Afghans who were hoping that the nation's first democratic elections would herald an end to the power of the warlords, who have dominated politics for the past decade.

title: Cannons Echo as Washington Drills for Reagan's State Funeral
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 - Howitzers positioned across Constitution Avenue from the Capitol boomed Tuesday as Army artillery crews rehearsed for the 21-gun salute that will herald the arrival Wednesday of Ronald Reagan's body to the Capitol Rotunda, where he will lie before the first state funeral in Washington in 31 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHHEIMER, IVY
description: RICHHEIMER--Ivy. The Merrick Jewish Centre mourns the passing of our dear member Ivy Richheimer, and extends heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband Alan, children Todd, Evan, Brett, sister Wendy Jacobs, and brother Lloyd Hersch. We pray they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Linda Altman, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the closing of the Drake Business School chain in New York City after the shooting of its chief executive, David C. Hart, misstated his age. The error also appeared in an article on May 25 about the shooting, at a subway station in Queens. Mr. Hart is 55, not 54.

title: 9 Iraqi Militias Are Said to Approve a Deal to Disband
description: American and Iraqi officials said Monday that they had won commitments from nine of the country's largest militias to disband, but there were immediate indications that the agreement might be difficult to enforce.

title: Stewart's Sentencing Delayed As Lawyers Seek New Trial
description: The sentencing of Martha Stewart will be postponed until next month while a federal judge considers whether she and her former stockbroker should have a new trial based on the testimony of a government witness who has been accused of lying.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON VANCE CORP., Boston, a money manager, said it agreed to buy Deutsche Bank's Scudder Private Investment Counsel, Boston, which provides investment advice and services to high-net-worth individuals and institutions for an undisclosed amount, thereby adding roughly $2.5 billion in assets to the $85.1 billion it manages.

title: No Tie to Rwanda Crash Seen in U.N. Tape
description: An independent investigation has concluded that an airplane black box shipped from Africa a decade ago and discovered this year in a locked United Nations file cabinet was not linked to the crash in 1994 that killed the presidents of Rwanda and Burundi and set off the massacre of hundreds of thousands of Rwandans.

title: Annual Cancer Conference Becomes Laboratory for Stocks
description: Shares of the biotechnology company ImClone Systems jumped Monday as investors responded to better-than-expected results of a study of its Erbitux cancer drug that were reported over the weekend at the annual cancer-care conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AHRENDT, CHARLOTTE
description: AHRENDT -- Charlotte on June 3rd, 2004. Former administrator at Alexander's Dept Store. Daughter of the late Charles and Florence. Interment services private. Further inquiries may be addressed to The Andrett Funeral Home, NYC.

description: he Ups and Downs of Raising a Bipolar Child: A Survival Guide for Parents," by Judith Lederman and Candida Fink, M.D., Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $14.

title: Man Is Shot to Death Near Prospect Park
description: A man was shot and killed last night in Brooklyn near Prospect Park, the police and witnesses said.

title: Court Says New Paltz Mayor Can't Hold Gay Weddings
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday permanently barred the mayor of New Paltz, N.Y., from conducting same-sex marriages without licenses, stressing the importance of public officials' obeying even those laws that they consider unjust.

title: World Briefing | Asia: High-Level India-Pakistan Talks
description: The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan will hold direct talks on the sidelines of a regional conference next month in Islamabad, the Pakistani Foreign Ministry said. It will be the first visit by an Indian official to Pakistan since a new government was elected in May. Both Pakistan and the new Indian government have vowed to carry on with the peace process begun in December. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: LAWYERS DECIDED BANS ON TORTURE DIDN'T BIND BUSH
description: A team of administration lawyers concluded in a March 2003 legal memorandum that President Bush was not bound by either an international treaty prohibiting torture or by a federal antitorture law because he had the authority as commander in chief to approve any technique needed to protect the nation's security.

title: Gore's Venting Stirs Up Senate Race in Florida
description: No one who follows South Florida's tangled politics expected Al Gore to endorse Alex Penelas, the mayor of Miami-Dade County and one of four Florida Democrats running for the Senate. But when Mr. Gore attacked the mayor last weekend as ''the single most treacherous and dishonest person I dealt with'' in the 2000 presidential campaign, even the most blas politicos gasped.

title: Thatcher to Attend Funeral
description: Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who shared an unbending ideology and a deep friendship with Ronald Reagan, is to deliver a recorded tribute to the former president at his funeral on Friday, her office said Monday.

title: Forced Nudity of Iraqi Prisoners Is Seen as a Pervasive Pattern, Not Isolated Incidents
description: In the weeks since photographs of naked detainees set off the abuse scandal at Abu Ghraib, military officials have portrayed the sexual humiliation captured in the images as the isolated acts of a rogue night shift.

title: Key Energy Services Gets Default Notice
description: Key Energy Services, an oilfield services company being investigated by federal securities regulators, said yesterday that it had received a notice of default on most of its debt, setting off a 10 percent decline in its share price.

title: Kidd Could Miss First Part of Season
description: Jason Kidd spent the afternoon on the golf course on Monday, a day before a series of basketball workouts to determine whether he will need knee surgery that could force him to miss the start of next season.

title: Justices Allow Suit Against Austria to Regain Art
description: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the 88-year-old niece and heir of an Austrian Jewish art collector can pursue her lawsuit against the Austrian government and its national art gallery for the return of six paintings by Gustav Klimt that belonged to her family before the Nazi takeover.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: On The Noisy Road To Ruin
description: Archbishop Sean Brady, the head of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland and Northern Ireland, is questioning the changes brought about by the country's rapid modernization, saying that many people are asking, ''Has Ireland lost its soul?'' and ''Have we thrown out the best of the old for the worst of the new?'' During a sermon at an abbey in County Kilkenny on Sunday, Dr. Brady said that ''an alienation from life itself'' had led to an increase in violence and suicides,'' and he urged people to turn off the ''constant noise'' and ''ceaseless chatter'' of stereos, televisions and cellphones one day each week to regain a sense of well-being. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: Of all the words written upon the death of Ronald Reagan, none have recurred more frequently than ''optimist.'' Reagan had a sunny, hopeful disposition, we've been reminded again and again.

description: FRANK ROBINSON won baseball's Triple Crown in 1966 and declined to talk about his feat 38 years later.

description: KONIGSBERG--Natalie. Five years have passed without you. We miss your special warmth, wit, style and kindness. Lovingly remembered by Fran, Marty, Don, Jane, Roz and Bob.

title: The Wrong Proliferation Message
description: As the world's strongest nuclear and conventional power, America should want to freeze weapons development and halt nuclear proliferation. Yet the Bush administration's proposed military budget moves in a different and more dangerous direction by seeking a sharp increase in the funds for research on two new kinds of nuclear bombs. The Senate should halt this reckless folly by voting next week for an amendment sponsored by Senators Edward Kennedy and Dianne Feinstein.

title: Innovative Buffalo Conductor Leads Her Troops to Carnegie
description: Regional American orchestras used to be a bigger part of Carnegie Hall's programming. The Buffalo Philharmonic, for example, appeared at the hall 20 times from its first performance, in 1967, to its most recent, in 1988. On Sunday the orchestra finally returned, with its current music director, JoAnn Falletta, but Carnegie didn't even put it on. The orchestra presented itself.

title: Chip Maker Narrows Sales Forecast For Quarter
description: Texas Instruments, whose semiconductors run more than half the cellphones sold last year, narrowed its second-quarter sales forecast yesterday and said demand for its products was ''slightly exceeding'' projections.

title: Genital Cutting Shows Signs of Losing Favor in Africa
description: Isnino Shuriye still remembers the pride she felt years ago when she leaned over each of her three daughters, knife in hand, and sliced into their genitals.

title: Dow Jumps 148 in Broad Rally Spurred by Jobs Data
description: Stocks rose yesterday, sending benchmark indexes to six-week highs, on optimism that employment growth will bolster the economy.

title: Catcher Is Only 17, But Yanks See Potential
description: Jon Poterson stood at home plate at Yankee Stadium 12 days ago and felt as if he were at home again. Poterson, who was born on Long Island and lived there until his family moved when he was 10, crushed batting-practice pitches into the third deck in right field, and it was the thrill of his life.

title: Ground Zero Decision Expected
description: A meeting of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation this week is expected to produce a decision on a cultural component for the World Trade Center site, people involved in the process say. They said the main candidates were the Joyce Theater, which presents dance; the Signature Theater Company; and a Museum of Freedom. Other groups expected to provide programming on the site are the New York Hall of Science in Queens and the Drawing Center, which exhibits historical and contemporary drawings. The decision would bring to a close a competition among cultural institutions that began a year ago with an invitation to arts groups worldwide. The invitation brought 113 proposals in September, which were narrowed to 15 finalists in February. The board of the development corporation is to make its decision in coordination with the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITHIES, DOLORES CYNTHIA
description: SMITHIES--Dolores Cynthia. Beloved mother, daughter, sister, grandmother, and godmother; patron of the arts, and friend to many, died peacefully at her home in Key Biscayne after a long illness. She was 65 years old, and surrounded by her children. Born in Bryn Mawr, PA, and raised in Havana, Cuba, Mrs. Smithies divided her time between Miami, New York and Gstaad, Switzerland, where she will be laid to rest. She will be rememberd for her devotion to helping others including underprivileged families, children with AIDS, and Cuban refugees. In her later years, she sponsored young artist from Cuba and other Latin American countries. Mrs. Smithies is survived by her four children, Andre, Sergei, Natasha, and Sasha; her mother Gladys, her brother John, her granddaughter Anastasia, her daughter-in-law Sandra and her godchildren. ''Dollsie'' will be missed and always in our hearts. Her generosity, joiede-vivre, beauty and elegance will stay with us forever. Funeral Mass will be held at St. Agnes Church in Key Biscayne, Thursday June 10 at 10 am. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Miami Art Museum, the IRC, or the GHHC.

title: Wal-Mart Sales in Range
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, said yesterday that June sales would reach the low end of the expectation range of 4 to 6 percent higher than last year.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN REACHES TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH UNION
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the major military shipbuilder, averted a strike at a shipyard that builds nuclear-powered aircraft carriers for the Navy by reaching a tentative agreement with the local union. Northrop would raise wages of workers at the Newport News shipyard in Virginia by more than 15 percent over the four-year life of the contract and set up a company-matching 401(k) plan for hourly workers under the accord, the company said. The labor agreement with United Steelworkers of America Local 8888 is the first negotiated with the union since Northrop acquired Newport News for $2.6 billion in 2002. Members will vote on the accord on Wednesday, the union's president, Alton Glass, said. Northrop is based in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Is Now Pursuing Americans Who Commit Sex Crimes Overseas
description: One suspect was a convicted pedophile from Baltimore accused of molesting boys in two Asian countries. Another was a doctor from Georgia who the Russian police said drugged his young victims in a St. Petersburg hotel. A third was a retired Army sergeant from Seattle who may have molested up to 50 children.

title: 'Swan Lake' Moves Inside, Dcor by Degas
description: Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov knew best when they choreographed their version of Tchaikovsky's ''Swan Lake'' in 1895. But among those who insist on departing from that touchstone original, Christopher Wheeldon can now lay claim to one of the most compelling alternative versions with his new staging of ''Swan Lake'' for the Pennsylvania Ballet.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Raw Sewage Closes District Attorney's Office
description: Staff members for the Orleans Parish district attorney evacuated their office after raw sewage backed up in it. The New Orleans Health Department found the building ''unsafe for human habitation,'' said the problem had been going on since May 7 and ordered it vacated until repairs could be made. A spokeswoman for District Attorney Eddie Jordan said the office would temporarily move to Israel M. Augustine Middle School. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Zoran To Buy Emblaze Chip Unit
description: The Emblaze Group is selling its semiconductor business to the Zoran Corporation for $54.2 million to raise cash and better enable the two companies to develop next-generation mobile handsets with video and other features. Zoran will pay cash for Emblaze Semiconductor and will take any intercompany loans outstanding in the unit, Emblaze, which is based in Ra'anana, Israel, said in an e-mailed statement. Emblaze Mobile, the handset division of Emblaze, will be a ''strategic'' customer of Zoran for applications devices, and will purchase chipsets and other components from it.

description: The ideas about how to memorialize Ronald Reagan are flowing in, creating ticklish situations for certain Democrats on Capitol Hill who are rushing to praise the former president  even though they loathed some of his policies.

title: Another Surprising Finish In Paris
description: The day after this year's French Open ended, the flags of many nations, including Argentina's and Russia's, still fluttered above the center court. But where there had been roars from the crowd, forehands and backhands, drama and tears (so many tears), there was now only the hiss of a warm breeze and the occasional rustling of papers as four workmen stuffed discarded programs into plastic bags.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: NextWave Seeks Sale Of 6 Licenses
description: NextWave Telecom, a cellphone company, sought bankruptcy court permission to raise money by selling its licenses in six cities in the United States. The licenses cover airwaves in New York; Denver; Portland, Ore.; Tampa; Sarasota, Fla.; and Tulsa, Okla., NextWave said yesterday on its Web site. The auction would be July 8. NextWave could raise about $1 billion from the sale, a Tejas Securities analyst, Igor Volshteyn, said. The company plans to use about $440 million to pay the Federal Communications Commission and will use ''several hundred million'' dollars to pay other creditors, a spokesman, Michael Wack, said. The company, based in Greenwich, Conn., sought Chapter 11 protection in June 1998 after it was unable to pay the F.C.C. for licenses won in auctions in the preceding two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMSON, RUTH, M.D.
description: ABRAMSON--Ruth, M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague. A pillar of the Mount Sinai community for more that 40 years, Dr. Abramson was a clinician, researcher, administrator, teacher, mentor and a role model to all. Her passion for scholarship and commitment to medical excellence inspired the hundreds of young physicians she trained in the specialty of renal disease. In 1997 The Mount Sinai Alunmi presented its most coveted award the Jacobi Medallion to Dr. Abramson in acknowledgment of her outstanding professional achievements and her extraordinary service to the Medical Center and the alumni. Our sincere condolences are extended to her family. William G. Stein, M.D. President Barry D. Stimmel, M.D. Vice President Elliot J. Rayfield, M.D. Secretary Betty J. Mintz, M.D. Treasurer

Dr. Fleischmajer was an outstanding teacher and mentor and will be sorely missed.

title: D-Day / 60 YEARS LATER: Sacrifices in Normandy live on in the European memory
description: Whenever I think of D-Day, it is not some Normandy beach that springs to mind but a peaceful French village about 15 kilometers inland. It is a pretty place called Fontaine-Henry, its houses built of a warm golden stone, and on one side of the village green a memorial to the dead of World War I. On the other there is a picture-postcard chateau, and next to it, the church. Walk through the gate and up the steps, turning left at the top. Underneath the yew tree, if you look closely, you will see that the churchyard wall is pitted with scars.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Write-Down At Wine Unit
description: The beverage group Foster's Limited said it would write down the value of its United States wine operation, Beringer Blass Wine Estates; cut expenses at the unit; and increase marketing efforts as it deals with a surplus of wine. The chief executive, Trevor O'Hoy, left, said Foster's would write down 300 million Australian dollars ($212 million), cut spending by 60 million Australian dollars and cut capital investment by 40 percent a year for five years. Beringer, which was bought by Foster's in 2000 had a 28 percent decline in earnings in the second half of 2003. The winery is in St. Helena, Calif. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITHIES, DOLORES
description: SMITHIES -- Dolores. The Board of Directors and staff of the International Rescue Committee are saddened by the death of Dolores Smithies, a valued member of our Board since 1969. Dolores was a tireless advocate and fundraiser for the cause of refugee relief and resettlement. She was especially devoted to assisting those who fled Cuba and came to the United States in search of freedom. We will miss Dolores deeply, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Winston Lord and James C. Strickler Co-Chairmen John C. Whitehead Chairman Emeritus George Rupp, President

title: D-Day / 60 YEARS LATER: Out of the night sky like phantoms:Sainte-Mre-Eglise remembers
description: SAINTE-MERE-EGLISE, France  Sixty years is a long time, especially when measured in the seasonal rhythms of the Normandy countryside, of horses foaling and apples to be picked and pressed into cider. But for the elderly residents of this ancient village, at least for the handful of hardy survivors old enough to remember, the events of D-Day are so vivid they seem to have happened only a decade or so ago.

title: Black and White, but Not Cut and Dried
description: The cookie that Nancy Thompson makes at Breadzilla, her bakery and takeout shop in Wainscott on the South Fork of Long Island, is not your Jerry Seinfeld black-and-white. It is rich and sumptuous, and instead of a glaze, it has slathers of fudgy chocolate frosting and vanilla butter cream. ''I never liked the sweet glaze with chocolate that never tasted like chocolate on a typical black-and-white,'' Ms. Thompson said. ''I decided to make one I could eat.'' The base is a generous, soft Pennsylvania Dutch sugar cookie, from a family recipe of her partner and former husband, Brad Thompson. The cookies are $3 at the shop, 84 Wainscott Northwest Road.

description: The country's top two airlines have asked the government for approval to raise their international fares by 5 percent to help them offset rising fuel costs. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fort Drum: Karzai Thanks Troops
description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan visited Fort Drum, in northern New York, yesterday to give his personal thanks to soldiers of the 10th Mountain Division for their role in Afghanistan. President Karzai, who was on his way to the Group of 8 summit meeting in Georgia, requested the visit, which was the first ever to the base by a foreign head of state. During a 10-minute speech, he read the names of 11 soldiers from the division who had died in Afghanistan, and later attended the awarding of a Silver Star and Purple Heart to Specialist Victor Thibeault. While in Kandahar, Afghanistan, the soldier had grabbed a grenade that was tossed into his vehicle and shoved it under his seat rather than throw it out into a crowded marketplace. ''We are moving toward lasting stability and democracy,'' Mr. Karzai told about 1,000 soldiers. ''And all of this would not have been possible without your help.'' Michelle York (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of Canada left its overnight interest rate unchanged at 2 percent, ending a series of rate cuts over the last 14 months aimed at stimulating the domestic economy. The central bank said growth was in line with expectations but the sharp rise in oil prices could push up inflation. Most analysts expect the bank to start raising interest rates later this year. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Market Share Drops
description: Nokia's market share fell in the first quarter to the lowest in about five years as consumers picked clamshell phones with cameras made by Motorola and Samsung Electronics, the researcher Gartner said yesterday. The global market share of Nokia, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, dropped to 28.9 percent from 34.6 percent a year earlier, losing ground to all its competitors, Ben Wood, an analyst at Gartner's British office, said. Motorola's market share rose to 16.4 percent from 14.7 percent, and Samsung's share reached 12.5 percent from 10.8 percent. Nokia's stock has fallen by a third since April 6, when the company, based in Espoo, Finland, said first-quarter sales fell 2 percent. It had earlier predicted rising sales. Nokia's sales rose 12 percent, to 44.2 million handsets in the quarter from 39.5 million, slower than the overall 34 percent market growth to 153 million handsets, Gartner said. A Nokia spokeswoman, Arja Suominen, declined to comment on the figures.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNILEVER, Rotterdam, the Netherlands, the world's largest manufacturer of food and soap, said it is selling its approximately $46 million stake in Elizabeth Arden Inc., severing its last ties to the No.2 perfume maker in America. The stake is about 2.32 million shares. The offering's manager, Morgan Stanley, will sell an additional 231,793 shares if there is demand.

title: Changing of Guard at the Volatile Paris Opera
description: At first glance, director of the Paris National Opera is a job to be envied. The institution, which dates back to 1669, has two large theaters as well as a permanent chorus, a 174-member orchestra and a top-flight ballet company, all supported by a hefty government subsidy. But there is also a caveat. Its 1,600 employees are led by Communist-backed labor unions with a penchant for last-minute strikes and low-intensity class warfare.

title: Report Says Aid to Weak States Is Inadequate
description: Even though the Bush administration has identified failed states for acting as breeding grounds for terrorists, it is doing very little to improve those countries and reduce the risk they pose to national security, according to a report released on Tuesday.

title: Sopranos Score In Finale
description: ''The Sopranos'' on HBO proved a powerful audience draw against very strong competition on Sunday night, matching up well even with Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals on ABC. Even though HBO is available in less than a third of the homes that the broadcast networks are, ''The Sopranos'' drew just under 11 million viewers, second to the 13.4 million who watched the game between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Detroit Pistons at that hour. (The game was not on against ''The Sopranos'' on the West Coast because it was shown there live at 6 p.m.) NBC's ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent,'' meanwhile, drew 9.5 million viewers, and the Tony Awards on CBS attracted 6.3 million, according to Nielsen Media Research. BILL CARTER

description: The police arrested 33 demonstrators outside an international conference on biotechnology at the Moscone Convention Center in San Francisco. Most were cited for blocking traffic, the police said, but five were arrested on felony counts. About 18,000 scientists, industry experts and government officials are attending the weeklong conference of the Biotechnology Industry Organization. The police said about 1,000 people marched against the use of genetically modified organisms, cloning and biotechnological drugs. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Minister Quits In Brothel Scandal
description: President Alejandro Toledo, buffeted by the lowest popularity ratings in Latin America, lost his seventh cabinet minister since November when the agriculture minister, Jos Len Rivera, resigned after news reports that underage prostitutes worked in a hotel owned by the minister's son. Struggling to maintain control of his country, Mr. Toledo has seen seven ministers resign under pressure in the past six months over a range of charges leveled by his political foes, everything from influence peddling to the inability to quell protesters who lynched a mayor in southeastern Peru. Juan Forero (NYT)
