title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deployment Of High-Speed Systems Rises
description: Deployment of high-speed Internet lines to homes and businesses accelerated during the second half of 2003, rising by 20 percent, compared with an increase in adoption of 18 percent during the first half of the year, according to statistics released yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. By the end of the year, some 28.2 million high-speed lines served homes and businesses, up from 19.9 million lines at the beginning of 2003, according to the agency. During the latter half of 2003, there was a 24 percent increase in the adoption of D.S.L., a high-speed technology provided by telephone companies. Adoption of cable modem service, provided by cable companies, rose 20 percent during that period. By the end of 2003, 16.4 million homes had cable modem service while 9.5 million had D.S.L. service, according to the F.C.C. statistics. Matt Richtel (NYT)

description: THE hulking, cone-shaped stainless steel tanks in this Brooklyn warehouse loom like missiles, but only a paranoid teetotaler could mistake their contents for weapons of mass destruction. What the tanks actually contain are ales and lagers, tens of thousands of gallons of the golden liquids, all patiently fermenting inside a former Borden's dairy plant reincarnated as a birthplace for adult beverages far more sophisticated than milk.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Chief Predicts Profit Increase
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's second-largest computer maker, will increase per-share profit more than 20 percent this year and ''the next couple'' as sales grow faster than the market, the chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, said yesterday. Ms. Fiorina reiterated a forecast for sales growth at a rate in the ''high single digits.'' The company sets plans on a two- and three-year basis, she said at a meeting with analysts in San Jose, Calif. Hewlett-Packard will increase revenue by winning more orders from existing clients, which today spend less than 10 percent of their total budgets on Hewlett-Packard products, Ms. Fiorina said. The company also wants to tap new markets including digital media, management software and security, she said. That creates a $1 trillion ''addressable market'' for the company, she added.

title: AVON SAYS QUARTERLY EARNINGS WILL BEAT FORECAST
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit would rise about 3 cents a share more than its earlier forecast because of lower tax expenses and higher sales in the United States and Europe. Profit will increase to 46 cents a share, Avon said. The average estimate of nine analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial was 43 cents. Avon earned 36 cents a year earlier. The company's effective tax rate may fall to 31 percent from 35 percent when tax strategies are put in place next year, Avon said. Sales are expected to rise 12 percent this quarter, as the company increases door-to-door sales staff and adds cosmetics lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEINIG, JOHN
description: HEINIG--John, of New York City and Millbrook, NY, died peacefully in the presence of his loving wife, Jean, on May 31, 2004, at the age of 90. Born in Berlin, he and his family left Germany in 1933 after his father, Kurt Heinig, a Social Democratic member of the Reichstag, refused to sign Hitler's Enabling Act at the risk of his life. After living in Paris during the 1930s he and his beloved first wife Hilde reached the U.S. in 1941. During World War II he served in the U.S. Army as an intelligence officer. After the war he worked for Roussel Uclaf in pharmaceutical sales and later for ZetaPharm. Hilde died in 1966 and in 1967 he married Jean Owen, who became a psychoanalyst. In 1973 they bought a property in Millbrook, where he spent many happy hours working in the woods. After his retirement at age 80 he enjoyed showing tourists around the city as a volunteer and tutoring non-English speakers. John was a modest but extraordinary man, who despite the difficult era he lived through, always looked forward to new experience and new possiblities in life. He was a man of great kindness, gentleness, integrity and devotion. John is survived by his beloved wife Jean, who will miss him beyond measure. He will also be greatly missed by his niece Karin Heinig, nephews Per & Mikael Heinig of Sweden, nephews Karsten & Jakob Bronnum of Denmark & 8 grandnieces & grandnephews. A private memorial gathering will be held on June 24.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Speaker Wants Hearing On Javits Center
description: The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, called yesterday for public hearings to examine Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to expand the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and further develop the West Side of Manhattan. The entire project is expected to cost over $7 billion, to be paid for with a combination of public and private money. In his proposal, Mr. Pataki suggested an extra 5 percent tax on car rentals at airports to help pay the cost. Mr. Silver said Mr. Pataki had provided little in the way of details, and that a hearing was therefore necessary. ''I have serious concerns regarding the massive financial investment called for under this proposal, as well as concerns about oversight and quality-of-life issues,'' Mr. Silver said. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Funeral Fit For A King
description: In a pageant-filled ceremony, French royalists installed a shriveled heart in a niche in the crypt of St.-Denis Basilica, hoping to put to rest 200 years of debate over the fate of Louis XVII, the son of the beheaded king and queen, Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. Many royalists believe the heart belonged to Louis XVII, and a DNA test of the heart four years ago confirmed that it came from a close relative of the executed queen. But controversy still swirls over whether Louis XVII died as a child or survived to adulthood. After the ceremony, monarchists shouted ''Long live the king!'' in support of the Duke of Anjou, Louis-Alphonse de Bourbon, one of several claimants to the French throne. But Charles Louis Edmond de Bourbon, the great grandson of a man who said he was the adult Louis XVII, insisted the ceremony was a sacrilege. Members of the Orlans family, who also claim rights of succession to the throne, were not invited. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 9 — Insurgents staged attacks on American forces and their allies on several fronts today, firing mortars at Iraqi militiamen west of here, setting two critical oil pipelines in the north ablaze and ambushing a military convoy in the capital.

title: Got Oil? Now, Try to Find Tankers to Carry It
description: Now that OPEC has agreed to raise its crude oil production quotas in hopes of taming high and jittery oil prices, industry experts are growing more concerned about both the capacity and the security of oil tankers, the next link in the supply chain.

title: Zimbabwe Announces A New Plan To Seize Land
description: Zimbabwe's land minister said Tuesday that the government intended to nationalize all farmland that it had not already confiscated under a contentious program of land seizures begun four years ago.

title: Drug Accusations Outlined Against 4 Elite Athletes
description: Tim Montgomery, the world's fastest man, and three other elite track athletes received official notification yesterday of potential drug violations that could result in their suspensions from the Athens Olympics.

title: Moving Beyond a Base in New York Office Leasing
description: Cushman & Wakefield, a national real estate services company based in New York, expects significant growth in its overseas operations in the next few years, according to Bruce E. Mosler, who will lead the company starting next year. International operations, which currently provide less than a third of the company's revenues, are expected to produce half within three years.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about a plan by Sheldon Silver, the New York Assembly speaker, to increase state aid to New York City schools misstated the amount of the proposed increase in some copies. It is about $4 billion over the next five years; $6 billion is the increase proposed for schools statewide.

title: New Service by TiVo Will Build Bridges From Internet to the TV
description: The Internet, in jumping past the personal computer and into the living room television set, is starting to give viewers the possibility of bypassing traditional cable and satellite services.

title: Project Aims for More Bustle in a Former Egg Capital
description: This former poultry town in the Sonoma Valley, 30 miles north of San Francisco, is unusual in that its downtown bustles on weekends and holidays but tends to be quiet at other times, because most of the jobs have moved to outlying areas.

title: Chinese Builder's Death Reveals Anonymous Web of Risky Labor
description: Yong Fa Cai did not know the man's name. He did not know what kind of construction experience the man had, either in New York or in his native Shanghai. All Mr. Cai knew was that the man had called his cellphone a few days ago, expressing interest in Mr. Cai's project to build a two-family house at 51-18 92nd Street in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Editorial Observer; A Russian migr Finally Gets His Russian Passport
description: After the grand ceremonies on the Normandy beaches on Sunday for the anniversary of D-Day, President Vladimir Putin was driven to the palatial Prefecture here for a series of meetings, and to hand my 83-year-old uncle his first passport.

title: Europe's Loss of Focus
description: PARIS  For Pierre Lellouche, a center-right French parliamentarian, there is one central factor behind European-American tensions: "Europe is going through a period of weakness and the less we weigh on history the more we rail against the power that determines history. The weaker we are, the more we hit out."

title: Market Place; SAP is looking mightier, not more vulnerable, after disclosures that it flirted with Microsoft.
description: AT the annual meeting of Deutsche Bank here last week, Henning Kagermann sat silently on the dais with other board members as a stream of shareholders voiced fears that the bank, Germany's largest, would be sold to a foreign predator.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Testing Voice-Over-Internet Service Overseas
description: AT&T has begun trials of its voice-over-Internet phone service in Asia and Europe for its business customers. The low-cost phone service, which uses high-speed Internet lines to connect calls, has already been rolled out in the United States. With the service overseas, customers will be able to dial internationally for a fraction of normal rates, as well as organize telephone conferences, check voice mail and forward calls. The trials will start during the third quarter in Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore and Britain. The company expects to introduce the service commercially next year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Qatar: Death Sought For Russians
description: Prosecutors are demanding the death penalty for two Russian security agents charged with the killing of a former Chechen rebel commander in Doha in February. The Chechen, Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, who was briefly the president of Chechnya, died when his car was blown up. Moscow has denied that the agents had any connection to the attack, but has acknowledged that they were engaged in anti-terrorist work in Qatar. A verdict is expected on June 30. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: A Cold Lunch, Easy on the Cook
description: IT is something of a clich that all women turn into their mothers. ''That is their tragedy,'' Oscar Wilde said.

title: 8 Leaders Welcome U.N. Backing for Iraq Transition
description: Surrounded by world leaders who sounded eager to put their bitter divisions on Iraq behind them, President Bush on Tuesday welcomed the adoption of a Security Council resolution on Iraq and said the nation was solidly on the road to democracy.

title: Nielsen Names Panel On Rating Changes
description: Nielsen Media Research in New York named the members of an independent task force yesterday to assess the changes the company is making in how it measures television ratings. The task force, which Nielsen had announced in April, is being formed in response to complaints that the changes would result in undercounting black and Hispanic viewers in markets like Chicago, Los Angeles and New York.

title: Will 'Sex and the City' Without the Sex Have Much Appeal?
description: Steven R. Koonin, the executive vice president of TBS, has a theory about ''Sex and the City,'' the hit HBO series scheduled to make its debut on Tuesday on his basic cable channel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLAGHER, MARY ANN (NEE O'SHEA)
description: GALLAGHER -- Mary Ann (nee O'Shea). Wife of 57 years to the late Thomas F. Gallagher, died on June 6 at her home in New Canaan, CT. Her three children were at her side. She graduated from Hunter College in 1939 and worked as a bacteriologist in Walter Reed Army Hospital during WW II. She is survived by her three children: Paul of Easton CT; Joan of New Canaan CT; Peter of NYC; and grandchildren Sarah, Timothy, Katherine, Caroline, James and Kathryn. Wake Hoyt Funeral Home, 190 Main St, New Canaan, CT, Wednesday June 9, 4-8pm. Funeral Mass at St. Aloysius R.C. Church, New Canaan, Thursday June 10, at 10am. Donations in her memory may be made to Alzheimers Association, NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, NY 10017.

title: NUCOR WILL BUY STEEL MILL IN ALABAMA FROM CORUS
description: The Nucor Corporation, a steel maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Corus Group's plate mill in Tuscaloosa, Ala., for $90 million. The acquisition will increase capacity at Nucor, which produced 17.4 million tons of steel last year, by 700,000 tons, or 4 percent. The transaction is expected to be complete in the third quarter, Corus said. Corus, a steelmaker based in London, sold the plant to focus on raw steel, which accounts for about 85 percent of its annual sales. Nucor is based in Charlotte, N.C.

description: SCHWARTZ--Edward R. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member and past president, Edward R. Schwartz. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, June and to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Richard J. Bronstein, Secy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, MIRIAM
description: LEVY--Miriam. Beloved wife of the late professor Naphtaly. Mother of Nicky Deitz, Rae Zachai, Jackie. Sister of Eli Klein (Israel) and Ruth Feust (Israel). Shiva at 461 Fort Washington Avenue until Sunday morning.

title: A Giants Assistant Has Cancer
description: Like all the Giants' coaches, their new offensive line coach, Pat Flaherty, had a routine physical provided by the team when he joined Tom Coughlin's staff. But the results were anything but routine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIVNICK, LEILA
description: PIVNICK--Leila. The Officers and Owners of Rentar Development Corp. mourn the passing of Leila Pivnick, beloved wife of Harold Pivnick, beloved mother of Susan Pivnick and Nancy Freedman and beloved grandmother of Olivia and Nicholas Freedman. We extend our sincere condolences to the family.

title: Hend Wins Final Spot at Qualifier
description: Scott Hend of Australia shot a par 3 yesterday on the sixth playoff hole in the United States Open sectional qualifying at Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit, N.J., to gain the final spot for the Open next week at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y. Twenty-one players qualified for 22 spots on Monday. The 10-man playoff for the final spot was halted because of darkness after four holes Monday night with five players still in contention. Hend and Matt Cannon of Huntersville, N.C., each birdied the opening playoff hole yesterday to become the lone survivors. On the next hole, Hend, who was third in the Bell Southwest Classic this year, made par and Cannon bogeyed. Bernie Beglane

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Serial Rapist Sought
description: The police appealed to the public last night for help in finding a man they believe has committed a string of sexual assaults in Brooklyn. The man, described by the police as black, in his 20's, who is 5-foot-8 to 5-foot-10 and weighs about 170 pounds, first struck on Thursday, when he raped and robbed a 17-year-old woman in the vicinity of Avenue J and the East 80's in Canarsie. The police believe the same man raped and robbed a 20-year-old woman early Saturday morning in the same area. In the most recent attack, he robbed and sexually abused an 18-year-old woman near Rockaway Parkway on Monday night, the police said. The man was last seen wearing a blue denim jacket, a red do-rag and a blue baseball cap. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Study Supports View That Ice Age Is Still Quite a Way Off
description: Despite the recent trend toward global warming, scientists have long wondered whether the earth was nearing another ice age  an end to the 12,000-year temperate spell in which modern civilizations arose. Some have said such a transition is overdue, given that each of Earth's three previous temperate intervals lasted only about 10,000 years.

title: Will the Kurds Go Home?
description: While the United Nations Security Council wrangled over military chains of command in Iraq and the violence in Arab cities like Karbala and Falluja grabbed the headlines, a story far more important to the country's future has been largely ignored: the growing unease of the Kurdish minority.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about celebrities' assistants misidentified one woman shown. She was Sheila Nevins, an executive at HBO, which held a film screening attended by assistants -- not Bonnie Kramen, an aide to the actress Olympia Dukakis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Plea In Stabbing
description: A man who was accused in November of fatally stabbing a co-worker in a fight over how to divide receipts from a discount bus service in Chinatown pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder and assault. The defendant, Lei Chen, 25, of Indianapolis, a partner in the bus company, argued with the 31-year-old victim, Zhen Ji Li, one of its drivers, as they stood at Pike and Henry Streets, then stabbed him nine times, the authorities said. An Immigration and Naturalization Service agent saw the two men struggling and held Mr. Chen at gunpoint until the police arrived. Sentencing is scheduled for July 20 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: The Rewards of the Pampered Grape
description: FROM a chalky slope high above this little hillside town, a patchwork of vineyards stretches as far as the eye can see, dotted occasionally with a thatch of trees or a cluster of buildings. Only the occasional rush of a high-speed TGV train interrupts the pastoral spell of this bowl-shaped valley in the Mconnais region of southern Burgundy. Lacking the drama of the impossibly steep vineyards of the Cte Rtie to the south or the allure of the exalted grand cru vineyards in the Cte d'Or to the north, the Mconnais has had to get by on the sort of quiet beauty that you see only when you look closely.

title: U.S. Military Contract Employee Is Shot Dead in Saudi Capital
description: An employee of an American contractor was shot dead on Tuesday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia's capital, the latest in a string of killings through which Al Qaeda or its sympathizers seem determined to try to drive foreigners from the kingdom.

title: Filling U.S. Roster Becomes an Adventure
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8 - The senior men's committee for USA Basketball met in Chicago on Monday night to discuss its dwindling national team.

title: Turbulence Shakes Boston As the Convention Nears
description: With six weeks to go before the Democratic National Convention starts in Boston, the city on Tuesday entered a new phase of convention-related disruption as picketing union members forced a delay in the start of renovations on the convention site and the transit authority said it would begin randomly inspecting passengers' bags on subway and commuter trains.

title: Hawaii Isn't Too Far to Cast a Fishing Line
description: Buying fish sight unseen can be risky. But Honolulu Fish, a 10-year-old restaurant supplier, now sells freshly caught fish from Hawaii to retail customers at www.honolulufish.com. Among them are buttery shutome (a swordfish), first-rate ahi (tuna) and meaty parrotfish with turquoise-flecked skin, which is excellent seared and then roasted. The fish arrives fresh, in superb condition -- better than in most stores. More than two dozen kinds of line-caught fish are shown on the Web site, with descriptions and cooking tips. Most of the fish come in portions of 1 1/2 to 2 pounds and cost, on average, $15 a pound, including overnight shipping. (Five pounds is the minimum order.) Wayne Samiere, a former marine biologist who owns the company, said he buys and ships 80,000 pounds of fish a day, adding that because he is the biggest FedEx customer in Hawaii, he gets bargain rates.

title: Dye Paints Subway, And a Robber Flees (Yes) Red-Handed
description: Ideally, the pack of dye that a bank teller slips into a robber's money bag explodes while the robber is in midflight, sending up an eye-catching puff of red smoke. This is exactly what happened to a robber in a subway station yesterday -- but with less than ideal results.

title: Poems Of Blood And Anger
description: If the world leaders at the G-8 summit meeting want to understand the war in Iraq, they should look beyond the war plans and U.N. resolutions. The most incisive analysis of war has often come from poets, like Homer or Wilfred Owen.

title: Car Bombs in 2 Iraqi Cities And Exploding Mines Kill At Least 18 More in Iraq
description: Car bombs exploded in two cities north of here on Tuesday morning, killing at least 11 Iraqis and an American soldier, military officials said. Dozens more were wounded.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a benefit peformance of the political satire ''Embedded'' attended by Lachlan Murdoch, publisher of The New York Post and a supporter of President Bush, misstated the nationality of his father, Rupert Murdoch, the media magnate, who also supports the president. Although born in Australia, he has been an American citizen since 1985.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERGER, EDWARD M.
description: GOLDBERGER--Edward M. of Tenafly, NJ, peacefully at home on June 8, 2004, age 87. Husband of Rhoda, father of Jane Tonia Widler and Peter David Goldberger. Grandfather of five. Award-winning radio scriptwriter, long time executive, Voice of America.

description: The Mars rover Spirit has dug up more evidence of water on the red planet, scientists said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIGUTOFF, FRANCES
description: WIGUTOFF--Frances, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Albert Wigutoff and daughter of the late Morris Nasin. Died on June 7, 2004, age 83. Survived by son Edwin (Sharon) and daughter Laura Tarlowe (Anthony), grandchildren Lisa, Jason and the late Dana and two great-grandchildren, Jared and Jillian. She will be missed and loved always. Services private.

title: In Mexico, Sugar vs. U.S. Corn Syrup
description: Along the sooty gangways and rickety catwalks of the Emiliano Zapata sugar mill, sweat-soaked workers operate presses, vats and ovens in a process that has changed little since the mill's first harvest in 1938.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mediation In Colombian Conflict
description: The government of President Vicente Fox has offered to serve as a mediator in the four-decade fight between Colombia's government and guerrillas. The offer was announced after the Mexican and Colombian foreign ministers conferred at an Organization of American States meeting in Ecuador. Both governments will seek ways that Mexico can serve as a go-between in negotiations toward a cease-fire. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Suffolk County Executive Says He Will Veto Capital Budget
description: A $200 million capital budget sailed through the Suffolk County Legislature on Tuesday and straight into a war over spending between legislators and the county executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBBINS, ESTHER CANELL
description: ROBBINS--Esther Canell, 92, on June 5, 2004. Predeceased by her husbands Jonas Canell (45 years) and Irving Robbins. Devoted mother of Roger (Elaine) Canell and Andy (Esther) Canell. Loving grandmother of Jay (Sari), Neil (Loren), Dina Cohen (Jason) and Ross. Adoring greatgrandmother of Jordan, Hayley, Dylan, Charlie, Emily and Jared. We will all miss her very much.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Jury Indicts Prep School Board
description: A grand jury has indicted the board of trustees at the prestigious Groton School on charges that members failed to report an accusation of sexual abuse to the state authorities. The board, charged as a whole, faces a $1,000 fine. Martha Coakley, the Middlesex County District Attorney, said the charge stemmed from a 1999 incident in which the parents of a 16-year-old student told school officials that their son said he had been sexually abused by other students, a charge Ms. Coakley's office said the school did not report to the authorities, as it was required to do. A Groton spokeswoman, Karen Schwartzman, said that the school had no reason to withhold a report and that the student did not provide the necessary details to prepare one. Ms. Schwartzman said the school reported three similar accusations of sexual assault to the authorities in 1999. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Acts on Corporate Shells
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for the first time suspended trading in shares of companies because they failed to file financial disclosure reports.

title: Holders' Group Shuns Argentine Debt Plan
description: The biggest bondholder group in Argentina boycotted a meeting on Tuesday with the government to discuss its latest offer to repay part of an estimated $100 billion in bad debt, saying the government's refusal to negotiate in good faith made the talks pointless.

title: Kerry Pays Respects to Reagan, but Takes a Swipe at Bush
description: On his way to pay his respects to Ronald Reagan, Senator John Kerry, his campaign otherwise suspended until the former president's funeral, nonetheless managed to take a swipe at President Bush for marginalizing Democrats in Congress and to highlight his own role in Mr. Reagan's history.

title: Shushing the Big City
description: Let's face it: New York City will never be quiet. Still, Mayor Michael Bloomberg and his administration are on the right track with a new ambitious noise ordinance. The city that never sleeps has long needed somebody to turn down the volume for those who occasionally do.

title: Microsoft Files an Appeal In European Antitrust Case
description: Microsoft said Tuesday that it had filed an appeal of the European antitrust ruling against it, saying that the regulators' remedies would undermine innovation. The company also said it would seek a suspension of the changes demanded by the commission.

title: Young Pitcher Tries to Keep the Past in the Past
description: Perhaps for once, Danny Almonte appears younger than his age.

title: Sports of The Times; Newark Should Step Back From Dance With Devils
description: THE hockey season ended Monday night, and no one can say if and when another will begin, certainly not the cheerleaders in Newark who are desperate to invest $210 million in the future of a niche sport that is skating on thin entrepreneurial ice.

title: Ohio State Coach Loses Job
description: Jim O'Brien, who coached the Ohio State men's basketball team the last seven years, was fired yesterday after the university said he gave $6,000 to a recruit five years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUSSMAN, ALBERT
description: SUSSMAN -- Albert. Died peacefully at home on June 8, 2004 after a long illness. Predeceased by his loving wife, Phyllis. Beloved father and grandfather of Bernard (Katherine), Daniel (Jill), Phyllis (Zachary), Rachel and Melanie. Executive VicePresident Emeritus, International Council of Shopping Centers. Funeral services on June 10 at 10 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 91st Street.

description: The Sun rose out of the ocean this morning with Venus clinging to it like a barnacle.

title: Game Maker Misses Earnings Target and Cuts 2004 Forecast
description: Financial disappointments continue to take a toll on Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the hit video game Grand Theft Auto. The company announced second-quarter earnings yesterday that were far below its own estimates and those of industry analysts.

title: As War Toll Rises, Governors Face Delicate Decisions
description: With bagpipes wailing, hundreds of mourners filed solemnly into a high school auditorium here on Sunday to honor Army Specialist Joseph Jeffries, 21, one of 18 Oregon soldiers killed over the last year in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Adelphia Witness Defends Big Cash Advances
description: Michael Mulcahey, the former assistant treasurer at the Adelphia Communications Corporation, testified yesterday that he never doubted that the company's founder, John Rigas, could repay cash advances of $1 million a month for expenses.

title: Man Charged In Decapitation Of Two Women in New Jersey
description: A man murdered his grandmother and the mother of his child yesterday and dismembered them in a home where the women lived in Ocean Township, N.J., the police said.

title: A Filmmaker Was Charmed By Her Notorious Subject
description: Ramona S. Diaz, who grew up in Manila and studied documentary filmmaking at Stanford, first met Imelda Marcos in 1993.

description: Increasing the pressure to obtain labor concessions, Delta Air Lines has told its employees that stiff competition and its own high costs mean its bid to avoid bankruptcy protection may not be under its control.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Body Found In Trunk Is Identified
description: The woman who was found in a trunk in the East Village on Sunday was identified yesterday as a homeless person with a history of drug arrests, according to the authorities. The police identified the woman as Myrna Gonzalez, 45, and said she had been arrested at least 18 times on drug-related charges. Her body was found about 4:25 p.m. Sunday when a homeless man stopped to inspect a trunk he saw in a large, weeded vacant lot on East 13th Street just east of Third Avenue. The trunk was wrapped with bungee cord, telephone wire and cable that he cut through. Neighbors said the trunk had been there for at least several hours. An autopsy determined that the woman had been strangled. Anyone with information about Ms. Gonzalez's death was asked to call the Crime Stoppers hotline at 1-800 577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Tears for a Soldier and Believer, Killed in Iraq
description: Sgt. Humberto F. Timoteo, one of four New Jersey National Guard soldiers killed in Iraq last weekend, was remembered by his family on Tuesday as a man who loved athletics, vacations and military life, but above all his wife and 2-year-old son.

title: Backup Steps Urged for Voting Machines
description: In a major sign of concern about electronic voting machines, a senior federal voting official recommended Tuesday that several backup measures be put in place before the November elections to try to inspire voter confidence in the machines.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Services Stake Acquired
description: An elec-tronics maker, Flextronics, said it would buy 55 percent of Hughes Software Systems from a unit of the News Corporation for $226 million to add software services to its products. Flextronics, which is based in Singapore and has offices in San Jose, Calif., agreed to pay 547 rupees ($12.15) a share for the stake, a 5 percent premium over the company's closing price on Monday. ''The piece that was missing in the puzzle was software services,'' Ash Bharadwaj, president for design services at Flextronics, said. Hughes Software has two development centers in India and one in Germany; it has 2,400 employees worldwide. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Ads of Both Campaigns Zero In on a Typical City
description: This city is considered to be so prototypically American that marketers have made it a major testing ground for products as divergent as Fat-Free Pringles and interactive television.

title: Recipe: Roast Chicken Salad
description: Time: 10 minutes

title: BURGER KING NAMES PRESIDENT FOR NORTH AMERICA
description: The Burger King Corporation named John Chidsey president of its North American business yesterday, less than four months after he was named chief financial and administrative officer. Mr. Chidsey, 42, will be in charge of franchise operations and marketing as well as the company's Canadian restaurants, Burger King said. He will continue to oversee the financial and information-technology departments on an interim basis. Mr. Chidsey was an executive at the Cendant Corporation before being named chief financial officer at Burger King in February. Burger King, based in Miami, is owned by the closely held investment firm Texas Pacific Group and partners.

title: Documents Build a Case for Working Outside the Laws on Interrogating Prisoners
description: JANUARY 2002 -- A series of memorandums from the Justice Department, many of them written by John C. Yoo, a University of California law professor who was serving in the department, provided arguments to keep United States officials from being charged with war crimes for the way prisoners were detained and interrogated. The memorandums, principally one written on Jan. 9, provided legal arguments to support administration officials' assertions that the Geneva Conventions did not apply to detainees from the war in Afghanistan.

title: Sneaky Moves on Tobacco
description: House Republicans are trying to slip through a measure that would provide almost $10 billion in buyout payments to tobacco growers in return for eliminating an outmoded price support system under which many of them are losing out to foreign competition anyway. The buyout is a bad idea in principle. Farmers should not be bribed every time Washington decides to end a subsidy program. But the particular buyout proposal being pushed through the House is especially harmful. It would use general revenues rather than tobacco industry funds to pay for the buyout, drive up the federal deficit and provide no role for the Food and Drug Administration to regulate tobacco.

title: Items That Could Make Illict Arms Gone From Iraq, U.N. Told
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 9  Equipment and material that could have been used to produce banned weapons and long-range missiles have been emptied from Iraqi sites since the war and shipped abroad, the head of the United Nations inspectors office told the Security Council today.

title: Stanley Cup Is in Florida, And the N.H.L. Is in Flux
description: As if they have not seen enough of each other the past two weeks, Martin St. Louis of Tampa Bay and Jarome Iginla of Calgary will face off again tomorrow night in another N.H.L. competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISCHMAJER, RAUL, MD.
description: FLEISCHMAJER--Raul, MD. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. Chairman of the Department of Dermatology for 17 years, Dr. Fleischmajer was highly respected, admired and recognized worldwide as a leading clinician and researcher. A devoted teacher and supportive mentor, he represented the best tradition of the medical center, exemplified by his dedication to teaching and commitment to clinical excellence. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. William G. Stein, MD, Pres. Barry D. Stimmel, MD, Vice Pres Elliot J. Rayfield, MD, Secy. Betty J. Mintz, MD, Treas.

title: Chinese Official Challenges U.S. Stance on North Korea
description: A senior Chinese official said Tuesday that he had doubts about the Bush administration's claim that North Korea had been trying to build nuclear bombs using uranium, and he urged the Bush administration to stop using the allegations to hold up nuclear talks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
description: The number of people unemployed rose slightly in May, and at a slower pace than expected, leaving the rate unchanged at 10.5 percent in seasonally adjusted terms. The Federal Labor Agency said the adjusted number of unemployed people rose by 9,000, to 4.37 million from April, while vacancies did not decline -- the first time since July -- indicating that the market was stabilizing. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: The Torture Memo, and the Outcry
description: To the Editor:

title: Dylan, Master Poet? Don't Think Twice, It's All Right
description: Christopher Ricks, the newly elected professor of poetry at Oxford, is also the Warren Professor of Humanities at Boston University, where he has a large and elegantly furnished office overlooking Storrow Drive, and he bikes to it every day from his house in Cambridge. The bookshelves contain a complete vellum-bound set of Johnson's ''Lives of the Poets'' and copies of the many books Mr. Ricks has himself written or edited -- books about Keats, Milton, Beckett and T. S. Eliot; editions of Tennyson, Housman and Eliot's early poems; anthologies of Victorian verse and of English poetry from the anonymous author of ''Sumer is icumen in'' to Seamus Heaney. In a corner by the desk there is also a boom box. Mr. Ricks brings this to lectures when he wants to talk about another of his favorite poets: Bob Dylan.

title: REDSTONE CONSIDERS TAKING MIDWAY GAMES PRIVATE
description: Midway Games Inc., the money-losing maker of Mortal Kombat video games, may be taken private by its controlling shareholder, Sumner Redstone. Mr. Redstone said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing yesterday that he had hired an adviser to study whether to take Midway private. Mr. Redstone, chairman of Viacom, raised his stake in Midway to 72 percent and said that he might increase that to more than 80 percent. He said on Monday that he was buying 1.25 million shares from departing Midway chairman Neil Nicastro. In April, he said that he may seek control of the company. The filing did not disclose the name of the adviser. Stock in Midway, based in Chicago, rose 65 cents, to $12.63 a share.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the biographer William Manchester last Wednesday misstated the year his wife, Julia, died. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: Corrections
description: The London Journal article yesterday, about British motorists' anger at aggressive enforcement by municipal parking officers, many of them working for private contractors, misstated an action taken by the city of Manchester to reduce the tension. title: CASTLE HARLAN TO BUY GARDEN-EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Castle Harlan, a buyout firm based in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the garden-equipment maker Ames True Temper from Wind Point Partners, for $380 million. Ames, founded in 1774, makes garden tools like rakes and shovels for customers including Home Depot, Lowe's and Wal-Mart. Wind Point Partners, based in Chicago, bought Ames in January 2002 from what is now called Jacuzzi Brands Inc., for $165 million. The purchase of Ames is the first by Castle Harlan in the lawn and garden industry. A large part of Ames's revenue ''comes from products that have the No.1 share in the market,'' said Justin Wender, managing director at Castle Harlan, who led the acquisition. Mr. Wender expects to complete the sale in the next eight weeks. Castle Harlan plans to expand Ames's business and keep its senior management team in place.

They are like children playing with a doll's house, but instead of make-believe furniture, their toys are the greatest collection of modern art in the world. Ever so delicately, tiny reproductions of ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon'' by Picasso, ''The Dance'' by Matisse and ''Flag'' by Jasper Johns have been taped to the walls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, BYRON H.
description: WILSON--Byron H. Died on June 2, 2004 peacefully in his sleep at his home in New York. He was the beloved father of Pamela Shirley (Wilson) Fuller of Adelphi, MD and D'Ashley Wilson of New York City, beloved father-inlaw to Arthur Fuller, beloved husband to Kathryn Reid of New York City. Byron was born on February 21, 1933 in The Bronx, New York. He attended Central Needle Trade High School in Manhattan. He served in the Korean War. Byron was a good friend and colleague to many throughout his life. Byron began his professional career as a model. After modeling he branched into accounting and into the voice-over industry. Byron loved life. One of his favorite sayings was ''Better to have been a has-been than a never-was.'' Byron is survived by his sister Juliana Ansah of Georgia, Theodore Wilson of New Rochelle, NY, Newton Wilson of Kansas and a host of nieces, nephews and other family members. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 12, at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, NYC, at 2PM. description: An anonymous artist staged an unwelcome one-person show at two of the city's leading museums last weekend. But the museums, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Guggenheim, said yesterday that they would not be pressing charges, even if they found out the artist's identity.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Real Estate Acquisition
description: The real estate company Inmobiliaria Colonial said it planned to buy a larger French property manager, Socit Foncire Lyonnaise, for 1.6 billion euros ($2 billion) after failing to expand at home. Colonial, based in Barcelona, bought a 55.6 percent stake from investors including a British insurer, Aviva, and a lender, Socit Gnrale, for 759 million euros, or 38 euros a share, it said in a regulatory filing. Colonial will make an offer to buy the rest of Foncire Lyonnaise, which is based in Paris, at the same price. With the purchase of Foncire Lyonnaise, Colonial would add the Paris market to Madrid and Barcelona and offices would represent 81 percent of the value of its holdings. (Bloomberg News)

description: Correction Appended

title: Honors for President Reagan
description: Alexander Hamilton, the founding father who was the nation's first Treasury secretary, is in dire need of a lobbyist to head off the rush in Washington to remove him from the $10 bill to make way for former President Ronald Reagan. There are plenty of competing proposals to put Mr. Reagan's portrait on the dime, the half-dollar or other bills. They seem just as motivated by politicians' eagerness to piggyback onto Mr. Reagan's popularity as they are by any genuine desire to honor him.

title: Pipe Down, PC
description: To the Editor:

title: As Oil Prices Rise, a Sense of Alarm in Asia
description: Thailand has imposed a curfew on its gasoline stations. Once free to stay open around the clock, gas stations will now be required to close from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, BERNARD
description: WALSH--Bernard. 91, a hero of D-Day, three times decorated, died on its 60th anniversary. He was a sculpture of great sensitivity and eloquence. He was also an innovator of framing designs who pioneered in conservation techniques. He is survived by Annie, his wife of 68 years, his daughter-in-law Susan and grandchildren Samuel and Leah. Requiescat in pace, dearest Bern.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column on June 1 about the Giants' signing of Kurt Warner and about several other quarterbacks who were switching teams in the National Football League referred incorrectly to Jeff Blake. He signed with the Philadelphia Eagles on May 28; he was not still looking for a team.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Big Apple For the Big Apple
description: Donna Karan, the fashion designer, plans to unveil a giant bronze sculpture of an apple designed by her late husband, Stephan Weiss, in Hudson River Park today. The sculpture, which is nine feet tall and weighs 6,000 pounds, will be temporarily placed in the park, which is near Mr. Weiss's Greenwich Village studio. Among those invited to the unveiling were Hugh Jackman, the Broadway and film star, and Ralph Lauren. Anthony Ramirez (NYT)

title: Quartet United By Its Checks And Balances
description: The Joe Lovano quartet at Iridium this week has two sides and two conciliatory middles. Hank Jones, the pianist, takes one side. Paul Motian, the drummer, takes the other. Both are masters. Mr. Jones sparkles and glides, his chords and runs served in perfect definition. Mr. Motian meditates and lurches subtly and remains a subtle abstraction.

title: For Developer With Arts Habit, On to Diplomacy
description: AMONG the Bush campaign's big contributors, Earle I. Mack may be one of only a few who subscribe to the left-leaning Harper's Magazine and enjoy the assaults on the administration by its editor, Lewis H. Lapham.

title: Reagan's Biggest Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawmakers Oppose Plan To Ease Sales Of U.S. Arms
description: House Republican leaders are blocking a Bush administration plan to waive licensing rules so Britain and Australia, two of America's closest allies in the fight against terrorism, can buy certain military items from the United States.

title: Bush, on 'a Special Day,' Greets New Iraqi Leader
description: An emotional President Bush met Wednesday for the first time with the newly designated interim president of Iraq, Sheik Ghazi Ajil al-Yawar, telling him, ''I never thought I'd be sitting next to an Iraqi president of a free country a year and a half ago.''

title: In a Room With No Jacks, Untethered Conference Calls
description: Meetings held by conference call already save time and money, not to mention those tiresome trips through airport security. Now a phone from ClearOne can liberate those huddled corporate masses from a device tethered to the wall jack.

title: Helping Retired Baby Boomers Manage Income and Expenses
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest manager of 401(k) assets, announced a new service yesterday intended to help individuals handle their money after they retire.

title: A Recall Vote in Venezuela
description: Venezuelans remain passionately divided over Hugo Chvez, a former military officer and failed coup leader who has been the country's elected president since 1998. But responsible behavior on both sides of that bitter divide, helped along by the dexterous mediation of the Organization of American States and the Carter Center, have now made it possible for Mr. Chvez's political future to be decided at the ballot box under a procedure he himself added to Venezuela's Constitution.

title: As Workers Strike, Parents Spend Day With Child in Tow
description: Some brought their children to stand beside them at work, behind bank teller windows or supermarket cash registers. Others missed work entirely. Either way, thousands of parents scrambled yesterday as workers at 350 subsidized day care centers began the second major strike in the city this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, CHARLOTTE ELSA
description: SHAPIRO--Charlotte Elsa. Of Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of Riverdale, NY passed away on June 7, 2004. Devoted wife of the late William Shapiro, mother of Charles, mother-in-law of Marya and grandmother of Will and Rebecca. Born in Germany, immigrated to the U.S, in 1931. Memorial service held Thursday, 11:30 am at Kraeer Funeral Home in Pompano Beach. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

description: Bush Sides With Bells In Pivotal Phone Case

title: Iraqi Leader Says He'll Respect Kurd Desire for Autonomy, at Least for Now
description: Prime Minister Iyad Allawi said Wednesday that his government would adhere to the interim constitution agreed to in March until elections are held next year, in an effort to defuse, at least temporarily, a looming crisis with the Kurdish leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWINDT, JOSEPHINE T.
description: SCHWINDT--Josephine T. on June 9, 2004 (nee Trovato). Beloved wife of the late Kenneth. Loving mother of Kenneth Schwindt and Cheryl Masto. Cherished grandmother of four and great grandmother of one. Devoted sister of Salvatore Trovato. Reposing at the Harden Funeral Home, 209 St and Northern Blvd. Visiting hours Thursday 2-5 and 7-10pm. Funeral Mass Friday St. Robert Bellarmine RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

description: Correction Appended

title: Bush Doesn't Expect NATO to Send More Troops to Iraq
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., June 10  President Bush made clear at the conclusion of the Group of 8 summit meeting here today that it was up to the new Iraqi government to request NATO assistance, and that he expected that any such assistance would come in a relatively modest form, such as training and remaking Iraqi forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLATZKO, MORRIS, MD
description: KLATZKO--Morris, MD, June 8. Husband of Ruth, father of David, Ann (Ron) Cohen, grandfather to Dana and Andrew. Riverside, 12:30 today.

title: Weaving Bartok's Jagged Edges Into Drama, Wildness Intact
description: Music in concert is one thing, music at a dance performance is another. Choreography transforms music, as Mark Morris showed so differently in two new works, ''All Fours'' and ''Violet Cavern'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about DidTheyReadIt.com, an e-mail service that notifies the sender -- without the recipient's knowledge -- of when and where a message was read, misstated its novelty. Other such services preceded it, including ReadNotify.com and ReturnReceipt.com; DidTheyReadIt is not the first.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When others stepped back, President Reagan stepped forward. And he did it all with great humility, with great charm and with great humor.''

title: D-DAY / 60 years later : Hero and villain:contrasting wartime roles for women
description: It is unlikely that the D-Day planners dreamed up the idea of using an American female spy with a wooden leg to relay information on German troop movements inside France and to work with Resistance workers to cut off German supply and communication lines. But that is what Virginia Hall, a Baltimore native and operative for the OSS, did in the days just before and after June 6, 1944.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Prison For Boys Who Abused Classmate
description: Three teenagers were sentenced to 15 to 18 months in prison after they were found guilty of leading a group that systematically brutalized a classmate over three months beginning last fall in a storeroom of their vocational school in Hildesheim, near Hanover. Six other young men received lesser sentences. The victim was sexually abused, kicked and beaten. His head was covered some of the time with a plastic bucket. The case raised an outcry in Germany when videos of the abuses, captured on a digital camera, were distributed on the Internet. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Offering Ministry, and Early Release, to Prisoners
description: The campus of Rick Warren's Saddleback Community Church in Lake Forest, Calif., covers 120 acres, and draws up to 20,000 people on Sundays. But to appreciate the full reach of this church and its leader you need to look in less manicured surroundings.

title: A Blogger's Recompense
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding Central American Spice To the Dinner Table
description: Steve Keister, a sculptor and ceramist in Manhattan, makes brilliantly colored glazed plates, below, inspired by the round 10-inch plastic foam package on Canal Street used to hold stereo speakers. (''The legs are cast from air pockets in the Styrofoam,'' Mr. Keister noted.) He said the brilliant colors -- purple, turquoise, yellow -- come from a Guatemalan shawl.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about the Philadelphia Eagles' lineup for the coming season referred incorrectly to the status of three players. Corey Simon is a defensive tackle, not a defensive end. Jeremiah Trotter left the team before the 2002 season, not before last season. Nate Wayne came to the Eagles from Green Bay before last season, not this season.

title: Car Kills Couple in Brooklyn; Man Is Charged With D.W.I.
description: Once a week, Arthur and Sylvia Horowitz took an express bus from Brooklyn to Atlantic City to do some low-stakes gambling at the Showboat or Bally's.

title: World Briefings
description: SOUTH PACIFIC

title: A Different Tack On Heartburn: Go On, Indulge
description: All the trappings of beer commercials are there: the come-hither poses of the seductively dressed women, the leering language of the ad copy, the paeans to activities of the night. The ads in question, however, are not for Budweiser, Miller Lite or the like, but for a heartburn medication.

title: Regulators Seek Clarity on Risks of Some Annuities
description: Saying that brokers and insurance agents have confused and misled their own customers, NASD and the Securities and Exchange Commission urged the industry yesterday to provide better explanations about the risks involved in purchasing variable annuities.

title: Trouble Talking to the Ladies  About Terrorism
description: Senate Republicans held a panel discussion today to explore the life and political achievements of President Ronald Reagan and their implications for the present, hearing from such Reagan administration veterans as former Attorney General Ed Meese and the speechwriter Peggy Noonan. ( Video )

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAX, ESTHER
description: MAX--Esther. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with profound sorrow the passing of Esther Max, wife of our retired Ritual Director, Rabbi Kalman Max. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Pakistani General Survives Attack That Killed 10
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 10  Ten people were killed and another 10 wounded today as a top Pakistani military general escaped an assassination attempt when unidentified gunmen ambushed his motorcade in Karachi, officials said.

title: Mets' Howe Gives Matsui A Pep Talk
description: Art Howe summoned Kazuo Matsui to his office Wednesday afternoon, not for a tongue-lashing, but for a pep talk and a promise.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Sisters Found Slain
description: Two sisters were shot to death in an apartment in Throgs Neck, the police said yesterday. Shortly before 10:30 p.m. Tuesday, neighbors heard gunshots. Deyanira Vazquez, 32, said yesterday that her husband, Quincy, ran next door and discovered the bodies of Loreen Merchan, 33, who rented the apartment just last month, and her sister, Yasmin Merchan, who was visiting from Waterbury, Conn. Loreen Merchan's three daughters, ages 15, 13, and 4, were unharmed, Ms. Vazquez said. The police said they had no suspects. Howard O. Stier (NYT)

title: Suspect Items From Iraq Shipped Abroad, U.N. Says
description: Equipment and material that could have been used to produce banned weapons and long-range missiles have been emptied from Iraqi sites since the war started and shipped abroad, the head of the United Nations inspectors office told the Security Council on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Ronald Reagan in late editions on Sunday and a condensed version on Monday misstated the scope of his brief run for the Republican nomination in 1968. Although Mr. Reagan tested his popularity that year, he did not enter primaries. The obituaries also misstated the origin of the campaign slogan ''It's morning in America.'' It was used in television ads for his 1984 re-election bid, not for the 1980 campaign.

title: Bringing San Franciscan Harvest To a New York Showroom
description: Ted Boerner, above, a modern furniture designer based in San Francisco, has opened a New York showroom, after years of being represented by Dennis Miller Associates. The 2,200-square-foot showroom displays the 50-piece Boerner collection of chairs, couches, dressers, beds and tables, like the solid walnut Harvest table shown ($9,000) and its set of four Harvest benches, $4,400. ''Having our own space,'' said Frank Pontes, Mr. Boerner's business partner, ''lets us show the full spirit of the collection.'' The Ted Boerner showroom is at 537 Greenwich Street (Vandam Street), second floor, to the trade only; 10 a.m. to 7 p.m., (212) 675-5665 or www.tedboerner.com. DIANE DANIEL

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 27 about pots for movable gardens misstated the phone number for Atlock Farm, a supplier in Somerset, N.J. It is (732) 356-3373.

title: National Briefing | Plains: North Dakota: 27,000 Pelicans Vanish
description: Some 27,000 pelicans have disappeared from their nesting grounds at the Chase Lake National Wildlife Refuge, 135 miles west of Fargo, leaving behind their eggs. Dean C. Hildebrand, director of the North Dakota Game and Fish Department, said his agency was investigating the case with the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service. The area has had severe weather. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaving Retailer
description: The Marks & Spencer Group, the retail chain, said that Vittorio Radice, left, the head of its clothes unit, would leave tomorrow as the new chief executive, Stuart Rose, prepared his own management team. Mr. Rose, who was hired to fend off a takeover attempt by the billionaire Philip Green said the decision for Mr. Radice to leave was mutual. Mr. Rose said he wanted to take more control of the clothing business and would have cut back on Mr. Radice's responsibilities.

title: Russian Court Overturns Acquittal in Spy Case
description: Russia's Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned the acquittal of a physicist who had been charged with espionage, ordering a new trial in a case that has been seen as part of a crackdown on researchers and scientists working with foreigners.

title: MAXWELL SHOE TO NEGOTIATE WITH JONES ON TAKEOVER BID
description: The Maxwell Shoe Company has entered into a confidentiality agreement with the Jones Apparel Group to discuss a higher offer after rejecting a $354 million takeover bid by Jones on Monday. The agreement was disclosed in a filing Maxwell made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, based in Hyde Park, Mass., said it expected to have discussions with Jones and did not plan to provide updates until a definitive agreement was reached. Maxwell said on Monday that it wanted more money from Jones, which raised its cash bid last month to $22.50 a share from $20. Maxwell makes AK Anne Klein shoes; Jones, based in Bristol, Pa., acquired the Anne Klein line of clothes in December.

title: Brewers Win Even as They Strike Out
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 (AP) - Scott Podsednik doubled home the tie-breaking run in the 17th inning, long after Ben Sheets lost his bid for a perfect game, as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Anaheim Angels, 1-0, Tuesday night.

title: New Peruvian Soft Drink Packs a Punch
description: Amid clanging machinery and the whiffs of steam on the factory floor, a new company is producing a soft drink that its creators pledge will transform this Andean country, if successful.

title: UNION PACIFIC CUTS SECOND-QUARTER EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Union Pacific, the biggest railroad in the nation, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings would fall from a year ago on higher costs to end shipping delays and buy diesel fuel. The forecast was about a third lower than analysts' estimates. Earnings will be 60 to 65 cents a share, compared with $1.05 a share last year, the company said. The railroad said ''operational inefficiencies'' like a shortage of train crews and track congestion, coupled with a 30 percent rise in fuel costs, were increasing expenses. Shares of Union Pacific fell $1.21, or 2 percent, to $58.78.

title: A Who's Who (and Less) Of Modern Architecture
description: From an ovoid-shaped brick tunnel commissioned by Vaclav Havel in Prague to a multidomed parliamentary library in New Delhi that looks like bubbling yeast, ''The Phaidon Atlas of Contemporary World Architecture'' (Phaidon, $160, complete with its own suitcase, above) offers a choice slice of millennially hip buildings, completed from 1998 to 2003. There are some biases, however. Eight buildings by Tadao Ando in four countries are included, but Rem Koolhaas's Dutch Embassy in Berlin is left out. And the work of neo-Classicists like Allan Greenberg and Leon Krier did not make the cut. Warning for shoppers: you'll need a stroller to get this book with the deadweight of a napping toddler, 17.5 pounds, back home. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Heavenly Climbers

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Monitor Approves Child Welfare Plan
description: The independent panel assigned to monitor the overhaul of New Jersey's child welfare system formally approved the state's plan to remake the troubled Division of Youth and Family Services yesterday. The plan, which calls for hiring hundreds of new workers and faster investigation of abuse and neglect allegations, is a key part of a settlement reached last year on a lawsuit that challenged the state's foster care system. The plan, titled ''A New Beginning: The Future of Child Welfare in New Jersey,'' was first made public in February and has undergone a series of revisions since then. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Suit Charges Silver With Tolerating Sexual Harassment
description: A former legislative aide who says she was raped by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver's former top lawyer filed a lawsuit here on Wednesday accusing Mr. Silver of failing to properly investigate an earlier, similar case and of tolerating a culture of sexual harassment in the Assembly.

title: Bell Canada Seeks to Offer Cable TV On Its Wires
description: Bell Canada has asked regulators for a go-ahead to offer cable TV service over its existing copper-wire phone network to counter a threat from cable operators.

title: Kupper Parker Acquires Rabasca Marketing
description: Kupper Parker Communications in St. Louis has acquired Rabasca & Company Marketing Communications in Melville, N.Y., for undisclosed terms.

description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Deal in Albany Will Be Late, Maybe Later Than Usual
description: Less than two weeks before the State Legislature is scheduled to adjourn, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, are discussing the possibility that a budget may not be passed until much later in the summer.

title: Home Aides End Strike; Union Vows More Pressure
description: With the three-day strike by home health aides ending yesterday, leaders of 1199/S.E.I.U., New York's largest health-care union, said they planned to hold sporadic strikes this summer against agencies that fail to reach contracts with the union.

title: A Little Getaway: Small, Simple, Fast and Fun
description: YOU have an egg, a pan and three seconds. Fry! You have a fork, spaghetti and three seconds. Twirl! You have an eye, some drops and three seconds. Squirt!

title: People
description: Tammy Haughey, general manager at Di Zinno Thompson, San Diego, was named president, succeeding Tom Di Zinno, who became chairman.

title: Bayonne Mayor Is Selected As an Interim State Senator
description: In a brief and well-choreographed session on Wednesday night, the Hudson County Democratic Committee chose Mayor Joseph V. Doria of Bayonne to fill the State Senate seat left vacant last month by the death of Glenn D. Cunningham, the Jersey City mayor.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Thursday about the Giants' negotiations with the free agent quarterback Kurt Warner referred incorrectly to the status of Kevin Thompson, another quarterback who had been with the team. He was released on May 20.

title: Legal Aid Society President Resigns, Citing Shortage of Funds
description: The Legal Aid Society, struggling with deficits and the threat of layoffs, said yesterday that Daniel L. Greenberg, its president and chief attorney, had resigned.

title: Attackers Hit Oil Pipelines, Police and a U.S. Convoy
description: Insurgents attacked on several fronts on Wednesday, firing mortars at an Iraqi militia brigade west of here, setting ablaze two important oil pipelines in the north and ambushing an American military convoy in the capital.

title: Injury to Brown Mars Jeter's Brilliant Return
description: Through all the discouragement and embarrassment he feels, Kevin Brown notices what is happening around him. Brown is not himself on the mound, but for now it does not matter. His Yankees teammates are that good.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about fears of a power vacuum at the Central Intelligence Agency after the departures of George J. Tenet, the director, and James L. Pavitt, the chief of clandestine services, misspelled the surname of Mr. Tenet's predecessor in some copies and misstated his middle initial. And because of an editing error, a correction in this space on Tuesday misspelled the predecessor's surname. He was John M. Deutch, not John W. Deutsch.

title: Sports of The Times; Ignorance and Arrogance Collide, Live and Off Color
description: LESS than an off-season since Janet Jackson was busted for her material breach of decency on the Super Bowl stage, Bill Parcells decided to open his flap.
