title: Who's Kidnapping the Pigeons, and Who Cares?; Animal Lovers See an Interstate Trade in Moving Targets
description: The reports are usually the same: around dawn, near a city park or plaza, two men jump out of a van, the license plate often concealed with tape. They toss a handful of seeds, and when pigeons descend, they swipe the birds up in a net.

title: How Reagan Forced Foes to Reinvent Party
description: Senator John Kerry and other leading Democrats are couching their remarks about Ronald Reagan in respectful tones this week, showing deference to the former president. But there is a political rationale at work as well.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 8 Charter Schools To Open
description: Eight new charter schools will open in New York City in the fall, some of them in public buildings, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday. The new schools are part of an unusual plan in which the city is using private donations and a nonprofit group controlled by the school system to open as many as 50 charter schools over the next five years. Also yesterday, Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the City Council Education Committee, called upon state regulators to reconsider a decision to close the John A. Reisenbach Charter School in Harlem because of poor test scores and other factors. New state English test scores, released last week, showed that while Reisenbach's eighth graders continued to lag, its fourth graders performed about as well as their peers citywide. Ashlei N. Stevens (NYT)

title: New Catalogs Cater to Children
description: GARNET HILL, the company known for its casual clothing and colorful home textiles, is introducing a lavish 64-page catalog this summer devoted to children and their parents' increasingly sophisticated tastes.

title: The Capital Pays Homage to 'a Graceful and a Gallant Man'
description: To the thrum of muffled drums, the strains of solemn music and eulogies from the leaders of the Republican-run Congress he helped to create, the body of Ronald Wilson Reagan returned Wednesday evening to the capital he campaigned against so often, then did so much to reshape through two terms as president.

title: Panel Calls for Sexual Harassment Charges Against Councilman
description: A City Council ethics panel recommended yesterday that a Queens councilman, Allan W. Jennings Jr., be charged with creating a hostile work environment for two female Council employees and acting inappropriately toward another member of the Council.

title: Study Ranks Bush Plan to Cut Air Pollution as Weakest of 3
description: A research firm that the Bush administration commissioned to analyze its plan to lower emissions from coal-fired power plants compared the plan with two competing legislative proposals and concluded in a report released Wednesday that the administration's plan was the weakest.

title: Archive Architecture: Setting the Spin in Stone
description: EVERY day, a worker climbs to the roof of the Clinton Presidential Center here and hoists three seven-foot-high numbers onto a steel frame. The numbers tell drivers on Interstate 30, just west of the site, how many days remain until Nov. 18, when Bill Clinton is expected to open the $175 million project that embodies his postpresidential ambitions.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Deal To Assemble Helicopters For Russia
description: Mexico and Russia made a deal to assemble Russian military helicopters in one of Mexico's poorest states, Hidalgo, after a meeting in Mexico City between Presidents Vicente Fox and Vladimir V. Putin. The project, which President Putin described as ''interesting, but small,'' is still in negotiation. It would aid Mexico's economy, which grew rapidly in the late 1990's but has been stagnant since 2001. A loss of 300,000 jobs in the ''maquiladora'' industry, which assembles piece goods from abroad into finished products, is in large part to blame for the slowdown. Many of those jobs have been lost to China and Central American countries, where wages are even lower than in Mexico. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Greets New Iraqi Leader

title: KRAFT TO ADD SOUTH BEACH TRADEMARK TO SOME PRODUCTS
description: Kraft Foods said yesterday that it would tap the popularity of low-fat and low-sugar foods by putting the South Beach Diet trademark on some products. Terms of a multiyear agreement with Dr. Arthur Agatston, the cardiologist who created the diet and a best-selling book, were not disclosed, Kraft said. Cookie and cereal sales have dropped at Kraft, the largest food maker in the United States, while Agatston's diet of foods lower in saturated fat, starch and sugar has spent more than a year on best-seller lists. A spokeswoman would not say which brands would carry the South Beach trademark.

title: Ex-Detainees Sue Companies For Their Role In Abuse Case
description: Lawyers representing former detainees who say they were sexually humiliated, beaten, and tortured at Abu Ghraib prison said Wednesday that they have sued two private companies that provided translators and interrogators at the prison.

title: Viewership Of Cable News Is Up, Barely
description: Extensive coverage of the death of former President Ronald Reagan by the three main cable news networks has so far given them only a modest bump in viewership, according to early ratings data.

title: Awaiting A Prospect, Baggage And All
description: For someone under house arrest, Willie Williams spends a lot of time away from home. Last Sunday, he traveled to Gainesville, Fla., to prepare for a court appearance that ate up all of Monday. On Tuesday he was back in school, wrapping up his last week at Miami Carol City Senior High School.

title: Economic Scene; The earning power of women has really increased, right? Take a closer look.
description: THE great defense against stagnating male wages in America over the last few decades has been the two-worker family. No doubt many women want to work to fulfill their own goals and gain financial independence. But consider the monetary advantages. The latest data show that the median income of two-worker families was nearly $71,000. If only the husband worked, the median family income was $41,000.

title: Peterson Relative Says He Noticed Inconsistencies
description: Statements made by Scott Peterson to relatives of his missing wife, Laci, were so inconsistent, one family member testified on Wednesday, that he secretly followed Mr. Peterson to a shopping mall and a golf course to see if something was amiss.

title: ARCHER DANIELS ARGUES FOR REDUCTION IN EUROPEAN FINE
description: Archer Daniels Midland told a European Union court yesterday that a fine of 39.7 million euros ($48.3 million) for fixing citric acid prices should be annulled or reduced. Archer Daniels, based in Decatur, Ill., was one of five companies fined by the European Commission in December 2001 for operating a worldwide cartel for citric acid, used as a food preservative, from 1991 to 1995. Lawyers for the company told a three-judge panel at the court, the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg, that the commission had miscalculated the fine because it relied solely on worldwide citric acid sales and disregarded European data.

title: Noise and the City: A Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastoral Scenes of Yore Make Way for Political Statements for the Wall
description: Jessica Smith, a textile artist and designer in Philadelphia, above right, has taken the toile de Jouy form and made it modern, witty and political. Her hand-printed toile wallpapers offer lighthearted social commentary. ''Eighteenth-century French toile depicted pastoral scenes with classical ruins, ladies in frilly dresses on swings,'' Ms. Smith said. ''I wanted to make my own pastoral countryside, and the countryside of America is the suburbs.'' Trash Day, top right and detail top left, is a homage to the day when suburbanites put the trash on the street for collection. Spying on China, above center, shows an American spy plane over a Chinese landscape, a reference to a collision between such a plane and a Chinese jet in 2001 off the coast of Hainan Island. Cars Go Beep, above left, has delicately rendered Hummers on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Vying for the Honor of Playing in Turkey . . . or Not
description: Eight of America's best teams clashed Tuesday in the quarterfinal stage of the United States Bridge Championships in Memphis. At the end of the day, the midpoint of matches lasting 120 deals, these were the positions by captain: Russ Ekeblad led Malcolm Brachman by 21 imps; Nick Nickell led Jimmy Cayne by 20 imps; Rose Meltzer led John Onstott by 10 imps; and Roy Welland led Richard Schwartz by 71 imps.

title: A New Ice Age? None Soon, Snow 2 Miles Deep Implies
description: Despite the recent trend toward global warming, scientists have long wondered whether the earth is nearing another ice age, an end to the 12,000-year temperate spell in which modern civilizations arose. Some have said such a transition is overdue, given that each of the three temperate intervals that immediately preceded the current one lasted only about 10,000 years.

title: Giants Hoping Shockey's Foot Is Only Sore
description: Giants tight end Jeremy Shockey missed Wednesday's minicamp with what the team described as a sore foot, and he traveled to Manhattan to have it examined by team doctors.

title: World Leaders Get a Glimpse of America's High Life
description: Ronald Reagan wanted to show off America's colonial traditions, so he held the 1983 summit meeting of leading industrial nations in Williamsburg, Va., on the streets Jefferson once walked. Seven years later, George H.W. Bush took his counterparts to noisy Houston, and Bill Clinton tried Denver to give the world a mile-high view of the booming American West and American Indian tradition.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CATERPILLAR, Peoria, Ill., a maker of heavy equipment, raised its quarterly dividend 11 percent, to 41 cents from 37 cents. The dividend is payable Aug. 20 to shareholders of record on July 20.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Hearing Set On Music Merger
description: The European Commission has scheduled a hearing on the proposed merger of the music units of Sony and Bertelsmann for next Monday and Tuesday. The commission, the regulatory arm of the European Union, listed objections to the deal last month, fearing that it would raise prices for consumers. The companies asked for the hearing; the commission must make a decision by July 22. Paul Meller

title: Should Doctors Help With Executions? No Easy Ethical Answer
description: Dr. Sanjeeva Rao used to look after the inmates at the state prison in Jackson, Ga., treating their high blood pressure and more serious ailments. When the state started using lethal injections in 2000, he took on another task: helping to execute them.

title: Bloomberg's Approval Rating Is Up, Poll Shows
description: Half of New York City voters approve of the way Michael R. Bloomberg is handling his job, the mayor's highest rating in two years, according to a new poll.

title: Wholesalers' Inventories Show Unexpected Decline for April
description: Inventories at American wholesalers unexpectedly fell 0.1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. It was the first decline in eight months, as demand for pharmaceuticals, imported automobiles and other goods outpaced supplies.

title: The Box House: Simplicity Cubed
description: WHEN Elizabeth Charles and her husband, Martin Halstead, decided in 1997 to build a weekend house here, 300 miles south of Sydney, they knew who they would like to design it: Glenn Murcutt. They also knew they could never afford him -- and that was five years before he won the prestigious Pritzker Prize. But they called him anyway, just to talk.

title: Strong Field at Buick Tunes Up for the U.S. Open
description: Phil Mickelson skipped the Buick Classic last year, but he was not alone. Davis Love III, Mike Weir, Padraig Harrington, Stuart Appleby, Kenny Perry, Darren Clarke and Adam Scott missed it, too.

title: Spain Arrests 6 Terror Suspects
description: Spain arrested six people on Wednesday on charges of helping to supply explosives for the March 11 terrorist attacks in Madrid, the Interior Ministry announced.

title: Ex-Treasurer of Adelphia Says He Received Only His Salary
description: Michael Mulcahey, a former assistant treasurer of the Adelphia Communications Corporation who is on trial for fraud, testified yesterday that he did not receive any direct benefit from funds the company transferred to the founder, John Rigas.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Ronald Reagan in late editions on Sunday and a condensed version on Monday misstated the scope of his brief run for the Republican nomination in 1968. Although Mr. Reagan tested his popularity that year, he did not enter primaries. The obituaries also misstated the origin of the campaign slogan ''It's morning in America.'' It was used in television ads for his 1984 re-election bid, not for the 1980 campaign.

title: Two Securities Firms Fined by Big Board
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and Morgan Stanley were fined and censured by the New York Stock Exchange's enforcement division, the exchange said in a statement yesterday.

title: At Summit, Police and Delegations Outnumber the Demonstrators
description: It is not just that the protesters are outnumbered by reporters and police officers. They are even outnumbered by the world leaders and aides who are taking part in the Group of Eight summit meeting that began Tuesday.

title: Weddings, Ever Fancier
description: To the Editor:

title: Night of the Living Taped (Spliced, Maybe?)
description: Precocity must have an opposite; maybe it's ''young at heart.'' That quality is on display tonight on ''The 2004 MTV Movie Awards.'' Its practitioners this year are Sharon Stone and Tom Cruise, movie stars in their 40's who, since their divorces, have been reaching out to juniors.

title: Paying Candidates to Run
description: The victory of a Democratic lawyer, Stephanie Herseth, in the race last week for an open House seat in South Dakota had some intriguing implications. Ms. Herseth is the first successful Congressional candidate of either party to take advantage of a change in the campaign finance rules that allows federal candidates to pay themselves salaries from their campaign treasuries. Approved two years ago by the Federal Election Commission, this exception to the prohibition on candidates' making personal use of campaign funds had bipartisan backing. It was intended to ameliorate the woeful shortage of competition for seats in Congress by making it financially possible for people who are not wealthy to take time off to run for office.

title: 'Avenue Q' Thumbs Its Nose at the Road For Life on the Strip
description: In a calculated gamble that subverts the traditional Broadway notion of a road show, the producers of ''Avenue Q,'' the newly minted Tony winner for best musical, have decided to forgo a national tour and opt instead for a long-term, open-ended run in Las Vegas, a city they say is perfectly suited for their subversively funny puppet show.

title: Where Chickens Clucked, Violins Sigh
description: LORIN MAAZEL has a farm. And on his farm, an hour south of Washington, are things Old MacDonald did not dream of: wax statues (like Madame Tussaud's) and a barnyard with a zebra, a camel and llamas (''Think Neverland, but tasteful,'' one recent guest said).

title: 1929:Guggenheim Generosity : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: NEW YORK: Mr. and Mrs. Simon Guggenheim have given $1,000,000 to the John S. Guggenheim Memorial Foundation for a system of exchange fellowships between the United States and Latin America.

title: PETRO-CANADA IS BUYING NATURAL GAS PRODUCER
description: Petro-Canada said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Prima Energy for $534 million, tapping into the growing production of natural gas in the Rocky Mountains. Stockholders of Prima, based in Denver, will get $39.50 in cash for each share, Petro-Canada said. Petro-Canada, based in Calgary, Alberta, said Prima had no debt and would have $60 million in cash when the purchase closed in late July. The transaction is at least the fourth acquisition of a Denver-based gas producer since April. The purchase will give Petro-Canada proven reserves estimated at 152 billion cubic feet of gas equivalent in a region that the Energy Department predicts will surpass the Gulf of Mexico as the largest domestic source of the fuel in the next decade.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: After Abu Ghraib; An American in The Hague?
description: The Bush administration has yet to accept much responsibility for the torture at Abu Ghraib prison. True, the president has apologized for the abuse on Arab television, and several top military officials in Iraq -- including the general in charge of the prison and her boss -- have been quietly suspended or will soon be transferred. But so far, legal responsibility has fallen exclusively on the seven court-martialed soldiers who were directly involved. Administration officials have argued that they themselves are not liable, since the incidents were the work of a few bad actors.

description: To the Editor:

title: News and Maps On the Go, Size Small
description: Many Web sites and services now provide online material tailored for the tiny screens and slower download speeds of palmtop computers and smart phones. A new service from Handmark Software offers information formatted for small screens, but with a twist: no Web browser software is involved.

title: Trouble Talking to the Ladies  About Terrorism
description: Senate Republicans held a panel discussion today to explore the life and political achievements of President Ronald Reagan and their implications for the present, hearing from such Reagan administration veterans as former Attorney General Ed Meese and the speechwriter Peggy Noonan. ( Video )

title: Restoration Completed
description: A decade of restoration for the 2,200-year-old Pergamon Altar at the Museum Island in Berlin has been finished. The work on the 370-foot-long, 7.5-foot-high altar, depicting Greek gods, kings and warriors, cost almost $3.7 million. The altar was discovered by the archaeologist Carl Humann in western Turkey in 1878 and brought to Berlin, where it remains one of that city's most treasured artworks. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: New Battles in Najaf, Casting Doubt on Announced Truce
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 10 — Militiamen loyal to a rebel Shiite cleric seized a police station in the center of the holy city of Najaf today after an overnight gun battle and proceeded to set prisoners free and loot the building. Six people were killed in the firefights, a hospital official said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: 37 Months For Cigar Smuggler
description: A lawyer, Richard Connors, 55, of Chicago, who was convicted in 2002 of smuggling thousands of cigars from Cuba, was sentenced to 37 months in federal prison and fined $60,000. The sentencing had been delayed to hear all motions. Mr. Connors, who represented himself in his trial, was also sentenced to three years of probation and was taken into custody because the authorities said he posed a risk to flee. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

description: Classic Gardens

title: Coach's Illness Adds To Linemen's Tumult
description: Even before this week, the off-season had been tumultuous for the Giants' offensive linemen. They seemed to be adding members by the truckload, trying to fix the mess that last season's line had become, all tossed into a unit that relies more than any other on cohesion. And they were told that their development might hold the entire season in sway.

title: The Beatles Online?
description: For years they have been reluctant to release their music catalog for sale online, but the Beatles may finally be buckling. Representatives for the Fab Two -- Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, the surviving Beatles -- are in talks with several companies to sell their music on the Internet, according to CNET, an online financial news service. If the Beatles opt to have an online presence, other bands might follow suit, said Matt Graves, spokesman for RealNetwork's Rhapsody Service, a music subscription service. ''This has been one of the holy grails of the online music world,'' he said. EMI owns the Beatles' master recordings, and ''any decision on this kind of move would need to be made jointly,'' Jeanne Meyer, a spokeswoman for EMI, said. EMI has been encouraging the remaining Beatles to make their songs available digitally. ''We think it would be absolutely fantastic if the Beatles elected to go for it,'' Ms. Meyer said. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: After Abu Ghraib; Fight Fire With Compassion
description: Recent reports indicate that Bush administration lawyers, in their struggles to deal with terrorism, wrote memos in 2003 pushing aside longstanding prohibitions on the use of torture by Americans. These memos cleared the way for the horrors that have been revealed in Iraq, Afghanistan and Guantnamo and make a mockery of administration assertions that a few misguided enlisted personnel perpetrated the vile abuse of prisoners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARZ, CLAIRE
description: SCHWARZ -- Claire (nee Fernhoff) February 15, 1908. Widow of Dr. Julius. Died June 9, 2004 in Denver. Formerly of Vienna, Austria & Monticello, NY. Survived by her son Marvin (Kathleen Post), grandchildren Ti mothy, Jonathan, Susan & Whitney and loving nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPPMAN, ELAINE
description: LIPPMAN--Elaine, 94, on June 8, 2004. A joyful and vibrant woman, wife of the late Samuel, sister to the late Marion and Janice, and dearly loved and loving mother of Marcia. She leaves behind such a rich legacy of laughter, friendship, and humanity. Services Friday June 11th at 11:30am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Exhortations But No Excuses As a Marriage Comes Apart
description: The battle between sexes is a fight to the finish in ''Waitin' 2 End Hell'' by the California playwright William A. Parker, at the 47th Street Playhouse. Frequent back talk from the audience is a reminder that Mr. Parker is known for provoking visceral reactions to his ideas about fractured relationships of men and women in black families.

title: Israel Offers to Pay Settlers to Leave Gaza; Reception Is Cool
description: JERUSALEM, June 10  Israel is willing to pay compensation in advance to encourage Jewish settlers to voluntarily leave the Gaza Strip in the coming months, rather than facing the prospect of a forced evacuation next year, government officials said today.

title: A Distant Music Player, Replenished Wirelessly
description: Thanks to its wireless connectivity, SoniqCast's Aireo SQ-1000-NA MP3 player can stay in your briefcase or your car as you fill it with your latest music downloads. Besides freeing you from bothering with a dock or cables, the Aireo can poll your PC for new songs and playlists at preset times. So while you sleep, it can wake itself up and sync with your PC's music collection, even from as far as your driveway.

title: Labor Demands Cast a Rich Mayor In a Miserly Light
description: Each June, labor protests are to New York City as dogwood blossoms are to the rest of the Northeast; spring would seem a bit empty without them.

title: Policy on Felons and Voting Is Still Unclear in Florida
description: County elections supervisors peppered state officials on Wednesday with questions about purging felons from their voter rolls, suggesting at a meeting here that numerous attempts to clarify Florida's policy had not ended confusion on the issue.

title: Teaching Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Running the Roots-Rock Sound Through a Shape-Shifting Machine
description: Back in the 20th century, Wilco played roots-rock. It reached back to proven materials: the twang of country, the steady chug of 1960's rock, the undulating sheen of the Beach Boys, the honky-tonk hymns of the Band and the melodic symmetries of pop. Singing about certainties that had been left behind, the band's leader, Jeff Tweedy, held on to comforting forms.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hicksville: Iraqi Electricity Minister Visits Keyspan
description: The minister of electricity for Iraq, Ayham al-Samaraie, met yesterday with Robert B. Catell, chairman and chief executive of KeySpan Energy Corporation, at its headquarters here to discuss ongoing energy issues in Iraq. The 45-minute meeting involved discussion of electrical transmission and distribution needs and pending infrastructure projects. Mr. Samaraie was in New York City to meet with representatives of the United Nations. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Ladislav Hecht, 94, a Tactician On the Tennis Courts in the 30's
description: Ladislav Hecht, once the captain of Czechoslovakia's Davis Cup team and perhaps the best tennis player on the European continent immediately before World War II, died May 27 at home in Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 94.

title: The U.N. Go-Ahead on Iraq
description: At a time when not much has been going right in Iraq, the Bush administration registered a clear diplomatic advance at the United Nations on Tuesday. While the outcome was inevitable, it was still a positive step when the Security Council unanimously voted for a resolution approving the transfer of some sovereign powers to an Iraqi governing body.

title: Euro Disney Reaches Deal To Rearrange Finances
description: Euro Disney, the financially troubled theme park near Paris, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement on a financial restructuring that would provide money for the design of new rides and attractions. But it gave no details, and a spokesman said it would be weeks before shareholders learn how they would be affected by the plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWE, MILTON
description: LOWE--Milton, age 87 of Key Biscayne, FL passed away June 8th, 2004. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Yvonne Lowe and his former wife Eleanor Lowe, daughter Mona (Dan) Morello, son Sheldon (Maria) Lowe, daughter Francine Lowe and grandchildren Billy, Alexa and Danielle Lowe. A kind gentle man always with a smile for his loved ones. He will be dearly missed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Bar Operator
description: GI Partners, a private equity firm created by the California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, has agreed to buy the Yates Group, a British owner of bars, for 93 million ($171 million). GI Partners offered 140 pence a share for Yates, which is based in Bolton and operates 152 bars. The price is a 37 percent premium over Yates's share price on June 2, the day before GI Partners said it was in talks to buy Yates. GI Partners was set up in 2001 by Calpers and the CB Richard Ellis Group, a commercial property broker.

title: You're in a Hot Spot, But How Hot? Count the Red Dots

The WiFi Seeker senses Wi-Fi networks and identifies their signal strength by illuminating one to four red L.E.D.'s on the small battery-powered device.

title: Now, a Great Leap Forward in Luxury
description: Wearing a white car-racing T-shirt, black plastic cargo pants and silver Nike running shoes, James Wang, a 27-year-old developer of golf courses and luxury homes, stepped forward on Wednesday as one of China's first two buyers of the Maybach 62, a 20-foot ultraluxury sedan marketed as ''the private jet of the road.''

title: Increased Coverage For Athens
description: NBC Universal Sports will televise 1,210 hours of Olympic coverage from Athens in August over six networks and in high definition, nearly three times more than was shown four years ago from Sydney on NBC and its cable outlets, CNBC and MSNBC. At least 300 hours from Greece will be live, mostly on cable, between 2 a.m. and 4 p.m. Eastern.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 14 about Warner-Lambert's settlement of a federal lawsuit over the marketing of the epilepsy drug Neurontin referred imprecisely to a related plea of guilty by the company. Warner-Lambert, now part of Pfizer, pleaded guilty to two criminal charges -- that it failed to provide adequate directions for Neurontin's use and that it engaged in interstate sale of an unapproved drug. While Warner-Lambert had been accused of paying doctors to prescribe the drug for unapproved use, that charge was not part of the guilty plea. The guilty plea and a fine settled all of Pfizer's civil and criminal liability to the federal and state governments.

title: Blame This Mets Loss on Hangover From Tuesday
description: When the Mets showed up at the Metrodome on Wednesday afternoon, they seemed stuck in the late stages of Tuesday night.

title: May Stores Acquiring Marshall Field's
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Marshall Field's, one of the most venerable names in retailing, for $3.24 billion in cash.

title: Euro Cup Stadiums: Portugal Goes for the Gold
description: WHEN the World Cup matches were played in Japan and South Korea two summers ago, the stadiums built for the competition, several costing up to $200 million, were all sci-fi appeal -- gleaming spaceships with dazzling features like a retractable roof, a field floating on a bed of air and a television camera on a ceiling track that followed the action below.

title: Spitzer Aide Gets Compliance Post at Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that it had hired Beth Golden as global head of compliance. Ms. Golden was deputy of special projects for Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general. She joined Mr. Spitzer in 1999, the year he took office.

title: Seen Downtown, a New Trend In Fixtures: No Wire Hangers
description: Innovation strikes twice. At the show Downtown last month at the Chelsea Hotel in Manhattan, two chandeliers were made from plastic coat hangers. Li Edelkoort, the chairwoman of Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, told seven former students to make something with objects from cheap shops, the Salvation Army or the street. Mark van der Gronden, one former student, said, ''We came with only a pair of scissors and plastic tape.'' They used wire and glue guns to make the airy chandelier at right.

description: In a move that critics say could lead to higher telephone rates, the Bush administration on Wednesday sided with the four regional Bell companies in a court case over the fees they charge their rivals for access to their networks.

description: ''Most people who come to visit Venice, they are barbarians,'' Stefano Gorghetto said the other day, adding to insure his point was made, ''They pillage the city.''

title: SEMPRA ENERGY PROMOTES EXECUTIVE TO PRESIDENT
description: Sempra Energy, owner of the nation's largest natural gas utility, said yesterday that it had promoted Donald E. Felsinger to president and chief operating officer, and that he would succeed Stephen L. Baum as chief executive when Mr. Baum retired in 2006. Mr. Felsinger, 56, previously oversaw nonutility businesses, according to Sempra, which is based in San Diego. The chief financial officer, Neal E. Schmale, 57, will succeed Mr. Felsinger. Sempra's nonutility businesses include energy trading and development of liquefied natural gas terminals.

title: Study Finds Senior Exams Are Too Basic
description: A study of high school graduation exams, rites of passage for more than half the nation's secondary school students, shows that they largely test material taught in the 9th and 10th grades. Such material, the study said, is often taught at the middle school level in other industrialized countries.

title: Facing Marion Jones And a Lack of Options
description: Marion Jones was noticeably absent from the list of four elite track and field athletes who received official notification on Tuesday that the United States Anti-Doping Agency had begun an attempt to bar them from the Athens Olympics.

title: Militant's Defiance Puts Pakistan's Resolve in Doubt
description: A brash 27-year-old Taliban fighter named Nek Muhammad is the talk of the town in this famed border city, long a haven for adventurers, rogues and revolutionaries. His defiance raises a central question in the American-led drive against terrorism: is President Pervez Musharraf doing all he can to hunt down Osama bin Laden?

title: Bush and Chirac Break Any Tension With a Joke About Food
description: The two world leaders looked like and proclaimed themselves friends today, with hardly a hint of the deep differences that divided them over the invasion of Iraq last year.

title: Nail Bomb in a Turkish Area in Cologne Hurts 17
description: A bomb filled with nails exploded in a Turkish neighborhood in Cologne on Wednesday, wounding at least 17 people, several of them seriously, the German police said.

title: D-Day In Iraq
description: There's been some good political news out of Iraq in recent days. The newly installed -- and now U.N.-blessed -- Iraqi government is made up of some really decent people. There is hope. But it will not be realized if the sort of incident that happened last weekend keeps being repeated. Two American and two Polish employees of Blackwater USA, a security contractor, were killed in an ambush on the main road from Baghdad airport to downtown Baghdad. Remember a year ago when Saddam's spokesman, the wacky ''Baghdad Bob,'' claimed that U.S. forces didn't control the airport? We shouldn't have laughed. A year later, we still do not fully control the main road from Baghdad airport to Baghdad. You can't build anything under those conditions.

title: Lyrical Judge Praises Eminem In Lyrics Fight
description: Comparing Eminem to Benny Goodman, Elvis Presley and Paul Simon, a federal judge ruled yesterday that the company that publishes a leading hip-hop magazine was in contempt of court for failing to comply with orders in a copyright battle with the rapper.

title: Two Said to Tell Of Libyan Plot Against Saudi
description: While the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was renouncing terrorism and negotiating the lifting of sanctions last year, his intelligence chiefs ordered a covert operation to assassinate the ruler of Saudi Arabia and destabilize the oil-rich kingdom, according to statements by two participants in the conspiracy.

title: White House Shuns Role on Textile Quotas
description: More than 130 Republican and Democratic members of Congress asked President Bush on Wednesday to persuade the World Trade Organization to delay the phase-out of a global quota system on textiles and garments.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: OmniVision Technologies May Restate Results
description: OmniVision Technologies, which makes chips that run digital and mobile-telephone cameras, said yesterday that it might restate some results and that sales and profit in this quarter would miss analyst estimates. Some quarters in its last two fiscal years might be restated after a company investigation, OmniVision said. The review involves ''cut-off issues,'' the company said without elaborating. It said the restatement might increase sales by $5 million for the nine months that ended Jan. 31, and profit might rise. Tore Svanberg, an analyst with Piper Jaffray & Company, said cut-off issues would involve the timing of the company's recognition of revenue. OmniVision also delayed releasing its quarterly financial statement, which was expected yesterday. The chief financial officer, John T. Rossi, did not return calls seeking comment. OmniVision shares fell $7.84, to $17.63.

title: Nassau Health Agency Chief Is in Severance Pay Dispute
description: Questions about the legality of a $125,000 raise for the chief of Nassau County's health care agency have erupted into a furor over the possibility that his recent resignation could lead to severance claims exceeding $500,000.

title: Readers Consider the Loss of TechTV
description: Last week, I mourned the passing of TechTV, the cable channel dedicated to computers, gadgets and helping us figure them all out. Just as it had begun to flower into an indispensable national resource, it was bought by Comcast and combined with its G4 video-game channel. In the process, Comcast canceled or gutted several outstanding shows.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial production in Brazil rose for a second consecutive month in April, gaining 6.7 percent from a year earlier and 0.1 percent from March, the government said. In the first four months, output increased 6.1 percent from the 2003 period, suggesting that South America's biggest economy is on the rebound after shrinking last year for the first time in more than a decade. The Brazilian economy expanded 2.7 percent in the first quarter and is expected to grow about 3.5 percent this year. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: 11 Chinese Workers Killed in Rebel Attack in Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, June 10 — Gunmen killed 11 Chinese workers and an Afghan guard early today as they slept in their tents alongside the road they had come to rebuild. The men were among 100 Chinese engineers and construction workers who had recently arrived in Afghanistan to work on a World Bank road project on a road running north from Kabul to its northern border with Tajikistan. Some of those killed had only been in the country a few days, the Chinese news agency Xinhua reported.

description: CASTELLOTTI -- Madeline. We deeply mourn the passing of our dearest and beloved friend, Madeline Castellotti on June 7. Madeline's strong work ethic and entrepreneurial leadership in her family business, John's Pizzeria, will be greatly missed by one and all--she was an outstanding businesswoman! Her friendship, guidance and wisdom will be profoundly missed by her many friends and colleagues. We extend our sincerest condolences to her son and daughter, Peter and Lisa, and the entire family. Linda S. Charette Robert D. O'Mara

description: Paris's mayor, Bertrand Delano, has invited four architectural firms to reconsider the entire 36-acre site of Les Halles.

description: Golf's new sultans of swing take their style as seriously as their scorecards.

description: Andy Newman captured a glimpse into the rhythms of a place that millions pass through each year but no one ever visits.

description: Pinar Yolacan, a Turkey native and recent graduate of Cooper Union, originally envisioned this portfolio as a performance piece.

description: Ray Charles, or "the Genius" as his fans refer to him, died at the age of 73.

description: Thousands of people, from Eagle Scouts and construction workers to the famous and powerful, paid tribute on Thursday to former President Ronald Reagan at the Capitol Rotunda.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sabotage Cuts Power to More Than 100 Key Electrical Lines
description: Sabotage attacks have cut the power flowing through more than 100 of the lines that form the backbone of Iraq's electrical grid since the American-led invasion last year, and nearly 1,200 of the huge towers supporting the lines have been toppled, according to an internal Iraqi government report obtained by The New York Times.

title: Corrections
description: A TV Watch article on Monday about the season finale of ''The Sopranos'' on HBO misstated the outcome of an attack by the character Tony B. on his Korean boss in an earlier episode. The boss was injured, not killed. It also referred incorrectly to a member of Johnny Sack's mob killed by Tony B. He was not a captain.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrests In 2 Bombings
description: The deputy prosecutor general, Sergei Fridinsky, told the Interfax news agency that two suspects had been arrested in the May 9 killing of the pro-Moscow Chechen president, Akhmad Kadyrov. He would say only that the two are Chechen residents aged 28 and 22. Mr. Kadyrov was killed when a bomb went in Grozny, the Chechen capital. In a separate action, the police in the south Russian city of Samara seized five Chechens suspected of involvement in a June 4 bomb blast that killed 11 people at a local market, Russian news agencies reported. The police have not determined whether the attack was a result of terrorism or gang warfare. A Russian human rights group charged that ethnic Chechens in Samara were being targeted in indiscriminate police raids. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWE, MILTON
description: LOWE--Milton. Heartfelt condolences to our cherished friends Mona, Francine and Sheldon. We all mourn the loss of your wonderful Dad. Love, The Cohens The Kaplans

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Friday with the Living Here column, about environmentally sensitive houses, was published in error. It showed Donna and Harry Gazelle at their house in Sunapee, N.H., which is discussed in today's column, on Page 7. (Brian and Betsey Olenick Dougherty are shown above at their house in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., which was discussed last week.)

title: Faster than you can say 'new generation,' Ted Sann is out at BBDO.
description: THE generational changing of the guard at the tradition-minded BBDO Worldwide accelerated yesterday with the unexpected departure of a longtime creative leader, Ted Sann.

title: 6 Acquitted in Killing of Russian Journalist
description: A military court on Thursday acquitted all six defendants in the 1994 killing of an investigative journalist who had uncovered graft in the Russian armed forces.

title: Taking Aim at the Professional Rodeo Circuit's Drug of Choice
description: That Copenhagen Cowboy, as they called Kent Cooper, was a saddle bronc rider on the rodeo circuit, one of the best in the world at trying to keep his spurs high on a horse that wanted no part of him. When he died two years ago at 47, the throat cancer was so bad it wrapped around his jugular vein and got into his brain.

title: Roosevelt Brown, 71, Dies; Hall of Fame Giants Tackle
description: Roosevelt Brown, the Hall of Fame offensive tackle who spent the last 51 years with the Giants as a player, an assistant coach and a scout, died Wednesday at his home in Columbus, N.J. He was 71.

title: With Mayor Out, the People Move In; New York Finds Many Uses for Gracie Mansion
description: Of the many unusual moves that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made right after taking office, one of the most notable was his choice to remain in his Upper East Side townhouse rather than move into Gracie Mansion, home to every mayor since Fiorello H. La Guardia. Instead, Mr. Bloomberg said the historic mansion would be used as ''the people's house.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, the fifth-largest United States bank, and the Mexican unit of HSBC Holdings, London, agreed to form a joint network to try to capture more of the $14 billion in transfers sent home annually from Mexican workers abroad. The agreement will allow Wells Fargo's InterCuenta Express service customers to collect money transfers at HSBC's 1,400 branches and 4,500 automatic teller machines.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Suit In Death Of 3-Year Old
description: The family of 3-year-old Amir Beeks, whose sexually assaulted and battered body was found in a Woodbridge culvert last year, has filed suit against the town's school board, as well as the state's Division of Youth and Family Services, for what it charged was negligence in supervising the troubled boy who was convicted of killing him. The boy, now 11, whom the authorities have never named, was sentenced last year to 18 years in a juvenile detention facility for luring the toddler away from a library and killing him. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Ronald Reagan's legacy on budgets and taxes misidentified the author of the book ''The Price of Loyalty,'' in which Paul H. O'Neill, President Bush's first Treasury secretary, was quoted as attributing to Vice President Dick Cheney the comment ''Reagan proved deficits don't matter.'' The book was by Ron Suskind, not by Mr. O'Neill.

title: And Now Back to Our Regularly Scheduled Program ...
description: With Ronald Reagan's funeral in the nation's capital now concluded, operatives in the competing presidential campaigns were practically counting the minutes until they could get back to the rivalry that was suspended this week because of the tribute ceremonies for the former president.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Sales Rise 34%
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it had fourth-quarter profit of $126.4 million as demand in Asia helped lift sales 34 percent. Per-share profit was 32 cents, contrasted with a net loss of 1 cent a share, or $4.4 million, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose to $571.2 million in the quarter ended May 30 from $425.3 million. Demand for chips used in cellphones and cameras bolstered sales. Shares of National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose 19 cents, to close at $21.34.

title: ANADARKO'S PLAN TO SELL ASSETS LEADS TO A RISE IN SHARES
description: Shares of the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, a United States oil and natural gas producer, rose yesterday after the company announced plans to sell more than $2.5 billion in assets and buy back up to $2 billion of its stock. The shares rose $1.50, or 2.7 percent, to $57.58 on the New York Stock Exchange. Anadarko, based near Houston, has been the top-performing oil and gas explorer in the last year among members of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The chief executive, James Hackett, said on Wednesday that Anadarko planned to sell properties that account for about 25 percent of output to strengthen its balance sheet and free resources for more promising projects.

title: Cashman And Wells Trade Barbs
description: David Wells is eager to pitch against one of the most formidable lineups in the major leagues when he opposes his once-beloved Yankees for San Diego on Sunday. It is evident that Wells no longer feels as warm and fuzzy as he used to about the Yankees.

title: St. Louis Named N.H.L.'s Best
description: Three days after winning the Stanley Cup, the Tampa Bay Lightning received more trophies last night in Toronto.

title: A Colony Lost, A Tradition Lingers
description: THIRTY-THREE summers is an awfully long time to spend covered in body paint, whooping your way across a stage in the mosquito-drenched heat of coastal North Carolina, and last winter Bob Midgette thought seriously about hanging up his coyote-trimmed loincloth for good.

title: Like a Bird in Flight: Capturing Today's Chinese Culture in Transition
description: What does a makeover of 5,000 years of culture feel like? Ask China, because that's what's happening there. Ancient cities are coming down; new ones are going up. Urban markets are spilling over with Western-style products. To a sizable segment of a youth-heavy population, the Cultural Revolution is a phantom, the tragedy of Tiananmen Square, yesterday's inexplicable news.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about families in which children's sports commitments restrict visits to weekend houses misstated one of the sports played by Paige Rudzin. She plays softball, not football.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, BERNARD
description: WALSH--Bernard. 91, a hero of D-Day, three times decorated, died on its 60th anniversary. He was a sculptor of great sensitivity and eloquence. He was also an innovator of framing designs who pioneered in conservation techniques. He is survived by Annie, his wife of 68 years, his daughter-in-law Susan and grandchildren Samuel and Leah. Requiescat in pace, dearest Bern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDFARB, RABBI MORRIS
description: GOLDFARB--Rabbi Morris. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi of the Hillel Foundation at Cornell for 32 years. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: Shares Are Modestly Higher, Up in a Short Trading Week
description: Shares made modest gains yesterday, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index posting a third consecutive weekly gain, the longest such stretch since January. Energy shares led the market amid optimism that economic and profit growth would withstand rising commodity prices for crude oil.

title: Edge Is All To Athletes, Balco Case Reveals
description: While it remains unclear how many track and field athletes will be disqualified from the Athens Olympics for their involvement in the unfolding Balco steroids case, one thing is certain, experts in sports doping say: some athletes have been willing to go to extraordinary lengths to circumvent traditional drug screening, apparently even using a drug designed to fatten cattle.

title: Employers to Form 'Buyers Club' Seeking Low Drug Prices
description: Hoping to slow the rising cost of providing health coverage, 50 of the country's largest employers are creating a buyers club to bargain directly with drug makers on behalf of five million active and retired employees and their families.

title: Legacy of Reagan Now Begins the Test of Time
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt once defined great presidents as those who were ''leaders of thought at times when certain ideas in the life of the nation had to be clarified.''

title: Rebel Cleric's Fighters Seize a Police Station in Najaf
description: Militiamen loyal to the rebel Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr seized a police station in the center of Najaf on Thursday, set prisoners free and allowed looters to plunder the building, witnesses and Iraqi security officials said.

title: Cleric's Aide Backs New Iraq Government; Clashes Continue
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 11  A representative of the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr endorsed the new Iraqi government in a sermon today, marking a reversal by Mr. Sadr. The representative also asked members of Mr. Sadr's militia to obey orders, an implicit request to adhere to a cease-fire that was broken this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GASSMAN, IRVING
description: GASSMAN--Irving. June 10, 2004 at age 92. Beloved husband of the late Ray, father of Arlene Ellner May, Elyse Gordon, and Stephen Gassman and father-in-law to Meryl. Beloved grandfather to Rachel Ellner, David and Bic Gassman, Darren and Apryl Gassman, Rachel and Russell Mindick, Jeffrey Scott, Lance Gordon and Ronnie Gordon. Great-grandfather to Arianna and Michael. He will be dearly missed. May he rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NWAJIDE, DR. ISAAC NNAMDI
description: NWAJIDE--Dr. Isaac Nnamdi on June 6, 2004 at the age of 47. With heavy hearts we mourn the sudden death of our most beloved husband, father, brother, friend, Pediatrician and son-in-law. Dr. Nwajide lived life with vision, energy and passion that touched all who knew him. Visitation at Edward F. Lieber Funeral Home, 266 North Central Ave, Valley Stream, NY, Friday 6pm to 9pm and Saturday 10am to 1pm.

title: Finally, an Old Dog That Can Learn New Tricks
description: Reports from owners notwithstanding, scientists have yet to discover a dog that can talk. But German researchers say they have found one that listens and learns like a human child.

title: Jazz Impresario Tries New Idea: Jazz, Just Jazz
description: George Wein is giving jazz a chance this year. For the 50th anniversary of his Newport Jazz Festival in mid-August -- now called JVC-Newport, since the Japanese electronics company for which it is named started sponsoring a number of his festivals in 1974 -- the titan of American jazz festivals is trying out a full schedule of the real acoustic thing.

description: Correction Appended

title: Behind Trans-Atlantic Cordiality: A Little Give and Take
description: A bit over a year ago, as demonstrations against the Iraq war mounted and the leaders of France and Germany campaigned passionately against the United States in the United Nations, the question was, how did trans-Atlantic relations get so bad so quickly?

title: Signs of Testosterone Are All Over the Universe
description: The concentration of synthetic hormones pumping through the vascular system of ''The Chronicles of Riddick'' matches any recent action-adventure movie in the sheer density of steroids per liter of body fluid. In its primitive universe of clanging armor and giant stone structures -- at once prehistoric and futuristic -- the faces are so grim you might conclude that except for a malevolent smirk or two, smiling must be against the law.

title: Gorbachev Honors His Enemy And Friend
description: His solemn duties for the day came first, and Mikhail S. Gorbachev bowed his head before the coffin of Ronald Reagan in the Capitol Rotunda on Thursday and stopped at Blair House to pay a condolence call on Nancy Reagan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARBALLEIRA, MANUEL J. M.D.
description: CARBALLEIRA--Manuel J. M.D., on June 10, 2004. Graduate of Columbia College and Medical School. Served our country as a Major in the U.S. Army during WW II. On staff at St. Clare's Hospital, Doctor's Hospital and French Hospital as well as having a private practice in NYC. House Doctor for the Metropolitan Opera for 15 years. Dr. Carballeira was very proud of his Spanish heritage and will always be remembered as a physician who was devoted to his community, patients and family. He was decorated by King Juan Carlos I for his service to the Spanish Diplomatic community in the United States. He is survived by his loving wife Assunta (Sunny) (nee Rockicioli). Cherished father of Catherine, Joseph and Katie, Andrew and Margaret and Lita and Danny. Dearest brother of Amelia Abella and the late Robert. Beloved grandfather of Andrew, James, Brooke, Christopher, Matthew, Rose, William, Joseph and Caroline. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Friday 2-5 and 7-10pm. Funeral Mass Saturday St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church at 9:15am. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: The Disability Lobby and Voting
description: Two obvious requirements for a fair election are that voters should have complete confidence about their ballots' being counted accurately and that everyone, including the disabled, should have access to the polls. It is hard to imagine advocates for those two goals fighting, but lately that seems to be what's happening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUSSMAN, ALBERT
description: SUSSMAN--Albert. We are so grateful for our lives being enriched by Al Sussman. We remember him with great appreciation and gratitude for the enormous contribution to our industry. He was a ''mensch.'' Kimco Realty Corporation Martin S. Kimmel Milton Cooper

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 28 about a federal corruption investigation of two former aides to Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey gave an incorrect description of the officials who confirmed that it was the aides, Gary B. Taffet and Paul A. Levinsohn, who were secretly taperecorded by an informer. The officials were federal investigators speaking on the condition of anonymity, not prosecutors with the United States attorney's office speaking in court.

title: Punishing The Poor
description: If you want to see ''compassionate'' conservatism in action, take a look at Mississippi, a state that is solidly in the red category (strong for Bush) and committed to its long tradition of keeping the poor and the unfortunate in as ragged and miserable a condition as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRANE, PATRICIA ANNE
description: CRANE--Patricia Anne. Of New York City, formerly of Aurora. Daughter of Thomas and Sharon Crane. Memorial Mass to be celebrated Monday, June 14th, 10 AM at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church, 348 E. 55th St.

title: A Smile That Stretches From Melancholy to Euphoria
description: The essence of Brazilian bossa nova as defined by its greatest composer, Antonio Carlos Jobim, is a mood of subdued yearning known as saudade, a Portuguese word that has no exact English equivalent. But in the hands of the guitarist, singer and all-around entertainer John Pizzarelli, the subtle balance between quiet joy and melancholy tilts decisively toward optimism.

title: Yanks' Front Office Watches Brown's Back, and the News Is Good
description: The Yankees seem to have survived a scare with starter Kevin Brown. A magnetic resonance imaging on his back yesterday did not show serious damage, according to a person who was told of the results.

title: An Economic Legend
description: In the movie ''The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance,'' a reporter defends prettifying history: ''This is the West, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.'' That principle has informed many of this week's Reagan retrospectives. But let's not be bullied into accepting the right-wing legend about Reaganomics.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Defense Minister Hospitalized
description: Defense Minister Peter Struck, 61, was hospitalized with heart problems, his ministry said. Mr. Struck returned to Germany on Tuesday from an exhausting trip to the Middle East and the Horn of Africa. It is not certain that he will be able to travel to Afghanistan next week as planned. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an emergency drill at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., misstated the position taken by Putnam County toward the emergency plan. The county did not refuse to endorse the plan; it supported it. An article on Wednesday about the drill misidentified the United States representative whose district includes the plant. She is Sue Kelly. (Nita M. Lowey's district includes parts of the evacuation zone, which covers areas within 10 miles of the plant.)

description: Lawyers for Stewart Request New Trial Again

title: Import Prices Increase 1.6%, Biggest Surge in 15 Months
description: United States import prices rose 1.6 percent last month, the biggest increase in 15 months, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The increase, which followed a 0.2 percent rise in April, was led by energy prices that were twice what economists had forecast.

description: There Goes The Letterman Booking

title: Venezuelan Recall Is in Dispute Even Before the Vote
description: Touch-screen voting machines, which have been plagued by security and reliability concerns in the United States, will be used in the recall vote on President Hugo Chvez, prompting his foes and foreign diplomats to contend that the left-leaning government may use the equipment to manipulate the vote.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: For Reagan, All Life Was Sacred
description: Ronald Reagan had not passed from this life for 48 hours before proponents of human embryonic stem-cell research began to suggest that such ethically questionable scientific work should be promoted under his name. But this cannot honestly be done without ignoring President Reagan's own words and actions.

title: United and Its Unions Agree On Benefit Cuts for Retirees
description: United Airlines reached an agreement with its unions yesterday on a plan to cut health care benefits for 50,000 retired workers and their family members, eliminating one of the biggest issues facing the airline, which is reorganizing under court protection.

title: Asian Scavengers Feed China's Hunger for Steel
description: At an abandoned Soviet Army base here, scavengers dig deep into the earth. Tossing aside concrete casings, they carry away precious loot: cast-iron water pipes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOMENZO, JOHN P.
description: LOMENZO--John P. Former New York State Secretary of State, Monroe County Court Judge, died June 7, 2004 at age 88 in Rochester, NY. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy; children, Jacqueline (Joseph) McGuire, John P. (Sophia) Lomenzo Jr., Nancy (Peter) Muller, Daniel (Joo) Lomenzo, Susan Lomenzo (Steven Kallen); grandchildren, Marcie (James) Burns, Daniel (Anastasia) and Erin McGuire, Michael and David (Deborah) Lomenzo, Anthony and Jacqueline Muller, Joony, Nicholas and Lee Lomenzo; brothers and sisters-in-law; and many nieces and nephews. A Funeral Mass will be held Saturday, 10 am, at St. Louis Church, 60 S. Main St., Pittsford, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to The School Of The Holy Childhood, 100 Groton Parkway, Rochester, 14623 or to the Alzheimer's Association, 435 E. Henrietta Rd.,Rochester, 14620. Expressions of sympathy may be mailed to his son at 4 Forest Grove Ct., Penfield, NY 14526.

title: A Nerdy Nobody of a Hero Who Proves to Be Napoleonic
description: One of the overarching jokes in ''Napoleon Dynamite,'' the odd, amusing debut of the 24-year-old filmmaker Jared Hess, is that such a grandiose, explosive title should be attached to such a small-scale, deadpan film. Napoleon Dynamite is also the name of the movie's awkward, frizzy-haired hero, a high school student in Preston, Idaho, whose world-conquering potential is invisible to everyone but him.

title: Weekender | Bradley Beach, N.J.
description: BEHIND the wide, sandy Atlantic shore and the gleaming boardwalk of Bradley Beach, in cozy neighborhoods of shaded lawns and frame houses with porches and peaked roofs, power saws buzz and hammers thud. In Bradley Beach, a small town on the Jersey Shore that is just 7 blocks wide and 13 blocks long, at least one renovation seems to be under way on every block.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the major league baseball draft included two erroneous references to the number of high school players chosen at the beginning of the process. The San Diego Padres were not the only team in the top five to take a high school player; the Milwaukee Brewers, who had the fifth choice, selected pitcher Mark Rogers of Mount Ararat High School in Orr's Island, Me. And after the Padres made their selection, six of the next nine choices were college pitchers, not seven of the nine.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on May 29 about a New York Philharmonic concert at which some audience members tried out hand-held computers that delivered analysis of the program with video images misstated the reason the pianist Leon Fleisher was not shown. While he did balk at the use of the device's commentary during his performance, he would not have been shown in any case: the single camera used for the program was fixed on Lorin Maazel, the conductor.

title: Univision Sues to Stop TV Rating System in Los Angeles
description: Critics of the changes Nielsen Media Research is making in the way it measures television ratings in major urban markets have taken their fight to the courthouse.

title: Contreras Gives Yanks Reason To Believe
description: Choo Freeman, the Colorado Rockies' No. 9 hitter with no career homers, had just crunched a high fastball into Monument Park. The Yankees had lost the lead in the fourth inning, and the game had reached a crisis point, as it always seems to when Jos Contreras is pitching.

title: Ex-Director Says Tyco Board Did Not Approve Large Bonus
description: The board of Tyco International never approved a $17 million bonus for its former general counsel, Mark A. Belnick, a former director testified yesterday at Mr. Belnick's criminal fraud trial.

description: The following is the text of the remarks by former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney at the funeral for former President Reagan, as transcribed by Federal News Service.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Producer Prices Rise
description: Japan's corporate goods price index rose 1.1 percent in May from a year earlier, the biggest increase in six and a half years, driven by rising prices for steel and oil. The rise in prices that companies pay for goods suggested Japan's long bout of deflation may be ending, though recent data show consumer prices are not rising as much. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Tourists Hurt In Danube Boat Crash
description: A German-owned boat carrying American, British and Canadian tourists on the Danube River hit a pillar of the Reichsbrcke bridge in central Vienna, injuring 19 passengers. The collision happened as the boat, European Viking, was turning. The ship was still functional, and the bridge, a popular landmark in Vienna, was only slightly damaged. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIDGES, CHRISTINE PAS ZKIEWICZ
description: BRIDGES -- Christine Pas zkiewicz. The Board of Trustees of Notre Dame School records with sorrow the death of Christine Paszkiewicz Bridges, '70, former trustee, loyal alumna and generous benefactor. A memorial Mass will be held at Notre Dame School in the fall.

description: The Bloomberg administration took issue yesterday with a City Council bill that would ban the sale and installation of certain car alarms, arguing that it was overly broad and could undermine police efforts to reduce auto thefts.

title: Oradour-sur-Glane Journal; Where 642 Died, a Wound Too Deep for Time to Heal
description: Sixty years ago, just days after Allied troops stormed the beaches of Normandy, a German convoy rolled into this sleepy town, rounded up its residents and gunned them to the ground before setting the buildings and the piles of still writhing bodies on fire.

title: A Top Pakistani General Escapes an Assassination Attempt That Kills 10 People
description: Suspected Islamic militants ambushed the motorcade of a top Pakistani general in the heart of the battered southern port city of Karachi on Thursday morning, killing six soldiers, three policemen and a civilian, but leaving the general unhurt, military officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSNER, CHARLES A.
description: POSNER--Charles A. Devoted husband, father, grandfather and distinguished jurist. Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty mourns with his beloved wife Lynn, their children Beth and Mark and grandchildren. Judge Posner was our valued board member 2 decades. His leadership helped serve tens of thousands of needy New Yorkers. He will be sorely missed. Joseph C. Shenker, President Merryl H. Tisch, Chairman William E. Rapfogel, CEO

title: Major Step Toward Casino In the Catskills
description: A $500 million Las Vegas-style casino in the Catskills moved significantly closer to reality yesterday when the Pataki administration signed an agreement with the Cayuga Indian Nation, settling the tribe's 200-year-old claim to 64,000 acres in upstate New York in exchange for casino revenues.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Ex-Governor Pleads Not Guilty
description: Donald Siegelman, the former governor, pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy and fraud. Mr. Siegelman and a former aide, Paul M. Hamrick, are accused of using $550,000 in state education money to rig bids to help Dr. Phillip K. Bobo win a contract to run a maternity health program for the poor. Mr. Hamrick and Dr. Bobo also pleaded not guilty. Mr. Siegelman, a Democrat who served from 1999 to 2003, has said the charges are politically motivated. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: On the Rugby Pitch, Reliving Old Battles (Emphasis on Old)
description: JUST down the road from the Robert Frost museum, two rugby pitches are laid out on the grassy runway of an old glider port. It is midmorning on the first Saturday in June, and as the sun arches over Kinsman Mountain, distinguished-looking gentlemen in shorts and striped jerseys begin running up and down, zipping a fat, oval ball among them. Ankle supports and knee braces and the occasional missing tooth are common. We look like a bunch of pirates.

title: Filling Hotel Rooms One Tank at a Time
description: IT'S too early to tell how much gasoline prices topping $2 a gallon will depress enthusiasm for travel this summer, but many tourist businesses aren't waiting for a definitive answer. title: Ex-Adelphia Officer Testifies He Never Told Board of Cash
description: Michael C. Mulcahey, the former assistant treasurer for Adelphia Communications who is on trial on fraud charges, testified yesterday that he never told independent directors about cash advances he had arranged for the company's founder, John J. Rigas, and two of his sons.

title: A Longer Wait For Citizenship And the Ballot
description: New York, long the doorway for immigrants seeking entry into American society, now has one of the nation's longest backlogs of newcomers awaiting answers to their citizenship applications. It now typically takes triple the time to become a United States citizen in New York as in San Antonio -- a year and a half compared with six months.

title: Rebel Barista With a Cause (Make That a Venti)
description: IN the cozy corporate lingo of Starbucks, the java-servers in company baseball caps and green aprons are so far evolved from folks who, in quainter, less caffeinated and less linguistically sensitive times, were dubbed soda jerks, that the coffee chain graces them with a special name: baristas. The moniker conveys a Euro-cachet, implies a certain skill set and is the entry-level niche at a $15 billion behemoth with a hot -- in more ways than one -- product and a rung on the Fortune 100 best-places-to-work list.

title: Russian Music Coloring a Magic Realm and a Nod to Mozart
description: The New York City Ballet danced with marvelous energy on Tuesday as it opened its Russian Music Festival at the New York State Theater. This series of programs to Russian scores continues through June 27, when the seasonlong Balanchine centennial celebration concludes.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Floor Fans Recalled
description: More than two million floor fans sold mostly at Home Depot stores have been recalled because of electrical problems that have caused fires, federal officials said. The distributor of the fans, the SMC Marketing Corporation of Grand Prairie, Tex., and Home Depot, based in Atlanta, announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The oscillating motion of the fans has damaged power cords on some of them, with the fans' plastic exteriors burning and melting. The recall includes 18-inch, pedestal fans with model number SR-18 or SP-18. The commission urged owners to return the fans to Home Depot for credit. John Files (NYT)

The fleet and the lucky reach the gates just as the conductor shouts, ''All aboard!'' Sweaty and winded, they flop into their seats with self-satisfied laughter as the train pulls away.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor Resigning
description: William Josephson, an assistant attorney general who shook up nonprofit organizations nationwide with his aggressive oversight of charities and foundations in New York, will leave his post this summer, the office of the attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, said yesterday. Mr. Josephson, a close confidant of Sargent Shriver and a founder of the Peace Corps, pressed for stronger regulation of nonprofit groups and more accountability. Mr. Josephson's office found financial mismanagement at Hale House and the Black United Fund of New York. Gerald Rosenberg, a lawyer who has specialized in nonprofit matters, will succeed him. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Three Kinds of Spirituality From Romanticism's Heyday

title: Judge Helps A Defendant Elude Arrest At Courthouse
description: A judge ordered a defendant to leave a Queens courtroom through a side door yesterday so he could elude a detective waiting in a hallway to arrest him in a separate robbery case, the police said. The judge's action prompted the police commissioner to call for a judicial misconduct investigation.

title: S.E.C. REVIEWS TRADES MADE BY CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF SWIFT

Mr. Moyes, who according to Swift made $622,000 trading 187,000 shares last month, is cooperating with the informal inquiry, Swift, of Phoenix, said. Swift said that outside council was examining purchases by Mr. Moyes and broker trades for a company buyback before it raised a profit forecast.

The legislation has been proposed by the Senate or Assembly for years. This year, the Assembly passed it, but not the Senate. Yesterday, Common Cause of New York, the League of Women Voters and the New York Public Interest Research Group released a report on lobbying called ''Out of Control,'' and urged the Senate to pass the bill. John E. McArdle, a Senate spokesman, said the Senate would pass a lobbying bill before the session ends. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Victoria, British Columbia
description: THOUGH elegant Victoria, at the southern tip of Vancouver Island, is the capital of British Columbia, it is actually closer to the United States than to the Canadian mainland. On a clear day the peaks of the Olympic Mountains in Washington seem tantalizingly close to visitors strolling along Dallas Road, a winding stretch of beachfront that curves around to meet Victoria's picturesque, boat-lined Inner Harbor. When dusk falls, the lights of Port Angeles, Wash., wink across the Strait of Juan de Fuca from Victoria's own spectacularly lighted provincial Parliament buildings and the landmark Fairmont Empress hotel. Victoria invites exploration with a lively and compact downtown, abundant parkland, miles of trails and what has been called the mildest climate in Canada. Taking a spin around the Tudor-style neighborhoods (a tribute to the city's English heritage) of suburban Oak Bay, cyclists can stop for picnic lunch near a towering totem pole (a symbol of the area's indigenous people) in Beacon Hill Park. For now, this gem of a city remains relatively uncrowded, but when the Winter Games come to the nearby mainland city of Vancouver in 2010, the secret will be out. BONNIE TSUI

title: CHRYSLER FACES AN EXTENDED INVESTIGATION INTO AIRBAGS
description: The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler faces an expanded federal investigation of almost 1.3 million minivans because they may have an airbag defect similar to a problem that caused a 2002 recall. The inquiry covers 1998 to 2000 models of Caravan, Grand Caravan, Voyager, Grand Voyager and Town and Country, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said yesterday. A faulty clock spring may cause a circuit failure, with the driver's airbag, horn or cruise control not working, the agency said on its Web site. The agency and Chrysler have received 782 complaints about the possible defect, with reports of four crashes with injuries, a spokesman, Tim Hurd, said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syosset: Two People Die In House Fire
description: A man and a woman were killed in a fire in a split-level house last night, according to the Nassau County police. The victims, described by the police as elderly, appeared to have been dead when firefighters removed them from the house at 46 Marlene Drive, Officer Bill Bendel said. The fire broke out about 8 p.m., fire officials said. Authorities did not immediately release the names of the victims. Two firefighters were treated for minor injuries. A neighbor, Alan Wagner, identified one resident of the house as Marc Fredericks. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fauchon Closing 2 Of 3 Stores
description: Fauchon, the Paris-based luxury-food company, will close two of its three Manhattan stores today. The company will maintain its store at 442 Park Avenue, at 56th Street, but is closing the store at 1000 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, the former site of the Sant Ambroeus coffee shop and restaurant, and the one at 1383 Third Avenue, at 78th Street. Dale Dewey, who has been the chief executive officer of Fauchon's American division since a change in management in January, said the shops had been doing well but the company now wants to expand by having its products sold in Neiman-Marcus stores instead of in its own chain of shops. He confirmed that negotiations were under way for Sant Ambroeus to move back into the store at 1000 Madison Avenue. Dimitri Pauli, owner of Sant Ambroeus, which now has a restaurant and bakery in Greenwich Village, refused to comment. Florence Fabricant (NYT)

title: OWENS CORNING IS NOT EXPECTED TO EXIT BANKRUPTCY IN '04
description: Executives at Owens Corning, the building products maker, said yesterday that it was unlikely the company would emerge from bankruptcy protection in 2004, despite prompt action by the judge who has been appointed to take over the case. The executives said they were confident that Federal District Court Judge John P. Fullam would get the case back on track quickly. But getting a confirmed reorganization plan in place before the end of the year seems unlikely, said Michael Thaman, Owens Corning's chairman and chief financial officer. Owens Corning's exit plan hinges on winning a ruling from Judge Fullam that the company and its units will be treated as one for purposes of the bankruptcy proceedings.

title: For a Theater, Good Connections Pay Off
description: The success of the Signature Theater Company is, in the end, irrefutable evidence of the power of one good idea. In 1991, James Houghton, then an aspiring director in his early 30's, came up with a plan for a theater company whose mission was deceptively simple: each season would be devoted to one playwright, who could do any of his or her work, new or old.

His co-star is his wife, Lisa Chess, also playing herself as a stage and film actress whose career has taken a backseat to her husband's, putting a strain on their relationship that can't be terribly unusual in Hollywood.

title: Corrections

It was a collection donated by Nabokov to the Library of Congress between 1958 and 1965, not one acquired by the Berg Collection of the New York Public Library in 1991. A reader reported the error a few days after publication; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Suicides At Record High
description: Suicides hit a record high of 32,082 last year as the economy struggled to emerge from a prolonged slump. It was the second year in a row in which suicides have risen, and the number represented a 1 percent increase over the 2002 level. Japan and the United States have roughly the same number of suicides, but the United States has more than twice the population of Japan. No religious prohibition exists against suicide in Japan. Historically, it has been seen as a way to escape failure. James Brooke (NYT)
