title: National Briefing | Washington: Judicial Complaint Committee Meets
description: The Supreme Court was the site of the first meeting of a committee established by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to study the handling of complaints against judges of the lower federal courts. The committee is headed by Justice Stephen G. Breyer, left, with four other federal judges and the chief justice's administrative assistant, Sally M. Rider, as members. When the committee was announced last month, its mission was widely misunderstood to be a review of judicial ethics. Instead, Justice Breyer said, its task is the ''narrow but important'' one of evaluating the effectiveness of the 1980 law that set procedures for handling complaints about judicial misconduct. The committee will begin by examining a sample of complaints against judges during the last several years. Linda Greenhouse (NYT)

title: IRAQ UPDATE
description: CAUTION ON NATO ROLE -- President Bush said he did not expect NATO to provide troops to strengthen or replace American forces in Iraq, sounding more cautious than he had before about a possible future NATO role. Mr. Bush's comments came at the end of the Group of 8 meeting, where President Jacques Chirac of France expressed opposition to any broad NATO intervention and made clear that his split with Mr. Bush over Iraq had not completely healed. At a news conference, Mr. Bush also said he could not remember whether he had seen secret Pentagon and Justice Department legal opinions that he was not bound by prohibitions against torture in questioning detainees in the fight against terrorism. title: A Troubling Dissent
description: The Supreme Court did the right thing this week by staying out of a Colorado redistricting dispute. It properly deferred to the Colorado Supreme Court's ruling resolving the matter. What is troubling, however, is a dissent by Chief Justice William Rehnquist and two of his colleagues that argues for diving into the conflict. Given these justices' eagerness to defer to the states in other matters, the dissent smacks of partisan politics and raises new concerns about the court's neutrality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHARLES, SAUL
description: CHARLES--Saul. 87, of Fort Lee, NJ and Boca Raton, FL. Husband of Edna (Kotin). Father of Linda Fishman, Amy Charles, and Dr. Robert Charles. One of the founders/ owners of Popular Club Plan and J. Crew Inc.

title: 2001 Mark Green Campaign Draws Prosecutor's Attention
description: The Brooklyn district attorney's office is investigating whether the 2001 mayoral campaign of Mark Green paid for a set of campaign fliers without properly reporting the expenditure, a law enforcement official said yesterday. The fliers and their origin became a major source of contention during that year's Democratic mayoral primary.

title: Kittles and Houston May Become Expansion Draft Bait
description: Isiah Thomas picked up the phone yesterday and called five Knicks. He needed all his charm and charisma to convince them that they were still important players despite what he was about to tell them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ex-Mitsubishi Chief Arrested
description: Japanese police have arrested a former president of Mitsubishi Motors and five other former executives on charges related to the company's failure to disclose a vehicle defect suspected of causing a fatal accident in 2002. The arrests follow admissions in recent months by Mitsubishi that its managers concealed knowledge about defective cars and trucks even after the company promised to come clean about such problems following a major cover-up scandal four years ago. Police arrested Katsuhiko Kawasoe, 67, left, who was president of the ailing automaker from 1997 until 2000. Mr. Kawasoe resigned after the company disclosed that it had hidden evidence of vehicle defects from regulators for more than two decades. Mr. Kawasoe and the five other former executives are being held on suspicion that they committed professional negligence resulting in death, according to a police official in Kanagawa Prefecture, west of Tokyo. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Central Bank Rate Unchanged
description: South Korea's central bank left its main interest rate at a record low for an 11th straight month after a government report showed consumer confidence dropped for the third time in four months. The Bank of Korea's governor, Park Seung, and his six fellow policy makers kept the overnight call rate at 3.75 percent at their monthly monetary policy meeting in Seoul. ''Domestic demand continues to be weak even as exports are healthy,'' Mr. Park said at a news conference after the decision. ''We will review our interest rate policy if the economy improves and prices become unstable.''

description: Israel is willing to pay compensation in advance to encourage Jewish settlers to leave the Gaza Strip, rather than face forced evacuation next year, government officials said Thursday.

description: Atext of former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's eulogy at the funeral of former President Ronald Reagan. Mrs. Thatcher, who has suffered a series of strokes, paid tribute to President Reagan in videotaped remarks. :

description: Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance company, has completed plans for the succession of top executives and for ensuring compliance with accounting rules and other laws, the company said yesterday, giving no details.

description: The Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, yesterday won the $100,000 Grand Prize Kelly Award, at the 23rd annual Kelly Awards for creativity in magazine advertising. The award came for a campaign for the Apple iPod that shows iPod users in silhouette against colorful backgrounds.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Report Faults Shell
description: Royal Dutch/Shell's oil operations in Nigeria play a role in feeding the continuing conflict in the country, a company report has found. Nigerian labor unions were in the second day of a nationwide strike to protest the recent increase in gasoline prices there, the latest in a decade of demonstrations protesting how little of the profits reaped from the oil-rich country reach some of its citizens. The strike has halted transportation and closed stores and schools, but has not yet affected the amount of oil flowing from the region, energy experts said. Nigerian oil made up 11 percent of crude imports to the United States in the first quarter of 2004, according to PFC Energy, a Washington consulting firm. ''We sometimes feed conflict by the way we award contracts, gain access to land and deal with community representatives,'' said the Shell report, an annual review of the effect the company's policies have on sustainable development. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Terror Suspect in Italy Linked to More Plots
description: A suspected ringleader of the Madrid train bombings who was arrested Tuesday has taken credit for orchestrating the attacks and has boasted that he was about to send a team of suicide bombers to Iraq, according to intercepts of his conversations monitored by Italy's anti-terrorism unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REAGAN, PRESIDENT RONALD
description: REAGAN--President Ronald. Florence D'Urso and her family mourn the loss of a great man and dear friend, our nation's beloved president, Ronald W. Reagan. His optimism and vision made our world a richer place; and his love of God and country set a beautiful example. We will be forever grateful to that courageous man of character for freeing us from communism, and making us proud, once again, to be Americans. Ronald Reagan will be deeply missed; but his charisma, his graciousness and his winning smile will never be forgotten. Our heartfelt sympathy, love and prayers go to his family and his beloved wife, Nancy.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Analogic Profit Falls 74%
description: Shares of the Analogic Corporation fell sharply yesterday after the company, which makes medical and security imaging systems, said its earnings declined 74 percent in the third quarter. Analogic, based in Peabody, Mass., reported earnings of 13 cents a share for its third quarter, which ended April 30, down from 51 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell to $92.3 million from $100.1 million a year ago. Shares of Analogic dropped $5.29, or 11.2 percent, to $42.03.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Richemont Profit Gains
description: Compagnie Financire Richemont, the maker of Cartier watches and Van Cleef & Arpels jewelry, had a 56 percent increase in second-half profit as sales rebounded and the company benefited from cost cuts. Net income rose to 371 million euros ($447 million) in the six months through March, from 238 million euros a year earlier, the chairman, Johann Rupert, said. The median estimate of seven analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was 359 million euros. ''High-jewelry sales are up; watches are doing well; Cartier is coming back,'' Mr. Rupert, 54, said on a conference call with journalists. ''Across the board, especially in the U.S. and Asia, things are looking a lot better.'' Richemont shut a Swiss plant and pared expenses at unprofitable brands including Dunhill as luxury-goods companies struggled with the worst slump in three decades.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fake Sultan Convicted
description: A jury found a Queens man guilty yesterday of grand larceny and scheming to defraud two women out of more than $100,000 in an elaborate scheme in which he claimed to be Middle Eastern royalty. The man, who was born Benjamin Maybanks, but later legally changed his name to Sultan ibn Chandler Sabah al Sabah Dantata, was convicted after two-and-a-half hours of deliberation in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Prosecutors said that Mr. Dantata, 40, told the women that although he was the son of the Kuwaiti prime minister, he could not get his funds because of turbulence in the Middle East. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Paltz: Gay-Marriage Charges Dropped
description: Saying the state's ban against same-sex marriages was unconstitutional, a New Paltz town justice threw out criminal charges yesterday against Mayor Jason West, at left, who was arrested in March after solemnizing the marriages of 25 homosexual couples in February. In his decision, Justice Jonathan D. Katz quoted Supreme Court Justice Louis Brandeis, who said: "We must ever be on guard lest we erect our prejudices into legal principles.'' Mr. West's lawyer, E. Joshua Rosenkranz, said, ''This is the first ruling in any court in the State of New York in which any judge has ever declared the ban on same-sex marriages unconstitutional.'' The mayor had been charged with 19 counts of solemnizing a marriage without a license, a misdemeanor. Donald Williams, the Ulster County district attorney, said he would appeal the ruling, The Associated Press reported. In a civil case earlier this week, a State Supreme Court justice permanently barred Mr. West from conducting same-sex marriages without licenses. Debra West (NYT)

title: IDT CORPORATION WILL CUT MORE JOBS AT WINSTAR UNIT

The job cuts are part of a Winstar reorganization, which will cost $50 million, IDT said. The company, based in Newark, said it had already set aside $25 million. IDT has cut 50 percent of Winstar's work force since it acquired the company for $42.5 million in 2001, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Winstar had 375 employees as of Jan. 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILDE, ROBERT
description: WILDE--Robert died Thursday, June 10, 2004 after a long illness. He leaves his wife Mary Jo Bacha Wilde and children Claire Elena, of Washington, DC, John Alexander of Boston, MA and Catherine Noelle of Pearl River, NY. He is predeceased by his brother Albert Wilde in 2002. Robert served the Archdiocese of New York as a priest from his ordination in 1944 until he retired from the active ministry in 1973 to marry. From 1948 through 1968 he was Professor of Biblical Greek and Ancient History at St. Joseph's Seminary in Dunwoodie, Yonkers, NY. During the 1960's he was a Professor of Classics at Cathedral College in Manhattan. He also taught theology at the College of New Rochelle and the Classics at Hunter College, NYC. His pastoral work included Parochial Assistant for twenty years at St. Elizabeth's in Washington Heights. As pastor of St. Joseph's in Greenwich Village, he initiated and guided the renovation of that landmark church. Robert retired as Compliance Coordinator in 1994 from the health benefits office for the Transport Workers Union in NYC. Robert will be waked from his home at 189 South Middletown Road in Pearl River, Sunday, June 13, 2004 from 25 and 7-9 pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be Monday, 10:00 am at St. Aedan's RC Church. Burial will follow at Rockland Cemetery, Sparkill, NY. Donations in Robert's memory may be made to the Memorial Library of Early Christianity - NEH Catholic University of America, Washington, DC. 20064.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Debt Vs. Asteroids
description: Representative Anthony Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Queens and Brooklyn and is considering a run for mayor in 2005, released a study yesterday showing that it will cost $525 per person to service New York City's $51 billion debt this year, implicitly criticizing the way Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has handled city finances. A spokesman for the mayor said yesterday that Mr. Weiner was the only member of the city's Congressional delegation not to add his signature to a letter to the United States Treasury secretary requesting a terrorism insurance program, but did propose legislation that would provide additional federal financing to help track and catalog asteroids that are dangerously close to earth. Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said, ''Instead of fighting for precious homeland security dollars for New York, Congressman Weiner's priority is funding interplanetary asteroid protection programs.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Married To a Machine
description: ''The Stepford Wives,'' Frank Oz's madcap re-engineering of a dusty, second-rate thriller from 1975, opens with a montage of happy housewives and their household gadgets. Making fun of images like these -- smiling women in Eisenhower-era perms and evening gowns swooning over their automated kitchen cabinets -- has become such a tiresome pop-culture staple that you may wonder if the movie, which opens today nationwide, has anything new to say about feminism, suburbia or consumer society. The answer is not really, but it does manage to fire off a handful of decent jokes and a few sneaky insights before losing its nerve and collapsing into incoherence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, BYRON H.
description: WILSON--Byron H. Died on June 2, 2004 peacefully in his sleep at his home in New York. He was the beloved father of Pamela Shirley (Wilson) Fuller of Adelphi, MD and D'Ashley Wilson of New York City, beloved father-inlaw to Arthur Fuller, beloved husband to Kathryn Reid of New York City. Byron was born on February 21, 1933 in The Bronx, New York. He attended Central Needle Trade High School in Manhattan. He served in the Korean War. Byron was a good friend and colleague to many throughout his life. Byron began his professional career as a model. After modeling he branched into accounting and into the voice-over industry. Byron loved life. One of his favorite sayings was ''Better to have been a has-been than a never-was.'' Byron is survived by his sister Juliana Ansah of Georgia, Theodore Wilson of New Rochelle, NY, Newton Wilson of Kansas and a host of nieces, nephews and other family members. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 12, at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, NYC, at 2PM. Charitable donations may be made to the following organizations: St. Vincent's Comprehensive Cancer Center, NYC; Cabrini Hospice, East 19th St., NYC, or East End Hospice Care, Westhampton, N.Y.

title: A Call for Arab Democracy
description: Leaders of the Group of Eight, the club of rich nations that gathered on a secluded Georgia island this week, have rightly placed the Arab world's democracy deficit on the global agenda. President Bush is to be commended for using the meeting to elevate so important an issue. In securing a G-8 statement calling for reform in the Middle East, he overcame European wariness about the wisdom of calling for democracy in that region, not to mention America's own history of championing the ''stability'' provided by authoritarian regimes. Unfortunately, the statement is about as far as the G-8 leaders were prepared to go.

title: Philippine election results delayed
description: MANILA:  More than a month after the elections here, a new president and vice president have yet to be proclaimed as endless debates and filibustering delay the counting of the votes at the House of Representatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCMENAMIN, JOAN STITT
description: McMENAMIN -- Joan Stitt. Age 79, died suddenly at home on June 11, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Edward B. McMenamin and sister of Barbara Greene and Britton Stitt. A graduate of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry and Smith College, she was the Headmistress of the Nightingale-Bamford School from 1971 until her retirement in 1992. A trustee of Robert College of Istanbul, The Masters School and the Lawrenceville School, she was active in the Head Mistresses Association of the East, the Headmasters Association, the Country Day School Headmasters Association, and the National Association of Principals of Schools for Girls. She was most recently a consultant with Educator's Collaborative. For information Frank E. Campbell. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: NORTEL SELLING TELEPHONE SOFTWARE UNIT TO VOLT

Nortel will receive a minority equity interest in Volt's VoltDelta unit, a provider of directory and operator services in North America and Europe. Financial terms of the transaction will be released when it closes, Mr. Kochman said. Volt is based in New York and Nortel is based in Ontario.

title: Nocturnal Adagio by Danish Composer
description: When the New York Philharmonic introduced the music of the Danish composer Poul Ruders to its audience, at a Horizons Festival concert in 1986, Mr. Ruders was a promising composer in his mid-30's. Since then, the orchestra has played several more of his works and he has become more widely known, mainly through a series of recordings on the adventurous Bridge label. One of his latest works, ''Final Nightshade: An Adagio of the Night'' (2003), brought him back to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, when Lorin Maazel led the New York Philharmonic in the world premiere of the score.

title: The Road to Democracy, via Damascus
description: Last month President Bush bowed to Congressional pressure and imposed economic and diplomatic sanctions on Syria. Although the president went beyond what Congress demanded -- banning most exports to Syria, prohibiting Syrian commercial flights to America and freezing assets of Syrians with known ties to terrorism -- he missed an opportunity to show that the United States is serious about democracy and self-governance in the Middle East.

title: At 82, a Leader of World Pairs
description: The second session of the World Wide Pairs, played last Saturday, proved to be a triumph for a great veteran. Heading the field of 6,075 pairs, playing in 41 countries, was 82-year-old Petra Mansell of Durban, South Africa, who first played in a world championship 44 years ago and owns two silver medals for world competition. Playing with Arthur Hughes, she scored 76.18 percent, which was 2.47 ahead of the nearest competitors, Vera Petty and Roman Smolski of Bermuda.

title: Who Was the Greatest President of the 20th Century?
description: ''I think he is one of the two greatest presidents of the 20th century, along with Franklin Delano Roosevelt.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Extremist Freed
description: The notorious white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche rode a black horse through Potschefstroom, a center of white conservatism, after being released from a South African prison where he had spent three years for the attempted murder of a black security guard in 1996. Mr. TerreBlanche, 60, said he might seek to revive the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, which fought to preserve apartheid, as a right-wing political party. But he was greeted by only a handful of his movement's members and was trailed throughout his ride by a throng of black South Africans who sang songs of the anti-apartheid struggle. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: INTERCEPT HIRES JEFFERIES TO EXPLORE STRATEGIES
description: InterCept Inc., which provides payment-processing services to banks and merchants, said it had hired Jefferies & Company to help explore strategic alternatives that include a possible sale of the company. InterCept, which is based in Norcross, Ga., also said that it had settled pending litigation with JANA Partners and that they would together support a group of nominees for corporate directors at InterCept's annual meeting. The company said in December that the chief executive, John Collins, had decided not to pursue an offer to take the company private. Mr. Collins told the company earlier in the year that he intended to make such an offer, and the board formed a special committee of directors to consider the proposal.

title: 2 Declarations By bin Laden May Be Used In Terror Trial
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that two declarations by Osama bin Laden calling for war against Americans may be used as evidence in the trial of Lynne F. Stewart, a lawyer accused of aiding terrorism. The decision was a setback to defense efforts to dissociate her case from Al Qaeda and the Sept. 11 attacks.

She was born in New Haven, Ct on December 13, 1917, the daughter of the late Anna Cabot Almy and Percy Wells Bidwell. Molly graduated from Radcliffe College and received a Masters Degree in Government from Columbia University. She was married to the late Elihu Root III. She is survived by a son David Root of Clinton; two daughters, Carolyn Root of Durham, NC and Alice Root of Vernon Center; four grandchildren, Hazel Bogan Nichols, Elihu Root Bogan, Rosalind Bogan and Sophie Root; a brother John Bidwell and two sisters Anne Minafra and Charlotte Ryder; and predeceased by a brother Samuel Bidwell. A Memorial Service will be held at 11am on June 14, 2004 at the Hamilton College Chapel, Clinton. Donations may be made to the Community Foundation of Herkimer and Oneida Counties Inc., 1222 State Street, Utica, New York 13502.

All are landmark pieces. To see them in chronological order on Thursday night at a packed New York State Theater was to watch Balanchine mature creatively over the decades and yet remain essentially himself.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Airbus Wins Orders
description: Airbus won a $2 billion order for 20 A330-200 planes from the China Eastern Airlines Corporation. The airline has an option to buy 10 more planes. The order is one of nine agreements signed by Chinese and French companies during a visit to Paris by Zeng Peiyan, vice premier of China. The accords were announced at a ceremony at Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin's residence in Paris. China Eastern is seeking to buy the twin-aisle A330, which can carry 250 to 330 passengers and sells for $121 million to $132 million, depending on the model. The latest order increases the lead of Airbus this year over the Boeing Company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ATLAS PIPELINE PARTNERS, Philadelphia, a natural gas pipeline partnership, said it agreed to acquire closely held Spectrum Field Services Inc., Tulsa, Okla., for $140 million. Atlas Pipeline will gain 1,900 miles of natural gas pipelines and a gas-processing operation in Velma, Okla. The purchase price includes payment of anticipated taxes due as a result of the transaction.

title: Wake Up the Watchdogs
description: As Congress wades through the failures in intelligence gathering that preceded the 9/11 attacks and the Iraq invasion, it should take a close, corrective look at its own oversight responsibility. For too long lawmakers have discovered grievous flaws in the nation's intelligence operations only after they appeared in the news media. Congress should begin working now to end what has been a period of dangerous passivity and deference toward the hydra-like intelligence community, with its 15 disparate agencies and budget lines.

It can best be appreciated by stepping back and taking in the full picture, so that each brightly colored tile blends into the others. As the United States signs a new free trade agreement with Morocco next week, we need to recognize the full mosaic of interests at stake.

title: F.D.A. ASKS GLAXOSMITHKLINE TO STOP RUNNING A PAXIL AD
description: The Food and Drug Administration asked GlaxoSmithKline to stop an advertisement for the controlled-release version of its anxiety treatment Paxil, because, the agency said, it was too broad and was misleading about safety issues. In a letter to Glaxo posted on the F.D.A's Web site Thursday, the agency said a TV ad for Paxil Controlled-Release was ''false or misleading'' because it suggested that the drug could be used by a broader range of patients than it was actually approved for and also implied that the drug was safer than actually demonstrated. The company was given until June 23 to respond. A Glaxo spokeswoman, Nancy Leone, said the advertisement the F.D.A. asked the company to stop running last appeared on May 9 and would not run again. She said the ad had been reviewed by the F.D.A. before it ran.

title: At Rites for Reagan, Soaring Farewells
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  In a soaring cathedral on the capital's highest hilltop, world leaders past and present came to remember Ronald Reagan on Friday as the perpetual optimist who saw his nation as a shining city on a hill, then sent him home to California for the final scene of what President Bush called a "great American story."

title: Untruth in Lending
description: Banks can charge overdrawn customers steep fees for what amount to short-term loans. But they are not required to disclose the loans' effective interest rates, which can reach into the triple digits on an annualized basis. Through these fees, some 1,500 financial institutions prey on mostly low-income customers, and the Federal Reserve Board appears willing to condone the behavior by going along with the absurd fiction that this bounce protection is a service, not an extension of credit.

title: Drivin' That Dynaflow
description: Mid-60's popular radio was a welter of youthful voices, just as it is now. But every now and then a disc jockey would work Ray Charles, who died on Thursday, into the rotation, and it was like hearing directly from Father Time. I could never figure it out. The voice was so adult, so yearning and playful, so self-contradictory -- reedy and smooth, high-pitched and grumbling at the same time. By then, a song like ''What'd I Say (Part I)'' was already an oldie, recorded in 1959 when Ray Charles was (still? already?) in his late 20's. And yet it sounded like more of a rave-up than even the early Yardbirds could muster.

title: 99 CENTS ONLY STORES WARNS ABOUT PROFIT DECLINE
description: 99 Cents Only Stores, a discount retailer that operates mainly in California, said quarterly profit would fall more than expected because of disruptions in distribution as competition from supermarkets increased. Second-quarter profit will decline to 4 cents to 7 cents a share, compared with an earlier forecast of 19 cents to 20 cents, the company said. Sales at stores open at least a year might drop as much as 4 percent. The company's president, Eric Schiffer, said it planned to hire consultants to assess inventory controls, after deliveries were delayed and stores could not stock enough merchandise because of overcrowding at a Los Angeles warehouse. The company is based in Commerce, Calif.

title: Big Employers Join Forces in Effort to Negotiate Lower Drug Prices
description: Hoping to slow the rising cost of providing health coverage, 50 of the country's largest employers are creating a buyers' club to bargain directly with drug makers on behalf of five million active and retired employees and their families.

title: BEST BUY TO SELL LIMITED QUANTITY OF GATEWAY PRODUCTS
description: The Best Buy Company will begin selling a limited amount of Gateway brand consumer electronics this month, the companies said yesterday. Best Buy will sell Gateway MP3 players, liquid-crystal-display TV's and home-theater equipment left over from Gateway's retail stores, which closed in April. Some goods will appear only online, while others will also be sold in Best Buy stores, a Gateway spokesman said. Gateway is based in Poway, Calif., and Best Buy is based in Richfield, Minn.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Reprieve For Internet Dissident
description: In a case that attracted international attention, a court convicted Du Daobin, a 40-year-old Internet dissident, of subversion but then commuted his sentence, Mr. Du's lawyer said. Mr. Du was sentenced to three years in prison, suspended for four years, an unusual legal maneuver that means he will not have to serve a prison sentence. Mr. Du, a civil servant from central China, was arrested last year after writing more than two dozen Internet essays criticizing the arrests of other Internet essayists and also advocating broader political freedoms. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Monitor Finds 'Crisis' At Atlanta Jail
description: The Fulton County Jail in Atlanta is in a ''state of crisis,'' said a physician who is monitoring conditions there. The monitor, Dr. Robert B. description: Alitalia, Italy's largest airline, might need to consider liquidation because it has not been able to stem losses, its auditor, Deloitte & Touche, said. Deloitte is ''withholding judgment'' on Alitalia's 2003 financial figures and without adequate measures to restore the carrier's profitability, management needs to examine other solutions, including filing for insolvency, Deloitte said in a statement. The carrier is seeking emergency financing, including a loan issued or backed by a state entity.

title: Lynn Nottage Enters Her Flippant Period
description: SITTING in an office at the New Dramatists on West 44th Street the other day, Lynn Nottage mused about the difficulty of summing up the work of Lynn Nottage. ''With August Wilson, it's very easy,'' she said. ''He's writing one play for every decade of the African-American experience. With Kushner, he's a political playwright and it's easier to place him. Lynn Nottage? Who is she?'' And then: ''I'm a contemporary playwright in a postmodern world.''

title: A Saxophone Hero's Big Break
description: BENNY GOLSON became one of the better young saxophone players in jazz during the late 1950's, particularly as a member of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers, the long-running band that crystallized the sound of hard-bop. That was no small accomplishment: it was also the blossoming time of John Coltrane, Sonny Rollins and Wayne Shorter. Later in life, Mr. Golson became better known as a composer of small-band jazz standards, including ''I Remember Clifford,'' ''Stablemates,'' ''Killer Joe'' and ''Whisper Not.'' But next week, Mr. Golson, 75, will become exponentially more recognizable, playing himself in a new film by Steven Spielberg, ''The Terminal,'' which stars Tom Hanks.

title: Whatever Happened To Teen Romance?
description: As a clinical psychologist working with teenagers and the mother of two adolescent girls, I was grateful, encouraged and, of course, concerned to read Benoit Denizet-Lewis's article (May 30). The dissolution of so many marriages, the worship of youth culture, the proliferation of pornography and its accessibility to young people, the Internet, cellphone technology and post-9/11 fears of terror are some facts of life that teenagers are grappling with. As adults, we need to be thinking, as your writer has, about these phenomena and about how they affect young people coming of age. Thank you for this intelligent and thought-provoking article.

They sold the home they bought 30 years ago, a sunny 2,000-square-foot apartment on West 12th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, and rented a two-bedroom penthouse apartment in Battery Park City.

description: The panel assigned to monitor the overhaul of the state's child welfare system formally approved a state plan to remake the Division of Youth and Family Services last Wednesday. The plan also calls for incremental caseload reductions, culminating in 2007 with a limit of no more than 25 children per worker. Each worker now manages the cases of slightly more than 40 children, state figures show. Richard Lezin Jones

title: Page Two: June 6-12; CRYIN' TIME
description: Ray Charles, who died Thursday at 73, was a performer, songwriter, bandleader and producer whose gravelly voice often brought a note of heartbreak to his songs. He blended gospel, the blues, rhythm and blues, jazz and rock 'n' roll. Several months ago, he was asked in an interview about the effect of blindness on his career. ''Nothing, nothing, nothing,'' he said. ''I was going to do what I was going to do anyway. I played music since I was 3. I lost my sight when I was 7. So blindness didn't have anything to do with it. It didn't give me anything. And it didn't take nothing.''

title: Once I Was You
description: MORE and more these days, I've been venturing toward the Times Square area, even if it's a little out of my way. I used to avoid the ''new'' Times Square because that was what real New Yorkers did, but lately I've been drawn to its colorful, touristy energy. I like navigating among its bombastic mobs; they make me feel as if I'm both being swallowed up by the crowd and am also the last man on earth.

title: 'One Shoe Off' at the Schoolhouse
description: DURING a very peculiar dinner party scene in the second act of Tina Howe's ''One Shoe Off'' at the Schoolhouse here, one of the play's five loopy characters says, ''I just had the most massive dj vu.'' You would expect a revelation, an insight or at least something significant. But nothing comes of that titillating line. It does serve as a handy critical summation of Ms. Howe's futile exercise in absurdism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDWARDS, KATHLEEN BRYAN TAYLOR
description: EDWARDS--Kathleen Bryan Taylor. Of Greensboro, North Carolina died on June 11, 2004. She was the granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Julian Price of Greensboro, NC and the late Mr. and Mrs. Bart Bryan of Florida, and the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bryan. A Mass celebrating the life of Kay Bryan Edwards will be celebrated by Monsignor Anthony J. Marcaccio, Monday at 11:00 AM in Our Lady of Grace Catholic Church. There will be a private burial service. Mrs. Edwards graduated from the Madeira School in Washington, DC, attended UNCG, and graduated from Sweet Briar College. She received honorary doctorates from Sacred Heart College and Belmont Abbey College. Bennett College awarded her Outstanding Leadership to Education. She served on many local, state and national boards. She was President of The Kathleen Price Bryan Foundation and The Julian Price Family Foundation. Mrs. Edwards was a member of the Wednesday Study Club, Wednesday Literary Club, Little Gate Garden Club, The Friday Club, Greensboro Junior League, Greensboro Women's Investment Club, and Greensboro Committee of the Colonial Dames of America in the State of North Carolina and gave support to many groups of charitable, cultural, historical and environmental non-profit organizations. Surviving are her children: Laura Edwards of Chapel Hill, Susan Edwards of Greensboro, Pricey Taylor Harrison of Greensboro, Melanie Taylor and her daughters, Kathleen Clay, Anne and Margaret Farland of Chapel Hill, NC; John Taylor, his wife, Leslie, and their daughters, Saskia and Annelies of Madison, WI; Kathleen Clay Taylor of Cranberry Island, Maine, Bryan Taylor, his wife, Carolyn and their children, McKinley, Caroline and Julian of Charlotte, NC; Howard Taylor, his wife, Shawn and their daughters, Gavin, Victoria and Kathleen of McLean, VA; Mrs. Edwards' sister, Nancy Faircloth, and brother, Joseph Bryan, Jr. Memorial contributions may be made to Greensboro Urban Ministry, 305 W. Lee St., Greensboro, NC 27406 or the charity of your choice. For more information, contact Hanes-Lineberry N. Elm Street Funeral Home in Greensboro, NC. Online condolences may be sent to www.haneslineberry.com

title: A Mystery Man Who Produced Piano Music by the Truckload
description: WHEN he died -- nearly 16 years ago, at 96 -- Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji was hardly more than a formidable name. It was a name that could be found on a few scores in libraries and music shops, but these had all been published long before and had remained unplayed for decades, by Sorabji's wish. He was never very interested in performances. He preferred privacy, which gave him the freedom to think on an unprecedented scale, covering great lengths of time without bothering about the customs of concert life.

title: Newark Stadium Vote Blocked
description: A state superior court judge has ruled that Newark officials acted properly in rejecting petitions calling for a public vote on an arena proposal. The ruling on Tuesday cleared a potential hurdle for the city, which is seeking to sell $200 million in bonds to finance the arena's construction. The arena would become a new home for the New Jersey Devils, who are expected to contribute an additional $100 million. The plan was approved by the city council last month. Referendum advocates, who submitted a petition with 4,600 signatures to the city on June 2, have appealed the decision. Jessica Bruder

title: Taping of Interrogations Is Praised by Police
description: Police departments that electronically record the interrogations of suspects have come to embrace the practice, according to a new survey of more than 200 law enforcement agencies in 38 states. The study found that officials in those departments almost uniformly said that the recordings saved time and money, created compelling evidence and were effective in resolving disputes about whether confessions were voluntary and about allegations of police misconduct.

title: Deal on Highlands
description: Legislative leaders reached a deal last Monday on a plan to restrict development on 400,000 acres in the northwest section of the state known as the Highlands. The bill would sharply curtail construction near the rivers, lakes and reservoirs that provide drinking water to half of the state's nine million residents. The plan had been stalled, but a compromise was reached when the administration agreed to provide property tax relief to some Pinelands residents, and support new measures to force the State Department of Environmental Protection to streamline the approval of building permits. The full General Assembly and State Senate are expected to approve the bill this week. David Kocieniewski

To a 23-year-old who had never been to France, St.-Pierre and Miquelon sounded glamorous, cosmopolitan and exciting. I resolved to go there as soon as I could.

title: Commander Swift Objects
description: Lt. Cmdr. Charles Swift received his first lesson in the misuse of power in 1980, when he was a plebe at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md. Subjected to one indignation after another at the hands of upperclassmen, he came to realize that those who meted out the most vicious abuse were often the ones who had, in their day, been singled out themselves for especially harsh treatment. ''For them, the system was about getting even -- 'I can't punish the ones who did this to me, but I can punish you' -- and that bothered me,'' Swift says. ''I vowed that I would never do it to anyone else, and when I was an upperclassman, I tried to stop it.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Matt Lucas and David Walliams; A Little British, Times 2
description: IT was 7 p.m. on a recent Thursday and Matt Lucas and David Walliams could be found in the Art Deco lobby of Claridge's discussing why they didn't want to have a drink in the hotel bar. Mr. Walliams, who lives near Claridge's and occasionally treats himself to afternoon tea there, was pragmatic. ''Too noisy,'' he said. Mr. Lucas's complaint was more conceptual, addressing the mirrored facade that effectively obscured the cocktail lounge's entrance. ''Maybe there is no bar,'' he said, gazing at his short, roly-poly reflection. ''Maybe it's just an illusion. That's happened to me before, you know.''

title: The Runners-Up
description: Pinar Yolacan, a Turkey native and recent graduate of Cooper Union, originally envisioned this portfolio as a performance piece. The idea, she says, was to explore the interactions between several women and the bizarre, flamboyant clothing made of chicken skin that she made for them. "I created the garments to look Victorian and feminine, with puffy sleeves, ruffles, and layers of fabric," she says, "and therefore pictured them worn by older, queen-like women." To find the perfect subjects, she placed an ad online and recruited through acting agencies, but found many by simply observing passersby on the streets of New York. (One woman was a former denizen of Andy Warhol's the Factory whom the photographer met in a Starbucks.) Yolacan began photographing her work simply to document it, but quickly realized that the documentation itself was strong enough to stand alone. Starting in September, prints from this portfolio will be exhibited in Yolacan's first solo show, at Silo, a new a gallery on the Lower East Side. Go to Slide Show

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, EDWARD R.

title: The Fidelity Fix
description: Why is it so hard to loosen the grip of AIDS on southern Africa? H.I.V.-prevention programs in that part of the world have been under way for years -- there have been campaigns to raise awareness about AIDS and to promote the use of condoms; clinics have been established to conduct H.I.V. testing and to treat sexually transmitted diseases that may accelerate the spread of H.I.V.; more recently, schoolchildren have been taught the benefits of abstinence -- and yet the virus continues to spread. About a third of all sexually active adults in Botswana and South Africa carry H.I.V., a rate nearly 10 times higher than almost anywhere in the world outside Africa. These prevention efforts have been sensible -- abstaining from sex or using condoms consistently do prevent H.I.V. infection -- but their effects have been disappointing.

title: A Retro Taste From Bully Hill
description: Catawba wine, once so popular that Longfellow celebrated it, slaked Times Square diners' thirsts until Prohibition. In the early 1900's, this native grape flourished in the Hudson Valley and Finger Lakes region.

title: Martha Graham Like You've Never Seen Him

title: Where Stardom Still Arrives With a Roar
description: THE Apollo Theater is not nearly as big as its name. The world-famous landmark, on 125th Street in Harlem, seats 1,500 people, tops. Its old-fashioned opera-house design dates back to 1914, when it first opened its doors as a burlesque theater. It was not until 1934 that the Apollo assumed its current identity, quickly becoming the most important stage for African-American entertainers, a title it has held ever since.

title: The Machines Men Still Want?
description: Who would have imagined we'd ever see their like again -- after all the hard-won advances, the shattered glass ceilings and the second-shift domestic arrangements, the growing cadre of warrior women stalking the corridors of power? The Stepford Wives -- those fetching icons of male-enabling demureness who fold laundry as if their lives depend on it (which, in a manner of speaking, they do) -- are back, in a new version of the movie about men who are so afraid of women's self-assertion that they are willing to murder them and replace them with mechanized facsimiles, the better to spend the rest of their days having sex with ''a piece of plastic,'' as William Goldman, who wrote the original script, once put it. Thirty years after they first floated onto the screen, dressed in frilly aprons or ice-cream-colored hyperfeminine outfits, bearing casseroles as housewarming gifts, displaying pea-size brains and cantaloupe-size breasts, the merrily robotic wives have been exhumed from the vault of eclipsed movie moments and given fresh cinematic life.

title: Senate Considers Lawyers to Try Rowland if He Is Impeached
description: Last week, while a legislative committee heard the first public testimony in its impeachment investigation of Gov. John G. Rowland, State Senate leaders were compiling a short list of lawyers to be considered for the job of trying his case, a legislative aide said on Saturday.

title: Providing Electricity When the Power Fails

No problem. Bigger or smaller group? That's fine.

title: IN THE REGION/Westchester; Upscale Newcomer In Grocery Lineup

title: Essay; Bloomsday, Bloody Bloomsday
description: VERY many years ago, when I was growing up in the town of Wexford, on the southeast coast of Ireland, I dearly wished to get hold of a copy of James Joyce's ''Ulysses.'' I had read ''Dubliners'' and ''A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,'' and had even written, on a big black Remington borrowed from my Aunt Sadie, a number of lugubrious short stories in what I thought was the Joycean manner, mainly devoted to the subject of death and all centered on a neurasthenic young hero whom no one truly understood, whose soul was much given to swooning and who went under different names but was always me.

title: Love That Mystic Hammering
description: Hey, Bobby, some editors over at The New York Times Book Review (remember ''I'm gonna grow my hair down to my feet so strange / So I look like a walking mountain range / And I'm gonna ride into Omaha on a horse / Out to the country club and the golf course. / Carry The New York Times, shoot a few holes, blow their minds''?) asked me if I'd write something about the words to your songs. I have watched you and listened to your lyrics and have been struggling to get as good as you are for about the last 40 years. You probably don't care much for somebody trying to analyze your head like this, and I sure don't pretend to be no intellectual, but these folks seem to think I'm up to the job. So I guess I'll ramble on about some lines of yours that I think are brilliant, like these, from ''Spanish Harlem Incident'': ''Gypsy gal, the hands of Harlem / Cannot hold you to its heat. / Your temperature's too hot for taming, / Your flaming feet burn up the street.''

A veiltail, a pompadour, a bloodfin -- powered by enough juice for a town of 10,000 -- blowing bubbles around a pack of Wrigley's Spearmint as big as a boxcar. It's the largest electric sign in the world.

Whatever they might like to think, the girls are still being treated like doormats, and the boys are developing a very unhealthy sense of entitlement. No wonder they're all depressed.

title: Gambling on Voting

To appreciate how poor the oversight on voting systems is, it's useful to look at the way Nevada systematically ensures that electronic gambling machines in Las Vegas operate honestly and accurately. Electronic voting, by comparison, is rife with lax procedures, security risks and conflicts of interest.

title: Paris Prepares to Take Back Its Belly
description: ''THE Belly of Paris,'' mile Zola's novel set in and around Les Halles in the late 1850's, vividly evokes the pungent smells, sights, sounds and tastes of the city's marketplace. Les Halles had long served Paris as its nutritional epicenter, in essence, its stomach. Zola wrote: ''Then there came three Brie cheeses displayed on round platters and looking like melancholy extinct moons. Two of them, very dry, were at the full; the third, in its second quarter, was melting away in a white cream.'' Yet Les Halles was far more than a marketplace, and when the demands of expansion and congestion forced the relocation of the market in the late 1960's, the historian Louis Chevalier somberly proclaimed, ''With Les Halles gone, Paris is gone.''

title: The Snowmobile Menace
description: Congress can take a big step this week toward ending the long-running dispute over snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks. A bipartisan group in the House of Representatives led by Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, and Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, will offer an amendment to the Interior Department appropriations bill that would prohibit snowmobiles in both parks beginning next winter. A similar amendment lost on a 210-to-210 tie vote last year. A favorable vote this time -- assuming eventual agreement by the Senate -- would be a victory for the parks, their wildlife and the many thousands of visitors who come to enjoy both.

title: I Write the Songs
description: When Wilco's lead singer, Jeff Tweedy, writes in ADULT HEAD (Zoo Press, paper, $14.95), his first book of poems, ''no one / will tell you / you are not / a rainbow / but the white kitten / is a snow cone,'' some readers may flash back to the terrible moment they were first forced to wonder (a) what a bustle was, and (b) what one might be doing in a hedgerow. Tweedy's poems are uncapitalized, generally unpunctuated and adhere to the notion of poetry as a series of surprising images -- for example, ''knives and forks / perform over my bed / fiberglass insulation, / a migrating pink dream.'' Sometimes, as in ''When I Say My Heart'' and ''Prayer #4,'' this approach yields poems that are interesting, if not necessarily cohesive. On the whole, though, Tweedy's awkward and occasionally embarrassing collection proves that you can be in possession of a guitar, three chords and the truth -- and still write a lousy sestina. David Orr

From the ground, Times Square does not seem so concentrated, though it is a canyon, and I love driving into Times Square at night, coming down Broadway into the chasm of absolute illumination. And if you climb out of the Times Square station, you are in a room in which you accidentally left the light on.

title: Back In Black
description: ''The thing I love about Johnny Cash is the sound of his voice, the physical sound of his voice,'' a punk rock singer told Nick Tosches in 1995. ''It's like buyin' a book called, like, y'know, America or something.'' It's not hard to buy a book about Johnny Cash, who died last September at 71. There have been countless biographies, and he wrote at least three books himself: two autobiographies and a novel called ''Man in White.'' This spring two lavishly illustrated large-format books about Cash have been released. The best is CASH (Crown, $29.95), by the editors of Rolling Stone, a mix of new material and terrific stuff from the magazine's archives, including a groovy and gripping chunk of new journalism by Ralph J. Gleason, published in 1969, about a Cash show in San Quentin. (''Let me tell you, baby,'' Gleason writes, ''approaching the huge concrete and steel structure of San Quentin, just approaching it defines the phrase bad vibes.'') The other book, CASH: An American Man (CMT/Pocket Books, $30), by Bill Miller, is basically an overstuffed scrapbook. On display here are things like Cash's Air Force uniform, even cancelled checks. Amid this pile of happy detritus is a photograph of a 1970's-era plastic container with Cash's grinning image on it. When Cash saw it, Miller reports, he rolled his eyes and said: ''You know you've made it when you're on a Slurpee cup.'' Dwight Garner

title: Through a Glass, Brightly; Swimming To Infinity
description: The future landscape of Times Square will develop from the ground up. Buildings will be linked by connectors, and facades will become porous, allowing access to stacks of theaters, stores and sports entertainment. Facades will be carved out and added to for new uses, and paths for pedestrians will spread like a matrix into the spaces between and on the tops of buildings. The public will circulate through facades and rooftops, experiencing Times Square almost as improvisational theater. The appearance of the ''in-between'' structures will vary, as they will all be built over a period of 50 years, each using materials and technologies particular to their era. As corporations seek ways to contribute to the public realm, spaces will be carved out of buildings so the public can view and experience Times Square from the air.

title: Diagnosis
description: Lisa Sanders (May 30) describes a case of severe mitral-valve stenosis that was misdiagnosed by an echocardiogram on two occasions, before finally being correctly assessed on a third attempt. But in Sanders's description of the physical exam, she makes no mention of any cardiac findings (positive or negative) using traditional skills, including auscultation with a stethoscope. In fact, such an exam, conducted with a modicum of skill, almost always gives the correct diagnosis of mitral stenosis. The echocardiogram should ideally be confirmatory to a diagnosis that has already been made clinically.

title: Dressed To The 9-Irons
description: A passionate if mediocre golfer, P.G. Wodehouse once wrote about his beloved sport: ''I wish to goodness I knew the man who invented this infernal game. I'd strangle him.'' Although the wisecrack most likely stemmed from Wodehouse's frustration with the putting gods, the Anglo-American humorist may have been suffering from fashion anxiety. In Wodehouse's day, golf was a stylish, gentlemanly pursuit, and players routinely stepped out in jackets, four-in-hands and hats. Although the fashions changed over time, golf required a sartorial commitment until the mid-80's, with men choosing their clothes as carefully as their clubs. But for the past two decades the sport has somehow gotten stuck in a sand trap. Dot-com-era chinos, bland golf shirts and caps that look like giveaways from a software convention have become par for the course.

title: Armed With Data, One Team Bucks The Conventional Use of Pitchers
description: At a simple ballpark just beyond Washington's Beltway, the Cincinnati Reds, baseball's oldest franchise, are conducting a little experiment to see how well the past mixes with the present.

title: An Electrician From the Ukrainian Town of Lutsk
description: I KNOW that's an odd headline, but it's not original with me. I lifted it from reporter Richard Bernstein's identification of an otherwise anonymous man he interviewed for an article published in The Times on April 25. This is not meant to criticize Bernstein: I don't know any electricians from Lutsk, but I would rather have one of them in my mind's eye than anyone identified as ''an analyst,'' ''an expert,'' ''a lawyer involved in the case,'' ''a senior State Department official,'' ''a Democratic strategist'' or any of the other standardized obfuscations that can make a morning with The Times so exasperating.

title: Yanks' Lieber Takes Hits, But Puts Team at Ease
description: The first task for Jon Lieber yesterday was to stay healthy. Throwing strikes, keeping the ball down, the things that might seem so important on any other day, were tossed aside in favor of relieving the worries of Yankees management.

title: Legs, Diamonds
description: BACK in the day -- the day being about 90 years ago -- the New Amsterdam Theater on West 42nd Street was populated by showgirls as delicious as lollipops, along with men whose pulses raced at the mere sight of them. By the time I arrived to check out the place in the late 70's, however, it was a mess. Not the worst thing in Times Square, but suffice it to say that the kung fu movies that had long since replaced the showgirls were the best thing the theater had to offer.

title: The Week Ahead
description: PHONE WARS It will be up to the Supreme Court this week to decide whether regulations that have kept wholesale telephone rates low will be extended. The outcome could affect 50 million customers, consumer groups say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FENTON, JOHN
description: FENTON--John, of New York City died June 8th, 2004 at the age of 75. Devoted husband of Yuri Fenton and beloved father of John Fenton, Anne Fenton-Wojtala and Agnes Mironov. He is also survived by six grandchildren. Graduate of Wesleyan University. He worked at U.N. University (Tokyo) as Chief of Information Services. He was an avid reader and loved to travel, to talk about politics and to laugh. The memorial service will be held July 17, 2004 at the Princeton Club of New York from 4-7PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Wesleyan University, Middletown CT 06459.

title: Taking the High Ground
description: At a time when the Israeli rightist parties are going through a wrenching debate over whether to approve Ariel Sharon's proposal for a unilateral withdrawal from Gaza, it's worth recalling Israel's previous experience in this regard -- its unilateral withdrawal from Lebanon. Although that withdrawal is remembered as a failure, it deserves to be rehabilitated. Israel's Lebanon withdrawal was a great strategic success -- for reasons that Israel should be studying now.

title: When Bad People (Translation: Teenagers) Do Good Things
description: DO not open your local paper at this time of year, because you will almost certainly read about teenagers doing bad things. Perhaps they're celebrating the coming of summer with a bit of vandalism, as in Monroe Township, where several high school students have just been charged with disabling the school bus fleet by letting the air out of 117 tires. Perhaps they're indulging in some prom-night car wrecks or senior-skip-day wickedness.

title: Turtle Bay, Kings Point, Fairfield, Brooklyn Heights
description: MANHATTAN

title: The Nation: Conforming in Canada; The Blue-State Nation to the North
description: IMAGINE if the 2000 presidential election had been held in Canada instead of the United States. Political scientists say Al Gore would have run away with the election; George W. Bush would have won no more than 1 of Canada's 10 provinces, and that would have been Alberta, where oil wealth and a taste for cowboy boots remind Canadians of Texas.

title: It Oughta Be in Pictures
description: TIMES Square is a magnet for moviemakers drawn to both its bright lights and a darkness that can be magical or menacing. These 10 films, spanning a half-century, showcase the neighborhood in often odd and unexpected ways. The only real constant is the Howard Johnson's on Broadway and 46th, one of the few Times Square talismans you can still visit today.

title: Panel to Seek River Project Funds
description: A PANEL called the Hudson River Congressional caucus has been formed to spearhead the effort. to secure more federal funds for development of land along the Hudson River, as well as for cleaning up the river itself.,

title: Today's Lesson: Don't Judge Them by Their Coffee Tables
description: You know those design-magazine photographs of fancy homes, with high-toned magazines artfully arranged on sleekly elegant coffee tables?

title: Drug Savings Won't Affect Food Stamps
description: The Bush administration said Saturday that it would rescind a federal policy that threatened to cut food stamp benefits for several million low-income elderly and disabled people who save money on their medicines by using the new Medicare drug discount cards.

title: Letters
description: 50 Years After Brown

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, Start Your Engines
description: KRISTEN McGILLIVRAY is ready for adventure this summer -- so long as it doesn't cost too much. Ms. McGillivray was, until recently, in the human resources department at an Internet company, LookSmart, in San Francisco. Now laid off, she has decided to use part of her severance package to take the kind of vacation that she might have denied herself during her years on the job.

title: After Years of Sludge, a Clash on the Cleanup; New Jersey Residents Want Ford to Do It Right This Time
description: When the Ford Motor Company closed its plant in Mahwah in 1980, the last car made there -- a two-tone beige Futura -- rolled off the assembly line and came to rest beneath a sign that exhorted workers to ''Do it Right the First Time.''

title: McGreevey Signs Malpractice Bill
description: Governor McGreevey has signed legislation that will provide $78 million in aid for doctors facing steep increases in malpractice insurance premiums. But the bill does not include the provision that insurers and the New Jersey Medical Society wanted most: a cap on pain and suffering jury awards for medical malpractice victims. The new law establishes a three-year subsidy fund of $26.1 million annually to defray the cost of medical malpractice insurance for health care providers. The fund will be paid for by a $75 annual fee on doctors, chiropractors, dentists, optometrists and lawyers, and by a $3 charge on state employers for each worker. Jessica Bruder

title: Street Smarts Separate Great Drivers From Good
description: When Jackie Stewart was asked recently what he thought of Mark Webber, he said that Webber, the Jaguar driver, had an advantage over most of his Formula One competitors, not so much in driving talent, but in that he had a brain.

title: Summer Is Serious Business
description: THE school year will end on Friday, June 25, at the Bright Beginnings Learning Center in Piscataway. But on the following Monday, Marion Crino, a special education teacher there, will be back in her classroom for a five-days-a-week summer school program that will run until the middle of August.

title: Surf Your Way To a Campsite
description: FINDING good information online about campgrounds can be an exercise in wandering in the wilderness, with trail markers that point in conflicting directions or send you deep into the electronic woods.

title: France Addresses Issue Of Another Hot Summer
description: AT the height of last summer's devastating heat wave in France, which sent temperatures over 100 degrees and left nearly 15,000 people dead, the French resorted to both dramatic measures and small gestures.

description: Correction Appended

description: STILL GRAZING

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They work for us. They are very good technicians and they give us expertise. But we make the decisions.''

title: Tiger Is Human, and Golf World Wonders if That's Good or Bad
description: Golf's most dominant force has not dominated for months. Is Tiger Woods currently the world's best player? The world ranking says yes. But this year's results suggest otherwise.

title: Slices and Curses In the Gilded Age
description: IN 1890, enamored of a game they had encountered while vacationing in Biarritz in southwestern France, a small group of wealthy Americans decided to bring golf back to their primary summer residence in Southampton. It was a time of excess, and the newly-minted millionaires and upper-middle-class burghers were always on the lookout for diversions. Sports especially intrigued them, and since a local tennis club founded in 1885 was constantly packed, it made sense that golf might be the next big thing.

title: Whatever Happened To Teen Romance?
description: Bravo for this eye-opening article. As a single mother in suburbia, I often feel like the odd parent out when I insist on even the most elemental parameters: ''Are there parents home where you're going?'' I am most bothered that smart teenage girls in post-feminist America would place themselves in such a subservient position. I do not believe for a second that meeting someone on the Internet, engaging in oral sex and then never seeing him again could ever be empowering or beneficial in the emotional development of young women.

title: Elizabeth Rourke, Christopher Avery
description: Elizabeth Jeanne Rourke, a doctor, and Christopher Norio Avery, a professor, were married last evening in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Linda Smith-Criddle, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the ballroom of the Longwood Towers.

title: Susan Kearns, Steven Engel
description: Susan Elisabeth Kearns, a daughter of Elsie R. Kearns and Thomas M. Kearns of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Steven Andrew Engel, a son of JoAnn and Mark F. Engel of Sands Point, N.Y. Judge John G. Koeltl of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, who is the bride's uncle, officiated at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Judge Alex Kozinski of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit took part in the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: Brick Lane, by Monica Ali. (Scribner, $14.) Set in the cloistered world of Bangladeshi immigrants in London's East End, this acclaimed first novel tells of an 18-year-old woman ''from the village'' who enters into an arranged marriage with a 40-year-old man who yearns to return home as a success. When his prospects sour, she becomes a garment worker and discovers her own desire: she falls in love with the man who delivers the clothes she works on. In her ''deeply rewarding'' tale, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2003, Ali displays a ''technical assurance and an inborn generosity that cannot be learned,'' Michael Gorra wrote in these pages.

title: Field Guides to the Bright Lights and the Dark
description: Damon Runyon wasn't the only writer enchanted by Times Square. Significant histories of the area, by James Traub and by Anthony Bianco (excerpts below), have been published in this centennial year, and many notable older books, still available, retell its story.

title: Square Meals
description: Once Times Square was the home of Rector's, where Diamond Jim Brady downed three dozen oysters and a half dozen lobsters at a sitting. Much later, Nathan's came along. Here are some relatively recent arrivals to the Times Square scene.

title: Pittsburgh
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''What's Doing in Pittsburgh'' (May 30): I moved to Pittsburgh two years ago and was quickly seduced by the industrial beauty, cheap rent, art scene and small-town funkiness. I would, however, take issue with Annasue McCleave Wilson's assertion that the city is devoted to its urban core.

title: Nickelodeon's 25th Year: Care for a Slice of Slime?
description: BLUE, Nickelodeon's impish game-hound, is now 7, or 49 in dog years. Members of the proudly juvenile ''Rugrats'' gang, at 12, are bumping up against adolescence. And the network's green slime, practically a character in its own right, is a venerable 21, old enough to drive, vote and go to war.

description: BEASTS OF EDEN

title: Childish Expenditures
description: My son went to dinner with four friends. One of the boys paid the check. Later that week he asked my son and another boy for their share, but he did not ask the other two boys. Often those boys are exempt from paying because of lack of funds. My son said he would pay only if those other two did. But mustn't he pay what he owes no matter what they do? C.L., Scarsdale, N.Y.

description: A bad break led to Jeff Sluman's disqualification from the Buick Classic on Saturday.

description: Lee A. Iacocca, who gave the world the Ford Mustang and revived Chrysler by popularizing the modern minivan, left the automobile industry a decade ago. But he is still pushing new ideas.

title: John Davies, 77; Remastered Jazz Records
description: John R. T. Davies, an audio engineer known for his expertise in improving the sound of reissued vintage jazz recordings, died on May 25 at his home in Burnham, Buckinghamshire, England. He was 77.

title: Serve Or Fail
description: About now, most recent college graduates, a mere week or two beyond their last final, are giving themselves a nice respite. Maybe they're on a beach, maybe they're on a road trip, maybe they're in their rooms, painting their toenails black with a Q-tip and shoe polish. Does it matter? What's important is that they have some time off.

title: On Baseball; Bringing The Variety Of Interleague Competition Home to Fans
description: FOR three decades, the designated hitter has been a source of controversy. It detracts from the strategy of the game, its critics argue. It turns players into half-players, as opposed to whole ones, they say. Have it in both leagues or in neither league, others say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAYNE, MIRIAM
description: FAYNE--Miriam on June 10, 2004. Beloved mother of Linda and Henry. Adoring grandmother of Alex, Zachary and Alexis. Beloved sister of Irving. Nurturing friend to many. Services Monday June 14, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Miriam's name can be made to the American Cancer Society.

Hayden of Federal District Court in Newark, took part in the ceremony.

title: 'Moanin' at Midnight'
description: Halley's Comet burned across the Mississippi night like a brakeman's lantern during June 1910, leading to suicides and whispers of Armageddon. Up north in Hartford, the Connecticut Yankees were lamenting the recent passing of the brightest star in the American literary firmament, Mark Twain. In New York City, W. E. B. Du Bois, anguished about race riots and lynchings around the nation, was preparing the first issue of The Crisis, the magazine of the new National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. In Reno, Jack Johnson, the first black heavyweight boxing champion, was training for his July 4th title defense against former champ Jim Jeffries, "The Great White Hope," a spectacle that would lead to more race riots. In Washington, D.C., Congress was debating the Mann White Slave Traffic Act, which would ban "the interstate transportation of women for immoral purposes"-a law specifically targeted at Johnson that would soon send him to jail for traveling with his white girlfriend.

title: A Million Kittens in a Sack
description: THE PARTS

title: Whatever Happened To Teen Romance?
description: Your article made teenagers seem, well, almost wise. Several things were particularly memorable. First, the use of condoms as the rule seemed exceptionally responsible. Second, most rational adults would agree that high school is no place for romantic relationships for exactly the reasons stated. Third, the tremendous benefits of having close friends of the opposite sex as a given, not as an exception, will pay compound interest over a lifetime. Fourth, the direct parallel between not ''dating'' someone from your school and not dating someone from the office was impressive. Fifth, the teenagers are right to think that there is no need to get all ''couply'' in high school or even college. There is time for that.

title: Ground Zero; Bush and Broadway; Abu Ghraib
description: GROUND ZERO

title: Veterans Speak Out
description: It was dispiriting to read the quotes from the veterans in the May 30 Lives column. Why is it that those who say they fought for freedom, democracy, justice and the so-called American Way fail to be the first to voice outrage when some of their own undermine and soil the supposedly noble fight? Cruelty can be so easy; justice and humanity are hard. I hope that the quotes you chose aren't representative of too many veterans. We are all sullied by Abu Ghraib and any evil done in our name.

title: Bond Buyers May Want To Note This Birthday
description: INVESTORS in a tizzy about rising interest rates should get a grip. The chances are that the cost of money will rise for a long, long time, says James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.

title: Memphis
description: Memphis's love of blues and gospel, rockabilly and soul is worn like a heart on a sleeve. Al Green, Roy Orbison and Elvis Presley smile down from restaurant wall posters, while hotels sport saxophone sculptures and staircases shaped like a piano keyboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOUZEL, DAISY FORNACCA
description: KOUZEL--Daisy Fornacca. Born in Genoa, Italy, raised in Florence and NYC and recent resident of Santa Monica, CA. Passed away June 8 of complications from Alzheimers disease. Daisy was the beloved wife of the late Alfred Kouzel, mother of Miriam and Margarita and of son-inlaw Stephen, grandmother of Zoe, Francesca, and Daisy. A graduate of Barnard College and PhD from Columbia University she was a college professor, scholar, poet, translator, bridge champion, political activist and above all a life-long death penalty abolitionist. A memorial service will be held in New York this summer. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to The National Coalition To End The Death Penalty, 920 Pennsylvania Ave, SE, Washington DC, 20003.

title: One Very Tangled Post-9/11 Affair
description: John Zazulka wonders why his children don't want to see him and blames their mother (typical in divorce): ''What is she doing to these kids?''

title: When the Bush Energy Policy Confronts Ancient Art
description: Blaine Miller, a quiet, slow-talking 57-year-old archaeologist, has made a career of studying the haunting scenes of net-wielding hunters and sinuous horned snakes on the smooth rock faces of Nine Mile Canyon near here. His colleagues consider him a leading expert on the 400- to 1,500-year-old images etched and daubed on the canyon walls. But Mr. Miller's bosses at the Bureau of Land Management barred him from evaluating recent proposals for natural gas exploration around the canyon after a gas company executive complained about his work.

title: Water Music, Captured on Film
description: IN the 19th century, artists and photographers flocked to the ocean as eagerly as explorers. Photographers like the Frenchman Gustave Le Gray (who at midcentury pulled off the feat of capturing a wave in motion and photographing the sea with a sky full of clouds) were as fascinated by the ocean as were painters like Courbet, Turner and Monet.

title: The Attraction of 'Interest-Only' Loans
description: ALMOST everyone dreams of owning that chalet in the mountains or cottage by the beach. But with mortgage rates creeping up and homes becoming pricier by the minute, owning vacation property may seem more out of reach.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Shooting the Great and the Good
description: Although he was a costume and set designer, a self-made dandy, an old-fashioned snob and a diarist, Cecil Beaton may have created his most significant legacy in his elegant and studied photographs. The handsome reproductions in BEATON PORTRAITS (Yale University, $50), by Terence Pepper, curator of photographs at the National Portrait Gallery in London, include a superbly androgynous Katharine Hepburn; Marlon Brando before his breakthrough in ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' looking, improbably, like a British schoolboy with long tousled hair; Francis Bacon appearing every bit as alarming as a figure in one of his paintings. Here also is an irresistibly seductive -- and remarkably hirsute -- Yul Brynner. In an included essay, Peter Conrad, who teaches English at Oxford University, persuasively argues that although Beaton glorified his subjects, he also ''glimpsed a reality that belied the fiction he was helping to create.'' And he observes that when the social-climbing Beaton was permitted entry into the upper-crust world of Ascot -- the very place he would recreate so effectively with his splendid designs for both the stage and film versions of ''My Fair Lady'' -- ''his presence there was a symptom of the democratization he despised.'' David Kaufman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, DAVID, M.D.
description: GOLDBERG -- David, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and longtime friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. William G. Stein, M.D., Pres. Barry D. Stimmel, MD, Vice Pres Elliot J. Rayfield, MD, Secy. Betty J. Mintz, MD, Treas.

title: The Fading World Of Leopold Bloom
description: June 16 is the 100th anniversary of the day in 1904 on which Dublin's best-known fictional Jew (and cuckold), 38-year-old Leopold Bloom, wandered the city as a modern-day Odysseus and, after numerous adventures located more in his mind than on the street, circumnavigated his way home. It also commemorates the first day that James Joyce, Bloom's creator, ''walked out'' with his wife-to-be, Nora Barnacle. On Bloomsday, as it has been known for more than 50 years, Joyce diehards will have a chance to celebrate his great novel ''Ulysses'' in costume, recital and booze. They can retrace Bloom's footsteps to Davy Byrnes's ''moral pub'' or indulge in Bloom trivia by buying cakes of lemon soap, as Bloom did for his secret epistolary lover, Martha.

title: What's a Tony, When There's a Helen to Win?
description: NO one thanked an agent or a higher power; no one made an impromptu speech against the war. Instead, the excited honorees thanked their teachers, cast mates, parents and, occasionally, ''everyone at my entire school.''

title: An Exhibit That Was Born to Run
description: Bruce Springsteen, fast cars and the Jersey Shore, a holy trinity in the canon of popular culture, converge in an exhibit that opens Thursday at the Newark Museum.

title: One Very Tangled Post-9/11 Affair
description: Susan Dominus's balanced profile (May 23) of Firefighter John Zazulka's post 9/11 personal life was a reminder of how futile attempts to assign ''good guy/gal, bad guy/gal'' labels are in matters of the heart. Though we find such dichotomies comforting, they are almost always false.

title: Deputy Foreign Minister Is Fatally Shot in Baghdad
description: Gunmen shot and fatally wounded a deputy foreign minister as he drove to work on Saturday morning. It was the first killing of a senior Iraqi official since the announcement of the interim government on June 1.

title: Rail Museum Dreams of Steam Shuttle
description: DRIVING through upstate New York a few years ago, Dick Horn glanced across a field and saw a railroad turntable rusting away in the weeds. The 62-ton steel derelict was not everyone's idea of a found treasure. But it was exactly what Mr. Horn had been looking for, essential to a dream he shares with many Long Island railroad aficionados: to have a real steam engine once more hooting along local rails.

title: Unions Allowed to Organize On Indian Reservations
description: Officials at both the Mohegan Sun in Uncasville and the Foxwoods Resort and Casino in Mashantucket said a decision late last month by the National Labor Relations Board that allows unions to organize on Indian reservations doesn't mean that unionization is headed for either casino.

title: Beyonc, From the Mouths of Babes
description: BEYONC'S ''Crazy in Love'' was last summer's inescapable Top 40 hit, booming nonstop from the Jersey Shore to northern Sweden. And even though it has long since faded from the charts, the tune is still raking in money -- albeit without Beyonc belting out the chorus. As featured on ''Kidz Bop 5,'' a new CD, the song is performed by an anonymous crew of grade-school students, whose twee voices make it sound no more sultry than ''Puff the Magic Dragon.''
