title: The Shy Master of The Movie Thriller
description: THE English director Mike Hodges has made so few films he should be legendary. Mr. Hodges's new movie, ''I'll Sleep When I'm Dead'' (opening on Friday), is just his ninth feature in 33 years, and even that total is a little misleading: he disowns ''A Prayer for the Dying'' (1987), which was taken away from him and recut by the studio, and ''Black Rainbow'' (1989) was never released theatrically in the United States. This sparseness of output should place him solidly in the maverick/perfectionist class of Stanley Kubrick and Terrence Malick, but a Mike Hodges film has never generated the frenzies of anticipation that a new Kubrick once did, or that a long-delayed Malick or Quentin Tarantino movie does now. In an age of hype and instant overexposure, it's almost easier to become a legend than to remain, as Mr. Hodges stubbornly has, a minor cult figure. There's a weird dignity in his obscurity.

title: Raymond Clausen, 56; Served in Vietnam
description: Raymond M. Clausen Jr., a helicopter crewman in the Vietnam War who was awarded the Medal of Honor for rescuing fellow marines stranded in a minefield under enemy fire, died May 30 at a hospital in Dallas. Mr. Clausen, who lived in Ponchatoula, La., was 56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSSI, JOHN DAVID
description: ROSSI--John David. On May 31, 2004 in San Clemente, CA. Born June 4, 1927 in the Bronx to Anita and John Rossi. Served in the US Army in France and Germany in the aftermath of WWII. He had two passions in life, his family and the FDNY. Loving husband of Mary Carey, father of five, John (Marienza), Maureen (Bill), Patti (Danny), Michael (Becca), Stephen (Kim) and grandfather of seventeen. He had 32 years on the job and retired as Deputy Assistant Chief. He is also survived by two sisters, Helen Peter and Sylvia Brown, and two brothers, Roland Rossi and Albert Rossi. Memorial Mass will be July 30, 2004, 10 AM at St. Edward Catholic Church, Dana Point, CA. Donations can be made to the New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475.

title: Chinese Characters
description: Of all the books I published in my years at Random House, one of the oddest yet most delightful was the revised third edition of a Chinese cookbook originally brought out by another publisher in 1945. ''How to Cook and Eat in Chinese,'' by Buwei Yang Chao, was, as far as I can discover, the first successful attempt to provide an authentic rather than Westernized Chinese cookbook. It includes more than 200 recipes, with a sophisticated introduction to Chinese culinary culture that covers ingredients, techniques, politesse, terms and tools. Chao's recipes are still accurate and easily mastered, and her commentary remains fresh and informative. And with her help, I created my own polyglot improvisations long before fusion became the fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINGEROTH, NATHAN D.
description: FINGEROTH -- Nathan D. Born in Poland and raised in NYC. Passed away on Sunday, June 13, 2004. Nathan was the beloved husband of the late Fran and the loving father of daughters Joyce and Sharon and son-in-law Robert. He was an adoring grandfather to Johanna, Sara and Leah Fine and was deeply devoted to his brother Al. A long-term resident of NYC, Nathan watched with amazement as the city he loved grew. title: 1929:Largest Mouse Farm : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO

In the outskirts of the city is a mouse farm which is said to be the largest in the world. Its equipment consists for the most part of rows of small wire cages in which the mice live and breed. As a white mouse matures in a fortnight, the management of the farm generally counts upon having at least 50 mice at the end of a year for each two they had to start with. On an average the farm sells 50,000 mice a year to the larger dealers and laboratories in Europe.

Born August 2, 1901 and the last survivor of three sisters and a brother, she was an unassuming renaissance woman with a passion for the arts that she pursued until the end in her quest to find the beauty in life. An accomplished artist, sculptor, composer and pianist, she was blessed with perfect pitch, playing requests ''by ear'' until nearly 100. She is survived by her loving daughters, Ruth Brandt, and Joan Kaufman, her seven grandchildren, Robert, James, Gary and John Brandt, Leslie Kaufman Akst and Thomas and Scott Kaufman, her 16 great-grandchildren, Ryan, Austin, Zachary, Alexis, Taylor, Skylar, Barrie, Dylan, Jesse, Danielle, Alisa, Adam, Chloe, Alexis, Remy, and Tyler, and a wealth of wonderful memories. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARX, ERNA (KAHN)
description: MARX--Erna (Kahn), passed away peacefully in her sleep early Sunday morning, June 13, 2004. Erna was the widow of the late Dr. Henry Marx (an accountant and professor). Dr. and Mrs. Marx escaped Germany during the Holocaust and came to New York. She remained a New York City resident until she moved to the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT, 3 years ago. For the last 25 years, Erna devoted her efforts to the American Red Magen David of Israel. She was the president of the New York City Chapter for ARMDI and was an integral part of its fundraising activities. Erna was particularly helpful in assisting in the development of the Magen David Adom Blood Services Center in Ramat Gan, Israel. For her service, Erna received many awards from ARMDI over the years. Recently, Erna made a substantial contribution to ARMDI, which has named the Blood Fractionation Institute at the Blood Center in honor of Dr. and Mrs. Marx. Erna celebrated her 96th birthday this past week and was treated to a wonderful day of shopping, personal beauty and dinner with her loving and special companion care givers. Erna thoroughly enjoyed her final years at the Jewish Home with exceptional care, compassion and friendship due to a tremendous staff of nurses and caregivers. For more information contact Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home in Fairfield, 203255-8993. Burial will take place Monday, June 14, 2004 at Montefiore Cemetery on Springfield Boulevard in St. Albans, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to ARMDI (New York, NY) or the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield.

title: A New, Inclusive Europe Yawns, And Picks a Fresh Parliament

title: Congress Toys With Forgiveness
description: It seems axiomatic in Congress that whenever a bill comes along that both parties agree must be passed, it becomes a magnet for every piece of pork, every political cause, every lobbyist giveaway. The latest example is an urgently needed measure to end a $5 billion annual subsidy for American exporters that has put the nation in violation of international trade practices. Over the last few months, even as Europe began imposing billions in retaliatory tariffs on American industries, lawmakers have contrived to turn this relatively simple vehicle into a $100 billion gravy train.

title: Light Pollution
description: New Yorkers know all too well the effect of light pollution -- the bright orange glow that floats above every city in the state at night. That glow represents wasted energy, light that should be focused downward from outdoor lighting but that is actually emitted skyward. It costs us real money, and it also costs us something more intangibly valuable, a chance to see the night sky in all its glory. There is a good opportunity to do something about this. The State Senate Rules Committee has in its hands a bill that would call for the use of fully shielded outdoor lamps designed to concentrate light on the ground and not in the sky. The Assembly has already passed an identical version of it. The Rules Committee should send the bill to the Senate for passage and and on to Gov. George Pataki.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Three Stabbed On West Side
description: Three people were stabbed and two police officers were hurt in a melee that began outside a West Side restaurant early yesterday, the police said. The violence began at 4:30 a.m. in front of the Soul Caf at 444 West 42nd Street near 10th Avenue when a man identified as Darron Marcelle, 26, pulled a knife and stabbed two people, one several times and the other once in the torso. He fled, and another man, Robert Dickerson, of 149th Street in Manhattan, ran after him and began stabbing him, according to the police. Two officers arrived and one suffered a broken wrist and a cut to the face while trying to arrest Mr. Dickerson, the police said. The second officer had minor injuries. Mr. Marcelle and the other two people who were stabbed were reported in stable condition yesterday. Mr. Marcelle and Mr. Dickerson were arrested on assault and weapons charges, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Criticizes State Judge
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg publicly rebuked a State Supreme Court justice yesterday for allowing a defendant to slip from her courtroom to avoid being arrested in a separate robbery case. Speaking at the annual National Puerto Rican Day Parade, Mr. Bloomberg said the judge, Justice Laura D. Blackburne, ''seems to have stopped being the neutral court officer that she was elected to be and seems to think she is a police officer.'' He added, ''I thought what she did was an outrage, and she should be ashamed.'' Officials from the police and court officers' unions have called for Justice Blackburne to be removed from the bench and criminally charged, but Mr. Bloomberg declined to do the same, saying, ''That's for the review process and the courts to decide.'' Justice Blackburne could not be reached for comment last night. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSNER, HONORABLE CHARLES A.
description: POSNER--Honorable Charles A. Compassionate Jurist, devoted husband to Lynn, adoring father to Beth and Mark, delighted grandfather and dedicated public servant to the people of Brooklyn. Charles served as a Kings County Executive Assistant District Attorney from 1990 until his appointment to the bench in 1995. His humor and wisdom were generously shared with all who knew him. It was his belief in the power of our children that led Charles to develop the District Attorney's Office Legal Lives Program, now in over 300 classrooms in Brooklyn. Every day throughout Kings County there are detectives, Assistant District Attorneys and staff members empowering children to fight drugs and violence and opening their hearts and minds to appreciating diversity. Friends and former colleagues join me in expressing our deepest sympathy to his family. He will be deeply missed, but his spirit lives on through this legacy to the children of Brooklyn. Charles J. Hynes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDS, BRUCE A.
description: SANDS--Bruce A., 72, of Longboat Key, FL and Rye Brook, NY on June 13 of colon cancer at home surrounded by loved ones. He is survived by his devoted and beloved wife Lillian, his greatly loved and loving children Leslie, Karen, Stephen, Allison and Jennifer, his steadfastly devoted stepdaughters, Hope and Rebecca, his loving brother Robert, his adored and adoring grandchildren Emma, Graham, Rachel, Jenna, Benjamin, Hannah, Jesse and Greyson, his always supportive and caring sons-in-law Michael Milsom, Andrew Greenspan and Scott Oling and loving daughter-in-law Jill Sands. Born and raised on the West side of Manhattan, he moved to Longboat Key in 1990. After graduating from Horace Mann and Yale, he served as an officer in the US Navy. He has been involved in community service since moving to Florida. He served on the boards of the Jewish Community Center and Temple Beth Israel as President, as well as the American Jewish Committee. He served as the first Chairman of the Center for Catholic/ Jewish Studies (an outgrowth of the American Jewish Committee and Saint Leo University). His passion for the Temple Beth Israel Men's Club, of which he is Past President, and the importance of children is highlighted with his deep involvement in helping to send children to Camp Coleman in Cleveland, GA. He was a recipient of the Jewish National Fund's Tree of Life award and greatly appreciated the beauty and love of his extended family in Longboat Key and at Temple Beth Israel. He recognized the power of family, friends and service and the importance of making a difference. He will never forget the great fortune of having a loving, caring family and he will never be forgotten. Funeral service to be held at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd. in Rye New York on June 15 at 1 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his name to Camp Coleman, 201 Camp Coleman Dr., Cleveland, GA 30528.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Aruba To Supply Wi-Fi To Schools
description: Aruba Wireless Networks, a company based in San Jose, Calif., that deploys wireless network systems into corporations and schools, plans to announce today that it is outfitting up to 30 Houston-area schools with Wi-Fi Internet access. The company said the contract, which will serve the more than 20,000 students in the Spring Independent School District, was among the largest deployments to date of wireless Internet at an American school district. A growing number of educational institutions, particularly universities, are deploying Wi-Fi access, which can be less expensive than outfitting a campus with high-speed land lines. A representative of the school district, which is based in a suburb north of Houston, said the district intends for wireless technology to become the primary form of Internet access for students and faculty. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Gas Network Discussed
description: Indonesia will hold talks later this year with other major exporters of liquefied natural gas, including Brunei, Oman and Qatar, to explore the possibility of setting up a supply network to back up their own sales obligations. Indonesia's top energy official, Purnomo Yusgiantoro, said that such a network could help reduce the risk that supply disruptions would prevent any one exporter from meeting its contractual obligations to sell liquefied natural gas to long-term buyers. Indonesia is the world's largest exporter of liquefied natural gas, with most of its supplies going to Japan, South Korea and Taiwan under contracts of up to 25 years. Recent production shortfalls, however, have forced Indonesia to buy liquefied natural gas in the secondary market to meet its obligations. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Israelis to Extend Barrier Deeper Into the West Bank
description: Israel is preparing to build new segments of its separation barrier around Jewish settlements that would mark the deepest penetration yet into the West Bank, a move that drew sharp criticism from Palestinians on Monday.

title: A New One From The Pixies
description: The news everybody has been waiting to hear about the Pixies reunion has been confirmed: They have indeed recorded new music. The band's first new song in 13 years, ''Bam Thwok,'' is available for download on Apple's iTunes Music Store. The song, recorded in March, was written by Kim Deal, the bassist, who said in a statement yesterday that her lyrics were inspired by a young person's notebook she found on the street. ''This kid had written a short story, a paragraph really, about a party that took place in another universe, about people and monsters that were partying together,'' she said. ''It's a song about loving everyone, showing good will to everyone.'' The chorus goes: ''Love. Bang. Crash. Wakka, wakka, Bam Thwok.'' The Pixies are touring Europe and will return to the United States this summer. The group is to play the Lollapalooza festival at Randalls Island in New York on Aug. 17. BEN SISARIO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Blood Supply Is Dangerously Low
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Immigrants' Arrests Protested
description: Immigrant advocacy groups gathered outside Gov. George E. Pataki's Midtown office yesterday to protest the role of state parole officers in helping federal immigration officials seize 134 immigrant convicts, 115 of whom had green cards. Unaware that their convictions made them deportable, most were arrested on May 25 by federal agents when they reported to their parole officers. Scott Steinhardt, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Parole, said its role was ''solely to ensure the safe and timely transition of offenders to federal custody.'' But Martin Ficke, special agent with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, said those arrested were ''hard core criminals'' seized in a crackdown on deportable parolees. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

title: Of 4 Choices, 4 Millionaires For 2nd Spot In Kerry Run
description: As Senator John Kerry takes a closer look at potential running mates for the Democratic ticket, he will find that the four senators he is considering have one thing in common: Like him, they are millionaires.

title: He Pushed the Hot Button of Touch-Screen Voting
description: Kevin Shelley is a big and voluble Irish politician, the son of a former San Francisco mayor, and not the sort you would figure for the heretofore semi-obscure job of California secretary of state. But Mr. Shelley, who was elected to the post in November 2002 after a career as a state legislator, has adapted the job to suit his style, taking the arcane matter of voting machines and turning it into a hobbyhorse that some predict he could ride to the governor's office.

title: Israel to Add to Barrier
description: Israel is preparing to build new segments of its barrier around Ariel and other Jewish settlements that are more than 10 miles inside the West Bank. The move has drawn criticism from the Palestinians, and American officials have objected.

title: Connecticut Indians Denied Tribal Status, Dimming 3rd Casino's Chances
description: An American Indian group's efforts to open a casino in Connecticut's largest city were stopped in their tracks on Monday when the Bureau of Indian Affairs rejected the group's application for federal recognition as a tribe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Expanding
description: The Elan Corporation, the drug maker, said it would invest 35 million euros ($42 million) in a new plant in Ireland, creating 120 jobs over the next five years. Elan has begun hiring workers and building the plant, which will be at Athlone and begin operating by December 2005, Paul Breen, executive vice president for global services and operations, said at a news conference in Dublin, where Elan is based.

title: Whitman Knapp, 95, Dies; Exposed Police Corruption
description: Correction Appended

title: Roll Over. Fetch. Sit. Smart Dog? Hmmm.
description: I have always been a bit defensive about the intelligence of my dogs. I have tried to be objective, but everything in human nature goes against objectivity when it comes to children and pets. Love and loyalty cloud the clear, stark gaze of science, and that, I suspect, is why several German scientists recently conducted experiments with somebody else's border collie.

title: Regulators Will Decide Fate of Bid For Mandalay
description: Now that Kirk Kerkorian appears to have won over the Mandalay Resort Group in a $4.8 billion merger with his MGM Mirage hotel and casino empire, there is one player left to beat: regulators.

title: Blissfully Subservient in Stepford, 1975
description: 'The Stepford Wives'

title: After Weighing Cost of Lives, 9/11 Fund Completes Its Task
description: Nearly three years after establishing a fund to compensate the families of Sept. 11 victims, the federal government said yesterday that it had completed the task and that it would end up paying more than 5,000 families almost $7 billion.

title: Go Negative on the Allies
description: For months, Senator John Kerry has been among the loudest in the chorus criticizing President Bush for not persuading our allies to shoulder more of the Iraq burden. But now it is time for Mr. Kerry to start admonishing the allies. The problem today is not the administration's reluctance to woo allies, but rather the allies' reluctance to be wooed.

title: A Mix of Beer, Free Speech and Home-Grown Hip
description: Oleg Tinkov sees himself as something more than Russia's ''beer oligarch,'' as he has been called here.

title: QLT to Acquire Atrix Labs for $885 Million
description: Correction Appended

title: Cable Thievery Is Darkening Daily Life in Mozambique
description: At first blush, it may not seem odd that Mozambican businesses are doing a brisk trade in three-legged aluminum pots, ferried by the truckload to buyers in nearby Swaziland and South Africa. In fact, it would not be odd at all, but for two things.

title: Man in the News; From Doodles to Clintons -- Simmie Lee Knox
description: It was more than 50 years ago that a blinding sunspot, an ill-timed turn and the whack of a whizzing baseball left Simmie Knox with a badly bruised and wandering eye.

title: 4 European Nations Object To Bank Accounting Shift
description: The effort to impose an accounting rule that would force European banks to disclose the market value of their investments in derivative securities ran into an obstacle Monday when four countries -- at least two more than had been expected -- told the European Commission they opposed the rule.

title: Bush Plans to Transfer Hussein to Iraqis, but No Timetable Yet
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  President Bush said today that his administration was making plans to transfer custody of Saddam Hussein to the new Iraqi interim government. But he refused to be pinned down on exactly when the transfer would take place.

title: Mets Count On a Lift From Reyes
description: Jos Reyes began his third rehabilitation assignment last night, and although the Mets did not give a date for his expected return, the timetable is perfectly clear.

title: S.E.C. to Increase Scrutiny of Some Annuity Sales
description: Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission criticized the variable annuity industry on Monday for what they called its attempt to play down the extent of improper sales.

title: Home and Away, Yankees Continue to Bring in Fans
description: The Yankees are in first place in the American League East, stage rallies at the drop of a hat and are filling seats at Yankee Stadium at a rate that would shatter last year's home-attendance record. And that noise you hear is George Streinbrenner crowing.

title: Quick. It's Cleanup Time.
description: The leader of the New York Senate, Joseph Bruno, is often Albany's truth-teller, sometimes inadvertently. Such was the case recently when Mr. Bruno, a Republican, stood in the well of his gilded chamber and said, fuming: ''What we do best in the Legislature is we study, review -- nothing. We do that very well.'' Around the room, people of all political views fell silent, then nodded in agreement. New York's Legislature increasingly does nothing extremely well. But what added to the oddity of the moment was that Mr. Bruno is the one person who could actually do something about it. He could be responsible for one of the most important reforms in Albany's recent history: adopting the Assembly's bill requiring lobbyists to register in order to get state contracts.

title: Latest From McCain on V.P. Reports: 'I Hope It's Over'
description: Senator John McCain wasn't saying much Monday about those weekend news reports that Senator John Kerry had personally but informally proposed the idea of Mr. McCain's joining the Democratic ticket, only to have the Arizona Republican repeatedly signal that he was not interested.

title: Financier Increases Offer for Horizon Natural Resources
description: The financier Wilbur L. Ross and a group of noteholders of the Horizon Natural Resources Company, a coal producer, said yesterday that they had increased their bid for the company by 16 percent, to $277.4 million. Some creditors, including Deutsche Bank and an unsecured creditors' committee, withdrew earlier objections and supported the new bid, Mr. Ross's private equity firm, WL Ross & Company, said. WL Ross, based in New York, has stakes in two coal companies in West Virginia; a buyout of Horizon would help increase coal production by almost five times. Horizon, based in Ashland, Ky., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in November 2002.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRT Holdings, Irving, Tex., which owns about 40 Omni Hotels in North America, said it had bought Gold's Gym International Inc., the fitness chain, from Brockway Moran & Partners Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., a private equity firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ABC Bogeyed When It Dumped Buick Playoff for 'America's Funniest'
description: It was an embarrassment: three golfers, then two, battled to win the Buick Classic on Sunday evening, and only viewers in parts of the West Coast could see the playoff to its conclusion.

title: Supreme Court Declines To Extend Phone Pricing Rule
description: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to extend the rules that require the four regional Bell telephone companies to lease their networks at deep discounts to rivals in local markets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Drug Bust
description: Two Americans were detained at the Istanbul airport while carrying 55.5 pounds of pure cocaine, the largest quantity ever captured by the Istanbul police, NTV television reported. The drugs, with an estimated street value of $5 million, were packed in plastic bags in the suitcase of an American woman traveling from Brazil to Turkey via Frankfurt. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: But When Dogs Speak, Do We Listen?
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVATORY
description: When Coral Turns White

title: Arnold's Busy; Can Anyone Here Flex and Shoot?
description: Contestants on American talent shows don't want just to be famous; they want fame of a certain kind. Those who dream of being renowned for beauty (''America's Next Top Model'') or music (''American Idol'') differ from those who want to be famous for heroism, or even heroism-simulation.

title: Bush Lauds New Prescription Discount Cards
description: President Bush traveled to the swing state of Missouri on Monday for a rare campaign skirmish over Medicare, an issue that Republicans once had high hopes of turning to their advantage this year.

title: On a London Stage, a Hearing for Guantnamo Detainees
description: Some men lie on bunk beds as if terminally depressed, others appear to be reading the Koran; a few are seen in the familiar orange uniforms of detainees at the United States naval base in Guantnamo Bay in Cuba. A man in a gray suit steps forward, and with the words, voice and gestures of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld he frostily explains the difference between ''prisoners of war'' and ''unlawful combatants.''

title: Hearings Open on Taxing Rich To Raise Property-Tax Rebate
description: The Legislature opened hearings Monday on Gov. James E. McGreevey's proposal to raise the tax rate on New Jersey's wealthiest residents, in the first income-tax increase in this tax-averse state in 14 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, JUSTIN
description: GOODMAN -- Justin. The Board of Governors of Middle Bay Country Club of Oceanside, New York, on behalf of its membership, wishes to express its sympathy and condolences to the family of its esteemed member Justin Goodman. He will be sorely missed.

title: Buyout Firm Wants a Lower Price for Duane Reade
description: The investor Robert M. Bass wants to cut $24.4 million from the $700 million he agreed to pay for Duane Reade Inc., the largest drugstore chain in New York City, because of higher costs at the company. Mr. Bass's buyout firm, Oak Hill Capital Partners, proposed cutting the cash portion of the price to $16 a share, or about $391 million, from $17 a share, the retailer said. Oak Hill would also assume Duane Reade's $285 million in debt. Oak Hill cited the chain's $12.6 million in costs related to union benefits and $4.4 million in added yearly expenses in a letter asking for the price reduction, Duane Reade said. The chain's agreement with Oak Hill, set to expire July 1, was extended to July 13.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Tuition Increase Is Rolled Back
description: Tuition at four universities in Connecticut's State University system will not be increased as much as planned, the Board of Trustees decided yesterday in a unanimous vote. Under a plan approved in December, tuition was to increase 12.5 percent in September. But trustees cut the increase to 9.6 percent. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Trade Center Cultural Decisions Affected by What's Best for Lincoln Center
description: When it came time early this month for a final decision on the cultural presence at the World Trade Center site, city and state officials' focus was in large part on what would be best for a cultural site some five miles to the north -- at Lincoln Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Most Day Care Centers Reopen
description: All but 20 of the 350 city-contracted day care centers reopened yesterday, the Administration for Children's Services reported, after day care teachers, protesting the lack of a raise and a contract since 2000, walked off the job, leaving thousands of low-income parents struggling to find alternative arrangements. Day care supervisors, who belong to another union, stayed out another day to vote on whether to continue the strike. They were to return pending the outcome of discussions with city negotiators today. The day care teacher's union is scheduled to meet with the city on Wednesday. Both sides warned that if talks were not productive, the strike would resume. Three centers remained closed in the Bronx, as did eight in Brooklyn and nine in Queens. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: Volunteer in College, or Else
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Prices Surge at Fastest Rate in 3 Years
description: Prices paid by consumers in May rose at their fastest rate in more than three years, the Labor Department reported today. But the news was greeted positively by stock and bond traders, who had been worried in advance of the report that the news might be worse than it was.

title: Choosing Breast Cancer Surgery
description: Why are so many mastectomies performed, when less invasive lumpectomies are often an alternative? A new study reports that part of the answer may lie with the patients.

title: Computer Associates Restates Revenue Again
description: Computer Associates International Inc. yesterday restated revenue for the first three quarters of its 2004 fiscal year, adding to the $2.2 billion the software company has restated since it uncovered misreported sales dating to 2000. Revenue in the nine months ended Dec. 31 was cut to $2.43 billion from $2.44 billion, Computer Associates said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Computer Associates changed the way it booked subscription revenue, according to a company spokesman. The S.E.C. and the Justice Department are investigating the company's accounting. The restatement is tied to tighter accounting policy but is unrelated to the fraud charges that led to the ouster of Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUKIET, JOSEPH J.
description: BUKIET--Joseph J. The Officers, Members of The Board and Staff of The American Society for Yad Vashem mourn the passing of Joseph J. Bukiet, founding member and Vice Chairman of the Society. He was a Holocaust survivor who contributed greatly to the cause of Remembrance. Condolences to the entire Bukiet family. Eli Zborowski, Chairman American Society for Yad Vashem

title: Reaganite by Association? His Family Won't Allow It
description: As Republicans try to cloak President Bush in the mantle of Ronald Reagan, their biggest obstacle may be Mr. Reagan's own family.

title: The Baton Is Gently Passed At Chamber Music Society
description: It is easy to posit intrigue when the outgoing artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center plays what amounts to a valedictory concert with another organization. But the classical music world is a small family. Whatever the reasons behind David Shifrin's departure from his post at the society, which was announced last September, his recital on Sunday afternoon was simply prompted by a former colleague: Jacqueline Taylor, once the society's director, now a co-founder of Free for All at Town Hall, which offers high-caliber classical concerts free to the public.

title: Weighing the Risks of New Plumage
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIMARCO, SALVATORE C.
description: DiMARCO--Salvatore C., Jr. Leica Camera Inc. records with deep sorrow the passing of a great Leica photographer and ultimate gentleman. Our heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathies to the entire family.

title: New York Outpaces U.S. Economic Growth
description: New York City's economic growth is finally outperforming the nation's after four years in which it lagged behind, according to a report issued yesterday by the city comptroller.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about a request by Gen. John P. Abizaid, commander of American forces in the Middle East, to replace the officer investigating abuse at Abu Ghraib prison referred incorrectly in some copies to the date General Abizaid was shown testifying at a Senate hearing. It was May 19, not last Wednesday.

title: Obesity an Illusion? Fat Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Gay Marriage On Trial
description: A court will hold a hearing on June 29 on the legality of France's first same-sex wedding, the district attorney's office in Bordeaux said. The mayor of Begles, near Bordeaux, married Stephane Chapin and Bertrand Charpentier on June 5, arguing that French law did not specifically forbid same-sex marriages, but France's justice minister asked the Bordeaux district attorney to begin annulment procedures. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Report Finds Social Security Is Better Off Than Forecast
description: The Congressional Budget Office said Monday that it foresaw a significant, growing deficit in the Social Security program, but concluded that the long-term outlook was less dire than the administration had projected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEISHMAN, MARY E. (NEE MILLER)
description: LEISHMAN--Mary E. (nee Miller). Of Yorkville. On June 12 after a long illness. Lifelong Democrat and community activist. Former District Leader of the Eastside Democratic Club and of Community Planning Board 8. Beloved sister of Elizabeth Sweetra, Catherine Weldon, James, Dennis, Edward and the late Francis A., William, Jerome and Francis P. Miller. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces, grand nephews and friends. Reposing at Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 St, Manhattan on Wednesday June 16, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, June 17, 10AM at St. Joseph's Church of Yorkville. Interment at Sacred Heart Cemetery in Stamford, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Investment Grows
description: China reported an acceleration in foreign direct investment, suggesting that government measures to slow the economy are not prompting overseas companies to scale back their expansion plans. Investment from abroad increased 11 percent from a year earlier to $25.9 billion in the five months through May after rising 10 percent in the first four months of this year and 7.5 percent in the first quarter, the Ministry of Commerce said.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Singer's Case
description: The singer James Brown has decided not to contest domestic violence charges, forfeiting $1,087 in bond, his lawyer said. The lawyer, James Huff, said that although a guilty verdict would be entered, Mr. Brown had agreed with the arrangement only to protect his relationship and privacy. Prosecutors said that in January Mr. Brown pushed his wife, Tomi Rae, to the floor of their home in Beech Island. Mr. Brown will spend no time in jail, a prosecutor, Anthony Odom, said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Decline
description: The number of companies filing for bankruptcy declined in May for the 17th consecutive month as the strengthening economic recovery aided small and medium-size businesses, according to a research company. For the month, 1,182 companies filed for bankruptcy, down 20 percent from the month a year earlier, while debts left by failed companies fell 33 percent from last year, to 537.2 billion yen ($4.9 billion), according to the research company, Teikoku Databank. Japanese companies are benefiting from increasingly robust economic growth this year, fueled by exports to China and a fledgling rebound in consumer spending. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: On Baseball; No Lead Is Really Safe Against Yanks
description: MYSTIQUE and Aura are back. Alex Rodriguez disclosed their return Sunday after the Yankees gained another stunning comeback victory.

title: A Canadian Gate Where Illegal Immigrants Knock
description: Nine people trying to sneak into the United States illegally by way of a moonlit raft ride might not be out of the ordinary if the raft were floating off the coast of Florida or crossing the Rio Grande.

title: Boeing Wins Navy Contract To Replace Sub Chasers
description: The Navy awarded one of the Pentagon's biggest military contracts of the year to the Boeing Company yesterday by instructing it to replace a fleet of submarine-hunting airplanes from the Lockheed Martin Corporation at a potential cost of $23 billion.

title: Greenspan Says Inflation Is Not Yet a Concern
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told members of the Senate Banking Committee today that ``inflation is not likely to be a serious concern,'' but that policy makers were watching the effect of rising energy prices on the world and American economies very closely.

title: One court battle between Miller and Anheuser-Busch is called off, but their war is far from over.
description: THE bitter battle between rival brewers over the bizarre issue of the royal provenance of carbohydrates may be vanishing, even as the two step up their fight for sales and market share.

title: U.S. Is Urged To Charge Hussein Soon
description: If the United States government does not bring charges against Saddam Hussein relatively soon it will be technically required, because of his prisoner-of-war status, to release him after the restoration of limited sovereignty, officials with human rights and aid groups said Monday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Journals Are Said to Seek Registry of Drug Trials

title: New Jersey Town Awaits Word Of Man Held in Saudi Arabia
description: Before Monday, Joel Mahr knew little about his neighbor, Donna Mayeux. ''The only time I remember talking to her was when her garbage can blew over here,'' said Mr. Mahr, 31.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom To Settle Microtune Lawsuits
description: Microtune, a maker of radio tuners and amplifiers, said yesterday that the Broadcom Corporation agreed to pay $22.5 million to end all patent and antitrust litigation. The one-time payment to Microtune is part of an accord that also binds the companies to license each other's technology, Microtune said in a regulatory filing. All current products are covered by the settlement, the companies said in identical statements. Broadcom, a maker of chips for consumer electronics and computer networks, and Microtune, based in Plano, Tex., have fought in courts for more than two years over which company invented circuits and other technology used in cable-modem tuners. Cable modems, which receive numerous signals, require tuners to select the correct frequency for transmissions. The settlement covers a half-dozen lawsuits, including one that Broadcom was appealing because the company had been ordered to pay more than $8 million and told to stop selling some products. Microtune's chief executive, James A. Fontaine, said that court order would be lifted.

title: Politicus : Confronting Europe:a presidential tradition
description: PARIS  Ronald Reagan, who Europe now thinks may not have been such a terrible leader after all, and George W. Bush, who it persists in regarding as fairly awful, shared a problem. They asked the Europeans to do what they could not easily offer.

title: Coughlin Wants Barber To Grasp His Philosophy
description: Coach Tom Coughlin has the defensive players slap at the football as Tiki Barber carries it back to the huddle at the Giants' minicamp. There is a point. Coughlin does not have his players slap at the ball for no reason.

title: MEMO PAD
description: FARE WARS -- Some airlines may be losing tons of money, but that has not stopped scattered fare wars as the peak summer season approaches and low-cost carriers try to grab market share. American Airlines, for example, sharply reduced fares between its Dallas-Fort Worth hub and Los Angeles, a route where AirTran Airways plans to start nonstop service July 1. At Washington Dulles International Airport, where upstart Independence Air is set to start service tomorrow, Delta Air Lines is adding four flights on Aug. 1 to its current schedule of 11 flights between Dulles and its Atlanta hub. Delta also announced a fare sale yesterday for summer and fall travel to and from Atlanta. Starting tomorrow, Independence Air will fly eight daily round trips between Dulles and Atlanta, and double that number on Aug. 1.

title: But When Dogs Speak, Do We Listen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Corruption Case Against Sharon Is Dropped
description: JERUSALEM, June 15 — Israel's attorney general dropped a bribery investigation against Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today, bolstering the Israeli leader's push to withdraw from the Gaza strip and raising speculation that he will try to bring the Labor Party into a new governing coalition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIMANNO, GERALD T.
description: DiMANNO--Gerald T., on June 13th, 2004. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Smith). Director of Fordham Law Alumni. Retired Colonel US Air Force. Senior Partner at O'Neill, DiManno & Kelly. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Francis of Assisi Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Lower Standard of Proof Angers Athletes and Lawyers
description: The United States Anti-Doping Agency is drawing criticism from athletes' lawyers for its practices, especially a recent decision that appeared to diminish the standard of proof for athletes accused of doping offenses.

Abizaid, commander of American forces in the Middle East, to replace the officer investigating abuse at Abu Ghraib prison referred incorrectly in some copies to the date General Abizaid was shown testifying at a Senate hearing. It was May 19, not last Wednesday. ( Go to Article )

title: Potato? Po-tah-to? Tomato? Gershwin!
description: Known as ''the jeweler'' for the precision with which he set words to music, the lyricist Ira Gershwin would probably have applauded the whip-smart final program of this year's revitalized Lyrics and Lyricists series, performed over the weekend at the 92nd Street Y. The artistic portrait, organized by Rob Fisher, who played dual pianos with Chris Fenwick, was written by David Ives and narrated by Sheldon Harnick. It featured the singers Ivy Austin, David Garrison, Darius de Haas and Rebecca Luker and the bassist Dick Sarpola.

title: Woman, 26, Pleads Guilty In Deadly Smuggling Case
description: A 26-year-old Honduran immigrant pleaded guilty Monday to being the ringleader of the nation's deadliest smuggling case, which left 19 immigrants dead after being jammed without air or water in a tractor-trailer that was abandoned in South Texas last spring.

title: I Sing the Body's Pattern Recognition Machine
description: The brain is a five-star generalizer.

title: Angola's Elusive Oil Riches
description: Last month, the Angolan government did something startling: it announced that an oil deal signed with ChevronTexaco would bring the country $300 million. The disclosure of a single figure may not seem a triumph of transparency, but in the past Angola -- like many other countries -- treated its oil revenue as a state secret. Revealing its oil payments is the first of many anticorruption measures that Angola desperately needs.

title: Ginter Pitching And Grinning Way to Success
description: Matt Ginter strums a banjo on the Mets' team plane, watches hunting DVD's in the clubhouse and prepares for a start by thumbing through catalogs advertising the latest in Buck knives.

title: Prime Medical Will Pay $145 Million for HealthTronics
description: Prime Medical Services, which makes devices that break up kidney stones, agreed yesterday to buy HealthTronics Surgical Services Inc. for about $145.9 million in stock, a move that would give it access to HealthTronics' technology for treating prostate cancer and bone injury. Under the agreement, shareholders of Prime Medical would get one share of HealthTronics common stock for each share they own. HealthTronics, based in Marietta, Ga., manufactures machines for treating kidney and bone ailments. The acquisition would give Prime Medical exclusive rights to market a technology developed by Edap, a French company with a device that uses high-intensity ultrasound to treat prostate cancer. Prime Medical is based in Austin, Tex.

title: A Rookie From Arkansas Is a Hit With the Liberty
description: For a self-described small-town mama's girl who had come no closer to Madison Square Garden than seeing it on television, Shameka Christon, the Liberty's No. 1 draft pick, seems right at home in the big city.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Only I'm Having Caviar And You're Rowing

title: Nokia Aims New Models At the Midprice Market
description: Nokia, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, announced an effort on Monday to win back customers and build up its crumbling share of the market.

title: Group Weighs Plan for Full Drug-Trial Disclosure
description: An organization of top medical journals is considering a proposal that would require drug makers to register clinical trials at their start in a public database in order for results, whether successful or not, to be later considered for publication, according to three people working with the group.

title: Gambella Journal; A River Washes Away Ethiopia's Tensions, for a Moment
description: Bath time here is a communal affair. Everyone grabs a bar of soap and heads down to the river.

title: The Bells and the Ruling on Access Fees
description: The decision by the Bush administration last week to side with the regional Bell companies in their legal fight over the access fees they charge others to lease their phone lines has set off alarm bells among consumer groups, long-distance providers and state utility commissions.

title: Volunteer in College, or Else
description: To the Editor:

title: Nation Builders and Low Bidders in Iraq
description: From the abuses at Abu Ghraib prison to the mutilation of American civilians at Falluja, many of the worst moments of the Iraqi occupation have involved private military contractors ''outsourced'' by the Pentagon. With no public or Congressional oversight, the Pentagon has paid billions of dollars to companies that now have as many as 20,000 employees carrying out military functions ranging from logistics and troop training to convoy escort and interrogations. Yet despite the problems and the widespread accusations of overbilling, it appears the civilian leadership at the Pentagon has learned absolutely nothing from the whole experience.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 18 about a guilty plea by Guy J. Velella, the former New York State senator, to a bribery charge misstated the length of time he served in the Legislature. It was 28 years, not 31.

title: Sterling Financial to Buy Pennsylvania State Banking
description: The Sterling Financial Corporation, which operates 56 banks in Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware, agreed yesterday to buy the Pennsylvania State Banking Company for about $44 million. Pennsylvania State shareholders will have the option to exchange each share for either $22 in cash, 0.83 Sterling share or a combination. The price is 66 percent more than Pennsylvania State's price on June 1, when the stock last traded. The purchase will allow Sterling, based in Lancaster, Pa., to expand into Harrisburg, where the population is rising, analysts said. As of March 31, Pennsylvania State had $201.3 million in assets; Sterling had $2.3 billion in assets. Pennsylvania State, based in Camp Hill, Pa., will keep its name, and the chief executive and board will stay.

title: Does He or Doesn't He? It's Harder to Tell
description: Correction Appended

title: Holocaust Memorial Respects the Dead (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Advertising spending in major media for the first quarter rose more than forecast, by 9.6 percent, to $31.5 billion, compared with the period in 2003, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Iceland: Bank In Acquisition Deal
description: The Icelandic bank Kaupthing Bunadarbanki agreed to buy Swedbank's Danish lending unit for $1.56 billion, doubling its size and adding to a Nordic expansion. Kaupthing, which is based in Reykjavik, said it would finance the purchase of the Swedbank unit, FIH, with a subordinated bond and a rights offer. The price consists of 9 billion Swedish kronor ($1.2 billion) and 2.9 billion kronor in capital transferred from FIH, Swedbank said. Kaupthing has made purchases in Sweden, Norway and Finland, and opened an asset management firm in Britain.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Military Success Claimed
description: A military spokesman said it had successfully completed a five-day operation against foreign militants believed to be hiding in a remote northwestern tribal region. The militants were killed or dispersed, he said. None were arrested. Local residents said militants may have simply fled the area. The official toll was 55 militants and 17 security officers killed. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wine Merchant Grows
description: A British wine warehouse operator, Majestic Wine, said profit in its second-half rose 17 percent after it opened more outlets and Britons increasingly favored wine over beer. Net income for the six months through March 29 rose to 4.3 million ($7.8 million) from 3.7 million a year earlier, the chief executive, Tim How, above, said. Sales advanced 15 percent, to 79.1 million. The company, which is based in Watford, England, increased the number of wine warehouses it operates to 115 as more British consumers abandoned ale in favor of wine. The British wine market is growing at 6 percent, it said, compared with a decline of 2 percent in the amount of beer sold in British pubs last year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Presidential Runoff
description: A second round of voting will be held this month after no candidate won a clear majority on Sunday. The front-runner was Valdas Adamkus, 77, who returned from the United States and served as president between 1998 and 2003. He will oppose Kazimira Prunskiene, the first post-Soviet prime minister, who has the backing of Rolandas Paksas, who was removed from the presidency in April on corruption charges but remains popular. The impeachment has thrown Lithuania into political turmoil as it prepares to join the European Union next month. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRESLIN, ROSEMARY
description: BRESLIN -- Rosemary. She was the best we had. Rosemary Breslin died at 47 yesterday in Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. She was a writer and lived on blood transfusions for the last 14 years. In the last six years, she had transfusions every 12 days. She fought with raw and endless courage and made it look so easy. She loved life so much and lived with such grace and dignity, and, above all, high humor. She wrote beautifully. She was the daughter of the late Rosemary Dattolico Breslin and Jimmy Breslin, and stepdaughter of Ronnie M. Eldridge. She was married to Anthony Dunne, son of Jean and Richard Dunne of Harwichport, MA. She leaves brothers Kevin, James, Patrick and Christopher and sister Kelly, and many friends, bereft. All of us still think we can talk to her. A service will be held at 2:30 PM, Thursday, at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, 135 West 31st St. Before dying, she dictated to her stepmother a list of people she didn't want to attend her funeral. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Rosemary Breslin Fund for MDS at Memorial Sloan - Kettering, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021 will be appreciated.

title: Recording Police Questioning
description: Civil libertarians have long argued that interrogations in major criminal cases should be recorded. A videotape or audio recording of the police at work, they argue, would deter coercive questioning and reduce the number of false confessions. But the police and prosecutors have resisted. Now a new study has found that in the small number of jurisdictions that record their interrogations, law enforcement has come to favor it. The study makes a strong case that the states and localities that do not require recorded interrogations now should start to do so.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Heavy Battles
description: United States-led troops have killed more than 80 militants and captured 90 in fighting in southern Afghanistan during the past three weeks, an American military spokesman said. title: A Recollection of Early Questions About Reagan's Health

The portrayals raised questions about the health, and particularly the mental faculties, of a man who at age 69 would become the oldest to be elected president. During the campaign, Mr. Reagan agreed to let me talk to all his doctors, examine his records and then interview him about his health.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: One Dead And One Hurt In Stabbing
description: A Bensonhurst man was fatally stabbed at a bar in Brighton Beach yesterday, and an employee was wounded. The man, Paul Pomagrin, was apparently celebrating his 21st birthday at Spoon, a restaurant and bar at 615 Brighton Beach Avenue, when he got into an argument about 1:30 a.m. with four men over a woman, the police said. An employee, Kosty Pocekin, 25, tried to pull Mr. Pomagrin inside, but was stabbed in the chest. Then at least one man stabbed Mr. Pomagrin in the abdomen, the police said. Mr. Pomagrin died at Coney Island Hospital, where Mr. Pocekin was in stable condition. The police said there were no suspects. Campbell Robertson (NYT)

title: Jones Says Proxy Adviser Backs Maxwell Board Change
description: The Jones Apparel Group, which has bid $354 million for the Maxwell Shoe Company, said yesterday that the proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services had recommended replacing Maxwell's board with five directors nominated by Jones. Jones, maker of Nine West shoes and Anne Klein apparel, will give up its takeover bid by Sunday if no agreement is reached or if it does not receive enough shareholder votes to replace Maxwell's board, the company said. Jones raised its bid last month to $22.50 a share from $20. Institutional Shareholder Services said the offer ''has reached a level where Maxwell management should give shareholders the opportunity to vote.''

title: Bitter At The Top
description: It's been said that every society has two aristocracies. The members of the aristocracy of mind produce ideas, and pass along knowledge. The members of the aristocracy of money produce products and manage organizations. In our society these two groups happen to be engaged in a bitter conflict about everything from S.U.V.'s to presidents. You can't understand the current bitter political polarization without appreciating how it is inflamed or even driven by the civil war within the educated class.

title: Ahold Reports Loss From Efforts To Pull Back From Acquisitions

Around the same time, two more bombs went off, one south of the capital, one north, claiming eight more lives, making it one of the deadliest days in Iraq in the past month.

title: The C.I.A. and Iraq
description: It is no secret anymore in Washington that the Senate Intelligence Committee has produced a 400-page indictment of the Central Intelligence Agency's bungling on Iraq and of the hype and wishful thinking that underpinned President Bush's decision to go to war. Yet the administration continues to withhold the committee's critique from the public while the agency's own censors vet it slowly, excruciatingly slowly, for classified material they deem too risky for disclosure.

title: National Briefing | West: California: No Peterson Mistrial
description: The judge in the murder trial of Scott Peterson rejected a request for a mistrial by the defense lawyer, Mark Geragos. Mr. Geragos, above, objected strongly when two police officers from Modesto testified that Mr. Peterson ''threw his flashlight down on the ground'' and uttered a curse word after being questioned on the night his wife, Laci, disappeared. Mr. Geragos said the officers' testimony had not been revealed to the defense, as required by law. He asked the judge, Alfred A. Delucchi, in the trial in Redwood City to tell the jury to disregard the statements. When the judge refused, Mr. Geragos asked for a mistrial. ''The defendant's demeanor cuts both ways, so I don't think it's a big deal,'' Judge Delucchi said in response. Mr. Peterson is charged with killing his wife and unborn son in December 2002. Elizabeth Ahlin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Guard At Nazi Camp To Be Deported
description: A federal immigration judge has ordered the deportation of an 80-year-old Queens resident who was an armed guard at a Nazi forced labor camp during World War II, the Justice Department announced yesterday. The man, Jakiw Palij, left, of Jackson Heights, was stripped of his American citizenship last year after a federal judge found that he lied about his past when he came to this country in 1949. He was ordered deported to Ukraine and has 30 days to appeal. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Ford's Hybrid S.U.V. to Cost 15% More Than Gas Versions
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that prices for its new gasoline-electric Escape, the first sport utility vehicle to run on hybrid technology, will start at $26,380, about 15 percent more than models powered solely by gasoline. The Escape will cost $3,300 to $3,425 more than a comparably equipped 2005 V-6 gasoline-powered XLT version, Ford said. The company is introducing its first hybrid just as high gasoline prices erode the popularity of some light trucks. Ford, based in Dearborn, Mich., estimates a front-wheel-drive Escape will get 35 to 40 miles per gallon in city driving, compared with 20 for gasoline-only models.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUKLIN, ANTHONY BENNETT
description: KUKLIN--Anthony Bennett. An attorney and retired partner with Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton and Garrison, died on Monday, June 14, 2004 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. The cause was a heart attack. He was 74 and lived in Larchmont, NY. A former president of the American College of Real Estate Lawyers and a Division director of the American Bar Association Section of Real Property, Probate and Trust Law, he was a past Chairman of the Real Property Division of the International Bar Association. He was a governor of the Anglo-American Real Property Institute and a former Chairman of the Real Property Law Section of the New York State Bar Association. He was also a former member of the board of directors for the Chicago Title Insurance companies. A graduate of Harvard University and Columbia Law School, in recent years he taught a course on Real Estate Transactions at the law school. He is survived by his beloved wife, Vivienne, daughters, Melissa and Amanda, son-inlaw John and grandchildren, Samantha and Michael. Funeral services will be held privately. Memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Binational Credit Card
description: Citigroup and its Mexican subsidiary Banamex are introducing a binational credit card that can be used by families on both sides of the border. A relative living in the United States will receive a card from Banamex's banking arm, California Commerce Bank, and a relative in Mexico will get a card from Banamex. The American cardholder may make payments, in dollars, on purchases charged on the card in both countries. Last year, Mexicans working abroad sent $13.2 billion to relatives at home. Banks like Citigroup and Bank of America have been looking for ways to tap into this cross-border flow. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

description: The Callaway Golf Company said yesterday that it expected second-quarter profit to fall to as low as 10 cents a share, well below Wall Street forecasts and cut its forecast for the year. Callaway, based in Carlsbad, Calif., said it expected to earn 10 cents to 14 cents a share in the second quarter on sales of $290 million to $295 million. Excluding one-time items, Callaway expects to earn 19 cents to 23 cents a share, below the 60 cents forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. It earned 52 cents a year earlier.

title: Gas Prices Lead Gradual Rise in Inflation

Before that, Virgin must find American investors willing to purchase at least 51 percent of the airline, and assume 75 percent of the voting rights, both of which are required for the federal government to certify the carrier as a United States airline. Virgin America plans to start service with 33 planes. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: Food Stuff; Fresh Pasta (Just Add Water)

She rolled out ''snakes,'' which I cut into nuggets that she lightly pressed with a fork, then arranged on a baking sheet, ready to boil up and serve. Fresh gnocchi in time for lunch!

He was Gus Williams, not Johnson.

title: Whitney Hires Renzo Piano To Design Its Expansion
description: The Italian architect Renzo Piano has been hired by the Whitney Museum of American Art to design an expansion for its permanent collection and for much-needed public and educational space. The decision was made at a special board meeting yesterday after a six-month search by the Whitney's architect selection committee.

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops Approve New Series of Audits on Abuse
description: In continuing fallout from the clergy sexual abuse scandal, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops voted overwhelmingly yesterday at a closed meeting in Colorado to approve a second round of audits to assess whether each diocese has carried out policies to prevent abuse.

title: Soft-Spoken and Melancholy, With Some Moments of Busting Out
description: Six songs into Dido's concert at the Beacon Theater on Monday night, right in the middle of yet another room-temperature ballad, ''Isobel,'' her guitar player unleashed a wailing solo. At first this seemed an act of musical sabotage -- Why ruin one of Dido's many unobjectionable songs? -- but the logic soon became clear.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer To Disclose Plan
description: The retailer Marks & Spencer said yesterday that it would disclose detailed plans aimed at improving performance ahead of its annual meeting in July, the latest move in the company's defense against a takeover attempt. The real estate magnate Philip Green, who owns other British clothing chains, made an unsolicited bid for Marks & Spencer worth about 7.5 billion; that bid was rejected on June 3. Marks & Spencer's new chief executive, Stuart Rose, who was hired in May to fight the attempted takeover, will explain the company's new strategy on July 12, two days before its annual meeting. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Pepsi Bottling Ventures, Raleigh, N.C., the third-largest bottler of Pepsi-Cola in the United States, plans to buy closely held Pepsi-Cola Bottling Co., Salisbury, Md., to expand into Maryland, Virginia and Delaware. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Anti-Terror Police Arrest 12
description: French anti-terrorism police arrested 12 people in nine locations north of Paris on suspicion of terrorist-related activities. The 12, including an Islamic cleric, were associated with a small mosque in the Parisian suburb of Levallois-Perret and are being held for questioning. The arrests come amid a crackdown on fundamentalist mosques in France as the country tries to stem the spread of radical Islamic groups. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: SONIC INNOVATIONS SHARES FALL ON REDUCED OUTLOOK
description: The stock of Sonic Innovations Inc., a maker of hearing aids, fell 38 percent yesterday after the company lowered its second-quarter earnings forecast, citing cutbacks in health care benefits in Germany. The company, which is based in Salt Lake City, said on Monday that Germany cut reimbursements for hearing aids by about 8 percent, and a co-payment was instituted for specialist doctor visits, including visits to physicians who fit hearing aids. The company said it did not expect German sales to return to first-quarter levels for the rest of the year. Sonic said it now expected second-quarter earnings of 2 cents to 4 cents a share on sales of $24 million to $25 million, below the earnings of 7 cents a share and revenue of $27.1 million expected by Wall Street analysts. Its shares fell $3.51, to $5.66 a share.

title: With a Tap From Putin, a Leader Emerges for Chechen Presidency
description: The leading candidate for the presidency of Chechnya emerged Tuesday when President Vladimir V. Putin signaled support for Maj. Gen. Alu Alkhanov, the Russian republic's top police official, a man who until now was little known to the public.

title: Backstage at Camelot: Scenes From a President's Marriage
description: Correction Appended

title: In Mexico, Anger Over Gas Terminals
description: Correction Appended

title: Slumping Bats Cost Walling His Job as Coach
description: On the day that the Mets fired their hitting coach, Denny Walling, and replaced him with Don Baylor, a photographer asked Baylor if he would pose in front of a wall near the home clubhouse.

title: When Politics Corrupts Money
description: The World Bank has a human rights problem: it doesn't respect them enough. The bank also has a political problem: concern about global poverty, according to its president, James D. Wolfensohn, is ''near a low point.'' Yet the bank, concerned about the second problem, seems to lack awareness of the first -- to the detriment of its mission to help the world's poor.

title: In D-Day's Shadow, Pacific Veterans Celebrate
description: Sixty years after they charged onto beaches here, aged American veterans strolled past tourist hotels on Beachfront Street on Tuesday in a parade marking the start of the 60th anniversaries of a series of battles that they describe as the ''D-Days of the Pacific.''

title: The Justices and 'Under God'
description: To the Editor:

title: AWARD FOR LORNE MICHAELS
description: Lorne Michaels, the creator and executive producer of ''Saturday Night Live,'' was named yesterday to receive the Kennedy Center Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. In a statement the center said, ''His creation of 'Saturday Night Live,' which has become an American icon, along with his work in film and on Broadway, has provided this nation with some of its greatest comedians.'' The cast of the show, which will begin its 30th season in the fall, has included Dan Aykroyd, John Belushi, Dana Carvey, Chevy Chase, Billy Crystal, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Eddie Murphy, Bill Murray and Gilda Radner. Over the last three decades Mr. Michaels has won 10 Emmys as a writer and producer. In a ceremony at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Oct. 25, Mr. Michaels will receive a copy of an 1884 bronze portrait bust of Mark Twain by Karl Gerhardt (1853-1940). JOHN FILES

title: The 'Last Civil War Widow' Has a Successor, It Would Seem
description: For the last several years, Alberta Martin had been celebrated as the last widow of a Confederate veteran of the Civil War. Flashing a Confederate battle flag, she traveled to commemorative ceremonies and descendants' gatherings, once shaking hands with the widow of a runaway slave who had fought with the Union Army.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Church Tax Measure Fails In House Committee
description: The House Ways and Means Committee killed a proposed measure to reduce the tax penalties on churches that engage in partisan politics. The measure, called ''Safe Harbor for Churches,'' attracted criticism because it was attached to a larger corporate tax bill just days after the disclosure this month that President Bush's re-election campaign was looking for members of ''friendly congregations'' to distribute campaign information at their places of worship. David Kirpatrick (NYT)

title: Prices for Consumers Show Large Increase
description: A surge in gasoline prices raised the consumer price index by 0.6 percent in May, the largest monthly increase in three and a half years, the government reported. Food prices also jumped, while the prices of many other items rose by enough to suggest that the inflation rate will continue to climb gradually.

title: Republican National Convention Donors
description: The following is a partial list of donors. The committee continues to withhold the amounts donated, saying only that the list includes contributors who gave from $2,500 to $5 million, and it has held back the names of 20 contributors who have asked not to be identified now, committee officials said.

title: Jackie Chan Dives In to Rough Up Jules Verne
description: Sometimes nonsense makes good sense. The latest remake of Jules Verne's 1873 globe-trotting fantasy, ''Around the World in 80 Days,'' is a deliriously silly caper that goes out of its way to thumb its nose at logic. This swatch of epic slapstick, in which three madcap adventurers from London play beat the clock in a race to circle the earth by any means necessary, lets all its seams show. Don't ask how the travelers get out of one scrape and proceed to the next. Let the animated chapter introductions fill in the blanks.

title: F.T.C. Rebuffs Plan to Create No-Spam List
description: The Federal Trade Commission declared yesterday that a ''do not e-mail list'' modeled after the immensely popular ''do not call list'' would not be effective, suggesting such a list might help spammers find legitimate e-mail addresses.

title: Abandoned Space, the Final Frontier? Hey, It's a Whole Other Business
description: When Wal-Mart opened a supercenter along Highway 183 in this Dallas suburb in the mid-1990's, its existing discount store about one mile to the east became one of the thousands of surplus big-box stores across the country that have had to be recycled or demolished. For eight years, the 85,000-square-foot building stood empty.

title: Dare We Call It Genocide?
description: The Bush administration says it is exploring whether to describe the mass murder and rape in the Darfur region of Sudan as ''genocide.'' I suggest that President Bush invite to the White House a real expert, Magboula Muhammad Khattar, a 24-year-old widow huddled under a tree here.

title: If Music Be the Food. . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Put on D.L. With Strained Back
description: The Yankees will give Brad Halsey his first major league start on Saturday in place of Kevin Brown, who was placed on the 15-day disabled list on Tuesday with a strained lower back.

title: If It's June 16, This Must Be Bloomsday
description: STATELY, plump Isaiah Sheffer rises each morning around 6:30, but every June 16, it is his custom not to dress in green. That's the anniversary of the day in 1904 when Leopold Bloom, the fictional Irish Jew in James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' walks through the streets of Dublin and his own interior life. Although Joyce pungently described a certain green as the color of Irish poets, Mr. Sheffer explains that to wear it, especially on this centennial of Bloomsday, would be a faux pas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SNOW, JULES JOSEPH
description: SNOW--Jules Joseph. On June 14, 2004. Adored husband and best friend of Joan. Loving father of Jamie and Marty Markowitz, Jeremy and Lisa Snow. Beloved Papa of Chloe, William and Andrew. Dear brother of Selma Nemeroff and the late Estelle Posner. Service today, 10AM ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the acquisition of Atrix Laboratories (which makes drugs for prostate cancer and skin conditions) by QLT (maker of the eye disease drug Visudyne) misstated the price of the deal, in cash and stock. It is $855 million, not $885 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Complaints Discounted
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday discounted claims by two women that they were bruised and threatened by police officers on Sunday evening after the Puerto Rican Day Parade. The women's claims -- first reported on New York 1 News -- grew out of a confrontation about 10 p.m. on Fifth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, after the police had tried several times to clear the street, Mr. Kelly said. An amateur photographer's video appeared to show the officers using pepper spray, and two women told a television reporter that they were manhandled and threatened, off camera. Mr. Kelly said he reviewed the video Monday night. ''There was a confrontation,'' he acknowledged. But, he said, ''I didn't see any inappropriate activity on the part of the police. They're moving people back.'' Mr. Kelly said officers from the Internal Affairs Bureau had visited the scene. City Councilwoman Sara M. Gonzalez said after meeting with Mr. Kelly yesterday that she would arrange a second meeting with him and residents of the community. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg also dismissed the allegations. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Another Coke Classic
description: Coke, America's most iconic brand, no longer seems to be it, or even the real thing. It isn't just Coca-Cola's lackluster performance that is worrisome. After all the attention placed on corporate governance in the post-Enron world, this blue-chip company's blue-chip board has become a weak guardian of shareholder interests. The board does not seem to have noticed that doling out tens of millions of shareholder dollars for mediocre results is no longer in vogue. The company has paid out more than $200 million in recent years to departing executives, most prominently to its former chief executives Douglas Ivester and Douglas Daft.

title: No Bams, No Tricks, Just Food and a City
description: AS a rule, the stars of cooking shows tend to be chefs with their respective affectations -- a propensity for screeching, exotic knife trickery or flaunting sex appeal. But the latest entry into the genre focuses not on the chef, but rather his venue, a federal-style mansion that has housed generations of New York mayors, and the city itself, a giant vendor of ethnic goods reflecting the city that the chef is cooking for.

title: After Sputnik, It Was Russian; After 9/11, Should It Be Arabic?
description: Correction Appended

title: An industry group wants to know who leaked the details of an audit criticizing Nielsen's changes.
description: IN another twist in the increasingly nasty dispute over the changes Nielsen Media Research is making in the way it measures television ratings, the Media Rating Council plans to investigate how details of a confidential audit, critical of Nielsen, became public.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; Downtown Hartford's Future May Be in New Hotel Rooms
description: The hotel industry here has been in decline for many years, with occupancy rates falling to less than 60 percent in the months after Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCONNELL, GERALD MILLER
description: McCONNELL--Gerald Miller. June 14, 2004. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Kevin, Patricia and Sean. Loving brother of Patricia Kennedy. Memorial Service Thursday, June 17, 2004, 4PM at the Society of Illustrators, 128 E. 63 St., NYC.
