description: A FEW things you may not know about Peter Hoffman:

title: Fox Seeks to Allow Mexicans Living Abroad to Vote in 2006
description: President Vicente Fox said Tuesday that he would ask Congress to allow millions of Mexican citizens living abroad to vote for president in 2006.

title: Who Needs Money When You've Got a Lot of Nerve?
description: Upspeak -- the phrasing of almost everything as a question -- is often cited as evidence of insecurity in young women. But the question mark is power for Nicole Richie, the trampy tyrant who lived with her pal Paris Hilton on a farm for ''The Simple Life'' last season. Questions from Ms. Richie can mortify; they can also be a prelude to full-on larceny or assault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WENGEL, SHELDON
description: WENGEL--Sheldon. On June 14th. Beloved husband of Linda. Loving father of Steven Sakamoto - Wengel, Robert Wengel and Marni Beyer. Adored grandfather of seven. Services at 1PM on June 17th at Oakland Mills Meeting House, Columbia, MD.

title: In the Age of Parity, It's Anyone's Open
description: Last year, two players not ranked among the top 100 in the world won major championships: Ben Curtis (British Open) and Shaun Micheel (P.G.A. Championship).

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: CUOMO APPEALS FOR 'FAHRENHEIT 9/11'
description: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York said yesterday that he had been hired by Lions Gate Films to help appeal a decision by the Motion Picture Association of America to give the new Michael Moore political documentary, ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' an R rating instead of PG-13. The ratings board said it had based its decision on the film's ''violent and disturbing images'' and strong language. The movie, which opens on June 25, gained wide attention after the Walt Disney Company refused to distribute it. A sharp critique of the Bush administration and its decision to go to war in Iraq, it later earned the top prize at the Cannes film festival. Lions Gate, an independent studio, agreed this month to distribute the movie. Mr. Cuomo, who said he supported Senator John Kerry's bid to unseat President Bush, said he had seen the film three times and was ''convinced that it should be viewed and reflected upon by as many Americans as possible.'' He said he did not believe the movie association's decision was politically motivated, but he added that ''there has been a tough political effort to keep this film from being viewed.'' RANDY KENNEDY

title: U.S. Planning to Turn Over Baghdad Airport to Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 16  American administrators will turn over civil aviation operations at Baghdad International Airport to the Iraqi Ministry of Transportation after a new Iraqi government assumes limited sovereignty on June 30, occupation officials said today. The airport's military operations will to be turned over by mid-August, they added.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, IDA
description: SHAPIRO--Ida, 93, formerly of Beechhurst, Queens. Died on June 13. A graduate of Hunter College, she retired in 1976 after a career as teacher and administrator at Bayside High School and Martin Van Buren High School. Pre-deceased by husband Irwin D. Shapiro, she is survived by sons Jonathan of West Newton, MA. and Ethan of Rockaway, N.J., brother Leon Smith of Monroe Township, N.J., three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Irishmen Freed From Prison
description: Three Irishmen linked to the Irish Republican Army were freed from a Bogot prison, two months after a judge found them innocent of teaching bomb-making to Marxist rebels but convicted them of traveling on false passports. The men, Niall Connolly, James Monaghan and Martin McCauley, were arrested in 2001 after leaving a rebel camp in the south. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fuel Output To Grow
description: The EnCana Corporation, an oil and natural gas producer, raised its output estimates for this year and 2005, citing strong natural gas production in the American Rockies and western Canada, as well as growth at its Alberta oil sands operation. Including the recent acquisition of Tom Brown Inc. of Denver, EnCana said that it now expected sales volumes to grow by 15 percent this year and 12 percent in 2005, to a total of 810,000 to 860,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day. The company, which is based in Calgary, plans to expand its capital spending by $850 million this year to almost $6.7 billion. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Making Old Music New Again
description: One could say the Riverside Symphony's program at Alice Tully Hall on June 10 was subversive in its newness. That is, nothing on it was all that new, but it wasn't all that familiar, either. The orchestra has devoted itself to less-explored corners of the repertory in its two-plus decades of existence, and this concert was no exception.

title: Yukos Offers a Settlement to Avoid Bankruptcy
description: Yukos, the Russian oil giant, has offered to settle the government's $3.4 billion tax claim in a desperate attempt to avert bankruptcy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oracle Earnings Increased 15% in the Fourth Quarter

title: UNITED INDUSTRIES AGREES TO ACQUIRE UNITED PET GROUP
description: The United Industries Corporation, which makes lawn and garden products, agreed to buy the closely held United Pet Group for $360 million from TA Associates, Friend Skoler & Company and company management. The combined company will have annual sales of $1 billion, including $250 million from United Pet, said Dan Johnston, chief financial officer of United Industries, which is based in St. Louis. United Pet, based in Cincinnati, will be a division of United Industries, which is owned by the buyout firm Thomas H. Lee Partners.

title: Sports of The Times; Woods Takes A Swing At TV Critics
description: AS Tiger Woods strode onto the fifth tee during the final round of the recent Memorial tournament, his caddie, Steve Williams, plunked down his big black bag of clubs directly in front of the lens of television's swing cam, blocking the video that television analysts use to dissect a golfer's mechanics.

title: City Plans to Rezone Overdeveloped Neighborhoods in Queens
description: More than a dozen neighborhoods in Queens will be rezoned to curb overdevelopment in the most ambitious rezoning of the borough in more than 40 years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday at Queens Borough Hall. By tinkering with these neighborhoods -- a process that began for some of the areas in 2002 -- developers will be prohibited from building multiple-family dwellings on lots that have traditionally served single-family homes.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bloomfield: Redevelopment Grants Set
description: Jane M. Kenny, regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced more than $3 million in federal grants yesterday to help decontaminate and redevelop old industrial sites in New York and New Jersey. The grants are part of $75 million in federal funds that the agency will provide to communities across the country for revitalizing thousands of polluted industrial properties, called brownfields, that present comparatively low health risks. Appearing at the municipal garage in Bloomfield, Ms. Kenny said that by bringing together private companies and government agencies to clean up and rebuild the contaminated sites, the brown fields program ''creates opportunities to solve local problems for redevelopment with local solutions.''

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Minor Maneuvering Problem For Rover
description: Just as it completed a two-month, two-mile journey to a hilly region on Mars of interest to scientists, NASA's rover Spirit has come up partly lame. Mission managers said that the motor driving the rover's right front wheel was drawing two to three times as much electrical current as those for the other five wheels, indicating that the motor's gears were not turning smoothly. The problem has worsened since it surfaced three weeks ago, but even if the balky motor burned out, the rover could still maneuver, NASA said. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: An Anxious Time for Boeing As a Fired Worker Starts to Talk
description: The Boeing Company is undoubtedly celebrating its victory this week over its rival, the Lockheed Martin Corporation, snatching a multibillion-dollar contract to build a new generation of submarine-chasing aircraft, a role Lockheed has held for more than 40 years.

title: IRAQ UPDATE
description: OIL LINE RUPTURE -- The bombing of oil pipelines near the Persian Gulf forced the shutdown of Iraq's main oil export terminal for up to 10 days, potentially costing the country $600 million in revenue. [Page A1]

title: A Lawyer Who Just Couldn't Say No
description: Thousands of lawyers helped Sept. 11 families. Many accepted a family or two; a few took on as many as half a dozen. But Daniel Kramer accepted about two dozen cases that were submitted to the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund -- far more than anyone else, according to a fund official.

title: T2 Group Is Acquired By Advanta, a Marketer
description: The T2 Group in Philadelphia, opened by Brian P. Tierney five months ago, is being acquired and absorbed by the Advanta Corporation in Spring House, Pa., a credit card marketer that is also a longtime client of Mr. Tierney. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Charges Against Kurdish Mullah Dropped
description: The authorities have dropped an investigation into terrorism charges against the fundamentalist Islamic cleric Mullah Krekar, a Kurd who founded the terrorist group Ansar al-Islam in northern Iraq. The government said that dropping the inquiry would not change its legal battle to expel Mr. Krekar, who was granted refugee status in Norway after the Persian Gulf war in 1991. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Torture, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLINK, SANDRA SCOTT
description: KLINK--Sandra Scott. Was lost to us after a long illness on June 10, 2004. Beloved mother of Kirsten Morehouse and Trina Morehouse of NYC. Cherished grandmother of Theodora Lindsay Scott Smith, wife of Fredric J. Klink. Editor at New York Magazine and King Features Syndicate. She was loved for her passion for animals, folk art, travel and literature, all shared with her many treasured friends and family. A dedicated volunteer, she donated time and energy to others. Her creativity and graciousness will live on in her adored girls. A celebration of her life and prayers for her final peace will be offered at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday, June 17th, 4PM.

title: Library Given A Collection Of the Makings Of Hit Musicals
description: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts has received a gift of thousands of pages of scripts, songs and other pieces of stage memorabilia from two of Broadway's best-known musical teams: Kander and Ebb, and Bock and Harnick. The donation, ranging from scraps of pure inspiration to less successful discards, gives a glimpse of the sometimes delightful, sometimes devilish backstage grind that went into making classic musicals like ''Cabaret'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Medical Marijuana Backed
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, left, announced his support yesterday for the medical use of marijuana during an unusual news conference with the talk-show host Montel Williams. They joined forces to support legislation in the State Assembly that would legalize the use of marijuana for the treatment of illnesses. Ten states allow such use now. ''Morphine, codeine and other controlled substances have been available for years to those who are in pain and for other medical purposes,'' said Mr. Morgenthau. ''Medical marijuana should join the list of carefully monitored drugs that should be made available to those in need.'' Mr. Williams, who suffers from multiple sclerosis, was overcome with emotion as he described the severe pain for which he uses legally prescribed marijuana, saying, ''There are times I can barely put my feet on the floor.'' Mr. Morgenthau said he had been swayed in part by one of his daughters, a medical doctor at a drug treatment program in a hospital in the city, who approves of medical marijuana. Asked by a reporter if he had ever used marijuana himself, Mr. Morgenthau, 84, blushed. After howls of laughter died down, Mr. Morgenthau smiled and said, ''I missed that generation.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: The Environment Shortchanged
description: The Interior Department's appropriations bill, scheduled for a House vote this week, is a stunning example of what happens to discretionary domestic programs when a complicit White House allows tightfisted lawmakers to have their way. Nothing much escapes the ax, including in this case two programs that were central to President Bush's environmental agenda in the 2000 campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHUTE, KATHERINE VAN VARICK
description: SHUTE--Katherine Van Varick, age 93, on June 11, 2004 in Georgetown, CT. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin R. Shute. Graduate of Smith College and Columbia Law School. Survived by her children, Benjamin, Jr. and Mary S. Ford; five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Funeral Services Saturday, June 19, 11:00AM, Christ Church, Redding Ridge, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Christ Church, P.O. Box 54, Redding Ridge, CT, or Grosvenor Neighborhood House Y, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCMENAMIN, JOAN STITT
description: McMENAMIN -- Joan Stitt. The Directors of The Clark Foundation note with profound sorrow the passing of Joan Stitt McMenamin, a beloved and esteemed educator who was a member of our Board of Directors for the past 25 years. Her passion in advocating opportunity for the education and training of those in need was resolute, and her wise counsel and guidance served our mission well. Joan will be deeply missed and our sympathies are extended to her family and to all those whom she has inspired over the course of her distinguished life. Jane Forbes Clark, President The Clark Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TALIAFERRO, C. CHAMPE
description: TALIAFERRO--C. Champe, of Hobe Sound, Florida on June 14, 2004. Airmail pioneer and stunt pilot in the 1920s and 1930s. Later flew DC3s to Florida and flying boats from New York to Europe. During World War II he tested fighter planes for Grumman and flew for Naval air transport. He participated in the Berlin Airlift and was a senior pilot for American Overseas and Pan American. In 1965 he retired as Chief Flight Instructor for Pan American. The next year he and a friend sailed his 40 foot sloop from Florida to Portugal. Husband of the former Margaret Salvage, father of sons James, Robin, Charles and daughter Barclay Marcell, step-father of Phyllis Wells and James Polk. Grandfather of four. If any wish to donate in his memory, the family suggests Juvenile Diabetes Research, 1800 South Australian Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33409. A memorial service will be held in the fall at Christ Memorial Chapel, Hobe Sound.

title: Kerry Calls Bush Off-Base on Economy and Cost of Iraqi Prisoner Abuse
description: Senator John Kerry sharply criticized President Bush on two fronts Tuesday. He asserted that Mr. Bush had overestimated the health of the economy and underestimated the damage to the United States from the Iraqi prisoner abuse scandal.

title: Where the Land Is a Tinderbox, the Killing Is a Frenzy
description: Before there were mass graves here, there was the matter of cows and corn patches.

title: What About the Children?
description: While developments on the terror front were dominating the news, Senator John Kerry turned today to an issue familiar to millions of American families: what to do with the kids when both parents work.

title: Keeping the Kids After School

Services Thursday, 11 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Program Would Ease Security a Bit for Frequent Fliers
description: Airport security officials will enroll 5,000 to 10,000 frequent fliers as ''registered travelers'' in a five-airport pilot program beginning this month, the Transportation Security Administration will announce Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANONICO, SALVATORE L.
description: CANONICO--Salvatore L. The Associates of Canonico & Ostrowsky are saddened by the loss of its founder. He was a skilled and devoted advocate, mentor and friend. ''We will grieve not, rather find strength in what remains behind.'' Joseph Ostrowsky Richard Freggans

title: National Briefing | West: California: Another Budget Deadline Passes
description: For the 19th straight year, the state constitutional deadline of June 15 passed without the Legislature's enacting a budget. But lawmakers and Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger expressed confidence that negotiations would produce a $103 billion budget by the start of the new fiscal year on July 1. Talks between the governor and the Legislature have been less contentious this year than in recent years, in part because this governor, a Republican, has already reached deals with local government leaders, teachers' unions and university presidents to reduce their financing next year in exchange for increases in later years. John Broder (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gallery Executives Indicted
description: The owner and manager of a Manhattan art gallery were indicted yesterday on charges that they sold forgeries of paintings by modern masters, including Paul Gauguin and Marc Chagall. The federal indictment charges that over 15 years, Ely Sakhai, who owns the Exclusive Art gallery, bought original works by major artists and then sold copies, often to collectors in Asia. The business began to unravel in May 2000, when Mr. Sakhai offered his original of a Gauguin work, ''Vase de Fleurs (Lilas),'' for auction at Sotheby's at the same time as a forged copy he had sold three years earlier was offered by Christie's, according to the indictment. The manager, Houshi Sandjaby, was also charged in the case. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILLESPIE, LORRAINE (NEE WILLIS)
description: GILLESPIE--Lorraine (nee Willis). Of Englewood, NJ on June 13, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Dizzy Gillespie (1993). Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30 A.M., St. Cecilia Church, Englewood, NJ. Interment Flushing Cemetery, Queens, NY. Donations to the Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, Dizzy Gillespie Fund, 350 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631 would be appreciated. For directions visit www.barrettfuneral home.net.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about advances in transplanting hair misidentified the manufacturer of dutasteride, a drug being tested for its hair-growing ability. It is GlaxoSmithKline, not Merck.

title: After Weighing Value of Lives, 9/11 Fund Completes Its Task

description: Gov. James E. McGreevey will sign all the ethics bills approved by the New Jersey Legislature last week, his aides said on Tuesday, disappointing critics who said the most contested bill did not go far enough.

title: Corrections

He was never an assistant to Thomas K. Finletter, who was the assistant secretary of state, not the secretary. The secretary was Cordell Hull.

description: Islamic militants holding an American engineer hostage in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday threatened to execute him within 72 hours unless the kingdom released the group's fighters from jail.

description: JEAN-JACQUES RACHOU, the owner of LA CTE BASQUE, now closed, has reinvented himself and his restaurant. At his place, renamed BRASSERIE RACHOU LCB, 60 West 55th Street, the formal dcor has been replaced by a classic brasserie look, all black and apricot with mirrors, tile and brass. It opens tomorrow with a broad menu, including oysters and profiteroles, and a $28 prix fixe dinner.

title: Complaint Against DeLay Ruptures 7-Year Truce in House
description: A seven-year-old unofficial truce discouraging House members from filing ethics complaints against one another disintegrated Tuesday when a freshman Democrat accused one of the most powerful members of Congress, the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, of ''bribery, extortion, fraud, money laundering and the abuse of power.''

title: Africa's Homeless Widows
description: Women feed Africa. They grow 80 percent of the continent's food, yet the land they cultivate is not theirs. Women own only 1 percent of the land in sub-Saharan Africa. Tradition says that when a man dies, his property passes to his adult sons or brothers. The widow and her children are often evicted and left destitute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMMER, HERBERT H.
description: HAMMER--Herbert H., 66, of Venice, Florida died on June 10, 2004 in Venice, Florida. He was born on October 30, 1937 in New York City and came to Venice, Florida from there in October 2003. He was vice president of Wood & Hogan located in New York City for 42 years before retiring in 2003. He attended Nottingham Academy in Maryland and Oberlin College in Oberlin, Ohio. He served in the US Army and was a member of the Venice Orchid Club. He is survived by his beloved wife, Susette Bryan Hammer of Venice, Florida; his loving stepdaughter, Elizabeth Bryan of Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania; his two brothers, Michael of New Jersey and Raymond of New York and his sister, Maude White of Pennsylvania. Memorial services on Friday, July 2, 2004 11:00 AM at Grace United Methodist Church, Peale Chapel. Donations in his memory may be made to the Humane Society of your choice. For more information Farley Funeral Home and Crematory, Venice Chapel.

title: Panel Zeroes In on Gifts to Rowland

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Inquisition Wasn't That Bad
description: Fewer heretics were tortured and fewer witches were burned at the stake during the Inquisition than is generally believed, the Vatican said. In a statement, John Paul II sought forgiveness for the church but said it was necessary to have a ''precise knowledge of the facts.'' The statement came with the publication of a 783-page book of findings on the Inquisition. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: VF ADDS KIPLING BELGIUM, A MAKER OF BACKPACKS
description: The VF Corporation, the maker of North Face and JanSport outdoor equipment, has bought a backpack manufacturer, Kipling Belgium, for an undisclosed price. The closely held Kipling had sales of about $69 million in 2003, VF said. Kipling, based in Antwerp, Belgium, owns 17 stores in Belgium, the Netherlands and Britain and has about 120 shops managed by distributors, mostly in Asia. VF, based in Greensboro, N.C., expects the purchase will add to profit this year and increase sales by about $40 million. The company, which purchased the Italian apparel maker Napapijri this month, is buying outdoor-product companies after sales of jeans, its largest product category, fell last year. North Face, also an acquired brand, helped increase first-quarter sales by 15 percent.

title: Trying to Bottle Moonlight and Magic
description: LET'S get the weird, mystical stuff out of the way first. If most people have heard anything about biodynamic winemaking and grape-growing, chances are they have heard stories about filling cow horns with dung and burying them in vineyards, about aligning cellar work with phases of the moon and of brewing odd potions, to be spread like voodoo charms over grapes and vines.

title: U.N. Agency Drops 2 Drugs For AIDS Care Worldwide
description: The World Health Organization has pulled two generic antiretroviral drugs from its list of approved H.I.V. drugs that are most often used in poor countries, saying a routine check found the manufacturer had not proved that they were biologically equivalent to patented drugs.

title: Massacre in Colombia Shows Resolve of Marxist Rebels
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 16  The massacre of 34 coca farmers by Marxist rebels signals that the rebels are prepared to brutally take back territory they lost to right-wing paramilitaries now engaged in disarmament talks with President Alvaro Uribe's government, political analysts said today.

description: The independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks has found that the Pentagon's domestic air-defense command was disastrously unprepared for a major terrorist strike on American soil and was slow and confused in its response to the hijackings that morning, according to officials who have read a draft report of the commission's findings.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 8-Year Prison Term For Editor
description: Ruling in an appeal in one of China's most closely watched cases involving press freedoms, a court in Guangzhou maintained the conviction of Yu Huafeng, an editor for The Southern Metropolitan Daily, but his sentence was reduced to 8 years, from 12 years. Mr. Yu was accused of graft, but among journalists the prosecution has been widely seen as punishment for the newspaper's aggressive coverage of the SARS epidemic and of police brutality against prisoners in custody. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cedarhurst: Fire At Newspaper Office
description: A fire tore through the roof of the headquarters of a Long Island weekly newspaper yesterday, fire officials said. The blaze started around 3:20 p.m. in a portion of the Nassau Herald where the printing presses operate, officials said. The fire, whose cause is not believed to be suspicious, became more stubborn when propane canisters in the printing room exploded. Workers who were inside the building when the fire broke out escaped unharmed, the officials said. Four firefighters were treated at local hospitals for heat exhaustion, the officials said, and others were treated at the scene. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: For One Widow, a Somber Acceptance
description: Like many who lost loved ones in the collapse of the World Trade Center, Grissel Rodriguez-Valentin had her doubts, initially, about the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund. But her gradual acceptance of the program was emblematic of how an overwhelming majority of families, in the painful end, reluctantly decided that even a program they viewed as flawed was a better option than an individual lawsuit against the airlines or the owners of the twin towers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cuts At Schering
description: The German pharmaceuticals group Schering said that it would cut jobs and close some research and development projects to raise profit. To focus on its more profitable segments, Schering said it would shut operations related to heart research and nervous system disorders and would split off the dermatology business. Those moves will eliminate 900 to 1,100 jobs. The chief executive, Hubertus Erlen, said at a news conference that the job cuts, which are in addition to 1,100 announced earlier, should help reduce expenses by 200 million euros by 2006. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Roosevelt: Voters Pass School Bond
description: Voters in the Long Island community of Roosevelt approved a $205 million bond yesterday to finance the construction of new elementary schools and a new middle school. Administrators said the vote marked a key step in the district's effort to replace its crumbling buildings and also repair its sagging image. The district, plagued by chronic financial problems and low test scores, was taken over by the New York State Education Department two years ago, the only school district in the state to fall under direct state control. The state will finance nearly 90 percent of the bond, and residents in Roosevelt will pay the remaining $25 million, school officials said. Construction on the new schools will begin in the autumn. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: CITY SHIFTS VIEW ON HOMELESSNESS
description: In an effort to reduce reliance on the municipal shelter system, New York City is seeking to increase resources to prevent homelessness and to eliminate longstanding practices that may encourage people to enter the shelter system. It may also ask single people and families to pay part of the costs of a shelter if they are financially able.

title: DELTA TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF SEPTEMBER FLIGHTS
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would reduce flights by its main airline and its low-fare subsidiary, Song, during September. The move reflected an expected drop in business after the busy summer travel season, the airline said. Delta plans to resume its regular schedules in October. Such a move is common among airlines, because business usually declines sharply after Labor Day. Delta, hit by financial problems, is conducting a top-to-bottom review of its operations, and has hired restructuring consultants, hoping to devise a turnaround plan by late summer. It has warned it might seek bankruptcy protection if it is unable to cut costs and win wage and benefit concessions from its pilots. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: Stretching Animal Skins, and Other Symphony Preparations
description: Ever since Leonard Bernstein presented his ''Omnibus'' programs and ''Young People's Concerts'' on television, no one has used that medium as a teaching tool with his galvanizing impact. In occasional television specials the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas has come closest, bringing to bear his telegenic charisma, keen ability to break music down into its component parts and compulsive desire to teach. title: Bloomsday, 1904
description: ''Sixteenth today it is,'' thinks Leopold Bloom, and the 16th it was, in June 1904. James Joyce, age 22, would walk out that very night in Dublin with Nora Barnacle, whom he later wedded. ''Ulysses'' is set on that day -- Bloomsday, as it has come to be called -- in honor of Joyce's meeting Miss Barnacle. Many Joyceans have made of Bloomsday a literary Mardi Gras, an odyssey through Dublin using the points of Joyce's compass, a day to celebrate Irishness and the peculiar verbal fecundity of that nation. In a novel full of celebrated talkers, it is Bloom, Jew and Irishman, who hovers, voice and thought, over the proceedings. As one barroom patron in the novel says, show Bloom a straw on the floor and ''he'd talk about it for an hour so he would and talk steady.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Gain In Car Sales

The rate of increase slowed in May from 4.1 percent in April because of one less working day in several countries and ''stagnating consumer confidence in some countries,'' the association said. German sales were down 7.3 percent from a year earlier.

The Registered Traveler pilot program will begin later this month at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, the agency said. The program is also scheduled to be rolled out through August at Los Angeles International Airport, George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston, Boston Logan International Airport and Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. The contracts, which were awarded by competitive bid, are valued at $2.47 million for Unisys and $1.31 million for Electronic Data Systems. Unisys shares rose 4 cents, to $13.93. Shares of Electronic Data fell 16 cents, to $17.64.

The couple, Ahmed and Fatiah Bechiri, and three accomplices were convicted of plotting against the Bechiris' son-in-law, Abderazak Besseghir, who worked at Charles de Gaulle Airport. All were sentenced to five months in prison with suspended sentences of 15 months. They were also ordered to pay $18,000 in damages to Mr. Besseghir, who spent nearly 10 days in jail after his arrest in December 2002 before he was cleared. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

description: A Bronx man was charged yesterday with murder in the June 8 shooting deaths of his girlfriend, Loreen Merchan, 33, and her sister, Yasmin Merchan, 26. The man, Edelmiro Cesareo, 30, was apprehended on Sunday in Arroyo, Puerto Rico, the police said, but further information about his arrest was not available. The Merchan sisters were found dead in an apartment at 187 Throgs Neck Boulevard that Loreen Merchan had rented about a month earlier, and which was also the listed address of Mr. Cesareo, the police said. Yasmin Merchan, who lived in Waterbury, Conn., was visiting when the shootings took place, and Loreen Merchan's three daughters, ages 4, 13 and 15, were left unharmed. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

By the time the three-day strike ended on June 9, 1199 had reached settlements with four agencies. All Metro, which employs 1,200 home health-aides, was one of the seven that had not settled. Like the four that previously settled, All Metro, based in Manhattan, agreed to raise wages for most health aides to $10 an hour in 2007 from the current average of $7. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Radicals Protest Faberg Display
description: A group of protesters entered the Patriarch's Palace inside the Kremlin and staged a raucous demonstration against President Vladimir V. Putin at an exhibition of Imperial Faberg Easter eggs, including the fabled Coronation Egg from 1897, left, and eight others purchased earlier this year by the industrialist Viktor Vekselberg from the holdings of Malcolm Forbes. The protesters, members of the fringe National Bolshevik Party, shouted anti-Putin slogans and tossed leaflets denouncing the Faberg eggs as symbols of a new authoritarianism in Russia. ''A new czar is being imposed on the country,'' one leaflet said. At least two protesters shackled themselves to displays, forcing the closing of the exhibition. Officials said six were arrested. At least 17 party members stormed the stage of the Bolshoi Theater last month in a protest that had unnerving echoes of the siege of a Moscow theater by Chechen guerrillas in 2002. The party also released a list of 188 ''patriot'' donors who gave $100,000. title: SCHICK SUES GILLETTE OVER RAZOR TECHNOLOGY PATENTS
description: Energizer Holdings Inc., the maker of Schick razors, has sued its bigger rival, the Gillette Company, in a dispute over diamond coating on razors. Gillette sent the Schick division a letter in December, claiming the Schick Quattro and Schick FX Diamond razors infringed ''one or more'' of Gillette's patents, said Eric A. Kraus, a spokesman for Gillette, which is based in Boston. Energizer's lawsuit, filed Monday in New Haven, seeks a court order stating that no valid patents are being infringed. Gillette, which makes the Mach3 razor, said it would defend its patents. The case is one of several filed by the companies over razor technology. Schick is based in Milford, Conn.

description: With the oil company he founded facing bankruptcy and much of his own wealth frozen by prosecutors, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky went on trial on Wednesday on charges of fraud and tax evasion in a case that lies at the murky intersection of Russia's politics, business and law.

description: One of golf's hardest workers, Vijay Singh, said it bothered him to take a day off.

description: MGM Mirage said yesterday that it planned to sell a casino in Detroit to try to win regulatory approval for its $4.8 billion purchase of the Mandalay Resort Group, which would create the world's largest casino company.

It was not the Wizards who prevented the three from joining the United States team.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Sales Rise
description: Retail sales in Brazil rose for a fifth consecutive month in April, gaining 9.9 percent from the year-earlier period, helped by a recent decline in interest rates, the government's statistics agency said. Appliance and furniture sales, which are especially sensitive to the cost of credit, led the surge with an increase of 32.8 percent. Supermarket sales rose 7.2 percent, suggesting that a broad economic recovery is under way. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: CARLYLE/RIVERSTONE VENTURE TO BUY OHIO OIL PRODUCER
description: An energy fund run by the Carlyle Group and Riverstone Holdings, in partnership with Capital C Energy L.L.C., agreed yesterday to buy a closely held oil and natural-gas producer, the Belden & Blake Corporation, for an undisclosed sum. Belden & Blake, owned by the buyout firm Texas Pacific Group, has proven reserves equivalent to about 360 billion cubic feet of gas in the Appalachians and Michigan, Carlyle and Riverstone said. Belden & Blake, based in Ohio, had 2003 sales of $109.1 million. The Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, and Riverstone, a New York investment company, announced in April that they had raised a $1.1 billion fund, Carlyle/Riverstone Global Energy & Power Fund II L.P., to buy energy assets.

title: Metro Matters; Politics, Religion And Silence
description: MARIO M. CUOMO is rarely concise, but yesterday, when asked why he thought prominent Roman Catholic Republicans in progressive New York hadn't spoken out about the latest Catholic political dispute, he didn't hesitate for a moment. ''That's easy,'' the former governor said with a laugh. ''They haven't been attacked.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: U.N. Picks Dane As New Governor
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan named Soren Jessen-Petersen of Denmark, a longtime international civil servant and expert on refugees, to head the United Nations administration that has run Kosovo since the end of the 1999 NATO bombing campaign to stop repression of the majority ethnic Albanians by Serbs. Mr. Jessen-Petersen, currently the European Union's representative to Macedonia and for 15 years an official of the United Nations high commission for refugees, replaces Hari Holkeri of Finland, who resigned last month after less than a year in Kosovo, citing health reasons. The province, legally part of Serbia-Montenegro, is governed by a Security Council resolution that gives the United Nations broad decision-making authority until its final political status is resolved. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: HEWITT ASSOCIATES TO ACQUIRE EXULT, A RIVAL
description: Hewitt Associates Inc., a consultant for human resources and administrative services, agreed yesterday to buy a competitor, Exult Inc. of Irvine, Calif., for about $598 million in stock, a move that would turn Hewitt into one of the 10 biggest providers of office support in the nation. Hewitt will pay 0.2 share for each Exult share, it said. The price is $5.45 a share, based on the closing price yesterday, a 3 percent discount. Hewitt, of Lincolnshire, Ill., said the purchase would cut per-share earnings by 15 percent in fiscal 2005 and 10 percent in 2006. Its stock fell 13 percent. Hewitt said its sales would increase by more than a third in fiscal 2005, to about $3 billion, from this year's projected revenue. The new company would have 2,300 human-resources customers and 300 clients who hire out their benefits plans.

title: Tiger Woods Is Clearly in Slump as 2 Pull Ahead at U.S. Open
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., June 17  Tiger Woods might still be No. 1 in the world golf rankings. But nobody who witnessed Woods's first round here today at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in the 104th United States Open would argue that Woods is immersed in what for him is a profound slump.

title: Shutter Lag Reduced To a Mere *
description: THE world is full of amazing things. But doesn't it seem as though there's always some fly in the ointment, some little annoyance that you wish you could obliterate? With e-mail, it's spam; with DVD's, it's the F.B.I. warning that you can't fast-forward through; with PC's, it's Windows.

title: Next Up: Low-Carb Nachos?
description: The low-carbohydrate diet craze, which has already transformed American eating habits, is going to work on that quintessential junk food, soda. Coca-Cola and Pepsi- Co this month began marketing two mid-carb sodas, C2 and Edge, which combine dietetic sweeteners with high fructose corn syrup to create, the companies claim, products that taste like regular colas, but with half the calories.

title: In Every Note, A Comment On Getting Old
description: Jazz accommodates a sense of honesty about the passing of time; it has to, since great jazz performers don't retire. In the past an Oscar Peterson concert left your neurons firing bright thoughts about invincibility. Now you're up against the realities of aging.

title: Kicking Her Way Up the Country Charts
description: In a country music world where recent female superstars have either been statuesque divas like Shania Twain or political lightning rods like the Dixie Chicks, the first one to have a No. 1 Billboard single in more than two years is a tobacco-chewing, tough-talking Midwesterner named Gretchen Wilson. Her autobiographical ''Redneck Woman'' (Sony) has topped the country charts for the last month, and ''Here for the Party,'' her debut album, which includes it, is also No. 1.

title: For a Desktop Tight on Space, A Compact PC Is a Good Fit
description: A 13-pound laptop might be unwieldy, but a desktop computer of that weight is positively svelte. I.B.M.'s revision of its ThinkCentre S50 computer weighs just that, and is 35 percent smaller than the S50 model it will replace. In fact, the new S50 weighs a pound less than I.B.M.'s first laptop, the 5140 PC Convertible, which lumbered into the marketplace in 1986.

description: Iran threatened on Wednesday to resume its enrichment of uranium -- a prerequisite for making nuclear weapons -- if the International Atomic Energy Agency passed an expected resolution rebuking it for not cooperating.

title: No Airline Bailouts
description: As part of its overall strategy to emerge from bankruptcy court and restructure the company, United Airlines is hoping to get $1.6 billion in federal loan guarantees. This plan should be thwarted. United is not entitled to a form of taxpayer support that was meant to stabilize the airline industry in the aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. United's woes nowadays have little to do with that tragedy.

title: Yankees Overwhelm Another Overmatched Rival
description: The Yankees may have the gaudiest left side of the infield in modern history, with Alex Rodriguez at third base and Derek Jeter at shortstop. The Arizona Diamondbacks, the team that beat the Yankees in the 2001 World Series, have Chad Tracy at third and Alex Cintron at short.

title: Old Patients, Making Doctors Better; Myths Explode as Physicians Get to Know the Elderly
description: The patient arrived, her brow wrinkled, looking impassive. She was punctual. She was 73. It was early afternoon, past lunch. The doctor was ready to start. She had set aside up to three hours, planning to use every minute.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Details Harbor Pollution
description: Ferries, tugboats, container ships and other commercial vessels that work in New York Harbor are an unregulated source of air pollution, producing as much smog-forming contamination in a year as 300,000 cars, according to a report released yesterday by Environmental Defense, an advocacy group. The big ocean-going container ships, which run their engines while docked to power lights, lifts and other equipment, produce the greatest amount of harmful emissions. The next largest sources of pollution in the harbor are tugboats and commuter ferries. The report recommends that the government impose strict emissions standards for newly built ships while also offering programs to modernize existing vessels with anti-pollution devices to lower air pollution in the harbor and in neighborhoods near the water's edge. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Clinton, at Film Premiere, Says Starr Abused Power
description: Former President Bill Clinton said last night that while he does not ''wake up in the morning hating Ken Starr,'' he nevertheless accused the former independent prosecutor of an ''abuse of power'' that ''crushed innocents.''

title: Spanish Judge Ends Inquiry Into Qaeda Cell Tied to 9/11
description: The Spanish judge investigating a cell of Al Qaeda in Spain and its ties to the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks in the United States announced Tuesday that he had concluded his investigation.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: College Credit Proposed For Apprentices
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey expanded his efforts to bring higher education to blue collar workers yesterday by proposing that trade union apprentices should be granted college credit for the job training they receive. The proposal has to be evaluated by the state's junior and senior colleges, he said. But the governor, speaking at the New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention, said he wanted electrical workers to be eligible to receive the credits by September, and apprentices from five additional craft unions -- the plumbers and pipe fitters, air-conditioning and refrigeration workers, carpenters , telecommunication technology workers and operating engineers -- by January 2005. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: RUMSFELD ISSUED AN ORDER TO HIDE DETAINEE IN IRAQ
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, acting at the request of George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, ordered military officials in Iraq last November to hold a man suspected of being a senior Iraqi terrorist at a high-level detention center there but not list him on the prison's rolls, senior Pentagon and intelligence officials said Wednesday.

description: An appellate court in Moscow on Wednesday upheld a ban on Jehovah's Witnesses in the city, a ruling the group's leaders said reflected mounting pressure on some faiths in Russia.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Man Sentenced In Rape Of Daughter
description: A 46-year-old man convicted of raping his 11-year-old daughter, who later hanged herself, was sentenced yesterday to 50 years in prison. The man, Timothy Lucie, left, a small-business owner who claimed the death of his daughter, Valerie, was an accident, was convicted this year of first-degree rape and first-degree sodomy. Mr. Lucie confessed to raping her and coercing her into remaining silent by threatening to cut off her long hair and telling her no one would believe her. A few hours after the rape, her 7-year-old brother found her hanging by a chain and dog collar from her canopy bed. Judge William Walsh of Onondoga County Court said: ''In all my years on this planet, I've never been at a loss for words. Today, I am. My sentence will have to speak for me.'' Michelle York (NYT)

description: President Bush's goal of sending people back to the Moon and then on to Mars without big budget increases can be achieved by reorganizing NASA and building a private space industry to help, a presidential commission said Wednesday.

description: Senator John Kerry apparently isn't too worried about the heat he is catching from some quarters for missing so many floor votes.

title: K2 WILL BUY THREE SPORTING-GOODS CONCERNS IN EUROPE
description: K2 Inc., the biggest ski maker in the nation, agreed yesterday to buy three sporting-goods companies for about $208 million, a move that would increase its apparel and equipment sales in Europe. K2 will buy ski-equipment manufacturers Volkl Sports Holding and the Marker Group for about $124 million, and Marmot Mountain Ltd., which makes outdoor apparel and ski clothing, for about $84 million. K2, based in Carlsbad, Calif., will complete the acquisitions next month and said they will add to 2004 earnings. After the purchases, K2 will get 20 percent of its sales in Europe, up from 15 percent; its annual ski production will almost triple, to 720,000 pairs, the company said.

title: Report Says Arrest Thwarted Use of Substitute 9/11 Pilot
description: Leaders of Al Qaeda considered using Zacarias Moussaoui as ''a potential substitute pilot'' in the Sept. 11 attacks because of friction between other plotters, but his arrest weeks before the hijackings apparently scuttled that possibility, according to the report released Wednesday by the commission studying the attacks.

title: VORNADO TO PAY $65 MILLION FOR CALIFORNIA GROCERIES
description: Vornado Realty Trust, which owns offices and shopping centers in the Northeast, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 25 supermarkets in Southern California for $65 million. The properties, which have an aggregate of about 766,000 square feet, are being bought from Newkirk Master L.P., Vornado said. Vornado, based in New York, has a 22 percent stake in Newkirk Master. Vornado expects the purchase to be completed in the third quarter.

title: McGreevey's Ex-Chief of Staff Is Accused of Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Gov. James E. McGreevey's former chief of staff yesterday of insider trading, charging in a civil complaint that he had used confidential information about corporate mergers to make more than $247,000 in profits on stock transactions.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Another Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: State prosecutors said they were investigating accusations that Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Dallas, had steered illegal corporate donations to Democratic candidates for the State Legislature in 2000 through a political action committee that he controlled. A spokesman for Mr. Frost, left, denied wrongdoing and said the accusations were intended to aid the campaign of his opponent, Representative Pete Sessions, Republican of Dallas. Redistricting has left Mr. Frost and Mr. Sessions seeking the same seat. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision Offers High-Speed Services By TV
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation will let its customers order high-speed Internet services using their televisions, one of the first operators to do so. Starting yesterday, Cablevision customers could turn to channel 901 to order the broadband service and have the cable modem shipped directly to their homes. Customers pay a discounted $29.95 a month for the first six months and can avoid a $50 fee by installing the modem themselves. Cable operators have been introducing new services, including broadband Internet connections and telephone lines, to attract new customers and retain existing consumers. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Market Place; French utility workers forcefully say no to joining the private sector.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadcom To Buy Zyray

Zyray, a closely held company, is based in San Diego.

title: EL PASO CREDITORS AGREE TO WAIT FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS
description: The El Paso Corporation, operator of the longest interstate natural-gas pipeline system in the nation, said yesterday that providers of $3 billion of credit had agreed to wait until Aug. 15 for financial reports delayed by a restatement of oil and natural-gas reserves. Waivers approved for a revolving credit line and other borrowing include a 29-day grace period should creditors declare default on debt exceeding a combined $100 million, El Paso said. The company, based in Houston, has not filed financial reports for the fourth quarter of 2003 or the first quarter of this year with the Securities and Exchange Commission, because of an audit that began after the company lowered its estimate of oil and natural-gas reserves by 41 percent in February.

title: F.D.A. PANEL ENDORSES DEVICE TO TREAT DEPRESSION
description: Cyberonics won the endorsement of a Food and Drug Administration panel for its brain-stimulation device for severe depression. The recommendation, made late Tuesday, could lead to approval for the first implantable tool to treat depression, and it set off a 77 percent gain in the company's share price yesterday. The panel endorsed the Vagus Nerve Stimulation Therapy System, saying its potential as a last resort for the hardest-to-treat depression patients offset Cyberonics' failure to prove the $16,000 device's effectiveness. The F.D.A. generally follows the advice of its panels. The device could benefit about 4.4 million depression patients, 10 times more than the number of epilepsy patients for which the device is already approved. Stock in Cyberonics, based in Houston, rose $15.12, to $34.81 a share. The therapy system is implanted under the skin and sends signals through the nervous system to the brain.

title: In Italy, With Little Fanfare, Big Stock Offering Is Planned
description: Never heard of Terna? Neither had most Italians until a month ago, yet next week the company is holding the country's largest initial public offering since 2001 and one of Europe's biggest stock offerings this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shipper Acquired
description: Exel, the world's largest distributor of goods for businesses, agreed to buy the Tibbett & Britten Group, which transports merchandise for Wal-Mart Stores Inc., for 328 million ($598.9 million) to expand outside Britain and in fashion and home-improvement retail. The offer of 668 pence a share is 36 percent more than the closing stock price on Monday, the day before Tibbett announced it had received a bid. Exel, based in Bracknell, England, aims to strengthen its business in mainland Europe, Latin America, the Middle East, Asia and the United States and to win contracts from companies that have shifted production to low-cost manufacturing countries. It expects to cut costs as much as 20 million a year and eliminate as many as 200 jobs by combining head offices with Tibbett, which is based in Elstree, England.

title: PANEL FINDS NO QAEDA-IRAQ TIE; DESCRIBES A WIDER PLOT FOR 9/11
description: The staff of the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks sharply contradicted one of President Bush's central justifications for the Iraq war, reporting on Wednesday that there did not appear to have been a ''collaborative relationship'' between Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. The assertion came in staff reports that offer a chilling, richly detailed chronology of the Sept. 11 plot and rewrite much of the history of the attacks.

title: Bush and Cheney Talk Strongly of Qaeda Links With Hussein

title: Democrats, DeLay and Doolittle
description: The House ethics committee has developed cobwebs in recent years as Republicans and Democrats have carefully avoided filing corruption complaints against each other, lest a mutual blood bath break out. But now comes a bit of ''Solon Bites Solon'' news: Representative Chris Bell, a Texas Democrat who was defeated in his party primary and has little left to lose, is taking a parting shot at the Republican majority leader, Tom DeLay of Texas. Mr. Bell is going before the ethics committee to accuse Mr. DeLay, one of Washington's major powers, of misusing campaign funds and favoring donors with legislative favors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUWIRTH, BENJAMIN
description: NEUWIRTH--Benjamin. CPA, died at his home in New York City June 16, 2004 at the age of 102. He is survived by his wife of seventy-three years, Anna. Beloved father of Sylvia Wagner (Robert), of Rockville, MD., and Paul D. Neuwirth (Delany), of Philadelphia, PA. He is also survived by grandchildren, Stephen R. Neuwirth (Nataly), James G. Neuwirth (Sandra), Leslie R. Wagner, David E. Wagner, and Richard H. Neuwirth, and four great grandchildren. Ben Neuwirth graduated The City College of New York in 1923. He was a partner in the international certified public accounting firm, Grant, Thornton, LLP., until his retirement in 1971. Prior to his Grant Thornton affiliation, he was a senior partner in the New York CPA firm, Klein, Hines and Finke. Mr. Neuwirth was an Adjunct Lecturer in accounting at Baruch College for two decades. He was a Vice President and Chairman of the publications committee of The New York State Society of CPA's. Mr. Neuwirth was a director and honorary chairman of The Board of The Riverdale YMYWHA where the auditorium and training facility are named in his honor. Until his death, he was a Trustee of the charitable Harry DeJur Foundation. Funeral service June 17th at 10 A.M. at The Park East Synagogue, 164 East 68th Street. Burial will follow in Mount Zion Cemetery in Maspeth, Long Island. Contributions may be made to The Riverdale YM-YWHA, 5625 Arlington Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TYSON, MICHAEL M.
description: TYSON--Michael M., retired Kidder, Peabody and Company Vice-President, active volunteer and athlete, died suddenly Sunday while biking near his Santa Fe, New Mexico home. The cause was a massive heart attack. Michael was born in Bryn Mawr, PA, in May 1933. After spending most of his youth working summers on the family dairy farm in Falls Village, CT, Michael graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1952. Following school, he served four years in the U.S. Navy, then attended Babson College where he received a BSBA (1959) and an MBA (1963). He began his professional career in 1959 at United Business Service as an investment consultant, and then moved to Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co. in 1963 as a securities analyst. In 1966, Michael worked as a broker for Smith Barney, and left there as Vice-President in 1980 to open and manage the first Kidder, Peabody and Co. office in Hartford, CT. Michael retired from Kidder in 1993. A lifelong traveler, Michael and his wife, Sarah, moved to France in 1994 to spend a year in Annecy. Upon their return from France, Michael and Sarah moved to Santa Fe, NM, where he immediately immersed himself in a wide range of volunteer activities with various organizations, including the St. Vincent Hospital Board, Kitchen Angels, Habitat for Humanity, AARP tax preparation, numerous Las Campanas boards, and the Kaune School. He is survived by his wife, Sarah Tyson; his sister, Rosemary Beer of Farmington, CT, and his three daughters, Jennifer Mandrack, of Denver, CO, Abigail Ciambrone of New York, NY, and Amanda Tyson of San Juan de Plan, Spain. He is also survived by his two stepchildren, James Condon of Easton, MA, and Jeanine Keay of Baltimore, MD, and his six grandchildren, Evan, Jennifer, Julia, Lino, Maya, and Micaela. Michael's friends and family will always remember him as a strong individual with a tremendous love of life whose hard work, great humor, and generosity were an inspiration and example to us all. Bat da da dat dat, da dat! A celebration of Michael's life will be held at 7:00 P.M., Sunday, June 20th, at the Las Campanas Spa in Santa Fe. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Kitchen Angels Endowment Fund, 1222 Siler Road, Santa Fe, NM 87507. The family thanks the Good Samaritans who tried.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about a decision by the executive director of the World Food Program to cancel a visit to Zimbabwe misstated his given name. He is James Morris, not Hames.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PROGRESS ENERGY INC., Raleigh, N.C., a power producer, said it had agreed to sell two stakes, worth a combined 49.8 percent, of Colona Synfuel L.P., a synthetic-fuel business, to capitalize on tax credits for the operation. The buyers were not identified, and terms were not disclosed.

title: Player's Tainted Past Stirs Little Commotion
description: Kazuhito Tadano, a 24-year-old right-handed relief pitcher recently called up to the major leagues, came off the team bus and entered the Cleveland Indians' clubhouse before Tuesday night's game against the Mets at Shea Stadium wearing, of all things, an orange-and-blue polo shirt, the team colors of the Mets. But none of his teammates seemed to take any particular notice, and it was apparent that he was not aware of it, either. He owned a shirt and had pulled it out of his suitcase and wore it to the game, along with a pair of blue jeans.

title: Queens Man Held on Links To Terror Plot In Britain
description: A Queens man has been arrested and the authorities are investigating accusations that he aided a group of men who British authorities believe were planning to blow up pubs, train stations and restaurants in London, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Critics Say New Law Undermines Venezuela Referendum
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 17  The government of President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela is poised to pack the Supreme Court with allies who could rule in the president's favor if an August recall referendum on his leadership were close and contested, a human rights group said in Venezuela today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Roadside Bomb Kills 4
description: A roadside explosion killed four Afghans, including two children, in northern Kunduz, another attack for which local officials blamed members of the Taliban and Al Qaeda. The remote-controlled bomb hit a car belonging to NATO peacekeepers, killing the Afghan driver, the two schoolchildren and an old man on the street nearby. A third child was injured. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: How Much Is That Uzi In the Window?
description: To the American troops in Iraq being subjected to a daily rain of fire from roadside bombs, mortars and rocket-propelled grenades, it often seems that the insurgents have limitless stocks of munitions. In fact, in the time I spent embedded with a platoon there, I heard more than one marine joke that the insurgents must have more bullets to spare than the Americans.

title: In Summertime Enrichment, The New and the Familiar Mix
description: The Mannes College of Music spends its summers presenting seminars -- part master class, part festival -- that are a treat for curious concertgoers as well as for music students. The faculty includes the college's staff members as well as guest performers, and the subjects are varied. A Beethoven festival has just ended, and the weeks to come include seminars in advanced music theory, the guitar and the keyboard.

title: Shockey Close to Deciding That Surgery Is Best Option
description: Although he planned to have another doctor examine his right foot, Giants tight end Jeremy Shockey said Wednesday that he was leaning toward having surgery, which would force him to miss at least the first week of training camp next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, EDWARD H.
description: MILLER--Edward H. On June 13, 2004. Beloved husband of Norma (nee Parenteau). Loving father of Franklin Anne Rowland and the late Naval Lt. Marianne Y. Miller. Devoted brother of Arthur Miller and the late Robert Miller. Caring grandfather of Kathleen E. Rowland and Leigh M. Rowland. A memorial service will be held 11 A.M. on Friday, June 18, 2004 at Christ's Church, Rye, NY.

title: There's No Sleep for These Fishes
description: Les Claypool, the bass-guitar player and leader of the oddball psychedelic band Primus, has a taste for the strange. He has, after all, written a song called ''Pork Soda'' and has named another of his groups Colonel Claypool's Bucket of Bernie Brains.

title: Read Our Article, And Purchase Our Hair Color While You're at It
description: Prevention magazine is coming out with a range of vitamins this fall. Parents magazine will introduce insect netting for baby strollers this winter. Maxim magazine, which brought out its own brand of hair color for men two years ago, is now thinking of putting its name on nightclubs -- and frozen food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, FRANCIS W.
description: RYAN--Francis W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Francis W. Ryan associated with The Times from July 1967 until retiring in January 1984.

title: Bill Clinton, on '60 Minutes,' Speaks of Affair With Intern
description: Former President Bill Clinton called his affair with Monica Lewinsky, a White House intern, ''a terrible moral error'' and sought to explain how his family handled the crisis in an interview with Dan Rather on the CBS program ''60 Minutes,'' to be broadcast Sunday.

title: President's Political Thorn Grows Only More Stubborn
description: Correction Appended

title: Finding Echoes of Iraq War In a Film About Vietnam
description: How many times has the phrase ''hearts and minds'' been used in the past year about the war in Iraq? And how many people know that the phrase goes back to 1974, when ''Hearts and Minds,'' a documentary about the United States' involvement in Vietnam, was released? And who remembers that the movie title reaches back a decade further, to a speech by President Lyndon B. Johnson? ''The ultimate victory,'' he said of the war, ''will depend on the hearts and the minds of the people who live there.'' Sound familiar?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EISENSTEIN, ENID ROSALINDE
description: EISENSTEIN--Enid Rosalinde June 17, 1953 - May 12, 1977 Beloved daughter, Without you No rose can grow; No leaf be green If never seen Your sweetest face; No bird have graced Or power to sing; Or anything Be kind, or fair, And you nowhere. Rebe Eisenstein, loving family and friends

description: To the Editor:

title: Liposuction Doesn't Offer Health Benefit, Study Finds
description: Having 20 pounds of fat removed by liposuction makes people look better but provides none of the protection from heart disease and diabetes that would result from losing the same amount of weight through diet and exercise, researchers are reporting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, ELLEN
description: KAHN--Ellen. SAR Academy mourn the loss of the beloved sister of our esteemed Trustee, Tobias Schapiro. May he and the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Rejects New Bid
description: The retailer Marks & Spencer Group said it turned down an increased offer by the British billionaire Philip Green that values the company at 8.35 billion ($15.3 billion), the second rejection this month. Mr. Green offered 370 pence a share, Marks & Spencer said. That was 3.6 percent more than yesterday's close. Mr. Green said this month that he was willing to pay 290 to 310 pence plus a 25 percent stake in Revival Acquisitions Ltd., a company formed to make the bid. Stuart Rose, the new chief executive of Marks & Spencer, said the new offer did not ''represent value for our shareholders.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Group Suspected In Lumberyard Fire
description: A fire caused $1.5 million worth of damage on Monday at a lumberyard in West Jordan, and protesters from the Earth Liberation Front may have been responsible. The initials E.L.F. were spray-painted on nearby property, and a letter was faxed to a radio station that said the environmental group had set the fire because the lumber company had ignored warnings to repair forklifts that the group said were causing excessive pollution. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Jackson's Off-Season Likely to Be Long
description: A smiling Phil Jackson appeared to be at peace, four of his five children by his side, the burden of managing, massaging and manipulating a lineup full of egos finally lifted from his coat-hanger shoulders.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Protesters Cut Power To President
description: Power workers in Paris briefly cut electricity to lyse Palace offices of the president, Jacques Chirac, the Eiffel Tower and the American Embassy as they continued their commando-style protests against the government's plan to privatize part of the state-owned lectricit de France. They also shut power to the Champs-lyses, the Interior Ministry, the British Embassy and major corporate offices. There were no reports of any emergencies caused by the abrupt blackouts. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: Witness in Oracle Trial Recalls a Bidding War
description: The Oracle Corporation and PeopleSoft cut prices in half during a bidding war to win an account with North Dakota, a state official testified yesterday at an antitrust trial to decide whether Oracle can pursue a hostile bid for PeopleSoft.

title: Tobacco Buyout May Imperil Corporate Tax Bill
description: It was supposed to be the deal that finally broke the logjam on a $140 billion corporate tax bill, but it could end up causing a new stalemate down the road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENHUT, SOL
description: GREENHUT--Sol. Uncle Sol truly lived by the command ''Love thy neighbor as thyself'' as he was truly concerned with the lives of others. When you played with Sol, he complimented you even on a fair shot. That's what his life was all about. We will miss him. Robin & Mike, Robin & Keith, Brooke & Gary

title: Klein, for Third Straight Year, Changes Public School Schedule
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday that he would change the public school schedule for the third year in a row, lengthening the school day by 10 minutes in elementary and middle schools in place of the extra 50 minutes of instruction on Tuesdays that he imposed for these schools at the start of this academic year.

title: The Danes Rule At the Modern Museum
description: THE Swedish home furnishings giant Ikea had an advertisement that declared of America: ''It's a big country. Someone's got to furnish it.'' Now that the big, newly refurbished Museum of Modern Art is nearing completion, the Danes are furnishing it. The Danish government has persuaded the museum to use Danish furnishings for almost all the public areas of its expanded quarters -- a triumph of trade policy and product placement.

title: When Your Signal Needs a Lift, Quickly Attach A Portable Antenna
description: Although wireless carriers continue to expand and strengthen their coverage areas, most cellphone users are still familiar with static, dropped calls and ''no service'' messages.

title: A Tight Circle Of Friends
description: Linda Nestle, 58, a partner in a benefits-consulting firm in Westlake Village, Calif., liked her wine and Scotch. And for three decades, she says, she controlled her drinking. But when vodka took over her life last year, her three business partners stepped in. In January, they hired a consultant to help them confront Ms. Nestle about her addiction. She entered a treatment center that day.

title: Account of Plot Sets Off Debate Over Credibility
description: In the Sept. 11 commission reports released Wednesday, the striking portrait of Al Qaeda as a wobbly but determined organization lurching toward its catastrophic strike against America was built largely on the two plot leaders' own words.

title: Attack by Colombia Rebels Threatens Fragile Talks
description: The massacre of 34 coca farmers in northeastern Colombia on Tuesday by leftist rebels may be a sign that the guerrillas are intent on regaining territory they have lost to a right-wing paramilitary group, political analysts said Wednesday.

title: New Match for Developer of Harlem Project
description: Nearly five years after city officials approved a plan to replace the abandoned Washburn Wire factory in East Harlem with a big-box shopping center, the project, East River Plaza, may be gaining momentum.

title: No Evidence Of Meeting With Iraqi
description: A report of a clandestine meeting in Prague between Mohammed Atta and an Iraqi intelligence officer first surfaced shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks. And even though serious doubt was cast on the report, it was repeatedly cited by some Bush administration officials and others as evidence of a link between Al Qaeda and Iraq.

title: The First Day
description: Tiger Woods shot a two-over-par round of 72 at the first day of the U.S. Open at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

title: Sublime Sculpture
description: The Guggenheim Museum's small but lucid survey of Constantin Brancusi is a perfect fit; his abbreviated curving forms soar with Frank Lloyd Wright's architecture.

title: Salad Days
description:
By SUZANNE HAMLIN
Whether your produce is your own or picked up at a farmers' market, here are some tools to make your summer dining easy and inventive.

title: After Open Ace, an Awkward Moment
description: Spencer Levin, who has just completed his sophomore year at the University of New Mexico, carded a hole in one Thursday, his first. It came on the 179-yard No. 17 at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Course. At the United States Open, no less.

title: Time for Action on Sudan
description: The United States and the U.N. secretary general have strongly condemned the vicious ethnic cleansing campaign sponsored by Sudan's government, which threatens hundreds of thousands of people with starvation before autumn. That's not enough. The situation demands strong action.

description: Jack Shainman Gallery

description: Seven holes into his first United States Open, David Roesch, a professional golfer in name only who nearly quit the game just last week, looked over his shoulder and saw his name atop a giant leader board overlooking the fairway.

title: Jacek Kuron, of Solidarity, Dies at 70
description: Jacek Kuron, who inspired and tutored generations of Poles to struggle against Communist rule, serving as the ultimately successful godfather of a resistance that coalesced around the Solidarity labor union movement, died yesterday in Warsaw. He was 70 years old and had been ill for more than a year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tenant With Bedbugs Gets Rent Relief
description: A Housing Court judge in Manhattan has decided that a Lower East Side man who suffered from an extreme infestation of bedbugs in his rent-stabilized studio is entitled to rent relief. The judge, Cyril K. Bedford, ruled that bedbugs were even more offensive than rats or roaches, ''feeding upon one's blood in hordes nightly, turning what is supposed to be bed rest or sleep into a hellish experience.'' The tenant, Peter H. Young, who lives on Ludlow Street, was awarded more than $2,600 in relief toward the $6,500 his landlord, Ludlow Properties, had demanded in back rent. Mr. Young's defense was that the bugs made his apartment uninhabitable, a breach of warranty. Judge Bedford found that the landlord had not done enough to eradicate the problem. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Taking Cues From Flowers and Sufi Ecstasies
description: Jennifer Muller offered some vivid dances on Tuesday night when her company, Jennifer Muller/The Works, presented a gala program at the Joyce Theater. Ms. Muller's company remains through tomorrow night at the theater, at 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea.

title: Seeing the Cosmos in Its Moths and Trees
description: Fresh out of graduate school, the Starn Twins or, as they prefer to be called now, Doug and Mike Starn -- hit the New York art world with a bang in 1986, the year of their first solo exhibition. In their expansive collages, images of roses, horses and old master artworks were romantically seductive, but what mattered was what they did to photography. Scotch-taping together multitudes of faded, murky, torn, wrinkled and otherwise distressed photographic prints, they gave photography an astounding painterly and even sculptural physicality, opening the medium to a whole new world of expressive possibility.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 2 about women in the work force in Nevada misstated a finding on their earnings from an analysis of census data by the Institute for Women's Policy Research, and the year it covered. Average annual earnings were $27,800, not $32,000 -- ranking Nevada 19th among all states and the District of Columbia, not among the top third. (The $32,000 figure and the top-third ranking were for white women, not women over all.) The data covered 1999; 2000 was the year of the report.

title: Lustful Royalty, Joking Coyotes and Other Beach Buddies
description: This summer you can amuse yourself by having sex with kings. Honestly, you can. You can have ''Sex With Kings: 500 Years of Adultery, Power, Rivalry and Revenge'' by Eleanor Herman, an author interested in royal shenanigans.

title: Florida Reports Progress In Re-enfranchising Felons
description: Gov. Jeb Bush announced Thursday that Florida had nearly eliminated the backlog of felons seeking to have their voting rights restored and that only 8,000 applications remained under review.

title: No. 10 Plays Hardest
description: The 189-yard, par-3 seventh hole, with its sharply sloping green, proved to be as difficult as advertised in the first round of the Open. When play was suspended at 6:55 p.m., No. 7 ranked as the second-most-difficult hole on the course in terms of relation to par. Only the 412-yard, par-4 10th played harder.

title: Bush and Cheney Talk Strongly of Qaeda Links With Hussein
description: President Bush and Vice President Cheney said yesterday that they remain convinced that Saddam Hussein's government had a long history of ties to Al Qaeda, a day after the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks reported that its review of classified intelligence found no evidence of a "collaborative relationship" that linked Iraq to the terrorist organization.

title: Major Oil Pipeline in Iraq to Be Restored
description: BASRA, Iraq, June 18  Oil could be flowing as early as Sunday through one of two major pipelines that were sabotaged a few miles from this southern Iraqi city earlier this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, JANE
description: WEISS--Jane. 103, widow of Max, mother of Betty-Ann. Retired teacher. Beloved sister to 10 and beloved aunt to 20. Reposing at Schwartz-Jeffers Funeral Home. Services Sunday, 10 A.M.

title: Pakistan Gunmen Kill Local Leader of Opposition Party
description: Unidentified gunmen in the southern port city of Karachi shot and killed an official of Pakistan's leading opposition party on Thursday, government officials said.

description: Ror a man in the middle of the vice-presidential frenzy, Representative Richard A. Gephardt was remarkably relaxed. Tranquil even.

title: Pakistan Says It Killed a Tribesman Who Aided Militants
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 18  Pakistani military officials said today that their forces had killed Nek Muhammad, a 27-year-old tribesman and former Taliban fighter whose defiance of Pakistan's military establishment had made him a folk hero among Islamic militants.

title: An Integration of Social Themes, Gestures and Humor
description: Aprogram by Joan Miller's Dance Players on June 11 at the Miller Theater was a pleasure for several reasons, chief among them the simple delight of being in the company of adults with a relaxed sense of professionalism, craft and imagination. Ms. Miller, a longtime choreographer and teacher in New York, has focused on training and inspiring young black dancers who stand out, as do her company members, for their humanity and easy expertise. Ms. Miller will doubtless never be in fashion as a choreographer, but she is a master at integrating social themes, movement and fanciful gesture, sometimes with infectious humor.

title: To Surprise of Researchers, Comet Has a Personality
description: The most revealing close-up pictures ever taken of a comet have scientists shaking their heads in astonishment. The rugged, diverse landscape of the comet Wild 2 is unlike anything they have ever seen or imagined: towering columns and spires rising above steep-walled craters and violent jets of gas and dust shooting skyward.
