description: J. Dennis Hastert , the House speaker, is going after the Democratic presidential candidate, John Kerry , again - and throwing in a few swipes at Nancy Pelosi , the House Democratic leader, for good measure.

title: Olympics Bill Does the High Jump, Leaving Some Greeks Low
description: With the opening Olympics ceremony just six weeks away and anxiety mounting over whether Athens can deliver a successful Games, Greece's conservative government said Thursday that the cost of staging the event was at least 30 percent higher than forecast.

title: On Two Continents, Companies Ask Politicians for Accounting Favors
description: JUST when the prospects for accounting reform were at their peak, the bull market came back. And with it came the power of those people who warn that bad things will happen if accountants report unpleasant truths.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fire Department To Review Alcohol Rules
description: The New York City Fire Department will appoint an internal group to review its regulations and penalties on drug and alcohol use, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday. The review is intended to ensure that the department is doing everything it can to discourage drug and alcohol abuse, he said. It was announced on the same day a city firefighter was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated after the police stopped him on Rockaway Beach Boulevard at 4:15 a.m., the authorities said. The firefighter, who was off duty, was identified as Gerard Ferrin, 47, of Shirley, on Long Island, a 19-year veteran. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Merck Backs U.S. Database To Track Drug Trials
description: Merck, one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies, says it supports the idea of a government-run database that would keep track of all late-stage clinical drug trials from start to finish.

title: Rumsfeld Admits He Told Jailers to Keep Detainee in Iraq Out of Red Cross View
description: Senior Pentagon officials acknowledged Thursday that a suspected Iraqi terrorist who was held in a military jail -- but kept off prison rosters -- should have been registered more quickly with the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Clouds Loom But Operas In the Park Remain Dry
description: Thunderclouds lowered over ''Nabucco'' and gray skies dimmed ''Madama Butterfly,'' but the weather held for two consecutive nights to allow the annual Met in the Parks concerts to proceed.

title: Not So Frivolous
description: President Bush traveled to Youngstown, Ohio, a few weeks ago to talk about health care, and before long he was reprising his complaint about ''junk and frivolous'' malpractice suits, which he said are discouraging good doctors from practicing medicine.

title: Cash vs. Benefits: Efficiency, or Assault on Russia's Soul?
description: Only weeks into a second term that President Vladimir V. Putin captured in part because he seemed to embody the welcome possibility of stability, his government has moved to dismantle a robust vestige of Soviet times: an array of social benefits that many Russians regard as essential.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBSTER, BARBARA (NEE PAYNE)
description: WEBSTER -- Barbara (nee Payne), of Glen Head, NY on May 22, 2004. A teacher and an avid reader. Beloved wife of the late Alan deForest, loving mother of the late Jonathan (Harriet), cherished grandmother of David (Tammy O'Donnell), Matthew and Benjamin. Great grandmother of Seamus and Molly. Aunt of Barbara Dodson (Robert), Judy Lawson (Jack) and Linda Hesselman (Ron Smith). Graveside Memorial Service 3PM, Saturday, June 26 at Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, NY. Further information Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave, Glen Head, New York 11545. Contributions may be made to First Presbyterian Church of Glen Cove, NY.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: MARTIN--Ellen Simpson on June 10, 2004. Wife of the late John G. Martin, Jr. Daughter of the late Frank and May Simpson of Little Falls, NY. Mother of John, Jean, Douglas, Anne, and Nancy. Memorial service at 11:00 onMonday, June 21 at Bedford Presbyterian Church, Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to SPCA, 590 North State Road, Briarcliff, NY 10510.

title: GlaxoSmithKline Says It Will Publicly List Drug Trials
description: GlaxoSmithKline , facing complaints that it selectively disclosed results from pediatric trials of its popular antidepressant drug Paxil, said today that it planned to create a company Web site that would publicly list all clinical trials on its marketed drugs.

title: The Price Of Life After 9/11
description: IT'S shop-closing time at the federal agency that was cobbled together to funnel taxpayer money to relatives of the dead and the wounded of Sept. 11. Checks have been cut, or will be soon enough. People who ran the agency, called the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, are about to pick up life where they left off nearly three years ago. They have won applause for a tough job well done.

title: Ignited by Their Absence, Two Hearts Grow Fonder
description: ''Facing Windows,'' a lush, surreally flavored immersion in voyeurism and romantic dreams, muses on many of the same themes as Alfred Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' and ''Vertigo,'' but from a more conventional emotional perspective. This seductive Italian film uses the image of beautiful strangers secretly and obsessively studying each other through opposite windows to reflect on two related romantic quandaries: the ''grass is always greener'' and ''absence makes the heart grow fonder.''

title: No Prison for 'Indian Chief' in Scheme for Catskills Casino
description: A man who submitted false documents to federal authorities in a scheme to gain recognition as an American Indian leader and open a casino escaped a prison term on Thursday when a judge sentenced him to six months of house arrest and five years of probation.

title: Knuckleballer Breaks The Yankees' Stride
description: Bernie Williams, who took eight years off between appearances in the leadoff spot, spoke Thursday about the importance of seeing pitches in that role. Then Williams paused, considering the kind of pitcher the Yankees would soon face.

title: High Kicks in Tutus Add Exuberance to Dazzle
description: Following its European and American festivals, New York City Ballet has moved on to a Russian music festival. Programs of composers grouped by nationality can lead to strange bedfellows, but the variety on Friday night at the New York State Theater was illuminating.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: JDA Software To Acquire QRS
description: The JDA Software Group, which makes software used by retailers, plans to buy the QRS Corporation for about $100 million in stock. Each QRS share will be exchanged for half a share of JDA. That values each share of QRS, based in Richmond, Calif., at about $6.13 a share, or 2.3 percent more than its closing price on Wednesday. Shares of JDA, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., rose 32 cents yesterday, to $12.57. (Bloomberg News)

title: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS WILL PURCHASE TWO COMPANIES
description: L-3 Communications Holdings, which makes bomb detectors and military electronics, agreed to buy two companies for a combined $208 million to add infrared sensors and laser-beam directors to its product line. L-3 will acquire Cincinnati Electronics for $172 million and Brashear for $36 million. The purchases of the closely held companies are expected to add slightly to 2004 results, L-3 said. Cincinnati Electronics, which has locations in Mason, Ohio, and Pasadena, Calif., makes infrared sensors for space and military use. Brashear, based in Pittsburgh, makes telescope systems, naval fire-control equipment and laser-beam directors. L-3 is based in New York.

title: Culture, History and the Sidewalks of New Haven
description: IN New Haven, town and gown meet head-on at the New Haven Green, a 16-acre park at the city's heart, with Yale just across the street. It's a landmark little changed since the 19th century, with oaks and sycamores shading a deep green lawn, a perfect starting point for sightseeing and museum hopping on walkable streets where ivy and the workaday city intertwine.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Signup For 9/11 Health Study Is Ending
description: The city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday that more than 41,000 people had signed up with the World Trade Center Health Registry, which was created last September to track the health consequences of the 9/11 terrorist attack over the next 20 years. The registry is open to people who might have been exposed to dust and smoke from the disaster. The enrollment period ends in 10 weeks. Information is available at (866) 692-9827 and at 311, the city's information number. Details are also online at wtcregistry.org. Officials called the registry the largest public health registry of its kind in United States history.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Rate Increase
description: Switzerland's central bank raised interest rates for the first time in four years, hoping to rein in any inflation resulting from the economy's recent expansion. The Swiss National Bank said it had raised the target range for its reference rate, the three-month Swiss franc Libor, by a quarter-point, to 0.5 percent. Jean-Pierre Roth, left, president of the central bank, said he expected the Swiss economy to grow 2 percent this year, reversing a contraction of 0.5 percent last year. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: 'Bound for Pleasure'

title: CHIEF QUITS AND SUCCESSOR IS NAMED AT NEOPHARM
description: NeoPharm's chief executive, James M. Hussey, resigned and will be succeeded by Gregory P. Young, who was an executive at Baxter International. Mr. Young will take over as chief executive July 13 and became a director effective yesterday, NeoPharm said. Mr. Hussey is leaving to pursue other opportunities, NeoPharm said. Neopharm's most advanced experimental product is a treatment for a form of brain cancer. An arbitration panel dismissed claims last month in a dispute between NeoPharm and Pfizer's Pharmacia unit stemming from delays in developing two cancer drugs. The joint venture ended in 2002. Neopharm is based in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 21 about fighting in Iraq quoted two comments incorrectly from a news conference by Maj. Gen. James Mattis, the Marine commander in the desert area near the Syrian border where an American missile strike killed civilians at what some Iraqis described as a wedding party. Denying that account, General Mattis said, "Let's not be naive, let's leave it at that" (not "Let's not be naive, bad things happen in wars") and "I don't have to apologize for the conduct of my marines" (not "for the conduct of my men"). title: Impac Literary Award Goes to a Moroccan
description: A Moroccan author, Tahar Ben Jelloun, was named the winner yesterday of the $120,000 International Impac Dublin Literary Award, the world's richest prize for a single work of fiction published in English.

title: Bush Spends A Long Day (And Night) On the Trail
description: President Bush swooped into Spokane on Thursday night to raise $750,000 for Representative George Nethercutt, the Republican who is challenging Senator Patty Murray for a seat in a politically competitive state important to Mr. Bush's re-election chances in November.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Argument On Witnesses In Murder Case
description: Preparations for the trial of Daniel Pelosi, left, the Long Island electrician accused of beating to death the millionaire Theodore Ammon, speeded up yesterday as the defense challenged the constitutionality of a state law controlling when the prosecution must reveal the names of any alibi rebuttal witnesses. The defense has yet to reveal what alibi, if any, Mr. Pelosi, who married Mr. Ammon's widow, may offer when the trial begins on Sept. 7, but argued it was unfair to allow the prosecution to wait until 10 days before the start of the trial to hand over the witness list. Prosecutors said that the defense had several chances to submit evidence of Mr. Pelosi's innocence but so far had not and that their office would need time to investigate any alibi. Justice Robert W. Doyle of State Supreme Court reserved a decision until mid-July. Julia Mead (NYT)

title: Pakistan Says It Killed a Tribesman Who Aided Militants
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 18  Pakistani military officials said today that their forces had killed Nek Muhammad, a 27-year-old tribesman and former Taliban fighter whose defiance of Pakistan's military establishment had made him a folk hero among Islamic militants.

title: ALBERTSON'S TO EXIT OMAHA, SHEDDING 21 STORES
description: Albertson's plans to sell or close 21 grocery and drugstores, cutting 180 jobs, as it exits the Omaha market amid competition from Wal-Mart Stores. Terms of the sale were not disclosed, but Albertson's said that second-quarter profit would be reduced by 6 cents a share. The Walgreen Company will buy the prescription files of nine Osco drugstores in Omaha that are closing. No Frills Supermarkets and Bag 'n Save will buy a total of 11 Albertson's grocery stores in Bellevue and Grand Island, Neb., as well as in Omaha. Hy-Vee agreed to buy one Osco drugstore in Council Bluffs, Iowa. Albertson's, based in Boise, Idaho, operates more than 2,500 stores in 37 states under the Albertson's, Jewel-Osco, Acme, Albertsons-Osco, Albertsons-Sav-on, Sav-on Drugs, Osco Drug, Shaw's, Max Foods, and Super Saver names.

title: Acting on Threat, Saudi Group Kills Captive American
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Paul M. Johnson Jr., the American engineer kidnapped last weekend by militants in Saudi Arabia, has been beheaded, his Al Qaeda captors announced today. Hours later, the top terrorist suspect in Saudi Arabia, who was believed to have been behind the abduction, was reported to have been killed in a gunfight with Saudi security forces.

title: Haunting Is Her Specialty
description: At 26, the pop-jazz singer Jane Monheit may still be too young to have her name identified with one song above all others. But that could change. If she continues to cry out the 1948 ballad ''Haunted Heart,'' by Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz, with the fervor she brought to her rendition at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening, it could become her signature. She has already recorded it; ''Haunted Heart,'' enhanced with a gorgeous arrangement by Alan Broadbent, is the standout cut on her last album, ''In the Sun'' (N-Coded Music).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FROMARTZ, BERNARD
description: FROMARTZ -- Bernard. 86. Lawyer and activist, was born in 1917 and died in May, 2004 in New York City. A Brooklyn native, he served in the U.S. Navy in WW II. He had a private law practice, worked on civil rights issues and launched a legal action against the Vietnam War. He represented draft resisters and volunteered with several organizations, including the National Lawyers Guild and the Board of the New York State Coalition of Concerned Legal Professionals, battling on behalf of farm workers and the working poor. He was an avid folk dancer and lived in New York, West Palm Beach and Spain. He is survived by his wife Sa-ard Fetner, his children Ernestine Stevenson, Lisa Fromartz, Bunji Fromartz and Samuel Fromartz, and four gran dchildren and five great grandchildren. He will be dearly missed.

He was Dr. John E. Wagner, a transplant specialist at the University of Minnesota.

title: Rivers and Michaels Show Pistons-Like Poise
description: On April 30, someone using my name suggested in these pages that Doc Rivers should not call the National Basketball Association playoffs for ABC and ESPN because being a network analyst and the new coach of the Boston Celtics created a conflict.

description: NEUWIRTH--Benjamin. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Benjamin Neuwirth, a respected leader dedicated to renewing and strengthening global Jewish life. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Anna; to his children; to his grandchildren; and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, JEROME G., M.D.
description: DAVIS--Jerome G., M.D., on June 6th, at the age of 89. A lifelong New Yorker, he brought joy to many, delivering thousands of children at New York Hospital. His love, warmth of spirit, strength of character and love of learning will be forever missed by his family and friends. Devoted husband of the late Florence, surviving family include brother, Morty, children, Daniel, Lorraine and Florence; stepdaughters, Mary Lou and Florence; grandchildren, Nancy, Suzanne, Lisa, David and Danny, nine great-grandchildren, favorite nieces, nephews, grandnieces and nephews, as well as dear friend and companion of six years, Doris. A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on Wednesday, June 23rd at the Metropolitan Synagogue, 40 East 35th St. at 1pm. Contributions can be made in his honor to New York Hospital to further cardiac disease research.

title: Ties That Bind a Family, Etched in an Orange Light
description: ''Father and Son,'' the new film by Alexander Sokurov, is like a dream within a dream. Its images and emotions are vivid, disquieting and also hermetic, and while it may frustrate your desire for clear storytelling and psychological transparency, it has an intensity that surpasses understanding. Mr. Sokurov, best known to American audiences for ''Russian Ark,'' his 90-minute, single-take digital video tour of the Hermitage, is a film poet whose deepest intentions risk being lost in translation.

title: An migr's Paradise Lost and Found
description: AN airline terminal is, by definition, a space you pass through on the way from one place to another, spending only as much time as is absolutely necessary. But the word terminal itself, which supplies the title for Steven Spielberg's new film opening today nationwide, also has some darker connotations that tug against its unassuming everyday meaning.

title: 41 Iraqis Killed in Two Car-Bomb Attacks; at Least 142 Others Are Wounded
description: A powerful suicide car bomb ripped into a throng of men waiting Thursday morning outside the army's main recruiting station in the heart of the capital, killing at least 35 Iraqis and wounding at least 138, health officials said. The men were lining up to enlist in the new Iraqi army.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jabil Shares Drop As Forecast Is Cut
description: Shares of Jabil Circuit, which builds electronics such as computer parts and broadcast gear for other companies, fell yesterday after the company cut its 2004 profit forecast. Net income will rise to 80 cents to 82 cents a share in 2004, down from its March forecast of 83 cents to 87 cents, the company, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said late Wednesday. Jabil shares declined $3.56, or 12.7 percent, to $24.49. Jabil said third-quarter net income rose ninefold to $40.1 million, or 19 cents a share, as sales gained 33 percent. Jabil expects sales of as much as $1.85 billion in next year's fiscal first quarter. That would miss the $1.86 billion average of 14 analysts in a Thomson Financial survey.

title: ACTING OFFICER AT IMCLONE TO FILL POST AS FINANCIAL CHIEF
description: ImClone Systems, the maker of the Erbitux colon cancer medicine, said its acting chief financial officer, Michael Howerton, will fill the post permanently. Mr. Howerton, 52, joined the company in August 2001 after 25 years at the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. He has been acting financial officer since May 2003, when Daniel Lynch left the position to become chief executive. ImClone has replaced executives after an insider trading scandal that started in 2002 and engulfed the former chief executive, Samuel Waksal, and Martha Stewart, founder of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.

title: Iran Assailed for Lack of Cooperation on Nuclear Program
description: VIENNA, June 18  Adding another black mark to its ledger of complaints about Iran, the International Atomic Energy Agency passed a resolution today sharply criticizing the Iranian government for its lack of cooperation in disclosing the details of its nuclear program.

title: A Pool and a Lighthouse? No, a Toll Plaza
description: AT the beginning of each episode of HBO's hit television series ''The Sopranos,'' Tony Soprano drives to his home in New Jersey through tollbooths onto the New Jersey Turnpike, passing the rusty viaducts and grim industrial areas that have long made the name Garden State seem ironic. They have also firmly fixed the state's place in the landscape of the national imagination.

title: Building-Approval Process Speeded Up in New Jersey
description: While environmental advocates lobbied frantically to stop them, New Jersey legislators approved a bill Thursday that would expedite approval of development in more than one-third of the state. The bill moved with startling speed; introduced three days earlier, it sailed through both houses after leaders struck deals to vote without debate.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fertilizer Concern Forecasts Gain
description: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the world's biggest fertilizer producer, said that its second-quarter earnings would be about a quarter higher than expected, reflecting strong markets for potash and nitrogen. Rising demand from China, India and Brazil, along with low inventories and tight supplies, has helped push up potash prices, while the nitrogen market has been lifted by a strong spring season and plant shutdowns in the United States. The company, which is based in Saskatoon, said that it expected second-quarter earnings to exceed $1 a share, up from the previous estimate of 70 cents to 90 cents a share. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Venezuelan Leader Braces for Recall Vote
description: The government of President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela is poised to pack the Supreme Court with allies who could decide in favor of the president if an August recall referendum on his rule is as close and contested as expected, an American-based human rights group said Thursday.

title: Bush and McCain Campaign Together in West
description: After a rousing introduction by Senator John McCain, the military hero who was once his bitter campaign rival, President Bush today told soldiers newly returned from distant battlefields that the 9/11 terror attacks and the war in Iraq were inextricably linked.

title: Putin Says Russia Wants Yukos to Survive
description: A day before an expected court ruling that could cost the Russian oil giant Yukos billions of dollars in back taxes, President Vladimir V. Putin said on Thursday that his government would do its best to assure that the company would not go bankrupt.

The tickets, with a face value of $94.50, cost me $59 each. Shipping via FedEx added $9.95. And finally, I paid $11.80, or 10 percent of the price for my two tickets, to an outfit called StubHub.

description: At 9:36 a.m. on Sept. 11, halfway through America's most calamitous morning, military air defense officials learned that American Airlines Flight 77 was just six miles -- and little more than a minute -- away from the White House.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial production in Argentina bounced back in May after slumping the previous month, suggesting that the country's energy crisis may not be hurting economic activity as much as many analysts feared. The government's statistics agency said on Wednesday that output rose a larger-than-expected 11.2 percent last month from the year-earlier period, and 1.7 percent from April. In the first five months of the year, output is up 12.4 percent over the same period in 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

description: The pilots' union at Delta Air Lines Inc. decided yesterday to seek a resumption of contract negotiations with the company, using updated objectives.

title: Putting the Sofa Where the Toyota Used to Be
description: WHEN Vivienne Stewart and her husband, Paul, bought their vacation home in Pawling, N.Y., in 1994, they planned to tear it down. Though it had more than 4,500 square feet of living space and four bedrooms, there was no place for the family to gather and the kitchen was so small that there wasn't even room for a table. For the Stewarts, who had five children, the floor plan just didn't make sense.

title: Dad's Out of the Closet; His Child Wants to Hide
description: A boy learns that his father is gay. This one sentence must have struck someone as intrinsically fascinating, because ''Jack,'' a Showtime movie about a boy with a gay father, is static and entirely unrealized, a one-dimensional social-issue dramatization that a high school guidance counselor might recommend in lieu of therapy.

description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to increase the strength of the Army by 20,000 soldiers, with lawmakers saying the military is badly strained by operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Nobody eviscerates the scary depths of male narcissism with such ferocity, and it is a huge relief to find Mr. Stiller flexing his oiled, low-comedy triceps with such vengeful glee.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Agreement On Immigration Bill
description: After three years of negotiations on how to control immigration, the government and the conservative opposition agreed on a bill that would make it easier for skilled workers to move to Germany to help with a shortfall of qualified workers but will toughen controls on foreign militants. ''This is a historic change for Germany,'' said Interior Minister Otto Schily, adding that for the first time Germany had defined itself as an immigrant society. The measure will allow the first major immigration of foreign workers into Germany, now home to seven million immigrants, since the country tightened its borders in the 1970's. Mr. Schily said he expected broad support in Parliament. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: We Love Him. Now Where's His Body?
description: Gram Parsons was just short of 27 when he died of a drug overdose in a California motel room in 1973, but his posthumous legend shows no signs of growing old. If anything, his plain-spoken, poetic folk-country songwriting style has undergone something of a revival recently as alt-country musicians like Gillian Welch and Lucinda Williams absorb his influence and invoke his name.

title: Actors' Union Authorizes Strike if Pact Isn't Reached
description: The membership of Actors Equity, the actors' and stage managers' union, has voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike if the union cannot reach a new contract with producers by June 27, when the current deal expires.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: School District Superintendent Vindicated
description: A state appeals court panel yesterday unanimously upheld the reinstatement of a Brooklyn school superintendent five years after he was fired over low test scores. The superintendent, Robert E. Riccobono, left, was fired by Rudy Crew, then the chancellor, in June 1999, in a purge of superintendents in low-performing districts. After the test scores at Mr. Riccobono's East New York schools were rechecked, it turned out that they had risen during his last year. Mr. Riccobono sued for reinstatement and won, but the city appealed. Yesterday, a five-judge panel affirmed the lower court's decision, finding that Mr. Riccobono had not received due process before being fired. Georgia Pestana, a lawyer for the city, said it was very disappointed by the ruling and was considering an appeal. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: SUMITOMO AGREES TO BUY HARTZ MOUNTAIN
description: The Sumitomo Corporation of Japan agreed to purchase the pet-supplies maker Hartz Mountain for $365 million to create a global pet-care business. Sumitomo and its United States unit agreed to purchase all the outstanding shares in JWC Hartz Holdings from J.W. Child Associates, a Boston buyout firm. The United States unit, the Sumitomo Corporation of America, will be the majority owner of the company, said Jewelle Yamada, a spokeswoman for Sumitomo America. As a Knick, and as a member of the Olympic basketball team that will represent the United States in Athens, he is finally feeling respected, finally feeling loved.

title: Maine, the Land of Vacations and Vampires
description: New England is an ideal setting for horror stories, offering, among its many macabre charms, creaky houses, churchyards, shotguns, three dismal seasons and the periodically uneasy coexistence of Protestants, Roman Catholics and skeptics. In the years since Stephen King of Maine came to preside over horror in fiction and film, it has become difficult to imagine that any other region of the United States could frighten us so profoundly.

title: The Rural Life; Candide's Advice
description: The most famous line in Voltaire's ''Candide'' is the final one: ''We must cultivate our garden.'' That is Candide's response to the philosopher Pangloss, who tries again and again to prove that we live in the best of all possible worlds, no matter what disasters befall us. Ever since ''Candide'' was published in February 1759, that line has seemed to express a reluctance to get involved, an almost quietist refusal to be distracted by the grand chaos of earthly events. And that reading might make sense, if Candide hadn't already lived through a lifetime of woe. In fact, that line is the summation of Candide's wisdom, his recognition that no matter how you choose to explain the world, the garden still needs cultivating.

title: Workers Say Late Shifts Often Mean Locked Exits
description: David Sandoval, who cleans the floors of the Met Foods Supermarket in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, walks in through the front door most evenings around 8:30. But when the gates come down an hour later, he says, the door is locked, and he is unable to leave until the manager comes in the next morning.

title: Man and 3 Children Drown, and a Church Family Mourns
description: A father, his two children and another little girl, all on a trip with a Chicago church group, drowned Wednesday in a Texas water garden.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Game Maker Considers Sale
description: The British computer game developer Eidos said it would consider ''strategic alternatives,'' signaling to the markets that it was looking for a buyer or a partner. In May, Eidos said that sales of its assassination simulation game, Hitman: Contracts, were lower than expected because of softness in the market, sending the company's stock plummeting. The market is not expected to improve in the short term, Eidos said yesterday, adding that the introduction of its Vietnam War game, ShellShock: Nam '67, will be delayed until September. title: Good Marks for Rank and File Who Responded to Attacks

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port Authority Backs New Path Cars
description: Returning to a project that was suspended because of the Sept. 11 terror attack, the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved spending $809 million to buy new PATH cars and to begin design work on a new signal system for the trans-Hudson tubes. The plan to buy the new cars as well as upgrade the signal system was originally adopted in November 2000 by Port Authority commissioners but temporarily put aside when the attack on the World Trade Center curtailed operations of the line and created new rebuilding priorities. title: IMCO RECYCLING TO BUY COMMONWEALTH INDUSTRIES
description: IMCO Recycling, which recycles aluminum and zinc, will buy an aluminum-sheet manufacturer, Commonwealth Industries, for about $175.6 million in stock, expanding its capacity to produce aluminum sheet from recycled metal. IMCO will exchange 0.815 share for each Commonwealth share, the companies said. The valuation is about 27 percent more than Commonwealth's closing price Wednesday of $8.60 a share. IMCO said it expected to complete the purchase in the fourth quarter. The combined company will have $2 billion in annual sales, 3,600 employees and 34 sites, IMCO said. IMCO is based in Irving, Tex., and Commonwealth is based in Louisville, Ky.

Still, the offensive against militants who fled into northwestern Pakistan continues, and Osama bin Laden remains on the lam. title: Mahler's Overarching Vision of Nature
description: If ever there were a strategic time for Lorin Maazel to demonstrate his many strengths as a conductor it was Wednesday night, the first of four performances of Mahler's massive Symphony No. 3 in D Minor. With this program the orchestra formally ends its current season, Mr. Maazel's second as music director. On Tuesday the Philharmonic announced that Mr. Maazel's initial four-year contract was being extended three years through 2009. Whatever one's take on his tenure so far, Mr. Maazel's performance was a reminder to even doubtful listeners that at his best he is a formidable musician and a commanding technician with seemingly unlimited stamina. Despite my reservations about aspects of this performance, Mr. Maazel was at his best on Wednesday night. (There are two more performances, tonight and tomorrow night.)

The 75-by-16-foot houseboat is the biggest rental on this man-made body of water, which straddles the border of Arizona and Utah. And it is by far the fanciest, with a hot tub and a wet bar, staterooms with TV's and DVD players, and a living room with a fireplace and an up-to-date entertainment center. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, GLADYS

Cherished wife of the late Irving Kaufman (former partner of Salomon Bros.), beloved mother of Maggie Kaufman Smith and Joyce Kaufman (Allen Miller) and cherished grandmother of Eben, Ethan, Laurel and Noah. As a young woman she was a buyer for the purchasing department of Macy's and then a secretary for Eagle Pencil Co. until she met Irving and had a marriage ''made in heaven'' for 50 years. title: National Briefing | West: California: Money Cited As A Motive
description: Prosecutors in the murder trial of Scott Peterson introduced money as a possible motive in the killing of Mr. Peterson's wife, Laci. A jewelry clerk in Modesto, where the Petersons lived, testified in Redwood City that Ms. Peterson had several pieces of jewelry she had inherited from her grandmother appraised in the weeks before she disappeared. When the clerk, Mary Anna Felix, told Ms. Peterson the jewelry was worth more than $100,000, ''she said that he would be very happy,'' Ms. Felix testified in a reference to Mr. Peterson. Ms. Peterson also had her wedding ring melted down and combined with a ring of her grandmother's, Ms. Felix said. That ring was still at the jeweler's when Ms. Peterson disappeared. Mr. Peterson's lawyer, Mark Geragos, suggested that it must not have been important to Mr. Peterson since he never picked it up. Elizabeth Ahlin (NYT)

title: 3rd Graders in Poor Areas Bear the Brunt of Promotion Rules
description: Results of the citywide third-grade exams show that in the city's lowest-performing school districts, as many as a third of the eligible students failed to meet the cutoff for promotion to the fourth grade. In District 5 in Harlem and in District 16 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, one in three children subject to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's new third-grade promotion rules now face the prospect of repeating third grade and have been urged to attend summer school.

title: Diageo Selects Grey For Tanqueray Brand
description: Diageo said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Grey Worldwide in New York, part of the Grey Global Group, by awarding the agency the United States creative duties for Tanqueray gin; the work had been handled by J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Women Acting Their Age, and Everybody Else's
description: Those who live in other people's skins don't need to worry about their own aging flesh. That, at least, would seem to be the comforting case with Kathy Najimy and Mo Gaffney, currently reviving some of the skits that made them comedy cult stars in the 1980's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Takes A Stand On Child Support
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would send letters to all city employees to remind those responsible for child support payments to keep up with them. The mayor noted that if a city employee refused to do so, the city's Office of Child Support Enforcement could take legal steps like seizing a tax refund, freezing bank accounts and suspending a driver's license. ''Child support payments are not optional,'' the mayor wrote. Winnie Hu (NYT)

description: Behind the gallery rope, Bob Duval waited with tears in his eyes, wondering how the day would unfold, wondering where his son's first tee shot would land.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: TV Chief Shot In Dagestan
description: A television executive in southern Dagestan was critically injured when he was struck by a sniper's bullet in Makhachkala, the republic's capital. Tagib Abdusamadov, director of the state-affiliated broadcasting company, was shot near a theater. The authorities did not immediately discuss motives or suspects. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

description: West Philadelphia Catholic High School set a national record last night in the 1,600-meter medley relay at the Adidas National High School Track and Field Championships in Raleigh, N.C.

description: In the course of a single week, New Jersey lawmakers approved two vastly different bills that could drastically alter the state's landscape for generations to come.

title: Battery Park Given Slice of Pie In South Ferry Subway Project
description: A $400 million renovation of the South Ferry subway station will move forward, city and state officials said yesterday, after an agreement was reached to use a part of the federal money for the project for improvements to Battery Park.

description: To the Editor:

title: Putin Says U.S. Was Alerted To Possible Attacks by Iraq
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that Russia gave intelligence reports to the Bush administration suggesting that Saddam Hussein's government was preparing terrorist attacks in the United States or against American targets overseas.

description: FOOTBALL

title: Bush and McCain, Together, Call Iraq War a Conflict Between Good and Evil
description: President Bush and his old political nemesis Senator John McCain shared a military stage on Friday to present an unusual joint defense of the war in Iraq, calling it a conflict between good and evil that threatened the existence of the United States.

title: Tchaikovsky's New York
description: The composer Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky arrived in New York on April 26, 1891, to conduct his works at the gala concerts inaugurating Andrew Carnegies new Music Hall, as Carnegie Hall was then known. During his stay, he conducted a series of concerts with the New York Symphony, which merged with the New York Philharmonic in 1928.

title: Leaders of 9/11 Panel Ask Cheney for Reports That Would Support Iraq-Qaeda Ties
description: The leaders of the Sept. 11 commission called on Vice President Dick Cheney on Friday to turn over any intelligence reports that would support the White House's insistence that there was a close relationship between Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda.

title: European Open Teams Event Is Starting Today in Sweden
description: The oldest international bridge event is the European Open Teams Championship, which was first played in 1932. The honor roll of winners includes almost all the great players from the other side of the Atlantic. The 47th championship begins today in Malmo, Sweden, and will continue for 15 days. The standings will determine the European representation in the 2005 world championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, JANE
description: WEISS--Jane. 103, widow of Max, mother of Betty-Ann. Retired teacher. Beloved sister to 10 and beloved aunt to 20. Reposing at Schwartz-Jeffers Funeral Home. Services Sunday, 10 A.M.

title: House Rejects Increased Aid To Secure Cities at High Risk
description: In a blow to the New York metropolitan region's antiterrorism efforts, the House rejected a move Friday to provide nearly $500 million to pay for security initiatives in cities believed to be at greatest risk of attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHERMERHORN, FRAN COISE GOUVERNET
description: SCHERMERHORN -- Fran coise Gouvernet. On June 9, 2004 in Cannes, France. Wife of the late Howard F. Schermerhorn. She is survived by her stepson, David K. Schermerhorn, of Deer Harbor, WA. Donations may be made to the Diabetes Association.

title: Hybrid Vehicles Hit the Heartland...Barely
description: Julie Buhl drives a Toyota Prius in pickup country.

title: Plan for Indian Casino Splits Illinois Town
description: A Wisconsin Indian tribe's proposal to build what would be the largest casino in Illinois -- a windfall that the mayor and a local congressman are eager to have -- is drawing ire from some local residents, who are organizing to oppose it.

Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: The Moor of Venice Gets Some Help
description: 'Othello'

title: 'We Have Some Planes'
description: Al Qaeda planned meticulously; the United States improvised. That's one of the alarming themes running through the Sept. 11 commission's inquiry into every aspect of the terror attacks. Indeed, the latest staff report on official Washington's minute-by-minute response to that morning's four suicidal airline hijackings is called ''Improvising a Homeland Defense.'' Along with the report, the commission also made public some chilling recordings, including a voice believed to be that of the lead plotter, Mohamed Atta, saying: ''We have some planes. Just stay quiet, and you will be O.K.''

title: Lawyer in Rigas Trial Says Prosecutors Oversimplified Case
description: A lawyer for Timothy J. Rigas, the former finance chief of the Adelphia Communications Corporation, told jurors yesterday that prosecutors relied on lying witnesses and ''grossly oversimplified'' evidence at his fraud trial.

title: Woods Stages Late Rally And Waits for the Wind
description: Tiger Woods was talking to himself. He launched a drive into the heather and shook his head. He whacked another into the tangled grass and quietly practiced his swing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AUTODESK INC., San Rafael, Calif., which makes design software, said it had promoted Carl Bass to chief operating officer.

title: Woman Jumps to Death
description: A 24-year-old woman jumped to her death from the balcony of her brother's 25th-floor Midtown apartment yesterday afternoon, falling to the middle of a busy crosstown street, where traffic was stalled for two hours, the police said.

title: Bernard Vonderschmitt, 80, Semiconductor Designer, Dies
description: Bernard V. Vonderschmitt, an electrical engineer who led early semiconductor research efforts and who later pioneered the business of separating chip design and manufacturing, died on June 9 at his home in Jasper, Ind., from complications from a stroke, according to a spokesman for Xilinx Inc. He was 80 years old.

title: Locksmith Accused of Bilking L.I. Hospital System for Years
description: Two obscure companies, Yankee Lock and Tubes Inc., made a strategic mistake when they hounded the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System last year to pay its bills more promptly, according to the authorities.

title: A Focus on Bush, Iraq and Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: OSI TO BUY DRUG TECHNOLOGY FROM PROBIODRUG
description: OSI Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed to buy a diabetes drug technology from the closely held Probiodrug of Germany for $35 million to extend its product portfolio beyond cancer drugs. The transaction includes patents for a drug that affects the body's production of glucose; it is set to enter the second phase of clinical trials in the United States and Europe for the treatment of Type 2 diabetes. Separately, OSI Pharmaceuticals, based in Melville, N.Y., said it would invest $50 million in its Prosidion unit, which is focused on diabetes and obesity drugs. The Prosidion unit is based in Oxford, England.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on May 26, about a history of penicillin called ''The Mold in Dr. Florey's Coat,'' by Eric Lax, attributed a distinction incorrectly to Anne Miller, a patient injected with that antibiotic in 1942. She was not the first American to receive it; others were treated in 1940 and 1941.

title: In Chicago, Hometown Support for the Airline but Doubts About Government Aid
description: For some it is a workers' issue. For others, it is a hometown issue. And for even others, the question of a loan guarantee for United Airlines is an issue the government should stay out of.

title: Pataki Offers New Proposal For Javits Center Expansion
description: Stung by criticism, Gov. George E. Pataki is sending a revised proposal to make possible a $1.4 billion expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center only weeks after he submitted his original bill to the Legislature.

title: Recalling Anguish in 2000, Kerry Is Mum on His No. 2
description: It is happening again to Senator John Kerry: Reporters and photographers are skulking outside his house early in the morning and late at night and mobbing him as he makes his way through the Capitol. At every step he faces questions about the vice presidency.

title: Israeli Platoon Leaders Fired Over Death
description: The Israeli Army dismissed the commander and deputy commander of a platoon whose gunfire shot and killed a 31-year-old Palestinian in a wheelchair on June 6 near Ramallah, a military spokesman announced Friday. It also transferred the entire platoon from the Kalandia refugee camp outside Ramallah and compelled it to undergo retraining.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 9 about reaction to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to reduce noise in the city referred incorrectly to the background of Dr. David J. Hellerstein, a psychiatrist who cited the excitement value of noise along with its costs. He is not the author of ''Undoing Depression: What Therapy Doesn't Teach You and Medication Can't Give You.'' The book is by Richard O'Connor, who did not figure in the article.

title: Lost Towers, Reflected in a Can
description: A familiar saw-toothed view of the New York skyline on a product with deep New York roots has quietly been altered. How it came to be changed is a story of corporate strategizing -- and of deciding to ease some customers' painful memories of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: New in Liberal Arts: Intro to Job Market
description: Matthew Santirocco is a scholar of ancient Greek and Latin poetry, and a strong advocate of the liberal arts. But as dean of the College of Arts and Science at New York University, he is also under siege from parents paying mammoth tuition bills who want to make sure their children will land the right jobs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a review of ''Constantin Brancusi: The Essence of Things,'' at the Guggenheim Museum, misidentified the tall wood sculpture at the right. It was ''King of Kings'' (1938). ''Adam and Eve'' (1921) is also in the exhibition.

title: To Side With Sharon, Peres Wants Joint Peace Plan
description: Shimon Peres, leader of Israel's opposition Labor Party, laid out on Friday for the first time conditions under which his party would join the government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: Tricks or Treats, It's All a Cheeky Pose
description: Skinny, messy, stylish, beery: the retro-rock movement has always been vaguely British in spirit, and British fans (and critics) remain the genre's most enthusiastic cheerleaders. Yet British bands have played a puzzlingly small part in this retro revolution. The Libertines never quite ascended into the pantheon, while the Darkness have more in common with Spinal Tap than with the Strokes.

title: Man Pleads Guilty in a Case Tied to Lil' Kim
description: On a day that went badly for Lil' Kim, the racy rap diva, a man pleaded guilty yesterday to federal weapons charges in connection with a shootout in 2001 outside a Manhattan radio station where she had just performed.

title: Iran Rebuked by U.N. Agency For Withholding Atom Details
description: Iran, increasingly isolated even by former allies, was formally rebuked by the International Atomic Energy Agency on Friday in a resolution that sharply criticized it for a lack of cooperation in disclosing the details of its nuclear program.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Delay In Gas Shipments
description: Indonesia, the world's largest exporter of liquefied natural gas, has asked one of its biggest customers to let it delay shipments from a plant in the province of Aceh for up to two years. Indonesia has asked Korea Gas, South Korea's monopoly importer of liquefied natural gas, to accept delayed shipments of about 330,000 metric tons from its plant in Arun, citing rising demand for gas by domestic fertilizer makers. Production at Arun, which is operated by Exxon Mobil, has been falling as reserves dwindle. Korea Gas has contracts to buy 3.3 million metric tons of Indonesian gas a year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Bringing Together Two Great Minds
description: 'Rush's Dream'

title: Cornell to Help Run Teaching Hospital in Qatar
description: Qatar plans to announce an ambitious effort today to develop a world-class academic medical center with the help of Cornell University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAVAGLIANTI, NINA
description: TRAVAGLIANTI--Nina. The President, Board of Trustees and Officers of Long Island University extend their deepest condolences to trustee Ed Travaglianti, Chancellor of the Brooklyn campus and his family on their loss. Our thoughts and prayers are with them during this difficult time. Roger Tilles, Chair, Board of Trustees David J. Steinberg, President

title: Window Guard Gives Way, and Boy, 2, Falls to Death
description: A 2-year-old boy fell out of a sixth-story window and died yesterday in Washington Heights after a metal window guard apparently gave way, the police said.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Deal For Predecessor
description: The former president, Frederick Chiluba, could avoid trial on graft charges if he returns three-quarters of the $41 million he is accused of stealing during a decade in office, the current president, Levy Mwanawasa, said. Mr. Mwanawasa said during a visit by Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, that he had extended the offer to Mr. Chiluba but has received no response. Mr. Obasanjo, who has tried to recover stolen funds from previous Nigerian regimes, urged Mr. Chiluba to focus on replenishing Zambia's treasury instead of jailing offenders. Mr. Obasanjo later met with Mr. Chiluba, sparking speculation that he was attempting to broker a deal to end the long-running conflict between Mr. Chiluba and Mr. Mwanawasa over corruption charges. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW -- Archie. So missed. We wish you could share our pride and joys. Much love, Gene and Three Generations

description: 'Typewriter Dreams: Three Centuries of One-Acts'

title: Sudan's Final Solution
description: In my last column, I wrote about Magboula Muhammad Khattar, a 24-year-old woman whose world began to collapse in March, when the Janjaweed Arab militia burned her village and slaughtered her parents.

title: Publisher Tries to Stop Leaks From the Clinton Memoirs
description: Lawyers for Bill Clinton's publisher scrambled yesterday to block leaks from his memoirs before its official release next week. But legal experts said a publisher had scant hope of keeping the contents under wraps after a copy fell into a reporter's hands.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the obituary page yesterday about a memorial service for the jazz drummer Elvin Jones at Riverside Church in Manhattan misstated the date. It will be at 10 a.m. next Saturday, not today.

title: Leaders Reach Agreement on a European Constitution
description: Correction Appended

title: Kerry's Cruel Realism
description: Sometimes in the unscripted moments of a campaign, when the handlers are away, a candidate shows his true nature. Earlier this month, Andres Oppenheimer of The Miami Herald asked John Kerry what he thought of something called the Varela Project. Kerry said it was ''counterproductive.'' It's necessary to try other approaches, he added.

title: Piazza Honored, but Cameron Takes Bows
description: Cliff Floyd noticed that Tigers reliever Danny Patterson had been careless against the two previous Mets batters in the ninth inning, especially on Ty Wigginton's liner to third for the second out.

title: Court Upholds Subpoena For Rowland
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court ruled Friday that the House committee considering whether Gov. John G. Rowland should be impeached has the authority to order him to testify before it.

title: Maggert Confident
description: Seeing Jeff Maggert's name on the leader board during the United States Open is hardly a surprise.

title: City Resolves Legal Battle Over Forcing Students Out
description: After months of legal skirmishing over New York City's policies regarding older students who have fallen behind, lawsuits charging that three high schools illegally discharged struggling students have been resolved. In the process, a tentatively cooperative relationship has emerged between the Department of Education and Advocates for Children, the group that brought the lawsuits.

title: A Focus on Bush, Iraq and Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Answers on a 4-Block Path to a Killing
description: The two teenagers were bored, wandering the darkened streets in what the police said was an apparent search for someone to rob. It was 3 a.m. on Thursday when they came across a homeless man, known by everyone in the neighborhood, resting in the back seat of a parked car, the police said. In East New York, Brooklyn, in the middle of the night, he was one of the few available targets. But he was not an easy mark, confronting the two boys who rousted him and then mocked him when he fell to the ground outside the car, according to the police. He reached for his nearest weapon -- an empty bottle -- and tossed it at them in a futile act of bravado.

title: Saying Farewell to an Indonesia She Knew Too Well
description: THE last thing Sidney Jones was thinking about when the scrap of paper was hand-delivered to her office early this month was that she was being served with a deportation order. But once she got over the shock, she was outraged -- the government had already refused to renew her work visa, so she was already being forced out.

title: Spotlight Falls On Champions
description: With Smarty Jones in the midst of a brief vacation, quieting the mania that surrounded his every move, horse racing's spotlight will shift temporarily today, focusing on some horses trying to nudge their way back into the limelight.

title: Refco Breached Contract, Jury Finds
description: A jury in New York Supreme Court has found that the futures broker Refco Securities breached a contract with a hedge fund, Tradewinds Financial, by making an unnecessary margin call. The hedge fund is seeking $45 million in damages.

title: The Draft Option
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. APPROVES GENERIC DIABETES DRUG BY IMPAX AND TEVA
description: Impax Laboratories Inc. and Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. said that the Food and Drug Administration approved a generic version of the Glucophage diabetes drug made by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. The companies will share profits from sales of the medicine, called metformin HCl extended-release tablets, Impax and Teva said. The companies join three other generic drug makers that already market versions of sustained-release Glucophage. Bristol-Myers said in April that first-quarter sales of Glucophage and related products fell 35 percent, to $161 million. Teva, based in Petah Tiqwa, Israel, said it would begin shipping the drugs immediately. Impax is based in Hayward, Calif.

title: Decyphering the Grammar Of Mind, Music and Math
description: Imagine a locked room in which a person sits alone staring into space. There is nothing to look at. Nothing to touch or taste or smell. Most of the world is stripped away. Except for sounds.

title: Glaxo Plans Public Listing Of Drug Trials on Web Site
description: GlaxoSmithKline, facing complaints that it selectively disclosed results from pediatric trials of its popular antidepressant drug Paxil, said yesterday that it planned to create a company Web site that would publicly list all clinical trials on its marketed drugs.

title: A Legend Among Clarinetists
description: Among the satraps who are an orchestra's principal players, Stanley Drucker is a long-lived king. He has been a clarinetist in the New York Philharmonic for 55 seasons, nearly a third of the orchestra's history.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Sales Rise
description: Tesco, Britain's biggest supermarket chain, said first-quarter sales rose 12 percent as the company cut prices and added products like duvets and curtains. Revenue at British stores open at least a year climbed 7.8 percent in the 12 weeks ended May 22, compared with a 5.8 percent increase a year earlier, the chief financial officer, Andrew Higginson, said. Tesco has added clothes, household goods and DVD's to try to get shoppers to spend more when they visit a store.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In a Sprawling Memoir, Clinton Cites Storms and Settles Scores
description: Former President Bill Clinton, in a 957-page autobiography that is by turns painfully candid about his personal flaws and gleefully vindictive about what he calls the hypocrisy of his enemies, blamed his affair with Monica Lewinsky on the ''old demons'' that have haunted him all his life.

title: How It Feels to Be a Circle or a Chord
description: Maria Schneider's orchestral jazz is about feeling. Like Wayne Shorter, she somehow expresses compassion through tones. Ms. Schneider, though, is more programmatic about it. She will set herself the task of writing music about intersecting circles in a Kandinsky painting, or hang gliding, or the symmetry in Coltrane's ''Giant Steps.'' But instead of reducing those ideas to formal devices, she tries to get at what it feels like to be intersecting circles, or an object in the air, or a set of chord changes.

title: Europe's Reluctance
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Going to Doctor Is Raped At a Medical Center in Nassau
description: A woman was grabbed and raped this week at Nassau University Medical Center on Long Island as she went to a doctor's appointment, prompting hospital administrators to order a review of all security procedures.

title: POLITICIANS FACE BISHOPS' CENSURE IN ABORTION RIFT
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops approved a statement on Friday on ''Catholics in Political Life'' that brands politicians who support abortion rights as ''cooperating in evil'' and leaves the door open for bishops to deny communion to such lawmakers.

title: Corrections
description: The Reverberations column in Weekend yesterday, about the continuing cultural impact of Leonard Bernstein, misspelled the surname of an actor who delivers a monologue addressed to him in the current Broadway production of ''Assassins.'' The actor is Mario Cantone, not Contone.

title: VALERO RAISES ESTIMATES FOR SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT
description: The Valero Energy Corporation, an oil refiner, raised its estimate for second-quarter profit because of higher refining margins and increased production. Earnings will exceed $4 a share, the company said, above the $3.75 a share expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Valero's chief executive, William E. Greehey, said in April that the company expected profit ''well over'' $3 a share. Valero, which is based in San Antonio, had net income of $1.08 a share during the second quarter of 2003. Profit rose 46 percent in the first three months of this year from a year earlier as stricter pollution rules curtailed gasoline output from some rivals and fuel demand surged. Valero said it was also benefiting from widening discounts on high-sulfur, or sour, crude relative to low-sulfur, or sweet, grades. Valero, which expects to report results on July 29, released its forecast after the close of market trading yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKER, JOYCE E. (NEE STERN)
description: BECKER--Joyce E. (nee Stern). On June 17th, 2004. Devoted mother, grandmother and attorney. Survived by husband Jacob, daughters Robin, Patrice and Debra, sons-in-law David Harris and Jonathan Berger and five loving grandchildren. Interment Friday, June 18th, 2004 will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Chabad of Northwestern Bergen County, P.O. Box 63, Franklin Lakes NJ 07417

title: A Man of Violence, or Just '110 Percent' Gung-Ho?
description: It hardly surprised David A. Passaro's neighbors or a former wife that he should be arrested for beating an Afghan man in custody last year, becoming the first civilian charged in the American military's widening prisoner abuse scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZYNCZAK, JOSEPH E.
description: ZYNCZAK--Joseph E. On June 15, at the age of 65. Beloved husband of Evelyn, devoted father of Joseph Jason and Aaron Arthur, son of Mary Seidler, and the late Joseph Zynczak, brother of Alice Fagnan, and Geraldine Parrinello. Attorney and friend to recording artists, producers and executives throughout the entertainment industry. His love of nature, strength of character and devotion to family and friends will be missed and shall endure in our memory. A memorial service will be held at 10 am, on Monday, June 21, at The Fellowship Church, Roscyk Hill Road, Machias, NY. Donations can be made in his honor to Roswell Park Cancer Institute, Buffalo, NY, or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, TN.

title: Firefighter at Fatal Scene Admits He 'Hit Something' Hours Before
description: A volunteer firefighter on Long Island who responded to a report of a dead man on the side of the road ended up turning himself in yesterday and admitting that he might have struck the man with his pickup the night before, the Suffolk County authorities said.

title: SBC SELLS SHARES IN TELKOM SOUTH AFRICA
description: SBC Communications and Telekom Malaysia sold 14.9 percent of Telkom South Africa Ltd. to institutional investors for 6 billion South African rand ($923 million) to take advantage of the stock's rise since last year's share sale. The price, 73 rand a share, is 1.7 percent less than the closing price of Telkom shares on the JSE Securities Exchange South Africa on Thursday, Telkom South Africa said in a stock exchange statement. SBC, based in San Antonio, is reducing its stakes in phone companies worldwide.

title: Messy Fight In Cases Against Athletes
description: Lawyers for three of the track athletes who were notified last week of possible drug violations picked apart the evidence offered by the United States Anti-Doping Agency yesterday, offering a preview of the messy battle ahead.

title: U.S. Signs Agreement to Protect Wreck of the Titanic
description: The United States signed an agreement yesterday to protect the Titanic from admirers and would-be scavengers whose dives more than two miles into the icy abyss of the North Atlantic are damaging the increasingly fragile remains of the world's most famous shipwreck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SENDAR, CAROL ELAINE
description: SENDAR--Carol Elaine. 64, June 18, 2004. Senior attorney New York State Attorney General's Office. Graduate of Vassar College and NYU Law School. Beloved daughter of Sylvia Sendar and brother of Michael Sendar. Caring aunt to Shawn and Jake Sendar. Cherished friend to many for her wise counsel and kindness. Interment at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, Sunday, June 20, 1 pm. Please make contributions to the American Ballet Theatre.

title: I'm Single, I'm Responsible and, Yes, I Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day yesterday about an executive who was promoted to worldwide chief executive of the Tribal DDB Worldwide agency misstated his surname. He is Matt Freeman, not Foreman.

title: Police in Turkey Arrest 4 Suspected of Ties to Suicide Attackers
description: The Turkish counterterrorism police said Friday that they had arrested four men suspected of being members of the militant Ansar al-Islam group who had planned and trained for suicide car attacks in Turkey.

title: Tyco's Former General Counsel Urges Trial Judge to Dismiss Case
description: Mark A. Belnick, a former general counsel of Tyco International, asked a New York judge yesterday to dismiss the criminal charges against him, including a claim he stole a $17 million bonus from the company.

title: Show Us the Proof
description: When the commission studying the 9/11 terrorist attacks refuted the Bush administration's claims of a connection between Saddam Hussein and Osama bin Laden, we suggested that President Bush apologize for using these claims to help win Americans' support for the invasion of Iraq. We did not really expect that to happen. But we were surprised by the depth and ferocity of the administration's capacity for denial. President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney have not only brushed aside the panel's findings and questioned its expertise, but they are also trying to rewrite history.

title: Chief White House Lawyer Gives Testimony in Leak Case

description: Alcoa Inc., the world's biggest aluminum maker, said it would move ahead with a $1.16 billion plan to expand its aluminum operations in Brazil after signing a 20-year power agreement with a regional power producer, Eletronorte. The investment includes $680 million to more than double alumina-refining capacity and $130 million to increase its smelting capacity by about a third at the Alumar plant in So Lus, Brazil, a joint venture with BHP Billiton. Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, said it was also considering investing $350 million to develop a bauxite reserve. Alcoa owns 54 percent of the Alumar smelter on Brazil's northern coast and 35 percent of the plant's alumina-refining capacity. Alcoa shelved its Brazilian expansion plans in January, saying that the country's new electricity authority could hinder investment returns.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS WILL HIRE 210 FOR MARINE CORPS PROJECT
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said it would hire 210 workers at a plant in Lima, Ohio, to produce a new amphibious vehicle for the United States Marine Corps. The United States will invest $88 million to expand the plant, which is owned by the government but run by General Dynamics, to make the Expeditionary Fighting Vehicle, the company said. General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., began developing the vehicles in June 1996 under a $200 million award. In July 2001 it got a $712 million contract to make and test nine prototypes. The program calls for the delivery of more than 1,000 vehicles, with production beginning in 2005 and continuing into 2018, the company said.

BellSouth notified the Communications Workers of America on Tuesday that it would eliminate the jobs, a BellSouth spokesman, Jeff Battcher, said. The union represents 45,000 of the company's 65,000 employees. That brings job cuts to 2,201 this year and almost 17,000 since 2000. Most of the cuts, 217, are in Atlanta in the wholesale unit, Battcher said. The rest are technical and clerical positions in the company's nine-state region, he said. BellSouth is based in Atlanta.

title: JONES GETS MAXWELL WITH FINAL $346 MILLION BID
description: The Jones Apparel Group, maker of Anne Klein clothing and Nine West shoes, agreed to acquire the Maxwell Shoe Company for $346 million to expand its footwear business. Jones will pay $23.25 a share for Maxwell, ending a takeover battle that began in February. Maxwell's board approved the agreement and recommended its shareholders tender their shares, the companies said. Jones's first offer of $20 a share was raised to $22.50 last month, and the company increased it again this week. The purchase allows Jones to broaden its line of women's footwear, including Easy Spirit and Bandolino, and combine Maxwell's Anne Klein shoes with its clothing businesses. Maxwell, based in Readville, Mass., makes the Anne Klein line of shoes under a license from Jones. Jones is based in Bristol, Pa.

title: New & Noteworthy

In a departure from many of his earlier novels -- it's shorter, for one thing, and not as violent -- Stone tells the tale of an unhappily married Midwestern professor and his dangerous affair with a divorce whose soul may have been stolen by her recently deceased brother in a voodoo rite. The lovers wind up on a politically unstable Caribbean island, where they try to recover family valuables and secure the return of her soul in a trance ritual. Last year our reviewer, Norman Rush, said this ''unnerving'' book illuminates ''subtle propositions about the human predicament and those extreme paths that purport to lead the seeker up and out of it.''
