description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Gazetteer
description: POPULATION: 7,050 (2004 est.)

title: Cole Porter's Two Biopics? They're Night and Day
description: IN ''Night and Day,'' the so-bad-it's-almost-good 1946 biopic starring Cary Grant as Cole Porter, one of Porter's most poetic, haunting songs is sung early in the movie by a group of cherubic Christmas carolers standing in the snow outside his family's Indiana home.

title: Sabotaged Pipeline Is Engineers' Nightmare
description: The gash in a critical pipeline that saboteurs struck four days ago remained submerged in a vast lake of crude oil on Saturday, defying attempts at repairs that would get the oil moving again to tankers in the Persian Gulf.

title: Jackson In No Rush To Coach
description: Throughout his coaching run of nine N.B.A. titles, Phil Jackson has broken the Knicks' hearts in head-to-head competition and reached a stratosphere they could only dream of. But what he never left behind was his affection for the place he spent 11 seasons as a player, where he learned coaching lessons at the foot of Red Holzman that he never forgot.

title: More Air Travelers, And Fewer Screeners
description: PASSENGER traffic is up substantially at many airports compared with last year, but the Transportation Security Administration is entering the peak summer travel period with only about 45,000 screeners, down from 55,000 in 2003. Government officials say they can keep the waiting lines down to reasonable lengths because they have made minor refinements to their hardware and procedures, but airport executives are worried.

title: Jennifer Curley, Paul Reichert
description: Jennifer Wells Curley and Paul Rudolph Reichert were married yesterday in Alexandria Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Helen M. Beck officiated at the United Methodist Church of Alexandria Bay, with Msgr. John C. Weimer taking part.

title: What O. J. Passed To the Gipper
description: NOT a single jelly bean remained unturned in the weeklong interment of Ronald Reagan, but a week later there's one question that still hasn't been laid to rest: what in heaven's name was going on?

title: When Brooklyn Gets the Shakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Reports on Attacks Are Gripping, Not Dry
description: In contrast to the plodding or self-promoting style of so many government documents, the staff reports of the commission investigating the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks have provided something truly rare in official Washington: a good read.

title: The World; What's a Life Worth?
description: LAST week, the federal government announced that it had wrapped up its work on the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund. It granted a total of approximately $6 billion to almost 3,000 victims' families.

title: Discouraging Young Drinkers
description: KATHY NIEBUHR, a Greenwich substance-abuse counselor, has heard all the stories. One seventh grade boy told her how he regularly climbed out of a window at night with a bottle of liquor and would drive his mother's car to his girlfriend's house, where he would sneak in to have sex. Then he would drive back home, his family none the wiser.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINSTRAL, GLADYS
description: WINSTRAL--Gladys on June 17th, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Bud. Loving mother of Donna (Mel) Engelson and Bruce (Judi). Cherished grandmother of Casey and Rich, Halley and Adam, Niko and Josh. Great-grandmother of Andie and Maggie.

title: Sidestepping the City Angst and Finding a New Life
description: AFTER months on the open-house circuit, hemmed in by rival home-hunters brandishing their checkbooks like weapons, Pam Zuckerman had had enough. ''It takes more time to buy a pair of shoes than to make an offer on a half-million-dollar apartment,'' she said.

title: When Chiefs Decline To Serve on Other Boards
description: AS corporate boards come under greater scrutiny, many chief executives are accepting fewer positions as directors of other companies. Tom Neff, chairman of executive recruiting operations in the United States for SpencerStuart, says he thinks that the shift will result in less-informed decision-making, which may hurt shareholders. Following are excerpts from a conversation with him:

title: The Modern's Dirty Laundry
description: IS it spring cleaning at the Museum of Modern Art in Queens, or what? The curators are heading back to Manhattan. And on their way out it seems they decided to sweep the clothes from their closets and the objects from their desks and put them on display in two small summer shows.

title: A Transition Under Fire in Iraq
description: One Bush administration forecast about Iraq is clearly coming true. As the days count down to next week's transfer of limited powers to an interim Iraqi government, things are getting worse. Attacks against Iraqis working with the American occupation authorities seem increasingly frequent and audacious. Last Thursday, Iraq's deadliest car bombing in months killed at least 35 people waiting to sign up for the new national army and injured more than 100 others.

title: Trial by Fire
description: UNTIL recently, perhaps the most public managerial challenge facing James M. Davy, a veteran public administrator and one of Governor McGreevey's most trusted advisers, came not in the realm of government or politics, but in an area that is often just as contentious: Little League baseball.

title: Tales From the North By Nine Inuit Women
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago in Vancouver, I visited the Anthropology Museum at the University of British Columbia, home to one of the best collections of American Indian art and artifacts anywhere. Looking at the displays devoted to the Inuit, mostly stone carvings of arctic animals, moccasins, amulets and hunting equipment, I was struck by their modesty and simplicity. Artistry didn't mean much to them, it seemed.

title: Rita Glavin, Matthew Amatruda
description: Rita Marie Glavin and Matthew Steven Amatruda, both prosecutors, were married yesterday at St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Waterford, N.Y. The Rev. John J. Byrnes performed the ceremony.

title: BackTalk; A New World Order in Elite Sports
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Governors Island Reopening
description: In a city as densely packed as New York, the idea of 172 acres of new open space sounds like something from another dimension or the Twilight Zone. But then there is Governors Island. Long used as a military post and shut off from everyday New Yorkers for more than 200 years, the 172-acre island at the mouth of the East River is coming out of mothballs, bringing with it some of the rarest and most spectacular views of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLITZER, JOHN R.
description: BLITZER--John R. 78, died at home on Thursday, June 3. Dr. Blitzer graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1948, and trained in adult psychiatry at the Payne Whitney Clinic of New York Hospital, the teaching hospital of Cornell Medical School. He is survived by his four children and his wife of 56 years, Amy Hughes Blitzer. A memorial service will be held at the Meeting House in Bradford, NH, on August 15, at 11 AM.

title: Political Points
description: Clinton's Place As a Role Model

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HERE KITTY KITTY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, MARVIN
description: FREED -- Marvin. Beloved husband of Rita, devoted father of Foster and Sherry, and Roger and Shawn. Cherished grandfather of Tricia, Jason, Rachel, Jordan, Kristen, Bethany, and Dylan. Decorated WW II vet, retired foreign currency trader for over 50 years and known as Papa Marvin to many children at ST/PCV. Funeral services were held on June 11th, 2004. A memorial service will be held at Temple Beth Emeth, Church Avenue and Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, Sunday, June 27 at 10:30 A.M.

title: Murdochs Share (Some) Power
description: When he appointed one of his sons as chief executive of British Sky Broadcasting last fall -- and offered the departing chief, Tony Ball, a 10 million (about $18.3 million) ''noncompete fee'' -- Rupert Murdoch touched off a revolt by the company's other shareholders. (His News Corporation owns 35 percent.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SMITH, PHILIP
description: SMITH--Philip. We love you and we miss you. Michael and Jeffrey

title: Why Did They Die in Cosmetic Surgery?
description: ON Feb. 16, Susan Malitz, a 56-year-old Connecticut woman, was admitted to Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital for what was to be a routine face-lift.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DOEMLING, MARY JANE HORAN
description: DOEMLING--Mary Jane Horan. Died June 24, 2002. You will always be loved and never forgotten. Your Son, William Horan Doemling

title: Coast to Coast
description: Funky street wear has landed at a store called LF in Southampton, N.Y., a beach town more used to the country club look. Named for its owner, Laurie Furst, a California clothing manufacturer, this LF is one of nine that Mr. Furst has opened along the East and West Coasts in the last three months. The stock includes one-of-a-kind items, imported from Los Angeles, London and elsewhere, which would be perfect for both Goldie and Kate. Piled high on shelves, tables and chairs are frayed denim skirts decorated with vintage men's silk ties (left, $160); cotton tanks studded with Swarovski rhinestones ($180 to $220); jeans embroidered with a dragon ($232); and tie-dyed linen tunics ($108) with matching cropped, drawstring-waist pants ($96). LF is at 87 Main Street, (631) 287-5081. ELIZABETH HAYT

title: Strangers in a Bar
description: SMALL G

title: The Fine Art of Car Bombings
description: WALID RAAD was 15 in 1983 when his family shipped him out of Beirut to Boston, just ahead of the militias that were targeting teenage men for enlistment during one of the most violent periods of the Lebanese wars. Now, in his art, he explores the inner life of hostages, the aftereffects of car bombings and the disconnect between official promises and how secure people feel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMINI, FARIBORZ
description: AMINI--Fariborz. Surrounded by his loving family, Dr. Fariborz Amini passed away peacefully on Sunday, June 13th, at the age of 73. Born in Iran, Fariborz Amini graduated from medical school at UCSF and served on the faculty there for 37 years. As a psychoanalyst, a child psychiatrist, an expert in affect and attachment, and a co-author of ''A General Theory of Love,'' Fari Amini deeply touched countless people with his extraordinary insight and authenticity. His indomitable spirit lives on in his beloved wife Elizabeth, his six daughters, and his grandchildren. A memorial will be held for him at The Branson School in Ross, CA, on June 27th at 10:30 AM. The Amini Foundation for the Study of Affect will continue to support his life's work.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Give 'Em the Old One-Two: Motivation and Hard Work
description: Most days the boxing studio at the Equinox Fitness Club in Chelsea is a swirl of spandex and sweat as New Yorkers grunt, jab and hop around like kangaroos. But on a recent afternoon, hands were folded in laps and the only weigh-ins came in the form of opinions from the nine high school students who were there to learn about careers in the fitness industry.

title: G.O.P. Offensive Slightly Weakens Views of Kerry
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 — When John Kerry effectively nailed down the Democratic presidential nomination on March 2, the White House was waiting. With relentless precision, it began a 90-day campaign to weaken Mr. Kerry's candidacy, a blast that included record spending on television advertisements and attacks on Mr. Kerry's credentials and ideology led by President Bush himself.

title: TREKKING IN A LAND OF VERTICAL VILLAGES
description: RISING abruptly from the sub-Saharan savanna, the sheer Falaise de Bandiagara stretches for nearly 100 miles through the West African nation of Mali. Over 1,000 feet tall, this dramatic Unesco World Heritage Site is the homeland of the Dogon people, who are renowned for their artwork and unique cosmology, and who live in adobe hamlets atop, beneath and terraced against the buff sandstone walls riddled with ancient cliff dwellings.

title: A Closer Look Under Many Hoods
description: FOR about six hours earlier this month, East Haddam was a car lover's paradise. Owners of exotic sports cars, including Lamborginis, Ferraris and Dodge Vipers, had been invited by Consumers Union, the publishers of Consumer Reports, to spend a day at its car testing center.

title: Gumbel and Nantz to Swap Roles
description: CBS Sports will announce tomorrow that Greg Gumbel will no longer call National Football League games with Phil Simms and will replace Jim Nantz as the host of ''NFL Today,'' an industry executive said last night. Nantz, in turn, will replace Gumbel as the network's No. 1 play-by-play announcer.

title: A Grande Dame With a Lively Past
description: BABE RUTH and Arturo Toscanini called it home. Plato's Retreat and the Continental Baths, where a young Bette Midler sang, moved in decades later. But the Ansonia, the Beaux-Arts wedding cake of an apartment hotel at Broadway and 73rd Street, eventually became as notable for its contentiousness as for its celebrities. In just one of the Ansonia's lively chapters, the building was threatened with demolition in the 1970's; only after considerable efforts by residents was it saved.

title: Q&A
description: Co-op Board's Financial Information

title: In Awe of Alaska
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading ''The Panorama of Denali,'' by Eric Asimov (Family Vacations, June 6). It revived fond memories of my vacation in Alaska five years ago. The vast area and incredible beauty are difficult to appreciate without being there.

title: For the Price of a Dam, Saving the Lakes
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, 94-year-old Charles Yust was sitting beneath a willow tree on the banks of Sunset Lake here, baiting fishhooks and casting lines with four of his great-grandchildren. Waiting for a nibble, he counseled patience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKER, JOYCE E. (NEE STERN)
description: BECKER--Joyce E. (nee Stern). On June 17th, 2004. Devoted mother, grandmother and attorney. Survived by husband Jacob, daughters Robin, Patrice and Debra, sons-in-law David Harris and Jonathan Berger and five loving grandchildren. Interment Friday, June 18th, 2004 will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Chabad of Northwestern Bergen County, P.O. Box 63, Franklin Lakes NJ 07417

title: UGANDA'S ANIMAL KINGDOM
description: MY wife, Jen, and I both work in environmental conservation, and we have been living in western Uganda for over a year now. On short forays we have explored many of the region's national parks. The country continually amazes us with its extraordinary diversity of rare flora and fauna and of landscapes: rain forest, classic African savannas and snow-capped mountains. Six of Uganda's 10 national parks are found in the western region. These protected areas vary in size and in the wildlife-viewing possibilities they offer, but nearly all of Uganda's most charismatic species, from lions to mountain gorillas, can be found here.

title: For Truth in Drug Trial Reporting
description: Pharmaceutical companies would no longer be able to hide the results of clinical trials that reflect badly on their products under a long overdue reform that gained momentum last week. The nation's largest doctors' group, some prominent medical editors and a leading drug company all threw their weight behind proposals to create a public database that would include the results of all drug trials -- not just the ones the manufacturers wanted to brag about.

title: SQUARE FEET/Midtown; A Notable 60's Hotel Is Getting an Upgrade
description: THE new owners of the Metropolitan Hotel at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street are changing plenty: the lobby, the bar, a restaurant, all 755 guest rooms and even the name.

title: The Money Issue
description: You refer to the former Enron executive Sherron Watkins as a whistle-blower when she is, in fact, nothing of the sort. Watkins never took her concerns about Enron's accounting irregularities to federal regulators or to the press. The memorandum she wrote was uncovered by Congressional investigators -- not because Watkins brought it to their attention herself. In fact, reading the text of Watkins's letter to Kenneth Lay, I got the impression that it is more than anything else a warning to him that the company might get caught. And for this, Watkins was -- absurdly -- named one of Time magazine's ''Persons of the Year.''

title: Springsteen's Brilliant Disguise
description: ON his dyspeptic 1983 album, ''Trouble in Paradise,'' Randy Newman recorded a song in which Bruce Springsteen confesses that he is tired of being ''the Boss.'' So he asks Mr. Newman, that sardonic singer-songwriter, if he would briefly fill in as America's most beloved working-class hero. This is one of the few instances in pop-cultural history where anyone dared to poke fun at the sanctified Mr. Springsteen, where anyone had the nerve to take the mickey out of the Boss and his studiously manicured image as the poet of the proles.

title: Taking Aim at Terror
description: THE nameplate on Joseph Billy Jr.'s desk may be the most unusual of its kind -- for a high-ranking agent in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at least. It gives Mr. Billy's name in English and in Arabic.

title: Used Autos: Depreciation Included
description: IN 1988, a journalist asked Roger B. Smith, the chairman of General Motors, what his company offered to compete with Chrysler's inexpensive K-cars. Mr. Smith, who would soon become best known as the elusive subject of Michael Moore's documentary ''Roger and Me,'' responded that G.M. indeed offered comparable value, directing potential customers to ''a two-year-old Buick.''

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Christopher Miller, Christopher Rivers
description: Christopher Lind Miller and Christopher Whalen Rivers were married at their home in Granby, Mass., on Friday. Richard M. Evans, a justice of the peace in Northampton, Mass., officiated.

title: Doctor's Testimony Leads To a Complex Legal Fight
description: Dr. John Fullerton, a San Francisco internist and an occasional expert witness in medical malpractice suits, opened a letter from the Florida Medical Association not long ago. He thought it was a membership solicitation.

title: Page Two: June 13-19; Striking and Striking Back
description: MAYBE Paul M. Johnson Jr., the New Jersey engineer for Lockheed Martin who was kidnapped a week ago by Al Qaeda militants in Saudi Arabia, never had a chance. His captors vowed to kill him if Saudi officials did not release hundreds of their jailed comrades. But the Saudis, sensitive to international demands to crack down on terrorism and loath to encourage more kidnappings by showing any willingness to negotiate, refused.

title: Prom Night, Safe and Sober
description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word/Slave Journals; 'I Shall Never Forget the Weeping'
description: IN the summer of 2002, an elderly woman named Gladys Watt walked into the Historical Society in Greenwich, Conn., with a weathered leather-bound notebook. The notebook had belonged to her neighbor, Lydia Turnage Connolly, who died in 1984 at the age of 99. When Mrs. Connolly moved into a nursing home in the early 1980's, she asked her friend to keep her things.

title: Skeletons of Sweetness And India-Ink Mutants
description: THE benefits of placing art museums in regional towns are well known. In just five years, for example, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art has helped revive North Adams, Mass., once an economically depressed mill town. And that's a model the new Shore Institute of the Contemporary Arts here looks to.

title: Todd Bishop, Gregory Weithman
description: Todd Maurice Bishop and Gregory James Weithman affirmed their partnership yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan. The Rev. William McD. Tully, an Episcopal priest, led the commitment ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 6 about the photographer Wang Qingsong misidentified the artist whose representation of Adam and Eve is recreated in Mr. Wang's large-scale work ''Romantique.'' It is Masaccio, not Michelangelo.

title: St. Joseph's Seminary Given Shorter-Term Accreditation
description: St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers, the 108-year-old training ground for priests of the Archdiocese of New York, has effectively been put on probation, receiving accreditation for 5 years instead of the usual 10.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE GOOD LIFE

title: The Unlikely Return Of the Superfreak
description: JADAKISS -- This almost famous Yonkers rapper has a gravelly smooth voice, an impossibly elegant flow and a mile-wide mean streak -- when he's not pondering his own death, he's probably planning yours. On the ferocious ''40 Bars of Terror,'' from his great new mixtape, ''The Champ Is Here'' (www.djgreenlantern.com), he explains how he updated his arsenal: ''I stepped my game up from a potato to a laser/ So you gon' need surgery even if it graze ya.'' Jadakiss also has a new album, ''Kiss of Death'' (Ruff Ryders/Interscope), which shows off his strengths as well as his greatest weakness: he's a poor songwriter, often interrupting his dazzling verses with dreary three-note choruses. Still, ''Hot Sauce to Go'' has a terrific sloppy-funky Neptunes beat, and on ''Why,'' Jadakiss answers a nagging question: ''You know why they made the new twenties? 'Cause I got all the old ones.''

title: Suffolk and Brookhaven To Acquire 330 Acres
description: In what would be the largest land purchase by Suffolk County in more than 10 years, the county and the Town of Brookhaven have signed an agreement to acquire 330 acres of pine barrens in Yaphank.

title: After Century in a Log Cabin, Emma Buck Dies at 100 or 101
description: Emma Buck, who ran a pre-Civil War family farm in Illinois that remained virtually unchanged into the 21st century, died on June 5 on the sleigh bed with handmade ticking she had slept in for 98 years, in the log cabin built by her great-uncle, a German immigrant, in 1849.

title: A Flowering of Art in Madrid
description: AS it stood, the Thyssen had no room to display more than 200 paintings, from Bruegel to Braque. The Prado could not organize blockbuster exhibitions without crowding into its permanent array of Spanish old masters. And unless it added some architectural flair to its sturdy 18th-century headquarters, the Reina Sofa could hardly compete with Europe's chic centers of modern art.

title: Bobb Schaeffer, 90, Curator and Fish Expert
description: Bobb Schaeffer, a curator and expert on fossil fish at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, died on June 2 at St. John's Home in Rochester. He was 90.

title: The Apprentice
description: THE SARI SHOP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREDERICKS, MARC
description: FREDERICKS--Marc. Composer. Loving husband of Theresa, father of Marc. Beloved brother of Don and Loretta Edmonds. Viewing Tuesday, June 22, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00PM at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., NYC. Mass at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 W. 71 St., 11:00 AM Wednesday, June 23.

title: The Rosenbergs; 'The Terminal'; 'Ch-Check It Out'; Ground Zero
description: THE ROSENBERGS

title: At 100, an Orchestra Looks Back, Briefly
description: AT a time when orchestras are supposed to be in a state of decay, the London Symphony is thriving.

title: 9/11 Panel Chiefs Reiterate Position on Qaeda-Iraq Ties
description: The leaders of the Sept. 11 commission reiterated today that they did not see any evidence of a collaborative relationship between Al Qaeda and Iraq's Saddam Hussein, and that this position did not differ from the view of the Bush administration.

title: Corrections
description: A group of quotations last Sunday from 12 people who spoke about Times Square as it observed its 100th anniversary omitted the name of the interviewer. She was Kate Jacobs.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: NOVELTIES & SOUVENIRS

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Juliette Lewis; Rock 'n' Acupuncture
description: ONE Tuesday night at the Kitchen, a homey restaurant in Silverlake, Juliette Lewis was defining her rock dream. ''We're trying to bring debauchery back into rock 'n' roll,'' she announced. She took a sip of herbal tea. ''I mean, raw power: not doing drugs but putting all your energy into your music. It's kind of a radical concept. It might be lame if we didn't rock so hard.''

title: The World; The Iraq-Qaeda Link: A Short History
description: FOR nearly three years, murky speculation, innuendo and inaccurate information have kept a connection between Saddam Hussein and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 alive in the American mind. Even as late as April, as the 9/11 Commission marched toward its ultimate conclusion, announced last Thursday, that no such connection could be found, 40 percent of the American population still believed in the link such a link.

title: The Money Issue
description: I submit that Bill Joy has his Greek mythology wrong (''Proceed With Caution,'' by Jon Gertner). Oedipus was destroyed not by truth but by ignorance. If only he had known who they were, he never would have killed his father and married his mother.

title: The Class System
description: In recent years, N.B.A. draft prospects have been categorized by more than size and position. Three classes have emerged -- the college player, the high school player and the international player. Here are some of the more intriguing members of each group. By CHRIS BROUSSARD

title: The Passion of Henry James
description: THE MASTER

title: A Quiet Fade-Out For the Light-Bulb Man
description: Watching David Gelb, 95, navigate precarious stacks of fluorescent tubing to locate and then gingerly handle the perfect bulb is a sublime experience. It is his combination of fragility and dexterity that makes it seem so.

title: Of, by and for the Fancy People
description: KALLIOPE KARELLA, like most first-time authors, celebrated her matriculation into the literary ranks with a book party. But unlike the parties of most first-time authors, hers was in a 24-room apartment last month at 740 Park Avenue, the home of her friends Stephen and Christine Schwarzman, with more than 100 of New York City's social thoroughbreds on hand. Her second book party was on Tuesday at the Chanel store on Madison Avenue, where the Greek consul general mingled with couture-clad models. A third book party will take place later this month in Athens. In ensuing months come the ones in Millbrook, N.Y., and Paris.

title: Their Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle of Farmer vs. Suburbanites Leads to a Big Stink
description: THE struggle between suburbanites who want to retain their bucolic views and developers who want to put houses on farmland is playing out here in a rather surprising, and smelly, way.

title: Condominium With a Private Club To Be Built in Chelsea
description: Most residents stepping through the lobby of the Chelsea Club condominium building on West 19th Street, with its serpentine columns wrapped in stainless steel, will be whisked right into their apartments by leather-paneled elevators, each with its own flat-screen television -- never a dull moment allowed.

title: European Disunion on the Pitch
description: Nothing like a little sport to provide the European Union with a reality check. As European leaders gathered in Brussels over the last few days to negotiate a proposed constitution for their ever-closer union, hundreds of thousands of soccer fans from all over the continent descended on Portugal for the 2004 European Championships, to wave their national flags and jeer at their fellow Europeans. Or, in the case of several hundred English hooligans on the coast, to beat up their fellow Europeans.

title: A Notorious Manhattan Address Changes Hands Once Again
description: THE Upper East Side town house once owned by Irene Silverman, who was murdered nearly six years ago, was sold last week for $10 million to a group of investors who plan to renovate it and resell it as two luxury triplexes.

title: Page Two: June 13-19; NEW LIFE
description: When Israel's attorney general dropped a bribery investigation against Prime Minister Ariel Sharon on Tuesday, it lifted a cloud that had threatened his political career. The decision gives Mr. Sharon a boost as he pursues his plan to pull Israel out of the Gaza Strip and has cleared the way for negotiations on reshaping his shaky coalition government. Greg Myre

title: Funny Cide Places Second; Azeri Fades
description: The last time Offlee Wild met Funny Cide, he was a forgotten also-ran in the 2003 Kentucky Derby, finishing more than 11 lengths behind Funny Cide, who would go on to flirt with a sweep of the Triple Crown races.

title: The Money Issue
description: 'Wholier Than Thou Foods'' is unsurpassed at the art of camouflaging yuppie excess with moral superiority (''The Virtue in $6 Heirloom Tomatoes,'' by Jon Gertner). People should know that air-freighted raspberries in midwinter will not save the planet even if they are organic.

title: The Boxcar Children: A Museum Caper
description: RUTH FLAGG said she was a painfully shy first grader in a class of 43 students at the Israel Putnam School in 1938 when a special teacher took the time to draw her out of her shell.

title: No Use Crying Over Spilled Billions
description: WHEN he became chief executive and, a year later, chairman of Time Warner, Richard D. Parsons was dismissed as a politician who just happened to run the biggest media company in the world. His performance since then suggests that he has a few other skills, but it's the politician in him that has a gift for making an entrance.

title: The Art of Reading the Daily Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Lena Shulga, Dennis Kiely
description: Lena Vera Shulga, the daughter of Dr. Irene Shulga of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and the late Sergei Shulga, was married yesterday to Dennis Daniel Kiely, a son of Ellen and Daniel T. Kiely of Pearl River, N.Y. Judge John E. Sprizzo of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, for whom the bride is a law clerk, officiated at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: A Westchester Opinion Page
description: The page you are reading now is a corrective, a fresh start, a new answer to an old riddle: how the editorial section of The Times can think globally and locally at the same time.

title: Climbing Above It All (in a Private Jet, of Course)
description: NOW for a few words about the temptations that make corporate chieftains go bad.

title: For Freshness and Style, Twin Cafes
description: IT may be that Jonathan Pratt, executive chef and co-owner of Peter Pratt's Inn in Yorktown, mami Caf in Croton-on-Hudson and the latest, a second mami Caf in Fishkill, is starting an empire. With the help of his partner, Craig Purdy, the newest venture is almost a clone of the original cafe, and it promises to be as successful.

title: The Golden Age of Self-Help
description: The very qualities that make self-help one of publishing's most despised genres -- its formulaic simplicity, its reduction of human beings to cartoonish types, its unrelenting optimism -- also make it popular with people who rarely read any other kind of book. Each new volume of advice promises life-changing lessons; each delivers more or less the same fistful of homilies. Perhaps the familiarity provides comfort, for to judge by recent titles, self-help's readers -- guilt-stricken, fear-plagued, stupid-choice-making as they are -- can barely stagger through a day without the assistance of trained professionals.

title: Putting the Comebacks in Perspective
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FOR WOMEN, AMONG OTHERS
description: It bills itself as the No.1 place in cyberspace for women and girls, but iVillage Inc., an Internet media company, is more inclusive in its corporate suite. It named a man, Steven A. Elkes, as its chief financial officer last week.

title: All's Fair
description: Q: Senator Lott, many people associate you not only with conservative politics but also with your curious hair. It never moves, even in the wind. Is it real?

title: Carroll Gardens Journal; A Tree Dies in Brooklyn (Alas, It's a Fig)
description: Peter Scotti's earliest memories of Brooklyn are all about figs. ''Every house on the block had a fig tree in the back, and a statue of the Virgin Mary or a saint in front,'' he said.

title: Carolyn Wu, Joshua Kurtzig
description: Carolyn Tessie Wu, the daughter of Tessie and Oscar Wu of Walnut Creek, Calif., was married last evening to Joshua Aaron Kurtzig, the son of Barbara and Michael Kurtzig of Elkins Park, Pa. Cantor Roslyn Barak officiated at Temple Emanu-El in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLIOTT, DOLORES DENGEL
description: ELLIOTT--Dolores Dengel, age 70, of Copake, NY, died peacefully at home June 12, 2004. Born in New York City, the daughter of Harry J. and Althea (Meeker) Dengel, Mrs. Elliott was a resident of White Plains, NY from 1937 to 1993. She received a B.S. in business administration from Good Counsel College in 1956 and was a medical transcriptionist in the Pathology Department of St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains from 1970 to 1986. Dolly owned and showed Pekingese and many other breeds of dogs, some of which were also used in advertising with various celebrities including Johnny Carson and Richard Avedon. Mrs. Elliott is survived by her husband of 48 years, Roger Palmer Elliott, and her daughter, Dr. Holly Elizabeth Elliott of Kerhonkson, NY. Her son, Roger Palmer Elliott, Jr., died in 1981. Arrangements are private. In lieu of flowers, friends may send memorial donations to Columbia Greene Humane Society, 125 Humane Society Rd., Hudson, New York 12534.

title: EX-AIDE ACCUSED OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission last week accused Governor McGreevey's former chief of staff, Gary B. Taffet, of insider trading, charging that he had used confidential information to make more than $247,000 in profit. Investigators said Mr. Taffet received tips from a friend who had obtained inside information from a secretary at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. That friend, Ronald A. Manzo, pleaded guilty to insider trading, federal prosecutors in Manhattan announced on Wednesday. Mr. Taffet, who was cited only for civil violations in stock trades, will most likely face a fine. David Kocieniewski

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUKLIN, ANTHONY BENNETT
description: KUKLIN--Anthony Bennett. An attorney and retired partner with Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton and Garrison, died on Monday, June 14, 2004 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. The cause was a heart attack. He was 74 and lived in Larchmont, NY. A former president of the American College of Real Estate Lawyers and a Division director of the American Bar Association Section of Real Property, Probate and Trust Law, he was a past Chairman of the Real Property Division of the International Bar Association. He was a governor of the Anglo-American Real Property Institute and a former Chairman of the Real Property Law Section of the New York State Bar Association. He was also a former member of the board of directors for the Chicago Title Insurance companies. A graduate of Harvard University and Columbia Law School, in recent years he taught a course on Real Estate Transactions at the law school. He is survived by his beloved wife, Vivienne, daughters, Melissa and Amanda, son-inlaw John and grandchildren, Samantha and Michael. Funeral services will be held privately. Memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: The Words Of a Father, Wise and Flawed; A Broken Man Leaves His Legacy in Letters
description: This is a Father's Day story of imperfection and failure, of multiple divorces and personal demons. But it is also a Father's Day story of a broken yet stubbornly dutiful and devoted man. It is a tale pieced together with the scraps of letters that a loving father kept sending to his children over the years of discord and despair -- from distant locales, both physical and emotional.

title: Sun Deflectors
description: Straw and raw silk hats by Leza Piazza, below, are many things, but never boring. It takes ''a self-assured woman'' to wear them, Ms. Piazza said, adding that Lauren Hutton recently bought one that was ''sassy -- like a pirate hat.'' Her other hats have pointed crowns, helmet profiles or brims large enough to cast a shadow. Ms. Piazza's career as a milliner started 10 years ago, when she was smitten by an Yves Saint Laurent creation that was beyond her means. So she taught herself how to make her own. She sells her collection ($45 to $200) at a sidewalk stand on Spring Street, near Crosby Street (weather permitting) and has a showroom in Park Slope, Brooklyn, open by appointment; (718) 857-2842. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JAMIE LEE CURTIS has never been better than in Mark S. Waters's sassy remake of FREAKY FRIDAY (2003). ''Enough with the drama, Anna,'' Dr. Tess Coleman (Ms. Curtis) tells her teenage daughter (Lindsay Lohan). ''High school is not that hard.'' Well, Tess will soon find out, when a magic Chinese fortune-cookie spell causes mother and daughter to exchange bodies. How will Anna handle her mother's psychotherapy patients? Will she pull off a talk-show appearance publicizing her mother's new book, when she doesn't even know the meaning of one of the words (senescence) in the title? How will Tess do on an oral pop quiz on ''Hamlet''? Will she sabotage the budding relationship between her daughter and that cute boy Jake with the motorcycle? Jodie Foster and Barbara Harris were good in 1976, but this version is more delightfully complex -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUTCHER, CHARLES
description: BUTCHER -- Charles. Busi nessman and philanthropist known for his generosity and passion for knowledge and justice, died at his home on June 12, 2004 after a long illness. At the time of his death, he lived in Boulder, CO, and maintained a family home in Maine. Charles Butcher was born in 1916 in Cambridge, MA, and attended Harvard University, where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Mathematical Economics. He was a conscientious objector during World War II and, as a consequence, received what he called his ''postgraduate education'' in federal prison and work camps. He continued to live his values for the rest of his life. In 1951, after several years in the printing business, Charles Butcher joined the Butcher Company, a familyowned floor care products company in Massachusetts. He became CEO shortly thereafter. Over the next five decades, he developed the Butcher Company from a small regional firm into a large, successful, socially responsible company with international reach, 100 times its original size. A pioneer in thinking about socially responsible business practices, he was invited to lecture at business schools and consult with business leaders. When he sold the Butcher Company, then headquartered in Marlborough, MA, to Johnson Wax Professional in 2000, Charles Butcher and his wife, distributed $18 million of the sale proceeds to the company's 325 employees. He published a book, How to Succeed in Business by Giving Away Millions. A lifelong fascination with science led Charles Butcher, in 1965, to found the Lazy Eight, a network of scientists interested in cross - disciplinary ap proaches to technical problem-solving, education and issues of poverty. In 1973 he began working with Dr. Larry Gold in the lab of the Molecular Cellular and Developmental Biology Department of the University of Colorado. In 1986, he was chairman of the board of Clonetics, a biotech start-up that gained international recognition for its genetic research; in 1991 he joined the board of NeXagen, a biomedical company. With Dr. Gold, he designed the Discovery Exchange to promote cooperation between academic scientists and business. In addition to his direction of the Butcher Company, his work with high-tech and biotech startups, and his own scientific research, Charles Butcher spent decades as an active and creative philanthropist. He dedicated his giving to encouraging and promoting civil liberties, -big-picturescientific thinking and creative cross-disciplinary research. In 2002, in recognition of his longstanding, continuous support for civil liberties and his leadership as a board member, the American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado presented Charles Butcher its 50th Anniversary Champion of Liberty Award. Charles Butcher, with his wife, in 2002, contributed $1.1 million to the University of Colorado to fund the launch of the Colorado Initiative in Molecular Biotechnology, which is using a multidisciplinary approach to unlock genomics secrets to improve the quality of life and health for all people. An energetic entrepreneur, a master sailor, and a generous friend and mentor, Charles Butcher was the father of eight children. His wife, the former Jane Weinberg, is a founder of the Women of the West Museum, the Co-Chair of the University of Colorado Conference on World Affairs and Co-Chair of Mother Jones magazine. Charles Butcher is survived by his wife, Jane, his children Catherine Butcher and husband Ben Pfohl, Susan Butcher and husband David Monson, Kimiko Butcher and husband Neil Grundy, Benjamin Butcher, Claudine Butcher and husband Michael Hannigan, Gina Lasky and husband David Lasky, and Andrew Butcher and grandchildren Ethan Pfohl, Naomi Pfohl, Tekla Monson, Chisana Monson, Charles Grundy and Rachel Grundy. His son, Charles Evan Butcher, predeceased him. Donations in memory of Charles Butcher may be sent to the American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado, 400 Corona Street, Denver, CO 80218; the Colorado Initiative in Molecular Biotechnology, C/O the CU Foundation, 4740 Walnut Street, Boulder, CO 80306; Hospice Care of Boulder and Broomfield Counties, 2594 Trailridge Drive E., Ste A, Lafayette, CO 80026; or Hemlock Foundation, PO Box 101801, Denver, CO 80246. A private memorial service was held in Boulder June 19.

title: The Harlem Project
description: Back in 1990, Geoffrey Canada was just your average do-gooder. That year, he became the president of a nonprofit charitable organization based in Harlem called the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, and he set out trying to improve the world, one poor child at a time. It was a bad moment to be poor in New York City. Harlem, especially, was suffering under the simultaneous plagues of crack cocaine, cheap guns and rampant homelessness, and Canada's main goal at Rheedlen, in those years, was to keep the children in his programs alive. The organization had an annual budget of $3 million, which it spent on a predictable array of services in Upper Manhattan: after-school programs, truancy prevention, anti-violence training for teenagers. The programs seemed to do a lot of good for the children who were enrolled in them, at least in part because of Canada's own level of devotion. He was obsessed with his job, personally invested in the lives of the children he was helping and devastated when they ended up in prison or on drugs or shot dead on the street.

title: Reconstructing Henry
description: What remains fascinating for a novelist about Henry James -- that isn't as fascinating, say, in someone like Whitman -- is that James is not open. Everything about him is ambiguous. Everything he was, he was also the opposite. He loved his family, he longed for them; he longed to be away from them. He loved England, he dreaded England. He loved going out at night, he hated going out at night. He loved women, he loved men. He loved working, he dreaded working. And the matter of his sexuality remains so strange and hidden, open sometimes, back enclosed again. He's constantly glittering, appearing briefly, clearly, and then going back in again in almost every way, including the fact that some of his short stories are so bad, for example, so clunky, so crude. And then the novel written in the same year is so beautifully made and so subtle. So that he's wide open for a novelist to go into the interior and tease out all that dramatically.

With the continuing wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the army expects more than 1,000 soldiers to graduate in fiscal 2006, a fourfold increase over 2003. title: The Money Issue

title: Band on the Couch
description: There is a scene midway through the documentary ''Some Kind of Monster'' that defines the film's vision; it's arguably the movie's most emotional moment and certainly its most archetypal. We see the rock group Metallica -- commercially the biggest heavy-metal success in history -- sitting around a table with a therapist, trying to establish how the band will finish recording its next album. The process has already been complicated by the departure of the bassist and by the drinking problem of the lead singer, James Hetfield, who has just returned to the band after a lengthy stint in rehab. Fifteen years ago, Metallica drank so much that it was referred to by fans as Alcoholica, and the band members all thought that was hilarious. But now things are different. Now Hetfield can work only four hours a day, because the other 20 hours are devoted to mending a marriage that was shattered by alcohol (and the rock 'n' roll lifestyle that came with it). The rules have changed.

title: Political Landscapes
description: The campaign stump, by its very nature, is a scripted and tightly managed affair. The overall effect -- the strategically selected backdrop, the fixed camera position, the obligatory pressed flesh -- is one of a highly manipulated and well-behaved space. But what if you were to pull back and reframe the campaign stump to include what lies just beyond? Not only would you see the TV trucks and flag-bearing cranes and other paraphernalia of the P.R. machinery; you would also see the uninterested passer-by, the surrounding traffic jam, the beginnings of the unruly everyday life that extends outside the campaign. The British photographer Simon Norfolk, a regular contributor to the magazine and the winner this year of the International Center of Photography's photojournalism award, embarked on this assignment, using a special large-format camera to capture, from a unique perspective and distance, the 2004 presidential race (including public appearances by the president, which are not technically campaign events). The images that he produced reward a different way of viewing the campaign, one that does not expect the photograph to deliver the candidate as the center of attention. Indeed, a viewer might linger over Norfolk's work before being able to locate the candidate. In these pictures, the unessential detail is everything, be it the sharpshooter with his binoculars perched on the rooftop; or someone lazing in the grass; or a Secret Service contingent; or the Washington press corps; or people gathering on the steps of a nearby building; or, outside a fund-raiser in Bal Harbor, Fla., a lone beachgoer fishing in the night surf.

title: 'War, Evil, and the End of History'
description: Old Holden Roberto can't get over it. Tonight, in Luanda, he has seen, with his own eyes, a truck full of Cubans and Soviets pass by beneath the windows of his house. My obvious surprise, my exclamations, are of no use. In vain I explain to him that the Cubans left Angola ten years ago and that the rare few that stayed have become dentists on the Marginal. He insists. Almost gets angry. And now this former fighter for the war of independence, this party leader, who has become, with time, this little gentle-looking man, with the cautious and conciliatory manners, with impeccably coiffed white hair, launches into a strange speech in which his glorious past is mixed up with hallucinations of the present: a jumbled confusion of insurrection against the Portuguese; the war, almost immediately afterwards, against the Marxists of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), who are victorious and oust him from power; Sartre on Capri; Fanon, who was a friend of his; and then that dark story of the Cubans, his enemies from long ago, he is sure he sees them returning, on certain nights, like ghosts, to the city.

Axelrod, the fugitive philanthropist and violin collector who fled the country in April shortly after being charged with tax fraud, was arrested at a Berlin airport on Tuesday as he arrived from Switzerland. Mr. Axelrod, 76, was indicted on tax fraud charges in April and accused of using a Swiss bank account to conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars. But it was his sale last year of rare violins, violas and cellos to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra at a discount of tens of millions that drew the attention of Senate committees. The I.R.S. allowed Mr. Axelrod a substantial tax deduction for selling the instruments at a loss. Ronald Smothers

title: Nadia Singh, Dave Rao
description: Nadia Singh, a daughter of Dolly and Indar Singh of Farmingville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dave Bharat Rao, a son of Christine and Bharat Rao of Dix Hills, N.Y. George Browne, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at St. Anne's Church in Garden City, N.Y. On Friday, Pandit Ramu Sharma performed a Hindu ceremony at the Woodlands, a country club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: School Budgets Fare Better on Second Vote
description: A month after Long Island voters rejected a record number of school budgets, fueling fears that high taxes had soured residents on their local schools, more than 15 budgets passed on second votes. On Tuesday alone, 13 school districts in Nassau and Suffolk counties held second votes, and all but 2 budgets passed.

title: Dodging Bullets
description: OVER the last several years, a proposed professional sports arena the centerpiece of Mayor Sharpe James's vision of a redeveloped downtown Newark -- has taken more turns than a jockey at Monmouth and dodged more bullets than one of Tony Soprano's crew.

title: Player Shortage Overcome
description: It was an unexpected opportunity. Kenny Arena, a little-used MetroStars defender, had just scored the first goal of his professional career and was being hailed to stop for a nationwide television interview as he left the field for halftime.

title: Garden City Rezones Acres for Residential Use
description: The Village of Garden City has rezoned more than 25 acres in the heart of the village that is owned by Nassau County from its current public use to strictly residential use. After two years of study, the village trustees voted this month to rezone the property where the county's Department of Social Services building sits to allow single-family homes, attached town houses or a mix of the two styles of housing, with a 35-foot height limit. The county estimates that the zoning would allow up to 90 single-family homes or 150 town houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLADOWSKY, MARILYN J.
description: SLADOWSKY--Marilyn J. Of New York City. Adjunct Professor at Hunter College. Devoted sister and precious aunt. Funeral services at Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, N.J. Tuesday, 1PM. For additional information call 800-938-6372

title: The World: Prosecutors Still Rule; Verdict in Russian Courts: Guilty Until Proven Guilty
description: ON paper, Russia has a judicial system arguably as free and fair as those in Europe or the United States. Of course, the same was said about the Soviet Union. Even Stalin sought to give his paranoid purges the imprimatur of due process.

title: As More People Nest, It's Great to Be in Feathers
description: IN October 1999, Jeffrey Siegel, then a vice president of Lifetime Hoan, a housewares distributor in Westbury, offered a hyperbolic prediction. ''The goal,'' he told HomeWorldBusiness.com, a Web site covering the housewares industry, ''is to be the No.1 company in kitchen gadgets, kitchen tools, knives, bakeware and cutting boards.''

title: Technology Alters How Closing Hole Is Approached
description: Among the attractions of major championship golf is that its highest drama is often played on theater-like stages, the pivotal and climactic holes of familiar courses. The last time the United States Open was played at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, in 1995, the iconic moment came at the 18th hole, when Corey Pavin laced a 4-wood 228 yards uphill to within 5 feet of the hole, assuring himself a par and his first major championship.

title: Even Midas Needs a Billboard
description: WHAT is a name worth? If it belongs to a certain real estate mogul and is attached to a 35-story condominium tower rising in this city's downtown, then the answer, at least according to Donald Trump, is, ''It's worth plenty!''

Lewis, who acquired the food conglomerate TLC Beatrice International in a leveraged buyout in the late 1980's, creating the nation's largest African-American business. Mr. Lewis died of a cerebral hemorrhage in 1993; he was 50.

title: Ideas & Trends; Suddenly, It's Hip To Conserve Energy
description: GAS prices finally headed down last week, and may have peaked for the year, the Energy Department reported. This is good news for drivers and businesses. But the pattern over the last 30 years suggests that this is bad news for anyone who believes that Americans, the world's biggest oil consumers, can ever curb their energy consumption.

Not just stripes, but windowpane plaids and traditional contrasting collar and cuffs were also to be seen. Cuffs in coordinated colors, left, were a new twist. While not exactly a buttoned-down look, it certainly was a change from graffiti-covered oversize T-shirts.

title: The Lady of the Lake, Long Island Style

To some people, though, the lake also suggests something mysterious. For years, it has been the source of ominous local legends, as a new photo exhibition, ''The Lake, the Legend, the Film,'' at Sachem Public Library here makes clear.

Zoe Carrington Thorne (Toni to her friends) was born in New York City on July 29, 1919, to John Norrish Thorne and Zoe Hannah Thorne. She attended Bennington College. Zoe and Benjamin Stilwell Holderness, an Army Air Corps pilot, were married in San Antonio, Texas, on March 7, 1942. The Holdernesses had four children, John, David, Timothy, and Mary, who all settled in the Northwest, and six grandchildren. A memorial service and reception will be held for Zoe Holderness at 2:00 o'clock on Saturday, June 26th, at St. Matthew's Church, in Bedford Village, NY.

Richardson & Son Funeral Home, 106 West St., Leominster.

description: PARIS, June 20  The Algerian army has killed the leader of North Africa's largest and most dangerous Islamic terrorist organization in a gun battle east of Algiers, according to the country's official news agency, dealing a serious blow to Al Qaeda's affiliates in the region.

The proposed program is meant to help to slow the transmission of H.I.V. and hepatitis C among intravenous drug users. The mayor, who backs the program, has 20 days to sign the ordinance. Jessica Bruder

The block's north end is anchored by a clutter of tattoo parlors and pornography stores, cramped together under blaring neon signs; a shuttered movie theater sits at its midpoint; another pornography shop perches at the block's southern edge.

This year, they are learning something that probably isn't taught in classrooms at Wharton or Indiana: that incentives used to lure their older siblings or friends just a few months ago may no longer be available, and that they probably will have to pay more than their friends who have already settled in.

Last year, Hillary Rodham Clinton's ''Living History'' became the best-selling political memoir in United States history (1.7 million copies sold). title: How Survivors Survive
description: Self-destructive people often come equipped with intoxicating charisma; it's one reason exhausted friends and lovers stick around and clean up their messes. That's the case with Lee, the young, beautiful and angry narrator of Jardine Libaire's first novel, HERE KITTY KITTY (Little, Brown, $22.95). A Tribeca restaurant manager, Lee makes a late-morning Scotch, after snorting coke all night, seem whimsically glamorous. But Lee's charm is fading, and she knows it: ''Innocence was finite and could not be regenerated.'' Even her sugar-daddy French boyfriend, Yves, who ''secretly loved chaos,'' tells Lee to get it together. Inevitably, she bottoms out, but there are no easy epiphanies in this dark, tender book. (And it's not the typical single-girl story of guy trouble and job boredom either.) Libaire instead wisely explores her heroine's long and difficult struggle to take care of herself: to be sober, to sleep peacefully, to be alone. In the process, the author offers glittering descriptions of New York life, both its obstacles and its promise. Suzy Hansen

title: Smithtown Debates Old Armory's Fate

title: The Re-Baathification of Falluja
description: It was payday for the Falluja Brigade, a dusty, flat, 100-degree day in late May, and hundreds of the brigade's soldiers were gathering at the city's railway station on the north end of town. A month before, during the siege of Falluja by 4,500 United States marines, this same railway station was attacked by American helicopters after insurgents inside the station fired rocket-propelled grenades at Marine snipers nearby. But now things were very different. On May 1, as Falluja and the world braced for an all-out assault by the marines, the siege was suddenly called off. The marines announced they were pulling out and ceding control of the city to a new, all-Iraqi force. The man who engineered the deal was Muhammad Latif, a 66-year-old former Iraqi Army colonel from Baghdad. Latif promised the Americans that he could pacify Falluja with a corps of laid-off soldiers from Saddam Hussein's army. Some would be former members of the Republican Guard, the elite force responsible for the regime's darkest hours, and some would be drawn from the insurgents the Americans had been fighting -- a very different situation indeed.

They are being held in secret locations and have been subjected to highly coercive interrogations, leading some law enforcement and intelligence officials to look skeptically at their testimony. The 10-member panel is scheduled to submit its final report at the end of next month. Here are some findings disclosed last week. PETER EDIDIN

title: The Harlem Project
description: Back in 1990, Geoffrey Canada was just your average do-gooder. That year, he became the president of a nonprofit charitable organization based in Harlem called the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, and he set out trying to improve the world, one poor child at a time. It was a bad moment to be poor in New York City. Harlem, especially, was suffering under the simultaneous plagues of crack cocaine, cheap guns and rampant homelessness, and Canada's main goal at Rheedlen, in those years, was to keep the children in his programs alive. The organization had an annual budget of $3 million, which it spent on a predictable array of services in Upper Manhattan: after-school programs, truancy prevention, anti-violence training for teenagers. The programs seemed to do a lot of good for the children who were enrolled in them, at least in part because of Canada's own level of devotion. He was obsessed with his job, personally invested in the lives of the children he was helping and devastated when they ended up in prison or on drugs or shot dead on the street.

title: 1904:Sun-Worshippers Meet : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: PARIS: Scientific and artistic "worshippers of the sun" will assemble this evening [June 21] on the Eiffel Tower to celebrate the summer solstice, which commences at twenty-eight seconds past nine o'clock. At that moment the sun will enter the Tropic of Cancer. The boom of cannon, announcing the commencement of the solstice, will give the signal for the beginning of the fete. M. Jansen, the Nestor of French astrologists, will open the proceedings with a brief speech. Then M. Camille Flammarion will deliver a discourse on "Sun Worship." He will recall how for forty centuries the sun has been the subject of adoration by the Gallo-Romans, the Druids, the disciples of Mithra, the Egyptians and the Aryans. He will remind his hearers of the role of the sun in cosmos, pointing out how it sustains the earth and creates and regulates all life on this globe.

It proposed a radical change in the way NASA operates, creation of a whole new entrepreneurial space industry and even a $1 billion prize for the first organization that puts humans on the Moon and sustains them there for a fixed period before returning them to Earth. The glaring defect in the panel's report was its failure to provide any thoughtful analysis or detailed justification for its proposals. The 60-page document amounts to a pep talk that is too skimpy to be persuasive.

title: PHILIP ROTH PICKS A BIOGRAPHER
description: The author Philip Roth, left, has chosen a biographer who is to be granted unfettered access to his correspondence, private archives, family and friends. The biographer, Ross Miller, 58, is a professor of English and comparative literature at the University of Connecticut, an architecture critic and the author of several books, Mr. Roth's publisher, Houghton Mifflin, and a spokeswoman for the university said. Mr. Miller, a nephew of the playwright Arthur Miller, said he would write a definitive biography. It is not an authorized biography. ''One of the reasons this is not so daunting,'' Mr. Miller said, ''is that I knew Philip when I was young.'' The book will be published by Houghton Mifflin in 2009 or 2010, Mr. Miller said. He is also the editor of the Library of America's planned eight-volume edition of Mr. Roth's writings. Mr. Miller's book ''Free at Last: Why the Jews Discovered America'' is to be published by Houghton Mifflin in 2006. In October Mr. Roth's 21st novel, ''The Plot Against America,'' is to be published by Houghton Mifflin. DINITIA SMITH

But that, of course, started to change last week when it was announced that the Tony Award-winning musical ''Avenue Q'' would forgo a national road tour in favor of opening in 2005 in a new $40 million theater in Las Vegas. The opening of ''We Will Rock You'' in Las Vegas may be less of a surprise because this rock musical features the type of large-scale spectacle that the city is famous for. When the show opened in London two years ago, it was roundly panned by critics, who mocked its futuristic plot about a group of rebels, the Bohemians, who are in search of a mythical guitar that was buried by the members of Queen themselves in the late 20th century. The show, whose producers include Robert De Niro and Jane Rosenthal and the Queen guitarist Brian May, above, and the drummer Roger Taylor, are to announce that it will begin its open-ended run on Aug. 16 at the Thtre des Arts, Paris Las Vegas. JASON ZINOMAN

title: 1954:Anti-Reds In Guatemala : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras: Anti-Communist leaders who launched the invasion of Guatemala by land, sea and air late Friday afternoon, said tonight [June 20] that their "Liberation Army" is encountering only feeble resistance and expects to capture the entire country within a few days. Representatives of the forces of Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, a former Guatemalan Army officer who directed the invasion, said their troops have penetrated up to 25 miles inside Guatemala and are "marching to the capital" of Guatemala City. Manuel Orellana Portillo, Col. Castillo's director of information, told a press conference there that only "sporadic scraps" with Guatemalan Army forces are being fought. He said that at many places, Guatemalan border guards have been withdrawn, leaving the frontier almost undefended. The "Liberation Army," seeking to overthrow the Communist-tinged government of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, reported the capture of the country's two chief ports.

title: Russia's Big Trial

The trial has attracted enormous attention. The extraordinary fortunes of the two defendants, and the parallel struggle for survival of Yukos, the oil company that made them rich, have turned it into a microcosm of the struggles that are shaping the new Russia.

Wheaton shareholders would get a minimum of 1 Canadian dollar in cash and Coeur stock for each of their shares, Coeur d'Alene said. It had previously offered a 50-cent minimum cash payment, it said. The offer values Wheaton at 4.09 Canadian dollars a share, based on Coeur's closing price. Coeur d'Alene Mines, based in Idaho, said it mailed a letter to Wheaton River shareholders yesterday urging them to vote against a proposed merger with the Iamgold Corporation of Toronto. Shareholders of Wheaton River, based in Vancouver, are scheduled to vote on the Iamgold proposal on July 6.

Sales are expected to increase 150 percent from last year, up from a previous forecast that sales would double, Taser said. The company, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., had revenue of $24.5 million in 2003. Qazi Faruque Ahmed, who founded Proshika, a nongovernment organization that offers microcredit and other mechanisms for sustainable development, is already in jail on corruption charges. The new charges say he tried to overthrow the government this spring by hiring people to attend an antigovernment rally. His lawyer said the government had filed the charge to harass Mr. Ahmed and his group, which has long been at odds with Islamic fundamentalists in and out of the government. Amy Waldman (NYT)

Last month, Femsa paid $1.25 billion to buy back a 30-percent stake held by Belgian brewer Interbrew in the beer unit, Femsa Cerveza. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Coram: Family Charged With Smuggling Immigrants
description: Three members of a Long Island family were charged with smuggling dozens of Peruvians into the United States since December 2000 and forcing them to live in cramped, squalid homes once they arrived, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Roslynn R. Mauskopf, said yesterday. The three family members, Mariluz Zavala, 42; her husband, Jorge Ibanez, 41; and the couple's daughter, Evelyn Ibanez, 20, all of Coram, garnished the salaries of the immigrants they smuggled into the country and controlled them with threats and intimidation, according to a statement from the United States attorney.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Cost Of Accounting Inquiry
description: Ireland's largest financial institution, Allied Irish Banks, said that it was likely to spend 50 million euros ($61 million) to deal with the revelation that its customers were overcharged for foreign exchange transactions starting in 1996, compared with an estimate of 25 million euros ($30 million) when the practice was exposed last month. An internal investigation into the overcharging, which was prompted by public outcry over a perceived lack of accountability at Irish banks, caused the additional cost. Allied Irish said that it expected ''significant'' growth in full-year earnings, based on cost-cutting and a 20 percent rise in loans in Britain and Ireland. Brian Lavery (NYT)

That criticism must be followed up with concerted pressure to keep Iran from joining the growing list of states armed with nuclear weapons.

description: Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign has returned a $2,000 check after discovering that it came from a former South Korean president's son who has been arrested and charged with tax evasion.

description: ''The Power of Resilience: Achieving Balance, Confidence, and Personal Strength in Your Life'' by Drs. Robert B. Brooks and Sam Goldstein, Contemporary Books, $22.95 (hardcover), $14.95 (paperback).

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Appeal To NATO
description: The United Nations special envoy to Afghanistan, Jean Arnault, called on NATO to send more troops to Afghanistan, saying that security remains a critical issue with the approach of elections in September. His comments come ahead of a NATO summit meeting in Istanbul, and just after a policeman was killed and a United Nations election worker wounded in an attack in southern Afghanistan. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: White House Releases Documents Related to Prison Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  The White House this afternoon released a stack of internal documents on the treatment of war prisoners to back up President Bush's declaration hours earlier that torture is "not part of our soul."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Budweiser Loses Trademark Ruling
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the world's largest brewer, cannot register its Budweiser name as a single trademark in all 25 European Union countries, according to the latest ruling in a century-old battle over the beer brand. In rejecting the company's 1996 application, the union's Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market said the Budweiser name was identical to one already registered by a Czech rival, Budejovicky Budvar, in Austria and France. Anheuser-Busch must instead rely on previously held national trademarks. In its ruling, the trademark office said the similarity of Budvar's product, above, with that of Budweiser might cause confusion in France and Austria.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DUANE READE INC., New York, the drugstore chain, said it had agreed to accept 2.9 percent less cash from Oak Hill Capital Partners, Menlo Park, Calif., the buyout firm controlled by billionaire investor Robert M. Bass, to speed completion of Oak Hill's takeover. The cash portion of the price was cut to $16.50 a share, or $404 million, from $17, or $416 million.

title: Funds' Manager Makes $100 Million Settlement With S.E.C.
description: Pilgrim Baxter & Associates, which oversees PBGH funds, reached a $100 million settlement with regulators yesterday to resolve accusations that it let some investors trade rapidly in and out of its funds.

title: S.E.C. to Order That Funds Have Outsiders As Chairmen
description: Overcoming strong opposition from the mutual fund industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday will approve a regulation forcing most of the nation's fund companies to replace their board chairmen with outsiders who are independent, commission officials said Monday.

description: The United States Olympic women's basketball team will have 13 days between the temporary suspension of the Women's National Basketball Association season on Aug. 1 and its first game against New Zealand in Athens on Aug. 14.

description: SHUB--Elizabeth (nee Charney). Died peacefully at home on Friday, June 18, 2004. Beloved sister of the late Dr. William Charney, aunt of Miriam Charney and Didi Charney, great-aunt of Evan Charney Maltby and Jacob William Charney-Beck. Award-winning editor, author and translator of numerous children's books. She will be greatly missed. Memorial service Tuesday, June 22, 2:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the New York Public Library.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision Offers $90 Monthly Package
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the largest cable-television operator in the New York area, said yesterday that it had begun offering a $90-a-month package of TV, telephone and Web-access service to lure customers from satellite and telephone competitors. The subscription rate, valid for the first year, costs $50 a month less than the three services, bought separately, would cost at regular prices. Customers will receive a basic package of more than 140 TV networks including CBS, Nickelodeon and CNN, as well as digital phone service and high-speed Web access, Cablevision said. Cable television companies are adding phone service and bundling offerings to increase sales and reduce customer defections. Cablevision's competitors, including the DirecTV Group, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and local phone companies like Verizon Communications, are jointly selling packages of services to customers. Cablevision's phone service, which uses so-called voice-over-Internet protocol technology to carry the calls over the cable systems, had 71,000 customers as of March 31. Shares of Cablevision fell 78 cents, to $21.22.

title: A New Leader Carrying Hope -- M. Jodi Rell
description: M. Jodi Rell likes to tell the story about the first time she ran as John G. Rowland's running mate, in 1994. Dressed in a suit and high heels, she came home from the campaign trail one night and saw that her family had neglected to take out the trash. She dragged the trash outside, her indignation rising. ''I'm running for lieutenant governor,'' she said she told family members upon returning. ''The least you could have done is taken out the trash.''

title: Webb Is Back in the Spotlight
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 20 - Alan Webb said his body was numb for the last lap of his mile race at the Prefontaine Classic on Saturday. He could not feel his limbs, but he still ran far ahead of the pack, the crowd at the University of Oregon's Hayward Field cheering him on to the fastest mile run by an American in the United States, 3 minutes 50.85 seconds. It was also the fastest mile run this year.

title: More Slot Machines for Tribes; $1 Billion for California
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger struck a bargain on Monday with five California Indian tribes that will provide the state with a quick cash infusion of $1 billion while permitting a sizable expansion of tribal gambling operations in the state.

title: Neither Rain Nor Long Lines Deter Clinton Fans at Bookstore
description: Umbrellas were dripping, bumping and inadvertantly hitching themselves together as onlookers huddled and tried to catch a glimpse of Bill Clinton as he began his book tour at Barnes & Noble in Rockefeller Center today.

title: A Band on the Way Out Goes Broadway
description: At an urban crossroads where the going-out-of-business sale has been a perennial marketing tool, what is one to make of the rock band Phish, which has announced its own demise, showing up to perform free?

title: Beating Kerry to Punch, Nader Picks a No. 2
description: Ralph Nader, who twice ran for president on the Green Party ticket, chose as his running mate on Monday a member of that party. The selection rekindled his association with the Greens and raised the outside possibility that they might endorse him and thereby put him on the ballot in 22 states and here in Washington.

title: Fear in the Workplace: The Bullying Boss
description: Every working adult has known one -- a boss who loves making subordinates squirm, whose moods radiate through the office, sending workers scurrying for cover, whose very voice causes stomach muscles to clench and pulses to quicken.

description: CLARA VILLAROSA was at her desk yesterday at 5 a.m., fully five hours before the start of business at her Hue-Man Bookstore and Caf in Harlem. This was not her normal schedule, not by a long shot. But then, it was not a normal day.

title: A Debate on How to Treat Precancerous Breast Disease
description: The first time Jane Leffingwell was told that she had a precancerous lesion of the breast, she received the least aggressive treatment available: breast-conserving surgery, or lumpectomy.

title: U.S. Official Cites 'Progress' but Sees G.I.'s in Iraq for Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 — The United States may have to keep troops in Iraq for years to come despite the "enormous progress" in bringing peace to that country, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz said today.

title: Rare and Monumental Work Finds Its Robust Challenger
description: The strangeness of Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji's place in the history of the keyboard is of his own making. An eccentric English pianist and composer, he devoted his concerts to his own works, which tended to be vast, technically demanding structures that required huge reserves of energy.

title: Long Island Man Accidentally Runs Over and Kills Daughter, 2, in Driveway
description: As a Father's Day barbecue wound down on Sunday night, Matthew Cavallaro climbed into his Ford Expedition and prepared to take his family home. What he did not see as he backed down the driveway, the police said, was that his 2-year-old daughter had wandered into the vehicle's path.

title: A Matter Of Faith
description: When Bill Clinton was 8, he started taking himself to church. When he was 10, he publicly committed himself to Jesus. As a boy, he begged his Sunday school teacher to take him to see Billy Graham. And as anybody watching his book rollout knows, he still exudes religiosity. He gave Dan Rather a tour of his Little Rock church, and talked about praying in good times and bad.

description: Incumbents in the New York Legislature enjoy job security that many would envy, with gerrymandered districts and fund-raising advantages helping most of them keep a stranglehold on their seats. That helps explain why party control of the Legislature has not changed hands in three decades: Democrats have an iron grip on the State Assembly, Republicans on the State Senate.

title: Elizabeth Shub, 89, Translator And Editor of Children's Books
description: Elizabeth Shub, a distinguished editor and translator of children's books from German and Yiddish, especially those of Isaac Bashevis Singer, whom she knew from her childhood and encouraged to write for children, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

Ms. Dorsey had been vice president and associate director at Magna Global Entertainment, New York, part of the Magna Global division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: A Governor Resigns in Disgrace
description: Connecticut has always liked to refer to itself as ''the land of steady habits.'' And the state's three-term governor, John Rowland, enjoyed being called the boy wonder of the Republican Party -- clearly a politician to watch. The voters apparently failed to watch in the right way. Mr. Rowland wound up facing both an impeachment inquiry at home and a federal political corruption investigation. Yesterday, he announced his resignation.
