description: If you cannot stop a snorer from snoring, how can you cut down on the noise? One way may be by inserting small plastic strips into the soft tissue at the top of the mouth, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Front Row; Off-the-Rack Lagerfeld, at H&M
description: He wears high white collars and still prefers to correspond with paper and pen, but everyone in fashion knows that Karl Lagerfeld is a champion multitasker. There are the collections he designs for Chanel, Fendi and his own label, Lagerfeld Gallery; the books he publishes under his own imprint; and the photographs he makes for magazines like French Vogue and V. Now Mr. Lagerfeld has given himself a new task: designing a small line of clothing and accessories for H&M, the Stockholm-based mass retailer.

title: MEMO PAD
description: AIR FARES DOWN -- After climbing slightly but steadily all year, average domestic fares at eight major United States airlines dropped 1.8 percent in May, according to the Air Transport Association. With overall domestic capacity expected to be up more than 10 percent this summer over last summer and low-cost carriers continuing to challenge bigger rivals for market share on competing routes, the sagging fares in May suggest that downward pressure could continue on summer domestic fares, industry analysts said. International fares, where there is no competition from low-cost carriers, have risen steadily all year, the trade group said.

title: Shareholders Show Support For Stewart At Meeting
description: Martha Stewart appeared at her company's annual shareholder meeting yesterday, addressing the faithful for the first time since becoming a convicted felon in March. Despite a bleak year that even she described as ''fraught with sorrow,'' the encounter seemed to be pro-Martha.

title: Preserving Today's Voices for Tomorrow's Fans
description: ALTHOUGH Major League Baseball abandoned Fay Vincent, the former commissioner, he has not abandoned baseball. He has quietly undertaken a project to record the oral histories of former players and other significant figures within the sport for the Hall of Fame.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Culture Shock
description: More than 40 Africans trying to enter Spain illegally were detained after their raft landed at a nudist beach near Cadiz. An amateur videotape broadcast on television showed the immigrants trying to avoid arrest while visitors to the beach, at least one of them unclothed, looked on. The police said the Africans, including four babies, would be sent back to their countries, which were not identified. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: U.S. Inquiry Now the Focus Of Case Against Governor
description: Federal investigators are focusing on a growing body of evidence that a rich friend of Gov. John G. Rowland's used intermediaries to mask cash payments to the governor while reaping state business worth millions of dollars, according to lawyers involved in the inquiry.

title: A Retrospective Diagnosis Says Lenin Had Syphilis
description: Whispers have circulated for decades that Lenin, founder of the Bolshevik Party and the totalitarian Soviet state it ushered to power, was afflicted with syphilis throughout his career. Now a new study turns that speculation into a retrospective diagnosis.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Union Looks At 2 Regions
description: The president of the Service Employees International Union announced that his union would begin a major effort to organize health and building service workers in two largely nonunion regions, the South and the Southwest. Speaking to 3,000 delegates at the union's convention in San Francisco, the president, Andrew Stern, also announced an effort to use the Internet to attract one million associate members, who would cooperate with his union on political, social and labor fights. In addition, he said his union would commit $1 million to work with national and local groups to pressure Wal-Mart to improve wages and working conditions and to be a better neighbor. Mr. Stern added that his union wanted to work with other unions to revamp the structure and priorities of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to make it more effective. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: A Deal for New Yorkers
description: In doling out a something-for-everyone budget, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, will undoubtedly score political points with virtually every imaginable constituency -- the working poor, homeowners, older New Yorkers, those who love libraries.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Ex-Presidential Aide Charged
description: Joshua Kulei, a former aide to former president Daniel arap Moi, became the first person charged with orchestrating a corrupt land deal three years ago that cost a state-owned company more than $3 million. Mr. Moi, who retired in 2002 after 24 years in office, was frequently criticized for running a corrupt government. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Rebel Raid Near Chechnya Is Said to Kill at Least 75 People
description: GROZNY, Russia, June 22  An audacious overnight raid by heavily armed militants in a southern Russian republic neighboring Chechnya killed as many as 75 people and wounded dozens more before the fighters withdrew with minimal losses and a cache of captured weapons, officials said today.

title: Rise in Advertising Spending Predicted at Home and Abroad
description: Aleading forecaster of advertising spending today raised his estimates for 2004, citing the improving economy, and offered an optimistic outlook in his first assessment of 2005.

description: KORNBERG--Selma Borden. June 9, 1913, to June 18, 2004. Partner and wife of the late Peter Kornberg. Mother of Michael Borden (Raymond Klein) and Alan William. Friend and mentor to many. Funeral services private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Second Seder Fund of Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th St, NY, NY 10021; or Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Deflation Slows
description: Consumer prices fell 0.9 percent last month, slowing from a rate of 1.5 percent in April and suggesting that five years of deflation may be ending. Prices were pulled down by housing, off 6.7 percent as more apartments went on the market. For durable goods like washing machines and refrigerators, prices dropped 1.3 percent, mirroring a trend in mainland China as banks have lent money for many factories to produce household appliances. But Goldman Sachs noted that prices rose in May for seven other categories of consumer prices, led by a jump of 10.4 percent for clothing and footwear. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Investigators Suspect Inside Help in Iraqi Pipeline Blasts
description: BASRA, Iraq, June 22  As one of two strategic oil pipelines in southern Iraq began flowing again after a pair of explosions shut down the country's crucial exports last week, investigators focused on current and former employees who may have given inside information to saboteurs.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Focus On Anti-Semitism
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said there was an ''alarming resurgence'' of acts of hatred against Jews in the world and suggested that United Nations bodies adopt resolutions explicitly condemning anti-Semitism. Speaking at the first United Nations conference on anti-Semitism, attended by many delegates who believe that the United Nations singles out Israel for criticism while ignoring anti-Israeli acts, Mr. Annan said, "When we seek justice for the Palestinians, as we must, let us firmly disavow anyone who tries to use that cause to incite hatred against Jews, in Israel or elsewhere." He earned a standing ovation, but applause also greeted the comment by Anne Bayefsky of the Hudson Institute, who said, ''This meeting occurs at a point when the relationship between Jews and the United Nations is at an all-time low.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Entangled With One Another; So Blame the Choreographer
description: There are fascinating choreographic bits in the two works Bill Young and Dancers performed on Thursday night at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, but those spurts of steps choreographed by Mr. Young and Colleen Thomas in collaboration with their agile dancers never convincingly cohered.

title: Editorial Observer; Treat the Epidemic Behind Bars Before It Hits the Streets
description: The murder of 20-year-old Raul Tinajero at the Los Angeles County Jail in April focused national attention on the violence that dominates much of the American correctional system. Mr. Tinajero had testified for the prosecution at a murder trial and had been guaranteed special protection that never materialized. The inmate against whom he testified roamed the jail for hours on a forged pass, the authorities say, until he entered Mr. Tinajero's cell and strangled him in front of his cellmates.

title: Nelson Goes Long Way for the N.B.A.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa:
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who built her own career as an antiapartheid radical during the 27 years her former husband, Nelson Mandela, spent in prison, appealed her five-year prison sentence on charges of stealing about $150,000 in a bank-fraud scheme. A court found Ms. Madikizela-Mandela guilty last year of creating fictitious employees of the African National Congress Women's League, which she headed, to obtain bank loans for others, and of conspiring to deduct false funeral-insurance charges from the loans. Her lawyer said she was trying to help people who otherwise could not obtain bank loans. Mr. Mandela and Ms. Madikizela-Mandela divorced in 1996. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: Few sights in science are sadder than astronomers standing in the rain.

description: President Bush spent a speedy two and a half hours here on Monday collecting $2.5 million for the Republican Party and promoting a ''healthy marriage'' initiative much favored by his conservative supporters.

description: In other decades, this would have been a routine moment for Martina Navratilova: a grass-court match at Wimbledon against an overawed, infinitely less adept opponent in which the games and the angle volleys went zipping by in a suspense-free rush.

description: The Carlyle Group, the private American investment firm, agreed on Monday to pay 220 billion yen ($2.02 billion) to the KDDI Corporation for 60 percent of a Japanese provider of cellphone and wireless Internet service in a deal that signaled a growing acceptance of foreign buyouts in Japan.

title: BAIN CAPITAL LEADS TAKEOVER OF LOEWS CINEPLEX
description: Bain Capital, an investment firm started by Mitt Romney, now governor of Massachusetts, is leading a $1.47 billion takeover of the Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corporation, the large movie-theater chain. Bain Capital of Boston, along with the Carlyle Group and Spectrum Equity Investors, is buying Loews Cineplex from buyout firms Onex Corporation of Toronto and Oaktree Capital Management of Los Angeles, the companies said. Onex and Oaktree Capital brought Loews Cineplex out of bankruptcy protection in 2002 by buying about $500 million of bonds and other debts. Loews, based in New York, has more than 280 theaters and 2,800 screens in the United States and other countries.

title: National Briefing | Washington: McCain Is Sued Over Campaign Finance
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, an architect of the largest changes to the campaign finance system in three decades, was sued by a constituent who wants further changes. The constituent, Chester P. Soling, 73, of Tucson, filed suit in federal court against Mr. McCain and other Congressional incumbents and challengers from Arizona to try to stop them from collecting campaign money from outside the areas they represent. Out-of-state money is a major source of revenue for many federal campaigns. The suit seeks to block candidates from taking money from nonconstituents and from using personal money for their campaigns above the maximum of $4,000 allowed for individual contributions. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Vietnam Veterans Wall Partly Closes
description: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial will be partly closed during the next five months while its lighting system is replaced. The east wall was closed June 11 and will remain covered until mid-August. At that time, the west wall will close for construction through October. Jan C. Scruggs, founder and president of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, said visitors would be able to request rubbings of names that have been covered for the renovations. ''This is the first time the wall -- or half of it -- has been closed to the public,'' Mr. Scruggs said. ''It makes us feel bad, so we apologize for that.'' Brian Wingfield (NYT)

description: When Timothy Placek tried to cash in his miles to fly his daughter from St. Louis to Houston last year, Continental Airlines told him no seats were available.

Oppenheimer and his colleagues could be found back in Haleakala, Hawaii, training a high-resolution United States Air Force telescope equipped with an experimental coronagraph on the star Omega Herculis, also known as Cujam. They recorded an image of the star and a dim companion star only a thousandth as bright.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PalmOne Posts 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Palm-One Inc., the world's biggest maker of hand-held computers, reported yesterday that it made a fourth-quarter profit as sales rose of its cellphone-equipped Treo 600. The shares rose 22 percent in extended trading. Net income was $13.3 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with a loss from continuing operations of $10.4 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the quarter that ended May 31 rose 23 percent to $267.3 million. PalmOne, based in Milpitas, Calif., is benefiting from growing sales of devices like the Treo 600 that combine mobile telephones, hand-held computers and cameras, and can send e-mail messages and provide access to Internet sites. It said on its Internet site that customers might have to wait as many as eight weeks for the Treo 600. In the third quarter, the company shipped 938,000 devices. The shares rose $4.65, to $26.11, in extended trading. They gained $1.11, to $21.46, in regular trading.

title: TOP COMMANDERS FACE QUESTIONING ON PRISON ABUSE
description: A military judge ruled Monday that the top American commanders currently involved in the Iraq war will have to submit to questioning by lawyers for two servicemen charged in the Abu Ghraib prison abuse case. The defense lawyers said they would show that the most senior military and civilian officials approved interrogation methods that violated the Geneva Conventions.

description: Elizabeth Willott is the kind of professor who gives the ivory tower a good name.

title: Murder in Ancient Greece, Accompanied by Choirs
description: In the 20 years he has been presenting his concerts with the Manhattan Philharmonic, the entrepreneurial conductor Peter Tiboris has shown a talent for spectacle. Many of his performances are huge choral jamborees, with choirs imported from schools all over the United States for what is, in effect, a vanity appearance at Carnegie Hall.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Ametek Acquires Precision Tool Maker
description: Ametek has acquired Taylor Hobson Holdings Ltd., a British-based maker of precision tools for the computer-chip market and other industries, for about $93.4 million in cash. Ametek bought Taylor Hobson, a closely held company, from London-based Permira, the manager of Europe's biggest buyout fund. Taylor Hobson's sales this year are forecast to be about $69.6 million, Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., said yesterday. Ametek said the acquisition would help its high-end analytical operation generate more than $250 million in annual revenue. Sales for 2003 were $1.1 billion, with the instrument unit contributing about 55 percent and the rest coming from sales of electric motors. The purchase will help Ametek reach the goal of broadening its offerings of precision instruments. Taylor Hobson's instruments are used in the manufacture of computers, telecommunication products, automobiles and digital cameras.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the use of new prosthetic technology at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington to help men and women wounded in Iraq misstated the number of American service members wounded since the start of the war. As of yesterday, it was 3,018, with another 2,120 who returned to duty within 72 hours of being wounded. (The figure of 675 represented those recuperating at Walter Reed.) ( Go to Article )

title: Webb Is Back in the Spotlight
description: Alan Webb said his body was numb for the last lap of his mile race at the Prefontaine Classic on Saturday. He could not feel his limbs, but he still ran far ahead of the pack, the crowd at the University of Oregon's Hayward Field cheering him on to the fastest mile run by an American in the United States, 3 minutes 50.85 seconds. It was also the fastest mile run this year.

title: U.S. Rules on Prisoners Seen as a Back and Forth of Mixed Messages to G.I.'s
description: Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the Bush administration's new rules governing treatment of foreign prisoners have been contradictory and have sent mixed messages to American soldiers, according to military personnel and documents.

title: Noonday in the Shade
description: In April 2003, John Ashcroft's Justice Department disrupted what appears to have been a horrifying terrorist plot. In the small town of Noonday, Tex., F.B.I. agents discovered a weapons cache containing fully automatic machine guns, remote-controlled explosive devices disguised as briefcases, 60 pipe bombs and a chemical weapon -- a cyanide bomb -- big enough to kill everyone in a 30,000-square-foot building.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Kenneth Kamler; Bringing Them Back, Healthy, From the Ends of the Earth
description: Kenneth Kamler, 56, is a man with a double life. For much of the year, he labors as a Long Island-based microsurgeon, specializing in hand reconstruction and finger reattachment. In his other guise, Dr. Kamler is an eminent adventure physician, a staff doctor with scientific expeditions journeying to remote corners to investigate how crocodiles mate or how NASA's medical equipment works at high altitudes. He is a vice president of the prestigious Explorers Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DINER, HARRY M.
description: DINER--Harry M. The Board of Governors and the members of the Noyac Golf Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our Founder, Dr. Harry M. Diner, and express our sympathy to his wife Mimi and entire family.

title: Mars' Round, Smooth Stones Have a Counterpart in Utah
description: Among the most intriguing discoveries from Mars this year are the almost perfectly round pebbles, nicknamed blueberries, that the rover Opportunity found strewn about at its landing site.

title: 'My Life'
description: Early on the morning of August 19, 1946, I was born under a clear sky after a violent summer storm to a widowed mother in the Julia Chester Hospital in Hope, a town of about six thousand in southwest Arkansas, thirty-three miles east of the Texas border at Texarkana. My mother named me William Jefferson Blythe III after my father, William Jefferson Blythe Jr., one of nine children of a poor farmer in Sherman, Texas, who died when my father was seventeen. According to his sisters, my father always tried to take care of them, and he grew up to be a handsome, hardworking, fun-loving man. He met my mother at Tri- State Hospital in Shreveport, Louisiana, in 1943, when she was training to be a nurse. Many times when I was growing up, I asked Mother to tell me the story of their meeting, courting, and marriage. He brought a date with some kind of medical emergency into the ward where she was working, and they talked and flirted while the other woman was being treated. On his way out of the hospital, he touched the finger on which she was wearing her boyfriend's ring and asked her if she was married. She stammered "no"-she was single. The next day he sent the other woman flowers and her heart sank. Then he called Mother for a date, explaining that he always sent flowers when he ended a relationship.

title: The Longest Day
description: June 21 is well-known as the longest day of the year, when the sun far outlasts the darkness as spring becomes summer. But Monday was also the longest day in recent memory on the campaign trail with Senator John Kerry.

description: On the wall above the cash register at Jake, a three-month-old boutique in the Southport neighborhood on Chicago's North side, hangs a poster-size aerial photograph of the city's Loop -- a rhythmic black-and-white gridwork of avenues and boulevards some may find reminiscent of another, far-away metropolis.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Juror In Peterson Trial
description: The judge presiding over the murder trial of Scott Peterson ruled that an exchange last week between a juror and Mr. Peterson's brother-in-law did not constitute misconduct. A television pool camera captured a brief statement by the juror, an airport screener known as Juror No. 5, to the brother-in-law, Brent Rocha. A pool representative who viewed the tape said last week that Juror No. 5 could be heard saying, ''could lose today.'' But the judge, Alfred A. Delucchi, said Monday that the juror never made that statement. Elizabeth Ahlin (NYT)

description: Investors have filed two lawsuits that accuse Deutsche Bank, the German financial giant, of working with several accounting, law and financial services firms, including American Express, to sell abusive tax shelters from 1999 to 2001.

title: Ohio Museum Attributes A Purchase To Praxiteles
description: The Cleveland Museum of Art has bought what it thinks is an ancient bronze sculpture of Apollo the Lizard Slayer by the classical Greek sculptor Praxiteles. If it is authentic, it will be one of the most important ancient bronzes in an American museum.

title: Front Row; Black Style at the Victoria and Albert
description: Why is it that the Victoria and Albert Museum in London seems to beat the curatorial pants off the fashion departments of American institutions? The question bedevils anyone who cares about these things. In New York, museumgoers get scholarly but uninspiring shows about the clothes of the Enlightenment. There, they get antic and politically charged exhibitions about, say, Vivienne Westwood, the orange-haired poster girl for the concept of designer as provocateur, a show at the Victoria and Albert through July 18.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telstra Plans Dividend
description: Australia's dominant telephone operator, Telstra, said it would pay shareholders 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($1.03 billion) a year for the next three years through dividends or share buybacks. The Australian government owns 51 percent of the company and has been trying unsuccessfully to win Parliament's approval to sell part of its stake to raise cash. Telstra's announcement caused the two major credit ratings agencies to lower Telstra's rating, but sent the company's stock price up 5 percent, to its highest since January. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

title: Honors for Stanford Swimmer
description: Tara Kirk, the Stanford swimmer, was named the college female athlete of the year. In ceremonies in Columbia's Low Library, she received the Honda-Broderick Cup.

title: A Family Feud at Molson as Profit Falls
description: For generations, members of Montreal's upper-crust Molson family have been brought up to believe, according to a biographer, that their names should appear in print three times during their lives: at birth, marriage and death.

title: CONNECTICUT'S GOVERNOR STEPS DOWN: Reaction; In the End, Sadness and Some Cheers, but Mostly Sighs of Relief
description: As Gov. John G. Rowland gave up his long struggle to stay in power last night with a resignation speech that put a brave face on a difficult moment, there was a touch of sadness, little cheering, and even less surprise among the people and politicians who watched.

title: Police Say Robbery Suspect They Fatally Shot Was Jailed Several Times
description: A robbery suspect who was shot and killed by a police officer in a TriBeCa subway tunnel on Sunday was a repeat offender who was released from prison in April after spending most of the last 13 years behind bars, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Justices Uphold a Nevada Law Requiring Citizens to Identify Themselves to the Police
description: People who have given the police some reason to suspect that they may be involved in a crime can be required to identify themselves unless their very name would be incriminating, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a case that had raised concerns about the boundaries of personal privacy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Automotive Unit For Sale
description: Centrica, Britain's largest supplier of natural gas, said that it was considering the sale of its Automotive Association, an insurer and provider of roadside service for drivers. The company purchased the association five years ago for about $2 billion as part of a bid to expand to other businesses. Centrica would not elaborate on any potential buyers for the group, but the company said that it was in ''preliminary'' discussions about a deal. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tycoon's Appeal Rejected
description: The Moscow City Court turned down an appeal to release Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the founder of the Yukos oil company, the Interfax news agency reported. Mr. Khodorkovsky's lawyers argued that his imprisonment was extended without the legally required consultations with prosecutors and the defendant. He has been in jail since last fall and his last pretrial detention period expired May 25. Mr. Khodorkovsky is accused of crimes including fraud and tax evasion. His trial, which opened last week, resumes Wednesday. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Albany's Annual Square Dance: Voting on Last-Minute Legislation
description: In their wisdom, the framers of New York's Constitution required lawmakers to let three days go by after the printing of a bill before voting on it. The idea was that good legislation, like fine wine, should age and breathe, so lawmakers would have time to read what they passed, and the public time to weigh in on it.

He picks up an air-conditioning filter. A filter? What was an air-conditioner? And what was that turnstile all about?

Closer by, a glum-looking couple sat, and chewed, in silence. Suddenly, there was a flurry of movement: a tipsy, teetering man knocked over the little lamp on his table and sent it hurtling over the edge.

description: The union representing ushers at Madison Square Garden voted unanimously last week to authorize a strike to protest a management proposal that it said would phase out their jobs in three years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer Sells Lease Unit
description: Italy's largest property and casualty insurer, Fondiaria-SAI, agreed to sell its Mercantile Leasing unit to Banca Italease for 121 million euros ($146 million) as it sought to reorganize. Fondiaria-SAI will earn about 36 million euros from the sale, the insurer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMTON, HENRY A.
description: SAMTON--Henry A., 97 years, nee Hans Szamatolski in Berlin, Germany died June 19th in Rye, New York. Husband for 67 years of late Margot Samton, father of Annette Marcus, Claude and Peter Samton; Founder Miltenberg & Samton Import-Export; Member 2 US Trade Missions Africa; longtime resident of Scarsdale; Extraordinary Father, Grandfather, GreatGrandfather, Father-in-law, Grandfather - in - law, Uncle, Grand Uncle, Dear Friend; A Jurist in Germany, he fled persecution, became a respected, productive and dedicated American...He will be sorely missed!

title: Sandwiches, With or Without the Bread
description: On Eighth Avenue near Times Square, a part of the city where subway has more than one meaning, Eban Ross, right, hopes to improve the sandwich options. Mr. Ross, a chef who worked with Michel Richard at Citrus in Los Angeles, has opened Carve, 760 Eighth Avenue (47th Street), a gleaming baby-blue-and-white spot. Fine ingredients like applewood smoked bacon, turkey cooked on a rotisserie and fresh tuna crusted with ginger and sesame are piled on fresh breads, or, for those counting carbs, wrapped in lettuce. Sandwiches are $5 to $9; soups, salads and breakfast items are also available.

description: The next governor of Connecticut, Lt. Gov. M. Jodi Rell, reintroduced herself to the state on Tuesday, insisting hers would be an administration free of the ethical questions that forced the resignation of the man she will replace on July 1.

title: Fit for an Emperor, Now Raised in America
description: If you think that pork has no business tasting like chicken breast, you might consider a special variety, from purebred Berkshire pigs. The meat is darker, more heavily marbled with fat, juicier and richer-tasting than most pork, and perfect for grilling. Berkshires, which are black, originated in England. Some were given more than 100 years ago to the emperor of Japan, where they are called kurobuta, and they are now being raised in Iowa for Snake River Farms in Boise, Idaho.

title: British Eyes Look at 1776 And See Less To Approve
description: Since Sept. 11, television has done a decent job of explaining why they hate us. Tonight PBS reveals why they have always hated us. ''Rebels and Redcoats: How Britain lost America'' is a wickedly revisionist view of the American Revolution, a ''Fahrenheit 1776.''

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Loudeye To Acquire European Digital-Music Provider
description: The Loudeye Corporation, which makes software to broadcast audio and video over the Internet, has agreed to buy On Demand Distribution, Europe's largest digital-music provider, for as much as $57 million in cash and stock. Loudeye initially will pay shares valued at about $18.4 million at Monday's closing price and $2.3 million in cash, and pay another $17.5 million in cash or stock through November 2005. It will pay an additional $18.8 million in cash or stock based on unspecified earnings goals in the next 30 months, the chief financial officer, Larry Madden, said yesterday on a call with investors. The acquisition will create the world's biggest licensed digital music catalog, with more than four million tracks, and help Loudeye expand into the $11 billion European music market, the chief executive officer, Jeff Cavins, said. On Demand, one of whose founders is the singer Peter Gabriel, has contracts with more than 70 record labels. The two companies combined will reach more than 70 percent of the world music market, Mr. Cavins said. Shares of Loudeye, which is based in Seattle, rose 15 cents to $1.47.

description: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs reported sharp increases in their second-quarter earnings yesterday, propelled by a surge in investment banking business and robust trading profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINANS, DEREK T.

description: A landmark settlement has been reached in a lawsuit brought by two New Jersey police officers who were badly wounded by a robber using a gun bought by a straw buyer at a South Charleston, W.Va., pawnshop, lawyers for the officers said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, SONDRA
description: MILLER--Sondra. Died at home June 20. She is survived by her husband William Arp, son Christopher, stepdaughter Rachel Ramstad. She is also survived by her beloved sister Helene Miller, niece Reyna Rosenshein, and brother-in-law Thomas Arp. A native of Brooklyn, she attended Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn College and received her Master's degree at Pratt Institute. She was an interior designer with the firm of William Cohen Architect. She was also a teacher, author, knitwear designer and clothing designer for Elie Tahari, Oleg Cassini, Chabot Freres and others. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Research, 1111 Stewart Ave, Bethpage, New York 11714.

description: WHEN I first met Ruth Rogers, which was more than 20 years ago, she had punk-pink hair, at least in the front. ''That was just a little phase,'' she says.

title: LUMENIS TO SETTLE CONTRACT DISPUTE FOR $4.09 MILLION
description: Lumenis Ltd., which makes cosmetic surgery equipment, will pay Palomar Medical Technologies Inc. $4.09 million to settle contract issues and litigation over royalties due on the sale of Palomar hair-removal products. Under the terms, Lumenis will grant Palomar paid-up licenses to a variety of products and will pay Palomar $4.09 million over the next six quarters, according to a statement. The company, based in Yokneam, Israel, said the payments would not affect earnings. Palomar, based in Burlington, Mass., sued Lumenis in October, claiming that Lumenis had not paid royalties on sales of the LightSheer Diode Laser System and its light-based hair-removal treatments. Lumenis has agreed to pay a 5 percent royalty on sales of the LightSheer retroactive to Jan. 1, according to the statement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Motorcyle Passenger Killed
description: A 20-year-old Long Island man was charged with manslaughter and drunken driving yesterday after he crashed his motorcycle into a concrete street divider, killing his passenger, the authorities said. Kilian Breen, 20, of New Hyde Park, was driving his 2002 Suzuki motorcycle across the Williamsburg Bridge into Brooklyn at around 4:20 a.m., when he lost control pulling onto South Fifth Street, and ran into the divider, the authorities said. His passenger, Justin Soluri, 20, also of New Hyde Park, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said the victim had been wearing a helmet but was wearing it improperly. Mr. Breen, who was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in stable condition, was also charged with reckless endangerment. Campbell Robertson (NYT)

title: Raising an Elegant Glass to a Platter of Fried Chicken
description: LIMITING sparkling wines to celebratory aperitif or dessert duty shortchanges them. They can complement any food: oysters, lobster, roast duck, grilled vegetables, risotto or a plate of buttery cheeses.

title: DUPONT DOW JOINT VENTURE SETTLES NEOPRENE CLAIMS
description: DuPont Dow Elastomers, a joint venture of the DuPont Company and the Dow Chemical Company, said that it would pay $36 million to settle claims by customers who say they were overcharged for neoprene, a synthetic rubber. The settlement was filed last month and is pending approval by the United States district court in Washington, a venture spokeswoman, Cathy Branciaroli, said. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., and Dow, of Midland, Mich., agreed in April to let DuPont direct federal and civil investigations into price fixing in the synthetic rubber markets.

title: Charities Face Increased Reviews by I.R.S. as Senate Considers Strengthening Oversight
description: As part of its contribution to a broad regulatory effort to police the nonprofit sector better, the Internal Revenue Service said Tuesday that it would examine some 400 foundations to determine whether the philanthropic institutions, which control billions of tax-exempt dollars, were complying with tax laws.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Gets Help
description: The Italian government said it would guarantee a short-term loan for Alitalia so the country's national airline would have the money to pull itself through a financial crisis that pushed the company to the brink of bankruptcy. Alitalia and the government would not give further details, but according to a person close to the airline who did not want to be identified, the loan will be for about 400 million euros ($484.6 million). The loan will give Alitalia, which lost 511 million euros last year, the money it needs to begin a restructuring plan that management says will return the airline to profitability in two years. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Rowland Opponent Has His Day in the Sun
description: He was at home here on Monday, trying to tune out the world, working on a book about political corruption in Connecticut that he also hopes to make into a movie.

title: 75 Die as Chechen Rebels Stage Raid Across Border
description: An audacious overnight raid by heavily armed militants in a southern Russian republic neighboring Chechnya killed at least 75 people and wounded dozens more before the fighters withdrew with minimal losses and a cache of captured weapons, officials said Tuesday.

title: Suing Wal-Mart but Still Hoping to Move Up
description: The way Betty Dukes tells it, it is not for lack of trying that she has failed to move up at Wal-Mart Stores. Despite repeatedly asking her managers how she could advance, she says, the jobs she wanted were filled by men time and time again.

description: SAN FRANCISCO — The flags are at half-staff for another couple of weeks, but the mourning for former President Ronald Reagan seems to have come to an end for the likely Democratic presidential nominee, Senator John Kerry.

description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater doesn't need to do too much more these days than just get out onto the stage and move about. It has built a fanatically loyal audience since two burly Dartmouth College students wandered into a dance studio there 33 years ago and never quite left. At its best, the company provides a much-needed breath of fresh air in the somewhat solemn climate of modern dance in New York.

title: Report Says Author Died of Complications From Anesthesia
description: Olivia Goldsmith, the author of the satirical novel that became the successful Hollywood movie ''The First Wives Club,'' died of cardiac arrest while under sedation for cosmetic surgery, the office of the chief medical examiner said late yesterday. While not attributing negligent conduct, the office noted that the death resulted from ''a known complication'' of the anesthesia and other treatment that involved four drugs that the examiner identified.

title: Magboula's Brush With Genocide
description: Meet Magboula Muhammad Khattar and her baby, Nada.

title: State Department Report Shows Increase in Terrorism
description: The State Department announced Tuesday that the number of significant international terrorism episodes rose slightly last year, and that the number of those injured in all international terrorism episodes went up by more than 50 percent. Both trends contradicted earlier findings cited by the Bush administration as evidence that it was winning the campaign against terrorism and later disowned as erroneous.

title: Nielsen Responds To Univision Suit
description: Nielsen Media Research is firing back at Univision Communications, which filed a lawsuit on June 9 seeking to stop Nielsen from changing the way it measures television ratings in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Monday about proposals to change the national anthem referred imprecisely to the presence of the word ''God'' in ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' While it does not appear in the commonly sung first stanza, it does in the fourth (final) stanza.

title: ELECTRONIC CARDS REPLACE COUPONS FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: The Bush administration announced Tuesday that it had completed one of the biggest changes in the history of the food stamp program, replacing paper coupons with electronic benefits and debit cards.

description: AFTER years of relegating food studies to nutrition programs and limiting wine studies to agriculture departments, universities in America and Europe have started taking another look at gastronomy as a serious academic pursuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SERIL, LILLIAN (NEE TRACHTENBERG)
description: SERIL--Lillian (nee Trachtenberg), on Monday, June 21st, 2004 at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Nathan, loving mother to Bobbie and Pearl, and dear stepmother to Zena Carp. Cherished sister to Ada Hinden and Gladys Feigenbaum. Loving grandmother to Sheri, Laura, Nathan and Adam, and great-grandmother to Jared, Aaron and Rachel. Services were held Tuesday.

title: Wild Flavor of the Yukon, Now in the Lower 48
description: SCOURING the upper face of Alaska, the Yukon River flows nearly 2,000 miles before it braids and breaks to the Bering Sea. Its name evokes Jack London, a sweet whiskey and a legendary run of king salmon. Of the three, the salmon is perhaps the least known, but that is about to change.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Wireless Carriers Plan New Data Networks
description: Two major wireless carriers announced plans yesterday to introduce high-speed data networks to keep up with Verizon Wireless and other rivals. Sprint said it planned to spend $1 billion in the next two years to upgrade the speed of its network. The company will spend most of that money in 2005 as it installs EV-DO, or evolution data optimized, service. EV-DO technology allows faster speeds for sending data to and from cellphones. Verizon Wireless, the country's biggest cellphone provider, is already upgrading its network using EV-DO technology. Separately, Cingular Wireless said it would accept bids from telecommunications equipment makers for a high-speed data network using U.M.T.S., or Universal Mobile Telecommunications System, technology. EV-DO and U.M.T.S. let cellphone users download video, music, e-mail and other data at speeds 40 times or more faster than current cellphone connections. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Europe Looks More Closely at Plan for Uranium Venture
description: The European Commission's competition division ramped up its investigation Tuesday into a planned joint venture between Areva, the nuclear power company controlled by the French government, and its counterpart Urenco, which is owned by energy companies in Germany, Holland and Britain. The new investigation is expected to last four months.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Yellow Pages Offer
description: France Tlcom began an initial public offering of its directory unit PagesJaunes, aiming to sell 30 to 43 percent of the company. The sale will contribute to financing the group's buyout of its Internet subsidiary Wanadoo. Shares of PagesJaunes are offered from 13.2 to 15.2 euros ($16 to $18.40) for institutional investors. The offering will be opened to private investors in a price range of 12.9 to 14.9 euros a share. The offering should end on July 6, and trading should begin on July 7, France Tlcom said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

description: What connects Devendra Banhart, Joanna Newsom and Antony are friendships, but also the homegrown-visionary aesthetic peculiar to northern California, and the quavering vibrato voices in various kinds of American folk music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNARDO, LILLIAN (BROWN)
description: BERNARDO--Lillian (Brown), 88, on June 21, 2004. Deeply loved wife of Joseph, mother of Steven (Leslie), Sheldon (Carol), grandmother of Ian, sister of Dora Weinberg, sister-in-law, aunt, friend. Lil embraced life with open arms. She lived each moment to the fullest--whether as teacher to thousands of children, reader and leader of a book club, traveler, playgoer, charity worker for OTR. She was a generous, shining presence for all privileged to know her. Funeral Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, Wednesday 10:00AM. Shiva at the home of Steven and Leslie Bernardo from Wednesday 2PM to Friday 6PM.

title: 'My Life': His True Love Is Politics
description: William Jefferson Clinton's "My Life" is, by a generous measure, the richest American presidential autobiography - no other book tells us as vividly or fully what it is like to be president of the United States for eight years. Clinton had the good sense to couple great smarts with a solid education; he arrived in Washington in 1964 and has been the nation's - or perhaps the world's - No. 1 politics junkie ever since. And he can write - as Reagan, Ford, Nixon and Lyndon B. Johnson, to go no farther back, could not.

title: Spread of Polio in Africa Makes U.N. Fear a Major Epidemic
description: As polio cases surge in Nigeria and the virus spreads to other countries, West and Central Africa are on the brink of the largest polio epidemic in recent years, alarmed officials of the World Health Organization and Unicef said yesterday.

title: Girl, 15, Fatally Shot on Porch of L.I. House
description: A 15-year-old girl sitting with two friends on a front porch was fatally shot late Monday night by a man who rode up on a mountain bike and began shooting, the Nassau County police said on Tuesday.

description: The Corcoran Group, one of the city's largest residential real estate sales firms, announced yesterday that it had purchased Citi Habitats, Manhattan's largest apartment rental company.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on June 8 about the Army's overtaxed combat brigades misstated the number of active-duty combat brigades then in Iraq and Afghanistan, and the total number of such brigades. There were 11 combat brigades in Iraq, not 14, and 1 in Afghanistan, not 2. The Army has 34 combat brigades in all, not 33; 1 was added on May 26. Since the Army can comfortably station no more than about one-third of its combat brigades in front-line positions (including 2 in South Korea), that leaves it roughly 3 brigades short, not 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONNELL, TERENCE
description: CONNELL -- Terence. On June 21, 2004. Owner of T. Connell Piano Movers. Beloved husband of the late Margaret (nee Fallon). Dear brother of Catherine Hubbard and the late Elizabeth Lennon and John Connell. Visiting Thursday, 9:30AM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial to follow 11 AM, at St. Patrick's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNOR, JOHN JOSEPH
description: O'CONNOR -- John Joseph. Passed into eternity on June 21, 2004. Veteran of the United States Coast Guard. Longtime worker of the landmark P. J. Clarke's. Survived by his niece Maureen and her husband Eric and one great niece Colleen and one great nephew Daniel. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd. on Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: GUIDANT TO DOUBLE SIZE OF ITS OPERATIONS IN IRELAND
description: The Guidant Corporation, a medical device manufacturer, will double the size of its operations in Ireland by hiring an additional 1,000 employees starting in 2005, the company said. The new employees, who will work at a factory that has not been built yet, will make drug-coated stents to prevent arteries from becoming reblocked after surgery. Mary Harney, Ireland's minister for enterprise and trade, said in a radio interview that Guidant already spends 80 million euros on wages at its base in County Tipperary, where it makes defibrillators and pacemakers. Guidant is based in Indianapolis. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Kerry's Long Flight to Say 'Aye' Runs Into a Storm of G.O.P. Delays
description: How far would a presidential candidate travel in one day to not cast a vote on an issue critical to his campaign? For Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts on Tuesday, the journey was 3,910 miles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAVIN, THEODORA
description: ZAVIN--Theodora, 82, on June 21, 2004, wife of the late Benjamin Zavin. She will be greatly missed by her surviving sons, Jonathan and Joshua, her daughters-inlaw Bernadette and Joanne, her grandchildren, Kate, Nathaniel, and Ryan, her sister-in-law, Fredda, and by a world of people, in and out of the music business who treasured her as a colleague, a mentor and a friend.

title: Unruly Scorn Leaves Room For Restraint, But Not a Lot
description: Respect for the president is a longstanding American tradition and one that is still very much alive, as the weeklong national obsequies for Ronald Reagan recently proved. But there is also an opposing tradition of holding up our presidents, especially while they are in office, to ridicule and scorn.

description: WASHINGTON, June 23 — President Bush today made another trip to Pennsylvania, a politically vital state, where he announced that Vietnam was being added to the list of countries in the administration's AIDS-relief program.

title: Truffles With Surprises Inside
description: Tucked among the mountains of green peppers and walls of olive oils at Fairway are sleek, dark boxes of fine chocolates made by Oriol Balaguer, an award-winning pastry chef who works with Ferran Adri at El Bulli, the avant-garde restaurant in Catalonia. A flat box, Collection 12, holds a dozen elegant oval truffles ($19.99), above, with shiny chocolate coatings and fillings that include cardamom, saffron, coffee and whiskey. Another box, Luxor Crujiente ($16.99), is triangular, like a Toblerone, and inside, deep dark chocolate enrobes a crunchy foot-long bar of hazelnut and chocolate.

title: AT&T to Stop Competing in 7 States After Ruling on Fees
description: TCorporation"/>AT&T Corp. said today that it would stop marketing its local and long distance telephone services to residents in seven states in response to the Bush administration's decision this month not to block Bell phone companies from raising their interconnection fees.

description: SAVITZ--Fannie, June 22, 2004, at the age of 90, beloved wife of the late Samuel, dearest mother and mother-inlaw, devoted sister and sisterin-law, doting grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Wednesday, June 23, 12 noon, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91 Street.

title: 4 Rivals Near Agreement on Ways to Fight Spam
description: Four large Internet service providers agreed yesterday to a partial truce in their battle with one another over potential technology to stop junk e-mail in hopes that they can devote their united energy to fighting spam.

description: FRIEDMAN--Melvin J. Born September 12, 1920 and died June 22, 2004, of Rye Brook, NY. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Gary, Harvey and Carol. Loving grandfather to Andrea, Mitchell, Nicole, Josh, Amanda, Molly, Joanna and Laura. Dear brother of Larry and Alice. We will miss him dearly. A memorial service will take place on June 24, 2004 at 1:30PM. Call Parkside Memorial Chapels at 914937-4888 for details. title: Federal Law On Sentencing Is Unjust, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in Boston ruled on Monday that federal sentencing laws were unconstitutional because they gave prosecutors too much power.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Partners Raises Profit Forecast
description: Nextel Partners, which sells a combined mobile-phone and walkie-talkie service, raised its 2004 profit forecast yesterday, citing solid operational trends without being more specific. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, will rise to $340 million, exceeding a previous prediction of $325 million, Nextel Partners said. The company did not estimate net income. In April, Nextel, which is based in Kirkland, Wash., reported first-quarter net income of $4.65 million, its first-ever profit as a public company. Shares of Nextel Partners rose 23 cents, to $15.56.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidences Rises
description: German investor confidence rose slightly in June, according to a survey released by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research. The institute's index, which measures expectations for economic growth, rose for the first time in six months, to 47.4 in June, after dropping to 46.4 points in May. The center expressed disappointment about the June outcome. ''While it is good news that the downward trend in the economic sentiment has stopped for the present, hopes of a marked pickup have not been fulfilled, though some fundamental data point to an economic recovery,'' the center said in a statement. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: U.S. Prosecutor Says Lawyer Aided Terror
description: Lynne F. Stewart used her position as a defense lawyer to create an illegal channel of communication out of a Minnesota prison cell that allowed her client, an imprisoned Muslim cleric, to summon his Egyptian followers to terrorism, a federal prosecutor said yesterday.

description: Just what is Europe?

title: National Briefing | West: California: Mistrial In Murder Case
description: With the jury deadlocked after 10 days of deliberations, a judge in Hayward declared a mistrial in the case of three men accused of murder in the killing of a 17-year-old boy who lived as a girl. The prosecutors said the defendants would remain in jail, pending a new trial. The men, Michael Magidson, Jose Merel and Jason Cazares, were charged in the beating and strangulation death in October 2002 of the boy, Eddie Araujo Jr., who went by the name Gwen Araujo. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: For Dessert, No Eggs Allowed
description: PANNA COTTA may be an Italian invention, but the idea of thickening sweetened cream with gelatin has spread far and wide.

title: For Iraq's Shiites, Faith Knows No Borders
description: While Iraq's Sunni Muslims continue their insurgency and the Kurds threaten to secede, America at least seems to have reached an accord with the country's largest group, the Shiites. The most respected religious figure, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, has approved of the Shiite-led transition government set to take over in Baghdad next week, and the militias loyal to the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr have peacefully abandoned their occupation of the holy cities of Karbala and Najaf.

title: Say Cheese, and New England Smiles
description: WEARING a white hairnet and a telephone headset as he walked around his cheese making room at Jasper Hill Farm in the wilds of the Northeast Kingdom of Vermont, Mateo Kehler looked like a muscular version of Lily Tomlin's Ernestine the telephone operator. The hairnet keeps things neat. But the headset? ''The phone never stops ringing,'' he said. It's all those people trying to buy some of his limited output of creamy raw-milk Constant Bliss, sharp Bayley Hazen blue and gentler Bartlett blue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINSON, JOSEPHINE
description: ROBINSON--Josephine. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Man Is Sentenced In Murder Of Neighbor
description: Stephen Manolis, an East Northport man convicted of strangling a 16-year-old honor student who lived next door, was sentenced yesterday in Suffolk County Court to 25 years to life in prison. After two trials, Mr. Manolis, 44, was convicted last month of second-degree murder in the 1996 strangulation of Kristin Scarabelli. The jury in his first trial deadlocked. The police identified him as a suspect early on, but did not arrest him until more than five years later. John Collins, Suffolk County's chief homicide prosecutor, linked him to the murder using DNA analysis that did not exist in 1996. Julia C. Mead (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Loss Narrows
description: The 3Com Corporation, which makes switches that run corporate data networks, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed as it snapped a five-year drop in sales. The shares rose in extended trading. The net loss in the period that ended May 28 narrowed to $18.7 million, or 5 cents a share, from $38 million, or 11 cents a share, a year earlier, 3Com said. Sales grew 4.8 percent to $183.3 million, the first gain since early 1999. The chief financial officer, Mark Slaven, will resign, the company said. Shares of 3Com rose 11 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $6.97 in extended trading. They rose 40 cents, to $6.86, in regular trading.

title: Clayton Kirkpatrick, 89, Editor Who Changed Chicago Tribune
description: Clayton Kirkpatrick, a former editor of The Chicago Tribune who presided over a sweeping transformation of the newspaper's editorial approach, died Saturday at his home in Glen Ellyn, Ill., a suburb of Chicago. He was 89.

title: Reviews of Guantnamo Detainees to Begin Soon, Navy Says
description: The secretary of the Navy said today that annual reviews of detainees at the Guantanamo Bay military prison in Cuba would begin within a matter of weeks, a process to determine whether they should be released or continue to be held as a "threat to America."

title: United Submits Third Request For Assistance To Loan Board
description: Five days after its last bid was rejected, United Airlines filed a revised application with a federal loan board yesterday, its third attempt to win assistance that would help it emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Files Show Rumsfeld Rejected Some Efforts to Toughen Prison Rules
description: Beginning in late 2002, a top general and a Pentagon working group sought permission to use much harsher interrogation techniques against Qaeda and Taliban prisoners than Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld ultimately approved, according to newly released documents.

title: Some Pupils Feel Squeezed Out By City's Small-Schools Program
description: ON the last day of music class, Francesca Bonfiglio sat in the chorus room of Celia Cruz High School in the Bronx, listening to the sound of success. Her teacher was playing back a recording of the student choir's performance at a recent statewide competition. The ensemble had won a gold medal, the highest ranking possible, and Miss Bonfiglio, 15, had taken the lead vocal in the gospel standard ''Rock-a My Soul.'' Those accolades came on top of the citation for excellence that she had earned a few months earlier for her solo recital.

title: What's Not on Tom DeLay's Summer Reading List
description: An estimated 1.5 million people have ordered advance copies of Bill Clinton's memoir , "My Life," which was officially released on Tuesday. Representative Tom DeLay , the House majority leader, is not among them.

title: Sonya Haddad, 67, Translator For Met Opera's Titling System
description: Sonya Haddad, who did opera translations for the Metropolitan's seat-back subtitling system, died on June 15 in the Bronx. She was 67 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Expansion Does Little To Affect Knicks or Nets
description: Rod Thorn excused himself twice during lunch. Thorn, the Nets' president, was looking at his cellphone and waiting to see which players would be selected by the Charlotte Bobcats in Tuesday's expansion draft.

title: In Champagne's Shadow, the Sun Shines
description: AMERICAN wines almost all bear a burden, but none more so than sparkling wines. Cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay and pinot noir all have French ancestors with which they have been endlessly compared. Only zinfandel, a wine that has reached prominence only in the United States, is exempt from the French albatross.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a book party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the release of ''My Life,'' by Bill Clinton, misspelled the surnames of four guests in some copies and omitted the given name of another, a television host. Among the guests were the broadcaster Robert MacNeil, not McNeil; the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., not Schlessinger; Maurice Tempelsman, not Templesman (who is a former companion of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis); and the writer Calvin Trillin, not Trilling. The television host was Star Jones, of ''The View,'' on ABC.

title: Sustenance for Anglophiles and Tennis Fans
description: I AM not the most sporty person in the world, but as an English person, I feel I should make the effort to watch Wimbledon. Patriotism doesn't confer many benefits when it comes to tennis, however, because even with my hazy knowledge of the game, I know we haven't provided any actual champions at the All England club in a long time. But still, watching and complaining is a national pastime.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FELD, ISABEL
description: FELD--Isabel. 1/23/2000. My darling & unforgettable, precious wife and lover for more than 60 years, I love you and miss you, not a day goes by that I don't think of you and cry for you and for me. Harold Feld

description: In a security operation ahead of President Bush's visit to Turkey this weekend, the Ankara police detained 12 people suspected of links with an illegal radical Islamic organization, the news media reported. Mr. Bush is to arrive in Ankara on Saturday and join the NATO summit meeting in Istanbul next Monday and Tuesday. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Lollapalooza Tour Canceled Amid Weak Concert Season
description: In a blow to the summer concert season already hurt by the loss of big tours by Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera, the touring Lollapalooza festival has been canceled because of poor ticket sales, the festival organizers said yesterday.

title: Senate Votes To Restore Media Limits
description: The Senate voted on Tuesday to repeal rules adopted by the Federal Communications Commission that make it easier for the nation's largest media conglomerates to expand and enter new markets.

title: 'Fahrenheit' Ads Use the Fuss the Film Is Causing
description: After picking its way through a minefield that included everything from finding a distributor to a battle over its rating, Michael Moore's documentary ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' opens in Manhattan today and in about 850 theaters nationwide on Friday. Attacked by the right as anti-military and praised by the left for its critique of the Bush administration, it is being marketed as the summer's must-see cinematic controversy, both entertaining and contentious.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- NoHo; A Neighborhood Rarity: New Offices
description: In a part of Manhattan where office buildings date to the first half of the 20th century or are carved from even-older industrial structures, a developer is putting up the first large speculative office building to be built near Houston Street in decades. And the developer says it has succeeded in leasing more than two-thirds of the office space, even though occupancy is months away.

title: Sandwiches, With or Without the Bread
description: On Eighth Avenue near Times Square, a part of the city where subway has more than one meaning, Eban Ross, left, hopes to improve the sandwich options. Mr. Ross, a chef who worked with Michel Richard at Citrus in Los Angeles, has opened Carve, 760 Eighth Avenue (47th Street), a gleaming baby-blue-and-white spot. Fine ingredients like applewood smoked bacon, turkey cooked on a rotisserie and fresh tuna crusted with ginger and sesame are piled on fresh breads, or, for those counting carbs, wrapped in lettuce. Sandwiches are $5 to $9; soups, salads and breakfast items are also available.

title: A Miracle That Transforms Three Blind Lives
description: The sentiment repeated like a mantra in ''Born to Be Blind,'' a years-in-the-making documentary portrait of three sisters, blind from birth, who sing and play the ganza on the streets of Campina Grande, Brazil, expresses the kind of religious fatalism that often accompanies a life of hardship and poverty.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Musician Killed
description: A former member of the iconic South African a cappella group Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Ben Shabalala, was shot and killed in Durban on June 16, the band's business manager said. The police have not identified a suspect. Mr. Shabalala sang alto in the 10-member group from the late 1970's to 1993, when he left to start his own business. He was one of the singers who made a major contribution to the 1986 hit album ''Graceland,'' by the American singer Paul Simon, which critics say played a crucial role in introducing American listeners to international music. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: For a Classic, Another Shade Of Elegance

Closer by, a glum-looking couple sat, and chewed, in silence. Suddenly, there was a flurry of movement: a tipsy, teetering man knocked over the little lamp on his table and sent it hurtling over the edge.
