title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VISCARDI, JANE A.
description: VISCARDI--Jane A. On June 22, 2004, of Guttenberg, NJ. Beloved daughter of the late John P. & Anna. Loving sister of John P. Jr. and Catherine, & the late Peter & Raymond. Cherished aunt of many nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial. St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, NY, 10AM, Thursday. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: From Iowa, Sophisticated Sweetness
description: AT Keen's Steakhouse in Midtown, keeping pace with the hip and the new is simply not a priority. The wood-paneled and etched-glass dcor dates from the Gay Nineties -- the 1890's, that is. The restaurant's private room is named after the actress Lillie Langtry, who was a regular in 1905. And there is mutton on the menu.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In Gun Trafficking
description: An immigrant from Kazakhstan who sold 37 guns to undercover officers in the Bronx and Queens over the past year was arrested yesterday on charges of weapons trafficking, the police said. The suspect, Serguei Volochenko, met with officers several times, always armed, and once pulled his gun in an argument over money, the police said. He also volunteered his services as a hit man and offered the use of his boat to dispose of murder victims. He was arrested at his apartment in Queens, where officers found five weapons, one loaded gun and 1,300 rounds of ammunition. The detectives purchased 31 handguns, two shotguns, two rifles and two machine pistols over the course of the investigation. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Iran Hints It May Free 8 Britons Seized on Boats
description: Widening a diplomatic rift with Britain, Iran said Tuesday that it was still deciding whether to free eight British sailors and marines it had arrested Monday, but indicated that the men could be freed shortly.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about an anti-American demonstration in Seoul, South Korea, misstated the purpose. The marchers opposed the government's decision to send troops to Iraq; they did not demand the withdrawal of American troops from South Korea.

title: To the Fringes of Space
description: The successful launching of a tiny rocket ship into space on Monday leaves us wondering whether we have just witnessed something akin to the Wright brothers' first rickety flight or Charles Lindbergh's pioneering solo trip across the Atlantic. Or was this simply an oddball achievement like ballooning around the world? Although some commentators say the flight may open a new era of space commercialization, its most likely impact will be on tourism. The flight seems quite likely to advance the day when well-heeled individuals will be able to take vacation flights into the fringes of space when they are bored with Antarctica or trekking through the Himalayas.

title: INSIDE
description: New U.S. Proposals Aim to Sway North Korea

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Death-Row Inmate Released
description: Ryan Matthews, sentenced to die for the 1997 murder of a grocer in a New Orleans suburb, has been released from prison pending a new trial. Last year, lawyers for Mr. Matthews said that DNA tests on a ski mask at the crime scene excluded him but matched another inmate. Mr. Matthews, who was released on Friday, was the second Louisiana death-row inmate to be freed in a week. On June 14, Dan L. Bright, convicted of a 1995 murder, was freed when the Orleans Parish district attorney rejected a new trial after the State Supreme Court overturned his conviction on the ground that prosecutors withheld evidence. Katy Reckdahl (NYT)

title: Doing Comedy Straight (As Far as It's Possible)
description: The correct size, for the record, is 54 triple E. But filling the bra of Edna Turnblad, the bigger-than-life housewife from the hit Broadway musical ''Hairspray,'' is more than a matter of physical dimensions. Padded lingerie can take a fellow only so far in redefining the role for which Harvey Fierstein received a Tony Award last year. Any actor who tackles Edna must find the heart beneath the fat suit.

title: Sports of The Times; Junior's Neighbors Under Cloud
description: FOR a few years, the dark cloud hung over Junior's house. His neighbor Tiger was winning golf tournaments and his neighbor Shaq was winning basketball championships. Junior was mostly accumulating a vast dossier of X-ray charts.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEXFOR INC., Toronto, a maker of a plywood substitute used in homebuilding, said it had agreed to buy the wood-panel unit of Agglo NV, a Belgian maker of oriented strand board and particleboard, for $60 million.

title: Saying 'economic expectations are much brighter,' a longtime forecaster raises his spending estimates.
description: A LEADING forecaster of advertising spending raised his estimates for 2004 yesterday, citing the improving economy, and offered an optimistic outlook in his first assessment of 2005.

title: The Next Stop for the Subway Is a Fully Automated Future; Testing a Computer-Controlled Train Line
description: The subway of the future was rumbling back and forth on the Canarsie line in Brooklyn the other day. Not sleek or silent, it seemed no different from any other train. But its innards set it apart, making it groundbreaking for a transit agency long dogged by a Luddite image.

title: Group That Killed Hostage Threatens Iraqi Prime Minister
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 23  The foreign terrorist group that took responsibility for beheading a South Korean hostage turned its sights on the new Iraqi prime minister today, issuing a statement in which it threatened to assassinate him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANTROWITZ, DEBORAH (NEE STARR)
description: KANTROWITZ -- Deborah (nee Starr) of Fort Lee, NJ and Palm Beach, Fla died on Monday, June 21, 2004, after a long illness. She is survived by her beloved husband, S. Edward Kantrowitz: children Pam & Matt Gladstein, Lori & Chuck Ludmer, Jamie & Mark Lorberbaum; grandchildren, Nicole, Barry, Scott, Carly & Matt; sister, Judy Smith; brother & sister-in-law Stanley & Iris Starr; Penny, Peaches & the late Boo. She was a member of Brandeis, Hadassah and the National Council of Jewish Women. In lieu of flowers, donations to either Hospice of Englewood Hospital or Sloan Kettering Hospital would be appreciated. Services are today, 10:00am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Revised Report Finds Increase in Terrorism
description: The State Department said the number of significant international terrorism episodes rose last year, contradicting an early report of a downward trend. The White House had cited that report as evidence it was winning its fight against terrorism, but disowned it after finding it was based on erroneous statistics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LABES, LEON M.
description: LABES--Leon M. Died June 23, 1989. I love you and miss you. Your Son, Steve

title: A Politician Looking for Funds? Here Are Two Useful Addresses
description: The office building at 865 South Figueroa in downtown Los Angeles is a fairly typical high-rise, but inside the plain reddish-brown tower is the headquarters of an investment management company that handles roughly $90 billion in assets.

title: USA Today to Raise Price
description: USA Today, the Gannett Company paper that is the country's largest newspaper by circulation, will raise its single-copy price to 75 cents on Sept. 7, the publisher, Craig A. Moon, said yesterday. It will be the paper's first price increase in 19 years.

title: Bernard S. Baker, 67, a Pioneer In the Development of Fuel Cells
description: Bernard S. Baker, a chemical engineer whose research and entrepreneurial instincts spurred the development of large stationary fuel cells for industry, died on Monday at the Bethel Health Care Center in Bethel, Conn. He was 67.

title: Ferreira, in 55th Major, Becomes Game's Iron Man
description: Despite the fact that the umpire announces the score after every point, tennis is not as much of a numbers game as some sports with similarly lengthy histories, like baseball. Statistics have limited value in tennis, in which patterns of play and big-point nerves are often the decisive factors. Because the main events, the Grand Slams, were open only to so-called amateurs until 1968, it is no straightforward task to compare achievements across eras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENSTERN, EDWARD
description: MORGENSTERN -- Edward, suddenly on June 17, 2004. A dear friend. Will be remembered always and sorely missed by all whose lives he touched. Taught us all to live, live, live. Warren, Ralph, Bryan, Gary, Fred

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Develop New Fiber Optic Lines
description: SBC Communications said yesterday that it intends to spend $4 billion to $6 billion over the next five years to deploy fiber optic lines capable of delivering next-generation television, Internet and voice services. The company said the deployment would be contingent on whether regulatory rules remain intact that would not force SBC -- and other regional Bell operating companies -- to lease their networks to competitors at low rates set by states. The company said that once the regulatory rules were clarified, it would deploy a network designed to deliver high-definition television, high-speed Internet service, and telephone calls delivered via the Internet through technology known as VOIP. SBC said it was already testing various applications of the network, including working with Microsoft to create digital television services. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Molson Says It Might Sell Stake in Brazilian Unit
description: The Molson Companies, Canada's biggest brewer, may seek a buyer for its 80 percent stake in the Brazilian brewer Cervejarias Kaiser unless Kaiser's fortunes improve markedly by January, Molson's chief executive, Daniel J. O'Neill, said at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday.

title: Follow The Aroma
description: HERE are some of the best New England cheese makers, and some of their best:

title: Sense and Nonsense: Legislature's Last Day
description: On this week's Tin-Cup Tuesday, so called because people from across the state come on that day during legislative sessions to beg lawmakers to pass their pet projects, two people dressed as grapes were seen wandering the hall of the State Capitol. They were not shilling for Fruit of the Loom underwear, but for a law that would allow New York's grocery stores to sell wine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, JACK L.
description: GREEN--Jack L. The Officers and Directors for the Friars Foundation deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Board member, Jack L. Green. A major force for the Foundation, Jackie was a loyal and dedicated proponent of fostering the performing arts and carried out our mission with determined passion. We value his guidance and applaud his hard work. He will be dearly missed, but the legacy of his commitment lives on and for that we are truly indebted. Leo Greenland, Chairman Cy Leslie, President

title: Confessions of a Policy Wonk
description: William Jefferson Clinton's "My Life" is, by a generous measure, the richest American presidential autobiography - no other book tells us as vividly or fully what it is like to be president of the United States for eight years. Clinton had the good sense to couple great smarts with a solid education; he arrived in Washington in 1964 and has been the nation's - or perhaps the world's - No. 1 politics junkie ever since. And he can write - as Reagan, Ford, Nixon and Lyndon B. Johnson, to go no farther back, could not.

title: Contreras Is Reunited With Family
description: Jos Contreras left the Yankees on Tuesday for a journey that promised to be his happiest since defecting from Cuba. He flew to Miami to see his wife and two daughters, who defected there on Monday, for a family reunion 20 months in the making.

title: A Blow to Health Plan Patients
description: The Supreme Court seems to have made the right legal judgment this week when it ruled that patients cannot sue in state courts when their managed care plans refuse to pay for treatments ordered by doctors. The nine justices' unanimous decision, expressed in majority and concurring opinions, left no room for doubt that a federal law known as Erisa, which governs employment-based health plans, pre-empts any effort by the states to give patients the right to sue for damages.

title: Mavs Pursue O'Neal; McGrady Deal Hits a Snag
description: On a day when the Charlotte Bobcats fleshed out their inaugural roster through the expansion draft, the buzz around the National Basketball Association continued to revolve around Shaquille O'Neal and Tracy McGrady, the superstars who have asked their teams for trades.

title: CARLYLE GROUP SELLS 6 OFFICE BUILDINGS IN EUROPE
description: The Carlyle Group, a Washington investment company, said yesterday that it had sold six European properties for 253 million euros ($306 million), 60 percent more than it spent to buy and refurbish the buildings. Carlyle, which has real estate, buyout and venture capital funds, sold five buildings in Paris and one in Milan. Carlyle used bank loans and a 430 million euro fund it closed last year to buy the buildings in 2001 and 2002.

title: Breaking Chops, Not Bread
description: In a move that had the political world buzzing, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has delivered the back of his hand to Representative Bob Ney, an important Republican from rural Ohio. As the G.O.P. convention in August draws near, Mr. Ney was looking forward to a political power lunch this week at the mayor's Upper East Side town house. But he was disinvited right after he voted against a $446 million proposal to help New York and other high-risk areas fight terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, BEN, DR.
description: BERNSTEIN--Ben, Dr. We mourn the loss of a cherished and longtime friend. A Diamond Founder of the Medical Center, his outstretched hand of kindness made a vital difference to the health care needs of the people of Jerusalem. He will be deeply missed. Sincerest condolences to the members of his family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: What's Not on Tom DeLay's Summer Reading List
description: An estimated 1.5 million people have ordered advance copies of Bill Clinton's memoir , "My Life," which was officially released on Tuesday. Representative Tom DeLay , the House majority leader, is not among them.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Plea In Bribery Case
description: Joseph Barry, left, a well-known developer of housing on the Hoboken and Jersey City waterfronts, pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court to charges of paying more than $100,000 in bribes to Robert C. Janiszewski, the former Hudson County executive, in exchange for his pushing through state and federal grants to aid Mr. Barry's housing developments. Mr. Barry, 64, former president of Applied Companies of Hoboken, was caught discussing the bribes on a recording device secretly worn by Mr. Janiszewski, who himself had been caught on tape accepting bribes from someone else. Mr. Barry pleaded guilty in a plea agreement to four counts of bribing Mr. Janiszewski and agreed to pay $1 million in restitution to the funding agencies. Under the agreement he faces up to 30 months in prison. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Small Bites
description: Ideal Cheese Shop, founded by Ed Edelman in 1954, has new owners, among them, Michael Binetti, above. The store is celebrating its 50th anniversary this Friday and Saturday by selling all cheeses, including some new artisanal ones, and other dairy products at a 20 percent discount. The store is at 942 First Avenue (52nd Street).

title: U.S. to Offer North Korea Incentives in Nuclear Talks
description: President Bush has authorized a team of American negotiators to offer North Korea, in talks in Beijing on Thursday, a new but highly conditional set of incentives to give up its nuclear weapons programs the way Libya did late last year, according to senior administration officials.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charter School Loses Fight
description: The trustees of the State University of New York declined yesterday to reverse a February decision to shut down a Harlem charter school. Parents and officials of the John A. Reisenbach Charter School had hoped the board of trustees would reconsider after City Councilwoman Eva Moskowitz, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, and others came to the support of the school. The decision came after critical remarks were made on Monday by James D. Merriman, the executive director of the Charter Schools Institute, an advisory panel that assists the board. Mr. Merriman said he had found the school's leaders unable to articulate even the basic mission of the school in a coherent and consistent fashion. Alex Mindlin (NYT)

title: Make a Meal Out of Bar Food (Sake Bar, That Is)
description: NEW YORK'S restaurant entrepreneurs come in all sizes. Usually the big ones get all the attention, whether Jean-Georges Vongerichten's latest extravaganza in the Time Warner Center, Steve Hanson's opening of yet another money machine or Danny Meyer's coming Shake Shack in Madison Square Park.

title: National Briefing | West: California: No Charges For Convicted Predator
description: Santa Clara County authorities decided not to seek charges against a convicted sexual predator who failed last week to meet a state deadline to register with the police. The man, Cary Verse, who struggled to find housing after being released from a program for violent predators, could have faced 25 years to life in prison had he been charged. Deputy District Attorney Victoria Brown said Mr. Verse mistakenly thought he had complied with the registration requirement by notifying the San Jose police that his motel room number had changed. ''We believe he followed the spirit of the law,'' Ms. Brown said. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TENENBAUM, SUSAN
description: TENENBAUM -- Susan. On June 21, 2004. Beloved wife of Mircea, devoted mother of Rodica and Radu, and mother-in-law of Steven Dreisin, and Kathryn Hammer. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra, Rafi, and Philip. Memorial service Thursday 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to The Neighborhood Music School, 100 Audubon Street, New Haven, CT 06511

title: Dancers Sharing Space With City Dwellers
description: Achoreographer known for his site-specific dances is on stairways now - the most sweeping, monumental ones to be found around New York. On June 17 that choreographer, Stephan Koplowitz, chose the stairs in front of the New York Public Library at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue for the latest installment of "The Grand Step Project."

title: National Briefing | Washington: Campaign-Finance Complaint
description: Campaign-finance activists filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission against a Democratic advocacy group, America Coming Together, or ACT. Thegroups filing the complaint -- Democracy 21, the Campaign Legal Center and the Center for Responsive Politics -- say ACT improperly paid for expenses using soft money, unlimited contributions from wealthy donors. Officials at ACT say they have done nothing improper. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: U.S. Offers North Korea Aid if It Phases Out Nuclear Program
description: BEIJING, June 23  The United States today presented North Korea with a proposal for phasing out its nuclear program in exchange for aid and security guarantees, as senior Bush administration officials acknowledged softening their hard-line stance to jump-start negotiations with Pyongyang.

title: Toxic Release Increased In 2002, Study Says
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said on Tuesday that the amount of toxic chemicals released into the environment increased by 5 percent in 2002, only the second time conditions grew worse since the yearly Toxic Release Inventory began in 1987.

title: State Senators Stall Approval Of City Rebates
description: The $400 property tax rebate for homeowners that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council have agreed on hit a speed bump in Albany yesterday when the State Senate decided not to allow the city to enact the plan until the long-delayed state budget is approved.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Flight To Rwanda
description: One of the two renegade military officers from Congo that seized the town of Bukavu earlier this month sought refuge in neighboring Rwanda with about 300 of his men to escape pursuing Congolese government troops, officials said. Congo has accused Rwanda of supporting the rogue officer, Col. Jules Mutebusi, a charge Rwanda denies. Together with Gen. Laurent Nkunda, Colonel Mutebusi has refused to join a unified army in Congo made up of former rebel forces. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Amid an Apartment Glut, Building Prices Move Up
description: Like many cities, Dallas has suffered from a glut of apartments in recent years as low interest rates have turned many renters into home buyers and a weak job market has forced young tenants to double up or live with their parents. With vacancy rates in Dallas at 10 percent or so, rents have continued to drop and landlords have been forced to offer inducements like a month or more of free rent or department store gift certificates to attract tenants.

title: A Trinity of Videos for One Religious Rap
description: Mel Gibson, it turns out, is not the only entertainer with a passion for Christ. Before a small gathering of music-industry insiders and record executives on Monday night at the TriBeCa Screening Room, Kanye West, a popular rapper, held a premiere for the three music videos (yes, three) that he plans to release with ''Jesus Walks,'' the third single from his multiplatinum debut album, ''College Dropout.''

title: The 'Evidence' for War (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Historical Society Shifts Focus With Its Shift in Leadership
description: Correction Appended

title: Seoul Says Killing Won't Alter Plans for Iraq
description: South Korea condemned the beheading of a Korean hostage in Iraq as an ''inhuman act of terror,'' and vowed Wednesday to go ahead with sending 3,000 more troops to Iraq this summer. But officials also braced for planned street protests on Wednesday against the increasingly unpopular troop deployment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, DIANE
description: YOUNG--Diane. Died on June 22, 2004. Beloved wife of Irwin. Devoted mother of Nancy Young, M.D. and Linda Young and mother-in-law of Mitch Marinello. Cherished grandmother of Samantha, Lindsey and Michelle. Loving sister of Arthur Nalven. She was an officer and director of Du Art Film and Video Laboratories, in New York City. Services Thursday, 11 AM, at The Community Synagogue of Sands Point, 150 Middle Neck Rd, Pt Washington, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Warns Loss Possible
description: Shares of Swiss International Air Lines fell 5.3 percent to a six-week low after the carrier said that it might post an operating loss this year because of a sharp increase in fuel prices. Fuel prices might increase costs by 85 million Swiss francs ($68 million), the carrier said. Swiss International has had losses of more than 1.3 billion Swiss francs since it was created in a government-led bailout in March 2002. It has cut 3,000 jobs since the start of 2003 to reduce costs and cut fares to attract more travelers.

title: 10 Million Women Who Lack a Cervix Still Get Pap Tests
description: As many as 10 million women who have had hysterectomies and who no longer have a cervix are still getting Pap tests, a new study finds.

title: PARMALAT FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION IN NEW YORK
description: Parmalat, Italy's biggest food company, filed for bankruptcy protection in New York yesterday to shield assets from creditors while the company tries to reorganize in Italy. The filing was made by Enrico Bondi, the commissioner overseeing Parmalat's bankruptcy in Italy. Two Parmalat subsidiaries, the Parmalat USA Corporation and Parmalat Capital Finance Ltd., filed their own bankruptcies in New York this year. Parmalat, which is based in Milan and makes products like Archway cookies and long-life milk, sought bankruptcy in Italy in December after the company could not document about 9 billion euros ($11.4 billion) it had claimed to have.

title: Our Towns; Tales of Woe (Where Youth Isn't Served)
description: IF William Shakespeare were writing from Stratford, Conn., rather than his home turf in England, he would be enthralled by the tale of charm and hubris, success and failure, avarice and ambition -- how a young man with great natural gifts rose so far, so fast, in politics, then, with his success seemingly assured, threw it all away for a seamy buffet of financial bonbons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGWAY, WALTER E.
description: LANGWAY--Walter E., 92, of Rocky Point, L.I. and Palm Harbor, FL died June 15 in Florida after a long illness. With a Ph.D. from New York University, he had a long career as an executive in the New York State Employment Service and a professor at the St. John's University graduate school of business. He never lost his lively spirit and his delight in helping others. He volunteered as an advisor to small businesses with the Service Corps of Retired Executives (SCORE) and the National Association of Suggestion Systems. He is survived by his daughter, Lynn Langway, as well as three nephews--Robert, Richard and Stephen--two nieces, Susan and Laura and their children.

title: Fast Track at the Airport
description: The idea behind the government's proposed ''registered traveler'' program is simple enough. If you agree to submit to a government background check to get a special ID card that contains a reading of your iris and fingerprints so your identity can be verified, you'll have access to a faster lane at airport security checkpoints. But, of course, nothing involving the federal government and large databases ever turns out to be simple. That is why the Transportation Security Administration is only now preparing to test the program at five airports, even though the idea was first floated in the immediate aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSKOW, MARGARET KAREN
description: JOSKOW--Margaret Karen. On June 21, after a brave struggle with bladder cancer at the age of 53. Beloved wife of Rafael Yglesias and mother of Matthew and Nicholas, cherished daughter of Jules and Charlotte Joskow and sister of Paul and Barbara, Andrew and Lisa. Services will be held on Thursday, June 24 at 11 AM at The Angel Orensantz Foundation, 172 Norfolk St. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Gilda's Club New York City, 195 Houston Street, NYC 10014.

title: Getting Into History by Getting Into Character
description: Natasha Gill's classroom crackles with tension. Sixteen Barnard and Columbia College students debate a 1790 law turning priests into employees of the revolutionary French government. Each student clutches a copy of Rousseau's ''Social Contract'' and struggles to make a persuasive case with eloquence, apt quotation and chutzpah.

title: Salesforce Raises $110 Million After Delay
description: Salesforce.com Inc., a maker of Internet-based sales software, raised $110 million in an initial public offering yesterday.

title: Empty Seats Unfilled At Top High Schools
description: The new high school admissions system in New York City has left dozens of seats for the coming school year unfilled in some of the city's most sought-after schools, according to admissions data and interviews with principals and other school personnel.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: ILO, the restaurant in the Bryant Park Hotel, will close next Wednesday after a three-year run. Plans are for it to move downtown and to keep its chef, RICK LAAKKONEN. The restaurant in the hotel is to reopen in November after a renovation by DAVID ROCKWELL, with a Chinese menu prepared by YUJI WAKIYA, a Japanese chef. Mr. Wakiya, who has restaurants in Tokyo, is a friend of the chef NOBU MATSUHISA, who will own and run the restaurant, tentatively named YUJI; backers include ROBERT DE NIRO.

title: U.S. Resolution Is Reworded To Keep Immunity for Troops
description: The United States circulated a reworded resolution among Security Council members on Tuesday evening to try to overcome broad opposition to its effort to keep its troops immune from any prosecution by the International Criminal Court.

title: When the Fetus Is Abnormal . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday about a seven-part documentary called ''N.Y.P.D. 24/7'' gave a misspelled surname at two points for a New York police detective who was the central figure in the first episode. He is Stephen DiSchiavi, not DeSchiavi.

title: In Presidential Politics, Where the Donors Are
description: By plotting the addresses of donors to presidential campaigns and the national party committees on a map, patterns of giving emerge. Data from the Federal Election Commission show apartment buildings, offices and other addresses where the occupants have given tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars to support the candidates. MATTHEW ERICSON

title: Miscellany
description: Creative Partners, Stamford, Conn., acquired and absorbed Emmanuel Kerr Kilsby, Stamford, a public relations agency, for undisclosed terms. Nick Kilsby, president at Emmanuel Kerr, was named director of the public relations division of Creative Partners, a new post.

title: Amendment's Backers Try Again on Same-Sex Marriages
description: Though a constitutional amendment that would ban same-sex marriage stands little chance of passing this year, the issue is nonetheless heating up on Capitol Hill, pushed by Republican leaders who are determined to force Democrats into an uncomfortable debate in the weeks before the Democratic convention at the end of next month.

title: The 'Evidence' for War
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks Send the Liberty To Its Fifth Straight Loss
description: Before the Los Angeles Sparks defeated the Liberty, 65-49, at Madison Square Garden last night, Liberty Coach Richie Adubato said the only thing standing between his team and an end to its four-game losing streak was shooting the ball well and executing on offense.

title: First Things First: A Home, A Car and a Federal Inquiry
description: Ninety minutes after his announcement on Monday that he would resign as Connecticut's governor, John G. Rowland dined alfresco with family and friends, lingering over a bottle of wine in the soft summer air at a trendy Hartford restaurant.

title: Anti-Doping Agency's Letter Described
description: The United States Anti-Doping Agency contends that Tim Montgomery, the men's 100-meter world-record holder, used five banned steroids in addition to the blood booster EPO and human growth hormone, and began using the substances as early as 2000, according to an article yesterday in The Los Angeles Times.

title: France Steps Up Its Investments in Iran
description: Undeterred by Iran's pariah status in the United States and by the shortcomings of the country's commercial climate, French companies have been increasing their presence in the country in the last few years.

title: Democrats Take a Look At Drug Tests
description: Correction Appended

title: Picture the Coffins
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain as Bush's No. 2?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PRISONER POLICY SET HUMANE TONE
description: In a February 2002 directive that set new rules for handling prisoners captured in Afghanistan, President Bush broadly cited the need for ''new thinking in the law of war.'' He ordered that all people detained as part of the fight against terrorism should be treated humanely even if the United States considered them not to be protected by the Geneva Conventions, the White House said Tuesday.

title: South Korean Is Killed in Iraq By His Captors
description: A South Korean interpreter who dreamed of becoming a Christian missionary in the Arab world was beheaded Tuesday by the insurgents who held him captive after his abduction five days ago near Falluja.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STAVSKY, ELLIOTT
description: STAVSKY--Elliott, reunited with his Creator on June 21. Devoted husband to Ruth, loving father to Lois and Isaac, Este, and Shalom. Adored grandfather of Sara and Dani. An Orthodox Jew with a universal soul. We will miss your kindness, compassion, humor and generosity of spirit. Burial in Jerusalem. Shiva at 9919 62nd Road, Rego Park, through June 27. Contributions in his memory may be made to F.E.G.S. 315 Hudson St., NYC 10013.

title: At One Point, 'I Was Deathly Afraid,' New Space Visitor Admits
description: For a moment, Michael W. Melvill thought he was going to be a ''squashed bug.'' A day after he piloted a rocket ship to the cusp of space, he said yesterday that the problems he experienced during the harrowing ascent -- including a violent roll to the left and a vital control system gone awry -- had led him to expect the worst.

title: Book by C.I.A. Officer Says U.S. Is Losing Fight Against Terror
description: Correction Appended

title: F.B.I. Agents in Drag Enjoy Wild Hamptons Weekend
description: Most movies require some suspension of disbelief. But ''White Chicks,'' a comedy starring the brothers Marlon and Shawn Wayans as African-American F.B.I. agents who disguise themselves as dippy white socialites for a weekend in the Hamptons, requires something more radical than that. A full frontal lobotomy might be a good place to start.

title: A 'Copplia' Revels in Its Creator's Reflected Glory
description: As the bows for his revival of ''Copplia'' seemed to end on Monday night, Frederic Franklin, 90 years young and still very much a ballet star, marched vigorously onstage at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Mets Hand Wilson His First Loss of the Season
description: The Mets used a No. 1 overall draft choice 10 years ago to take Paul Wilson, a pitcher from Florida State. He was often hurt and never amounted to much, so they traded him to Tampa Bay for two players. Remember Rick White and Bubba Trammell?

title: Leonel Brizola, 82, Dies; Opposed Military Rule in Brazil
description: Leonel Brizola, the former governor of Rio de Janeiro state and a veteran leftist whose role in trying to head off a military coup in the early 1960's made him a towering figure in Brazilian politics, died Monday night at a hospital near his home in the Copacabana district in Rio de Janeiro. He was 82.

title: Hollinger to Sell Telegraph To the Barclay Brothers
description: Hollinger International agreed on Tuesday to sell its most valuable asset, the Telegraph Group, to the Barclay brothers of Britain for 665 million ($1.2 billion) in cash.

title: Tyson Looks in the Mirror And Sees a Troubled Man
description: Inside a modest home on a calm street that runs through the well-manicured suburbs here, far from the flashy 24-hour strip clubs that teased him like sirens in Las Vegas, and farther from the trash-talking stoops of his native Brooklyn, the most devastating and controversial fighter of his generation, Mike Tyson, has been plotting his revenge in secret.

title: No Agreement on Education or Other Sticky Issues as Legislative Session in Albany Ends
description: New York State government is often run like a giant game of chicken. With a $100 billion budget and dozens of laws that would affect New Yorkers hanging in the balance, the state's leaders stake out their positions, dig in their heels, and try to bend their adversaries to their will.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNOR, RITA MARGARET, (NEE MCCARTHY)
description: O'CONNOR--Rita Margaret, (nee McCarthy), on June 20th of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of Raymond, devoted mother of Raymond, Jr., Eileen and Timothy Hodgdon, Cathleen and Michael Vaccari, Nancy, Marita and Anthony Agresta, adored grandmother of Brendan and Claire Hodgdon and Ryan Agresta, dear sister of James A. McCarthy. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday and Wednesday June 22nd & 23rd. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mercy R.C. Church, 70-01 Kessel St., Forest Hills, NY 9:30 A.M. Thursday, June 24th. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimers Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNOR, TIM
description: O'CONNOR--Tim. Of New York City, beloved husband of Renee Zuckerbrot, devoted son of the late John and Theresa O'Connor, passed away suddenly on June 22, 2004. Survived by his sister Patricia O'Connor and brother Tom O'Connor. He will be sorely missed and remain forever in our hearts. Services are private.

title: AOL Engineer Sold 92 Million Names to Spammer, U.S. Says
description: Asoftware engineer for America Online stole the Internet provider's customer list  some 92 million names  and sold it to an on-line marketer, setting off a torrent of unsolicited commercial e-mail commonly known as spam, federal authorities said today.

title: Italian Leader Accuses Opponents of Cheating in Election
description: While Italian pollsters explore the subtleties of voter sentiment that led to Silvio Berlusconi's lackluster European election results, the conservative prime minister has offered an easier explanation.

title: JetBlue Is to Announce Plans to Add LaGuardia Service
description: JetBlue Airways said today that it would begin service from LaGuardia Airport in September with seven daily flights to Fort Lauderdale, giving it operations at two of New York's three major airports.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teachers Charged In Internet Sex Sting
description: Two Queens teachers -- one employed by a public high school, the other by a parochial grammar school -- have been charged in separate incidents with trying to arrange sexual encounters over the Internet with a New York City police detective pretending to be a 14-year-old boy and a 14-year-old girl, the authorities said. Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown said yesterday that Anthony Laufgraben, 34, a social studies teacher at Benjamin Cardozo High School in Bayside, and Daniel Gettens, 53, a science teacher at Sacred Heart of Jesus Grammar School in Bayside, were arrested in recent days after an undercover sting operation. They were arraigned on charges of attempted dissemination of indecent material to minors, attempted criminal sexual act and attempted endangering the welfare of a child. Mr. Gettens was also charged with attempted rape. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: You May Now Remove the Black Armbands

He dreamed that Islamic terrorists had exploded a weapon of mass destruction in the United States and that Washington had made a retaliatory strike in the Muslim world. description: W.H. Smith, the British newsstand operator, suspended takeover talks with Permira Advisers, a buyout firm, because Permira was deterred by the magazine and book retailer's pension deficit. Permira is ''highly unlikely'' to offer 371 pence ($6.75) a share for the company, W.H. Smith said. The retailer also said it was in talks ''with a number of parties'' to sell its Hodder Headline publishing business to return cash to shareholders.

Wolfowitz, a prime architect of the Bush administration's Iraq policy, said Tuesday that the Pentagon had underestimated the violent tenacity of an insurgency that formed after Baghdad fell, and he acknowledged that the United States may be forced to keep a significant number of troops in Iraq for years to come.

Perfume, limos, a shipment of 1,500 Ping-Pong tables, for God's sake.''

title: Strangling Democracy
description: Last month the Czech Republic joined the European Union. Our country now has the same democratic principles and freedoms, brought here by the ''velvet revolution'' 15 years ago, as the community of nations that was built on the basis of respect for these values. This transition to democracy in Central and Eastern Europe, the outcome of a wider movement against totalitarianism, would never have succeeded without the support of a democratically minded world public.

title: One Party, No Budget
description: Despite their control of Congress, Republican leaders are in the embarrassing position of failing one of the annual tests of effective government: enacting a new budget. So, hoping for cover in the fall campaign, Republicans are brandishing hollow proposals intended to show that they are dealing with the decade of record deficits that they have fueled by exuberantly approving President Bush's tax cuts.

Rowland of Connecticut misstated the number of checks he or his wife wrote to state contractors last fall as late payments for work on their Litchfield cottage. There were four, not five. description: BETWEEN trips to the restaurants, the casino, the theater, the spa and the jazz club, passengers aboard the Queen Mary 2 often flock to another popular spot: the ship's bridge. But their view of the captain at work often leaves them deflated.

title: Bush Backs Condom Use To Prevent Spread of AIDS
description: President Bush said on Wednesday for the first time that the United States should ''learn from the experience'' of countries like Uganda in fighting AIDS and embraced the use of condoms to prevent its spread, a sensitive issue among conservative groups that have fought the adoption of any strategy that does not focus on abstinence.

description: The United States bowed Wednesday to broad opposition on the Security Council and announced it was dropping its effort to gain immunity for its troops from prosecution by the International Criminal Court.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew for the 11th consecutive month in May, driven by growing exports to China and other Asian countries. The May surplus expanded 35.5 percent, to 934.2 billion yen ($8.6 billion) as exports rose 9.8 percent, to 4.72 trillion yen ($43.5 billion) while imports grew 4.9 percent, to 3.79 trillion yen. Demand from Asian consumers for Japanese consumer goods coupled with demand from Asian factories for Japanese parts and equipment are driving the surge. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Alzheimer's Drug Provides 'Little Overall Benefit,' Researchers Say
description: The most widely prescribed drug for Alzheimer's disease, Aricept, does not delay the onset of disability or the need for placement in a nursing home, British researchers are reporting. They say that the drug has "disappointingly little overall benefit" and is not cost effective, and that better treatments are needed.

title: 'Modern Antiques' Make Trek From Notting Hill to NoLIta
description: ''I wanted a modern antique market full of surprises,'' said Cath Kidston (right), who two weeks ago opened her first American shop in NoLIta. She has had a store in Notting Hill in London for 10 years and is known in the United States for her signature florals, stripes, solids and nautical themes, which fill the bright, bilevel New York shop. Oven mitts (inset; $19 each) and cotton napkins (far right on cake stands; $35 for a set of four) share space with tea sets, bedding and aprons. (The one on Ms. Kidston is $55.) Vintage jewelry, tote bags and fabric are also available. Cath Kidston is at 201 Mulberry Street (Kenmare Street); (212) 343-0223.

title: Brooklyn Crime Tales Flavored by Neighborhood
description: Tim McLoughlin, a Brooklyn writer and editor, stopped off at a local bar after a Brooklyn Cyclones game. Along with the beer, the bartender, Thomas Morrissey, thrust his unpublished short story, ''Can't Catch Me,'' into his hands. Mr. McLoughlin loved the piece, about a detective who investigates the murder of a Bay Ridge baker who is found dead one day in his shop. The clue lies in the gingerbread cookies the man was baking when he was killed.

title: Egyptian Aide in Talks on Future Security Role in Gaza
description: Gen. Omar Suleiman, the director of Egyptian intelligence, visited top Israeli and Palestinian officials on Wednesday to work out the precise role Egypt would play in overseeing security in the Gaza Strip once Israel relinquishes the coastal territory to the Palestinians.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Army Report Undercut
description: Soldiers who said they accidentally killed a peasant family of five after firing on them from a long distance, in the mistaken belief that they were guerrillas, actually shot at least one of the victims at point-blank range, the country's Internal Affairs office said in a report obtained by The New York Times. The soldiers had initially said they had fired from 22 yards away, but the report showed that one of the peasants was hit from less than two feet away in the April 10 incident, which claimed the lives of a baby and three teenagers and prompted a public apology from President lvaro Uribe. The report said that the ''military version is not in accord with what really happened.''

title: Worms Like Wireless Phones, Too
description: THE Internet is crawling with viruses, and now one worm has even inched its way onto wireless mobile phones. The new Cabir smartphone worm is thought to be the first pest that spreads itself from phone to phone by means of the Blue-tooth wireless technology.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rowland Makes It Official
description: Gov. John G. Rowland submitted his formal letter of resignation yesterday, two days after announcing he would step down. The letter, dated June 21, was received by the secretary of the state's office at 12:10 p.m. It contained one sentence: ''I hereby announce my resignation as Governor of the State of Connecticut effective 12:00 noon, July 1, 2004.'' William Yardley (NYT)

description: Gardens, like memories, can grow grander with time. Or they can be forgotten altogether.

title: WHEATON RIVER INVESTORS WEIGH 2 TAKEOVER BIDS
description: The Coeur d'Alene Mines Corporation said yesterday that it would ask Wheaton River Minerals shareholders to approve a $1.7 billion takeover bid and reject a rival bid from a Canadian mining company, the Iamgold Corporation. Wheaton's board repeated its recommendation that its shareholders should reject the Coeur d'Alene bid in favor of the bid from Iamgold. Coeur d'Alene raised the cash portion of its offer earlier this week. Separately, Iamgold, which has been fighting a takeover battle of its own, urged shareholders to reject a proposal that it be acquired by Golden Star Resources of Littleton, Colo. Shareholders of Wheaton, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and Iamgold, which is based in Toronto, are scheduled to vote on the proposed merger of those two companies on July 6.

title: American Prairie Overlooked No More

title: The White House Papers
description: It was certainly good to finally see documents indicating that President Bush did not order the torture of prisoners. The newly released presidential memo of Feb. 7, 2002, talks about treating detainees humanely and refers comfortingly to American values. Unfortunately, beyond that there's not much comfort in these documents, which only confirm that the Bush administration fostered a culture of permissiveness regarding the treatment of prisoners that ultimately led to the Abu Ghraib disaster.

description: A few years ago, the armored car business was one of Brazil's fastest-growing industries. As urban crime and kidnappings soared, armored car dealers sprouted up by the dozens, and sales jumped almost sevenfold in five years.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled an ambitious plan yesterday to reduce the number of homeless people in the city by two-thirds over the next five years, proposing to build thousands of units of new housing and put new restrictions on city shelters.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ratings Raised
description: Standard & Poor's raised its ratings on many of Japan's top banks citing a better business environment and progress made reducing bad loans. The ratings company said a recovery and an easing of the decade-long drop in land prices were brightening the outlook for the banks, which have spent much of the last decade whittling away the bad loans left from the collapse of Japan's stock and property markets in the early 1990's. S.&P. raised its rating on the long-term debt of Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi by one level to A-minus and its rating on Mizuho Bank by one level to BBB-plus. The company also raised its ratings on six other large banks. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron Posts Profit
description: Micron Technology Inc., the world's No.2 maker of computer memory chips, reported it made its second quarterly profit in three years as average prices for its memory products rose 45 percent. Third-quarter net income was $90.9 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $214.9 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales jumped 52 percent to $1.12 billion in the period that ended June 3. Micron has changed how it lays out transistors in chips, making them smaller and cheaper to build. Micron shares slipped as revenue missed analysts' estimates. Shares of Micron fell 51 cents, to $13.95, in extended trading. They had risen 60 cents, to $14.46, in regular trading.

title: Craft Confirms a Comet Link For Peculiar Moon of Saturn
description: The Cassini spacecraft bearing down on Saturn has confirmed that its farthest moon, Phoebe, is an icy remnant of the solar system's birth more than four billion years ago, scientists said Wednesday.

And in the summer, most Beetle owners could only roll down the windows and dream about air conditioning.

title: Latin America Graft and Poverty Trying Patience With Democracy
description: On a morning in April, people in this normally placid spot in Peru's southeastern highlands burst into a town council meeting, grabbed their mayor, dragged him through the streets and lynched him. The killers, convinced the mayor was on the take and angry that he had neglected promises to pave a highway and build a market for vendors, also badly beat four councilmen.

description: A draft that may be remembered more for its trades than for its selections has already been turned upside down. The Washington Wizards and the Dallas Mavericks pulled off a deal last night that could have repercussions throughout the National Basketball Association.

description: Jon Lieber has always been able to rely on his command. Ninety percent of the time, Lieber estimates, he knows exactly where his pitches will go. His right elbow is healthy again, but it is fooling him, too. Lieber is not hitting his spots anymore, and the results are discouraging.

description: Two days after the Supreme Court overturned a Texas law allowing people to sue managed-care companies for refusing to cover treatments, Senator John Kerry vowed Wednesday to create a federal patients' bill of rights as he blasted the Bush administration's health care record.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: 14 Charged In Identity Theft Ring
description: The Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon, announced yesterday that 14 people were charged with operating an identity theft ring that lifted credit card numbers from patrons of at least two Nassau restaurants. Joseph Cataldo, 63, of North Massapequa, was identified as the ringleader and one of five people indicted on charges of enterprise corruption, punishable by up to 25 years in prison. Mr. Cataldo is charged with obtaining the numbers, counterfeiting cards in his home and distributing them to accomplices. Big-ticket items were bought with the fake cards and sold for cash to finance ''extravagant lifestyles,'' Mr. Dillon said. Julia C. Mead (NYT)

title: Scaling the Heights, With a Disc as Sherpa
description: NOW that it's officially summertime, millions will soon enjoy a traditional pastime: exploring America the beautiful. But with today's gas prices, the car isn't everybody's first choice of vehicle. Canoes, hiking boots and mountain bikes suddenly look a lot more attractive.

Mr. Dorf was the devoted husband of Marilou, the caring father of Robert and James and daughter-inlaw Jodie. He shared with his family his love of travel, the arts, sports and New York City. Mr. Dorf had a long and distinguished career as a customs broker and freight forwarder, but particularly enjoyed his participation and accomplishments with eleemosynary institutions. title: High Court Justice Supports Bar Plan to Ease Sentencing
description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy endorsed proposals by a special commission of the American Bar Association on Wednesday for a return to more discretion in criminal sentencing and for alternatives to long prison sentences for people convicted of less serious crimes.

description: Private passenger information from six airlines, four more than originally disclosed, was given to government contractors to test prototypes of an airport screening system developed for the Transportation Security Administration, the Bush administration said on Wednesday.

title: Corrections

title: For Gibson, 'The Passion' Seems Mostly A Blessing
description: Two months after the phenomenal success of his film about the Crucifixion, ''The Passion of the Christ,'' the director and movie star Mel Gibson is being courted by many in Hollywood for his connection to middle America, but still held at arm's length by others who found his film divisive.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Space Still Awaits
description: A New Jersey scientist remains scheduled to go into space with Russian cosmonauts next spring, the American company that is coordinating his flight said yesterday, contradicting reports that the trip had been canceled. After a report from the Interfax News Agency that said the scientist, Gregory Olsen, would not get to travel with the Russians because of health problems, an official at Space Adventures, the company in Virginia overseeing the flight for him, said Mr. Olsen had an unspecified medical issue, but it would not prevent space travel. Mr. Olsen, who has been training in Russia since April, is paying $20 million for his trip. Jason George (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Restrictions On Kohl Files
description: A federal court ruled that files compiled by the East German secret police on former Chancellor Helmut Kohl may only be released to journalists and historians if their publication does not violate his privacy, and only ''with the consent of the person affected.'' The decision means that the files on Mr. Kohl ''must remain largely sealed in future,'' the ruling said. The decision came after a yearlong legal battle between Mr. Kohl, who wants to keep the files closed, and the government custodian of the Stasi archives, who pointed out that documents of other political figures have been published. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Accord Reached in Latino Civil Rights Case
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's office announced an agreement on Wednesday with the Village of Freeport on Long Island in a federal lawsuit that accused village building inspectors of violating the civil rights of Latino residents during housing inspections.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suit Over Classified Data
description: A group promoting greater openness in government sued the Justice Department and Attorney General John Ashcroft over his decision to retroactively classify information given to Congress two years ago about problems in the F.B.I.'s translation program. The group, the Project on Government Oversight in Washington, said Mr. Ashcroft's decision was an ''egregious misuse'' of the government's ability to keep documents secret. The attorney general said disclosure could harm national security. The material centers on claims made by a former F.B.I. linguist about bureau problems in translating terrorism material. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cellphones And Phone Lines
description: One in three Americans are willing to ditch their fixed phone lines and use only cellphones, according to a poll by an online cellphone retailer, LetsTalk, and Wirthlin Worldwide. The 1,000 Americans over the age of 18 who were surveyed said they would switch if cellular network coverage increased and companies offered customers more free minutes. In the poll, 42 percent of those surveyed said cheaper wireless minutes would persuade them to drop their local phone lines, while another 31 percent cited better wireless coverage. Nine percent said they did not expect to drop their local phone lines, while 1 percent said they already relied on cellphones entirely. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Guerrilla campaigns are going to extremes, but will the message stick?
description: ''I LOOK at this as an art form,'' said Helen Wallace MacDonald, an energetic ''field agent'' in a guerrilla marketing street team, as she searched a Manhattan subway station for places to affix static-cling stickers that promote Le Tigre apparel. ''I'm serious,'' she said.

title: JetBlue Will Begin Flying Out of La Guardia
description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it planned to begin service from La Guardia Airport in September with seven daily flights to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., giving it operations at two of the New York area's three major airports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMTON, HENRY A.
description: SAMTON--Henry A. Founder of Miltenberg & Samton 60 years ago. He developed M & S to be a respected and promiment company in the worldwide confectionery industry. His business friends and associates will remember him for his dedication, knowledge, trust and hard work. In 1985, Ronald Kehle acquired M & S and Henry continued his strong desire to remain active until 1997. title: First Use Your Brain, Then Unleash Your Brawn

They pace back and forth, endlessly circle a building or just stare off into space, occasionally turning to stare off in a different direction. The only thing that really piques their interest is the sight of me, but honestly, piquing a zombie's interest is not a good thing.

title: Watching as the Children Starved
description: The country was horrified last fall when New Jersey officials found four emaciated children -- including a 10-year-old weighing only 28 pounds -- who had been systematically starved by their adoptive parents over a period of years, even though the family was supposed to be under the supervision of caseworkers from the state's child welfare agency. The children have gained weight and been nursed back to health since being removed from the home. But thousands of other children will remain at risk until the state restructures its Division of Youth and Family Services along the lines of a plan that was recently approved by a panel of experts and forwarded to the courts for judicial review.

description: Iran said Wednesday that it would free the eight British servicemen it has held since their boats strayed into Iranian waters on Monday, but the logistics remained unresolved.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Remains Of Body Found In Water
description: The bottom half of a man's body was discovered floating in the Kill Van Kull off the Livingston neighborhood yesterday morning, the police said. A tugboat operator discovered the body at 7:35 a.m. in the water off Richmond Terrace and Bement Avenue between New Jersey and Staten Island and called 911 from a nearby shipyard. Neither the man's identity nor the cause of his death could be immediately established. The office of the medical examiner took custody of the remains. Eddy Ramirez (NYT)

title: Venus Williams Upset at Wimbledon
description: LONDON, June 24  Strange things were happening on center court at Wimbledon today as Venus Williams and Karolina Sprem, her 19-year-old opponent from Croatia, exchanged shrieks and two-handed backhands in the second round.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Gemstar To Settle S.E.C. Case
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International, publisher of TV Guide magazine, will pay $10 million to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it overstated its advertising and licensing revenue by almost $250 million from 1999 through 2002. The money will be distributed to investors who suffered financial losses, the S.E.C. said yesterday. Gemstar, based in Los Angeles, neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. Randall R. Lee, director of the S.E.C.'s Los Angeles office, said the penalty reflected both the magnitude of Gemstar's misconduct and the cooperation the company had exhibited since Henry C. Yuen left as chairman last year.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Order Cheney to Release Energy Papers
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Supreme Court handed a major political victory to the Bush administration today, ruling 7 to 2 that Vice President Dick Cheney is not obligated, at least for now, to release secret details of his energy task force.

title: THE BBC TIGHTENS STANDARDS
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it would improve training for its newsroom employees, subject articles relying on anonymous sources to greater scrutiny and set up a new system to correct on-air mistakes. Under plans set out in a report by Ron Neil, a former BBC executive, the BBC will also establish a college for broadcast journalists. ''As the largest employer of journalists in the U.K., the BBC has an obligation to take the lead in strengthening training in craft skills and promoting debate about journalistic standards and ethics in broadcasting,'' the report said. The BBC commissioned the report after an independent panel led by Lord Hutton concluded in January that a broadcast on BBC radio in May 2003, saying that the government had exaggerated its intelligence on weapons of mass destruction to make a stronger case for war in Iraq, was itself unfounded. Lord Hutton's condemnation led to the resignation of the BBC's two top officials and started a round of soul-searching about the BBC's mission and future. SARAH LYALL

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Vodafone Seeks New Chief For Japan
description: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest wireless operator, is searching for a permanent chief executive for its Japanese unit after its former head, Darryl E. Green, quit after declines in profit and customer spending. The company named J. Brian Clark as interim chief executive of Vodafone Holdings K.K. and Vodafone K.K. in Japan until a successor is found, a spokesman, Ben Padovan, said. Japan is the group's biggest market. Mr. Green quit for personal reasons, the company said. Vodafone's chief executive, Arun Sarin, said last month that he would bring serious change to Japan. Mr. Green's departure coincided with the resignation of Vittorio Colao, chief executive of Vodafone's Italian business, the company's third largest by revenue. Mr. Colao accepted the position of chief executive of the Italian publisher RCS MediaGroup S.p.A., Vodafone said. Shares of Vodafone dropped a penny, or 0.8 percent, to 121.75 pence in London.

title: Iacocca Throws His Support Behind Kerry
description: SAN JOSE  Coming here to promote his plans for the new economy, Senator John Kerry got a lift today from an icon of the old, Lee A. Iacocca, former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SYDNEY, WILLIAM J.
description: SYDNEY--William J. World War II Veteran, Staff Sergeant, 331st Bomb Group Guam, printing company owner, Shakespeare enthusiast, died on June 9, 2004. Survived by his wife Claire, sons Steven and Howard and three grandchildren, Lauren, Amanda and Richard.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Protesting Farmer Gets Six Years In Prison
description: A tobacco farmer who drove a tractor rig into a decorative pond on the Mall in March 2003 and threatened to blow himself up was sentenced to six years in prison. The farmer, Dwight W. Watson, 51, of Whitakers, N.C., was convicted in September of making a false threat to detonate explosives and of destroying federal property, charges that carried a prison sentence of up to 20 years. Mr. Watson has said he was protesting cuts in federal tobacco subsidies, which he said had forced him to give up his farm. John Files (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Genocide Charged
description: Physicians for Human Rights said a ''genocidal process'' is unfolding in western Sudan, where armed Arab militias, with the backing of the government, have waged widespread attacks on black African residents of the Darfur region. ''It is essential for those who still survive in Darfur, for those who have desperately sought refuge in Chad, for future populations anywhere on earth, and for the sustainability of the regime of international norms and law that we collectively name this crime for what it is and intervene to stop it from succeeding,'' the Boston-based group said in a report. The government in Khartoum denies that it has supported the militias. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: No To Sexist Slurs
description: The government approved draft legislation to make sexist and homophobic slurs punishable, comparing the offense to racism and anti-Semitism. The bill, to be submitted to Parliament next month, would outlaw ''incitements to discrimination, hatred or violence against a person or group of people based on their sexual orientation'' or gender, the government said in a statement. The violation carries a jail term of up to a year and fine of up to 45,000 euros. The bill was drafted after a gay man was badly burned in an attack in January. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Return Of The Icon
description: An ancient icon of the Virgin Mary that Orthodox Christians revere as miraculous returned to Russia after more than half a century in the United States. The Tikhvin Mother of God icon, which according to Orthodox tradition was painted by St. Luke, mysteriously appeared in Russia in the fourteenth century and a monastery was built on the site. The icon, which is credited with saving the monastery from Swedish invaders in the 17th century, was brought to the United States by an migr bishop, who said it should be returned once Communism fell and the monastery was restored. It will be displayed briefly in Moscow before returning to Tikhvin monastery 125 miles east of St. Petersburg. Sonia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Utility Workers Injured In Manhole Fire
description: Two Consolidated Edison workers were seriously injured yesterday in a manhole explosion, the company said. The two workers were sent to Westchester Medical Center's burn unit, where their conditions were not immediately available. A third worker suffered from smoke inhalation, and four others received treatment for shock, said Joseph P. Petta, a spokesman for Con Edison. The explosion, in a manhole on Central Avenue just south of Tuckahoe Road in Yonkers, took place around 11 a.m. as the crew connected feeder cables. Mr. Petta said such episodes were rare. No power failures occurred. The names of the workers were withheld pending notification of their families. Thomas Crampton (NYT)

''We spent a lot of time on ergonomics,'' said Charles Lazor, who formed the company with John Christakos and Maurice Blanks in 1996. More than 100 Iraqis and at least 2 American soldiers were reported killed, with hundreds more people wounded.

description: A few lucky babies are destined for success in a particular direction, but whether the Bachs, the Strausses and other musical families are successful by genes or by nurture is arguable. There are mathematical and artistic families, and the same is true of bridge players. The extended family of Gail Greenberg, for example, has more than 80,000 masterpoints.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Killed By Subway Car
description: A woman was hit and killed by a subway car yesterday in the Brooklyn Bridge Station in downtown Manhattan, the police said. The woman, Joan Olaizola, 39, of Brooklyn, apparently fell on the tracks from the southbound platform of the No. 4 and 5 lines about 4:45 p.m., the authorities said, and was unable to get back on the platform. A woman who identified herself as the victim's sister, said by telephone last night that Ms. Olaizola was epileptic and had recently switched to a new antiseizure medication, which had apparently caused her to faint. ''When she fell and regained consciousness she tried to get up and they tried to help her but it was too late,'' said the woman, Laura Olaizola. Ms. Olaizola was pinned by a subway train that had come into the station and died soon after, the authorities said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: A Svelte Soprano Pleases, but Fans Play Down Size
description: Playing the title role in ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' at its opening on Tuesday, the German soprano Anne Schwanewilms certainly looked slinky in her swirling black dress with its skinny little straps. But it was not clear whether her pleasing litheness was essential to the role, as the Royal Opera had contended when it removed Deborah Voigt from the production because she was too heavy.

Services Thursday, 11 AM, at The Community Synagogue of Sands Point, 150 Middle Neck Rd, Pt Washington, NY.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Peterson Juror Is Dismissed
description: The judge presiding over the murder trial of Scott Peterson dismissed a juror after spending more than two hours in his chambers questioning each of the 12 members of the jury. The judge, Alfred A. Delucchi of San Mateo County Superior Court, did not publicly state a reason for dismissing the juror, Justin Falconer, 28. Mr. Falconer had also been questioned by the judge on Monday after being recorded on videotape speaking to Mr. Peterson's brother-in-law.

title: A Very Muscular Baby Offers Hope Against Diseases
description: The moment the little boy was born, the hospital staff knew there was something unusual about him. His muscles looked nothing like the soft baby muscles of the other infants in the nursery. They were bulging and well defined, especially in his thighs and upper arms.

title: S.E.C. ELEVATES ITS INQUIRY INTO CAREER EDUCATION
description: The Career Education Corporation, operator of the Katharine Gibbs secretarial schools and for-profit colleges, said yesterday that a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry had been raised to a formal investigation, setting off a 25 percent decline in its share price. Career Education has been accused in lawsuits by shareholders and former employees of tampering with student records and manipulating financial results. Sean Murphy, a spokesman for Career Education, declined to comment. The company disclosed in an annual report filed in March that the S.E.C. investigation stems from accusations that Career Education inflated enrollment at schools in Montclair, N.J., and in Santa Barbara, Calif. Career Education relies on government-sponsored aid programs and has said in filings that it generated 61 percent of the company's 2003 revenue from the programs.

description: As a shining symbol of democracy, the United States capital is not ordinarily a place where coronations occur. So news that the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the eccentric and exceedingly wealthy Korean-born businessman, donned a crown in a Senate office building and declared himself the Messiah while members of Congress watched is causing a bit of a stir.

Mr. Obama was the first African-American president of The Harvard Law Review. (The first African-American editor was Charles Hamilton Houston.)

title: Bomb in Istanbul Kills 4 and Injures 14
description: ISTANBUL, June 24  A small bomb exploded on a crowded public bus here today, killing 4 people and injuring at least 14 as security officials prepared to close off swaths of the city in advance of a NATO summit meeting here on Monday that President Bush is scheduled to attend.

description: Thinking about redoing a house on the eastern end of Long Island? The Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead has outlets for Pottery Barn, Tupperware and, among others, ABC Carpet & Home, where Chinese lacquer furniture is on sale in nontraditional colors like wasabi, tangerine and robin's-egg blue. A stool with a drawer, seen above, was $295 but is now $125 and a CD chest, above left, painted blue, was $595 and is now $395. At Exit 72 on the Long Island Expressway (631-208-1720). description: In an ominous sign of the instability in Russia's southern Caucasus region, authorities said Wednesday that the coordinated raids earlier this week in the republic of Ingushetia were conducted by a mix of local and Chechen fighters and led by an Ingush commander.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Retailer's Profit Rises
description: The clothing retailer Hennes & Mauritz said its second-quarter profit rose 5.6 percent, helped by its expansion in the United States, where the company has opened 14 stores in a year. Net income climbed to 1.76 billion kronor ($232 million), or 2.13 kronor a share, in the three months through May, from 1.67 billion kronor, or 2.02 kronor a share, a year earlier, the chief executive, Rolf Eriksen, said. Sales rose 7.5 percent, the company said. Hennes, which is based in Stockholm, said its outlets in the United States were profitable, before depreciation, for the first time last quarter.

title: Thou-Shalt-See TV
description: Inspired by the runaway success of religion-themed novels like the ''Left Behind'' series and Mel Gibson's ''The Passion of the Christ,'' broadcasters are devoting more of their prime-time schedules to shows dealing with God, faith and the afterlife.

title: Economic Scene; Until a more thorough study is done, it is impossible to know whether private or federal airport screeners perform better.
description: IN remarkably short order, the federal government hired 45,000 workers and took over passenger screening at virtually all airports in response to Sept. 11. Would the private sector do a better job?

title: North Korea Is Studying Softer Stance From the U.S.
description: The United States presented North Korea with a proposal on Wednesday for phasing out its nuclear program in exchange for aid and security guarantees, as senior Bush administration officials acknowledged that they were softening their hard-line stance in negotiations with North Korea.

description: John D. Negroponte was sworn in as the United States ambassador to Iraq on Wednesday and vowed to work with the government in Baghdad taking power next week to restore security, economic reconstruction and democracy.

description: Germany's biggest stock offering in years, Postbank, made scarcely a ripple on its first day of trading on Wednesday. But there was a palpable sigh of relief in German financial circles, where this troubled deal had symbolized the country's deeper woes.

title: A Hoard of Gold That Afghanistan Quietly Saved; 2,000-Year-Old Heritage Narrowly Escaped the Taliban
description: Under the Russians it was barely glimpsed. The Afghan Communists allowed only peeks. Through the years of civil war and Taliban rule, its existence was kept secret by a handful of unassuming museum and bank workers, even as other priceless pieces of Afghanistan's cultural history were destroyed.

title: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty In Import Case
description: A leading antiquities dealer pleaded guilty yesterday to a federal charge that he had falsified a customs document about the origins of an ancient silver ceremonial drinking vessel that his gallery later sold for $950,000.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BSkyB Selects Executive
description: Jeremy Darroch, the finance director of the Dixons Group, a consumer electronics retailer, is leaving to become the chief financial officer of the British Sky Broadcasting Group. Mr. Darroch, 41, left, will probably leave Dixons in a few weeks, the retailer said. At BSkyB, he will succeed Martin Stewart, who will leave in August. BSkyB, based near London, ''is at an interesting stage of development and it's one of the biggest companies in the U.K. by market capitalization, so that's the attraction,'' Mr. Darroch said. At BSkyB, Mr. Darroch will work with the chief executive, James R. Murdoch, as the company seeks to gain customers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the timing of an appointment to succeed George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, referred incorrectly to the duration and dates of C.I.A. service by one possible successor, Representative Porter J. Goss, a Republican from Florida. He was a case officer for 12 years, spanning a period from the late 1950's to the early 1970's, not for 10 years in the 1960's. The article also referred incorrectly to the position in the Republican leadership held by another candidate for the job, Representative Christopher Cox of California. He is the fifth-ranking Republican in the House (that is, the fourth-ranking Republican after the Speaker).

title: AT&T to Halt Some Residential Marketing
description: AT&T said yesterday that it would stop marketing its phone services to residents in seven states, an action the company said was in direct response to the Bush administration's decision not to intercede in the dispute over the fees carriers like AT&T pay to the Bell phone companies for the use of their networks.

title: Doing Our Homework
description: When I was growing up, my parents used to say to me: ''Finish your dinner -- people in China are starving.'' I, by contrast, find myself wanting to say to my daughters: ''Finish your homework -- people in China and India are starving for your job.''

Although they are not washable, the plates can be wiped off and reused as long as they are not stained with ketchup or grease. They are available in two sizes, 9 inches ($8 for a set of 8), and 7 inches ($6 for a set of 8) at Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street), New York; (212) 226-6800. Bambu's Web site is www.bambuhome.com.

description: SAN JOSE  Coming here to promote his plans for the new economy, Senator John Kerry got a lift today from an icon of the old, Lee A. Iacocca, former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: The Ever More Graspable, And Risky, American Dream
description: For years, Ray and Shahrazad Daneshi sought to buy a home, only to be told that they did not earn enough to qualify for a mortgage. But they recently managed to buy a small house in the shadow of Disneyland for $360,000 -- six times their annual income -- thanks to a lender who allowed them to borrow the entire value of the home, with no down payment.

description: GREEN--Jack L. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved Dean Emeritus, Jack L. Green. We are deeply indebted to the personal guidance he provided us while serving as a Member and Officer of the Club.
