Klein, Treasurer Stu Cantor, Scribe Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: MOODY'S DOWNGRADES DELTA'S DEBT SECURITIES
description: Delta Air Lines' $11.8 billion in debt securities was downgraded by Moody's Investors Service because of concerns that losses would continue and cash flow would be reduced without labor and operating cost reductions. Moody's said that it lowered the senior rating to Caa1 from B3 and the senior unsecured debt rating to Caa3 from Caa2. All the ratings are below investment grade. Debt backed by Delta's aircraft also was downgraded. Delta's ability to reach agreement with its pilots' union on lower pay and work rules more favorable to the company ''in a timely fashion is uncertain,'' Moody's said in the statement. Delta, based in Atlanta, has said it may seek bankruptcy protection without the pilot cost cuts.

title: In a Show About Sexual Exploits, Blushing Is a Sin
description: Here's what ''The Graham Norton Effect'' could have been: a raucous showcase for campy humor and true confessions, a gay-straight alliance to flout taboos and comfort those who reveal their secret shames. Here's what the first episode of Comedy Central's new series turns out to be: a freak show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Counseling Program Extended
description: Project Liberty, a crisis-counseling program for people and groups affected by Sept. 11, which was to close down at the end of this month, will be allowed to continue at least until September, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced yesterday. Senator Clinton, who has been an advocate of the program, learned of the extension from a letter sent this month by the Department of Health and Human Services, said Jennifer Hanley, the senator's press secretary. Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said he hoped the extension would give Senator Clinton and others a chance to press for another year of services. About 9,000 Fire Department members have already used the program, he said. Mary Spicuzza (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Homes Are Rehabilitated
description: Officials of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development visited a rehabilitated building in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday to announce that they were close to rehabilitating more than 300 properties that had been caught up in a home mortgage scandal. Under a scheme to defraud HUD's 203(k) program, real estate speculators bought hundreds of dilapidated properties in the late 1990's and sold them at vastly inflated prices to nonprofit groups inexperienced in housing. Those groups then defaulted on the loans, prompting city and federal officials to embark on a $168 million program to renovate the properties. Twenty people have been arrested, and 13 have pleaded guilty. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: AOL to Buy Advertising.com, an Online Direct Marketer
description: America Online agreed yesterday to pay $435 million in cash for Advertising.com, a company that specializes in online direct marketing for mortgage companies, correspondence courses and the like.

But that's still too common for Joe Bortz, who over the past 30 years has acquired some two dozen one-of-a-kind concept cars -- notable not only for their rarity, but also because they were never intended to survive.

title: Signs of Heat Beneath California Cool
description: Ed Ruscha's reputation as a cool dude precedes him, as it always has. How could it not? That would be the 1960's, of course, and while these attributes may have been more mythic than actual, Mr. Ruscha typified them to perfection.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Compensation From France
description: Paris agreed to pay Switzerland 3 million euros ($3.6 million) for damages incurred during the Group of 8 summit meeting of 2003, which took place on the border, the Foreign Ministry said. The voluntary payment will compensate for the damage protesters caused in Geneva and Lausanne during the talks in the French resort at Evian. The compensation comes on top of a 12-million-euro payment to which France had agreed before the talks to help defray security costs in Switzerland, the ministry said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Celebrating A River's Artful Revival
description: THE sounds of chamber music and Shakespeare soliloquies drift over the upper Housatonic River as it flows from Pittsfield, Mass., to New Milford, Conn., past well-heeled summer towns and sought-after second-home retreats. Appropriately, a celebration lasting several months along this section of the river will depart from typical summer-festival fare, replacing hot-dog-eating events with organic picnics and beauty contests with sculpture tours.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster And Best Buy In Deal
description: The digital music provider Napster has teamed with Best Buy, the electronics retailer, to enlist new subscribers. Under the deal, announced yesterday, Best Buy will promote Napster through in-store marketing and media advertising. It will also set up a co-branded version of the music service for sales online through Bestbuy.com. In return, Best Buy, based in Richfield, Minn., will receive stock in Napster's parent, Roxio, based in Santa Clara, Calif., worth up to $10 million over the term of the multiyear agreement. The two companies will finance marketing activities jointly. Best Buy will feature Napster products in its brick-and-mortar stores and demonstrate the service through interactive kiosks. Napster will also support Best Buy's artist promotions. Napster, which began as an unauthorized song-swapping Web site, has transformed itself into a service that offers music downloads for a monthly fee.

title: Dogfights in the Senate
description: Senator John Kerry went racing back to Washington this week, bent on supporting a Democratic attempt to increase spending on veterans' health benefits. But Senate Republicans craftily held off consideration of the measure -- proposed as an amendment to a Pentagon spending bill -- until the heavily scheduled presidential candidate had to give up and return to the campaign trail. We can understand Mr. Kerry's frustration -- he said the Senate majority leader was trying to ''shut the door, lock people out.'' But we're glad the measure died. It was only a vehicle for political posturing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Arroyo Declared President
description: Congress proclaimed Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo the winner in the May 10 presidential election, ending a bitter debate that divided the country. The political opposition insisted that Mrs. Arroyo had cheated. This was the first election since the fall of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos, in 1986, that an incumbent president ran. Under the Constitution, an elected president cannot run again, but Mrs. Arroyo was vice president under President Joseph Estrada, who was driven from office in 2001, and completed his term. Her opponents said she used her incumbency to spend billions in government money to influence voting by giving out rice and health insurance cards, among other things. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronics Prices Decline
description: The prices of consumer electronics continued to fall this spring, according to a new report from NPD Intelect. Prices declined 2 percent across the board in April from March, NPD, a market researcher, said yesterday, with prices dropping for 19 of the 27 products it tracks. The company said the biggest drop in dollars was in plasma and rear-projection televisions, both of which fell about $40 over March prices. ''TV prices remain under pressure as new screen sizes, new distribution channels and new brands alter the playing field at the high end of the market,'' Stephen Baker, director of industry analysis at NPD, said in a statement. ''Falling prices for plasma, which have declined over $1,000 since last January, and rear-projection TV, have put stress on category pricing all the way down to the basic tube set.'' DVD recorder prices declined 9.9 percent. Prices of personal CD players dropped 7.2 percent. Desktop and notebook PC prices fell as well. Notebook prices leveled off from an increase in March, and desktop prices dropped 5 percent from the previous month -- the biggest one-month decrease since November. Desktop PC prices are the only category that has seen an increase in average selling prices since January 2003.

The company had bought the newly completed but vacant 1.1-million-square-foot tower between 44th and 45th Streets 12 years ago for a bargain basement price of $119 million. It will continue to occupy about 40 percent of the tower, which will still be called the Bertelsmann Building. title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Declines
description: The jobless rate in Brazil fell in May for the first time this year, dropping to 12.2 percent from a two-and-a-half-year high of 13.1 percent a month earlier, the government's statistics agency said. But real wages, which are adjusted for inflation, slipped 0.7 percent last month from April to an average of 866.1 reais, or about $277 a month. The drop in unemployment is good news for the 18-month-old government of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, whose approval ratings fell below 30 percent this month, in large part because of growing discontent over the jobs outlook. UAL's net income in May 2003 was $64 million, including $300 million in United States aid for costs related to the Iraq war, and the company, based in Chicago, had an operating loss of $155 million.

description: Pitching his plans for the new economy, Senator John Kerry was embraced on Thursday by an icon of the old, Lee A. Iacocca, the former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: 4 Killed in Istanbul Bus Bombing Before Bush Visit to Turkey
description: Four people were killed when a bomb exploded on a crowded public bus here on Thursday, a few hours after a similar device blew up near a luxury hotel in Ankara, Turkey, where President Bush was due to stay this weekend in advance of the NATO summit meeting on Monday.

title: DEMAND FOR COSTLY SHOES BOLSTERS NIKE PROFIT
description: Nike Inc., the world's No.1 maker of athletic footwear, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings increased 23 percent as demand for products including $110 Shox running shoes and $125 Huarache 2K4 basketball sneakers bolstered sales in the United States and Asia. Net income rose to $305 million, or $1.13 a share, from $246.2 million, or 92 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the quarter ended May 31 climbed 17 percent, to $3.5 billion from $3 billion, were also helped by the falling dollar and last year's purchase of Converse Inc.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on June 17 about a report by the staff of the Sept. 11 commission calling into question ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda misstated the month in which Nicholas Berg, a 26-year-old American, was beheaded by militants in Iraq. It was May, not March.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: House Committee Says C.I.A. Is Courting Disaster by Mismanaging Its Human Spying
description: In a scathing report, the Republican-led House Intelligence Committee has warned that the Central Intelligence Agency is heading ''over a proverbial cliff'' through mismanagement of its human spying operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTINI, NAEL, M.D. DR. O.
description: MARTINI--Nael, M.D. Dr. O. Wayne Isom and the entire Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery notes with sorrow the passing after a long illness of our friend and colleague Nael Martini, M.D. Dr. Martini, the former Chief of Thoracic Services at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, was a caring surgeon who was dedicated to his patients. We express our condolences to his wife Robin, his children Jenny, Suzanne and John and his grandson Elliot. O. Wayne Isom, M.D. Chairman, Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery Weill-Cornell Medical College

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Kingston: Judge Bans Same-Sex Marriages
description: Justice E. Michael Kavanagh, left, of State Supreme Court, issued a restraining order yesterday banning all village trustees in New Paltz from performing same-sex marriages. The temporary order was a result of a suit brought by Robert Hebel, a village trustee. It came two weeks after a trial judge in New Paltz declared the mayor, Jason West, not guilty of criminal charges for officiating at such marriages. After that ruling, two village trustees who had been appointed marriage officers by the council began solemnizing same-sex marriages. In the suit, Mr. Hebel asks the court to declare both the appointment of marriage officers and same-sex marriages invalid. Thomas Crampton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDMAN, BERT
description: SEIDMAN--Bert. The officers, staff and members of the Jewish Labor Committee note with deep sadness the passing of Bert Seidman, a Vice President and longtime leader in our organization. For many years active in our Washington DC Chapter, he was a thoughtful and dedicated trade unionist, whose wisdom and commitment to improving the lives of working men and women made a difference for millions of workers. We extend our deepest condolences to his children, and to all of his family and friends. Stuart Appelbaum, President Avram B. Lyon, Exec. Dir.

title: Regrets, They Have a Few
description: The country is more disillusioned about the war in Iraq and more fearful than at any time since the war began that it has only served to increase the chance of another terror attack inside the United States according to surveys of public opinion that came out this week.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to publish on a Web site the thousands of comment letters that it sends to public companies and mutual funds each year about their annual reports, public offerings and other filings, officials at the agency said on Thursday.

title: Hindu Nationalists Ponder Unexpected Defeat in India Elections
description: The Bharatiya Janata Party, which suffered an unexpected defeat last month in India's parliamentary elections, concluded a three-day meeting on Thursday that reaffirmed its commitment to its core Hindu nationalist philosophy while exposing the fissures within the Hindu nationalist movement.

title: Deaniacs Lining Up to Support Kerry
description: ANAHEIM  For people who followed Howard Dean's quest for the Democratic nomination this primary season, the past week on the campaign trail with Senator John Kerry has been deja vu all over again.

title: A Musical Gospel That's Made Converts of Pop's Multitudes
description: So it turns out Aretha Franklin didn't actually sing the national anthem at the fifth and final Pistons-Lakers N.B.A. championship game. Her producer, Brian Pastoria, told The Detroit Free Press that she lip-synched to a track she had recorded last year in the vestibule of her house in Bloomfield Hills, a Detroit suburb. No wonder they kept cutting away from her to meaningless shots of the auditorium. I figured it was because she looked a little frumpy. Turns out that she was lip-synching so sloppily that everyone would have noticed had the camera focused on her face.

title: Arafat Agrees To Appoint Security Chief
description: After weeks of prodding, the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has agreed to appoint an interior minister to take charge of security for the Palestinian Authority, Israeli and American officials said Thursday.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Sexual Video by Students Prompts Inquiry in Scarsdale
description: Some students called it an assault; others said it was just a stupid high school prank, fueled by alcohol. But nearly everyone at Scarsdale High School has heard of the video, shared over the Internet, that shows two freshman girls in a sexual encounter on a couch while boys shout encouragement in the background.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Space Station Crew Aborts a Spacewalk
description: The International Space Station crew was forced to abort a critical spacewalk on Thursday when pressure in the oxygen supply of one of the two astronauts began to drop too quickly.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the Senate's passage of a $447.2 billion Pentagon spending measure for 2005 misidentified the political party of Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, who criticized a Democratic effort to expand health benefits for veterans. He is a Republican.

title: Telecommunications Shares Send Indexes Downward
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by telecommunications shares, after the AT&T Corporation cut its profit and revenue forecast. Weaker-than-expected reports on durable goods orders and jobless claims contributed to the decline.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a revised prospectus for the initial public stock offering of Google misidentified the source of a ''Google bomb,'' a form of online manipulation that causes a designated Web page to appear as the first response to a particular phrase search. (In this case, the tactic caused the search engine to reply to the phrase ''out of touch management'' by displaying a Web page that described Google's top management.) While a person close to the company said Google employees had engaged in the practice, Daniel Brandt, the operator of a Web site critical of Google, later acknowledged that he was the source.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   O'BRIEN, LOIS LEVIN
description: O'BRIEN--Lois Levin. Dearest, we are having Mass said today for you. Our prayers are that you rest in peace, free from pain and sorrow. We miss you daily. Jack and Jeremiah

title: New U.S. Airstrike on Falluja; Iraqis Hint at Martial Law
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 25 - United States marines attacked the insurgent stronghold of Falluja with airstrikes today, and Iraq's new government again strongly hinted that it would declare martial law, but said nothing about its timing or scope.

title: In Search of Food, Water and Human Kindness After an Ecological Catastrophe
description: Nobody likes to be the bearer of bad news -- except, perhaps, Michael Haneke. An Austrian director who makes movies in French, Mr. Haneke presents a view of human nature that is rigorously, even elegantly pessimistic. His subjects include murder (''Funny Games''), racism (''Code Unknown'') and extreme sadomasochism (''The Piano Teacher''), and he approaches them with a shrugging, analytical sang-froid, ruthlessly purging his stories of anything that might smack of sentimentality or sensationalism.

title: Navratilova Plays Well, But Loses A Rematch
description: It was a much closer match, but it ended the same way on grass at Wimbledon as it had ended on red clay at the French Open: 47-year-old Martina Navratilova lost to 19-year-old Gisela Dulko.

title: Inventiveness And Intimacy, Russian Style
description: Peter Martins's ''Concerto for Two Solo Pianos'' almost always feels surprising. This tangy little augmented trio looked better than ever but still bizarre when it was revived by the New York City Ballet last Saturday night at the New York State Theater. It will be performed again tomorrow night.

title: Stock Options Debate Comes to Silicon Valley
description: At a protest rally that filled a downtown plaza on Thursday, there were more khakis and clip-on cellphones than denim and flannel as hundreds of technology workers opposed a change in accounting regulations that they think threatens the lifeblood of Silicon Valley.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Minimum Wage Law Approved
description: A state district judge approved a new wage ordinance for workers in Santa Fe. The law requires businesses with 25 or more employees to pay at least $8.50 an hour, instead of the federal minimum of $5.15. The law was passed by the City Council after proponents cited the city's high cost of living. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: With the surprise departure of John J. Mack from Credit Suisse First Boston yesterday, Brady W. Dougan, a relatively unknown banker -- at least by the standard of Mr. Mack's reputation -- will take over the volatile firm.

title: New York and Connecticut Agree to End Cable Dispute
description: New York and Connecticut officials ended their battles over two electric cables across Long Island Sound yesterday by agreeing to reactivate a new cable that had been turned off and to replace an aging cable that had become unreliable.

title: A Victory for Cheney
description: Saying a lower court acted ''prematurely'' when it rejected a request from Vice President Dick Cheney to block disclosure of records from his energy policy task force, justices sent the case back to the court.

title: The Garage Of Dreams
description: CONCEPT cars like the Buick Y-Job and the Pontiac Banshee were built to live a short life in the spotlight, feeding the dreams of the car-buying public. But one collector has kept the memories -- and the cars -- alive. Page 10.

title: Hollywood Turns Out for Kerry Fundraiser
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25  It could have been Oscar night, what with Billy Crystal cracking wise about movies and politics, money and baseball  just like the old days when the Academy Awards ceremony was held across the street at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. But when Mr. Crystal tried a joke about former President Clinton's forthcoming children's book  "It's called the Little Engine That Could Because It Could"  it fell flat.

title: If Only Humans Behaved as Well as Tigers
description: Deep in the soul of the most ferocious tiger there is a purring pussycat struggling to get out. That's the cuddly anthropomorphic premise of ''Two Brothers,'' a family-friendly movie made for the same audience that likes to imagine talking animals, although none of the beasts in ''Two Brothers'' converse in anything but expressive roars.

description: ALong Island seafood store employee was indicted yesterday on a charge of murdering a co-worker who allegedly rebuffed his advances.

description: MANILA:  The Philippine Congress on Thursday proclaimed Gloria Macapagal Arroyo the winner in the May 10 presidential election, ending a bitter election season that divided the country.

description: GRUDER--Vivian. A woman before her time, who experienced the world as few did. Peacefully, after a long fulfilling life. Dedicated executive assistant to Harry Brandt, president of Brandt Theaters. Dear sister of Ruth, Herman and the late Beatrice, Leon and Annette. Loving and devoted aunt and great-aunt to many. She will be remembered by her family and many friends. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Miriam Hospital Foundation, Providence, RI. in memory of her niece, Francine Steiner Brem. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

description: The New Jersey Legislature worked into the early morning hours today, debating Gov. James E. McGreevey's $28 billion budget.

title: DEBT RETIREMENT TO CUT PROFIT AT WELLS FARGO
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank, said this week that it would have about $176 million in pretax costs this quarter for the retirement of $2.44 billion in debt. The debt repurchase will cut second-quarter earnings per share by about 6 cents, Wells Fargo said late Wednesday. The company, based in San Francisco, was expected to report a profit of $1.04 a share, according to the average estimate of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Financial. The company said last week that it would pay as much as $2.5 billion to retire all or part of 17 debt securities to cut interest costs. The bank's consumer finance division, Wells Fargo Financial Inc., issued most of the debt, which has a principal value of $4.63 billion. The debt retired had been issued at interest rates substantially above that of recent financings, according the statement.

title: ENRON SELLS GAS PIPELINES FOR $2.35 BILLION
description: The Enron Corporation, which owes creditors more than $74 billion, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its natural gas pipeline system in the United States for $2.35 billion, but left open the possibility of accepting other bids. Enron accepted the offer from CCE Holdings, a joint venture of the Southern Union Company, based in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and GE Commercial Finance Energy Financial Services. The $2.35 billion includes the assumption of debt and will become the initial bid in a bankruptcy auction in September. The CCE bid ''sets the opening price for the auction,'' said an Enron spokeswoman, Karen Denne. ''We'll solicit additional bids until Aug. 23.''

title: Promotions Granted to 1,500 Who Failed 3rd Grade Tests
description: Nearly 1,500 third graders will not be left back despite failing at least one of their citywide tests this spring, the New York City Department of Education announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   POST, SHELDON
description: POST--Sheldon. 9/25/36-6/25/ 88. Founder, Chelsea Pines Inn. Chair, NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Board, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah. Loving partner, son, brother, uncle, friend, proud gay Jew. As we celebrate Gay Pride this weekend, we recall a generation lost in the ongoing war against AIDS. Sheldon fought hard for a better world, and would be astonished to see how far we have come. Please join Tom Klebba and me in remembering those gone too soon: Mark Fuschetti, Peter Monette, Gary Olde, Jon Flaherty, Tom Dickey, Gary Brubach, Benn Brown and Wayne Kell, Tom Bradley, Garon Douglas, Jay ''Peggy Sue'' Farrar, Dean X. Johnson, Allan Kendric and Ron McSwiggen, Bob Levine, Eddie Peters, Quinton Johnson, Norman Sweet, Eddie Tilchen, Martin Teitel, too many others. ''Sometimes people leave you halfway through the wood, do not let it grieve you, no one leaves for good.'' Rest well, Sheldon, knowing that you and all our friends will be remembered and celebrated as long as we live. Jay Lesiger

title: Lillian Seril, 95, Dies; Landlord at Center of Rent Strike
description: Lillian Seril, who as landlord of a grand Upper West Side apartment building, the Belnord, became the central figure in one of New York City's longest rent strikes, died on Monday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. She was 95 and had been living as a tenant at the building she once owned, at 225 West 86th Street.

title: The Canucks' Bertuzzi Is Charged With Assault
description: Assault charges were filed in British Columbia on Thursday against the Vancouver Canucks' Todd Bertuzzi for a sucker punch and face-first slam to the ice that left the Colorado Avalanche's Steve Moore with a broken neck.

title: Abu Ghraib Testimony
description: The head of an Army unit facing abuse charges said the top military intelligence officer at Abu Ghraib prison, Col. Thomas M. Pappas, was in the cellblock the night a detainee died during interrogation.

title: Deaniacs Lining Up to Support Kerry
description: ANAHEIM  For people who followed Howard Dean's quest for the Democratic nomination this primary season, the past week on the campaign trail with Senator John Kerry has been deja vu all over again.

title: In Chirac offer, a poisoned chalice?
description: PARIS:  In the latest chapter of the simmering power struggle between France's two most closely watched politicians, President Jacques Chirac told his finance minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, that he was free to seek the presidency of the ruling party, traditionally seen as paving the way to the presidency of the country.

title: Powell Plans to Travel to Sudan In Effort to Stop Militia Attacks
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will travel next week to Sudan, including the western Darfur region where government-backed militias have killed thousands of people and driven more than a million from their homes, the State Department announced Thursday.

title: Parents Ask for Waiting Lists At Schools With Open Seats
description: City Council members, parents and the head of the city teachers' union criticized the New York City Department of Education's new high school admissions process yesterday, saying the department had wronged students by leaving dozens of seats unfilled at some of the city's most prized high schools.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Student Sentenced For Planting Box Cutters
description: A 20-year-old college student who said he had hid box cutters and other banned items on airplanes to expose security weaknesses received two years of probation. The student, Nathaniel T. Heatwole, was also ordered to perform 100 hours of community service and pay a $500 fine. United States Magistrate Judge Paul W. Grimm ordered him not to fly on commercial airlines without permission from the Federal District Court in Baltimore. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: 2 Citigroup Executives Suspended
description: Robert Morse, the chief executive of Citigroup's corporate and investment banking operations in Asia, said in a memorandum to his senior management that the company had suspended two investment bankers in China for ''the presentation of false information to the company and its regulators.'' The memo added, ''We immediately informed the appropriate government authorities of the suspension and will cooperate fully as they pursue this matter.'' The two were Margaret Ren, Citigroup's vice chairman for investment banking in China, and Earl Yen, a director of investment banking in China; neither of them was available for comment. A Citigroup spokeswoman declined to provide specifics, saying only that, ''for Citigroup to take this action, you can assume the misrepresentation was serious, but it did not involve client matters.'' Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Massachusetts Politicians Fight Over a Kerry Victory
description: No, the Republican governor of Massachusetts is not really conceding a presidential victory for the Democratic senator from Massachusetts.

title: High School Procession At the Draft
description: Dwight Howard stood next to Commissioner David Stern at the Theater at Madison Square Garden last night, his smile nearly as wide as the brim on his new Orlando Magic cap, his braces glistening in the spotlight. The Magic, faced with the choice between defense and immediacy or versatility and potential, chose the latter, taking the 18-year-old Howard over Emeka Okafor, perhaps the most dominant college player in America last season.

title: Testimony Ties Key Officer To Concealing of Iraqi Death
description: The company commander of the unit charged with abusing prisoners at Abu Ghraib testified Thursday that the top military intelligence officer at the prison was in the cellblock the night a prisoner died during interrogation.

title: Tyco's Former Top Lawyer Says He Deserved Big Bonus
description: Tyco International's former general counsel, Mark A. Belnick, told jurors yesterday that he earned ''every dollar'' he got from the company, denying a government charge that he stole a $17 million bonus.

title: Bach and Nothing but Bach
description: John Kamitsuka made his New York debut 20 years ago and has performed in New York several times since then. Each of his piano recitals has been received with caveats, principally about his disinclination to explore the keyboard's range of color and power. But Mr. Kamitsuka's recital on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall, sponsored by the Abby Whiteside Foundation, suggested that this pianist may have found himself at last.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Gestevision Shares Surge
description: Shares of Gestevisin Telecinco rose as much as 23 percent in their first day of trading as the growth prospects of the company, which owns Spain's largest commercial TV station, attracted investors like Alberto Espelosn to the nation's biggest initial offering since 2002. Mr. Espelosn is part of a team managing $7.2 billion at the investment bank Ibercaja Gestin. The shares climbed as high as 12.50 euros ($15.11), and traded at 12.06 euros in Madrid, up from the offer price of 10.15 euros. Two Telecinco investors, Dresdner Bank and ICE Finance, raised 753 million euros ($910 million), after selling shares at the top end of the range for the offering. Money managers ordered more than 20 times the shares on offer, encouraged by the advertising outlook in Spain, where economic growth outpaced Europe's average in each of the last eight years.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Image Raises Forecast
description: Silicon Image, which makes semiconductors for high-speed communications, raised its second-quarter revenue forecast yesterday. The company also said its chairman and founder, David D. Lee, planned to step down as chief executive and would lead a search to find a successor. He will stay on as chairman. The company said it expected revenue for the second quarter ending on Wednesday to increase 16 percent to 20 percent from the first quarter, when it had sales of $35.9 million. Silicon Image, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had said it expected revenue to rise 8 percent to 13 percent from the first quarter. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAFFER, SHELDON P
description: SAFFER--Sheldon P, 78, of West Dennis, MA, died Monday at Cape Cod Community Hospital of a heart attack. Devoted husband of Lois Saffer (nee Zionts), beloved father of David of Hatfield, MA, Wendy Saffer Johnston of Farmington, CT, and Judith Auerbach of Monsey, NY, loving father-in-law to Tom, Lisa and Neil, adored grandfather of nine, and cherished brother of Lenore Tagerman. title: Separatist Revives Movement in Quebec
description: Until a few months ago, Gilles Duceppe was a shaky leader of the fading separatist movement in Quebec, seemingly destined to be an odd footnote in Canadian history.

description: Wherever they go, the Yankees attract crowds. In the Bronx or away, the Yankees' combination of habitual winning, star power and that famous scent of menace have created a nearly irresistible lure.

description: KAPLON--Sally, on June 22, 2004. Adored wife of Martin through 60 wonderful years. Beloved mother and friend to Karen and Jon. Cherished ''Madre'' to Greg, Analeigh and Alison. With her unique, irrepressible spirit, that rarest blend of charm, glamour and wisdom, all whom she touched will miss her deeply.

title: U.S. Seeks a Deal to Shield Americans From Iraq's Courts
description: The Bush administration is negotiating an agreement with Iraqi leaders to continue shielding Americans from criminal prosecution by Iraqi courts, but without the the new government's formal adoption of the arrangement, administration officials said Thursday.

title: Attacks in 5 Iraqi Cities Leave More Than 100 Dead
description: Fighting raged in five cities across Iraq on Thursday as insurgents unleashed a surge of apparently coordinated attacks that killed at least 105 people and wounded hundreds more.

description: FITERMAN -- Miles. The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum are deeply saddened by the death of Miles Fiterman, husband of our Board Member Shirley. Shirley and Miles are longtime supporters of our endeavors in Palm Beach and of our Modern Art Department. We offer heartfelt condolences to the Fiterman family. Ronnie F. Heyman President, AFIM James S. Snyder Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir. Israel Museum

title: 36 Hours | Fort Worth
description: ONCE the dusty, dowdy sidekick to Dallas, Fort Worth seems well on its way to becoming the liveliest two-step in Texas, an irresistible combination of cowboys and culture. In a two-decade overhaul, significantly helped by generous oil-rich natives, the little fort that was created to protect Dallas has grown up to become a center of innovative architecture, art, music, ballet and opera. Sundance Square, the revitalized, spirited downtown, is a model of urban planning. ''Where the West begins'' was Fort Worth's 1800's descriptive -- and still, with more big blue sky than skyscrapers and more sidewalks than freeways, the city proper (population over 500,000) is unabashedly hospitable to drop-ins. As for that Texas summer heat: no problem. Curled brim, high-vented cowboy hats are sold and worn everywhere, even inside with air-conditioning. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Stewart Should Be Denied New Trial, Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors had no idea that a government witness who testified about ink analysis in Martha Stewart's federal criminal trial earlier this year was lying on the stand, the United States attorney said in court papers filed yesterday.

title: New U.N. Envoy Approved
description: The Senate on Thursday unanimously approved the nomination of former Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican, to be the next American ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Report Clears Albany Bishop In Sexual Misconduct Inquiry
description: Outside investigators issued a report yesterday clearing the Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany, Howard J. Hubbard, of accusations of sexual misconduct. The investigation, requested by the bishop and led by a former federal prosecutor, identified a possible source of rumors about him: a gay priest who cruised bars and an Albany park in the 1970's, calling himself ''the bishop.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an agreement on New Jersey's budget for the 2005 fiscal year misstated the increase in spending over the budget adopted a year ago. It is $4 billion, not $3.3 billion. The headline also overstated the progress of the budget legislation. It was approved by committees, not the full Legislature.

title: U.S. and China Take Small Steps on Trade
description: After nearly a week of prickly discussions on trade, China and the United States agreed to meet twice a year with the aim of eventually granting China the status of a market economy.

title: Wolfowitz Offers Apology To Journalists Covering Iraq

title: Frosty Reception to Greet Bush in Ireland Ahead of Summit
description: ENNIS, Ireland, June 25 — President Bush arrived tonight at the heavily guarded Dromoland Castle, as Irish authorities braced for large demonstrations across Ireland against the American occupation of Iraq.

title: Bush Interviewed in Leak of C.I.A. Name
description: A team of federal prosecutors interviewed President Bush in the Oval Office for more than an hour on Thursday as part of their investigation into whether administration officials illegally disclosed to a journalist the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer, the White House said.

title: Media Ruling Merely Irritates Big Owners
description: Frustration was the dominant emotion among media company executives yesterday as they digested a federal appeals court ruling that largely reversed the Federal Communications Commission's efforts to loosen limits on media ownership.

title: Legislature Is Given Task Of Correcting Law's Flaw
description: In finding the state's death penalty law unconstitutional, New York's top court handed the task of correcting it back to the State Legislature -- the same body that failed this year to pass a budget and many important pieces of legislation, or to even address the same court's order to come up with a plan to fix New York City's schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWENTHAL, JESSE

title: Viacom to Buy German Rival to MTV

title: Women and Wal-Mart

A federal court has decided to permit a class action to go forward that covers about 1.6 million women who work, or have worked, for the company. The ruling does not discuss the merits of the case, but it should give new attention and leverage to women who say they have been discriminated against in pay and promotion.

title: A Loss for Open Government

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bus Transfer Delayed
description: A long-awaited transfer of seven private bus lines to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will not go into effect on July 1, as planned, but face a delay to Dec. 5, city officials said yesterday. The Bloomberg administration requested that the private bus companies, which serve Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, be allowed to continue temporarily while city officials renegotiate the terms of the transfer with the M.T.A. The initial agreement called for the M.T.A. to create a regional bus authority, but the State Assembly failed to authorize it. A Bloomberg official said yesterday that the transportation authority now planned to create a division to run just the seven bus lines, a move that would not require legislative approval. But the official added that the new agreement might not include as many protections for bus workers or existing services. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Banks Urged To Continue Some Lending
description: With data showing that bank lending dropped sharply in May after government warnings about overheating in the economy, the China Banking Regulatory Commission urged banks to continue lending to those sectors of the economy that have not been identified as growing excessively. Liu Mingkang, the commission's chairman, said in a statement posted on the government agency's Web site that a continued supply of credit was needed to many companies to prevent them from defaulting on previous loans. But Rodrigo Rato, above, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, suggested in a statement in Beijing, at the end of a visit there, that China still needed to beware of excessive growth. He warned that ''continued vigilance will be needed to ensure that further policy tightening is undertaken in a timely manner to facilitate a soft landing.'' Keith Bradsher (NYT)

Net income in the quarter that ended May 31 increased to $48.6 million, or 19 cents a share, from $15 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier, ATI said. Sales gained 38 percent, to $491.5 million, from $355.7 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had estimated ATI would earn 17 cents a share on sales of $465.7 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOVEN, LEO J.
description: KOVEN--Leo J. Beloved husband for 55 years of Joan Cummings Koven, devoted father of David and Diane, Richard and Melinda, and Suzanne and Carlo, and adored grandfather of Julia, Rachel, Sophie, Lily, Tony, Giancarlo, and Sam, and loving brother of Jean K. Miller. Dr. Koven passed away on June 24th, 2004; he was 86. A resident of Boca Raton, FL, who summered in Bridgewater, CT, Dr. Koven was a native of Brooklyn. He was graduated cum laude from Yale University in 1939 and from New York University Medical School in 1943. He served in the United States Army and was stationed in Europe as Battalion Surgeon and Regimental Surgeon for the 102nd Infantry Division, 2nd Cavalry Regiment between 1944 and 1946. He achieved the rank of Major and earned three Battle Stars and two Bronze Stars. Following his military service, Dr. Koven completed training in orthopedic surgery at the University of Iowa and then established a medical practice in Brooklyn, which he maintained from 1949 to 1989. He was on staff at the JewishHospital of Brooklyn until 1978, serving as Departmental Director and Chief of Residency Training and then as the Director of the Department of Surgery. From 1978 until 1988, Dr. Koven was Departmental Director and Chief of Residency Training at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He served with CARE-MEDICO training surgeons in South Vietnam in 1962 and in Afghanistan in 1965. He was an active member of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, American Jewish Congress, Federation of Jewish Charities, and the Board of Regents of Long Island College Hospital. He served as a delegate for Senator Eugene McCarthy at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Dr. Koven's interests included painting and sculpting, James Joyce, Arctic journals, American primitive art, Asian art and Judaica. He is remembered for his keen wit and intellect and for his love of the cultural bounty of New York, but above all for his devotion to his family. Funeral service will be held 11:15 AM on Sunday, June 27th, 2004 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in Dr. Koven's memory may be made to The Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, 9901 Donna Klein Blvd, Boca Raton, FL 33428 or The Greater Washington Coalition for Jewish Life, 124 New Milford Turnpike, New Preston, CT 06777.

title: Rowland Aides Say He Knew of State Contractor's Inside Track

Rowland knew that the winning contractor on a major project had an unfair advantage but voted three times anyway to authorize the project's financing, according to people who have seen a draft of the final report by the House panel that had been weighing whether to recommend impeachment.

title: This Terrorist Is Bad Enough on His Own
description: Despite the finding by the 9/11 commission staff that there is no evidence of a ''collaborative relationship'' between Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda, Bush administration officials continue to insist the two worked together. As evidence, they frequently cite Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the 37-year-old Jordanian who is arguably the most dangerous terrorist in the world today. Mr. Zarqawi, who fled his Afghan training grounds after the American invasion and found safe haven in Iraq, was most likely behind the string of bombings across Iraq on Thursday that killed more than 100; in May, he beheaded Nicholas Berg, an American communications engineer working in Iraq.

title: Contreras Eager to Pitch With Family on Hand
description: When Jos Contreras woke up at his home yesterday in Fort Lee, N.J., it was because his 3-year-old daughter had climbed into bed and roused him. He used to dream that one of his daughters was waking him, but for 20 draining months it was only a dream. The dream would end and he would cry.

title: 2 Koreas Sidestep U.S. to Forge Pragmatic Links
description: Wielding wrenches on a rainy morning, South Korean marines methodically dismantled a wall of 48 olive-green loudspeakers that only days earlier had been blaring news and pop music to sentries and rice farmers working on the North Korean bank of the Han River.

title: Chief Insists Credit Suisse Still Has Global Ambitions
description: The chairman of the Credit Suisse Group denied on Friday that the company had abandoned its ambitions as a global bank and said instead that Credit Suisse intended to grow by making its core banking business more competitive before it considered major foreign acquisitions.

title: Youth Who Like Films Rated R, But Not Chaperones, Get a Card
description: With school out for summer, Kirsten Larson and Sydni Norris of Bloomington, Ill., often head with their friends to the Parkway Cinemas. But they do not always pick the same movie to see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, TERRY
description: GORDON -- Terry. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, loving mother of Paul, dear grandmother of Edward, devoted sister of Helen Kopelson. Services 11:30 AM Sunday, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue (near East 10th St.)

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday about the use of eyedrops to reduce the risk of glaucoma in African-Americans misstated the treatment's effect. The drops lower the pressure of the clear fluid in the eyeball; they do not affect blood pressure.

title: Drug Maker Acknowledges Some Negative Test Results
description: Forest Laboratories has said a recently concluded test found that its antidepressant Lexapro did not help depressed children and adolescents, an announcement that comes amid the growing controversy over clinical drug tests.

title: The Price of Prisons
description: Thirteen million Americans have been convicted of felonies and spent time in prison -- more than the population of Greece. And they tend to return to prison again and again. Of the 650,000 inmates who will be released in 2004, two-thirds will be back behind bars within few years. The cost of keeping so many in jail -- the operating expenses for state prisons alone is around $30 billion a year -- has created bipartisan concern. Congress, which spent so many years obsessed with how to look tough on crime, is currently considering legislation that would tackle two of the big factors behind the revolving-door phenomenon: the huge number of mentally ill people in prison, and the difficulty ex-convicts have in carving out new lives in the law-abiding world.

description: To the Editor:

title: To Keep Martin, Hamstrung Nets May Have to Deal Kidd
description: The Nets never thought it could get any worse than last summer, when the entire franchise seemed on pins and needles as the free-agency period began, wondering whether Jason Kidd would leave the team on the heels of back-to-back trips to the N.B.A. finals.

title: KEYCORP ACQUIRING EVERTRUST FINANCIAL FOR $194 MILLION
description: KeyCorp agreed to purchase the EverTrust Financial Group for $194.7 million as it expands its holdings in the Puget Sound area in Washington. EverTrust shareholders will receive $25.60 a share in cash, a 28 percent premium to the closing price on Thursday, the companies said. KeyCorp has 73 branches in the Seattle-Cascades area, and with the deal will gain $770 million in assets and 12 bank branches in Snohomish and King counties. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter. KeyCorp is based in Cleveland, and EverTrust in Everett, Wash.

description: BASKETBALL

title: SYNGENTA AGREES TO BUY A 90% STAKE IN GOLDEN HARVEST
description: Syngenta, the major maker of crop chemicals, agreed to buy 90 percent of Golden Harvest of the United States for $180 million to expand its share of the North American corn and soybean seed markets. Golden Harvest, which has 4 percent of the United States market for corn and 3 percent for soybeans, had combined seed sales of $167 million in 2003, Syngenta said. The purchase will bring Syngenta's share of the United States corn market to 15 percent and the soybean market to 13 percent, the company said. Syngenta is based in Basel, Switzerland, and Golden Harvest, which is family owned, is based in Bloomington, Ill.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Senator Charles E. Schumer's decision to repay $20,000 in public funds spent on political and fund-raising trips, after questions were raised by a Republican rival, misstated the makeup of the New York Legislature, where the rival, Howard Mills, has served for six years. Democrats control only the Assembly; Republicans control the Senate.

title: Ex-Tyco Official Says Actions Were Proper
description: Mark A. Belnick, the former general counsel of Tyco International, told jurors at his criminal trial yesterday that he had ''no reason'' to doubt the company's chief financial officer when he said Mr. Belnick did not have to tell regulators about millions of dollars he borrowed from the company.

description: To the Editor:

description: I like to drink my language in,

title: It Was a Very Good School Year, Klein Says
description: On the last day of school for New York City's 1.1 million pupils, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that the school year, one of the most turbulent in the history of the system, had been a success.

title: About New York; Last in Flophouse, Alone With Bowery Ghosts
description: Being the last man living in one of the last flophouses on the Bowery has its benefits. No wait for a shower or a toilet. No sounds of casual sex coming from the other side of the wall. No need to keep an eye out anymore for Juliano, that big bully in stall No. 36.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, ROSE P.
description: MILLER--Rose P. In loving memory of our mother and grandmother who had a long caring life, widow of Harry Miller, died peacefully at her home at the age of 95. Mourned by her loving family who will miss her greatly. Funeral: Temple Israel, Scranton, PA., Sunday 11AM. Contributions to Temple Israel, Scranton, Pa. Joel Miller & Bette-Jane Raphael, Sheila and David Rothman, and grandchildren Matthew Rothman, Jethro Miller, Micol Rothman, Jake Miller, Rose Miller

description: THE Mets have to move.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture on Monday showing Abdurahman Khadr, a former detainee of the American military prison in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Clifford Krauss of The New York Times.

title: Grey Moves Toward Sale; Interpublic Loses Officer
description: Two big owners of advertising agencies faced unexpected changes yesterday, with the Grey Global Group taking the first step toward a possible sale and the Interpublic Group of Companies announcing a management shake-up.

title: Democrat Says He'll Address G.O.P. Meeting
description: Senator Zell Miller, a Georgia Democrat who has often been at odds with his party, plans to speak at the Republican National Convention this summer, Congressional aides said Friday.

title: Bush Gets Chilly Reception On Eve of Meeting in Ireland
description: President Bush arrived Friday night at the heavily guarded Dromoland Castle as the authorities braced for large demonstrations across Ireland against the war in Iraq.

title: Safer Without Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; The bishops' debate on Roman Catholic politicians who back abortion rights was more nuanced than a statement suggests.
description: Documents posted this week on the Web site of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops provide fresh light on the struggle of the bishops to address the question of politicians who publicly identify themselves as Roman Catholics but consistently disagree with church teaching concerning abortion.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Quick H.I.V. Test Is More Widely Available
description: A rapid saliva test for AIDS can now be used in doctors' offices and H.I.V. counseling centers, the Department of Health and Human Services said. The test, known as the OraQuick H.I.V.-1/2 test, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in March, but only for use in certified laboratories. The F.D.A. waiver granted this week means it can be used in an estimated 180,000 sites, said the test's maker, OraSure Technologies of Bethlehem, Pa. The test works with saliva or a drop of blood and, like a home pregnancy test, gives easy-to-read results in 20 minutes. An estimated 225,000 Americans are unaware that they are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and public health authorities believe that many have not been tested because they fear needles. Also, the department said, 8,000 infected people who come to public clinics to be tested each year do not return to get their results a week later. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: City To Close 100 Schools
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley will close 100 of the city's worst-performing schools within the next six years, replacing most with charter schools and with contract schools that use private money. Mr. Daley took over the city's public schools nine years ago, and although many have made great academic strides, others have remained troubled. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: For Liars and Loafers, Cellphones Offer an Alibi
description: Cellphones are chock-full of features like built-in cameras, personalized ring tones and text messaging. They also gave a real boost to Kenny Hall's effort to cheat on his girlfriend.

title: Tales of Night of Terror in Russian Region
description: As the shooting erupted here in the capital of the southern Russian region of Ingushetia on Monday night, Senior Lt. Abuyazid Kostoyev gathered four officers at the central police barracks, hurried them to a police car and sped toward the chaos they could hear outside.

title: Candidate, Under Pressure, Quits Senate Race in Illinois
description: Crippled by accusations about sex clubs and losing support from his own party, Jack Ryan, the Republican Senate candidate in Illinois, pulled out of the race on Friday, leaving Republicans searching for a new face to defend a critical Senate seat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Slips
description: Germany's economic recovery remains fragile, according a survey of its business climate. The Ifo Institute's monthly index fell to 94.6 in June from 96 in May, surprising analysts who had projected an increase. They attributed the decline to weakness in German domestic consumption, which offset growth in exports. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HIGHLAND HOSPITALITY CORP., McLean, Va., a real estate investment trust that focuses on owning hotels, said it agreed to buy four hotels in New Jersey, Georgia, New York and Massachusetts from Wyndham International Inc., Dallas, for $227 million. Wyndham International said it planned to use the proceeds from the sale to pay debt.

title: Cuban Families, Kept Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Mall Businesses Merge
description: Shareholders of Westfield Holdings, Australia's largest listed retail property developer, approved a plan to acquire Westfield Trust and Westfield America Trust, and create what will be the world's largest publicly traded manager of shopping malls. The combined company, to be called the Westfield Group, will have a market value of $27 billion. John Shaw (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Arrival to Close Streets And Divert Feet Near Garden
description: New York City announced ambitious security measures yesterday for the Republican National Convention, including shutting down Midtown thoroughfares for hours each day, putting a concrete barrier around Madison Square Garden, and letting protesters get only as close as one corner of the convention site.

title: Ruling on Death Penalty Clouds Existing Sentences
description: An appeals court decision on Thursday to overturn the death sentence of Stephen LaValle, who was convicted almost five years ago of raping and murdering a 32-year-old Suffolk County teacher, has thrown the state's three other death row cases into legal limbo. While legal experts say it is unlikely that any of the three death row inmates will now be executed, prosecutors, defense lawyers and victims' families said yesterday that they were still trying to figure out where their cases stood and what would happen next.

title: Wildly Optimistic Grand Slam Brings Success and Apology
description: Those who watch tennis are accustomed to seeing a player quietly apologize for a lucky fluke, like a shot that hits the top of the net and trickles over. The beneficiary may mutter ''Sorry,'' but he does not mean it.

title: BLACK CAN FILE SUIT CHALLENGING DAILY TELEGRAPH'S SALE
description: Conrad M. Black, the controlling shareholder of Hollinger International, can file a lawsuit challenging the $1.33 billion sale of the company's Daily Telegraph newspaper in London, a judge said yesterday. Delaware Chancery Court Judge Leo Strine Jr. said an injunction barring Lord Black from interfering with Hollinger International's plan to seek bids for the newspaper chain's assets did not prevent him from suing to argue that the chain could get more for The Telegraph. The British billionaires David and Frederick Barclay have offered to buy the paper.

title: A Tour of Beethoven Sonatas
description: Though most pianists tackle at least a good number of Beethoven's 32 sonatas, not many have all these diverse, challenging and extraordinary works in their active repertory at one time. To play the entire cycle takes resourceful technique, enormous musical intelligence and plenty of stamina as well as a willingness to immerse oneself whole in the music.

title: Boone Is Back in Game With Indians
description: Aaron Boone sheepishly said that the Cleveland Indians had asked him not to talk about the one-year contract that he agreed to until they officially announced it today. But Boone, the former Yankee, confirmed that he would be playing for the improved Indians in the next phase of his career.

title: 2 U.S. Marines Killed in Afghan Attack
description: Two United States marines were killed and one was wounded in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday evening when they were ambushed during an operation near the border with Pakistan, the American military in Kabul, the Afghan capital, said in a statement on Friday.

title: Undermining the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Iran: Road Crash Kills 90
description: At least 90 people were killed after a fuel truck crashed into six buses at a roadblock in southeastern Iran, the Iranian Student News Agency reported. The explosion was intensified when another fuel truck and two trailers were engulfed in the fire. The accident occurred Thursday night on the road from Bam to Zahedan. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: A New Deadline
description: After meeting in London with Northern Ireland's main political parties, Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland set a deadline of September for restarting the province's stalled local government, which was suspended in 2002 by British authorities for the fourth time in four years amid allegations of continued activity by the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Ahern said the groups involved must resolve issues like guerrilla disarmament and police reform through renewed negotiations this summer. Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, said the governments had accepted a time limit demanded by Unionist parties, which want stronger links between Ulster and Britain. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Consumer column in Science Times on Tuesday, about cosmetics that are advertised as alternatives to anti-aging treatments like Botox and collagen injections, gave an incorrect title for Jon D. Packer, chief executive of Centerchem, a supplier of ingredients for the cosmetics. He is not a doctor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FRANKEL, BRUCE
description: FRANKEL--Bruce. One year or one day--it makes no difference--you are not here and our hearts ache for you. Anita and Rem

title: Fo Shizzle, That Big Bad Chrysler Really Does Sizzle
description: When a global tastemaker like Snoop Dogg calls, the Motor City listens.

title: U.S. Attacks Falluja as Iraqis Renew Hint of Martial Law
description: United States marines attacked the insurgent stronghold of Falluja with airstrikes on Friday, and Iraq's new government again strongly hinted that it would declare martial law, but said nothing about its timing or scope.

title: SANOFI TO SELL CANCER DRUG TO PFIZER AFTER AVENTIS DEAL
description: The French drug maker Sanofi-Synthlabo agreed to sell to Pfizer the Campto drug made by Aventis once Sanofi has completed its acquisition of Aventis. The sale, for $620 million, is at the demand of competition authorities. Completion of the sale is contingent on Sanofi's successful takeover of Aventis and on approval by the Federal Trade Commission. Sales of Campto, a treatment for colorectal cancer, reached 264 million euros ($321 million) this year. Pfizer is based in New York. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: After Smarty Jones Is Retired, He Will Have a Kentucky Home
description: Smarty Jones, who narrowly lost a bid for the Triple Crown earlier this month, had part of his future mapped out for him yesterday. He will stand at stud at Three Chimneys Farm near Midway, Ky., at the end of his racing career, and it will be up to his owners and not the breeding farm to decide how long he will keep racing.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Lawsuit Claims Trick Settlements
description: A lawsuit filed Thursday said that a chemical company, BioLab, had tricked people affected by a fire into accepting tiny settlements. A May 25 fire at the company's warehouse in Conyers sent a huge plume of smoke tainted with chlorine into the sky east of Atlanta for hours, forcing the evacuation of thousands of people. The suit said people representing the company ''trolled gymnasiums'' and places where local residents had sought shelter and gave them amounts as small as $50 or $75 as ''free money'' that turned out to be settlements of all claims. A spokesman for BioLab said it was still reviewing the suit. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Death Penalty: Court Roster May Be Key To Its Future
description: Disappointed supporters of capital punishment lashed out on Thursday at a ruling from the state's highest court that effectively suspended the state's death penalty. The judges in the court's 4-to-3 majority, they said, showed that they were out to sabotage capital punishment and would never approve an execution.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about deaths among illegal immigrants who crossed from Mexico into Arizona included an erroneous report from the Border Patrol about the timing of an advertising campaign to discourage the crossings. The Border Patrol said it plans to run the ads soon; they have not begun appearing.

title: U.S. Cites Scant Progress in Nuclear Talks With North Korea
description: Describing nuclear talks here as ''some good, some bad and some ugly,'' a senior Bush administration official said Friday that the United States and North Korea had made little headway in resolving their standoff, but intended to keep trying.

title: German Expert Warns Balco Investigators
description: A prominent German anti-doping official has told federal authorities that Balco documents purportedly relating to the Olympic sprint champion Marion Jones indicate an attempt to conceal the use of performance-enhancing drugs through a screening technique used in the former East Germany.

title: MCI to Cut 2,000 More Jobs And Consider Curbs in Service
description: MCI said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 2,000 jobs at four call centers as it struggles to compete in the long-distance phone market.

title: F.D.A. DOES NOT APPROVE AKZO NOBEL UNIT'S ANTIDEPRESSANT
description: The pharmaceutical and chemicals company Akzo Nobel said yesterday that its Organon USA division failed to win approval from the Food and Drug Administration for its antidepressant Gepirone, also known as Variza. Akzo Nobel hoped to generate hundreds of millions of dollars a year selling Gepirone. The announcement was another blow to Akzo's struggling pharmaceutical division, which has lost sales since the release in the United States of generic competitors to its best-selling antidepressant Remeron. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Well, I expressed myself rather forcefully, felt better after I had done it.''

description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Strikers Fired
description: Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd., the platinum producer, said that it fired 1,700 workers who struck at the south section of its main mine and that it might lose production as a result. Rock drill operators went on strike Wednesday to protest working conditions.

title: Juvenile Center Is Star in State Scandal, and a Film
description: William B. Wickwire is a state prosecutor with years of experience in juvenile cases, and yet he had never seen the place where many young offenders are sent. ''That's why I came,'' Mr. Wickwire said at the opening of a documentary produced by teenagers about the state's main juvenile correctional center.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Government Budget Surplus
description: Brazil posted a primary budget surplus of 5.8 billion reais ($1.87 billion) in May, putting the country on track to meet fiscal targets of a $14 billion loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund. During the first five months 2004, Brazil recorded a primary surplus, which excludes interest payments on debt, of 38.3 billion reais, equivalent to 5.87 percent of its gross domestic product. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 17 about quantum teleportation, in which characteristics were transferred from one atom to another, misstated a result of a precursor experiment in 2001. Researchers at the University of Aarhus in Denmark achieved a step necessary for teleportation by entangling two clouds of atoms. They did not teleport a magnetic field between the clouds.

title: The Irish Love for Writers Goes Beyond a Pint and a Peat Fire
description: Mayor Gay Mitchell of Dublin was unhappy back in 1992 with his city's association with the poverty-stricken 1980's and the shadow of violence in Northern Ireland. So he turned to its most famous export -- after Guinness, perhaps -- and decided to set up a literature prize.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Economy Surges
description: New Zealand's economy grew 2.3 percent in the first quarter -- the fastest rate in four and a half years. The economy grew more than three times the revised 0.7 percent pace of the fourth quarter, Statistics New Zealand said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OTTLEY, MABEL J.F.
description: OTTLEY--Mabel J.F. Of Manhattan, beloved wife of the late Peter Ottley and devout Catholic, on June 24, 2004 at the age of ninety-eight. Born on December 24, 1905, Mabel worked in the millinery department at Bloomingdales, in Manhattan, until she was eighty years old. Visiting Sunday 2-5 at the Bernard F. Dowd Funeral Home, 165-20 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30AM at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs RC Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY.

description: LEVY--Travis Stanley, 91, of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, NY, on June 24. Beloved husband of Joan; loving father of Karen, Kenneth, Stuart & Jerald; special Dad to Ira, Karin and Charlie; dear brother of the late Harold & late Martin; cherished grandfather of Michael (Jenny), David (Pamela), Paul (Kimberly), Jessica, Sonja, Eric & Allison; adored greatgrandfather of Zachary, Maxwell, Jacob, Alexandra, Noah, Nicholas, Benjamin & Eli; special uncle of Susan (Paul), Amy & Steven, Richard (Gerrie) & Jeffrey (Patti). Graveside services Sunday, June 27, 11 a.m., Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: SS Officer Wins Appeal
description: The Federal Court of Justice has overturned a war-crimes conviction of a former SS officer, Friedrich Engel, 95, for ordering the execution of 59 Italian prisoners near Genoa in May 1944. Ruling on Mr. Engel's appeal, the court said that the case had been dealt with ''incomprehensibly late,'' and that given Mr. Engel's age and frailty, it was no longer possible to hold a new trial to clear up doubts about a 2002 verdict by a Hamburg court, which had found him guilty and sentenced him to seven years. He has been free pending his appeal. In 1999 Mr. Engel was convicted in absentia in Italy for killing 246 Italian prisoners in four incidents. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Father Who Threw Child From 7th Floor Gets 32 Years
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 25 - A father who tossed his daughter from the window of a seventh-floor apartment in June 2003 was sentenced to 32 years in prison on Friday, said Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney. The child survived with bruises, scratches and a broken rib after tree branches broke her descent.

title: Dithering As Others Die
description: The ongoing genocide in Darfur is finally, fortunately, making us uncomfortable. At this rate, with only 250,000 more deaths it will achieve the gravitas of the Laci Peterson case.

title: Hitler Reappears in '04 Campaign, This Time in Bush Ad
description: Suddenly, Adolf Hitler has become a bit player in the 2004 presidential campaign.

title: Sports Briefing
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL

title: Cheney Owns Up to Profanity Incident And Says He 'Felt Better Afterwards'
description: Vice President Dick Cheney, long portrayed by his aides as unperturbed by partisan attacks, admitted Friday that he ''probably'' cursed at a senior Democratic senator this week, said he did not regret it and added that he ''felt better afterwards.''

title: Education Secretary's Allies Depart Under Cloud in Houston
description: Three years after Rod Paige left his job as schools superintendent in Houston to become the federal secretary of education, his successor and several of his closest associates are stepping down, some amid questions about how business dealings have been conducted in the district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUDER, VIVIAN
description: GRUDER--Vivian. A woman before her time, who experienced the world as few did. Peacefully, after a long fulfilling life. Dedicated executive assistant to Harry Brandt, president of Brandt Theaters. Dear sister of Ruth, Herman and the late Beatrice, Leon and Annette. Loving and devoted aunt and great-aunt to many. She will be remembered by her family and many friends. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Miriam Hospital Foundation, Providence, RI. in memory of her niece, Francine Steiner Brem. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Experimental SARS Vaccines Work on Animals, Studies Say
description: American and European scientists independently reported Thursday that they had protected animals from the SARS virus by two different types of experimental immunizations, raising hopes that they could ultimately be used among humans.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Internet Equipment Venture
description: The Japanese electronics companies Hitachi and NEC said they would join forces to manufacture Internet routers and switches. Hitachi will own 60 percent of the joint venture and NEC will hold the remaining 40 percent. The new venture is set to start in October and would focus first on expanding sales in Japan. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, ROBERT
description: SCHWARTZ -- Robert. The President, Chairman of the Board, Executive Board, Board of Education, Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, parents and students of the Hebrew Academy of the Five Towns and Rockaway (HAFTR) deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed and dedicated Executive Director, Mr. Robert Schwartz. His sudden passing is an immeasurable loss to our yeshiva and a personal loss to all who worked closely with him. Devoted husband to Arlene, loving father to Deborah and Michael Ungar, Rabbi David and Miriam Schwartz, and Charna and Eric Schubert. Beloved grandfather to Jared and Arielle Ungar, Rena and Yonina Schwartz, and Jason Schubert. ''May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.'' Funeral services are Sunday morning, 9:30am at the Young Israel of West Hempstead. Mr. Alan Hirmes, President Mr. David Zahner, Chairman of the Board Dr. Aaron Gindea, Co-Chair, Board of Education Dr. Solomon Blisko, Co-Chair, Board of Education Rabbi David Leibtag, Educational Director

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 2 Palestinians Killed In Nablus
description: Israeli troops shot and killed two young Palestinian men as the soldiers searched for suspected militants in the center of Nablus for a second day, Palestinians said. Hundreds of soldiers entered Nablus on Thursday and have taken over more than a dozen buildings looking for militants and explosives laboratories, according to the military and Palestinian residents. Palestinian medical workers said that at least 18 Palestinians had been wounded by Israeli gunfire and rubber bullets. The Israelis are looking for seven suspects, most from Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, an offshoot of Yasir Arafat's faction, Fatah. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Using Congo And Belgians As a Metaphor For Iraq War
description: Several times during Ping Chong's and Michael Rohd's ''Blind Ness: The Irresistible Light of Encounter,'' a ball rolls across the stage unnoticed or at least not commented upon by the characters. At first it's of medium size and white; then it's larger and black. A Congo chief appears in his red tribal uniform and announces that each white twig he holds represents a human life snuffed out by the white men from Belgium. Soon he is standing under a deluge of twigs. The Force Publique, the feared Congolese colonial policemen, march onstage, rendered appropriately faceless by black stocking masks.

title: For teens, it's a tough transition
description: BERLIN  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Friday, July 2, 2004:

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend yesterday about ''Jewel in the Heart,'' at the Plum Blossoms Gallery in Manhattan, misspelled the surname of an artist whose photographs are in the show. She is Lois Conner, not Connor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LURIE, OLGA RUBINOW
description: LURIE--Olga Rubinow. On June 24, 2004, at the age of 97. A child psychologist and specialist in the emotional health of children. Beloved wife for 66 years of Walter A. Lurie; mother of Ruth Lurie Kozodoy and the late Michael Rubinow Lurie; grandmother of Sarah (and Vitali) Penso, Peter Kozodoy, and Elizabeth Kozodoy; great grandmother of Avraham Penso. She was the daughter of the late Dr. I. M. Rubinow, noted authority on and advocate for Social Security, and the late Sophie Himwich Rubinow. Service Sunday 1 PM at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck. Contributions may be made to the Guidance Center, 70 Grand Street, New Rochelle, New York 10801.

title: A Quiet Revolt Puts Costly Journals on Web
description: When Dr. Miguel Nicolelis, a neurobiologist at Duke University, decided to release a groundbreaking study in an upstart online journal, his colleagues were flabbergasted. The parks' operating budgets have nearly always been too skimpy, and in recent years a substantial backlog of deferred maintenance has built up. Every now and then, a politician offers to do something about it. In 1956, President Dwight Eisenhower began a successful 10-year campaign, called Mission 66, to spend a billion dollars upgrading services and facilities. And during the 2000 campaign, George Bush promised to do away with the maintenance backlog within five years.
