title: Good At His Job
description: ''I hate to paint portraits! . . . Youth can better stand the exactions of a personal kind that are inseparable from portraiture,'' John Singer Sargent (1856-1925) confided late in life to the artist Walter Tittle. The irony is that Sargent was the most celebrated portrait painter of his time, commanding the best clientele, prices and reviews. Between 1900 and 1907, Sargent averaged 17 monumental portraits a year, primarily of British aristocrats and arrivistes eager to promote their lineage or wealth; even after officially retiring from portraiture in 1907, he turned out some 20 more as he was continually prevailed upon by friends and prominent people, including Woodrow Wilson and John D. Rockefeller. JOHN SINGER SARGENT: The Later Portraits (Yale, $65), by Richard Ormond, an art historian, and Elaine Kilmurray, research director of the John Singer Sargent catalogue raisonn project, scrupulously plumbs the artist's last 25 years and interestingly does not attempt to cast him as a great modernist innovator but rather as a technically superb commercial artist who understood -- and ultimately tired of -- the demands of pleasing his patrons. If he was criticized by the avant-garde for being formulaic -- Sargent himself praised Whistler for never doing the same thing twice -- the authors exhibit that his best work brilliantly captures his sitters' physicality and temperament. In 1900, the critic Roger Fry wrote of Sargent: ''Such works must have an enduring interest to posterity simply as perfect records of the style and manners of a particular period.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

Born in England and raised in New Zealand, she was thrust into a troubled, troubling family, whose pursuits included the occult and sexual shenanigans of varying stripes; not only that, but everyone, including her father, mother, uncle and grandfather, churned out novels, stories, memoirs and film scripts. ''Her portrait of London in the 1950's and 60's is intricately evocative,'' Janet Burroway wrote here in 2003. In fact, on the same September evening when Ms. Hibbard was arrested outside a bar for punching and scratching a marine, her co-star Brad Fiorenza was ensnared for public intoxication in an unrelated incident and sent to the drunk tank.

Butts III, pastor of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church, was stunned recently when three couples who wanted him to preside at their weddings asked if he would alter the traditional marriage vows. Forget the till-death-do-us-part injunction, they suggested. Instead, would he mind substituting a more realistic escape clause, say, ''as long as our love shall last''?

title: The Last Nick Drake You Need
description: BLACK DICE -- This Brooklyn collective comes from rock but keeps trying to outpace anyone's assumptions about what rock bands do. Over a seven-year career, they've been both loud and aggressive and the opposite of same; they've used funk beats with real drums; they've done structure and noise. They've already made music you could probably call ''atmospheric,'' but on ''Creature Comforts'' (DFA Records), it seems to be turning into mist. These sound collages keep changing shape and texture, playing with your expectations; it's almost random. The record takes a long time to get anywhere. And then a minute into ''Night Flight,'' the last track, the weirdest thing happens: suddenly a genuine, shimmering pop groove appears.

title: Page Two: June 20-26; A CALL FOR CONDOMS
description: He didn't draw much attention to it, but President Bush surprised some listeners by endorsing condoms, which some of his religious supporters reject, in a speech about AIDS to a Philadelphia church. Mr. Bush said the country could learn from Uganda's success using the ''ABC'' approach, which stands for abstain, be faithful and use condoms. He was careful to say abstinence was the only sure-fire method, and that condoms should be used only ''when appropriate.'' Critics of his AIDS policies say that expressions like ''when appropriate'' can be used to limit distribution to, for example, prostitutes only. But the United States will supply 550 million condoms to the third world this year, more than any other foreign aid donor, and the number has more than doubled under the Bush administration.

Abortion is, admittedly, a moral issue -- but not one that can be settled by theology or by religious authority.

Too low? Too scratchy?) I admit that sneaking her into restaurants and manicure parlors in her tailored you'd-never-know-there's-a-dog-in-here quilted Sherpa bag is a little unorthodox -- but it's probably done by legions of dog owners. title: A Different Mexican Revolution
description: RECENTLY, American movie audiences have begun to discover Mexico. In 2001, Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu's ''Amores Perros'' jolted art house patrons with its vivid brutality and stylistic daring, and the following year Alfonso Cuarn's ''Y Tu Mam Tambin,'' flush with youthful eroticism and crazy formal energy, provided a fresh shock to the jaded cinephile's system. At once challenging and accessible -- full of wit, beauty and melodrama as well as novelty and provocation -- these were the kind of movies that seemed to open up a new world of possibility. Unprecedented as they may have appeared to North American viewers, they also seemed to gesture backward, toward a rich and thorny history. To watch them was to be seized by a giddy intuition: this is where movies are going. But that excitement was also accompanied by a curiosity based (speaking for myself, at least) on ignorance: movies like this don't just happen. Where did they come from?

title: A Nominee With No License

title: Honk if You Hate Car Alarms
description: Mayor Bloomberg's quest to improve the quality of life for New Yorkers has him reaching again for the mute button. Ice cream trucks that play jingles, dogs that bark too long, even loudly humming air-conditioners are targets of his latest proposed overhaul of the city's noise code. The public has been, in general, loud in its approval. That's why it seems odd that the mayor's hit list on racket-makers excludes what may be the most teeth-grindingly annoying of all: car alarms. The Bloomberg administration has been reluctant to put stringent limits on the alarms because they are seen as a deterrent to car theft. The number of cars stolen or broken into has indeed come down greatly in the last decade. But that's probably a result of the same improved police work that brought down crime in all other categories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OPPENS, EDITH
description: OPPENS--Edith, died June 24 at her home in New York City. A passionate musician and dedicated piano teacher, she was for many years on the faculty of the Mannes College of Music, as well as at the Aspen Music Festival and School. She also had numerous wonderful private students. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Kurt, and her sister, Ella Heller. Survivors include her daughter, Ursula; her cousins, Risa Hirsch Ehrlich, Judith Norell Strasfogel and Ian Strasfogel, and their children, Viviana and David Ehrlich and Daniella and Gabrielle Strasfogel. During her last six years she received loving care from Dorothy Braham and Selma Wright. title: The Golden Rule Is Taking A Beating
description: IT'S called ''gazumping'' in England, the process by which someone selling a piece of property accepts an offer from one buyer, maybe even going so far as to shake hands on it, then quickly -- and often surreptitiously -- accepts another, higher, offer from a second buyer, leaving the first buyer with his pockets agape and his heart broken. Gazump is a glorious, full-bodied word, with a lusty feel in the mouth; the behavior it outlines, however, is anything but satisfying.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IN the new Cole Porter biography, ''De-Lovely,'' which opens on Friday, Kevin Kline as Porter watches a screening of Michael Curtiz's NIGHT AND DAY (1946). As Cary Grant and Alexis Smith embrace in the final scene, Porter says, ''If I can survive this movie, I can survive anything.'' Grant plays Porter from his Yale days through his success as a sophisticated composer (''I Get a Kick Out of You,'' ''Let's Do It,'' ''Miss Otis Regrets,'' ''Begin the Beguine,'' ''In the Still of the Night'' and on and on) and ends shortly after the riding accident that paralyzed him. The film doesn't even hint at his affairs with men (big surprise). It's a silly Technicolor piece of fluff, but oh, the music! -- Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELAY, NELLIS
description: DeLAY--Nellis. The entire School for Strings family mourns the death on May 27, just short of her 85th birthday, of Nellis DeLay, a longtime member of the School's cello and chamber music faculties. Preceded in death by her husband Clifford Harvuot, for many years a principal singer with the Metropolitan Opera, and her sister Dorothy DeLay, the distinguished violin teacher, she is survived by her daughter Susan Harvuot and her son Clifford Harvuot, both of Rockland County, NY, and her sister Louise DeLay Carlson of Albuquerque, NM. Nellis was a graduate of the Oberlin Conservatory and The Juilliard Graduate School, where she studied with Felix Salmond. A beautiful player as well as an exceptional teacher, she served for many years as principal cellist of the New York City Ballet Orchestra. She was a very special person, and will be sorely missed by her many students, colleagues and friends. Louise Behrend, Founder-Director Michael Novogratz, Chairman of the Board Alexander Yudkovsky, Executive Director Sheila Keats, Associate Director Emerita

title: DEVELOPER ADMITS TO PAYING BRIBES
description: Joseph Barry a well-known developer of housing on the Hoboken and Jersey City waterfronts, pleaded guilty last Tuesday in federal court to charges of paying more than $100,000 in bribes to Robert C. Janiszewski, the former Hudson County executive, in exchange for his pushing through state and federal grants to aid Mr. Barry's housing developments. Mr. Barry, 64, former president of Applied Companies of Hoboken, was caught discussing the bribes on a recording device secretly worn by Mr. Janiszewski, who himself had been caught on tape accepting bribes from someone else. Mr. Barry pleaded guilty to four counts of bribing Mr. Janiszewski and agreed to pay $1 million in restitution to the funding agencies. Under his plea agreement, he faces up to 30 months in prison. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBBIE, SEYMOUR
description: ROBBIE--Seymour, a prolific television director from the earliest days of the medium, died June 17th at his Beverly Hills home after a long battle with ALS. He was 84. Robbie, who grew up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, entered the business as a pageboy for CBS in New York and was soon directing such early live shows as ''Studio One'' and ''Omnibus,'' where his ''Life of Samuel Johnson'' won a Sylvania Award. His other ''Omnibus'' shows included scripts by William Saroyan and Gore Vidal, in which he directed such stars as Geraldine Page and Helen Hayes. In a career that spanned both coasts over four decades, Robbie directed hundreds of TV drama and comedy episodes dating from Jackie Gleason's ''American Scene Magazine'' and including ''The Man from U.N.C.L.E.,'' ''F-Troop,'' ''Lost in Space,'' ''Mannix,'' ''It Takes A Thief,'' ''Barnaby Jones,'' ''Kojak,'' ''Hart to Hart,'' ''Murder She Wrote'' and ''Remington Steele.'' He also directed two feature films, ''CC & Company,'' starring Ann-Margret and Joe Namath, and ''Marco,'' starring Zero Mostel. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Shirley, and sons, Paul of Los Angeles and Thomas of Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEAMAN, WILLIAM
description: SEAMAN--William. William Bernard Seaman, M.D., a leader among radiologists in New York and nationwide in the 1960s and 70s, passed away in his home in Tequesta, Florida on June 7, 2004. Dr. Seaman, who was 87 years old at the time of his death, was born in Iron Mountain, MI, the son of Dorothy and Benjamin Seaman. Dr. Seaman graduated from the University of Michigan and received his M.D. from Harvard in 1941. He completed a residency in Radiology at Yale in 1947 and by 1955 had reached the rank of full professor in the Department of Radiology at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, MO. In 1956 Dr. Seaman accepted the position of Professor and Chairman of the Department of Radiology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University in New York City, where he served as chair and holder of the James Picker Professorship until 1982. He remained on the faculty at Columbia until his retirement in 1990. During his prominent career Dr. Seaman served as president of numerous organizations, including the Association of University Radiologists (195556), the NY Roentgen Society (1961-62), the Society of Chairmen of Academic Radiology Departments (1967-68), the American Roentgen Ray Society (1973-74), and the American College of Radiology (1980-81). Dr. Seaman also served as the Chairman of the Board of Chancellors of the American College of Radiology, which is the College's highest position, and on several advisory committees of the National Academy of Science. He published over 100 scientific articles, primarily in his field of gastrointestinal radiology, and presented 15 named lectureships. A worldrenowned lecturer, Dr. Seaman was inducted as an Honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Radiology in London, England, being one of only 10 Americans to hold that honor at the time. He received the W.B. Cannon medal of the Society of Gastrointestinal Radiologists and the gold medals of the Association of University Radiologists, the American Roentgen Ray Society and the American College of Radiology. Dr. Seaman is survived by his wife of 60 years, Veryl, three children & five grandchildren.

When the show, directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, opens on July 22 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater (previews started Tuesday), the boat will float down from the flies on chains; still, for verisimilitude, you could do worse than rehearse the scene in the basement at Lincoln Center, so deep underground it might pass for Hades.

The fish are more numerous than they have been in years, boating is booming, and towns that once turned their backs on the river teem with tourists.

title: Lawmakers Scurry From the Light
description: There's surely nothing new about indulging messianic conceits on Capitol Hill. But a dozen or more lawmakers allowed power fantasies to balloon a step too far when they honored invitations to the bizarre self-coronation of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon as Messiah at a Senate reception room last March. News has just leaked of the loony event -- one of scores of usually mundane photo-op toadyings that occupy Washington lawmakers. Now the attendees are fleeing the record of the crowning as if it were a burning building. ''I had no idea,'' said one in post-coronation remorse.

title: The Fidelity Fix
description: I was a World Health Organization epidemiologist assigned to support the Uganda AIDS program from 1987 to 1994, during the years Uganda reversed its AIDS epidemic, and I am relieved to report that Helen Epstein (June 13) got the story right. The message central to the Uganda success was not ''A.B.C.'' (''abstain, be faithful, use condoms'' -- an idea that came later), but ''zero grazing'' -- which meant stick to one partner. The other parts of the equation for success were the level of support for prevention and the way in which the government developed its program, which involved more than 25 government, community and clergy sectors. The Uganda success came by design.

title: Kerry's Campaign Has Soared From Poorhouse to Penthouse
description: John Kerry's presidential campaign was close to broke not long ago, but now he and his aides are traveling in style. They have begun chartering a 757, packed with first-class seats, good food, sleeping accommodations -- even a stand-up bar. They hardly shy away from top hotels, like the Four Seasons in Palm Beach and the St. Regis in Los Angeles.

title: A Postman Who Rings Twice and Sometimes Even More
description: IT was 1:30 in the afternoon as the lanky man in the dusty blue postal uniform removed the first rubber band from the bunches of mail that filled his three-wheeled United States Postal Service delivery cart to overflowing.

title: Six Sparklers For the 4th
description: PUTTING fizz into the Fourth of July is easy on the East End. Party givers can find the top local sparkling wines at old reliable producers like Lenz, Pugliese and Wlffer and, newly, at Martha Clara.

title: Always the Super, Never the Star
description: JOEL BRODY knows the secret to getting a good view at the Metropolitan Opera House. For the last 30 years, during his career as a supernumerary, or extra, for operas and ballets at the Met, he has marched as a soldier in ''War and Peace'' and transformed himself into a witch in ''Hansel and Gretel.'' But in ''Romeo and Juliet,'' in which he usually plays a butcher, his job afforded him the chance to see the performance of a lifetime up close. It was Natalia Makarova's balcony scene in the American Ballet Theater production of the full-evening dance.

title: Counting The Hats On Auditors
description: HAPPILY, there's a lot more information this year on how much companies are paying their auditors and for which services. While the data may seem dry, it is must reading for investors concerned about the independence of their companies' auditors.

title: A Landlord Locks the Windows
description: Q. I rent a one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn. My landlord recently came into my apartment -- in my absence but with my consent -- to fix my radiator. While she was there, she installed locks on every window. Now the only way to open them is with a key, which she has, and I don't. Is this legal? . . . Vanessa Juarez, Brooklyn.

title: Condo Owner Wants Storage Space
description: Q. I own a medical office in a condominium. The building has another doctor's office and about a dozen residential apartments. Every unit owner except me has a storage space. I asked for a space at the condo meeting but was voted down without comment. I also asked for monetary compensation for not having a space but did not receive it. How do I proceed to get a storage space like everyone else, or monetary compensation for not having one? . . . Peter Dworan, Brooklyn.

description: PLEASANTLY gentrified to some yet disappointingly sanitized to others who knew it when the hottest clubs along its cobblestone streets had names like Hellfire, the Manhole or the Anvil, New York's ever-heaving meatpacking district still has enough of that gritty je ne sais quoi to make it Manhattan's hottest 24/7 scene.

''I figured that finding a cat-sitter would be easy,'' said Nicole Davis, who took a half-share in a house in the Hamptons this summer to learn to surf.

title: In India, the Deity to Know

In a scene an American father could appreciate, a party planner wants to erect a tent in a hot new color: white. With that, the already exasperated father of the bride erupts, insisting on a nice, normal tent -- in, say, a traditional red.

title: The Netherworld of Nonproliferation

What should surprise us is how long we have ignored this problem and allowed it to fester. Whoever wins the next presidential election this November had better overhaul the C.I.A. and put the intel back into the agency's name, or we all might be swept off the nuclear precipice.

The news came as President Bush traveled to Turkey for a NATO meeting.

title: Photo-Op
Sure Hand in East Northport
description: THE Blue Room in East Northport is a surprise, a terrific restaurant in an unlikely location with food that delights jaded taste buds. One peek at the menu had us shouting ''wow'' and wanting to order everything. It's not often one has a choice between Dixie-style fried chicken with jalapeo cheese grits, sauted escarole and red-eye gravy, and lobster removed from the shell, placed atop a plum tart and surrounded by a savory vanilla sauce dotted with ramps. Both the familiar and the exotic were splendid dishes I'll long remember.

title: Debate Swirls Around the Status of a Protected Mouse
description: The Preble's meadow jumping mouse is a timorous nocturnal beast of the highland prairie, protected from human dominion in Colorado and Wyoming since 1998 by the Federal Endangered Species Act. Dr. Rob Roy Ramey II is a scientist at the Denver Museum of Nature and Science who will tell anyone who asks, including Congress, that he thinks the trouble with Preble's is that they are not threatened with extinction at all. Not even a proper subspecies, he adds.

title: The Nation: Fear Factor; In an Age of Terror, Safety Is Relative
description: ON the subway a few weeks after the Madrid bombings, I noticed a parcel under a seat. I asked other passengers, but no one claimed the object. I looked inside the parcel and saw some papers and an elaborately wrapped object the size of a grapefruit. The train pulled into Metro Center, the main station of the Washington subway. I contemplated that I might be about to pick up a bomb, but then I'd already been stupid enough to look inside, so I carried out the package, put it on a bench and told the station manager. Officers appeared quickly, though trains continued running and people kept milling past.

title: The Lure of Profits On the Waterfront
description: FOR the last 17 years, Charles Kron has made and repaired bagpipes from his 5,000-square-foot space in the industrial building at 145 Palisade Street in Dobbs Ferry. The structure, originally built for the Anchor Brewing Company in 1889, is perfect for the heavy equipment that manufacturers need.

Curious patrons kept turning their heads, unsure of the group but certain that something special was in their midst.

description: IN the swirl of mayhem and change that has made up the 15 months of war and military occupation here, it is an irresistible daily impulse to ask yourself whether this colossal American enterprise will fail or succeed.

title: Bush Meets With Leader of Turkey Ahead of NATO Summit
description: ISTANBUL, June 27  President Bush reassured Turkey today that it was once again a friend in good standing, despite its refusal to support American troops in the invasion of Iraq last year. Meanwhile, administration officials pressed other reluctant NATO allies to commit themselves to rebuilding Iraq's security forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRUMKIN, BENJAMIN
description: FRUMKIN -- Benjamin. 93, died June 24, 2004 after a nice, long life enriched by the love of his wife Sunny, his children Barbara, Neal, Yvette and their spouses, grandchildren Kera, Alena, Ann, Jesse, Lori, Matthew, Joanna and one great-granchild Sara, as well as many other relatives and friends. A wonderful, strong and gentle, caring man devoted to family and social issues, he showed his integrity, intelligence and humor throughout his life. A constant fighter for progressive ideas, he worked for a world of justice and peace without oppression or exploitation. His values live on in us.

description: AS dance careers go, Hans Kriefall's was somewhat atypical. Like most professional dancers, he spent his childhood obsessed with the profession. ''All I ever wanted to do was dance,'' Mr. Kriefall, 38, said.

title: Henman, Federer and Williams Advance at Wimbledon
description: LONDON, June 27  A different crowd filled up the comfortable seats and narrow pathways at Wimbledon today: a younger crowd, a louder crowd, a dressed-down crowd, with more backpacks and more piercings; and with more exposed midriffs than even the world's best women's tennis players are sporting on court these days.

title: THE FROGS
description: IN 405 B.C., Aristophanes imagined a highly impractical solution to that seemingly timeless problem: a lack of good plays to see. In ''The Frogs,'' Dionysos, the God of drama, is so unhappy with the state of the theater that he descends into the underworld with his slave Xanthias to bring Euripides, the king of dramatists, back from the dead. In 1974, more than 24 centuries worth of theater complaints later, Burt Shevelove wrote the book to the musical adaptation of ''The Frogs,'' with music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. In that version, pictured here -- and in the current adaptation by Mr. Lane, opening on July 22 at Lincoln Center Theater -- Dionysos heads to Hades to find George Bernard Shaw instead.

title: 'Shameless'
description: The boy serving behind the bar oozed confidence the way most of the predominantly twenty-something crowd oozed CK One or Escape for Men. He was cute in that silky, sulky, vaguely Latin way that promised a career modeling underwear for Calvin Klein, or at the very least a job behind a gay bar in Soho. He was also absurdly, enviably young-certainly no older than twenty. Martin felt attracted and resentful in roughly equal measures. What was it John always said about yesterday's trade becoming tomorrow's competition? Well, there was little danger of that happening in this case. Martin knew from years of experience that boys this young and this pretty rarely performed sexual favors for anyone who couldn't match them in the beauty stakes-pout for pout, muscle for muscle. And at thirty-two, Martin was in rather a different league.

title: At 92, Still Teaching Good 'D'
description: TRYING to describe Bea Thomas is a bit like trying to zero in on a moving target. ''Feisty'' is one word that often comes up when people mention her, but that doesn't quite do it. ''Disciplined'' is another, but that's only part of the picture. What most people do when they are trying to sum up Mrs. Thomas, a popular field hockey coach, is to resort to a story.

title: Something Old, Something Blue
description: FOR generations, White Plains, the center of county government, showed its softer, more romantic side as a destination for brides-to-be. The city had nearly a dozen bridal shops within walking distance of one another on Mamaroneck Avenue, Main Street and East Post Road. Brides and their mothers would ride the bus north from the Bronx or drive in from the outer suburbs and spend the day going from boutique to boutique, searching for the perfect dress.

After reading the letters (June 13), I have to ask what happened to the belief that we strive to become integrated: spiritually, intellectually, emotionally and physically. For the teenagers interviewed, the operative word was ''detachment.'' This coping mechanism is freedom gone amok -- freedom with license, not freedom with responsibility.

title: When 'The Love Boat' Meets Stoppard
description: IT is surprising that the Bay Street Theater had not in 12 seasons presented a play by Tom Stoppard. More surprising, now that it has, is that it should select ''Rough Crossing,'' a breezy 1984 comedy about a group of theatrical gadabouts assembling a play during a trans-Atlantic voyage to New York. That the production, directed by Daniel Gerroll, is buoyant has less to do with the craftsmanship of the vessel than with the cunning company that powers it.

title: The Sex and Scandal Capital
description: Imagine for a moment that you're a politician in Albany. Imagine introducing yourself at a dinner party back home or a gathering at your daughter's school. If you have any feelings -- and some legislators still do -- you recognize the look, the raised eyebrow, even the outright scorn. Worse, you realize that New York's State Legislature deserves it. It's not just the overall hapless do-nothing record the lawmakers racked up this year. This has been a season dominated by sex and scandal.

title: A MONUMENT'S MINDER

Hundreds of other people mill around the echoing rotunda, stopping to pay respects at the tombs of King Vittorio Emanuele II, King Umberto I, Queen Margherita di Savoia and Raphael, ''the prince of painters,'' but mostly staring up, way up, to marvel at the vastness of the dome and watch the disk of fading daylight visible through its wide-open oculus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAASS, HERBERT HALSEY JR.
description: MAASS--Herbert Halsey Jr. Passed away in Mission Viejo, CA on June 21, 2004 after a battle with Parkinson's disease. He was born on March 18, 1919 in NYC. After graduating from Brown University he served as an officer in the U.S. Army during World War II at Bletchley Park, England, where he assisted in breaking the German code. Afterwards, he received a law degree from Columbia Law School and practiced law at his father's firm. He married Jill Warburg in 1953 and moved to Beverly Hills, where they had six children, Jeffrey, Tracy, Brian, Peter, Garrett and Gregory. Herbert worked as a financial analyst, most recently for Morgan Stanley. After his divorce, he married Arlene Fournier Baker in 1966. Until a few years ago he was an avid tennis player and enjoyed long afternoons with friends and family at the Beverly Hills Tennis Club. He also served on the board of the Parkinson's Institute in Sunnyvale, California. He was a warm and charming man who brought good humor into everyone's life. He is survived by Arlene, his wife of 37 years, six children and five grandchildren. He requested that no memorial service be held. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Parkinson's Institute, 1170 Morse Avenue, Sunnyvale, CA 94089-1605.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOVEN, LEO J.
description: KOVEN--Leo J. Beloved husband for 55 years of Joan Cummings Koven, devoted father of David and Diane, Richard and Melinda, and Suzanne and Carlo, and adored grandfather of Julia, Rachel, Sophie, Lily, Tony, Giancarlo, and Sam, and loving brother of Jean K. Miller. Dr. Koven passed away on June 24th, 2004; he was 86. A resident of Boca Raton, FL, who summered in Bridgewater, CT, Dr. Koven was a native of Brooklyn. He was graduated cum laude from Yale University in 1939 and from New York University Medical School in 1943. He served in the United States Army and was stationed in Europe as Battalion Surgeon and Regimental Surgeon for the 102nd Infantry Division, 2nd Cavalry Regiment between 1944 and 1946. He achieved the rank of Major and earned three Battle Stars and two Bronze Stars. Following his military service, Dr. Koven completed training in orthopedic surgery at the University of Iowa and then established a medical practice in Brooklyn, which he maintained from 1949 to 1989. He was on staff at the JewishHospital of Brooklyn until 1978, serving as Departmental Director and Chief of Residency Training and then as the Director of the Department of Surgery. From 1978 until 1988, Dr. Koven was Departmental Director and Chief of Residency Training at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He served with CARE-MEDICO training surgeons in South Vietnam in 1962 and in Afghanistan in 1965. He was an active member of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, American Jewish Congress, Federation of Jewish Charities, and the Board of Regents of Long Island College Hospital. He served as a delegate for Senator Eugene McCarthy at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Dr. Koven's interests included painting and sculpting, James Joyce, Arctic journals, American primitive art, Asian art and Judaica. He is remembered for his keen wit and intellect and for his love of the cultural bounty of New York, but above all for his devotion to his family. Funeral service will be held 11:15 AM on Sunday, June 27th, 2004 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in Dr. Koven's memory may be made to The Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, 9901 Donna Klein Blvd, Boca Raton, FL 33428 or The Greater Washington Coalition for Jewish Life, 124 New Milford Turnpike, New Preston, CT 06777.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARMER, CAROL
description: FARMER--Carol. World renowned futurist, consumer trend analyst, captivating keynote speaker and strategic advisor to the Fortune 50 on issues of marketing and positioning. Carol died, unexpectedly, of a massive stroke on June 19, 2004, in Delray Beach, Florida, while visiting from her home, Brenguelven, in Landudec, France. Born in Columbus, Ohio on August 14, 1944 to John Edwin Farmer and the late Ruth Cooper Farmer, she is survived by her father and stepmother, Jeannine of Columbus. She graduated from DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana and spent her early business career with the strategic consulting firms, Management Horizons and The Doody Company in Columbus, and then as Executive Vice President, Marketing, for Lerner Stores and the retail divisions of American Can, both in New York. Her prominence and recognition grew in the mid - eighties when she opened her own firm, Carol Farmer Associates, first in New York City, then in Boca Raton, Florida and, in 1994 in France. Carol was actively involved in numerous management and retail-related organizations and served as a director of two NYSE listed companies ---The Sports Authority and Lowe's Corporation. She was respected for her unique angle of vision, one that translated complex social, economic, political and cultural issues into business solutions. In the early nineties, Carol launched trendtrax as an interactive video newsletter for senior management. Her latest body of work converged in the concept she termed, ''Second Wind,'' insights and analysis of how baby boomers are continuing to re-define the aging process. Carol was a voracious reader, a lifelong learner and an early adopter of the creative use of computer technology. She was loved deeply by a worldwide circle of friends who have come together this past week to express their grief and console one another via e-mail and telephone. Carol will be remembered for her infectious curiosity; her generosity to friends; her beloved Bedlington terriers; and her latest passions ---Brittany and combining her life-long skill in painting with photography, video and digitized imagery. Her remains will be cremated and her ashes scattered over the waters at Pte. du Brezelec in Brittany. Celebrations of the life of Carol Farmer will be held in both Columbus and New York City and will be announced at a later date. Contributions can be made in her memory to the Animal Rescue League, 3200 N. Military Trail, W. Palm Beach, Florida, 33409, 561-686-3663.

title: Mirage in The Desert
description: It has been a charged and burdened time -- the D-Day commemorations, the death of a president, the daily carnage in Iraq, the pictures from Abu Ghraib prison, a July 4 just over the horizon -- the sublime and the squalid, the decent and the desperate in American life so overlaid upon one another that it is hard to reconcile the high rhetoric of one moment with the terrible reality of the other. As Americans remembered the boys of Pointe du Hoc and the president who immortalized them, they had to read reports of government lawyers telling their superiors that ''the infliction of pain or suffering per se, whether it is physical or mental, is insufficient to amount to torture.'' The discordance between the high sentiments heard at President Reagan's funeral and the lawyers' attempts to justify the unjustifiable left you unable to determine whether the rhetoric of the funeral was a moment of spiritual reaffirmation or just an exercise in organized amnesia. The memoranda from White House counsel, and from Department of Justice and Department of Defense lawyers, gave new meaning to Robert Lowell's phrase ''savage servility.'' Their argument that ''the president's inherent constitutional authority to manage a military campaign'' rendered the United States' obligations under the Torture Convention ''inapplicable'' to interrogations conducted pursuant to his command left you wondering if they had ever heard of the Nuremberg tribunal. You might have thought that after Justice Robert Jackson's great opening speech at the war crimes trials of Nazi leaders in Nuremberg, no American lawyer would ever dare to use obedience to superior authority as justification for inhuman acts of abuse. In the memos that filled the pages of our newspapers, there was more than servility. There was also a terrible forgetting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKER, DOROTHY GOLDSTEIN
description: BECKER--Dorothy Goldstein. Died June 27, 2004, at age 85. Beloved wife of the late Sidney B. Becker for 57 years. Devoted mother of Daniel, William and David. Loving grandmother of Sarah and Samuel; Anne, James and Leslie; Michael, Ruth, Benjamin, Rachel and Jordan; and a newborn great - grand daughter. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College with a BA degree and received a Masters in Social Work and a Doctorate in Social Welfare from Columbia University. A tireless champion of the rights of the poor, she taught social work at the undergraduate and graduate levels at Barnard College, Hunter College, New York University and Bar-Ilan University. She served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College, and, in recognition of her dedication and support, was awarded by the college with the honorary degree of ''Keter Shem Tov'' (Crown of the Good Name), which is bestowed upon persons of academic and communal distinction. She was a dedicated Zionist throughout her life, and, in partnership with her husband Sidney, contributed with extraordinary generosity to organizations in Israel and the United States that promoted the long term survival of the Jewish people. A lover and supporter of arts and culture, in her later years she devoted herself to painting. She will be remembered as a woman of remarkable insight, insatiable intellectual curiosity, and unfailing wit and charm. Funeral services Tuesday, June 29 at 9:30 a.m. at ''The Riverside,'' West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Congregation Beth Israel, North Adams, MA. May her memory be for a blessing.

He married Elizabeth Anne Schilling in 1961, and started a family in River Edge, NJ. He lived in Upper Saddle River, NJ, for 14 years before moving to Chestnut Ridge, NY. An insurance broker, Jack was a cofounder of Dunlop, Onderdonk and Wilson, Inc, of Manhattan, a top fund raiser and a member of the WalkAmerica Executive Committee for the March of Dimes, an avid golfer, and a devoted family man. Survived by beloved wife Elizabeth and five children, John of Hoboken, NJ, Paul of Wyckoff, NJ, Amy of Boston, MA, Beth of Hoboken, NJ, and Chris of Boston, MA, and siblings Sue Bach of Chapel Hill, NC, and Fred of Amagansett, NY. Also survived by six loving grandchildren, three daughters-inlaw, Trang, Maria and Colleen, and son-in-law Kevin. Predeceased by his sister Beth Walker Shapleigh of Vero Beach, FL. Visiting Monday, 7-9 pm, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, NJ 07481. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 11 am, at St. Elizabeth's RC Church, 700 Wyckoff Ave, Wyckoff. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in Jack's name to the Jack Onderdonk Memorial Fund at Green Meadow Waldorf School, Chestnut Ridge, NY, or the March of Dimes of Greater New York.

description: With the Federal Reserve about to raise interest rates for the first time in four years, Joyce Diffenderfer is beginning to wonder how she and her husband, Curtis, will deflect the growing cost of their $16,000 in credit card debt.

title: Dubai keeps superlatives coming
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  The world's tallest building. The world's biggest shopping mall. One of the world's fastest-growing airlines. Dubai's ruling family loves superlatives, and the unrest in other Middle Eastern countries has barely slowed down the rate at which they acquire them.

title: White Sox Acquire Garcia
description: Before the Seattle Mariners traded Freddy Garcia to the Chicago White Sox yesterday, they called Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman to let him know they had a strong offer. A few hours later, the Mariners called again and said they were taking the White Sox' offer.

title: Saudis in Terror's Shadow
description: Ever since President Bush set his sights on war, many Americans have looked around the world and wondered if Iraq was really the worst problem out there. North Korea, and probably Iran, are the countries busily creating nuclear weapons in defiance of international law. Sudanese leaders worked closely with Osama bin Laden and slaughter their people as callously as Saddam Hussein did. Pakistan has provided nuclear weapons technology and fuel to rogue nations.

title: Fari Amini, 73; Used Science To Study Love
description: Fari Amini, a psychiatrist known for his work linking memory with bonds formed in childhood, died June 13 at Marin General Hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 73 and lived in nearby Ross.

title: Before Global Warming, There Was Global Soaking
description: THE PRESERVATIONIST

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Devil Rays Are Hoping Lightning Strikes Twice
description: In an era of ephemeral champions, where teams climb from worst to first only to tumble back to mediocrity, Daryl Rauch is bold enough to advertise her loyalties in permanent ink. She is also smart enough to footnote her tattoos with dates. Her red pirate flag honoring the Tampa Bay Buccaneers includes the Roman numerals from the team's 2003 Super Bowl victory. Her latest tattoo, in the black, blue and silver of the Tampa Bay Lightning, the new Stanley Cup champion, is so fresh her skin remains swollen.

title: IRAQ UPDATE
description: AMERICAN HOSTAGE -- Al Jazeera television broadcast a video in which Iraqi militants threatened to behead an American marine unless the United States released Iraqi prisoners. Another group said it would behead a Pakistani unless Pakistan ceased cooperation with American forces. Three Turks seized last week also face decapitation if their captors' demands are not met. [Page A1]

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about problems faced by teenage girls in Iraq gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a young woman whose family sent her to work in a hair salon because her father is unemployed. She is Beatrice Sirkis, not Sikris. ( Go to Article )

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on April 27 about changing scientific priorities at NASA referred incorrectly to President Bush's plan to pay for human exploration of the Moon and Mars. In January, the president proposed increasing the agency's five-year budget by $1 billion, about 1 percent, and shifting $11 billion to the Moon and Mars plan from other NASA programs during that period. Counting other increases already planned, NASA's 2009 budget would rise about 17 percent from the 2004 level. Mr. Bush did not propose a 20 percent increase solely for the exploration plan. (A reader pointed out the error in a letter dated May 17, which went astray at The Times; another letter, on June 4, required detailed research for this correction.)

title: Contreras's Big Victory: His Family
description: Jos Contreras finally had everything he always wanted yesterday, in baseball and in life. He had the chance to be reunited with his family, the chance to pitch for the Yankees and the chance for his wife and two daughters to watch as he threw dancing forkballs against the Mets at Yankee Stadium. Cotton candy was never a part of his dreams, but it was a sweet addition for his children.

title: College is Next Step For Girl Who Prevailed
description: When she was still commuting from a homeless shelter in Queens to her high school honors program in the Bronx, Tabitha F.'s yearning to soar sometimes made the burdens of poverty even harder to bear. Reading ''Great Expectations'' in her shelter bunk bed, with her mother and four younger siblings sleeping nearby, she said she identified with Pip, the poor boy in the Charles Dickens novel, ''when he runs away and starts to cry because he realizes his position in life.''

description: FOOTBALL

title: Queens Man Is Charged In Crash
description: A Queens man was arrested late Saturday after careering a Jeep through streets in South Jamaica, knocking down poles, slamming into cars and seriously injuring a 14-year-old girl on a sidewalk, the police said.

title: In Anger, Ordinary Iraqis Are Joining the Insurgency
description: At a teahouse in this palm-lined city, jobless men sit on wooden benches talking about killing American soldiers.

title: Respect for Heaven by Action on Earth
description: Ronald K. Brown made dancing both an affirmation of faith and a call to action in the productions his company, Ronald K. Brown/Evidence, offered Saturday night in Page Auditorium here as part of this summer's American Dance Festival on the campus of Duke University.

title: Waiting for Albany
description: It's become an annual ritual wherein the tail wags the dog. The mayor and City Council work furiously to wrap up work on New York's spending plan for the fiscal year beginning July 1 -- in this case, a $47 billion budget. Then they wait for decisions on critical aid from Albany, where everything is put off until state lawmakers get around to it. This year, though, that's not all bad.

title: No Spot Is Locked In For Gymnasts At U.S. Trials
description: With hair pulled tightly back into ponytails or buns and faces sprinkled with glitter, the country's top female gymnasts knew the truth: They were performing for only one person at the United States Olympic trials. They could feel that single set of dark eyes on them.

title: Palestinian Rockets From Gaza Kill Two Israelis
description: SDEROT, Israel, June 28  For the past three years, the people in this town on the edge of the Gaza Strip have lived with the persistent shock of Qassam rocket attacks, more than 200 of them, but they have withstood the assaults because the notoriously crude rockets have fallen harmlessly in fields, roads or backyards.

title: An Advance in Digital TV Is Coming. Why Isn't Anybody Excited?
description: Correction Appended

title: The Long Trail to Apology
description: All manner of unusual things can happen in Washington in an election year, but few seem so refreshing as a proposed official apology from the federal government to American Indians -- the first ever -- for the ''violence, maltreatment and neglect'' inflicted upon the tribes for centuries. A resolution of formal apology for ''a long history of official depradations and ill-conceived policies'' has been quietly cleared for a Senate vote, with proponents predicting passage. Tribal leaders have been offering mixed reactions of wariness (''words on paper'') and approval somewhat short of delight (''a good first step'').

title: Pro-European Democrat Wins Presidential Election in Serbia
description: A pro-European democrat won Serbia's presidential election on Sunday, allaying fears of a possible revival of nationalist extremism in the country.

title: The Troubling Case of the Phantom Readers
description: Like hundreds of other media organizations that still use paper as the principal means to deliver news in an increasingly electronic world, Newsday, The Chicago Sun-Times and the Spanish-language daily Hoy have been under pressure in recent years to maintain their readership and, ideally, increase it.

title: Has Greenspan Underestimated the Pace of Inflation?
description: The final chapter of Alan Greenspan's tenure as the chairman of the US Federal Reserve will begin on Wednesday with what will be a turning point in the Fed's recent history. Its policy- setting board is widely expected to raise interest rates by a quarter-point, the first rise since May 2000, kicking off a tightening cycle that is likely to fill the remainder of Mr Greenspan's term, which is expected to end in 2006.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about reception difficulties experienced by digital-television owners referred imprecisely to the availability of local stations' digital signals from cable and satellite services. While such channels are limited on satellite, many are indeed being carried on cable; as of March 31, cable companies offered digital signals from a total of 382 stations, according to the National Cable and Telecommunications Association.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ferrer Criticizes Rebate Plan
description: Fernando Ferrer, a likely Democratic mayoral candidate in 2005, suggested yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was buying voter support with his plan for a $400 property tax rebate for homeowners. In an interview on WNBC-TV, Mr. Ferrer, a former Bronx borough president, said it was not surprising that Mr. Bloomberg's approval rating had recently risen, considering his proposal ''to send most people, or 700,000 people who happen to be homeowners and co-op and condo owners, a $400 check in the mail.'' City Council Speaker Gifford Miller, another Democratic mayoral hopeful, supports the rebate. Asked about Mr. Ferrer's comments, Mr. Bloomberg told reporters yesterday, ''There's nothing political'' about the rebate. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Court Rules on Use of 'Midstream' Miranda Warning
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The Supreme Court today repudiated a police tactic sometimes used to skirt the principle of the 1966 Miranda ruling, the source of the now familiar "you have the right to remain silent" warning given to criminal suspects.

title: Reaffirming the Rule of Law
description: Part of the "new normal" that the Bush administration ushered in after Sept. 11 was a radically broader view of the government's power to detain people. The administration claimed the right to hold foreign terrorism suspects in an indefinite legal limbo in Guantanamo, and to designate American citizens as "enemy combatants" and hold them for years without access to lawyers. Yesterday, the Supreme Court delivered a stinging rebuke to these policies. In a pair of landmark decisions, the court made it clear that even during the war on terror, the government must adhere to the rule of law.

title: Oil Prices Hit Two-Month Low After Early Power Transfer in Iraq
description: Crude oil futures hit a two-month low in New York after the American-led occupation authority handed sovereignty to Iraq two days ahead of schedule, tempering concern that terrorists would disrupt the country's petroleum operations.

title: Nassau Leader Names Opponent For State Senate Deputy Leader
description: Joshua Ketover is a Long Island lawyer specializing in personal-injury work who has never held an elected office, but the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, named him on Monday as his choice to run against one of the state's most powerful politicians.

description: The United States and the Philippines will hold joint military exercises in the Philippines in a counterterrorism training program aimed at destroying the local cells of a Southeast Asian network with links to Al Qaeda, Filipino officials said Monday.

But militants lofted several salvos at a nearby Israeli town, including two that struck during a visit by Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon.

description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected Congress's latest effort to curb children's access to sexually explicit material on the Internet. But at the same time it gave the Bush administration a second chance to defend the law as a trial on its constitutionality goes forward in Federal District Court in Philadelphia.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Deal To End Rail Havoc
description: The government said it had reached a deal with hundreds of demonstrators who occupied railroad tracks south of Naples for three days in a protest against the planned reopening of a contentious garbage dump. The action brought rail travel to a halt in the area, and left up to 16,000 passengers stranded at the start of a main holiday season. The authorities said they reached a deal for the dump to reopen temporarily while an alternative was found. Some protesters said they would renew the protest if the authorities did not keep their part of the bargain. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Accused In Hit-Run
description: A man accused of a hit-and-run collision that left a 14-year-old girl seriously injured and three others hurt was charged with drunken driving and reckless assault, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday. The man, Richard Shropshire, 56, of Jamaica, could face up to 25 years in prison for the collision on Saturday. The police said Mr. Shropshire had told them that he had used heroin frequently and had been drinking vodka in the hours before he ran a 1996 Jeep Cherokee into several vehicles and hit Latoya Davis, 14, around 11:10 p.m. on 164th Street in South Jamaica. Ms. Davis suffered a broken hip and punctured lung, and remained in critical condition and on a ventilator at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens, according to the district attorney's office. John Holl (NYT)

title: United Again Denied U.S. Aid to Emerge From Chapter 11
description: The third attempt by United Airlines to get a package of government loan guarantees failed yesterday, and it will not get a fourth chance.

title: The Oldest Americans May Prove Even Older
description: On a hillside by the Savannah River, under tall oaks bearded with Spanish moss, an archaeologist and a graduate student crouched in the humid depths of a trench. They had reason to think they were in the presence of a breathtaking discovery.

title: VISTEON PRESIDENT IS PROMOTED TO CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Visteon Corporation, an auto parts maker, promoted its president, Michael F. Johnston, to chief executive yesterday, replacing Peter J. Pestillo, who has held the job since the Ford Motor Company spun off Visteon in 2000. Mr. Johnston, 57, who has been president since September 2000, will take over the new job Thursday. Mr. Pestillo, 66, will remain chairman until the shareholders meeting in May. Visteon, based in Dearborn, Mich., also said yesterday that it would offer $35,000 to encourage some factory workers to retire.

title: Corrections

Susan B. Anthony was not held in a prison cell; after her arrest for illegal voting in the 1872 presidential election she was placed under the custody of a United States marshal.

title: A Church Enriched by a Choir Of Crickets, Frogs and Birds
description: Kimberly Bartosik's look of an ethereal earthling, practical yet somehow of another world, captured much of the spirit of Merce Cunningham's art during her nine years with the company. Ms. Bartosik's new piece, ''I sat down on the bank the grass was damp a little then I found my shoes wet,'' presented on Friday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, is recognizably a product of those years and subsequent work in video and the study of art history.

title: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS CUTS QUARTERLY FORECAST
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc., a maker of birth control pills and urology products, cut its second-quarter sales and profit estimates and said it planned to lay off half of its sales force. Earnings will fall to 31 cents to 33 cents a share on revenue of $400 million, $10 million less than previously forecast, the company said. Excluding one-time items, the company expects a profit of 39 cents to 41 cents a share, down from its prior forecast of 50 cents to 52 cents a share. Net income was 47 cents in the year-earlier period. Watson, based in Corona, Calif., plans to eliminate 300 of its 600 sales jobs as it reorganizes to focus on urology, kidney disease and generic drugs. Contraceptive purchases fell short of forecasts because of increased competition. Watson will close a factory in Miami and end a contract sales-force agreement with Ventiv Health Inc., helping save $80 million to $90 million a year, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORELLE, CONRAD
description: FORELLE--Conrad. Of W. Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Westhampton Beach and Muttontown, NY, on June 27, 2004 at age 89 years. Husband of Blanche for 64 years, father of John, Anne, Jane and Frank; grandfather of Kevin McCarthy, Charles, Luke, Chas, Taylor Casey, Elizabeth and Grace. He was born in New York City and obtained his Bachelor and Master degrees in Civil Engineering from the City University of New York. After professional positions in Bermuda and New York, in 1950 he cofounded Schumacher & Forelle, Inc., an engineering and construction firm, from which he retired in 1979. Active in various charities of the Catholic Church on Long Island, he was invested in the Order of the Knights of the Holy Sepulcher over 40 years ago. A service will be held on Wednesday, June 30th at 12:00 noon at St. Joseph's Chapel at McKeen Towers/Lourdes Pavilion, 311 S. Flagler Drive, W. Palm Beach. A memorial service will be held in Westhampton Beach later this summer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Carmelite Sisters at McKeen Towers/Lourdes Pavilion, 311 S. Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33401. Quattlebaum Funeral Home, W. Palm Beach, FL 561 832-5171

With those words, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor confronted the claim of President Bush that the "war on terror" entitles him to act without any meaningful check by the courts. She and seven of her colleagues on the Supreme Court firmly rejected his presumption of omnipotence.

description: ISTANBUL, June 29 — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan begged hesitant NATO leaders today to rush troops to his country to protect officials trying to register voters for coming national elections.

title: Final Boarding Call for Your Flight to the Ends of the Earth
description: I'm a big outdoors person, and I love flying with my husband, Bill, to remote places like Patagonia. On a trip to the Brooks Range in Alaska with David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, and his wife, Dianne, we flew out of Fairbanks, heading for the Arctic Circle, and pulled into a landing strip that was just frozen tundra. We came to a full stop at, of all things, an outdoor basketball court adjoining a cluster of buildings. We all got a laugh. ''David is everywhere,'' I recall saying.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Voucher Law Unconstitutional

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORTON, JACK
description: MORTON--Jack, 94, of Vero Beach, Florida, died on June 28, 2004, at his home at John's Island after a long, full life. He was born June 6, 1910, in Newport, NC, and moved to Washington, DC, in 1931, where he lived before making Vero Beach his permanent home. Mr. Morton graduated from George Washington University in 1936 with a Bachelor's degree in psychology. In 1939, he founded what is now Jack Morton Worldwide, a leading experiential marketing and global brand communication agency. The blue Chevrolet Suburban was traveling west on Eastern Parkway about 6:30 p.m., when its driver, whose identity was not released by the police, tried to turn left onto Rochester Avenue and was hit by an oncoming car. The Suburban spun around and hit a lamppost, and three of the eight children inside were thrown from the vehicle, the police said. The 4-year-old, the son of the driver, was in critical condition at Kings County Hospital Center. An hour later, several blocks away, a Ford Expedition hit an 8-year-old girl who was crossing Eastern Parkway near Troy Avenue. She was in critical condition at the same hospital. The driver was charged with unlicensed operation of a vehicle, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

The transaction comes a year after Razorfish and more than 300 other companies that went public during the Internet boom agreed to a $1 billion settlement related to claims that their stock offerings were rigged. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IMPERATORE, GEORGE E.
description: IMPERATORE--George E., 82, of Boca Raton, Florida formerly of Franklin Lakes died on June 25, 2004 in Boca Raton. Family sources report that Mr. Imperatore's death resulted from a chronic heart condition. Mr. Imperatore was born in West New York, New Jersey, educated in the local schools, served in the Civilian Conservation Corps. and as a Seabee in the Navy during World War II. Upon his discharge from the service, Mr. Imperatore and four of his brothers founded in 1947 what became A-P-A Transport Corp., which was for many years one of the most successful transporation companies in the United States. Mr. Imperatore served A-P-A, based in North Bergen, New Jersey with terminals throughout the eastern United States and Canada, as Executive Vice President and Director of Sales until his retirement from A-PA in 1982. Among many transportation industry honors and distinctions that Mr. Imperatore earned was his Presidency for many years of the Traffic Club of Northern New Jersey. Upon his retirement from A-P-A, Mr. Imperatore and two of his sons founded in 1985 Imperatore Courier Systems, Inc., a courier service based in Little Ferry, New Jersey. Mr. Imperatore was also a significant investor in real estate projects in New Jersey and in Florida, to which he moved in the early 1990's. Mr. Imperatore was extremely committed to a large number of charitable and civic causes, including The Paige Whitney Babies Center in Basking Ridge, New Jersey, Deborah Hospital in New Jersey, The Boy Scouts of America and The American Cancer Society. Mr. Imperatore also served with distinction as Vice Chairman of The Palisades Interstate Commission in New Jersey and New York in the late 1980's, in which capacity Mr. Imperatore assisted in curbing development above The Palisades in New York and New Jersey. Mr. Imperatore is survived by his wife, Sandra, of Boca Raton; his sister, Anna Kortrey of Bogota, New Jersey and his brother, Arthur E. Imperatore, Sr. of Weehawken, New Jersey; five sons, George G. of River Vale, New Jersey; Mark H. of Franklin Lakes, New Jersey; Harold J. of Basking Ridge, New Jersey; John A. of Wyckoff, New Jersey; Luke E. of Riverside, Connecticut; and sixteen grandchildren. Mr. Imperatore may be viewed at Vander - Plaat - Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes, New Jersey on Wednesday, June 30, 2004 from 2:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. There will be a Mass of the Resurrection for Mr. Imperatore at Most Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church, 787 Franklin Lake Road, Franklin Lakes on Thursday, July 1, 2004 at 10:00 a.m. Mr. Imperatore's family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Paige Whitney Babies Center, One East Oak Street, Basking Ridge, New Jersey 07920. For further information www.vanderplaat.com

''We have evidence indicating that they were supplying arms to insurgents, conducting rocket attacks on the military, attacking nongovernmental aid organizations helping Afghanistan build a national infrastructure, funding ambushes and trafficking opium,'' the statement said. description: BECKER--Dorothy Goldstein. The Reconstructionist Rabbinical College expresses its heartfelt sorrow to her sons, Daniel, William and David, and to her grandchildren, Sarah and Samuel; Anne, James and Leslie; Michael, Ruth, Benjamin, Rachel and Jordan on the death of Dorothy, mother and grandmother. Beloved wife of the late Sidney B. Becker, she was a dedicated Zionist and a passionate supporter of Reconstructionist Judaism in North America and in Israel. She was an active member of the College's Board of Governors, and received the Keter Shem Tov award recognizing her embodiment of Judaism's finest values, unimpeachable integrity, intensive pursuit of intellectual endeavors, and boundless generosity. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Share Buyback
description: The telephone com-pany KPN said that it would buy back shares worth 1 billion euros ($1.21 billion) and refinance more than 3 billion euros of bonds. The buyback represents 6.7 percent of KPN's outstanding shares as of June 25, the company said. In total, KPN said it would pay about 2.1 billion euros to shareholders this year, including an earlier plan to buy stock for 500 million euros and not counting the interim 2004 dividend. The company, based in The Hague, also said it would refinance three bonds maturing in 2005 and 2006 as it worked to extend the maturity of its outstanding debt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi's Party Loses Milan
description: Battered by defeats in European Parliament elections earlier this month, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi suffered another major reversal, this time in regional elections that eroded his power base in Milan. The defeat opened further rifts in his center-right coalition and persuaded Mr. Berlusconi to return home early from the NATO summit meeting in Turkey. In voting over the weekend, the center-left opposition won 52 provinces, as against 11 for Mr. Berlusconi's supporters. The loss in Milan for his Forza Italia party was particularly significant since it is the headquarters of Mr. Berlusconi's huge business and media empire and is where he also owns the AC Milan soccer team. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZYSMAN, DAVID H.
description: ZYSMAN--David H. The entire Yeshiva University community and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary express profound sorrow over the passing of a devoted leader of Yeshiva University who also dedicated a lifetime of professional service to the building of the State of Israel. Known far and wide as a passionate and imaginative fundraiser, he served as Vice President for Development of the University for almost 12 years and was the grand architect of substantial and unparalleled growth in its fundraising. A Benefactor and honorary alumnus of YU, he established David H. Zysman Scholarship Funds on behalf of RIETS and all of the affiliated schools of the University and played a major role in the founding of YU's Sy Syms School of Business. The historic Main Building on the University's Wilf Campus was named David H. Zysman Hall in his honor in recognition of his extraordinary commitment to Yeshiva University and the world Jewish community. For 35 years he served as national director and New York director of Israel Bonds, which he helped found, and helped generate more than $10 billion in sales on behalf of Israel. Condolences are extended to his sister Rosita (and Philip) Shamis, and to his nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, and to his longtime friend, Zipora Koppel. May his entire family and many friends be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Services Tuesday, June 29th, 11:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees

description: A man was in serious condition last night after being shot by an off-duty police officer in a Newark Pathmark store. Witnesses told the Newark Police Department that the victim, Roland Dancy, 34, of Brooklyn, began knocking over displays inside the store about 5:30 p.m. The officer, Cornell Irving, 57, who was working as a security guard at the store, tried to calm Mr. Dancy, but he ''continued to behave in a threatening manner'' and walked toward the officer with an umbrella, the department said in a statement. Officer Irving then fired several shots, striking Mr. Dancy in the leg and torso. Mr. Dancy was in stable condition last night at a nearby hospital. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: THOMSON TO ACQUIRE INFORMATION HOLDINGS
description: The Thomson Corporation, owner of the Westlaw legal research service and the First Call financial data provider, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Information Holdings Inc. for about $585 million, a move that would let it expand the services it offers to scientific and health care customers. Thomson will pay $28 a share for Information Holdings, a 5.9 percent premium to Friday's closing price. Thomson, which distributes education, legal, financial and scientific information and services electronically, is relying on acquisitions to help it outpace last year's 2 percent sales gain. Thomson plans to double revenue at its scientific and health unit, its smallest business, to about $1.5 billion in five to seven years. Information Holdings, based in Stamford, Conn., had sales of $81.4 million and net income of $31.2 million last year. Most of the products that Information Holdings sells are subscription-based. Some of the businesses that Thomson will acquire include Liquent, which sells regulatory software for the life sciences and pharmaceutical markets, and Micropatent, which provides patent and trademark information.

title: MEMO PAD
description: AIRPORT CAPACITY STRAINS -- Mainly because of a return of robust business travel and the growth of low-fare carriers, 9 of the 35 top airports in the United States are operating above their passenger levels before Sept. 11, 2001, and 6 more will exceed pre-9/11 passenger levels by the end of the year, said Marion C. Blakey, the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration. Over a longer term, more runways and other facilities are needed, the United States Department of Transportation reported last week. The agency said the report is the first to evaluate in detail air travel patterns and economic and population projections against current service and capacity at domestic airports. According to the study, 15 airports will need to add capacity to accommodate growth over the next decade. The list includes Metropolitan Oakland International; Bob Hope in Burbank, Calif.; Long Beach; John Wayne-Orange County; Tucson International; Albuquerque International; San Antonio International; Houston Hobby; O'Hare International; LaGuardia; Kennedy International; Newark Liberty International; Philadelphia International; Palm Beach International and Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International.

McGreevey signed a bill yesterday that will increase income taxes on wealthy New Jersey residents by $800 million and provide bigger property tax rebates to elderly and middle-income homeowners. Democrats have called the increase the ''millionaire's tax'' even though it applies to annual salaries exceeding $500,000. A portion of the settlement, $1 million, will go to a former Banner employee, Debbie Evans, who filed a lawsuit under the whistleblower provisions of the United States False Claims Act.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry yesterday and an article in The Arts about the box-office performance of Michael Moore's film ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' referred imprecisely to the record it set over the weekend and to the one set earlier by his 2002 film ''Bowling for Columbine.'' The $21.8 million earned by ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' made it the highest-grossing feature-length documentary ever, surpassing ''Columbine.'' Neither film set a record for documentaries over all: ''Everest,'' a 44-minute large-screen film released in 1998, has earned more than $80 million in the United States and more than $125 million worldwide.

title: Reaffirming the Rule of Law
description: Part of the ''new normal'' that the Bush administration ushered in after Sept. 11 was a radically broader view of the government's power to detain people. The administration claimed the right to hold foreign terrorism suspects in an indefinite legal limbo in Guantnamo, and to designate American citizens as ''enemy combatants'' and hold them for years without access to lawyers. Yesterday, the Supreme Court delivered a stinging rebuke to these policies. In a pair of landmark decisions, the court made it clear that even during the war on terror, the government must adhere to the rule of law.

title: F.D.A. GRANTS PRIORITY STATUS TO MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS DRUG
description: Biogen Idec Inc., a biotechnology company, and its Irish partner, the Elan Corporation, said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration granted priority review status to their multiple sclerosis drug Antegren, cutting the period for regulatory consideration to about 6 months from 10 months. Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., is counting on Antegren to make up for slowing growth of older medicines. Elan of Dublin needs a successful product to help return to profit after selling more than $2 billion in assets to pay debt. Unlike multiple sclerosis medicines that must be injected up to three times a week, Antegren is being developed to be administered intravenously once a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIBNER, PAULA
description: RIBNER--Paula. At the age of 96, died peacefully of natural causes in Long Branch, NJ on June 25, 2004. A resident of Palm Beach, Florida, she was a nationally acclaimed bridge player, the fifth woman to achieve Life Master ranking and a member of the only allfemale team ever to win the coveted Reisenger Cup, one of the major national open events. She was respected not only for her brilliant card play but also for her lovely demeanor at the table. Over the years, she was as smart as she was beautiful. Her brains complimented her glamour, she had wisdom with graciousness,-and a woman widely admired by friends and family-a truly beautiful woman in every sense of the word. After a brief career in show business, she was always up for a good party. She also served as a Nurse's Aid during all of World War II. She had three happy marriages: first to Edward Bacher, a World War II Admiral, then to Maurice Levin, a prominent real estate developer, and finally to Lloyd Ribner, an amateur golf champion. A loving and tender mother, she is survived by her two sons, Donald Bacher and Fred Bacher from her first marriage, along with seven grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. In the end, on her final days she retained her most prized possession, an extraordinary mind.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Iran Project No Worry, Nuclear Chief Says
description: The director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Mohamed ElBaradei, said Russia's project to help Iran build a civilian nuclear reactor was not a cause for international concern, even though the agency was investigating allegations that Iran was furtively developing nuclear weapons. Meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin at his residence outside Moscow, Dr. ElBaradei effectively endorsed Russia's plans, adopted after American criticism, to insist that Iran return any spent nuclear fuel at the plant, being built in Bushehr. The Bush administration has repeatedly complained that Russian expertise and equipment could be diverted to any secret weapons program, which Iran denies having. Although Russia has insisted that the project will move forward, the final phase of the plant's construction has been delayed several times and is now not scheduled for completion until next year. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Singing Leatherneck
description: The debut album of Josh Gracin, left, a lance corporal in the Marine Corps who happily doesn't sing like Gomer Pyle, has entered the July 3 Billboard country chart at No. 2. Corporal Gracin, who is on active duty at Camp Pendleton in California and has signed with the Walt Disney Company's Lyric Street Records, sold more than 57,000 copies of his self-titled album in its first week, the most by a rookie male country singer since 1992. He first gained attention as a contestant on Fox-TV's ''American Idol 2.'' ''Josh is a real soldier, not someone playing a soldier in videos,'' Lyric Street's president, Randy Goodman, said in an interview. ''He has a folksy charm and charisma that, to his and our good fortune, was able to be conveyed over TV.'' It is rare, but not unprecedented, for a serviceman on active duty to have a country hit. In 1966 Army Staff Sgt. Barry Sadler's ''Ballad of the Green Berets'' reached No. 2 on the country charts and No. 1 on the pop charts. Corporal Gracin is to be honorably discharged in September, and said he planned to move to Nashville to pursue his music full time. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Court Backs Ban On Muslim Scarves
description: The European Court of Human Rights rejected an appeal by a Turkish student barred from attending an Istanbul university wearing a head scarf and said the ban was not discriminatory. The ruling was considered to have implications for other countries, among them France, which will ban head scarves and other religious symbols in public schools beginning in September, and Germany, where Muslim teachers have appealed measures barring them from covering their heads. In its decision, the Strasbourg-based court said that ''measures taken in universities to prevent certain fundamentalist religious movements from pressuring students who do not practice the religion in question, or those belonging to another religion, can be justified.'' The judges also said bans approved in the name of the separation of church and state could be considered ''necessary in a democratic society.'' Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Judges Order Death Row Remedies
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled that death row inmates at the Parchman penitentiary lived in such filth and heat as to constitute cruel and unusual punishment. The inmates said they were subjected to profound isolation, cells encrusted with fecal matter, urine and food, and malfunctioning toilets. The decision affirmed a lower court's orders that the state give death row inmates cleaning supplies, fix toilets, provide fans and cold water in summer, and house psychotic inmates separately. The state had argued that no inmates had contracted serious illnesses from conditions in prison. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: EL PASO MOVES TO STEM A DECLINE IN PRODUCTION
description: The El Paso Corporation, which this year slashed its assessment of oil and natural-gas reserves, said it planned to stem declining production and cut costs by increasing efficiency at its Gulf Coast drilling sites. Average daily production will rise to the equivalent of 825 million to 875 million cubic feet of natural gas this year and next, the company said. Output fell to the equivalent of 814 million cubic feet of gas a day in the current quarter through June 15. It was 956 million cubic feet in the first quarter. The company expects to spend $850 million this year and next on oil and gas production, executives said in a conference call with analysts and investors. More than 70 percent of this year's spending will be in the Gulf of Mexico, coastal sections of Louisiana and Texas, and in onshore fields in the Southern Plains and Rocky Mountain regions.

description: The Target Corporation, the nation's No.2 discount retailer after Wal-Mart, said yesterday that June sales would be well below expectations, setting off a 4 percent decline in its share price. Target, based in Minneapolis, released its forecast after the close of trading on Monday; yesterday, its stock fell $1.75, to $42.29 a share. Target said demand at stores open at least a year was weak for electronics, shoes and children's clothing. The company had forecast sales to increase 5 percent to 7 percent from a year earlier.
