title: F.D.A. TO SPEED REVIEW OF NOVARTIS CANCER DRUG
description: Novartis, the drug maker, said yesterday that federal regulators would speed their review of the company's request for approval of a new use of Femara, a drug used to treat breast cancer, to reduce the risk of a relapse after women complete therapy with tamoxifen. The Food and Drug Administration granted a priority review for the expanded Femara claim, requiring the agency to make a decision in six months of the April application date, Novartis said. The F.D.A. aims to complete its review of drug applications in 10 months. Approval would give women a way to extend prevention therapy after tamoxifen, which studies have shown loses effect after five years.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Black Deputies Sue County
description: Seven deputies of the Harris County Sheriff's Department and a former deputy, all of them black, sued the county, which includes Houston, contending they had been humiliated in an investigation of a sexual assault complaint. The plaintiffs say they were among 16 black deputies ordered to join a lineup in view of other officers and jail inmates in 1999 after a woman said she had been raped by a black man in a sheriff's uniform. No charges were filed. According to the suit, some of the deputies were not on duty at the time and others did not fit the description given by the woman. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Settles Suit In Massachusetts
description: Microsoft will give $34 million in software vouchers to settle an antitrust lawsuit by Massachusetts consumers who claim they were overcharged. Judge Judith Fabricant of Superior Court in Middlesex County gave preliminary approval to the settlement on Monday, the company said. Microsoft agreed to pay $104.6 million to Arizona consumers to settle a similar lawsuit and has paid $1.55 billion to settle suits in 10 other states. Under the settlement, Massachusetts consumers who bought Microsoft products from Jan. 3, 1996, to Dec. 31, 2002, will get vouchers. Massachusetts schools will get half the unclaimed vouchers. More than 100 consumer lawsuits were filed after a federal appeals court in 2001 ruled that Microsoft illegally protected its Windows operating system.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Siebel Accused Again Of Selective Disclosure
description: Siebel Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of customer-service software, was sued a second time by securities regulators who say two executives violated a rule barring selective disclosure of news to favored investors. The Securities and Exchange Commission says in its suit that Kenneth A. Goldman, Siebel's chief financial officer, and Mark D. Hanson, who heads investor relations, told institutional investors last year that the company was performing better than it had publicly stated. Siebel, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., as well as Mr. Goldman and Mr. Hanson, were named as defendants. It is the second time that Siebel has run afoul of the agency's Regulation Fair Disclosure, which forbids companies to release news selectively. In November 2002, Siebel paid a $250,000 penalty to the S.E.C. for violating the rule at an invitation-only conference sponsored by Goldman Sachs in 2001. The new case was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Siebel said in a statement that no violation of Regulation FD occurred, and that it was ''prepared to pursue resolution of this matter'' through litigation. The S.E.C. said in the complaint that on April 30, 2003, Goldman ''made positive comments about the company's business activity levels and transaction pipeline.'' It added, ''These statements materially contrasted with negative public statements made by the company.'' Siebel shares fell 42 cents, to $10.59.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: E.P.A. May Add Suburbs To Pollution List
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that it wanted to add New York City's suburbs to the list of areas it believes are not meeting federal small-particle air pollution standards. In February, the Pataki administration said the city's five boroughs were not meeting the standards. The agency wants to add Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Nassau and Suffolk Counties to the list. The state will have 120 days to comment on the proposal. Then it will have until 2008 to come up with a plan to bring the state into compliance by 2010. Michael Cooper (NYT)

description: If weekend weather is all that matters to you, then this has not been a perfect June. Perhaps no June can ever be perfect. But do you remember a year ago? Here in the Northeast it rained almost every day the whole month. If it wasn't raining, the sky looked as if it were thinking about it. Wedding planners were in a frenzy. Tent renters prospered. Vegetable gardens long in the planning were simply abandoned. People dropped their hoes and walked away. The only consolation was the state of the reservoirs. It was a good month to be a silver-lining kind of person. Plenty of clouds.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Growth Intact
description: The unemployment rate fell in May while consumer spending and factory production increased, indicating that Japan's two-year-old recovery remains on track. The unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since August 2000, declining to 4.6 percent in May, from 4.7 percent in April. Spending by households led by salaried workers rose 5.6 percent in May compared with a year earlier, a sign that a rebound in consumption that helped fuel strong growth in the first quarter is continuing. Meanwhile, industrial production for May rose 0.5 percent from a month earlier. Growth in production was slower than forecast though economists said they still think a long-term trend of increasing production remains intact. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Abu Ghraib, Stonewalled
description: While piously declaring its determination to unearth the truth about Abu Ghraib, the Bush administration has spent nearly two months obstructing investigations by the Army and members of Congress. It has dragged out the Army's inquiry, withheld crucial government documents from a Senate committee and stonewalled senators over dozens of Red Cross reports that document the horrible mistreatment of Iraqis at American military prisons. Even last week's document dump from the White House, which included those cynical legal road maps around treaties and laws against torturing prisoners, seemed part of this stonewalling campaign. Nothing in those hundreds of pages explained what orders had been issued to the military and C.I.A. jailers in Iraq, and by whom.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cisco To Buy Actona For $82 Million
description: Cisco Systems, the world's largest maker of computer-networking equipment, agreed yesterday to pay $82 million in cash for Actona Technologies Inc., to increase sales of software that links offices in different locales. Actona, a closely held company based in Los Gatos, Calif., makes software that helps companies send and receive files, as well as back up and store that information, Cisco said. The purchase will be completed by October. Shares of Cisco rose 41 cents, to $23.71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BABB, PHILLIP STILING
description: BABB--Phillip Stiling. Died on June 12th, 2004. He was 91, and passed away after a brief illness. He was the husband of the late Winifred Tate, and the father of three children. He is survived by two of his children: Sarah Babb Sexsmith and Christopher Tate Babb and five grandchildren. His youngest son, Perry S. Babb, succumbed to esophageal cancer in 1991. Phillip Babb graduated from Yale University in 1935, and received his MBA from Harvard in 1939. He was a director at McKinsey and Company for 21 years. In 1985 he was awarded the Yale Medal for his extensive work in support of the University's Yale Science and Engineering Association. He was also a skilled craftsman who made fine ship models, as well as numerous beautiful pieces of furniture in the Shaker style. He was buried in a private ceremony at the Meeting House Hill Cemetery in Brattleboro, VT, on June 17th.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Suffolk To Aid Hispanic Voters
description: The United States Department of Justice and the Suffolk County Board of Elections have resolved accusations that the county was preventing Spanish-speaking residents from voting by failing to provide adequate language aids. Under a consent decree filed yesterday in federal court, the county will translate voting materials into Spanish, fire poll workers who have mistreated Spanish-speaking or Hispanic voters and provide more training for poll officials. The Justice Department may also monitor elections to determine whether the county complies with the agreement. The federal government had accused the county of violating the Voting Rights Act by failing to translate voting information and ballots into Spanish. Patrick Healy (NYT)

He said he did not know the terms. In 1998, Dr. Michael Obasaju mistakenly implanted embryos from the black couple, Deborah Perry-Rogers and Robert Rogers of Teaneck, N.J., into the white woman, Donna Fasano. The Rogerses' case against the clinic is scheduled to go to trial in September. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: NATIONAL SENIOR CARE BUYS MARINER HEALTH CARE
description: Mariner Health Care Inc., a nursing home operator, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by National Senior Care Inc. for about $615 million. The offer of $39 a share is 49 percent more than Mariner Health's closing stock price on Monday. National Senior, an entity formed for the purpose of the merger, also agreed to assume $385 million in debt, Mariner Health said. The company, based in Atlanta, runs 263 assisted-living facilities and 11 long-term acute-care hospitals. Stock in Mariner Health rose $7.55, or 38 percent, to $27.65 a share.

The second is that Prime Minister Iyad Allawi is an Arab Shiite who both Sunnis and Shiites will follow.

The unit is based in Farmington, Mich. A Chrysler Financial spokeswoman said Columbus Bank and Trust, a unit of the Synovus Financial Corporation of Columbus, Ga., was the previous card issuer. description: After a trial that revived echoes of fear in a Brooklyn courthouse, a Bedford-Stuyvesant man was convicted yesterday of the 2002 murder of a man two days before the victim was expected to testify against a murder defendant.

description: PASADENA, Calif., June 30  The Cassini spacecraft approached Saturn tonight, on course to go where no robotic visitor from Earth has gone before: into an orbit of that faraway planet of serene beauty embellished by an exquisite array of encircling rings.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Bailout Might Grow
description: Mitsubishi Motors is hoping to raise more money for an emergency bailout as it struggles to stem the damage from a widening recall and falling sales. The carmaker said that J.P. Morgan Securities might underwrite the purchase of Mitsubishi Motors shares worth as much as 150 billion yen, up from its initial plan to contribute 100 billion yen ($923 million). Other investors may increase their stakes, raising the package to as much as 546 billion yen, compared with a goal of about 450 billion yen under the initial plan announced last month. The carmaker was forced to seek a bailout from Mitsubishi companies and other investors after its largest shareholder, DaimlerChrysler, decided in April to stop supporting the company. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Giving Corporations the Psychoanalytic Treatment
description: Since a corporation is legally defined as a person, it makes some sense to ask what kind of person a corporation might be. The answer offered by ''The Corporation,'' a smart, brooding documentary directed by Mark Achbar and Jennifer Abbott, is: not a very nice one.

title: White House Says It's Addressing Court Concerns on Captives
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Refusing to concede that Monday's Supreme Court rulings were a defeat, the White House said today that it is moving quickly and aggressively to address the justices' concerns over the treatment of detainees seized since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES AGAIN INCREASES BID FOR WHEATON
description: Coeur d'Alene Mines of Idaho has raised its bid for Wheaton River Minerals, the gold and copper producer based in Vancouver, British Columbia, to 2.6 billion Canadian dollars ($1.9 billion) in cash and stock, from 2.4 billion Canadian dollars. Coeur d'Alene, the world's largest silver producer, is seeking to thwart a proposed share exchange between Wheaton and Iamgold of Toronto, on which Wheaton shareholders are scheduled to vote on July 6. Iamgold is the target of a separate hostile bid by Golden Star Resources of Denver. Golden Star raised its offer earlier this week. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: In F.B.I., Innocent Detainee Found Unlikely Ally
description: It took no more than a week for James P. Wynne, a veteran F.B.I. investigator, to confirm the harmless truth that only now, more than two years later, he is ready to talk about. The small foreign man he helped arrest for videotaping outside an office building in Queens on Oct. 25, 2001, was no terrorist.

title: A Highly Designed Design Complex Gets a New Life
description: From the moment it opened in 1975, Cesar Pelli's massive and daring Pacific Design Center, with its almost startlingly blue glass exterior, became an instant icon, looming over the surrounding small houses and shops and helping to give this neighborhood, which was incorporated as a city in 1984, a distinct identity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect In 6 Burglaries Arrested
description: A man suspected in at least six burglaries in Manhattan has been arrested, law enforcement officials said. The suspect, identified by the police as Stephen Jacks, 49, of Queens, was driving a black Mercedes across the Queensboro Bridge at 10:30 p.m. Monday when an off-duty New York City police sergeant, Kevin Harford, recognized the car from a previous burglary case, the police said. Charges are pending against Mr. Jacks, whom the police suspect of stealing more than $20,000 in jewelry from an East End Avenue apartment on Friday. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tax Bill For Honda
description: The tax authorities have ordered Honda Motor to pay 13 billion yen ($120 million) in additional taxes on profit from its motorcycle business in Brazil. Tax authorities say Honda did not allocate enough of the profit from its Brazilian subsidiary, Moto Honda da Amazonia, to its headquarters business in Japan for the six years to 2002. Honda said it would pay the tax but would appeal the ruling. Honda's Brazilian unit made about 820,000 motorcycles last year and 90 percent of them were sold in Brazil. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: London: Next City of the Sky?; Architects Are Pushing to Remake the Capital's Profile
description: ''Earth has not anything to show more fair,'' Wordsworth wrote of London two centuries ago. But the ''ships, towers, domes, theaters and temples'' that he admired from Westminster Bridge have long since given way to a more tawdry view, shaped as much by postwar bad taste as by wartime bombing. Now, with a panache rarely seen here, London has concluded that it is time to repair its battered skyline.

title: British Team Withdraws From Henley
description: The opening heats of the 155th Henley Royal Regatta, which dates to 1839, begin today in Henley-on-Thames, England, but one team is already out of the Grand Challenge Cup, the regatta's premier eight-oared event. The British national team's Olympic eight, which was to be making its only racing appearance in Britain before the Olympics, withdrew Saturday after losing to the Harvard heavyweight varsity in Switzerland. Norman Hildes-Heim

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Citigroup Venture
description: Citigroup said it would incorporate its Singapore consumer banking business, the latest push to increase lending to individuals in Asia. Citibank N.A., the consumer banking unit of the company, said the new lender, Citibank Singapore, would have paid-up capital of 1.5 billion Singapore dollars ($874 million). The move will enable Citigroup to negotiate with banks to gain access to their automated teller machines.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Court Rejects Marriage Suit
description: A federal appeals court has denied a conservative group's effort to suspend gay marriages, which became legal in the state on May 17. The State Supreme Judicial Court ruled in November that same-sex couples had the right to marry under the State Constitution. The Legislature approved a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage in March. It must pass again next year and could be on the ballot as early as November 2006. The suit, which was dismissed by a federal judge last month, contends that only the governor and Legislature have the ability to change marriage law. The appeals court ruled that the high court's ruling ''does not plausibly'' threaten a republican form of government. The Liberty Counsel, which filed the suit on behalf of the former president of the Massachusetts Catholic League and 11 legislators, said it would appeal to the United States Supreme Court. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Pay $400,000 In Billing Settlement
description: AT&T will pay $400,000 in fines and issue refunds to as many as 311,000 New Yorkers to settle claims that the company billed customers who did not order service. AT&T was fined for charging a $7.72 monthly long-distance fee to clients who had not signed up, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, said yesterday on his Web site. An AT&T spokesman, Bob Nersesian, called the problem a billing error and said the company would not switch people without authorization. The settlement caps a six-month investigation that began after hundreds of complaints from consumers, Mr. Spitzer said. The error affected 200,000 to 300,000 AT&T customers nationwide and 800,000 nonclients, the company said. The company is processing refunds, and consumers do not need to do anything, Mr. Nersesian said. He declined to say how much AT&T will refund. On Jan. 1, AT&T started a $3.95 monthly charge for its basic state-to-state long-distance plan, Mr. Nersesian said. The new charge resulted in ''a billing error caused by a combination of system issues,'' he said in a statement. He declined to elaborate.

title: Military Plans to Call Up Soldiers Who Left Service
description: Amid Congressional concerns that the military is stretched too thin, the Army is preparing to take advantage of a rarely used wartime program that allows it to recall soldiers who have left the service and did not join the reserves. Pentagon officials said Tuesday that 5,600 former soldiers were going to be called up for yearlong tours, mostly assignments in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHMAN, SHELLY J.
description: ROTHMAN--Shelly J. We are saddened to report the death of our member, Shelly J. Rothman, President of Project Hope Emeritus. He was a person who always had a smile on his face, and a word of encouragement for those around him. His can-do attitude about anything attempted by our Labor and Business Lodge became contagious in his company. He was always available to us, and showed a willingness to bring help in any way he could. Day in and day out, he showed the kind of motivation and leadership all of us at B'nai B'rith so much admired. But even more than the leadership position, we have always valued his close and friendly association with our membership. There is for most people, that one special individual who becomes a mentor, offering guidance, introductions, inspirations, encouragement, solace over difficult times, and most importantly, an example of success. For us, Shelly was that person. Louis L. Levine, President Martin Adelstein, First Vice President Louis Weiser, Vice President Sidney Lew, Secretary-Treasurer Warren Lew, President Project Hope Steven Levine, B'Nai B'rith International Henry Segal, Administrator Harold Wolchok, Director

title: From a Caterer's Front Office, Cupcakes To Salute
description: Spoon, 17 West 20th Street, is the pocket-size outlet for Melissa Chmelar's company, Spoon Catering, which can be glimpsed in back, churning out bright, homey food for private parties. Like Ms. Chmelar's cooking and baking -- her cupcakes in bunting colors ($2) are available tomorrow and Friday -- the shop has a country look, with canning jars lining the whitewashed walls. Spoon opens at 7:30 a.m. with crumbly little scones ($1) and a chubby baby quiche ($3.50). By noon there are soups ($3 to $4.50), including Tuscan bean and carrot ginger; well-composed sandwiches ($6.50 to $7); and salads ($5 to $7). Ms. Chmelar (at left in photo, with her head chef, Sara DeMars Cerasoli) does not replenish: what's sold is sold, and the doors close at 5:30 p.m. and stay closed on weekends.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on June 24 about the dismissal of deceit accusations against Forstmann Little & Company in a suit involving investments for Connecticut's state pension fund referred incorrectly to trial testimony by Harold W. Furchtgott-Roth, the company's economic expert. He said that the investments, in XO Communications and McLeod USA, were not in conflict with his company's offering memo -- not that they were. Mr. Furchtgott-Roth testified that XO and McLeod did not hold a dominant worldwide position in their market segment; he did not say that such a position was by itself a criterion for Forstmann Little investments.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Lower Price For Philips LCD
description: The LG.Philips LCD Company, a maker of liquid-crystal displays, cut the price range for its initial offering by as much as a fifth amid concern over demand for flat screens. Philips LCD, a venture of LG Electronics and Royal Philips Electronics plans to sell stock at the equivalent of $30 to $36 a share, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. By comparison, a June 25 filing in South Korea gave a range of 37,100 won ($32) to 52,600 won ($46). The company plans to sell 13.5 percent and has scheduled to price the shares on July 15, the Korean filing said.

title: SHARES FALL AFTER JACOBS ENGINEERING CUTS FORECASTS
description: The Jacobs Engineering Group said profit for the third quarter and the year would be lower than expected, setting off a 14 percent decline in its share price. Jacobs said after the close of trading on Monday that a major, unidentified customer cut capital spending, which resulted in a canceled project and suspended work. The company, based in Pasadena, Calif., also cited delays in government contracts, especially in its buildings and facilities business. Jacobs Engineering expects net income to fall to 50 cents to 54 cents a share in the quarter ending June 30 from 58 cents a year earlier. For the full year, the company expects to earn $2.20 to $2.30 a share, less than its previous forecast of $2.44 to $2.50 a share. It earned $2.27 a share in 2003. Stock in Jacobs Engineering fell $6.43, to $40 a share.

Reich, 55, of Jamaica, Queens, was also arraigned in federal court on charges of obstruction of justice and making false statements to F.B.I. agents. Mr. Reich, who ran as a Conservative Party candidate for Congress in 2002, is accused of forging a judge's signature in a civil case in which he was a defendant. He faces up to 20 years in jail. Attempts to reach his attorney, Stephen Mahler, were unsuccessful. John Holl (NYT)
